description:
Ebisu used to be one of my go-to sushi spots when living in the Sunset, and previously would've easily given it five stars. My latest visit for lunch was still great, but not as stellar as previous times. 

We usually would get one roll then some nigiri, but this visit we were more looking for rolls. We got:
- Gyoza appetizer
- #29 roll (Deep fried Salmon, Yellowtail, Shrimp, & Scallion wrapped with Fresh Tuna)
- Family Affair roll (Unagi, Crab, Avocado, Tenpura, Shrimp and Cucumber)

We really loved the family affair roll, but weren't impressed by #29. The salmon inside the roll was very dry. And unfortunately, my boyfriend got a huge bone in one of his bites. The gyoza was fine, but not super flavorful. 

This was more of a 3-star experience, but giving 4 stars as every other time I've been it's been much better.
author: Jessie K.

description:
Great local sushi spot! The fish was really fresh and the atmosphere was super. We got the gyoza and miso soup to start but they ended up coming out at the same time as the sushi. The yellowtail nigiri was delicious and really crisp, definitely a highlight of the meal. We got the Behind the Green Door roll which was also tasty.  Ordered Kobe beef kushiyaki and it was amazing. 

The service was also very fast, which is always a plus in my book. I'm looking forward to eating here often!
author: Kevin P.

description:
San Francisco has so much to offer, but parking can always be a pain. You either park close and pay, or risk having your window broken. Ebisu is close to the park, which has lots of parking, but it's at your own risk. The bums can be sketchy.

Friends from Vegas were in town. They wanted seafood, but nothing raw. So the safest bet was sushi. Ebisu got great reviews, so we decided to meet here.

Dinner scheduled at 6:30. Our friends put their name down for a table around 6, and the wait time was about 30 minutes for a table of 4. The seating is very cramped inside. I'd suggest sitting at the bar if you're alone or just a party of two.

I personally love raw fish and was eyeing the omakase, but nobody wanted any and I didn't think I could finish it all myself. My boyfriend and I ended up getting an order of mixed tempura and 2 rolls. 

The tempura had a good mix of veggies and shrimp, but the batter was too thick. That plus not frying long enough resulted in uncrispy tempura. 

The two rolls we got were the dragon and Tokyo tower. The Tokyo tower was disappointing because it only came with four pieces. I'd have to say that they do put more shrimp tempura than most places, but I couldn't get past the size of the roll. The dragon roll looked really nice, but taste wise, it's what you would expect from a dragon roll. 

I guess I came here with high expectations because of the reviews, but it fell a little short. Maybe because everyone raves about the omakase and that's what we didn't get! Definitely something to consider getting if I come back.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
I could go to Ebisu once a week for the next year and it would not be enough! This is quite possibly my new favorite restaurant in San Francisco. I almost didn't go to Ebisu as my friend asked, but then my Hinge date bailed on me so I didn't feel guilty about trying a new Asian place near where my friend lives. 

First off, location: good location in the Inner Sunset, near UCSF Parnassus and some Metro Muni lines. I haven't spent much time in that neighborhood but really liked the vibes I got from walking around before and after dinner. 

Secondly: lines. My friend and I got there just before 6 on a Friday night and were seated immediately. Shortly after, a large line appeared and people were waiting both inside and outside! Luckily there's lots of cute shops to explore in if you have to wait. 

Thirdly, the food: the best part. There were so many cold and hot appetizers to choose from, so many entrees, so many sushi dishes, and specialty rolls, my friend and I spent a good 15-20 minutes figuring out what to order. We decided to split everything: the 49er roll, kakuni, 1-2 person Omakase, and matcha creme brûlée. 

The 49er roll had salmon, avocado, tobiko, shiso, and lemon. We were hesitant to try it due to the lemon but it worked! It was a thin slice and brought a unique tang to the roll that I wouldn't recommend for everyone, but I enjoyed it. We did not try the Dexter Carter but had considered it. 

The kakuni appetizer was TO DIE FOR. The fatty pork belly tasted caramelized, and, like the 49er roll with lemon, fruity due to a satsuma sauce. 10/10 would recommend the kakuni. 

The omakase for 1-2 people was plenty for us! It came with tuna, salmon, butterfish, yellowtail, amberjack, and halibut. The butterfish and amberjack were surprisingly perfect (they were the pale-colored ones I think), but they were all good and fresh and hearty slices. I believe each one came with 3 slices each. It was filling and well-worth $28! 

Even though my friend and I were stuffed, we went ahead and tried the matcha creme brûlée. The wait and trip out to the Inner Sunset would be worth it just for this unique dish. There was a thick layer of mousse beneath the crispy burnt top layer. The bottom layers were colder than that layer on top. It came with a thin shortbread-like cookie with matcha filling that was alright--the main focus was on flipping matcha creme brûlée! A must-order. 

Lastly, service: some other reviews here said service wasn't very good or professional, which was the opposite of my experience. Everyone working there was calm, knowledgeable (I asked which sashimi was what at least three times), warm, and kept filling up my water cup! They politely and discreetly tried to get us to leave to flip the table by giving us the check early and asking if we wanted dessert when we still had some sashimi left on our plates, which is to be expected. 

Bathrooms could be cleaner but they are gender-neutral. 

TLDR: amazing restaurant with great service. Order the kakuni and matcha creme brûlée, as well as a specialty sushi roll. Well worth the cost and trip to the Inner Sunset.
author: Lizzie S.

description:
One of those places with a zombillion reviews, long wait line, but worth it. 

1. Service is just ok, they have a high turnaround rate. Not a very big place so seating is quite limited, big parties should call ahead. There's a good amount of tables but that also means you're really close to the person next to/behind you.

2. Food is always good. Consistently high quality, fresh and good. Their Chirashi bowl is my favorite. I think it's around $24 but trust me, it's really worth it. Gorgeous bowl and generous portion. 

3. Ebisu is family favorite restaurant and go to Japanese restaurant. You won't regret!
author: Elle T.

description:
This place is probably one of the best Japanese Cuisine/Sushi places in this area.

The food is so flavorful, the beef is 10/10, the sake flights are delicious (and priced well). 

I love the ala cart too since I wanted to sample a variety of foods. Definitely try the beef skewers it was melting in my mouth.
author: Elijah B.

description: This place is overrated. Food was just okay and overpriced. Service was so bad. Left with a very bad experience, will not recommend for true sushi lovers.
author: Cecilia H.

description:
Recently had a wonderful dinner at Ebisu with the family. Given we rarely venture into the Richmond and or sunset we were presented with a wonderful opportunity to venture outside the city (while still definitely being in the city, but you know what I mean). 

Arrived at around 5:30 on a Saturday and waited about 30 minutes for a table of 4 (not bad at all). Service was quick and sushi was delicious, this place is definitely worth the hype for a mid to high end sushi. Everything was fresh and completely delicious. 

Items of note:
- Oysters- seriously amazing, you must. Large, covered in tobiko, and definitely something I will be thinking about for days to come. 
- Agadashi Tofu- I personally just love it, the order was huge, 8pieces, perfectly friend/ breaded (prob the wrong term). 
- nigiri sampler- delicious, as you would expect and the maki roll was great, light fresh, clean (salmon, cucumber, shiso) 
- Romeo and Juliet roll- I personally loved it. Not a fan typically of mayo on rolls but coupled with the scallop it was delicious and the perfect creamy bite!
- uni nigiri- pricey at $18, but delicious and don't for a second regret it

We had other things, but the takeaway is that everything was delicious and prices are reasonable. Wouldn't have changed a thing and highly recommend.
author: Adele T.

description: Tried the Omakase and tempura, it was good, deserves a 4 but not close to a 5, service was great and filled up fast
author: Kelly C.

description:
First thing I noticed when I walked into the restaurant was how flustered the waitresses looked. No smiles at all and the agitated expressions on their faces were not welcoming at all. 

Didn't have to wait in line for too long since I sat at the bar. Our chef was an older man. He was really nice and sweet. He had a smile on his face even though it was super busy!! 

Nigiri and sushi rolls were was okay. Not memorable, but would definitely come back to try the wagyu beef and lobster special.
author: Bonnie T.

description:
I was visiting relatives last minute in SF and my cousin Tim said he felt like Japanese.  I'm not one to say no (it's food!) and I trusted his judgement.  What I didn't expect was how much I fell in love with the food here.  

I didn't bother checking yelp reviews and ordered the Dragon Roll for myself.  I also shared a chicken teriyaki Bento Box with my grandmother.  

* Dragon Roll  $15
Unagi, Crab, Avocado, Tenpura, Shrimp and Cucumber Unagi, Crab, Avocado, Tenpura, Shrimp and Cucumber--  Everything about these rolls was perfection.   Fresh, tasty, crunchy from the tempura, and oh how the white rice just enveloped all the goodness in these.  Must order again.

* Chicken Teriyaki $16
Grilled chicken thigh and breast w/ carrots Yukon potatoes and broccolini--  Seasoning on the grilled chicken was on point. Slightly charred, with a little crunch from the skin and a tinge sweet from the teriyaki sauce.  Carrots and potatoes were just an added bonus in this dish as they were steamed to serve as accompaniment.  And the broccolini?  I'm a little partial to broccoli as it's my favorite vegetable.  Gobbled these up.

Note to self:  Must come back.
author: Lorie N.

description:
Great sushi place in SF! Chefs are friendly, sushi are fresh, some cook items are beautifully presented. 
I came here a few times and so far I haven't been feeling disappointed.
The deep fried lobster meat was very well presented, the tempura flour tasted crunchy, the mayo sauce sprinkled with flying fish roe tasted very delicious .
The sushi roll topped with mango and salmon also very tasty.

This place has always been very busy, I suggest come before 7pm.
author: Irene X.

description:
Ebisu was packed on a Saturday right after opening. Be prepared to wait if you don't arrive early. Regardless, they served sushi insanely fast. Another perk was the atmosphere. The inside of Ebisu is swanky- floor to ceiling wood, with no windows, yet bright lighting.

All of the sushi is standard price. I ate a King California roll with real crab, a tuna cucumber roll with malleable fish and thinly sliced crunchy cucumber, sake sushi, and one piece of syrupy tomago for dessert ($25.50 in total) Each roll was cut into eight pieces, and a little shorter than a traditional six piece roll. On the outside, extremely sticky rice with loads of (almost excessive) vinegar produced an acidic tang. A hint of lemon mixed with the sweet king crab was another interesting flavor profile that I experienced, in addition to very salty salmon in the sake sushi. It tasted as though the salmon had leap from the ocean onto my plate, salt water and all. Even the simple rolls possessed complex flavors. I can only imagine how the special rolls must taste!
author: Cecily T.

description:
3.5 stars
Unfortunately, waiting is probably inevitable here. We waited around 30 minutes for a table for 4. Luckily, the waiter came around pretty fast. I ordered the Combo 4 bento box with beef teriyaki, maki sushi, and gyoza. The bento box also comes with miso soup and rice. The miso soup was good and not too salty. The unagi nigiri basically melted in my mouth. The caterpillar roll was crunchy and also so delicious. That was really some good sushi. 

The bento box was kind of underwhelming. I did like the beef teriyaki and gyoza, but it wasn't that much. The maki sushi was good, but I'm not a big fan of raw fish. I didn't really like the other stuff that came in the bento box. The salad and the greens and the other stick like food were kind of weird. I just would've preferred only the foods listed under Combo 4. 

If I ever come back, I will only order sushi or order one of the other lunches/dinners. No more bento box for me.
author: Allyson L.

description: Hands down, my new favorite place for sushi! There was a bit of a wait when my party of four came in, but honestly it was worth the wait! We ordered about five rolls. If I recall correctly, we got their 49er, crunchy roll, this scallop roll, caterpillar, and honestly I forgot the last one haha. There was also this jalepeño kind of roll, it wasn't bad, but I'm not a big fan of peppers. I do have to say that this does give a good kick in your mouth haha. Going back to these rolls, I've had a majority of them before at different sushi places. Buuuuut, once I had a taste of the rolls at Ebisu, it felt like they were on a whole different level. Customer service was excellent, and the food came out quickly. I had a wonderful experience here, and if I have an opportunity to be in the area, I would definitely come back here!
author: Mabel L.

description: Loved this place! Went for lunch and everything I tried was super tastey. For me, I ordered salmon nigiri and a caterpillar roll and both were delicious. I could definitely tell the fish was good quality. Also, sitting at the sushi bar was cool, I got to see the chef make my food right in front of me and he was very friendly. I noticed the place does get pretty busy during this time, all the tables were full. Also, heard that it gets pretty busy during dinner so plan for a long wait. Great place and would totally come back!
author: Jessica F.

description:
I came here with a friend who used to live in sf and said we HAVE TO GO. 

So glad we did, because this may just be my new favorite spot. 
We got the wagyu beef appetizer
-5/5 comes with 3 different dipping sauces

Then we decided to do omakase since we were at the sushi bar. 
Our sushi chef was awesome, listened to what we wanted, and gave us a great array of fish. He topped it off with Uni at the end which was to die for. 

We went on a Thursday night around 7:30pm, and the place was packed. Definitely get here around 30 min prior to when you actually want to eat. 

Overall, I will def be back. 5/5 - and that's hard for me to say. 
The quality was as good as more expensive places I've been to in the city, and the price was good. Two people w/ omakase and appetizers was right around $150. That's not bad! 

Can't wait for my next visit!
author: Janessa H.

description: Fresh, really good sushi. My friend and I went all out and got a lot of food for the two of us. Loved everything. Con: long wait, small restaurant. Very very tiny restaurant people kept saying excuse while I was eating to get past behind me. Damn can I just eat in peace!
author: Debbie D.

description:
My friend and I came here for dinner to celebrate her birthday. There was a slight wait around 6ish, but we put our name on the waitlist and got seated in about 15 minutes. It's a pretty decent space with bar seating to observe the wonderful sushi chefs, and a fair number of table seatings. It can get quite loud with the large crowds, but still a good place to enjoy a meal and have good convos. 

The servers were quick to help us and suggest dishes. We ordered the seafood salad and tempura appetizers. And the Dexter Carter the Double Hamachi. The appetizers weren't anything spectacular. The Dexter Carter had salmon, lemon, shrimp, avocado, tobiko and shiso, and the Double Hamachi had yellowtail, scallion and tobiko. The rolls were pretty good. We enjoyed the Dexter Carter more than the Double Hamachi. Think the Double Hamachi was drenched in a bit too much sauce. The fish overall tasted pretty fresh. Pricing was usual SF price, with the Dexter being $12.50 and the Double Hamachi was $15. I would def come back again and probably go for my traditional nigiri style ;D Plus, it's in a great location with lots of dessert options afterwards :)
author: Jackie C.

description: I think I might have found my favorite Japanese restaurant in the Bay Area!! I was pleasantly surprised by how fresh the sushi was and the service is A++! Their sushi chef's were very professional too. I ordered one of the sashimi's and the chef told me specifically to not dip with the soy sauce and omg, it was heavenly!  I will definitely be back for more! It was so worth the wait
author: Chelsea T.

description:
Come here if you're looking for good sushi, not mediocre fill up sushi but also not top of the line break your bank sushi.

Pros:
+ Quality fish, good appetizers and rolls
+ Sushi bar seating available
+ 5 minute wait for the sushi bar on a Monday @ 8PM

Cons:
- Never really liked the small and cramped seating

Recommendations:
+ Gyoza
+ Rainbow roll (if you're into rolls)
+ Hamachi toro nigiri
+ Aji nigiri
+ Chu toro nigiri

Skip:
- Either the amberjack or albacore nigiri
- Wagyu or Kobe nigiri

I'm personally not a rolls person, but since my friend wanted it, we ordered the Rainbow and Rock n Roll. I've always liked their rainbow roll. Never disappoints. Most of the nigiri were good, except the amberjack I believe. It fell flat for me and lacked flavor. The Chu toro was delicious! Would've gotten the otoro but at $18/2 pieces, I just couldn't do it. Gyoza was perfect and not overly salty.

Total: $100 ish before tip for 2 people with 0 drinks.

Will be back when in need of good sushi.
author: Fanny W.

description: Good restaurant that is popular among foreign people. Looks like over 90% of customers are not Japanese. I ordered Ebisu combo, that is good, and I guess the amount of "shari" (rice beneath of fish) is localized to bigger than regular sushi. Not good points are non home made miso soup and non natural wasabi. But totally good restaurant.
author: Keisuke W.

description:
I need to start off this review with a declaration: The Kakuni is simply AMAZING! It's a super tender pork belly infused with flavor and I would really recommend it to anyone who eats meat. 

For rolls, we tried the California roll with real crab, which was alright. Crab tasted fresh. The Tootsie Roll sounded very interesting since it is fried salmon inside a soy wrap. Tasted okay but I would stick to raw fish for the rolls. The family affair roll was solid, but not amazing. 

For my entree I had the deluxe sushi combo which was a 10 pc sorted nigiri with different fish, eel, fish egg over rice pieces wrapped in seaweed. Freshness is the key to good sushi and all the food at this place is fresh and high quality. Good overall but I didn't like the fish eggs. 

The portions are good. Expect to pay a good amount, as this is a bit more upscale than your average Japanese restaurant. ($20-35/person depending what and how much you order)

Service is too notch, interior is small but dimly lit for a cozy and intimate setting. It gets crowded for dinner so come early, they don't do reservations. 

Food: 4.75/5
Value: 3.5/5
Service: 5/5
Overall: 4.75/5
author: Brian G.

description:
This place is usually swamped with people waiting so expect at least a half hour wait for dinner. When you are finally seated, you are crammed into a small table that is right next to the next table. I was feeling a bit claustrophobic in here. My boyfriend and I were craving rolls so we tried a couple with a couple of pieces of nigiri. 

Behind the green door
You can go ahead and close that green door once you finish because this roll was disgusting. The fish on top was not fresh and you can tell by the taste. It was rancid and I couldn't get the taste out of my mouth even with a couple of swish of tea. 

Dragon roll
Wasn't the best I had but you really can't mess up a dragon roll. 

Romeo and Juliet
Yes! This is the one. I actually like this one. I think this roll is my star crossed lover in this restaurant. Would definitely order again.

Seared Salmon belly nigiri
Fatty and buttery. My favorite taste buds were turned on. That crisp charred after taste you get. Lovely.

Mixed tempura
I love how the batter was so light but just enough where you had a crunch to it. 

Waitresses were friendly but the fact that one of them kept accidentally bumping to the side of my head light weight annoyed me. It's okay though. This establishment is small and that's what happens when there's no moving space.
author: Ada H.

description:
Absolutely delicious! I have been here two times so far and have experienced a consistently high-quality service and dining experience. Yelpers should be forewarned that there is *almost* always a wait here (or so it seems). I would suggest putting your name down before looking for parking (which as we know, could take a while in the city). We waited about 40 minutes for a table of 2. But it is well worth it!

We ordered salmon, albacore, tuna, yellowtail and halibut nigiri. The tuna was the only disappointment but the others were spectacularly delicious. 

My favorite rolls here are the 49-er and the Dexter Carter (very similar). 

I also recommend ordering the sake flight, it was really nice to try out a few different sake's at a reasonable price. 

Will definitely be back! :)
author: Ani S.

description:
The Good: tempura, lobster dynamite.  

The Bad: all the rolls! They fall apart b/c the rice this place uses is not even sushi grad rice. Absolutely not worth it. 

The Ugly: my party waited for almost an hour b/c they kept skipping the three of us and giving tables to party of twos so they could sit more ppl. Shady business practice! Finally they sat us down and gave us the exact same small table that could sit only two ppl! I wouldn't have it so I had to let them know that was not OK! And the clipboard guy gave in and let us sit at a larger table instead. 

The final word: Will. Never. Return.
author: Angela F. W.

description: Pretty good. We had a delux combo and sukiyaki lunch. We shared the plate good portion for two.
author: Liz K.

description: Came here for a dinner date and their nigiri was legit. I tired their otoro for the first time and loved it. The Hamachi Toro was mediocre, but the monk fish was definitely tasty. How can I forget their wagyu?! It's perfectly flavored. We lefted pretty happy. Would I come back? Yes!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
This place is small so be prepared to wait to get seated especially during dinner time. The service was great and attentive and even the owner dropped by to asked how we're doing (not a lot of mom/pop shop usually do that to get that personal touch/feel).

We had the combo sashimi, eel roll, and a bunch of other rolls (can't remember). OMG. It was sooooo good and the fish were so fresh. I'm so glad I get to try this place and fellow yelpers def persuaded me with its high ratings. This will def be my regular go-to place when I'm in the area! YUM-O!
author: Cindy L.

description:
Food and service OK
Waiting time 45 minute for Wednesday and very tiny space to sit and eat.
Quality of sashimi just below average not as expected.
Monthly promotion has to be purchased and used for next meal only.
author: Isabelle Z.

description: Came at 9 pm on Saturday night, no wait. Ordered the charashi (sashimi on top of sushi rice) while my buddy got the dinner combination. Oh my goodness the charashi was GOOD. Fresh, melt in your mouth sashimi. Reasonably priced at $22. My buddy's bento box dinner was $20 and had generous portions. We are definitely coming back!
author: Wendy L.

description:
Everything about this place is great. The atmosphere and the food is just fantastic. My favorite roll here is the 49ers role as I've seen on other reviews too. It's just the best roll I've ever had. It's so darn good! 

This place will be busy if you come on a weekend and they do not take reservations. Wait times are usually not too bad, unless you have a larger group. We sent one person earlier to put a name down, so I recommend that if you have a larger group. 

My main recommendation here is the 49ers role! I've had others, but this one stood out to me the most. And again, Id like to emphasize the environment and atmosphere at this place, very cute. 

I recommend it if you're looking for a good sushi place! This is definitely it.
author: Daniel C.

description:
We've been wanting to come here for awhile and finally got the chance yesterday afternoon.  We arrived just after noon yesterday and the place was already filling up.  Our hostess and waitress, a charming Japanese woman, greeted us and seated us at a table.  The sushi bar was also available, but we weren't having sushi.  We ordered the lunch chicken teriyaki ($14) which came with miso soup, small bowl of rice, yukon potatoes, broccolini, carrots, and a fresh salad.  The dish was impressive and attractive.  Additionally, we had a caterpillar roll ($10) which consisted of unagi, cucumbers, avocados and sesame.  These rolls were wonderful and had a delicate almost velvety taste.  The last item was special ramen soup  (can't remember the exact price) which was a little disappointing.  It seemed a little bland and could use a few more added ingredients.

The service was superb as our waitress was very attentive without being overbearing.  Certainly, we plan to come here again.  Its a small place, but can accommodate 5+ if you get there early enough.
author: Robert J.

description: This place is probably one of the best Japanese Sushi places in San Francisco. The restaurant is an odd mix of bustling & tranquil.
author: Danielle B.

description:
Had a very nice lunch here with my wife and a friend. The food was mostly very good but in the expensive side. The waitress did bring one incorrect sushi order. 

The grilled shiitakes were amazing. The Maui onion was undercooked so most was too strong, raw onion flavor. The shiso ume temaki was good. The mixed veg maki tasted ok but was rather macerated and looked unappealing. My wife and friend enjoyed the ankimo, hamachi, uni, miso and other things they ordered.
author: Marco M.

description:
Fish was not fresh, over washed by water and defrosted, losing all its essential taste. They tried to use different kinds of sauces to cover it up. sorry my tongue is very sensitive to umami (grew up with fresh live seafood in Asia). Also, one of the sushi chefs in the middle was drinking shots like crazy and got tipsy, FLIRTING with two female customers right at the sushi bar...That was EXTREMELY disturbing to experience his unprofessionalism and flirty dirty lines. He should be FIRED!

Nice modern decor, good sushi mancraftship
author: Qi H.

description: I love living close to Ebisu, especially now that they are open for their new ramen lunch. In terms of quality per dollar and overall deliciousness, this sushi is hard to beat. Bonus points for awesome hot appetizers like their grilled lamb chops. The chefs are friendly and the overall atmosphere is fun.
author: Connor D.

description:
Awesome neighborhood restaurant!
Family run business, which I will always support. 

I've been here several times over a span of 25 years and it never disappoints. 
Great menu, awesome sake selections, Japanese beers in bottles or draft. 
But best of all is the food! Everything is fresh and well prepared. Very professional servers with great personalities. 
Highly recommend, enjoy!
author: Jetsforme M.

description:
disclaimer: 4 stars for appetizers, 2-2.5 stars for the sushi experience. This will be a super long review since we went all out :)

Came here on a Saturday around 6:30pm, waited about 45 minutes for a table for 4. The hostess in charge of the waitlist seemed grumpy (at least she was equally indifferent to everyone I guess....).

Once seated, the food was served very quickly after we ordered and the waitresses were really nice and friendly. 

Appetizers:
Kobe (Beef) Sashimi -3.5 stars- always heard about this raw beef sashimi but never actually tried it, wasn't sure if I would able to stomach raw meat but it was fine! The meat was unsalted, soft and chewy. It came with a small plate of soy sauce, which was good, and three types of spicy sauce, which I did not like so I skipped.

Sake Steamed Mussels -4 stars- I really liked this appetizer but it was very salty. I liked the flavors in the soup containing a leafy green (spinach?), shiitake mushrooms and dried scallops in a sake/soy sauce soup base I think. Glad we made the switch to mussels based on the waitress's recommendation, she said it has a bigger portion than the clams.

Gindara (Sake kasu marinated black cod) -5 stars- almost missed this gem! Very tasty, the fish practically melts in your mouth, the smooth garlicky (sake kasu) sauce was also very good. This was definitely our favorite appetizer/dish of the night. The only unfortunate part was the small portion size since it was an appetizer, we had to savor every last piece 

Oyster Dynamite -4.5 stars- YUM! Oyster and sea urchin covered in tasty mayo and tobiko sitting in shells that rested on top of mounds of salt, be careful not to accidentally eat some of the salt on the bottom! I think that may be why my family complained that it was "too salty".

Hotate (Bacon wrapped scallop) -2 stars- just as simple as the description says, nothing special. Can be skipped.

Seafood salad -2.5 stars- was just okay, just sashimi pieces and imitation crab mixed in with seaweed salad and some type of balsamic vinaigrette. Would not order again.

Sushi:
Despite this being a sushi bar, sushi is NOT what I would recommend at this restaurant. Sushi rice is bad quality and the quality of the sushi got progressively worse with every dish presented at our table. 

Family Affair -3.5 stars- this was one of the better rolls of the night.

49er -2.5 stars- We usually go for this roll when it's an option at sushi places because we like that sour, refreshing lemon taste that goes well with the salmon but the slices of lemons on this roll tonight was TOO RIPE and a little bitter/salty- ruined the roll for us.

Romeo & Juliet -3 stars- nothing special.

Cherry Blossom -1 star- this was the last sushi dish that arrived, some of the pieces of salmon sashimi was starting to turn grey and it was just nauseating. We were so upset that we had to bring it up to the waitress, who listened but didn't offer anything to make up for it.

Dessert:
Matcha Creme Brulee -3 stars- I had expected this to be a hot or warm desert but the creme brulee was a bit cooler than room temperature when it arrived at the table. Nothing extraordinary about this green tea-flavored creme brulee, it was okay but not something that I would highly recommend. It comes with a thin wafer cookie that had green tea cream filling, which was pretty good.

Mochi ice cream -4 stars- packed with flavor! We tried green tea and mango flavors.

In conclusion, YES to appetizers and NO to sushi here.
author: Amy T.

description: For years Ebisu has been my favorite sushi spot in the city. The wait can be hit or miss (no reservations) so just be prepared to wait for dinner if you arrive at 6pm or later. My absolute favorite thing on the menu is the seafood salad - a mix of raw fish with seaweed salad (and other stuff I'm prob forgetting) in a super light dressing. It's fresh, delicious, and totally unique, IMO a must-get when you're here! The Bento boxes are also a great value for the amount of food you get, especially with lunchtime prices. Overall I absolutely LOVE Ebisu and couldn't recommend it more!
author: Tracy C.

description: I enjoyed their lunch special for takeout. Ordered a Saba special, which had a large piece of fresh Saba, which was perfectly grilled. Not too salty as well. ($14) I liked the roasted potatoes, carrots and broccolini, which are unique side dishes for Japanese food.
author: Thomas L.

description:
Ebisu is my go to/favorite sushi spot in the city. The atmosphere is classic. Very small/marrow restaurant, but sublime. The sushi is creative, and delicious. The fish is fresh, and always plated perfectly. Not one bad thing to say besides the usual wait. ((always worth the wait))

favorite rolls: Romeo and Juliet and the #29.
author: Amanda F.

description:
This is THE best sushi spot in San Francisco. Don't argue with me because you'll lose. I don't even want to write this review because it means the lines will be even longer than they already are, but, I LIVE for this sushi. 

Their crunch salmon skin handroll is out of this world. All of their fish is SO fresh. Currently sitting in NYC and crying that we don't have sushi like this here.
author: Jackie C.

description: My girlfriend and I came to Ebisu on a whim when the original sushi place we had planned on going to was closed for the night. We were at the right place at the right time. We had no idea how busy it would get, but when we arrived 10 minutes after they opened, we were seated promptly even though a small line had already started to form for larger parties. From fish to rice, I could tell the ingredients used were of high quality. We ordered oysters and chirashi. The oysters were probably some of the best oysters we've ever had, while the chirashi also was some of the best I've ever had. Overall, it's a really cute restaurant with really great food! Come right at 5:00 when they open and you shouldn't have a problem with seating for smaller parties.
author: Ashley F.

description:
My favorite sushi restaurant in San Francisco. Nuff said.

Fresh fish and delicious rolls which let the fish be the star without smothering in sauces. The interior is trendy, cozy, and cool. My mouth is watering just writing this review.
author: Nina M.

description:
Took my self to dinner here. Ordered Amaebi, Mirugai and Uni. All were fresh and delicious  
The young sushi chef with glasses was super nice and helpful.
author: Kay L.

description: Disappointed and frustrated!! Came here with a friend because of all the amazing reviews, however, service and food quality are both quite bad. The dragon roll was the only decent thing. I don't eat sashimi so I got myself a bento box with beef. More than half of the med cooked beef teriyaki was really chewy. My friend didn't like her sashimi bowl either. What pissed me off the most was when I put the leftovers in a togo box, an old lady walked up and offered if I needed more togo boxes. I thanked her and let her know I already have one. She stared at the greens and tempura on my bowl that I didn't want to take for a good 5 second, and then snatched my to-go box open!! She then looked at what's in the box, left it open, and walked away without saying a word!! Left me and my friend on WTF???
author: Sharie H.

description: Hands down my favorite spot for sushi in San Francisco. You might have to wait for a bit because the interior is small, nice and cozy. But the wait is worth the wait because the freshness is 5/5 stars. My boyfriend and I come here about 3 times a year and they are always so consistent. One time we brought our friend that was studying abroad from Japan here and he really enjoyed it. He asked about the sushi chef to the waitress and found out the main Chef is from Osaka, Japan. Not sure if that's still true since that was a while ago, but it's nice to know that they really take pride in how they prepare their food just like Japan.
author: Adrienne G.

description:
So, when you have to wait this long, it better be a great experience. Next time I would get there very early, just to avoid the line... and to struggle for parking. There were an average amount of hits and misses here, so it didn't seem like a great experience worth the wait. 

The menu is more than overwhelming or, as some would say, there are a lot of choices. A Lot!
There were many "exotic" offerings, so I thought I would try some different items. Nothing thrilled me. The sushi rolls were crumbling, which made it difficult to enjoy them, and even harder to share. 

There are a lot of great ratings here, so statistically speaking, you'll probably like it, but I was not as impressed as I had been led to expect. And be aware... it is NOT inexpensive. Even by sushi standards it's a hefty tab. 

There are a lot of fine sushi restaurants, and full menu Japanese restaurants out there, without some of the pains you have to go through to eat here.  Or maybe try it here at Ebisu, for lunch.
author: James G.

description:
Get your name on the list as soon as you walk in the door. Waiting area is small considering the traffic they receive every open evening. Drinks are affordable and i was tempted to pre-order a beer but was called to sit at a table faster than i anticipated. Hooray!

I came here mostly for for the fish. Variations of sashimi, nigiri, sushi rolls and hand rolls caught my attention. The Dexter Carter roll was my favorite. Everything was delicious for the great price $$ they offered. No wonder it's a popular spot. The one hot dish that stood out - the Asari Miso. Simple, warm miso soup with clams. I could've ordered seconds i liked it so much. 

Attentive service. Sushi bar or tables. Good for parties of all sizes. Families, date night, friends. Good for sushi cravings!
author: Samantha L.

description: I really like the vibe of this place. It's a small restaurant with an intimate feel. The waitresses were really friendly and were quick to pick up any finished plates on the table to keep your area clean. I was pleased with the portions. I ordered the Combo 2 Bento box and I really like how they added potatoes and grilled carrots and broccoli to the meal. I also ordered the rock n roll and family affair and I would highly recommend giving family affair a try. Overall I really enjoyed my experience here and I would gladly come back in the near future.
author: Joanne C.

description: Came here for the first time with my family and had an amazing time! Not only were their sushi options on point, their non fish options were delicious too. I told them it was my brothers birthday and they included a complimentary red bean ice cream scoop for him. We had a good laugh at how embarrassed he was when our waiter came out singing. These little things are what really makes a restaurant stand out to me. We'll be back many more times!
author: Tiffany T.

description: Hands down next value sushi joint on the west side. Exceptional selection of fish and always a great sample of new specials. Family owned and fun establishment makes it extra special after all these years.
author: Alex J.

description:
Omakase all the way!

Ebisu is one of those places where I can sit down, tell the chef to give me whatever he thinks is good that day, and not break my wallet!  I would definitely recommend doing the omakase, your chefs will know what's good.  It's also the kind of place that's not overly pretentious - the last time my friend and I were there we told the chef we weren't very hungry, but wanted just a few very delicious bites.  The staff and sushi chefs treat you right whether you're ordering just a couple pieces or an entire feast.  Quality of the fish is solid, especially if you're ordering off the specials menu.

Tips and Tricks
-You can still order omakase even if you're not seated at the sushi bar, but interacting with your chef is fun!
-You can tell your chef you want a certain amount of pieces, or just have them keep coming until you're full
-It's in the Inner Sunset, so parking can be a little tough
author: Jessica L.

description:
Mouth-watering sushi that melts in your mouth!! Once you sit down, they immediately serve you a warm towel to wipe your hands and a small bowl of edamame to snack on. My friend and I sat at the bar and got to order from the sushi chefs themselves. 

My favorite roll was the caterpillar roll - not only did it look super aesthetically pleasing, it tasted wonderful as well (eels and avocado are the best combo!). It did take a while to get seated, wait for our food, and receive the check, but it was a nice experience overall.
author: Kris C.

description:
This place is great!

After we ordered sushi and Combo No 1 and Combo No 2, we've been first served with complementary Miso soup, that tasted really good.

Servise, staff, ambient, price, location - basicly everything is *****.

It would be waste of time to go in to details. Just try Ebisu - it will make you happy.
author: Marino F.

description: Seated us very quickly and ambiance is pleasant. Food was of very good quality and was brought out fast. Overall very happy with my experience. I recommend the chicken teriyaki!
author: George T.

description: Regular menu items are priced right for the quality of the fish. The lunch bento boxes look like they're a great deal -I have yet to try them. The specials posted on the wall behind the sushi bar are quite pricey for one piece each, but are oh soo good and tastes fresh. I enjoy eating at the sushi bar more than at the tables because you can do an open tab and order whatever you want directly from the sushi chef. Quite a fun experience and almost better than doing omakase style at other places since you get to choose what you want with a less costly bill.
author: Donna M.

description: I LOVE Ebisu! I've gone here twice now and was very please each time I went. They have a huge menu and and very friendly staff which is always a plus! It may be small but the wait time is actually not too bad when they are packed!
author: Daniel C.

description: One of my favorite sushi spots in SF. Fresh, great quality sushi. Always packed, expect to wait. Parking is very difficult in the area. Absolutely worth it though!
author: Raisa G.

description:
To alert everybody, there are no reservations here and tables are seated by a first come first serve basis. So, be prepared to wait possibly one hour if you come at a peak time.

This is one of my favorite go-to sushi spots if I'm looking to get a roll that is made with quality. The chefs here keep the sushi at a good rice to filling ratio. My favorite roll overall is the double hamachi, you can't go wrong if you can handle raw fish. Their ankimo is also very fresh and sit it in a light dish of ponzu and radish. 

If you sit at the bar, then you can get edamame on the house (which is a plus) and also order directly from the sushi chef. However keep in mind that if you sit at the bar you might probably bump arms with someone who sits next to you because the space is so tight and you can't hang your purse anywhere.
author: cheryl c.

description: Are used to eat here years ago with a good friend of mine and had such fun memories. Upon eating at this place in early 2018 I found it to be simply average. There's nothing wrong with it and the food tasted just fine. It just doesn't stand out. I didn't find the fish to be fresher or tastier than any other sushi place. Although I do give it props for some authentic dishes on the menu. Prices are about what you expect from a Japanese joint. And it's a solid inner Sunset location. Having said that, I'm not sure I would make a special trip just to eat here like I used to back in the day.
author: Robert C.

description:
Came here for the first time the other night for a bday dinner. It was raining and this place was packed. The wait was about 30 mins at around 730 pm. We got seated pretty fast because no one wanted to sit at the bar. So our party of 5 did....we ordered everything directly with the sushi chefs at the bar.

We ordered:
- omakase  (there's one that's 30 dollars and one that's 60)...they'll fry the shrimp head for you which was delicious. Discovered ankimo (it's fish patte)  and loved it!!!!!!! 
-California rolls
-uni rolls
-oysters shooters
-fresh oysters
-warm sake 
-Hamachi kama
-spicy tuna hand roll 
-××× rolls 
-spider rolls

Everything was amazing. Service was great for an Asian place. Our bill with tip and evrything came out to almost $500 dollars. But it was worth it!!
author: Caitlin P.

description:
The very best quality sushi you can get in San Francisco. Sit in front of Suzuki (the most senior of the sushi chefs) and do omakase. Let him feed you what's best that night, let him cook a couple of grilled items for you. Let him choose and you won't regret it. Splurge and get the premium toro, it melts in your mouth. Take advantage of the specials. Buy the chefs a beer. Take a couple of hours and really savor these dishes one by one. Just don't break up with the boyfriend who takes you here several times a week, like I did! 
P.S. The remodel on the inside is simply dreadful. Pay no mind, just face the sushi bar.
author: L. M.

description:
We came here on a Monday night for 4 people and we ended up waiting an hour and a half. It's definitely easier to get seated here if you're in a party of two.

Here's what we tried:
Rock n Roll Handroll
Unagi nigiri
Tamago nigiri
Lobster tempura
Chicken teriyaki
Tokyo tower 
Fried chicken 

For some reason the seaweed from the handroll and the roll was very tough. The eel was very good though. The Tokyo tower roll was falling apart and also had tough seaweed. I am not sure if it is because we waited a bit before eating those items, thus making the seaweed hard or if it came like that originally. I digress though.

The nigiri was fresh and good. The tamago was really delicious. The Chicken teriyaki came in a big portion and was tender, savory and the sauce interesting. The Lobster tempura was quite good and tasted better with the spicy sauce. The fried chicken was not very good though. It was very greasy and the skin came off, to the point where it was soggy. 

Overall, I would come back here.
author: Guilliana J.

description: This place is beyond classic.  Steve and family have been rocking sushi for 30 years.  The sashimi is always super fresh.  The rolls are fun.  The staff is just super nice and attentive.  It does get crowded, but not too loud.  The decor is traditional Japanese.  It's s really nice place.  Check it out.
author: Alex I.

description:
This place is really solid, and potentially a 5-star restaurant given what it is. Just a really dependable sushi restaurant. I usually find sushi restaurants hit or miss. and Ebisu is the rock that sits right in the middle.

We often go for lunch, and usually the wait is minimal and the service is fast. They have a massive menu, including lunch specials for bento boxes (~$16), sushi, udon, hot and cold appetizers, along with other things. I like the Tempura Udon for all the foggy days in the park.

There is a small sushi bar (maybe 10 seats), and tables in the front and back of the restaurant. 

Inner sunset can have pretty limited parking. If you're at Cal Academy or the de Young, it's only a 10 minute walk!
author: Steph D.

description:
Everything we had was super fresh and delicious. The place itself is beautiful and welcoming. 
The service was so quick and efficient. 
Great place!
author: Or L.

description:
Perfect. It was busy but they were very efficient about getting us seated. The waitress saw we had kids so immediately brought forks and water for them. All of the plates and cutlery were clean.

We got our order in (a bento, a roll and a Chirashi) and it came promptly. The presentation was nice, the fish was fresh and smiles all around. What you won't find here: over-sauced rolls, ranch dressing or pink ginger. The prices are not budget but they are reasonable.

All in all, a great experience. This place has been around a while and they could rest on their laurels given the crowds, but it seems the owner has a serious work ethic and system to keep this place humming.
author: Dante J.

description:
The wife had a craving for sushi tonight. As a husband, I tried to fulfill all her needs and craving and I've found Ebisu here on yelp with raving reviews! Prices were outrageous, so I've decided to take the wife here. 

Upon entering the restaurant, we were greet by the owner and only waited a few minutes before we were seated. So far so good.... however, the negative follows. 

Ive never had sashimi (omakase) tasted this horrible along with two fish bone left in it. The $28 twelve pieces omakase didn't look too fresh. And I thought maybe it was the lighting where we were seated. Oh man, was I wrong?!? Three of the "pieces" of sashimi was not a complete piece. But rather two small chunks put together and formed into "one piece". One pieces of the hamachi even had a small piece of skin attached to it, which was very chewy and I had to spit it out. Being a Chinese when I was taught not to be wasteful. I've forcefully finished the whole dish of "omakase" while the wife had only two pieces and dropped her chopsticks. 

The reason I am offering two stars as review was because the staffs' service was on point, and the cooked food was actually decent. 

The wife ordered the oyster dynamite, which was very rich and flavorful. The hotate skewer (beacon wrapped scallops) were the highlight of the night.

By the way, their rolls are much more expensive and did not leave a positive impression at all. 

All in all, YELPERS beware!!! It's either a HIT or a miss according to some yelp reviews. Mine experience was a negative one. Try at own risk!
author: Eric Z.

description: Really great omikase with decent pricing. Friendly, clean environment with great service. The restaurant is relatively small and always has a line (30-40 min wait). Their bento boxes have some atypical add-ons along with the rest of your meal.
author: Kristine C.

description:
Despite the great reviews I saw for this place it fell short for me. My friend and I came around 9:30 on a Wednesday Night and we were told that we would get seated shortly. We waited about 10-15 minutes and then were seated. The waitress came by and took our drink orders and then told us the Chefs Specials on the blackboard is highly recommended. We ordered the XXX Roll, Giants Roll, and Romeo and Juliet. 

I personally am not the biggest sashimi fan so it was my fault to not realize all the rolls we ordered were sashimi based. However I decided to put my preferences aside and try it out. All the rolls were just okay, there wasn't anything super special about them. After a few pieces they started to taste all the same. 

However the bright part of it all is the service is great! Hilary our waitress was super friendly and helpful. 

I'll probably come back again but order some other rolls that are based more towards my preferences.
author: Yinja L.

description:
Pretty cool sushi spot. Pricing is around the middle for a sushi joint, but the fish is very fresh. If you order rolls just be prepared to order more since they are fairly small

There is usually a wait since no reservations are taken, we waited about 30 mins on a Friday night. Also the hostess is very particular about where the customers sit.
author: Mason L.

description: A neighborhood treasure for many years. My child thoroughly enjoys all of the small plates. We order piles of edamame with the todaroshi lime and lemon garlic, chawanmushi egg custard, cold or hot agedashi tofu. For years, the specialty roll to get was the 49er and for us it still is. The salmon with lemon rind and shiso is just right. For those complaining about the curt waitstaff, that has not been our experience. Some are in hurried, but they warm up to you after a while.
author: A K.

description: The restaurant does not take reservations; first come, first serve. But I arrived and was immediately seated. Our waitress was very attentive. The sushi was fresh and enjoyable. Wish they had live uni when I went but unfortunately not, maybe it's not in season. The interior inside of the restaurant is very appealing. Parking is a bit difficult to find, but as any place in Sf is. I believe majority of the parking around the area was parallel parking they did have side by side slots but mostly parallel.
author: Kassandra M.

description:
This place is so good. Now I understand why this place has so many reviews and a great rating. We walked in and put our name down on the list. Yes, there was a wait but it wasn't horribly long. They have a few seats in the walkway for you to sit down and wait until your party gets called. We sat at the sushi bar, which made it a better experience. We were able to ask the sushi chefs their recommendations for sushi and sake. We watched our sushi chef, Eric, make all of our rolls and nigiri. It was like watching a beautiful piece of art being made every time. I will definitely come back for more. 

Deluxe sashimi: Our friends ordered it and really liked it. 

Family Affair Roll: My favorite roll. The Maui onion on top made the roll. 

Sunset Roll: Another tasty roll. Everything in it just worked well together. 

Lobster Tempura: Good! Good chunks of lobster. 

Albacore Toro Nigiri: I asked our chef what he recommended and this is what he made us. Sooo good. It just melts in your mouth. He even told us how we should eat it. No soy sauce. All in one bite. 

Torched salmon nigiri: I liked torched sushi because it really transforms the flavor. 

Torched escolar nigiri: Beautiful and simply tasty. 

Braised pork belly: Amazing! If you want some meat, this is what you should get. The beautiful braised pork belly was bathed in a delicious sauce.
author: Nicole S.

description: Very yummy. Wait was extremely long, probably an hour and a half but restaurant is small and service is great so wait is worth it. Lots of types of fresh fish posted on the walls with clear prices. Otoro was fantastic, salmon belly also very good, fresh. Desserts were also amazing: matcha creme brule and sake drunken berries.
author: Mary A.

description:
Unfortunately didn't have the best experience. Ordered 4 specials rolls and they came out less than special. The presentation wasn't tasteful, the rolls were falling apart and the fish didn't even taste it's most fresh. Pretty disappointed considering the reviews. 

Some rolls we saw at the bar looked a little better, but if we are ordering a special roll it should be fresh and looking presentable. Staff was very nice and atmosphere was good. Just wish the sushi itself was better.
author: Kerry G.

description: This was a phenomenal meal and worth the wait! The Romeo and Juliet roll is melt in your mouth delicious.
author: Anne B.

description:
We were excited to try a new to us, very highly rated on Yelp, sushi bar for dinner. When we arrived it was packed, a good sign when visiting a new restaurant. After having a terrible meal, I have no idea what people are raving about. This's is the worst sushi I've ever had. The chef behind the bar was sloppy and lacked attention to detail. Our order for a roll without tobiko (roe) came covered with it. He rightly remade it. The fish was flavorless, the roles sounded interesting but were nearly inedible. We ordered three roles and didn't finish any of them. That has never happened, leaving unfinished roles- never. 

This place is off our list. With so many positive reviews for this place I really don't know what to make of it. Absolutely terrible sushi.
author: Fred F.

description:
I think this place is cool. It's kind of really packed -- and although that's normally a good thing, I think it's because they have a great tourist location.

Don't get me wrong, I think they serve good food and the location is great but I would not consider this to be really great Japanese cuisine. My instinct says to me they are serving the tourists.

I got the sashimi plate and I did not find the ingredients or freshness to be extraordinary. Just kinda what to be expected. The crowdedness of the place kind of made me feel claustrophobic.

However, there is no denying that I liked it. It was a satisfying meal. If you are going to one of the museums, I think this is a A-OK option.
author: Jack T.

description:
This sushi joint is fun. The inside looks like you are in a Japanese town. The staff is extremely friendly. The sushi is great. It's a little pricey but you can tell it's good quality. Even the California rolls are fantastic. We had 6 orders of sushi rolls and 2 pints of beer for $70. 
The parking is a bit tough since it is a very busy area. This is a must try place
author: Kevin S.

description: Amazing experience at Ebisu. Nigiri and rolls with the freshest cuts of fish I have ever tasted that melt in your mouth like butter. Sushi chef at the bar was so friendly and honored to serve us. Dining experience was the best I have had in the bay. If I'm ever in the area again I know I'll definitely be back.
author: Tay H.

description:
Always pass by this place thinking it'll be pricey, subpar and extra crowded Sushi. It was pricey & crowded but the sushi was actually better than expected. 

Visited here with my homeboy who loves rolls as opposed to fresh fish options like Sashimi or nigiri. The rolls, not my fave but did have a good flavor to them. 

Ordered Xxx roll, sunset roll, lobster tempura and my homie ordered a special extra extra (5x extra) spicy Tuna roll. Out of the rolls I'd have to say the Sunset was the best; I'm not one for fruit and stuff on sushi. The lobster tempura was cooked just right. Little flavorless but the spicy mayo gave it a nice taste. 

Also ordered Aji, Uni, Hamachi, Albacore and Ootoro. Each piece was good, presented great and tasted fresh. The Uni was my favorite.
author: John M.

description: This is my husband's & my favorite place to go for special occasions. Not only is the fish incredibly fresh and buttery, but the service is amazing. We love to sit at the sushi bar and interact directly with our sushi chef. The house sake is incredibly smooth and sweet, plus the oyster shooters are delicious every single time. Please come here if you love fresh sushi. You won't be disappointed!!!!!!!!
author: Melissa C.

description: I called and asked about a party of 10 with kids at 5pm, and the lady on the phone said, oh no problem, just come.  We walked in 10 minutes later, the hostess gave us the dirtiest and disgusting look! And said we only have 30 tables, so we cannot seat you!  WTH!
author: Sandra N.

description:
My favorite sushi restaurant in San Francisco. I think that in the city, this is the only place that has fish that's of a caliber similar to what you get fresh in Japan. I love their  sashimis: scallop, Uni, tai, amaebi, they have it all. 
Their sushi rolls are also really good. I especially like the 49er and the triple X rolls. The twist of lemon on the 49er really brings out the freshness of their salmon. 
The sushi chefs are also super friendly and if you sit at the bar you can strike up a conversation with them.
author: Heide K.

description: Yummm! Best sushi I've had by far. Small and cozy and the best hamachi toro I've ever had! Highly highly recommend.
author: K N.

description:
Came here for the first time a month ago to get our sushi fix. I really enjoyed the XXX roll. It had refreshing slices of mango on top! The dragon roll was also very yummy. I'm a sucker for shrimp tempera. The rolls aren't over stuffed with rice which may or may not be a good thin depending on what you like. Miso soup comes in those bowls with the lids to keep it hot throughout the meal. It wasn't too salty or had a powdery taste like most places. 

We also ordered oysters (not really a fan of slimey things so I had 1) and they were teeny tiny and quite expensive! My boyfriend and I were still hungry after two rolls, oysters, and soup so we decided to order another roll off the chef's special. Bad idea !!! I forgot what it was called but the fish was mushy ): 

The service was decent, but I think the cash register system broke down when we asked for our check. Maybe that's why it took 20 minutes to get our change back but overall good experience and will most likely come back for their other rolls.
author: Nancy C.

description:
I was close to giving this place 3-stars, but the food is too good.  High quality, great attention to detail, and delicious.

Only complaint is that I went alone and there was space at the bar, but instead of offering me a spot there, they made me wait.  A couple waltzed in and without asking was seated right away at the bar.  I went up there and asked to be seated at the bar and they obliged.  Still, it felt pretty awkward.
author: Andrew P.

description: Costumer service is horrible! After dining in Ebisu for many year, we where asked to leave at 9:30pm. We already paid our bill. I was showing a video of my kids to my cousin. We where about to leave in 5 min. A rude waitress came up and said we need to go because they have a lot of people waiting. We have waited patiently for 1h for our table. After my family and my friends spend a lot of money throughout so many years in this restaurant. They made it very clear that we are not welcomed there. They don't value long time costumers!  We are very  sad to leave this restaurant...  I will not tolerate disrespectful behavior after soooooooo many years of being a loyal customer!!!
author: Lidia A.

description:
The best raw fish in the US! 

Everything about my experience at Ebisu was flawless-- the Kobe beef skewers, any and all of the fish, some fantastic hand rolls, and a great mix of both traditional Japanese cuisine and interesting California concoctions. 

Would recommend 10/10 times.
author: Briana S.

description:
These were honestly the best Maki rolls we have ever had. We knew California had good sushi but this was just next level. 

We ordered the Louisiana hot link, the crunchy roll and the Spider roll. All three were very flavourful, tightly rolled, and didn't have so much sauce that it would overpower the combination of ingredients. The hot link roll somehow managed to taste like a real hot link. 
I even tasted real crab flavor when I bit into the Spider roll which I have never had happen before.

We had the lobster dynamite, a special written on the wall. The sauce was amazing but the lobster was a bit overcooked.

I would definitely come back for the Maki rolls.
author: Jam M.

description: My wife and I stopped in here for dinner by chance after a visit to Calacademy and we were blown away by the hospitality, quality and value. Sitting at the sushi bar and ordering omakase was truly a delight, and even the regulars were very welcoming. Next time, which I'm sure will be soon, I'll snap some pics :)
author: Bob I.

description: Excellent sushi and sushi with good service AND a nice atmosphere.  This was my third time here, and the food and service has been consistently top drawer.  Isn't that an old expression?  Really though, if you're in the mood for sushi, give Ebisu a try!
author: Frank S.

description:
Definitely a no frill, great food, japanese restaurant in SF. They have a good selection of rolls and appetizers, but most importantly, the fish and sashimi are always fresh. If you're able to get your hands on this, order the hamachi kama! So good. 

I would probably stay away from the noodles and stick to their sushi, nigiri, rolls, and sashimi here. Also, the sea bass or black cod hot appetizers was great. 

It does get crowded during dinner hours, so plan accordingly. The wait staff is great and very accommodating in making suggestion per your request. Probably not the best place for large parties, but a nice dining options for dates :)
author: Diane T.

description:
Ebisu is a San Francisco institution that is populated by both locals and visitors alike. If you live in the area, you've probably seen their commercials on tv or the small mob that forms outside the restaurant on weekends.

Ebisu is a solid sushi spot and probably the most reliable in the Sunset. It's not my favorite place as there aren't too many things on the menu that stand out, BUT I've been here half a dozen times and have never been disappointed with anything. The fish is always incredibly fresh and their Omakase sashimi is truly a work of art. I've never seen a more beautiful and creative presentation. And I love how they take away the shrimp head and bring it back all fried and crispy. Yum :) The bento boxes are also great if you want something filling and affordable. Definitely try the uni if you're a fan and the toro ain't too shabby either. 

The decor is earthy and modern with beautiful wood paneling and strikes the perfect balance between casual and intimate. The servers are all very friendly and if you snag a seat at the bar, the sushi chefs will strike up a conversation with you.

I have recommended Ebisu many times to friends who want quality sushi and a pleasant atmosphere. They're good for those new to Japanese food but also those who know what they're doing. The prices are slightly above average. Expect to spend about $30 a person in order to be full, but for the freshness and quality, it's worth it!
author: Deanna Y.

description:
Overpriced and slightly below average fish.

We ordered the omakase for 1-2, sukiyaki, and rainbow roll.

Normally when you think omakase, you think of chefs selection nigiri, but instead this place served sashimi "omakase". They might as well called it assorted sashimi platter. Regardless, I wanted to try the fish to see the quality. The fish arrived with generic fish samples like salmon, tuna, hamachi... Definitely not a chef's selection. The cut was terrible, uneven, and I had square pieces. This was a huge let down and though the price was $28 I felt like I overpayed for convenience store sashimi that I could've prepared myself.

The rainbow roll also had a ton of bones in the unagi and was surprisingly small. It was literally half the size of any dragon roll that I've ever had, about the same size as the tempura.

The sukiyaki was average.

In total I paid $76 for this meal and had way better quality sushi and food for $50-60 at Live Sushi, or Zushi puzzle in the city. Don't see how this place has 4 star reviews and long lines, perhaps the sunset has poor selection of Japanese food in general.
author: Gordon Z.

description:
I've been craving sushi for a while. But with the roommate's family owning a sushi restaurant, I tend to avoid dragging him out when I have sushi cravings. Since I was home alone, I decided to get sushi delivered for dinner. Postmates had sent me a $10 off coupon code, so I used them to order from Ebisu on Saturday, April 2nd. I placed the order at 5:18pm and it arrived at 6:32pm.

*Oysters Barnabi (1PC): 1/2 Shell oyster with uni, ikura, uzura and ponzu ($17)
*Sake Steamed Clams ($13.50)
*Omakase (sashimi): Chef's sashimi selection serves 1-2 person ($28)

I enjoyed the oysters barnabi very much. An oyster with uni, quail egg and ponzu? Yes please! But was it worth $17?! Absolutely not! Way too pricey for one oyster. Even if it does come with uni. The clams were actually a pretty good serving. I believe I got about 25 clams. But they were super tiny. Not much meat. The sauce it came in had great flavor, but I found it a touch too oily. The sashimi platter was okay. I got three small slices each of 10 varieties of fish. Not the freshest I've had, but okay at $28.

I had asked for an itemized receipt so I could see the prices of each item. There was something listed as a Special item: Box at $2.93, so I guess they charge extra for takeout items? I wasn't quite sure what that was for, but whatever. It was less than $3.

Okay place for sushi. I love their oyster barnabi, but they need to make the price more reasonable. Three stars overall.
author: Elena N.

description:
Came for lunch on a Saturday. Wasn't too crowded, but they have signs up in the waiting area that show that during peak times they have a decent line. 

Ordered the Dragon roll and a miso. I'm a sucker for flavorful miso and this one hit the spot. The Dragon roll was delicious with unagi, tempura and fresh, ripe avocado. All fantastic. Also had a chance to try my Mom's combo box. Decent veggie and shrimp tempura and delicious salmon teriyaki. 

All the fish was very fresh and the service was good. Average pricing. Will come back as this is one of my favorite neighborhoods.
author: Anna P.

description: Long wait and among the 10 dishes ordered, the only one that was great was the otoro.
author: agnes l.

description:
This place was great. Came here for my birthday with my boyfriend. Pretty small place, sat side by side with another table but that's SF I guess. We got miso soups, sake, a bunch of rolls and it was very good. The scallop roll was amazing. 

Will definitely be back when we're in the area. A little bit pricey but sushi usually is anyway.
author: Hayley D.

description:
My boyfriend and I always have the hardest time deciding on dinner and by the time we got super hungry and it was 9pmish, we took it to Yelp to see what would pop up. My boyfriend had me decide between Mokutunya and Ebisu and I chose Ebisu because I figured it'd be cheaper than the other place. Hopefully?

Ebisu is located on Irving St and it's on a pretty busy part of the street and parking is all on the streets and metered till 6pm. Because my boyfriend and I came here so late at night we were actually able to find parking on the same block so no hassle there. 

Ebisu looks small. Once you walk in, you're in a waiting room that has one table and 3 chairs. Odd. We walked up to the hostess table and luckily we didn't have to wait for a table either. The overall atmosphere and look of this restaurant was pretty nice. 

The menu itself is quite a read. There was a lot of options to choose from whether it was noodles, sushi, or appetizers. It took a while for my boyfriend and I to decide but eventually we got their deep fried calamari, sushi combo, spicy tuna roll, and I forgot the other thing my boyfriend got. Everything came out in a timely matter and it was all good. Price wise - it's pricey but it's also in San Francisco so I can't say I didn't see that coming.

Overall, come back? It's good, but I feel like we probably won't be back unless we're craving sushi hella late again. There are other more convenient places for us to go, but still good.
author: Venus L.

description:
Overall, my friends did not like this place.  My food was so-so, but I've definitely had better too.  Came here on a Saturday evening and the place wasn't too packed.  We waited a bit for a party of 8, but not as long as you might expect.  Maybe it was partly due to the rain that day.  The seating here is a bit tighter for a large party, but it worked out.  

I had the 49er roll and the Louisiana Hot Link roll just because I wanted to see if that roll lived up to it's name.  The 49er roll was about what I expected.  It hardly had any shiso inside like the roll claimed to have.  I always enjoy a roll with lemon and salmon.  The fish could have been fresher, it was borderline slimy.  The Louisiana Hot Link roll lived up to it's name surprisingly.  It hardly tasted like fish and moreso like meat.  It was an interesting experience, but I'd probably share this one if you're looking to try it.  It wasn't really a roll that I could handle much of, but it was sort of worth the try.  I saw some of my friends get the Omakase sashimi which I had been skeptic from ordering.  It wasn't worth the $28 price tag.  Most of the fish seemed like very small cuts, and it didn't seem too special at all.  

For a place that got a Michelin recommendation in 2014, the place doesn't seem like it has kept up with SF standards.  There are probably a handful of other restaurants you could get better sushi at now.  I wouldn't recommend coming here.
author: Bryson L.

description:
Pricy menu for fish in terms of what it is. 

The wait wasn't too long because we were willing to sit at the bar. I ordered the chirashi and while there was a decent amount of fish on the plate, the tuna didn't taste as great as I would have expected for the price. It had a slightly grainy texture. That being said, the presentation was pretty and the other fish tasted pretty good.

Service was great! We had 3 waitresses attending to our group of 3.
author: Brenda T.

description:
This used to be my absolute favorite restaurant growing up as a kid (yes, I was born and raised in SF!) I used to come here on my birthday every year with my mom as her treat. I always loved eating at Ebisu oved coming here - it was always something to look forward to! The interior wasn't so snazzy back in the day, but it remodeled a few years back and now has a beautiful modern interior.

I went here recently since we got a giftcard for Christmas. We ordered maybe 11-12 different nigiri, tempura, and a temaki to finish. Some of the fish we ordered were very fresh and nicely sliced - the toro, Ocean Trout, Red Snapper, Amaebi. However, there were some that were just average. I'd say about half the nigiri we ordered were excellent, and the other half just average. In the past when I came here, I think the sushi was at least 75-80% good cuts of fish! But I think they may be going downhill =(  Also, our bill came out to $180. Super crazy price considering the fish wasn't amazing across the board. It was pretty disappointing since I've grown up with this place. Overall, the sushi isn't HORRIBLE, but I can't say it's my favorite anymore. I'm hoping that this night was just an off-night.
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Highly recommend this restaurant. We started with Kobe beef and then moved on to sushi we had the sashimi special for 2 and 2 assorted rolls. You can not go wrong. We also had some hot sake which hit the spot on the cold evening.
author: Andrew M.

description: Been going to Ebisu for over 20 years. This place is always crowded for dinner and they normally do not take reservations. So either you arrive early for the first seating or expect to wait up to 1 hour or more. In its early days Ebisu was definitely the only game in the Irving side of town and one of the few good Japanese restaurants actually owned and managed by Japanese in the City. Now Japanese restaurants are all over town, but most are run by Chinese or Koreans. It's like there are almost no Italians left in N. Beach these days behind the Italian restaurants.  Despite the increased competition Ebisu remains one of the top goto restaurants in the City for sushi and Japanese cuisine over the years. That in and of itself is impressive as most restaurants do not last so long under the same owner. Fortunately there are now many more high quality Japanese restaurants in the City for those of us who no longer feel the need to wait in line. Even if the food is good , it's no longer worth the wait when there are other choices now. For me It is more enjoyable to do lunch at Ebisu. The food is the same, entrees are slightly cheaper, more specials during lunch and better access to a table or bar seating, and you can have a normal conversation without the noise in the evening. Chirashi is a good deal for lunch. The fresh live uni and scallops are always delicious when available. All the nigiri sushi selections are always fresh and the fish sliced consistently to a thickness that goes well with the rice. The rice is one of the things that distinguishes this and any other Japanese restaurant in my opinion. Here the sushi rice is usually well prepared with the right level of starch and vinegar content and the texture of each grain of rice can be individually appreciated. Most run of the mill joints run by Chinese or Koreans don't serve authentic sushi rice. As for rolls, Ebisu is one of the originals in town. One can't go wrong with any of their rolls. My understanding is that rolls, other than Tekka and cucumber wrapped in nori, however, are not indigenous to Japanese sushi cuisine but invented here like pizza or burritos. You will not find rolls in a real Japanese restaurant in Japan. Thank goodness for the evolution of rolls, however, as they are beginning to catch on in Japan. Ebisu makes some of the best originals and new ones keep coming over the years. I would probably give Ebisu 5 stars for being around  for so long and maintaining consistent quality over the years, but the long dinner wait generated by the hype in general takes one star off in terms of overall dining experience.
author: Giovani T.

description:
Food tastes okay here but for a rather high price at small quantities. This is what we ordered for three people.

Omakese for 1-2 people: slices were cut thin
49er roll: average and on the small side
Family affair: the tastiest roll/favored food of the night

Bill came out to $55. Instead of spending an additional $30-$40 for more food, we decided to walk down to San tung.

Overall, I left feeling a little salty over the entire experience. I feel like I'd rather spend $25 at sushi zone for two tasty mango rolls.
author: Mimi T.

description:
For a place that does gangbuster business, practically a line out the door, Ebisu serves less than stellar sushi. It's like kids in years past along with their parents went crazy during Christmas for a Talking Elmo or a Cabbage Patch Kid and in the end, you probably ended up looking at that must-have toy and were like: "Why the hell did I want this so bad". 

So that was my experience. I waited about 35 or 40 minutes to be seated only to get below average sushi in a tiny hole in the wall restaurant. I ordered the:

Ebisu Sushi combo: it came with 10 pieces of nigiri and maki. The quality of fish was low, rice was cold and hard. The price was $26 and I can see why the prices are fairly low, the quality isn't there.

Dragon roll: the unagi along with the other ingredients were sparsely added. One of the worst drag on rolls I've eaten and I've eaten a lot.

The service was fine despite the long wait which they can't control. But I don't know who to blame for the food at Ebisu, the sushi chef? The owner? Trump? Obama? But whoever is responsible for this poor quality sushi at Ebisu with its legions of novice sushi enthusiasts. The sushi and Talking Elmo had their day, it's time to move on.
author: Michael L.

description:
Excellent sushi and wonderful service from Chef Eric! 
Will be recommending to friends and will be undoubtably visiting again.
author: Erin F.

description:
I was really torn whether to give this place 3 or 4 stars, I'd probably give this place a 3.6 rating so I guess it's closer to 4 stars.  Today we got a chance to try this place due to the fact that there was no wait (it's a Wednesday night if you're wondering). 

Anyhow, once seated I ordered the makese ( the $50 one that's supposed to feed 3-4 people) which I split with a friend, my fiance got the grilled mackerel, we also got a spicy tuna roll, an alaskan roll, an appetizer made out of baked salmon and scalop, and a tempura shrimp handroll.  
Soooo the quality on the makese sashimi was above avarage, I wouldn't say superb but definitely above avarage, the frustrating thing about the makese was the fact that it said it's good for 3-4 people, psh yea right (2 of us split it) we were still hungry after we finished it so we ordered more smh.  As far as the rolls go, the fish quality was good but the roll itself fell apart and it wasn't a fluke they all did.

Would I come back here?  Mmmm maybe to try a chirashi, however I definitely feel this place is somewhat overpriced.
author: Josh Giosue D.
