description: We heard this restaurant was good from family. It definitely lived up to and exceeded expectations! All of the rolls and nagiri were very delicious. Favorites included Family Affair, Romeo and Juliet, XXX roll, and Kobe beef nagiri.
author: Jen S.

description: We went here for lunch on our visit to SF. We waited about an hour to get a table for 6. I ordered sashimi and rolls. The sashimi was very fresh and delicious. It was a very busy restaurant so the service wasn't as good as other restaurants. They did the best they can. I recommend coming there when it's just opened if you don't want to wait.
author: Charles N.

description:
I write to offer an enthusiastic recommendation. I do so because this is not my go-to place. We live in the neighborhood. My wife and I eat Japanese food at least once a week.

So why not Ebisu? It has great food, very good service, and the ambiance/buzz you'd want for a first date or to impress someone on any occasion. 

It's just more high end than I'm looking for. That's a compliment, basically. It's at a level you could imagine -- and people do -- come to this area just to eat here. The places we prefer are more local; you probably wouldn't drive to get there.

Anyway, Ebisu is probably the single best Japanese restaurant in the Inner Sunset. That would be a consensus opinion. I do eat here for lunch, because the other options at that time are clearly a full level below Ebisu. If I were dating, I'd come here for dinner.
author: Frank W.

description: Favorite Japanese restaurant in the city!! They have everything from udon to bento boxes to sashimi-- all amazing quality and absolutely delicious. Mmmmmm
author: Joline F.

description:
One of the best sushi restaurants in SF. My bf use to hate sushi-he's tried it many times from different places, but for some reason started eating it after I took him here. There is always a long wait on the weekends, so be prepared for a wait. I usually come here during slower hours because I don't like to wait to eat.

This place is amazing. Great quality sushi for an affordable price. My go to sushi spot in the city. I would definitely go out of my way to come to this place.

I've tried everything here from the rolls to the bento boxes to the Chirashi bowls. Their steamed sake mussels is a must try as well. It's really good! You can't go wrong with anything off the menu.

Will be back again and again.
author: Jessica S.

description: My favorite hangout for sushi and Japanese cuisine.  Always fresh, always festive.  Service very good.
author: R C.

description: Pretty good (considering this is cheap for sushi in SF). Plating wasn't (some of the sushi looked kinda messy) but it was still really yummy.
author: Connie H.

description: I would give 5 stars if the service had not been so bad. So much pressure to leave before we even finished eating. The food itself was fresh. I had a tuna don buri lunch. The fish melted in my mouth, excellent consistency and quality. Love the food but disliked the service.
author: Lauren K.

description:
Good god, loved this place last Monday. There was a wait with a few couples in front of us, however we got a table extremely fast.
We ordered the sashimi bonito tataki with skipjack and ponzu.... I HAVE BEEN CRAVING IT EVER SINCE! It was fantastic. We got the crunchy roll with a soybean wrap, not basic and plain like you'd think, extremely good. Also got the "behind the green door roll" not actually all that tasty. Oh and we got a hand roll, super good. 
By the way the service is OUTSTANDING. Don't listen to the bouje, enjoy this little neighborhood restaurant.
author: Allison C.

description: By far my favorite place for sushi in the city. The quality of the food here is on par with places around town that cost way more.The fact that their prices are reasonable makes this place a great value. It's in a small place in the inner sunset but definitely worth the wait. The service here is good, the wait staff typically are running around the place because its usually busy but I've never had any issues. If you get a chance I'd recommend sitting at the bar with the sushi chefs, they always provide excellent service and can really direct you to the best fish they have for that day. They serve other Japanese dishes which aren't that bad but if you're coming here stick to the sushi and you won't be disappointed. Most of the rolls here are on par with other places in terms of creativity, variety, and size. My recommendation is to get the nigiri. They have an extensive list of fish which are always of high quality and be sure to ask about the specials of the day which can really be a bright spot. My favorites are the sake toro (salmon belly), unagi (eel), otoro, and waygu. The sake toro and otoro just melts if your mouth. The unagi is cooked just right with the perfect balance of sauce. The waygu which I don't see everywhere was something I tried on a whim was a pleasant surprise and is one of my favorites as an interesting change of place to regular sushi, wagyu itself melts and tastes amazing but definitely different from sushi. I haven't had any sushi or rolls here that I didn't like and for the prices they charge you'll want to come back for more.
author: Peter P.

description:
Small japanese restaurant, solid sushi, great service. 

I'm particular about sushi, I like to be able to eat them in one bite. I hate when you have to bite it, the whole thing just falls apart! That being said, the rolls here are the right size, fits perfectly in my mouth. 

Sashimi is fresh. They have a XXX roll, which is their roll of the day. Today's roll was a spicy tuna roll with mango, avocado and salmon sashimi on the outside. I loved the mango! Something about fruit and fish does it for me. 

Sukiyaki: Love soupy things and this hit the spot. Lots of thin slices of beef and tofu. Drown your rice with the broth. It can get a little salty as most sukiyakis do. 

Next time I should try out the gyoza....all three people sitting on the table next to us ordered an individual plate for themselves. Must be really good...
author: Jen P.

description: Absolutely love this place! Everything melts in your mouth. You can immediately taste the quality of food. Highly recommend
author: Clara L.

description:
I've never had such an experience before... Let me fill you in :)

Despite the wait, my friends and I were able to get the much coveted seats at the bar. We also enjoyed quick and attentive service from both the sushi chefs and the waiters. Everyone is so friendly here! My friend recommended a lot of dishes to try out because she's been to the place many times before.

We started off with the Hamachi Toro, the Salmon Toro, and the Monkfish Liver. WOW. The Hamachi Toro was my favorite of the night, because it was such a smooth texture and fresh flavor. I felt like my mind was blown, it was so good, like I've never had anything like it. Mind you, I've had my fair share of rolls and just begun my Chirashi mission at Japanese restaurants...

The monkfish liver was by far something that surprised me. My friend described this dish to me as something like foie gras, but from monkfish. It tasted like caviar! With a super subtle hint of lemon as well. I would order this again! 

We also got mussels, which were good as well, and it came out as a soup, and there are so many mussels! WORTH. The broth was also very flavorful, a bit of spice to it but not overpowering at all, very well seasoned.

We got a couple more dishes as well, but I unfortunately can't remember their names :( But let me tell you, it's so refreshing to find such a gem. I haven't ventured out to the Sunset area too much, but I will definitely be returning again! 

I'll be dreaming of that Hamachi Toro, yum!!
author: Amanda L.

description:
Ebisu is a great Japanese restaurant located conveniently in the inner sunset district of SF. Came here with my family a few times.

The quality of the sushi rolls is pretty good but a bit small for the price. I personally found the 49ers and Romeo&Juliet rolls my favorites - the salmon is very fresh. Also highly recommend the Kobe beef skewer. Not sure if it is actually Kobe beef (as I have tried that in Japan), but nevertheless, still very savory!

For set menus, I highly recommend the shioyaki saba -- the mackerel is so juicy and tender, and salted to perfection. It comes with a large portion of salad, broccolini, carrots, and potatoes.

Lines can get pretty long, so recommend that you try to visit during non-peak hours.
author: Alvin W.

description: I called in to order a rainbow roll to-go, and the lady said that it would take 20 minutes. After 20 mins I walked to go pick it up just to find out that they didn't even get my order down. I kept asking the lady at the cash register  how long it would take, and I was completely ignored. I got my food after waiting another 15 minutes. On the other hand, the fish was fresh and tasted good. Definitely come to eat in instead of getting to-go.
author: Andrea K.

description:
Let me first start off by saying that every sushi aficionado is entitled to his/her opinion on what the best sushi place is...

That said, I have found incontrovertible proof that, in my honest opinion, Ebisu is perhaps the best sushi experience I have had thus far. To make things short and simple, here are my 7 paths to Nirvana that I experienced.

# Path 1: First Impressions
Because of budget constraints, I have never really taken the time to explore fancy sushi restaurants, so I am not well versed in the vibe of what a true sushi bar looks like. But stepping into Ebisu, I felt like I was in another world. Immediately after you step across the lavender curtains, you will feel like you have crossed into another part of SF that you have never seen before. On top of the aroma of tempura and the lovely interior decor (i think they recently remodeled), I felt right at home. 

The menu is very lengthy and exquisite. Don't be turned off by the prices (it's not that bad), and but be turned ON by the wide selection of sashimi, rolls, appetizers, etc. After a long debate with my friend, we ordered the Okasame, Toro (albacore belly), Family Affair, and Romeo and Juliet. Now, here goes...

# Path 2: Okasame. 
In Japanese, Okasame means "I'll leave it to you," which is a fine and beautiful name. The Okasame, is basically a chef's selection of sashimi for you and possibly another person to eat. My friend and I got the $25 one, which included, halibut, skipjack, escolar, tuna, salmon, hamachi (I think that's all?). It's definitely safe to say that each one had its one unique, fresh, flavor that I have never experienced before at any sushi bar/ restaurant. The hamachi and escolar in particular were very fatty and mouthwateringly delicious (melts in your mouth).

# Path 3: Toro
OMY, THIS IS THE ONE. Even though this one was a bit pricy, YOU HAVE TO GET THIS ONE. Sometimes it's not offered or they're out, but ask! The taste, texture, and everything in between is too hard to describe, so please do yourself a favor and check it. You get two pieces, so share with a friend!

# Path 4: Family Affair
First of all, I usually don't get rolls (yuck, California), but the descriptions on Ebisu's menu, on top of their fancy names, caught my eye. The Family Affair -Tuna, Avocado, Albacore, Maui Onions, Negi,Tobiko and Spicy Aioli- was definitely something I have never experienced before. So many flavors in one!!!

# Path 5: Romeo and Juliet
Can it get better? YES. Romeo and Juliet-Scallop, Salmon, Avocado, Tobiko and Japanese Mayo- definitely stole the show for us. With every mouthwatering bite, you not only taste the soft, fatty, texture of the salmon, but you also experience the chewy goodness of scallop. That... plus the mayo! 

# Path 6: The Atmosphere
If you ever have the opportunity to sit at the sushi bar, make like Shia Labeauf and DO IT. I had my initial hesitations about sitting at the bar (less quiet), but it's safe to say we had a blast. Our chef (forgot his name :( ) was so funny, kind, and everything in between. He answered any questions that we had and made our time a memorable one! And next to us was a funny drunk couple who was served by Sazuki, apparently a sushi chef who rivals that of Jiro. We're definitely checking him out next time. 

# Path 7: The generosity. 
However, what really made our experience was the generosity and kindness of our chef. Seeing that we were curious about a lot of the items, he generously let us try some! For example, we got to sample this roll (i forgot the name omg) but best yet, he let us try Sazuki's famous kobe beef. Even though we only had a small slice, I think I was in heaven haha.

Overall, this place is THE PLACE that I have been looking forward to. Maybe you have found better, but I honestly had a blast and felt really bad leaving. In the end, the total was about 69 (add another 13 or so for tip), which was a lot less than my WTP (I was thinking it'd be 100). But check this out yourself.

Eat well and prosper my friends,
author: Bryan W.

description:
My to-go order was wrong and I was overcharged, only realizing this once I got home. On top of this they took 40min to bring the food when the receptionist said it would only be 15 minutes (and somehow they took another 10 minutes just to process my card). When I called to rectify the issue the lady over the phone was very inconsiderate as well. Highly recommend avoiding this restaurant until they get their act together.

-They have a new payment system that lead to a lot of frustrations. They were understanding in the end and provided a full refund. The food here is very good if not for the issues mentioned above.
author: Ed L.

description: What a gem. Nigiri sushi was fresh and authentic. One of the better bento boxes I have had (Combo A and B were both ordered at our table and very satisfied).
author: Alex B.

description: The sushi was very fresh but the lobster tempura was yummy and didn't need the tempura sauce. The teriyaki steak was tender but they could of added a little more teriyaki sauce to make it perfect for my taste.
author: Edgar P.

description: Fell short for me: Service and staff were friendly and great. Nigiri and sushi rolls had a little too much rice and rolls were loosely made. Very extensive menu, felt like I was reading a book. Liked the shiso touch in some of the rolls. I always see a line, glad I tried it, now my curiosity is gone. I'm sticking to my other sushi places like Saru and Daigo.
author: Sarah T.

description:
Two years after my first visit, Ebisu continues to be fantastic.

After parking in the street, I wandered in at 11:30 AM when things weren't too busy yet and got a table without a reservation.  Score!  Sipped on some very hot tea and decided to order the sake toro nigiri, the aji nigiri, the double hamachi, and for old times' sake, the 49er. 

Every single piece of sushi was incredibly delicious, with fish that just melted in my mouth. The sake toro was fatty and satisfying, and the lemon and salmon combination of the 49er was very refreshing.  I clearly remember thinking, oh my god, this is what sushi should be like all the time, and my boyfriend said that Ebisu had effectively ruined other sushi for him. 

Overall, a must-visit for any sushi enthusiasts in San Francisco.
author: Emily Y.

description: Love this place.  Great atmosphere.  Enjoyable conversation at the sushi bar.  And the best fish in San Francisco.
author: Noah W.

description: Wow. Visiting friends and had this as our first meal in San Fransisco. We are from Baltimore,  MD and LOVE sushi ... but this BLEW US AWAY. We sat at the sushi bar, and Tom was AMAZING.  Wonderfully fresh fish, and ordered a few "chefs special rolls" - totally worth it. I told him what him what I liked, and if I could dream up a sushi roll ... he created it. Were only in town for a week, but will definitely be back before we leave. I cabt recommend this place enough.
author: Ally L.

description: fantastic service, great atmosphere, the owner is often, if not always behind the sushi bar preparing food himself. Everyone is very personable, and the portions are generous.
author: Justin Y.

description: This is my go to sushi place in SF. fresh fish and friendly staff. I always go for the Omakase. I would suggest in order to avoid the line up, which is always huge, you should go during lunch time and close to their closing time.
author: Lawrence L.

description:
I'm coming here again.

As you enter underneath some blinds, you enter a sleek, Japanese decor with wooden tables and a long Sushi bar. Multiple sushi chefs behind the counter, and you see an elder Japanese sushi master joking with patrons... You know you got to be in for some good fish. Chalk board behind the chef shows their fishes of the day and their specials. 

Service is friendly and quick. A little crammed in terms of table space, but that's OK, it means they can fit more people in, and you'll probably get seated faster.

For rolls: had the poke, family affair, chef's special, louisiana hotlink
Nigiri: Sake Toro Salmon Belly
Appe: Kakuni

Everything was excellent, fish tasted fresh and of high caliber. As they say on the menu, these guys are legit. The chefs are trained superbly, and know the right amounts and combination of ingredients to place in everything. They even tell you to dip the fish in the soy sauce, not the rice. If that isn't legit, I don't know what is.

Favorite roll that we had: Family Affair.

If you want extra indulgence, you gotta do the kakuni. Awwwww so tender. The sweet potato puree adds the right balance to the fatty kakanu.

In summary, I'm coming here again.  And you should too.
author: Edward L.

description: Absolute favorite sushi place in SF! Fish is always fresh and yammy. The creativity of their work makes the dishes look even more delicious.
author: Alisa G.

description:
Hamachi & Tamago nigiri that exceeded my expectations.   Those are my sushi benchmarks and  Ebisu delivered!   I also appreciate some anago, which isn't always easy to find (back East at least).  My dining partner had me try Toro for the first time.  The "fatty" in its name never really appealed to me, but it was melt in your mouth.   I would say stick with the traditional nigiri, sashimi or chirashi for best experience.   Amazingly fresh fish.   

No reservations & they won't seat you until everyone in your party is arrived.  Get there timely to avoid a wait.
author: Sophia I.

description: Overrated sushi restaurant. The ootoro nigiri ($18) was tiny compared to other competitive restaurants, did not taste very fresh, and was cut into little squares! What a joke. The sushi rice on some of my other nigiri pieces were also quick to fall apart when picked up with my chopsticks- definitely a no-no for such a highly rated sushi spot. The hamachi kama was super dry and needed to constantly be dipped in its accompanying sauce to be edible. Additionally, with the restaurant closing earlier than their 11pm posted time, we were rushed to order any additional items before the kitchen closed. The servers became sloppy and looked like they just wanted to get out of there and go home. They were also busy just chatting amongst one another. Due to the time crunch, I was unable to order any dessert, and the server didn't bother to ask me. It was only after the fact that they told me that it was now too late to order dessert. Geez! Plus, the server forgot to pack some of my leftovers as I had requested. Overall, sloppy sloppy sloppy. There are truly better sushi restaurants to spend your $$ at in San Francisco. Most of the patrons there looked like they were neighborhood locals. Makes sense. Won't be coming back.
author: Phan ..

description: One of my favorite lunch spots. Best bento in #sf. Going to miss coming here for a healthy happy lunch reward. It's a complete bento lunch, with perfect miso, great salad and even grilled veggies. So #fresh. Some of the best uni, toro, Saba. A couple of awesome rolls and a great dinner spot too. But it's the bento that pulls me in regularly. Will visit more when I get back here.
author: Chris H.

description:
5 stars for the good food. Recommend the gyudon for lunch. Veggie rolls are delicious. Kids enjoyed their udon but I don't understand why they can't add wakame to it if I'm willing to pay for it. 


1 star for service. I ordered to go and my server was not friendly. Also, they added 1.25 as a to go box fee which I've never encountered before (tourist tax??). 

I live close enough so I haven't ruled out going again if I'm on this side of the park and craving sushi. I refuse to pay the to go fee when other yummy places nearby don't do that so it would be for sit-down only.
author: Hanster P.

description: I used to think that Ebisu was one of the best Japanese restaurants in the city but now it seems like their cutting corners in the freshness and overall quality in the food. Ebisu was my wife's and I go to spot for Japanese food period. The last few times we went we were both very disappointed with the food. The salmon and eel nigiri (I always order those 2) weren't fresh. The regular California roll used to be made with real crab but now it's made with imitation crab. At first we thought it was an isolated incident but the 2nd and 3rd time we knew Ebisu are cutting corners at the cost of quality. Unfortunately i regret to say we're not going here again.
author: Raymond M.

description:
This place gets SUPER busy...and they usually only seat you if your whole party is there. Even on a weekday with a table of two, I've had to wait 30 minutes. The place itself is pretty small with table as well as a bar to eat at. Most of the time the tables are almost right next to each other and you can basically hear the other person's conversation...and getting out / maneuvering around the people and tables can be a bit stressful.

Food wise, the fish is always so fresh and the rolls are delicious. Pretty good alcohol menu. The service is decent but I do feel like they want you in and out of the place.
author: Allison S.

description:
Food great. Trying to get a gift card is like dealing with a third world country. Terrible customer serv
However, Charlie was most helpful in correcting this. Everyone else needs to be trained
author: Martin A.

description:
Solid sushi,  I have been here twice for lunch, and wasn't disappointed either time.  I think I got the chirashi both times.  They also have bento boxes,
Nigiri, and rolls.  I got a couple of pieces of nigiri and a friend got a rainbow roll, and those were good also.
author: Joshua G.

description: Their wait time estimate is NOT accurate at all. And we waited until a number of 4-people to be seated and then gave us a 4-seater table for 6 of us. This is ridiculous. Nothing can justify such a horrible service! Not coming back again!
author: Becky B.

description: Excellent Japanese restaurant that has Japanese folks who work there.  The service is excellent and the food quality is great.  This is a popular place, so consider reservation or a short wait for table at dinner time.
author: Thomas P. L.

description:
Not too impressed. I've been wanting to go here for a while since it's near my house and there is always a line to get in. Finally went last night and probably won't be back. The waitress accidentally gave us an appetizer that the table next to us had ordered. Without paying attention, we thought it was what we had ordered so we started eating it. Once the waitress realized the mistake and told us, we were halfway finished with it. She apologized, and we still got our other appetizer. To our surprise, we were still charged for both - the one we ordered, and the one mistakenly given to us.

We ordered the XXX roll, Louisiana Hot Link, and something else that wasn't too great. We were very disappointed by the Louisiana Hot Link. It was a unique sounding roll, and was uninspiring. I thought the XXX roll tasted good; however, my girlfriend didn't think the fish tasted fresh.

Overall, the service was decent and food was mediocre. I've definitely had much better sushi in the city, and expected a lot more. Definitely not worth the line to get in, but if there isn't a line it's not a bad place
author: Tyler B.

description:
Finally! Fantastic sashimi!!!!

Every piece was wonderfully fresh and delicious. I worked my way through each fish and picked a favorite. The next time through I had a different favorite. And yet again the third time through. Each and every fish on the plate was fantastic. And for the first time I did not mix the wasabi in the soy sauce. Instead I placed a small dab on each piece before eating. 

Seriously, the sashimi was so delectable it needed nothing. Soy sauce wasn't necessary. 

Parking is very difficult, but the location is great. Just outside Golden Gate Park, so arrive early, find a great spot in the park and enjoy nature for a while. Then take a walk to Ebisu and have a memorable meal.
author: Scott N.

description:
My favorite sushi in SF - great value and fantastic sushi. My go-to orders are the seafood salad (chopped raw fish with bamboo shoots and yummy dressing), family affair roll (has amazing maui onions on top), and the go giants roll (spicy scallop!) 

I highly recommend sitting at the sushi bar and talking with the sushi chef to learn what fish is especially fresh or good that day. I have had some great experiences just telling the sushi chef to make me something good - high risk, high reward. 

Go preparing for a wait, especially if you are more than two people. I usually put my name in, go for a happy hour drink, and then hop back in the queue.
author: Tory C.

description:
Came here with my wife and two kids last Tuesday evening. Overall the sushi and sashimi was very good. A bit pricey for the portion but that's not the reason for the 3 star ratings here. 

Now keep in mind that this was a Tuesday night. We arrive at 645 and the place was pretty busy but not packed to where the waiting list was crazy. We waited an hour to get a table of four and it was just mind boggling how so many party of twos were sat in front of us. There was even a couple who arrived after us... They finished eating and left before we were even seated. I just think that it wasn't difficult at all for them to put two tables together and form one for four. Pretty bad accommodation when you have us waiting for an hour while you sit every couple that came in after us!!!! I guess they make more money that way...

Nonetheless service was quick after we got a table and food was good. We spent our $200 bucks there and are pretty certain we wouldn't go back a 2nd time. This is an ideal place to go on a date for two I guess.
author: Choy S.

description: The quality of fish is A+ and consistently delish every time we go for the last 10yrs.
author: Miriam B.

description: This popular sushi restaurant in inner sunset is always packed! They have a fun long sushi counter that turns seats quickly. Their sushi is always fresh, with friendly service, plenty of alternative food choices like hot/cold appetizers and sushi rolls! The restaurant isn't very large so it's harder to do big groups, but I enjoy the loud atmosphere and hyped up vibe when dining at this restaurant with people enjoying their meals. I love ordering from their fresh fish of the day menu, from toro to scallops to basic rolls, the sushi chefs are consistent on their plating. Check this place out when you're craving excellent sushi after an enjoyable day at Golden Gate park!
author: SF Diner A.

description:
the food was great ! the rolls was ok. The apps were to die for. I would go there but expect a wait. 

I had such a Blast.
author: Abdul M.

description: Amazing food! Small place, but totally worth it even if you have to wait for a table!
author: Diana B.

description:
So I actually never write reviews on yelp but definitely always read them.  This experience, however, warranted taking the time to share my thoughts.  I'd been to Ebisu for sushi once prior to my last visit and thought the sushi was great.  I went for the second time on Saturday and the experience was quite different.  While seated at the sushi bar I saw a cockroach crawling along the bar.  Our waitress just killed the roach in our presence and acted like it was no big deal.  She didn't seem concerned. In fact, her lack of concern indicated to me it was not the first time with these creepy crawlers...at the sushi bar! 

Having witnessed an insect crawling next to an area where food is located reflected poorly on the sanitation and cleanliness of this restaurant.  The unprofessional reaction only made things worse.
author: Maggiebui B.

description:
I've lived around the block for years and just always passed this place by because I hate waiting. However, this time I decided to come and put my name down and just wait because I'm a good friend. And then they immediately called my name and oops my friend was like 30 minutes out. I think if you're flexible with seating and come in a small group, 2-4, you'll get a table quickly.

We splurged on a bottle of sake, some sashimi obviously and it was pretty fantastic. They have a pretty big menu, so if you want miso cod, etc. they can def make your dreams come true too. Also, I saw o-toro on the specials menu..... $18 I believe they said for the nigiri.

Friendly, effortless service, which is amazing considering how busy this place is. On the pricier side, but it's worth a splurge sometimes especially when your friend decides he's going to take you out for flaking on you the other night. :D
author: Vivian H.

description: Went here for a friend's birthday dinner, and it was pretty good. There flavors weren't much more unique than other restaurants though, and it was on the pricer side. We had to wait 45 mins to get a seat, but it was worth trying at least once.
author: I K.

description: Live Scallops.... So Good! Best Sushi in the city!!! The wait is long but very worth it! Service was great also!
author: Carlos F.

description: Stumbled to this restaurant because we wanted to eat at the isakaya down the street.They were closed Yelped and found this place.The wait was 1 hour and met some nice people while waiting.I have to say the wait was well worth it.We ordered the Combo bento boxes AB and C. Everything was so fresh and good portions.Worth the 1 hour drive to get there from the East Bay!
author: Barbara C.

description: You're going to wait a long time to eat here but once you get in you won't regret it. The food is delicious and varied. The service is also attentive and superb. I ordered dinner combo 2 which came with beautiful presentation in a bento box. It is fairly expensive but worth the experience.
author: Sterling H.

description:
Takeout Order - Ordered 4 rolls, and 3 of the 4 were completely falling apart as we picked them up.  Very poorly rolled and difficult to eat.  Also ordered unagi nigiri and it looked and smelled gross and well past its prime.  We decided it didn't seem safe to eat (lost money on that, because we ordered takeout).  Ordered a side of spicy mayo, and rather than a nice homemade sauce, they just squirted a bit of sriracha and a bit of mayo into a cup and didn't bother to mix it up.  On the bright side, the edamame trio was decent.  Bottom line: if we had dined in house, we would've sent back at LEAST 2 of the items we ordered.  

This was a one star experience this time, but I'm giving two stars because the previous dine-in visits were more successful.
author: Stephanie F.

description: After finally trying EBISU - now all the other japanese restaurants in my list pale in comparison. Yes, even after waiting an hour to get seated...it's really as good as it gets!
author: Jackie A.

description:
HUH??? Why is this place rated so highly? I'm disappointed, SF yelpers!!

I got a good variety from the menu and each item was mediocre at best. The sushi rolls were minuscule with barely any fish and mushy rice. It tasted like rolls from an AYCE sushi buffet place.
We got ankimo (monk fish liver) and it was crumbly. We order ankimo often and Ebisu's quality was quite bad. It needs to be like pate: creamy and flavorful. This was definitely not it.
Ordered the hamachi collar. You canNOT overcook this baby, it needs to be just right to capture the buttery, softness of the meat. We got a tough, seemingly days old product that tasted like something from a chain restaurant.
Got the unagi don. Holy jamoly, the unagi was oversauced, mushy, and BLEHHHHH. The rice was mushy too -- how do you screw up rice?!
Same with the edamame , seemed old and mushy -- how do you screw up edamame?!

All of this mediocrity cost us close to $90...wtf.
So sad to have wasted my trip to SF on my day off here.
Also, it's nice that the sushi chefs are light-hearted and have fun but at certain times, their jokes and rowdiness were at the brink of unprofessionalism. One of the sushi chefs was claiming loudly, almost in a proud manner, that they were still waiting for their fish delivery and trying to get rid of their older fish. He was also eating pieces of sashimi in front of us as well as tossing pieces of fish to the other sushi chef across the bar.

Not coming back.
author: Sharon C.

description: The nigiri was to die for - super fresh and good rice. I ordered agadashi tofu and lobster tempura however and it was plain gross. The tempura batter was heavy and super greasy. When I asked to return it the plate left with the server who returned a few minutes later saying that I could take it to go if I wanted, but I ordered it so I have to pay for it. It's a shame because I would have liked this place to be a regular spot for me. I will never be returning however.
author: Becca B.

description:
Fast service and really fresh sushi. Best sushi that we had during our time in San Francisco. 

The wait was about 45 minutes but it was well worth the wait!
author: Will P.

description: Went for lunch. Had oyakodon and some nigiri. The oyakodon was mostly dry and flavorless-- worst I've ever had. The chicken was hard like from some gas station salad. If there was any dashi, I couldnt taste it. The nigiri was fine. Slow service, but nice server.
author: Antonio F.

description: Came here for a weekday lunch, and the place was packed. The wait time was longer than expected, but the food was worth it. I tried the Sake Steamed Clams, one of their hot appetizers, and really enjoyed its strong, buttery flavor. The clams themselves had a great chewy texture. I also ordered their Combo 2 bento box which comes with a variety of tempura, maki sushi (standard roll-like sushi pieces), maguro sushi (tuna sashimi), salad, rice, miso soup, and a mini seaweed mountain (?). The tempura was freshly fried, perfectly crispy on the outside and the veggies/shrimp/yams thoroughly cooked on the inside. The maki rolls and maguro sashimi were just okay. I would recommend trying another bento combo, maybe one of the teriyaki ones. They also allow substitutions with some of their items in the combo, for instance all California rolls for your maki sushi. A surprisingly nice ambiance inside, with attentive service.
author: Natalie L.

description: 5 star lunch...if your in the mood to spend a little extra for lunch check out ebisu.. there fresh fish definitely hits the spot,check out the special menu
author: jonathan h.

description: Really great sushi place. It was very busy but our wait was not too long, and the service was good. Every dish we ordered was excellent. The poke had generous servings of raw fish, the uni was very fresh (so good!), and I enjoyed my first experience eating Ankimo (monk fish liver). Every dish is plated and presented beautifully, both a joy to look at and eat. Highly recommended, I'll visit again for sure when I'm back in SF.
author: Tracy C.

description: Each dish was amazing! So glad we got the last hamachi kama they were serving that night because it was grilled to perfection and the lobster dynamite was full of buttery deciousness
author: Xavier W.

description:
Very good lunch here yesterday.

Had a craving for sushi and my lady and I wanted to go somewhere in the Sunset. We found this place in my bookmarks on Yelp and made our way here. As you walk in you can't help but notice the flying purple strips around the entrance of the door. Just a nice touch.

As you walk in there are a few paintings on the wall. Seating very prompt. There is a counter just as you turn left in entering. The tables are nicely laid on inside. You have a choice of sitting at a table or near the sushi bar. The first thing I noticed was all the fish being cooked and the aroma of spices. This is a familiar smell for those who eat a lot of sushi or go to a lot of sushi restaurants. 

The waitresses here are very nice. They can answer all questions about the menu and the different types of sushi. I know my sushi pretty well but everyone once in awhile I see new sushi rolls on the menu. But, on this day I let the lady order the food. She likes sushi a lot and it was my TREAT so why not order what you want. She was pleased with that.

I think we wound up getting 3 or 4 items from off of the menu. She was very excited to be here. I think she had heard about this place from one her co-workers. 

The meal was exquisite. Just enough portions to fill both appetites. 

Great time, great service, and even better meal. Thank you to everyone that worked on 8/28/15.
author: Robert F.

description:
Nice ambiance in here. Was able to find parking on the street easily, but it was a rainy day so I'd imagine it may be more difficult typically around lunch time.

The service was not really friendly, but it was quick.

We all got bento boxes which provided a variety and plenty of food for each person. The sushi is not exceptional but it was good and the meats and veggies were done well.
author: Susan G.

description: Great interior decor. However, I don't think our Nov 2017 experience is as yummy as the first time I ate here in March 2015.
author: Cynthia L.

description: This place is amazing for fresh sushi. They have a board behind the chefs showing what fresh sushi/sashimi they have for the day. I believe I got the salmon belly last time and I was blown away. Service is great and I would definitely recommend trying to sit at the bar. I love watching the chefs work and how they can maneuver with being so busy!
author: Nicole N.

description:
2 blocks away from my school and I have been coming here almost everyday (wallet is crying).

Really good sushi and customer service is also really good. It feels very home-y with the sushi bar setup. They have lunch specials that are $17 that will fill you up + have leftover to bring home. Rock n' roll (unagi with avacado) is my favorite.

I'm pretty sure the workers there are Chinese, not Japanese lol.
author: Anna H.

description:
I grew up in the Sunset, and Ebisu is the sushi that I grew up with. I've been a fan for more than 20 years and Ebisu has consistently remained my favorite sushi restaurant. They have the freshest fish and very talented chefs.  The only downside is that parking is very tough in the neighborhood and that the wait times are usually 45 minutes to an hour. 

Be sure to check the board for the night's specials - they change nightly. Usually they have several different types of toro (fatty tuna and salmon belly) which is my absolute favorite. If you're an uni fan, be sure to get the live uni if they have it - it's very special and is much better than the regular (but still very good) uni. Other favorites include the XXX roll and the double hamachi roll. If you're lucky, you'll be able to sit at the bar and be served directly the the chef in front of you.
author: Allen T.

description:
Really good sushi but after coming a few times I've realize the experience and quality depends on the chef you get. Some things I've tried:

XXX Roll: This came with salmon, mango, and avocado on the outside and spicy tuna inside. Pretty good and decent amount for $16.

Kobe: Yum! Great flavors and came with a delicious dipping sauce.

Salmon: Good.

Unagi: Good.

Hamachi Toro: I was pleasantly delighted by how delicious this was. I usually don't like hamachi but this piece didn't have a strong fishy taste and was very fatty.

Salmon Toro: Hands down our favorite if the night!! It was such a big piece of fish and totally melted in our mouths. 

Our sushi chef was really friendly and even gave us free pieces of fish liver. Service was attentive and fast overall.

Total was only $54, which was very reasonable for the amount and quality of food we got. We look forward to coming back.
author: Sophia H.

description:
After looking at the reviews for this restaurant, I just had to come here! I've had this restaurant bookmarked for SO long! Came here earlier on a Friday and parking was a little tricky to find but hey, what do you expect it's SF, right?

The wait for a table was 45 minutes so I decided to do some walking about in the meantime. Once seated, I was able to get a table close to the sushi bar and see the sushi chefs whip up all the good sushi rolls!

I'm not a big fan of raw fish, but I decided to try it for my first time. I tried Uni and I must say I am NOT a fan of it! At least I tried it right?

I also ordered:

-Seaweed Salad-Can't really go wrong with that, right? A+ for the salad! Yummy! :).
-Tempura- It was so delicious and tasty! A big A+ for that as well.
-Dexter Carter- Let's just say this is a must try! It was so fresh and yummy.
-XXX Roll- With Salmon, Mango, Avocado and spicy Tuna- This was my favorite, the mango and avocado was the topping to this sushi! **A must try as well**

Overall, I would come here again to try their bento box and sushi rolls again, which I really enjoyed. 

Customer service was very good here. Although they were very busy the waiters and servers were still able to check in and make sure that our water was refilled and that we were satisfied.

Be prepared for the long wait if you are going on a weekend! Happy eating! :)
author: Porsche C.

description: This is a local gem.  I like the vibe of the restaurant.  If you are planning to come here, make sure to be here right when it opens as wait times tend to get long.   The lobster dynamite and hamachi kama are a staple when i come here.   Try the sake flight as well.   Friendly staff and have that family feel.
author: Luis E.

description:
Quality sushi for an affordable price! This is my go to place for sushi. Ever since my friend took me here, I can't think of anywhere better for the price and quality.

Expect to wait in line, or come in past peak dinner hours. The first time here, I came in around 7:00pm and waited 40 minutes. Next time I came at around 9:00pm and waited about 15 minutes.

I recommend everything I've tried: the double hamachi roll, swamp roll, crunchy roll and sake toro. Everything tastes super fresh and comes out pretty quickly.

Overall, service is amazing. The workers seem content and seem to enjoy their jobs :) That's kind of rare to see. Plus the complimentary edamame and orange after was a nice touch.

I can't wait to back!
author: Corinna T.

description: i used to love this place. It was to go place for reasonable priced yet good quality sushi.  I was very disappointed with not so good quality fish (specially tuna) ...not sure what  has changed there.
author: K M.

description:
I've been coming here for years, it's always been fresh and the service has always been great, until now. If you have a great restaurant you can't just sit back and rely on a good reputation. You have to keep working for it, that is to say bring your A game to Friday night rush. Total fail. 

The quality of fish, the quality of service and even the portions have suffered (the size of the cut has decreased significantly over the years). I think Ebisu fails to stand up to the test of time. I feel bad for not having put in a good review when I should have years if not even just 6 months ago. 

When I spoke to a manager about it she was receptive. Then she had a total fail as well. She told me that the server took my criticism personally and that every one makes mistakes. I never spoke to my server about the issues I was having, I spoke directly to the manager, whatever she said to the waitress I don't know but I never said a harsh word to her to make her cry. I feel like the manager was trying to make us both feel bad. 

When people regard your establishment as a place to come for a celebratory meal at a one of the most busy times you should live up to it. Never going back,  ever.

Next fail, she offered us desert, I declined. She served it to us anyways. That really pissed me off, I can't eat ice cream and I already promised my daughter desert. So then my daughter had 2 desserts. 

Our server sucked horribly. The service was disjointed, some stuff just didn't even show up. The wrong thing showed up due to the fact that the server didn't understand what I ordered and then just decided to bring something else. The meal I ordered came out 15 minutes after my wife and kids entrees, then the appetizer I ordered arrived after that. 

This experience totally ruined all the good memories I have of this place. I will leave two stars for the good times.
I have been coming here for over a decade, Good bye.
author: Ben M.

description:
This place is small so the wait was pretty long on a Wednesday. I believe we waited around 45 minutes, which was okay since we knew there would be a wait after reading the reviews. 

The salmon skin roll, bonsai, was very good, so was the family affair, the salmon roe was a little different than we are used to, the Hanukkah roll had smoked salmon and was a little fishy. We also ordered the seared albacore sashimi with onions and ponzu, we did not love it and this is usually our favorite dish. I don't know what was off but something was. 

Will definitely go back and try some other dishes.
author: Jessica S.

description:
love this place! sooo good. my sister and I came in about 30 mins after they opened and the place was almost packed. just a few minutes after we were seated, a line had already formed out the door. the new remodel looks beautiful! i love all the architectural details. 

i ordered the bento ($16) with the beef teriyaki, maki, and gyoza. the beef teriyaki was like steak and it was delicious. not a big portion but it came with potatoes and carrots so it still filled me up. the salad was really good as well as the maki. i'm not a gyoza type of person because the ones i've tasted in the past were not very good... but Ebisu's gyoza was BOMB!! it was thee best gyoza i've ever tasted. it tasted homemade and fresh, like it has never been frozen. that and the beef teriyaki was the highlight of my meal.

my sister also ordered the Boston Roll and that was really good as well. it had some crunch on it because of the cucumbers. 

highly recommend this place! definitely want to come back here.
author: Carmina D.

description:
Wow, that was amazing sushi I just ate. Especially the nigiri. My boyfriend and I came from the movie theaters and I was craving sushi, so we tried this place.

We ordered: Oyster on 1/2 she'll with no ponzu sauce, blue fin toro nigiri, uni nigiri, salmon toro nigiri, Arch Deluxe sushi roll, and the Romeo & Juliet. 

Omg the blue fin toro and uni was SO good. The fish like literally melts in your mouth. The salmon toro was alright. Romeo & Juliet roll was my favorite, the arch deluxe was a bit too much. 

But man, oh man, the blue fin toro and uni nigiri was just amazing!!
author: Ritney N.

description:
A friend recommended this restaurant to me, and I'm so happy he did. One of the best sushi restaurants I've been to!  The ambiance a small warm feel, with the sushi bar along one entire wall.  Several people making sushi, and everyone working was so cheerful, gracious and hard working.

It's a bit of a wait, but there is a reason why!  The fish is fresh, the options are plenty, and everything is delicious.
author: Roxy L.

description:
Excellent spot. Our sushi chef was Eric, who I believe is the son of Ebisu's owner. He was happy to engage in a dialogue about the food and the process, which was both really informative and quite fun. I wanted to try uni for the first time, and I trusted his opinion that what they had at the time was high quality and worth having. It did not disappoint; creamy, sweet, with no bitterness whatsoever. It was an absolute treat.
The rest of our sushi was of equal quality and made with great care, something which I appreciate very much. Each bite was meant to have a purpose, and it was some of the best sushi I've ever had.
Beyond the great fish and Eric's really awesome work, the whole staff was very kind and the space itself is both cozy and contemporary. It's a really pleasant neighborhood as well. I can't wait to go back!
author: Will H.

description:
The vibe of Ebisu feels authentic enough with sushi chefs serving you directly if you're seated at the sushi bar. But I agree with other reviewers that the quality and taste of the sushi do not live up to the wait, the hype, and the price. We ordered the Tiger Eyes appetizer (that came last), Swamp Roll, XXX Roll, and a Negitoro roll. 

Here are my complaints:
- Rolls were all rice and very little fish
- The fish were diced up! To me, that ruins the taste and texture because it just tastes mushy.

Actually, every roll tastes like mush in your mouth. There's nothing appetizing about that at all.
author: Thao T.

description:
With such high reviews, I was expecting at least decent sashimi. Did I get that? NO. I thought I test it out by first ordering salmon sashimi, 8 pieces for $16, decent priced. Highly excited for soft, buttery sashimi, the order comes and I am in shock! The so-called "8 pieces" is really 4 slices cut in HALF - what a total rip off! The half pieces are small in itself, too! Not only that, the fish did not smell too fresh and to top it off, the fish was chewy. THIS IS SO NOT GOOD QUALITY FOR THAT PRICE. At $16, I at least expected 8 real pieces and somewhat decent quality - this was far below anything. Total disappointment. 

Two stars is really for the waitress who was friendly and provided good customer service. 

I don't get why this place is rated high, maybe I should try different sashimi, but I did not get a good first impression, and the way the sashimi was cut in half is the biggest turn-off from wanting to give this a second go. Bye Felicia.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Love this place!  Sushi is excellent.  Just don't come if you are in a hurry.  No reservations and very popular!
author: Sharon I.

description: I am not a sushi person, but enjoy Japanese food on other levels.  went for lunch, was greeted nicely & served in
author: sandie g.

description: Bought the 8 piece sashimi.  What they did was take 1 sashimi and cut it in half as you can see in the picture.  I felt like I was ripped off.  To make it worse, the sashimi was not fresh at all.  It was so chewy and had a distinct old fishy taste to it.  Wouldn't recommend this place to anyone.  I will give them one star because the waitress was nice.
author: Randy P.

description:
Ebisu has become my new go-to guilty delivery pleasure. 

When I want to treat myself  - I like to order the 49er roll and Dragon Roll from Ebisu and I hungrily anticipate my carb-y order via Postmates.

Ebisu's fish is excellent and their presentation is lovely. 

The 49er Roll is comprised of Salmon, Lemon, Avocado, Tobiko and Shiso. The Salmon is divine and buttery - and the flavor is further accentuated by the ornate thin lemon slice upon each piece.

The Dragon Roll is comprised of Unagi, Kanikama, Avocado, Tenpura Shrimp and Cucumber. The flavor is definitely sweeter than the 49er roll - but it's just as decadent and worth trying. Though I usually try to avoid rolls with fried vegetables or fish - the Dragon Roll is worth the grease.  

I am not a fan of lines - so it's been years since I've actually dined in at Ebisu. If you have a similar aversion to lines - but crave well prepared fresh sushi and Japanese food - get your delivery on from Ebisu.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Came here twice before but this was my first time sitting at the bar. My friend and I were lucky and sat down between a couple regulars so we were treated royally by Julio. Most of the things we had were off-menu and we ended up making some friends that night. I honestly don't remember any of the names of the food we had but it was the best sushi I've had to date! 

The only thing was the wait was torturous (as expected for a Friday dinner) but it was so worth it. We got seated around 8 and ended up staying till closing at 11. I will return to get some of the fabulous sushi made by Julio and Suzuki!!
author: Cathy N.

description:
I have been there in the past but need to update my 4stars to 5stars. 
My advice: Just sit on the sushi bar with Susuki and/or Julio. Go there with no set menu and just let them inspire you what is fresh and special. 5 stars is NOT an exaggeration.
author: Dagmar W.

description:
pros:
excellent menu options and delicious sushi
friendly service
reasonably priced

cons:
extremely long, long waits
tight space and seating
author: Anne G.

description: Absolutely one of SFO's BEST Sushi restaurants. Great staff and excellent cuts of fish. The beef sukiyaki and s as good as you can get in Japan. This time I tried the lobster dynamite and the whole family loved it.
author: Ed S.

description:
3 people had:
- sunomono 
- 49er
- miso
- family affair 
- xxx (salmon, avo, mango) 
- chicken teriyaki 

Sunomono vinegrette was flavorful, small quantity but redeeming. 

49er and family affair were my favorites. The 49er is a divine combination of flavors, and could have been improved by more content and less rice on the outside of the roll. 

Xxx of the day was a bit too fishy-savory for me. Family affair was decent, not as noteworthy as the 49er. For the price I don't know if I'd come back. Maybe to try some new rolls and hopefully find one as memorable as the 49er.

If you have money to burn I definitely recommend Ebisu, if not you might consider digging up something that gives better bang for your buck. (It wasn't bad though).
author: Mackenzie P.

description:
My family and I returned to Ebisu after a really long time because we were all craving some sushi. I always thought Ebisu was pretty good but the long wait always make me not want to wait. 

Tonight, I had the beef teriyaki ($25) and I also got some nigiri (maguro, sake toro, amaebi, & hotate). The sake toro, amaebi & the hotate was on the fresh fish specials & I thought they were much better than the maguro. So if you plan on ordering a la carte from the sushi bar, get whatever you would like, but do focus on getting the sushi from the fresh fish specials. The nigiri made me super full so I regretted ordering the beef teriyaki, but after taking a bite of the beef teriyaki, it was so good I was living. They do it differently than usual: serving it with veggies, yukon potatoes & the beef teriyaki in steak form. The beef & vegetables were so flavorful & cooked perfectly. I wasn't able to finish it but I did not regret getting it at all. 

We arrived at the restaurant at around 7PM & had to wait for about 30-40 minutes. But as we were eating, I noticed it wasn't as crowded at around 7:30PM, however, we ate here on a Tuesday night, so I think the next time we come to eat here earlier in the week, we will come at around that time.
author: Victoria H.

description: Great food ordered the catipillar roll best thing ever!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Great food best thing on the menu. Service is great. I would recamend u 2 go there.
author: Adam S.

description: Came here for lunch on Monday and we ordered the Chirashi. Tasted very good and we will come back again soon.
author: Wendy L.

description:
I have been to Ebisu twice with mixed feelings, but it was the third visit that solidified my opinion.

For some reason, Ebisu is touted as this bougie, legit Japanese restaurant in the Inner Sunset. The place to take your friends and family who are visiting the city. 

However, I actually don't think the hype is worth the money and the time you spend waiting for a table. The timing of the dishes generally don't make sense-- we got appetizers after our main course and sushi. 

What I thought would have been the saving grace of our dinner, their green tea creme brulee for dessert, came to us overcooked and stale. I was sorely disappointed.
author: Pia D.

description:
Ok, I came here for my first time with my brother because we're exploring San Francisco and the place looked sketchy on the outside and lonely. We were there 20 min after they had opened the restaurant. When we walked inside, it was another world inside. It's a small restaurant but it's really nice and the waiters are very nice and on top of everything! 

The food is bomb! You have to try the caterpillar roll! It's the best I have had. The dish display is nicely presented. 

Service is really good. I was impressed. When I was done eating, someone would pick up the plate as soon as we were done. I would definitely come back if I visit San Francisco.
author: Roxanne R.

description: Favorite sushi spot. All the fish is to die for. The family is so welcoming. Puts love into all they do! Plan on waiting 30 minutes during the week and an hour on weekends
author: Lauren M.

description:
I've always like this place.  I grew up in the Sunset and have been here plenty of times but it's been years since I actually stepped in this place until yesterday.  It was nice to see that they remodeled the place.  My son and I stepped in about 20 minutes prior to closing so they were in a rush to get us in and out of there.  They have a great selection of rolls and prices are reasonable.  Since I'm with child, I stayed away from raw fish and ordered cooked sushi rolls. I ordered a salmon teriyaki bento box for my son.  

The rolls are well made and service is fast and efficient.  I can't wait til I can try their entire menu again.  I usually give my son some apple juice but they didn't have any type of juice to serve for kiddos which was a pain.  I will definitely return soon!
author: Christine P.

description:
I had an event at the park and as always I was craving sushi so Ebisu was there to save the day. The place was very busy considering it was a late Wednesday night but I was dining alone so I was seated at the bar right away. The employees were all very friendly including the sushi chef.

I ordered the sashimi omakase and the sabagari maki roll. The sashimi omakase is more like a slightly fancier sashimi combo. It had around 25 slices of fish and was served beautifully. However the actual selection, quality, and creativity wasn't all the impressive. If you aren't looking for more less-commonly found types of fish and you want bang for your buck, this is a good deal. But personally I was hoping for an omakase that would feature their daily selection or a dish that would showcase the chef's creativity and unfortunately this wasn't it. Still for under $30 it's a pretty good deal. The quality isn't great but at about $1 a slice, you get what you pay for. The selection included seared albacore, saba, butterfish, yellowtail, salmon, ikura, etc. I'd suggest getting this platter to share. I was happy to see the sabagari maki roll on the menu. It's a great combo more places should have. I found the rice a bit mushy and the roll wasn't well formed but it was cheap and I still enjoyed it. 

Overall, Ebisu is an ok sushi spot. There's better options in SF but if you're in the area it's not bad.
author: Vivian C.

description: One of the top sushi spots in SF is what I hear and what I've tasted! Arrive off-peak time or be prepared to wait.
author: Leo I.

description:
7PM. Weekday evening. And what?! There's people waiting outside already?? Most of them were families with small children...but still!

Ebisu is VERY close to Golden Gate Park and positioned perfectly right outside the heart of Inner Sunset. Street parking is bountiful if you happen to have good timing. It opens 

You have many different types of "sushi people." There are the "SAKE SAKE SAKE people," then your "white-folk-NO RAW PLEASE-people," the "I LOVE sushi...but what they really mean is bento boxes people," and well...my sister and I are the "sushi to us means specialty sushi rolls." Being from the South Bay, we've had our fair share of yucky sushi spots to delicious melt-in-your-mouth-raw-fish-heaven centers...so we hoped that Ebisu would be the latter. There are two other sushi spots literally right next door and across the street from Ebisu, so we figured that this place was the best because they were the only spot with people sitting around outside.

Ebisu is a small spot...and I'm talking about SMALL even for SF standards. They have two restrooms in the back, but the tight spacing makes you want to hold your pee until you get home. The poor servers have to constantly walk in one single-file-line to deliver the sushi plates to the back kitchen and to the customers' tables! It's pretty much a tight-spaced disaster waiting to happen. BUT the intimate ambiance is consequently increased tenfold and the vibes would be described as Asian-modern with a hint of sleek and a dash of zen. The cute old lady who we thought owned this spot is easy to see on any dining occasion. And the servers are a diverse bunch from Caucasian (shoutout to our chill server!) to Cantonese.

As an outsider and not an inhabitant of SF, I did not think the prices were too high at all! In fact the $9.50 crunch roll and $13 #29 roll were pretty average and almost considered "cheap" as compared to some other SoBay spots for sushi. I wouldn't say this was the "best sushi" I've ever had, but the presentation and pricing at Ebisu gets applause from this Yelper. Food-wise though, the rolls weren't sticking together as much as I'd like and the floor plan is a bit narrow for a completely well-rounded experience. They also have sake and beer!! Cheers to you, Ebisu.
author: Jodi H.

description: My boyfriend got me take out from here- we got two things 1) Romeo and Juliet and the other 2) a family affair. The fish was SO fresh. They also give plenty of wasabi which is perfect ! I got the sushi 20 min later and it was amazing !! I'm going to for sure come and eat in one day!!!
author: Amy Y.

description:
My friend and I were in the area and decided upon sushi since almost all the other restaurants in the area had a long wait time. Seating didn't take too long, which is great because I usually don't wait longer than 30 minutes when dining out. I am not sure if they take reservations, but I try make reservations at any restaurant that honors them during peak hours.

We ordered the kobe beef skewer and the $25 omakase special. The kobe beef skewer was juicy and tender, although I haven't actually had legitimate Kobe beef in Japan to make a valid comparison Pricing is on par with other sushi places and the quality of fish was quite fresh, surprisingly. The albacore, salmon, and surf clams were my favorite, and there is enough sashimi pieces to share between two people.

Pleasant service coupled with an ambiance that is reminiscent of good times in Japan. Definitely check this hidden gem if you're in the area.
author: Christina T.

description: We came here at dinner time and waited around 10 minutes as the place was packed. We were sat right in front of the chefs and had to order right from them. They understood our vague requests and got our orders perfectly. The waitresses still took care of our drinks and what not. We ordered different nigiris (salmon, scallop, sweet shrimp, halibut), and they were the freshest most tender melt-in-your-mouth pieces of nigiri we have ever tried. The sushi rice was warm, and vinegary. I would HIGHLY recommend the Romeo & Juliet roll because the scallop was so sweet and the salmon + avocado complimented the whole roll. The rainbow roll was also delicious. Omakase was amazing and featured different kinds of fresh fish that all melted in your mouth. The three chefs out of the four were very experienced (one looked young like an apprentice), and they were all friendly. This was one of if not THE MOST authentic sushi place we have tried in America. It is well worth the price, and we will definitely come back again.
author: Qingbo Z.

description: The fish and uni are pretty fresh, unfortunately, I ordered some sushi, all the rice still not cook done, when I ate the sushi, it gave me the bas feeling.
author: Jeslie K.

description:
We came around 5:45 on a Saturday night and the restaurant was already filled with about a 30min wait. The space is small, but turn around was quick. The crowd seemed to die down after 7:30PM, so later may actually be better.

We ordered the 49er roll, which I enjoyed, along with a selection of our favorite nigiris. Fish was fresh, service was quick, no complaints. It was definitely good, but I'm not sure it's worth the hype. 

One tip is to take public transportation / uber / lyft as parking is so difficult in this area! My bf took longer to park than it took for me to wait to get a seat.
author: Cynthia X.

description: Always fantastic. Love ebisu. 49er roll all the way. Great staff and amazing Sake as well.
author: Miles C.

description: The best Sushi around.  We drove from Solano county because its soo good.  Always the freshest fish and the Sushi chef's are amazing It's also next to Golden Gate Park.  I recommend Ebisu to anyone who wants truly great Sushi.
author: Joyce C.

description:
Crowded little place with yummy sushi. My friend and I came here on a Saturday night for sushi. A wait was expected. What wasn't expected was a decently sized waiting area, sheltering us from the cold night air. The wait wasn't too long for 2 people open to be seated at either bar or table. We got seated at the bar. Watching the chefs work to create our order was fun. I don't normally choose the bar, so I don't see it very often. Our orders were taken relatively promptly given how busy it was. Our nigiri orders were delivered to us by the chef we sat in front of! It didn't take him very long to get and finish our order. 

I'd come back here the next time I have a craving for nigiri or sashimi.
author: Connie T.

description: Wow, I had no idea there was such an awesome sushi restaurant in the Inner Sunset. We sat at the bar which is always the best spot in a good sushi restaurant imo. The staff was fun and helpful. They suggested lots of great things. We ordered so much I won't put them all here but I think everything is probably top notch. We will be having dinner here again soon!
author: Zoom G.

description: I'm sorry but this place is over price ,overrated.... been here twice for bussiness meeting due to client recommend ebisu.  I have one of the worst sushi experience.  Waiting long for a table and it's like a rush rush dinner . 4 person tab came $460 with out tip.... better of eating at sushi Sam
author: christian l.

description: I usually go in and ask for Julio or Yubin. They're both awesome at the sushi counter. You probably couldn't get any better fish in the city. Omakase (chef's choice) might set you back a little, but it is well worth it every single time. This is my go-to place for good sushi.
author: Alton Y.

description: Great food. Best bento box I've had. Comes with way more food than most Japanese restaurants offer. Had the salmon teriyaki with tuna sashimi and vegetable tempura. Will definitely visit again.
author: Josh M.

description:
The boyfriend and I got hungry one Tuesday afternoon and decided to drop by this restaurant. Just like any Japanese restaurant, they warmly greeted us. We were promptly seated when we arrived at 12:30pm. 

Firstly, we ordered tea for drinks and it was mediocre green tea. They have decently priced bento boxes for lunch only, and we decided to get the beef teriyaki and salmon bento combination box (Combo 3 and 4) for $16 each. 

Miso soup came first, in a very cute bowl and matching lid. The miso soup here didn't taste like sodium galore, and it was salted to perfection, salty enough but not like you're drinking the ocean like other places. 

The whole bento box took around 15 minutes to get to our table. We were both in awe of all the food that was included in this lunch special. My bento box came with 5 raw bite sized pieces of lean tuna, seaweed salad, house salad, grilled salmon , yuka potatoes, carrots, and tempura with a variety of veggies. The lean pieces of tuna was fresh, but not the best piece of tuna I've ever had. Seaweed salad tasted the same everywhere. House salad was fresh and light. I don't prefer vinaigrette dressings, so I didn't enjoy it as much. Salmon was just okay; the first piece was perfectly cooked, as it was moist and squishy. However, the second piece was overcooked, as it was very dry. My favorite part of the bento box was surprisingly the yuka potatoes that was mixed with the salmon. It had a smokey toasted flavor like house potatoes, but it was also sweet with the teriyaki sauce that came with the salmon. Tempura was also really good, as it was light and not overbearing with the grease. 

Lunch was overall a good experience, but it wasn't life changing.
author: Harmony C.

description:
We found Ebisu because we were searching for authentic Japanese restaurant that was open on Sunday.  Sounds silly, but try to find one in SF open on Sundays, and has good food.

Anyways, after trying several restaurants prior to our family arriving in SF, we thought Ebisu had the best flavors, sushi properly done, nori fresh, and rice seasoned perfectly. Tempura batter light, crispy and flavorful.  It's in an area of SF we don't normally hang out, but if in the area, on a Sunday, and craving Japanese food, will return.

They don't take reservations, and it's very busy week nights or ends.  Be prepared to put your name on a list and wait.
author: Tom S.

description: Great fish, generous potions. Highly suggest the bento box. It comes with much more than what they say is on the menu. Architecture inside the restaurant is pleasant and feels authentic. This lady walks around with a giant pot of green topping off everyone's tea. It's lovely. Not 5 stars because they were a little slow with one of our sushi rolls. They were busy though
author: Molly G.

description: This place is a hidden gem. Fantastic Japanese cuisine but at a reasonable price? It blows my mind every time I come here. Especially appreciate how bluefin toro doesn't cost me an arm and a leg but it tastes so fresh.
author: Nayeli C.

description:
AMAZING!  My fiance has been going here for 30 years and we had to stop by while we were in SF visiting his mom.  Suzuki San is an amazing sushi chef and gave us amazing sushii.  This is what we had for dinner:

Albacore Toro (MY FAVORITE-- so buttery and fresh, love the toppings he added)
Maguro 
Hamachi Toro
Halibut Cheeks and fin
Geoduck (skewered and lightly grilled with leeks)
Amaebi
Fried Ebi head
Unagi
Iwashi
49'er Roll

It was a lot of food for 3 people-- we left there, stuffed, and super happy.  I can't wait to eat there again.  MUST get here early and get your name on the waiting list. Otherwise, it's a lonnnng wait.
author: Monica A.

description:
This place was decently busy at 9pm on a Wednesday night, and I can see why. Large selection of fish, the fish was fresh, the presentation was very good, and the service was great.

Interesting menu...several Jewish inspired sushi rolls. I'm not a big fan of rolls, but the one that I had was really fantastic. I think it was called the Romeo and Juliet roll, had tobiko on scallops topping a salmon and avocado roll. Great combo.

Will definitely return the next time I'm in town.
author: Alex N.

description:
Nice atmosphere, but food a bit pricey and I think poisoned me!! 

* KAKUNI - 5 - YUM, this is bomb!! So tender and the sauce was mouth watering. Definitely get this.

* MISO SOUP - 4 - okay, I know it's just miso soup, but after having a little bit too much to drink at B2B, this soup hit the spot

* KOBE BEEF SASHIMI - 3.5 - I think this was what poisoned me.  It was pretty good, comes with 3 different spices (garlic, spicy, spicier) and a sweet dipping soy sauce, but raw beef? Later on that night, I had horrible runs and even threw up what I ate. My friends also had the kobe beef sashimi, but I have a really sensitive stomach so I don't know. Just don't mix it with alcohol.  

* CHICKEN WINGS - 3 - normal. I don't know why my boyfriend ordered this, probably expected chicken karaage when it was just normal chicken wings haha

* ROMEO & JULIET - 2 - I saw someone's review who said this was bomb, but it was a lie. And this was $14.50?! Not worth it!! :( 

OVERALL: Nothing special in my point of view, except the Kakuni.
author: Raquel Y.

description:
Hands down one of my favorite Japanese restaurants in the city. 

Let's get some of the cons out of the way: the place is small. Very small. The tables are all placed very close together and the bar space feels a bit cramped as well. 

And naturally, with such high quality food, there's going to be a huge wait. Luckily, there are some pretty great shops and cafes in the area that you can bide some time :)

Now for the food: as I mentioned, the fish is incredibly fresh and definitely high quality. The food is carefully prepared in both presentation and finesse. The sushi and sashimi are the stars of the show, so definitely get a plate or two to share amongst your group

For the rolls, I would recommend the 49ers roll and the family affair. For sashimi, I prefer the salmon (who doesn't) and the hamachi. 

It's a bit pricey, but well worth the quality you're gonna get. The owners are also incredibly sweet--a nice married couple that you can see working the front and in the kitchen :)
author: Jay P.

description: It took us a while to get in on a Saturday but the service was really good and the sushi was fantastic.
author: Robert R.

description:
It's always packed. There's always people waiting. I always thought it was just a hype, not worth the wait... But oh, it is worth it. Or at least worth eating late for. 

Sushi makes me so happy. Good sushi makes me even happier. This places makes me giggle inside and jump for joy. I've only been here twice, but I can say is my new favorite spot. Great sushi is hard to find... And it's most telling when I try the Uni and amaebi (with fried head). Oh boy, they nailed both. The Uni, although expensive at the MP price, it was so delicious both times. And the amaebi fried head was fried to perfection. So light and crispy you can each the entire head... Even the eye balls (but I didn't eat it)!! So good!!

Sashimi is always fresh. We got nigiri and the sashmi sets, you can order half orders. The carashi bowl was also delicious and presentation was on POINT. Hamachi Kama-- ooo weee, so tasty and crispy. It comes with some spinach and seaweed salad. 

So far we liked everything we've tried here. One thing to note that I was not a fan of: the tiger eyes appetizer. It was not that tasty, not what I expected.

I still give it two thumbs up and 5 stars, because an amazing sushi restaurant is way hard to come by... My only wish was there wasn't such long lines all the time!
author: Lorraine W.

description: The wait for dinner time was expected.  Food is very good. The portions are smaller than expected.
author: HQ S.

description:
Amazing, quaint, long time staple of quality sushi and experience in the Inner Sunset. It's my go to location for some fresh fish at a reasonable cost with an amazing experience. 

Something for everyone. From your traditional lunch time bento boxes and your quality tempura to some of the freshest fish and "affordable" omakase in the area. 

I highly recommend for the fish route that you, "follow the chalkboard" and go for the freshet of the day. Chat up the chefs and be cordial, they are a great crowd that understands what service means with a great product.

Here's to many more years that Ebisu hangs around in the ever changing SF food scene as a landmark. Cheers!
author: Joseph L.

description:
Solid sushi place! The bf and I came here for an early bday dinner, and was seated at the sushi bar after a 15 min wait. 

BE WARNED: this place is CRAMPED. They utilized every single inch of this place. The sushi bar definitely had no elbow room whatsoever. 

We sat in front of the sashimi chef Kevin, who was very insistent in serving us items and recommending items for us. Our sushi bar bill grew and grew. Luckily we didn't mind and enjoyed many of the things he insisted that we needed. If you are aset on not spending too much and only want a few things, I would recommend sitting at a table! 

For the food: everything we tried was absolutely great! The sashimi salad(poke) and the live scallop were definite standouts in my book.  The grilled calamari and the pink cadillac are both items I could've done without. Both were a bit on the dry side.
author: Kay A.

description: My family and I were San Francisco and we stopped at Ebisu because a couple recommended it and between the service Mei gave us and our food it's easy to say this is the best sushi restaurant I've ever been too!(and I've been to A LOT)
author: Tayler N.

description: We stopped in for a quick lunch and this sushi bar was terrific! The waitress help to select a couple of rolls and we had a really great experience here. We also had a 30 minute limit on our parking and we got out just in time.
author: david m.

description:
Like food combinations that juxtapose each other- salty/sweet; crunchy/soft? 

If so, order this sushi combo- ikura (roe), quail egg, uni.

It is SO GOOD. One of the best pieces of sushi I've ever had. It's not on the menu, so I had the server put in my custom order.

Flavors- Creaminess from the quail egg, soft texture from the roe, freshness from the uni, consistent base from the rice that ties it together, and saltiness from the seaweed wrap. 

Other notes- live uni dish is well known, good sushi and fish variety, parking is hard to find, limited seating as it's a small restaurant.
author: Joanna L.

description: The worst service I have ever experienced at a restaurant. I asked if anything on the menu was gluten free, I am celiac and had to come here because family chose it for dinner. The waitress replied "nothing on the menu is gluten free." So I sat at dinner w a cup of tea starving. Usually a sushi restaurant can make you a plate of sashimi or steamed vegetables.
author: Andrea G.

description:
As its self-description notes, Ebisu has been a local institution for the past 30 years, serving a variety of Japanese dishes in a newly renovated space - a modern marvel with angular wood ceilings and a bar resembling a back-alley joint in Tokyo.  I've passed by Ebisu several times while visiting family, but never had a chance to dine here until a recent visit to Golden Gate Park.  Given the notorious wait and the small size of the restaurant, I was lucky to be seated almost immediately at 12:30PM on a Sunday and was mostly satisfied with my visit.

Ebisu has an extensive menu featuring almost everything you could possibly want from a Japanese restaurant, like sushi and sashimi as well as tempura and sukiyaki.  Since the restaurant is named after the Japanese of fishermen and most reviews highlighted the fish, I ordered the assorted sashimi ($22).
