Although I wasn't able to fully identify the pieces of fish that came with the assorted sashimi, I did count at least 18 separate pieces of fish / seafood, but some pieces were admittedly smaller or chunkier than others.  Generally, the fish tasted fresh and had nice texture, but didn't have the elusive melt-in-your-mouth quality that typically defines really great sashimi.  As such, I didn't think this was the best sashimi ever in spite of the overall quality of the fish, and I thought that the price was a little higher than what I would have otherwise paid for sashimi at comparable establishments in LA.  And, disappointingly, the assorted sashimi did not include salmon - my favorite fish!  I also sampled the beef teriyaki don ($12) and thought that it had a nice sauce that was both savory and sweet.  But, I would caution those who don't like having their rice drenched in sauce against ordering donburi, as none of the rice remained untouched.

Service was generally good in spite of the busyness of the restaurant.  (Since most of the restaurant has smaller, two-person tables, you'll probably end up waiting for a bit if you have a large party.)  Staff always made sure that our water glasses were full and used plates were removed.  And, even though we had clearly finished eating, the restaurant didn't give us our bill until we had asked for it, ensuring that we could enjoy our post-meal conversation without being rushed.  

As with most restaurants in San Francisco, parking is street only.  You're probably better off walking or taking public transit if you're not interested in circling the cramped blocks for a space.

I would definitely recommend checking out Ebisu if you're looking for a decent sushi after spending the day in Golden Gate Park, but probably wouldn't go out of my way to come back unless I desperately wanted sushi in the area given the higher than average prices and the number of comparable restaurants located elsewhere.
author: Greg T.

description:
This place has gone seriously downhill. For the insane prices - 2 pieces of scallop nigiri for $15 - you would expect at least polite, responsible service. And more likely fine dining service.  But no, even a small table of three couldn't get their food to arrive at the same time. The differential between the dishes arriving was about 10 minutes. So all told, a 20 minute delay between the first entree arriving and the last. What's more the last dish to arrive was wrong and they offered grudgingly to replace it but "you'd have to wait." The server didn't know the specials on the board "what is the xxx," "I don't know...I'll go ask." You'd think by 7pm the server's already done this at least twice.  

It was unbelievably bad service, as if we were in a cafeteria, not a fine dining restaurant. The food was extremely pricey, and just okay sushi, though beautifully made. 

And then, something I ate there had me vomiting just a few hours later. I have no signs of having caught a virus, this is straight up something I ate was not good and my body rejected it. 

There are so many sushi places now, Ebisu's not kept it's game up. It's charging high end prices for low quality dining.
author: Sarah S.

description: Expect a wait for a table but well worth it. Felt like being transported to Japan. Amazing fresh and tasty sushi. Lobster tempura was THE BOMB! I'm not usually a fan of tempura, to greasy and heavy. This was so light, melts in your mouth.
author: Lalenya M.

description:
Pretty disappointed! I am always up for trying new, highly regarded sushi spots. Big fan of Koo just up the st, so figured I'd try this place out. 

We waited for about 40 minutes and the place was pretty busy for a Thursday night. Service was great, but the sushi...

We started with the veggie tempura and that was pretty good. Although a few of the items were undercooked. However, this can be standard with tempura. 

Our first roll was great. It was a lobster special roll. 

Our second roll...oh boy. I noticed by the 3rd piece the ratio of fish to rice was almost 90% rice. There was almost no fish inside the roll. By the time we got to the middle of the roll we were literally eating rolled rice with salmon on top. I never send things back, but I had to. They made a new one for us, but the problem persisted! WAY too much rice. I eat sushi all the time and I have been to so many, less hyped sushi restaurants that have better rolls than this. We were pretty blown away that the second time around there was still hardly ANY fish inside the roll. 

But, the straw that broke the camels back, there was a BONE in our sushi. My bf almost swallowed it. Again, in all my years of eating sushi this has never happened to myself or my boyfriend -- especially at a nice spot. Yuck!
author: Sarah W.

description:
My favorite sushi place by far! I've been here multiple times, and I know it can get crazy busy, but I always opt to sit by the bar, so I've never had to wait. My aunt used to come here at least once a week - for years - but hadn't been back in almost 7 years. However, the owner & his wife still remembered her! Crazy. You can't really go wrong here - my family & I usually split the $50 plate of sashimi [I forget what it's called], and order a few rolls & some soup & we're good to go. Plus the $50 plate allows you to try all sorts of fish, and I've never had fish this fresh before. I also try to ask the chefs what their best cut of the day is, and I'll usually go for some of that as well. Love the salmon toro. Yum...

The green tea creme brulee is also SO good here. Get it. You know you want to.
author: Amy L.

description:
My girlfriend and I are big sushi fans and love exploring new spots. This one had a very japanese feel to it.

Service was very quick and server was nice, we came in on a Tuesday at it was busy so I'm sure the weekends are very packed as it is a smaller spot.

Presentation and taste were great and the sashimi was super fresh. 

I would recommend the xxx role and also the family affair. 

Will be adding this to one of our fav spots.
author: Priyang P.

description: This is my favorite sushi restaurant in the city. They have extremely high quality fish, delicious rolls, great service, and when the bill comes they don't demand your first born. It's my favorite because I can get the high quality sushi I crave and I can leave paying about $25 a person instead of $45+ like most other places with fish this tasty and fresh. BONUS - they bring you a hot towel before your meal like traditional Japanese places :)
author: Morgan M.

description:
This place is my go-to when I am in the city. The fish is fresh, beautifully presented, and the staff is very hospitable. Going down this list of reviews, I read some complaints about how there is not enough fish in the rolls - I have never run into that problem while eating here. Real sushi should be bite size, not ginormous. If you want monster sushi, with less quality fish, eat elsewhere. 

I'LL BE BACK!
author: Alexandra S.

description:
My go-to spot for sushi. The food always tastes good and their service is stellar. What I usually get:

Garlic edamame 
Calamari tempura - super fresh
Dragon roll
Dexter Carter
49er
author: Saba S.

description:
Ebisu has been in the neighborhood long enough that on a Sunday night at 6pm, there is a line of 15 people. Surprisingly, or maybe not surprisingly, Ebisu caters to a non-Japanese crowd. Unless you're into frilly sushi bars that make americanized rolls and fancy fusion-y appetizers, I suggest that you don't go to Ebisu.

First, the prices do not justify the quality of food they're serving. Although they get fresh fish like aji and kanpachi that $10 sushi bars don't get, it's a shame what they do to the fish. 

And I don't think it's excusable to get fish mixed up. Case in point: we ordered hamachi belly twice, separately. First time it came looking light pink, and the second time, more white and fatty. Any idiot can tell that they are not the same cut. Not really a mistake any sushi bar should be making.

Moreover, their "bluefin" tuna was obviously frozen and defrosted, god knows how many times, or more likely the case, it wasn't bluefin at all.

For the kind of money Ebisu is charging, I'd rather go to Kazu Sushi and have a more authentic and intimate experience.
author: Sherry L.

description: Great food! We got the dragon roll, spider roll, Kobe beef, along with two dinner combos - chicken teriyaki and salmon. The portions are quite generous as well. Although there was a wait, it was well worth it! Would recommend!
author: Alex L.

description: I was 3rd in line before open with seven in are group.  We sign in even one but us got a a table and I was told sorry no room. I can wait 1 hour for next seating time . Why I was 3 in line . I lady said sorry no room now . And walk away .0
author: Thomas F.

description:
Not sure what happened to the customer service here, but apparently its not a priority to them anymore. I have eaten at Ebisu two other times (long time ago) and it was amazing, but after this recent experience I doubt I will be coming back.

Let me first say the food is superb, but to me having great food
author: Caleb T.

description:
4.5 stars. It's a great value for the price. My friend and I shared the smaller omakase, volcano lobster, tamago, and a large beer for only $27 each (tax and tip included!). The omakase was not mind-blowing, but on other occasions I have seen my friends get delicious chef's creations or fresh market choices from the chalkboard behind the bar. The presentation is beautiful, and you will find yourself ordering more than you expected as you watch other people's rolls come out and find yourself tempted for the same.

Don't be intimidated by the line out the door, as the hostesses are pretty fast at moving it along. That being said, you will not feel rushed through dinner. You will be welcomed with a hot towel and edamame as soon as you are seated. If it's just two or three people in your group, you are likely to be squeezed in at the bar. I wish there were coat hooks for purses or jackets, instead of having to keep it on my lap (else you'll trip the servers behind you). 

Bonus: one of the chefs reminds me of Jiro!
author: Cat N.

description:
I have passed by this place many times and my friend finally just told me we had to go.  I guess it's kinda weird that I went in wanting sushi but fell in love with the miso soup.  I had the deluxe combo and the spicy tuna.  The combo was pretty good.  Spicy tuna was very seasoned.  But I just wanted more of that miso!

Me and my friend sat at the bar. The wait time for two was not too bad.  We grabbed menus so we could decide what we wanted while we waited.  A lot of items on the menu are lunch only, so I feel like we missed out a bit since we came for dinner.

The customer service is great.  The sushi chef at the bar was really friendly.  There was a small mistake on our bill but it was promptly corrected.  Overall, a good experience.  I would like to come back for lunch sometime.
author: Audrey D.

description:
Their Sashimi Combo named Omakase Set, is amazing!  The presentation looks colorfully wonderful and the taste is delectably fresh!  Have it with their clear and clean tasting sake named Mirror Sake, which the waiter suggested, then it is a perfect combo!

You can't go wrong with any of their sushi rolls, either!  Finely drizzled with distinct sauces, combined with sashimi and other whole ingredients, it is delicious!

Service was good to go!

What a long line and wait for a table here during peak hours!  That's my only one main complaint.

Ebisu fulfilled my sushi and sashimi craving!
author: Tiffany D.

description: I would have never found this place but it's a great hidden gem. They are small but we got in pretty quickly and the food was great.
author: S A.

description: Dinner started off nicely. The edamame were perfectly salted. We ordered the dragon roll which was fresh and delicious. Our beef Kobe and shiitake mushroom skewers had a lot of flavor. And then we got our not so great tasting lobster tenpura. For some reason it tasted a little funky, like freezer-burnt. Everything up until that point was fine including the great service. Great restaurant. Probably would've gave them five stars had it not been for the last dish. Take Home: don't get the lobster tenpura.
author: Betty T.

description: Best sushi place in town. My favorite roll is their sunset roll. You would have to wait about 45-60 minutes usually. No reservations so anticipate waiting. Sushi was fresh and made pretty quickly. Great service and good date spot!
author: Kerry K.

description:
This restaurant already has a strong following.

They did a real good job.

Fish was quality. The sushi chefs are pros.

No real wow factor.

A dependable place for a strong value sushi or cooked Japanese meal.
author: Paul N.

description:
I have eaten at Ebisu three times. The first two, i enjoyed spectacular omakase for dinner. At my most recent visit (lunch), my party again ordered omakse (small), and some small plates to share.

The sashimi was not even sliced all the way through. The fatty tuna was, at least, very tasty, but the rest of the selections were dull and flavorless.

I'll go again for dinner-- maybe it's a change-of-service thing-- and update my review.
author: Jake S.

description: Food coma! The master sushi chefs here are true artists at their crafts. Sure, the wait is long, but you have to wait to eat great food, and great it is! The live uni was a hard find anywhere, and I was really looking forward to it on our trip to San Francisco. It came out beautiful as I had seen through the Yelp reviews. The oyster barnaby was just plain amazing  (so amazing that I ended up getting 5 of them). The oysters, monkfish liver, and whatever else we stuffed our faces with were more than enough to send us to food heaven! Highly recommended.
author: Andy N.

description:
I'm a bit hesitant to give this place 5 stars, honestly, relative to what you are getting in the inner sunset, this is definitely 5 stars. I'd say it's somewhere closer to 4.5, but I'm rounding up.

I came here tonight (a Friday night) with a classmate close to 8:45pm. There was a ridiculous "line". By line, I mean you add your name to a list of names on a piece of paper. At first, I was a bit discouraged by the 10 small parties above our name, but it moved quite quickly. The wait really wasn't that long. While we waited, we looked at the menu and decided what to get. 

To be honest, I've been to Kiki, Hotei, Kazu, and Izakaya Sozai and have not been impressed at all with any of the foods. Mediocre at best. Thus, I was pretty skeptical about Ebisu. However, all my presumptions have been destroyed.

Here's what we got:
++Sake Steamed Clams - Dashi sake butter broth - $9
This dish was probably the favourite of the night. The broth was delicious. If you've had belgian mussels, this is the japanese equivalent. Very delicious, and there were a handful of clams.

++Live Scallops with fried something on the side - around $18ish
These scallops were like butter and melted in your mouth. It was really good. I wasn't quite sure what the fried stuff was. I asked but didn't hear, and didn't ask for further clarification. Scallops that melt in your mouth though, omg. Use the lemon.

++Oyster Dynamite - Oysters and sea urchin baked in house dynamite sauce - $11
This dish was okay. It didn't stand out as anything special. It came with 4 pieces and were mounted on a mound of salt. It looks like mashed daikon, but don't be fooled.

++Bincho Tataki - Seared albacore w/ onions, tobiko & ponzu - Small $16
Very flavourful. A little bit too salty for my tastes, but all the other flavours meshed really well. This was a very good dish though. It was nicely seared on the outside, and very tender on the inside. Again, the inside was fresh enough to melt in your mouth.

++Double Hamachi - Yellowtail, Scallion and Tobiko - $14.50
I like hamachi. Lots of hamachi. This sushi was a standard size, with very fresh hamachi. For just the size, 14.50 isn't quite worth it, but you're also paying for the quality of the fish I guess. It was worth getting for sure, but I'll try a different roll next time!

Service was very good. Our table was too small for the amount of food we ordered. We tried to finish some dishes to be cleared away. Water was promptly refilled, tea was refilled, and we were checked on a few times to make sure everything was good. Towards the end, we were checked on quite often. I can appreciate the attentiveness.

Overall:
+Good service
+Fresh fish
+Delicious dishes
-Long wait

I am for sure coming back and I highly recommend this place. It's a bit on the pricer side, but it's worth it. I'm currently contemplating getting the $100 gift card for $85.
author: Kaje Y.

description: Probably the best Japanese food I have ever had in my life. Just go sit at the sushi bar (as we did) and let the sushi masters order their picks for you ( as we did). I don't remember which ones we ate,but each and every one was delicate, fresh and tasty. One I do remember is not sushi,but the miso glazed cod..fantastic!
author: Nikhil R.

description:
Real score is 2.5/5 stars, but I don't mind rounding up to 3 because the staff were so nice. Went on a date here with a guy who had only eaten sushi once before and didn't think he would like it. Nothing else close by was open so we decided to just go for it.

After living in Japan for a while, I know what fresh, high-quality fish tastes, smells, and looks like. I also love sushi (American and traditional Japanese), so I was excited to try this place out considering the reviews.

The ambience was nice, and the service very good (although a bit slow, but it gave us more time to talk). 

He ordered the teriyaki chicken plate as a backup, and we ordered two rolls (49er and Spider) that looked appealing to him. I also ordered inari because I absolutely love it and most American sushi restaurants don't have it.

The teriyaki chicken plate is a very large portion of food as it comes with a nice serving of chicken, a yummy salad, steamed veggies (also very yummy, nicely seasoned and not mushy), and pan-fried potato wedges. Comes with miso soup. Easily enough to feed two people who are hungry but not ravenous. We should have only ordered one roll in hindsight, but we didn't realize the chicken plate would be so big. 

I was pleased that he loved both rolls. The 49er roll was very good and a unique combination because of the lemon and shiso leaf (they have another version of this with added shrimp on the menu as well), I wish the salmon had been fresher but for American fish standards it was good I guess. I did not like the spider roll, the crab meat might have been fake and was not seasoned well... overall, not a very tasty roll in my opinion. Inari was good enough, the agedashi tofu pouch was a bit too salty but I can't complain too much because I was just so happy to have some. The date also liked those too :)

Overall, a good date place because of the atmosphere for sure, and I was so relieved that my date liked the sushi. If you don't have high expectations for sushi you should definitely check it out.
author: Mary B.

description:
We were visiting the area and decided to have Japanese food for lunch.
Being that we were from out of town, I thought the two hour parking option was good enough.  Boy was I wrong.  

Our party was 6 individuals and we waited for an hour and a half and I am so glad we did. 
The food was authentic and fresh.  
We ordered a variety of food like bento box lunches, sushi and donburi.  
The bento boxes had several flavors.  
Who knew potatoes could be made to taste that way?  
The individual responsible showed so much talent.  
The portions were ample.  
The sushi was a balanced portion of rice and fish.  
I have been to Japanese restaurants that aren't authentic hence there was more rice than fish.  The fish in other places were like slivers.  
My kids wanted green tea ice cream and they didn't scrimp on those either.
I had to move the car for additional time so we could savor our meal.

This was an experience and would do it again!
author: C O.

description: I recently just went to this sushi place last night !!! It was my first time eating raw fish and I really enjoyed the flavor and the  cut of The fish . Also the waitress was really supportive and helping me get good choices for starters , the water was clean .  Keep in mind I'm only 12 so make sure you read this !!! Overall I love this place and I'll come back very soon !!! If you don't enjoy raw fish please don't go here ! There is miso soup though that's pretty good ! Please buy sushi!!  I love sushi !!!!!!!!!!!
author: Lucy C.

description:
We found this place on a whim and went in, hoping for a quick dinner. We ended up waiting over 45 minutes for the table, after being told it was a 20 minute wait. Regardless, we were eventually seated. I was surprised by how generously sized the tables were (relative to the size of the restaurant). The restaurant itself was a bit too warm for my liking and certainly detracted from my experience.
 
We ordered five specialty rolls and the Agedashi tofu to share between three people and were pretty content with how full we were. We got the Dragon roll, Spider roll, veggie tempura roll, salmon skin roll, and the XXX (daily special). The fish in the rolls were all really fresh and the rolls were made to order. I loved the aesthetics of the Spider roll in particular, as it was presented with scallions and tempura crumbs adorning the end piece. Most rolls had 8 pieces each though a few had 4-6. Overall I was very impressed by the mix of flavors and textures and consistent quality across the rolls. The Agedashi tofu was crisply battered though not too heavily and the soy sauce blend in which it was served wasn't too salty. It was also served with battered and fried mushrooms, which provided a pleasant contrast in texture.
 
Service was not too slow once we sat down. The waitresses were all very polite. I would give the ambiance 2 stars but the food 4.5 stars. Overall 4 stars.
author: Isabella C.

description:
Great sushi!

I came to Ebisu the other day for dinner with the boyfriend. 

Ordered:
- fresh oysters on the half shell
- live scallop
- ankimo
- Giant's roll (spicy scallop roll topped with ocean trout & black tobiko)
- double hamachi roll

Pros: There is no doubt the sushi is super fresh and delicious here. You are definitely in for a treat. The service is also exceptional and they're always very attentive.

Cons: The restaurant is on the smaller side, so you definitely want to get to the restaurant earlier. 

Side note: This was my second time here and I got really lucky because I was sitting next to a screaming baby. The staff kept on apologizing, but ultimately it really isn't their fault.
author: Denise K.

description:
Came here with the husby and were impressed. Waiting time can be a bit taunting but not too bad. We went during rush hour (was told my hostess) around 7pm. We waited approximately 30min which was much shorter than he had expected.

The room is small. Let's just say if there was a fire. It would be tough to find a way out with everyone crammed in like sardines (my reason of deducting a star). Everyone is sitting nearly elbow to elbow and you can hear every conversation around you clearly. 

On to the service and food. Waitress was very tentative and made our experience worth the wait. Once we got seated, she immediately came over to ask for our drink order. A few minutes later came back and asked if we were ready to order. Talk about giving us enough time to browse the menu. Perfect timing.

Ordered: 

- Omakase (chief special) for 1-2person $28 superb! So fresh and buttery.
- Romeo and Juliet (must try! Melts in your mouth awesomeness) $17.50
- Potato bug ( I think that's what it was called - A LOT of unagi) not a fan. Ordered it because we were craving it but would rather not. It was not ALOT of unagi. Just a slice on top and pieces inside. We were thinking there will be a pile of it. My fault for assuming. $16

Overall bill was approx $61 not including tax and tip

We will definitely come back again
author: Julie B C.

description: All the nigiris were delicious. Hamachi nigiri and salmon toro nigiri were my favorites. My bf and I also had their romeo and juliet roll, it was fresh and we enjoyed the simplicity of it. We had to wait 30 mins during a weekday dinner service, but it was worth the wait. We are definitely going back for more soon.
author: Lacy L.

description:
This is a solid Japanese restaurant in San Francisco. I've always passed by this restaurant and have seen a long line each and every time. So one day, my boyfriend and I decided to eat here. As most Japanese restaurants I know tend to close in between lunch and dinner times, Ebisu was no different.

We arrived at 4:30pm and sat on the bench outside patiently. Little did we know that the doors open for sign in at around 4:40pm! Unfortunately, we got short handed and were after 5 different parties that knew the drill. 

Moreover, the food was excellent. We ordered the Dragon Roll, Uni, and the Sukiyaki.

Dragon Roll- $14.50
Uni- $17.00 /2 pieces
Sukiyaki- $19.00

If you want a great value dish, I suggest ordering the Sukiyaki. The portion was huge and was definitely worth the money. In fact, it was so huge that my boyfriend and I didn't even finish it. We doggy bagged that home!

The sushi. YUM!!! FRESHNESS in every bite! I'm a noob in eating sashimi and such so  I'm still exploring my tastebuds and preferences. However, I do want to note that I've had UNI one other time and I can definitely say Ebisu is SPOT ON with their Uni. It was buttery, fresh, melt in your mouth, seafood goodness. I enjoyed each and every bite! 

In addition to the Uni, my boyfriend ordered the Dragon Roll w/ spicy mayo on the side. This was definitely his favorite! 

Overall, it was a great meal! We really enjoyed the fresh quality of their fish. Also, to note their service is excellent. The waitresses filled our water multiple times throughout our meal and were so attentive if we needed anything.

I'm looking forward in dining again!
author: Briana H.

description:
Oh man. SO GOOD. So so so good.

My family and I were lucky enough to come with a friend who's a regular here and knows the good stuff.

What we ordered:
- Sunrise/Sunset Roll (They're the same but Sunrise has quail egg, Sunset doesn't)
- 49er Roll
- Spicy Tuna Roll
- 2 balls 1 strike Roll
- $50 Sashimi

Everything was amazing. DEFINITELY try the Sunrise or Sunset Roll (depending on whether you like quail egg), the 49er roll, and the 2 balls 1 strike roll. Seriously cannot wait to come back here.
author: Amanda L.

description:
I've been to Ebisu a few times, for both lunch and dinner, and I'm quite satisfied with what they have to offer. They have quite an extensive menu, so I'd advise against looking through every single option because you'd just be wasting your time. Ebisu has a lot of choices for sashimi, nigiri, and specialty rolls, along with appetizers, udon, and bento box meals. The restaurant is small and tables are very close together. There's bar seating as well, where you get to order directly from the sushi chef instead of a waiter/waitress.

If you like variety in a meal, I recommend the lunch or dinner combo bento boxes, at $15 or $20, respectively. They're excellent deals and contain enough food for up to two people! The meal includes miso soup, rice, green salad, seaweed salad, cooked spinach salad, and three entrees. The entree options include shrimp and vegetable tempura, teriyaki salmon, chicken, or beef, fried oyster, sashimi, or maki sushi. There's quite a selection here.

I've tried the Omakase dinner set, which is the chef's selection of sashimi. It's priced at $25 (serves one to two people) or at $50 (serves three or four people). In reality, if you love sashimi, get the $25 set all for yourself because it's enough for one person. The sashimi selection varies, but most of the time, maguro and sake are included.

I haven't been very pleased with some of the specialty sushi options here. I tried the Boston Roll (salmon, cucumber, avocado, crab and tobiko) and the 49er Roll (salmon, avocado, tobiko, shiso, and lemon). The Boston Roll had imitation crab, which was a huge disappointment. And the 49er roll had too much rice so that the fish to rice ratio was off.

Ebisu offers expensive, but still considered affordable, sushi. Quality is fresh. Service friendly. Restaurant is a bit small and there can be some wait time during busy hours. Nevertheless, Ebisu is my go-to Japanese restaurant in the Inner Sunset!
author: Priscilla W.

description:
I now consider myself a regular here. I hope to be a regular as much as Roberto. If you're a regular, you'll know who Roberto is. I wish I could give this place 10 stars. Or more. This is hands down one of two of my favorite places in the city to get the freshest nigiri and delicious rolls. I'm not a fan of fancy fusion rolls anymore. Most menus of sushi places are full of over-riced (and over-priced!), not fresh fish topped with some "special sauce" to cover up the non-freshness. Not here. Not up in here! When I do feel like a roll, I go with the Go Giants! roll or the Dexter Carter. I only sign up for the bar. I accept no less.

My go-to nigiri list: 
-otoro
-amaebi
-bluefin
-saba
-hamachi

You MUST also get the aji. Ask for the fried body. And eat it! 

Bottom line, if you want the tastiest, freshest sushi, come here. If not, save me the wait time and go home! Or go risk food poisoning at one of the many inferior sushi joints crowding up the city's food scene.
author: Kaliah C.

description:
So so good! I ordered a spider roll sandwiched in between two pieces each of uni, toro and unagi. The spider roll was large and colorful, perfectly fried and delicious. I swallowed the uni whole, savoring every chew as it exploded in a buttery potent flavor reminiscent of the sea. It was amazing.

If you want no pretension, good quality sushi with knowledgeable chefs trained in the Edo style, with a simple yet vibrant ambience, visit Ebisu.

In Search of Uni | The Secret of My SucCecil https://secretofmysuccecil.com/2016/02/20/in-search-of-uni/
author: Cecil P.

description: My Gf loves sushi and for her bday I told her to pick whatever restaurant she wants. She ended up picking this place, the sushi tasted nice and fresh. We ordered uni, hamachi toro, Kobe beef, scallop, mirugai, bluefin toro, and some oyster appetizer thing everything tasted delicious. We only ordered one roll the Family affair. It was so good and I love how they don't put a lot of rice when they make rolls. Only a little rice and the fish. The  best was when they surprised my gf and sang happy birthday to her and provided her with ice cream. They don't take reservations, the restaurant is small, so expect a wait. Other then that the wait staff is pretty attentive, and I highly recommend you sit in the bar table for a greater experience.
author: Ralph O.

description: San Francisco has almost as many sushi places as parking meters at this point, but Ebisu is hands down my favorite! I would appreciate it if they had reservations, but I will wait for them. For lunch, I am a huge fan of the chirashi bowl (the mushroom!!! - you will understand what I mean once you try it). For dinner, you have to go ahead and try as many sushi rolls as you can and sashimi (freshest in the bay). They also have some nice sake flights, which I have had the pleasure of trying a few of. You simply can't go wrong here.
author: Nikita K.

description: We decided to try Ebisu since my boyfriend and I were having a sushi craving. This place did not disappoint. This restaurant is a bit cramped & crowded in which you need to have patience if waiting in front. We were seated at the bar and I am glad we did. We had a little entertainment with our dinner. We were able to order our sushi at the bar and watch our sushi rolls being made. The sushi chefs were all so friendly interacting with most of the customers. My favorite was the 49er roll. Fish was fresh, restaurant was clean, and it was fun to see the chefs use their torch to caramelize some of the sushi rolls. I'd come back here again.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
One of the better sushi places I've been to - highly recommend it. Everything was fresh and well made. Some highlights:

- Kakuni Appetizer (Pork Belly): Wow, just perfect! Very juicy and not too fatty. Far exceeded my expectations.
- Omakase (for 2): Beautiful presentation of an assortment of sashimi. All fresh fish, but the winner was the salmon - melts in your mouth, 5 stars... the best I've ever had!!

Courteous and attentive service. The restaurant has a nice modern/wood look and is on the smaller side with the main area looking a little tight. Our table was separate from the main area which was nice. We arrived on the earlier side and didn't have to wait. Parking is tough.
author: Josh L.

description:
Finally made it over to this legendary Japanese restaurant and I am happy to say it was worth it.

The wait is a little long and the restaurant is tight and cramped, but the food is phenomenal. I'd even venture to say that it's the best Japanese food in San Francisco. Their sushi options are vast and their dinner items are big in portions. If you have some time and you can make a night out of it, venture into that area and put your name on the list. There are plenty of shops around the area to kill time at.

Their combination dinners are great for getting a diverse taste of the many different things on their menu.
author: Bradley C.

description: I came here for the first time about a month ago on a double date. This place was recommended to us by a friend and he said its the best sushi he's ever had. He did tell us to get there at 5pm exactly because it gets packed. We had just left Golden Gate park which is right across the way so we must of gotten there at like 5:05. It was already packed. I could not believe it. There was a wait for a table or we could site at the bar. So we sat at the bar while the sushi makers made their Sochi right in front of us. I had some fresh oysters. Delicious. I also had the steak tofu and it was amazing. My husband and I shared a roll that had some mango in it and it was like a party in my mouth. I never would of that of having mango in my sushi but it somehow worked. This place is at the top.
author: Priscilla R.

description:
I think I found another favorite sushi joint!  sushi, sashimi, price, quality and service on point!

omakase for two - $25 - yummy. fresh slices of fish with a nice variety. I wouldn't say it's one of the best omakase in order of speciality of fish, but definitely worth $25 of many fresh slices of sashimi.. I like.

mud pie $10 - fried uni wrapped in seaweed - save your $10 it was not my cup of tea, I think uni raw is the best.

dragon roll - one of the most nicely presented rolls. good amount of unagi, avocado and tempura. very tasty and not too much rice.

lunch bento box $15 - chicken teriyaki and tempura.  comes with miso soup and rice. good piece of white meat chicken that was moist and nicely glazed. a lot of sides in this box. green section with seaweed salad, sautéed spinach and another type of green veggie.  tempura was a bit soggy though, but fresh veggies I do like.

monkfish liver $10 - yummy and meant to be shared with two or three people. fatty slices and delicious topped with radish and yuze or ponzu sauce(?)

udon ebisu - chicken, veggies and tempura with udon in cask iron bowl. this was probably the most disappointing dish and DO NOT ORDER the udon.  everything else was great, but this udon just did me wrong. soggy noodles and nothing special about the udon :/  looks were deceiving and just it worth the $14 bucks. 

service - superb! dishes came literally all at once in ten minutes. super friendly servers and refilled water multiple times without even having to ask!  service was one of he best for such a packed lunch hour! 

I also love the interior of this place and its a cute date night kind of place. everything inside is like a little wooden tea house.  with all the fresh sashimi and quality of food and quantity, it didn't break the bank too much and I would definitely come here again :)
author: Josie L.

description:
This is my go-to sushi place in SF; I end up returning about 15 times a year. With all the positive reviews here and the 15-45 minute wait time (especially on Fri/Sat), I don't think I'm alone in this opinion. Probably best to get there early/when they open, or the later seating periods.

Most important for a sushi joint, the fish is always fresh and of high quality, and the rice done perfectly. They also have quite a selection of fairly unique rolls. For the most interesting experience, I recommend sitting at the sushi bar, and (if you're open to trialing food you normally wouldn't order on your own and aren't strictly budgeting) go omakase and let the chef guide your experience. All the chefs are skilled and personable.

If you choose to forego sushi or focus on cooked foods, everything is seasoned and cooked well, and the portions are very generous for the quality. My personal favorites are the hamachi kama appetizer and kurobuta pork special (though they may not be offering that at this time). Even the beef teriyaki is above par; it's practically a steak with teriyaki seasoning. 

The atmosphere's pretty casual, it's definitely close quarters and high volume. I still recommend for a casual date night, family dinner, hangout with friends, or just if you're in the mood for sushi. Groups of 6 or less are probably best, though I recall seeing a group of 10-12 every once in a while.
author: Mack W.

description:
I came here awhile ago to try the Kobe beef sashimi and nigiri and ended up discovering something else even more amazing.. The oyster dynamite! My friend and I loved everything we ordered but there were two that really stood out to us! The decor was pretty and it wasn't too packed when we got there! Arrived right when they opened and were seated immediately :) 

Highlights:

Service was real nice. They kept coming back to make sure everything was okay and going well. 

Kobe Beef Nigiri - YUMM! It was real good by itself and with the sauce!

Oyster Dynamite - DELICIOUS. We didn't plan on it, but we ended up ordering a second one. Maybe a third one too.. I really don't remember but it was BOMBBBB.
author: Fiona H.

description: THE BEST SUSHI IN SF! Amazing staff. Amazing chefs. Worth the wait. DO NOT SKIP. I could go everyday and night
author: Chelsea S.

description: I really like the sushi. The special roll from the chef is my favorite. Also 29 roll is pretty good.
author: Katherine V.

description:
Yes!! Finally found our go-to sushi spot in the city. Ebisu puts the rest to shame.

Melt in your mouth fish
Cool interior
Friendly, fun sushi chefs
Incredibly decent prices

We'll be back and back and back for more. Already looking forward to it
author: Sarah G.

description: Strongly recommend the wagyu, Aji sushi/sashimi, and Gindara. Those are the highlight of the day!! By the way the decor is so traditional!!! Love it.
author: Annabelle L.

description: I took my fiance here for her birthday last month, and she LOVED it. The crispy salmon hand roll was one of our faves. Sitting at the bar was quite the experience. For a moment, we forgot we were in SF. It felt "authentic" and we can't wait to go back!
author: Cindy V.

description:
Hell yeah. This was exactly what I was looking for in SF while I was there for a short trip. It's a short walk from the gorgeous golden gate park. And the prices are quite reasonable. The sashimi was some of the sweetest, most creamy fish I have ever had in my life. I also loved the rolls too. I liked the 49er and family affair. The interior is simple, yet chic and clean.

I lucked out and got a table Saturday early afternoon. It filled up very fast. Worth the wait though.
author: Jean S.

description:
Dropped in to Ebisu for a late lunch with my significant.  Enthusiastically greeted with warm smiles around.  Sat at Sushi counter and marveled at all the fresh sashimi! 
Many choices menu.  Decided on the two persons Omakaze special and Pork Tonkatsu, Gyoza,  Vegetables tempura combo.
Nice presentation, good portions, and delicious to match!
Good service! Fair prices! Good atmosphere!  Highlight was meeting the Boss again and exchanging warm pleasantries! 
Needless to say,  we recommend and will return to enjoy!
author: Kay L.

description: Best bento I have ever tasted ! Great quality food, very balanced tastes, reasonable prices ! A bit of rush in the service, but definitely, I will stop by again
author: Constant P.

description:
One of my favorite sushi places so far! Tried this place one night after seeing it on my Instagram feed and decided to just go for it. 

My friend and I ordered three rolls:

- 49ers roll: Love this. It was refreshing, the lemon was cut at just the right thickness (or thinness) and the salmon was fresh. 

- Family Affair: This was my favorite roll of the night! I was skeptical to try this at first, given that it comes with onions and I'm not a very big fan of onions, but it was delicious. There's just something about it that had me hungry for more after we devoured the roll. 

- Romeo & Juliet: not my cup of tea, to be honest. It was just not as tasty as I had hoped for it to be after reading Yelp reviews and asking our waiter about it when he recommended it to us. 

But, aside from the last roll, the fish on the rolls we ordered tasted fresh - not super fishy like it had just come out of the ocean, but it was really good, cut right, and it seemed like it had the right proportion of fish, rice, and other ingredients that came with the rolls. 

What's different about these Ebisu rolls is that they don't use seaweed! Or at least in the rolls that we ordered, but it tasted great. We didn't notice that there wasn't seaweed until we were halfway finished eating. 

We also ordered the Ebisu udon... Don't get it. Save yourself the money. 

We left the restaurant craving for it the next day. But, you know, we had to stop ourselves. It's too soon haha. 

Next time, we're looking forward to trying the Omakase, Kobe beef sashimi and Uni!

I recommend this place for sushi lovers. It will change your life. Well, it changed mine. Can't really speak for yours. Haha
author: Vanessa M.

description: Be prepared to wait in line! We got here around 6 on a Friday night, after a friend told us there would be a line starting around then. There were around 15 groups in front of us so we headed around the corned to a bakery to get some snacks to curb my appetite, cause let's be real, who wants to have date night with a hangry person. After my belly was full, we headed back (maybe a half hour later) and learned they had already called our name! Luckily, their policy is that if they skip you, just let them know when you come back and they will drag you next (so nice!) we got seated at the bar which I highly recommend. The sushi chefs were friendly and outgoing and extremely attentive. We tried multiple pieces of nigiri, the Kobe beef appetizer and the Hanukkah roll with smoked salmon. The quality of the fish was unreal. So fresh and tasty! I was really pleasant surprises with the Kobe beef as well, even though the idea of eating raw beef kind of weird as me out a bit. That thought went away as soon as I took my first bite. The sauce they give you for this app is killer too. I will definitely be back  to try the omakase since I barely scratched the surface of their extensive menu.  Definitely check out their specials of the day!
author: Sam L.

description:
Lunch, dinner, and to-go at Ebisu is usually reserved for a special treat - birthdays, reunion with high school friends, I am sure you get the picture. But going a few times has allowed me to try Ebisu's appetizers, entrees, rolls, sashimi and sushi.

The food at Ebisu is pricey but the food is always good, not mind-shattering fantastic but it satisfies my Japanese craving. I have tried: Two Balls No Strike, Oysters on the 1/2 Shell, Gindara, Salmon Teriyaki, Chirashi, Live Uni, XXX Roll, Chef's Special Roll, Double Hamachi, Behind the Green Door, Crunchy, Family Affair, and an assortment of nigiri.

Service is a hit or miss and it is usually packed. Luckily the times I dined here, I have not had to wait more than 10 minutes for a table. Parking is the most agonizing part about eating at Ebisu because it is so difficult to find.

What I recommend:
-- gindara
-- two balls no strike
-- live uni
author: Andrew W.

description: This place is good, but not GREAT in my opinion. Husband loves this place a lot cos of their nigiri. I love the dinosaur feet for appetizers. It's shrimp wrapped in shisho leaves and fried in tempura batter. SO good. The bento boxes are great as well but a bit pricey. If you come here, be sure to try the kobe beef nigiri and have them SEAR it. I have to say that it's really good! Great customer service too.
author: jessica t.

description: Tried some uni, albacore toro, and salmon sashimi. Best thing was the albacore toro, the presentation and bit of citrus was very harmonious. The uni was shockingly cold and didn't have the best taste. And the salmon sashimi was standard. Ended up paying around $40 for the meal. Wished I had just saved my money to go to Kusakabe for their omakase.
author: Binh P.

description:
Whenever we're in SF, my husband make a bee-line for Ebisu. It's the combination of incredible freshness, fantastic flavors and attentive service in a cozy, clean environment that makes this our favorite sushi spot in the city. 

I don't know that I can say anything that the other 1200 reviews haven't already, but I know this: their salmon is outrageously great, and so smooth and tender it's like butter. Also, the miso soup is perfection -- delicate, salty and tasting slightly of the sea. If you're not up for raw fish (or unable to eat it for the moment, like my pregnant self), the gyoza are an excellent option -- steamed or fried. I was also really excited about their generously-sized and delicious house salad, which is very reasonably priced, especially for the freshness and portion you get. 

The space is really comfortable and simple -- clean, not a ton of room, but very well managed with a sushi bar that runs the length of the place. There's plenty of table seating, but I don't know that I'd come here with a huge group. 

If you don't have a ton of time to dawdle over your meal, fret not as you can get in and out of here for lunch in less than 30 minutes, if you need to. We had a huge meal in the early afternoon and were pleased with how prompt and efficient the service was. Big bonus, especially during a hectic or cramped work day!
author: Hilary H.

description:
Fresh fish and delicious ingredients. 
The room is small and noisy but the kitchen make you forget everything. 
It is not kids friendly.
author: Marilia F.

description: Masters of their craft in delicate culinary arts and manifested with outstanding decadence .
author: Justin L.

description:
+ THE FOOD
HANDS DOWN best salmon sashimi I've ever had!! I had a half order of the salmon sashimi, half order of the octopus sashimi, and the asari miso. The salmon was so fresh and the texture simply melted in my mouth. I definitely wish I ordered more of this. The octopus was a bit too tough for me to chew on. Even though it was really thinly sliced already, they natural texture of the octopus was really tough but it had great flavors nonetheless. The asari miso was delicious but I thought there would be a stronger flavor. I also tried some of my friend's cold tofu appetizer and it came in such large portions! I would have preferred eating the agedashi tofu instead since the cold tofu fell apart easily. 

- THE PRICES
Prettttty dang expensive. The salmon sashimi came to be $2/piece as it was $8 for a half order. The other appetizers were decently priced around $4-5. The sashimi was definitely worth the price but I wouldn't be coming to this place every week because I can't afford it!
author: Cindy C.

description: Two stars because our servers were attentive. We came here for dinner a few nights ago, and were not very pleased with our experience. I had called in prior to arriving to ask if we needed reservations. The older woman told me they did not accept reservations, and it was "First come first serve", that was understandable. I asked how long the wait was, she told me 30-40mins. We arrived 10mins later at 7:50pm. I signed in, and waited with my party of 3. At the 40min mark, I got up and asked the older woman how much longer, she said "A couple mins." I couldn't help but notice she was seating groups that were coming in after us, because they were parties of 2. She had done this with (3) other parties that came in, and signed in after us. When I got up to ask about this, she brushed me off and ignored my question. We were finally seated at 8:50pm, we had been there an hour waiting! My poor son was starving! They seated us at a table in the middle of the room, with an awkward beam cutting off the table. We were able to order our food quickly and the staff was very pleasant. We ordered several rolls and an Omikase platter. Although some of the fish was good, other cuts of fish were not. Some were still frozen in the middle. We were not impressed and the food was definitely not worth the wait. We will not be coming back here.
author: Steph T.

description:
One of the best sushi places I've ever eaten at!!!
So fresh and so tasty!

Highly recommend  it! Sashimi sampler was really good and so were the fancier rolls! The grilled hamachi was also very tasty! 

The staff was very friendly and the place was very clean. I'm definitely coming back here.
author: Mary J.

description:
Wow. I can see why there are so favorable reviews!

Expect a wait. I'd suggest arriving at Ebisu as soon as it's open. I came here by myself last nite and the wait to sit at the sushi bar was about 25 minutes. 

As with any sushi restaurant, I like and aim to sit at the sushi bar. Once you do at Ebisu, be sure to ask to sit near Julio the sushi chef, he works Tues to Sat. Julio was very friendly and personable and truly made the eating experience worthwhile. He was very in tune to what my preferences were and provided me with some options.  Through his recommendations, I enjoyed the hamachi toro, albacore toro, and the aji (Spanish mackerel).

They do have omakase - which I will do next time - and price points are $25 and $50.

The Ebisu nigiri is okay, the toros are amazing!

Pricing wise, I'd say Ebisu is a little above average but you're getting access to a wide variety of sushi that I feel are the most abundant versus other sushi spots.

Another reason to love Ebisu, they have a rewards card program!  Ask for the rewards card when you're ready to pay the bill and then you can start earning points.
author: John M.

description:
They don't take reservations, but we called in 15 minutes before we got there to put our names on the list.  We were seated within 10 minutes!  We got the following items:

Tofu Agedashi - Good-sized portion and it comes with a tasty hot sauce/broth.  It's a great appetizer.

Hamachi, Uni, and Aji- Fresh and delicious - 2 pieces each.

Salmon skin hand roll - Generous helping of salmons skin through the entire roll.

Rainbow Roll - Good options to have a variety of fish.  My favorite is always the hamachi.  8 pieces.

Spider Roll - 4 pieces.  I've had better spider rolls.  It was a bit dry and tasted mostly like batter.

Matcha Creme Brulee - The concept is interesting, but a  bit bland and flavorless.  I mostly enjoyed the hard caramel layer on top.  It comes with two green tea cookies.

Overall, the sushi was fresh and the service was good.  It cost about $100 between 2 people for the food, sake, and 2 beers.  Definitely worth coming back, but will make sure to call the restaurant early to put names on the list!
author: Helen T.

description: Cute restaurant with very good food. Aesthetic was on point, and very clean. Good service and filled with nice people!
author: Lina O.

description: Excellent sushi, fresh and delish....Service is below average. Reservation are not accepted expect to wait.
author: Adelaide B.

description:
Came here based on friends recommendations.  Tried 6 rolls, only one of them was pleasantly tasty.  Miso soup was great. 

The crunch roll was really bad.  We paid more than $40 each person and it was not worth it. Compared to other sushi places in SF, Ebisu can do a lot better.  

The restaurant was so steamy, warm and smelled too fishy inside. 

.
author: Ahmad A.

description:
Ebisu is my favorite Japanese restaurant in SF!
FRESH fish and special offerings you expect from a big city restaurant. 



Tonight I had the Chirashi and the oyster appetizer. My stomach was comfortably full.

You will not be disappointed, oh and the natives eat here, so that's always a good sign!
author: Karen S.

description: We found this place based on great reviews on Yelp and was very excited to try new sushi place. The service was good, but the sushi are far from great. The quality and taste of them was very disappointing, the sushi were falling apart, bad quality and too little fish. We went out we the disgusting after-taste and ended up eating ice-cream to get rid of it. Not recommended.
author: Arina N.

description: I must say our visit was a bit disappointing.  Last time I was there must be over 15 years ago.  I was so excited that we finally get to go back.   The Romeo and Juliet roll and the agedashi tofu were both very tasty.   However, all the fish we ordered were just so so.   The 3 orders of hamachi toro @$9.50 was the most disappointing.   I even asked the chef if he gave me regular hamachi instead of toro.   None of the other nigiri we ordered impressed me either.   Ebisu will no longer be a restaurant that I crave to go back to
author: Renee Y.

description: I've been missing this place my whole life lol. Went there yesterday just to try out new restaurant, it was not a disappointment!!! The Dragon roll is literally the best I had, very crunchy, tastes fresh, and was very flavorful. The Kobe beef yakitori, very tasty, and wow it was amazing!!! The grilled squid was cooked to perfection. Service was amazing. These server girls are what others should follow. Japanese people are the most polite and respectful people in the world!!!
author: Range B.

description: I had the chirashi bowl and it was AMAZING. Good vibes, was craving sashimi, and came here  with a friend to catch up. Might be biased because of the good atmosphere but the food tasted amazing so 5 stars!
author: Victoria C.

description:
With their impeccable service and food, I can see why there's always a line out the door.  My bf and I ordered the Oyster Dynamite (very tasty), Omakase (my favorite! and the fish is fresh) and last but not least their Sukiyaki (kobe beef with veggies and fish cakes was good)  It sort of reminds me of Shabu and it was a pretty big portion.

Overall, I enjoyed the food and the service. I will definitely recommend this place to my friends and family.  

Since I like this place so much, i already know what I would like to order next time. Instead of ordering the $25 Omakase, i'm going to order the $50 Omakase.  I was told there's additional fish selection that's not included in the $25 order.
author: Amy T.

description:
BEST. SUSHI. EVER. So fresh.

I highly recommend making reservations prior to cause this place be packed! The space is tight so you'll most likely be squeezed into a space a tad too small but so worth it. Make sure your entire party is there or they won't seat you. Not great for large groups. 

My friend ordered the Romeo and Juliet specialty roll and I totally devoured it. (Sorry JJ!) The waitress was very accommodating of my gluten allergic and made sure nothing we had would kill me. I still dream of this sushi.
author: Lily M.

description:
If u want to eat the best sushi in town, o to Ebisu. 
The presentation of the plates are awesome. 
They are delicious !!! And the owners with employers are super nice and gentle. 
They can help you to choose if u don't know and also they teach how to use the chopsticks. 
If u want to eat sushi don't doubt to go there!
author: Agostina D.

description: It was wonderful, neat and clean place with tasty food
author: Imran M.

description:
This is a review for the Saba Nigiri. I also ordered a few rolls, but I think that a sushi restaurant is only as good as how well they prepare their nigiri (and saba is my favorite). The saba was very fresh and tasty. The rice did not fall apart and was well seasoned with white vinegar. My only complaint is that the actual piece of fish felt a little tough (as if it was in the fridge and did not thaw long enough).

The rolls I ordered were the Swamp Roll and the Double Hamachi roll. The rolls were well made and did not fall apart. The rolls were tasty. The oranges that came at the very end were also very sweet!

I will have to go back and try the rest of the menu!

Pros:
- Solid standard specialty rolls
- Nigiri was well prepared
- Service was amazing
author: Jeff M.

description:
This does cost more than other sushi joints but you do pay for the quality. Beautiful presentation of food. Delicious and exciting. Feels little tight in restaurant.

Give me sake 
and sushi
and
I will have a 
good time.

never get tired of it.
author: Veranna N.

description:
It doesn't get better than Ebisu!

Be prepared to wait a little but once sat, the service is great. Fresh sushi at a reasonable price. Sushi is never cheap, and we felt like we could have been charged way more for the variety and quality of the fish.

I recommend sitting at the sushi bar! We got recommendations for the best dishes of the day and enjoyed watching the chefs.

We got:

Sushi
Chef's Special*
Family Affair*

Cold appetizers
Ankimo (steamed monkfish liver)
Kobe Sashimi*

Nigiri
Hamachi toro (yellowfish belly)
Sake toro (salmon belly)*
Sake (salmon)
Bincho (albacore)
Umi Masu (ocean trout)
Hirame (halibut)


*Standouts: Family Affair, Sake Toro, Chef's Special, Kobe Sashimi

The rolls were perfectly balanced, not too much rice.

Will definitely go back to try more sushi and the Kushiyaki (skewers). If you do not mind a wait, I can't recommend Ebisu enough!
author: Sophie C.

description:
I seriously LOVE this place!  The sushi is so fresh and the flavors are succulent. The staff work as fast as they can to prepare you your meals and constantly check on you. I am very please with their customer service. Even though they tend to be really busy and there is almost always a wait, it is totally worth it. If you drink, they serve beverages while you wait so it isn't that bad.

A roll I suggest you try is the Romeo and Juliet Roll. This is a  Salmon, Avocado, topped with Scallop, Tobiko and Japanese Mayo. So yummy!!  ALSO, try the Family Affair Roll. This is Tuna, Avocado, topped with  Albacore, Maui Onions, Negi,
Tobiko and Spicy Aioli. Delicious. FYI, posted a photo of this roll.
author: Elysha O.

description: Get the dynamite oysters!! The staff is great, the food is better. Only thing I couldn't wish to be different is a bigger resteraunt because the seating is pretty limited. But worth the wait!
author: Brittany A.

description:
My favourite sushi restaurant in town!

Everything is very fresh and the chefs are so nice.

The only downside is the huge waiting list, but again, it's understandable, given that the food quality is so high.
author: Andreea C.

description:
Really awesome Japanese restaurant.  To have a 5 star experience here, you absolutely have to try the appetizers.  We literally made a meal of it.  

Some of the absolute musts:
-Pink cadillac (scallops wrapped in salmon)
-Sake clams - FAVORITE dish of the evening
-Sake sampler
author: Alyx F.

description: The food here was good however I felt really ripped off by the potato bug roll that stated there was A Lot of Eel in it in the description. It was 17.50. When the roll showed up we were shocked at the regular looking amount of Eel on it. I told the waitress it was false advertising, but she didn't do anything about it.
author: Tanya S.

description: It's good, not great. Most sushi is about the same anywhere, so you'd be hard pressed to really tell the difference here. A bit high in my book but perhaps fair to others. Bonus: if you have special requests like inari or futomaki, they'll accommodate.
author: Andrew R.

description: My favorite sushi restaurant and it has been that way for over 10 years! It is a family owned and run restaurant. We love sitting at the sushi bar and ordering omakase from Eric (the son). We have had them cater our partys and Steve (the owner) did an outstanding job! Leave your phone number at the front desk and head over to Yancy's bar on Irving (old school). Definatly a locals favorite!
author: Brayton F.

description:
A w e s o m e

Came here randomly and we were not disappointed! Really cute interior, really really friendly service. :) Even though we were the last ones in the restaurant (oops) they did not rush us and were really kind and friendly. I definitely want to come back again!

And the food... wow!!

- Salmon Sashimi= SO FRESH! So good!!! Beats any of the regular sushi places I go to, by far. I'd give 6 stars if I could!

- Miso Soup= So refreshing, not salty and overbearing at all

- Fried Chicken Wings appetizer = REALLY really good. Very simple but still very flavorful and delicious!

- Family Affair roll = wow. SO delicious. Really really fresh, really delicious. Wowwie!!

We got one more roll (it was a house special), but cannot remember what it was called. It was really fresh and delicious too~ but the Family Affair roll really outshined it.

Really loved it here! Please come check it out! :)
author: Sophie S.

description:
After a whole day of pizzas I needed something light.. and Japanese was a perfect choice for that.  Having enjoyed sushi bar experiences in the past we opted for the sushi bar so that we could order chef's special dishes.  I don't think we really requested anything other than "recommendation by the chef".  The dishes given were delicious ... and did I mention delicious? I think I did ask for blue fin tuna toro but that request I don't think was fulfilled (hence the minus 1 star).  

All in all great Japanese restaurant and recommended!
author: Sujan H.

description: Best sushi restaurant in SF! Long wait though, so go 15-30 mins earlier than you'd like to be seated. Earlier the better! Parking is miserable. The salmon nigiri was decadent.
author: Stephanie T.

description: Great. Been here for years & people know of this spot. Always busy but turnover is quick so you write your name on a list & can definitely get in within the hour. Also dynamite sushi! Friendly staff (although sometimes hard to hail because of business), knowledgable sushi chefs, great specials & plentiful variety!
author: Lindsey D.

description:
My table popped in around 1:50pm, ten minutes before they close for lunch and were quickly seated. The waitresses were very kind and patient, but were visibly trying to clean up as many of the other tables as possible. Hence, they were a bit more forgetful and inattentive. I did really enjoy the interior decorations and the intimate setting. It's perfect for small groups of 4-5. 

We tried the Dragon Roll and it was decadent. I'm definitely not a foodie, but enjoyed the balance of flavors. However, the price is definitely high for the size. 

I also got to try the beef sukiyaki, which the waitress recommended. Sukiyaki is essentially clear noodles in savory broth, with veggies (napa cabbage,  tofu, carrots) & meat (choice of chicken or beef with some fishcake) served in an iron pot. The dish is more on the sweet side and comes with rice and miso soup. I expected there to be more noodles, but there was only a pinch of it. I've never had sukiyaki before and did not have anything to compare it to. Anyways, the bowl is consider large for one person so share if you can and order something on the side. I liked how the beef were thinly sliced and the portion of it was generous. However, I didn't like how the pot was essentially boosted up by the insane amount of napa cabbage under it. For the value, I'd take down a star. 

I think I would return to try more of their sushi rolls.
author: Priscilla C.

description:
Sorry guys - 3 stars from me is an issue, but here is some info so that you may improve and issues that a $35 lunch for two should not experience

-Seat requests denied, twice, as lunch was ending - restaurant had plenty of space
-Asked for water and tea, 4 times, literally
-Instead of processing check, looking at cell phone
-Questions about the menu? Misunderstood.
-Eye contact from staff, non-existent
-More interested in cleaning condiment containers and getting people out of the restaurant than servicing clients
-Areas of the restaurant have heavy perfumed scent - why?

The food? Pretty darn good... But the attitude was just strange from the start. Don't get it. Perhaps it permeates from the top - within the menu it tells you how you are supposed to enjoy sushi and how they serve the proper amounts...

Service was the same from every staff person.
author: John G.

description:
Been meaning to try this place for a long time. Didn't think my friends would be down because I felt like this place would be expensive but they were down.

Decor is simple, staff is really attentive and polite. 

There were three of us. We ordered the edamame trio and a bunch of rolls of which I forgot the names of. We ordered like 5 rolls. I only remember the one I wanted which was the Crunchy Roll. 

The edamame was good. I liked the lime one best. I liked all of the rolls we ordered. Fast, clean, good presentation. I liked the Crunchy Roll best because of the texture. 

There was one roll we ordered. It looked wild and I didn't really know how to approach eating it but it was good. I wish I remembered all the names. 

Everything was good and I thought it was decently priced. I can't give exact prices because a friend paid for it in my place. 

I'd go back for more though. I'm sure the price is worth it.
author: Sofia R.

description:
LIVE UNI!


http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1K_lFglA5fOYquqltYcdg#TdNnlS5j6Wh-gAsf0Ji_qg
(I think I just Died.....)

Unfortunately They ran out of Fresh Kobe Beef Sashimi.
Deluxe Sashimi was pretty good, Fresh Seafood.

Service was well presentable, friendly and Quick.

Worth the wait if you like raw seafood.

And by celebrating for my 600th REVIEW!, this is what I DO!. GO BIG!
author: Helena H.

description: One of my most favorite Sushi places in San Francisco.  I always come here for my birthday and have never had a bad experience in the last seven years, I highly recommend getting the 2 balls no strikes for the appetizer.  It's Tuna and avocado heaven and worth the price!  It is a pricey place, but you're getting your money's worth.  I've sat at the Sushi bar and at the tables, and either is a great experience.  I recommend this place for a nice date night, or even for groups of 4 to 6. A+
author: Arman J.

description: Very nice neighbourhood restaurant, extremely good quality sushi. Owner is always at the restaurant making sure the patrons are satisfied. The sushi chefs are quick, efficient and friendly. Servers move around constantly making sure your plates are cleared and taking care of your needs. I highly recommend a try if you have not been there.
author: Wailun L.

description: this place is solid, but it's not ORGASMIC. It's nice inside, the dishes and sushi are good, but nothing life altering making me want to ditch every single japanese restaurant I've ever visited. Not to mention, I know one of their suppliers, so I'll leave it at that.
author: Aaron C.

description:
I'm going to give an extra star for the service and the freshness of the food...  But this place is way overhyped and can't understand why it's crazy busy all the time...  We went through the gauntlet of the usual suspects just out of curiousity; 

- spicy tuna = uninspiring, bland and not even the slightest hint of "spicy"... 
- King California roll = I'll let the photos do the talking, it looked like a five year old put the roll together, and then someone decided to cut the rolls with a dull butter knife or a hatchet...
- Kobe beef = overcooked...  That's almost criminal in some states...  

Toro seemed fresh, dragon roll was well received but the quality and taste of the rolls left much to be desired...  This should not be in the top contenders in San Francisco...  Top of my list so far is Saru...  While slightly more expensive and the service might not be as sharp as Ebisu, the taste and presentation are both top notch... 

Not wanting to take away from the employees here though, they are five star all the way...  Very tentative even when the place is packed...  Someone just needs to sharpen the hatchet used to cut the sushi...
author: Tristan L.

description:
Ebisu, you beautiful gem.

My boyfriend took me here for a Saturday lunch! It was pretty busy, but we were able to snag the last open table before the wait started. Be forewarned, this place is TINY! there's not even 10 tables and about 8 seats at the bar. But definitely not a turn off. It made it very comfortable. The decor is very simple and homey with high celings and minimal art on the walls. It was very cute:)

To start off, we got the oysters on the shell. The balance of tobiko and ponzu sauce was perfect! Then we ordered the live sea urchin because we noticed it at the bar and it was the best uni I had ever had in my LIFE. It was so fresh and it came on a bed of ice and it was just lovely. We ordered three rolls to finish off our meals. The first roll was the XXX roll. It was a salmon roll, topped off with more salmon, avocado, mango slices, tobiko and GOLD. Like, edible gold glitter. It was a delicious roll but the presentation really won me over with the glitter! The next roll we had was the Family Affair.I was a bit iffy about the Maui onions but it paired nicely with the spicy aioli! The last roll we had was the Romeo and Juliet(his pick. cute, right?). This roll had scallop AND salmon on it, which made it a winner in my eyes.

We ended the meal with a couple of sake bombs and we were good to go! I was very impressed with the creativity of the specialty rolls and the presentation of the live sea urchin. It's definitely an experience for your mouth and I would recommend this to all sushi lovers! It's a bit pricey, but SO worth it!
author: Kathleen N.

description: Been to Japan many times ...Ebisu is so authentic! Forgot where I was. So many wonderful choices.  The freshness of the fish is only exceeded by the beautiful presentations and delightful staff (Toi) and Steve.
author: Larry M.

description:
I came back for lunch again because the experience was so good the last time. Sat at the bar, no wait. Very attentative and friendly staff. 

I'm not sure what my friend ordered, but it was the same this time--like a chef special sashimi assortment 10 fishes. ( good for 3 or 4 to share) but it was between the 2 again. :) beautiful presentation. Fried the fish bone and shrimp head at the end. 

Shared the salmon skin salad--crunchy salmon skin, perfect dressing. 

Customized Avocado, unagi, and spicy tuna hand roll- yum. 

Hamachi Kama-3 pieces--Perfectly grilled. 

Scallop nigiri--yummy.
Not too big on butterfish. 

Beautiful orange fruit plate arrangement by sushi chef! Special! 

Had a great time!
author: Queenie B.

description:
We had sushi omakase with Tom today. It's not on the menu but you can ask for it. In fact, we only had sake and sushi. 

We were all very very satisfied after a two hour meal. Generous portions, good selection of fish, well-made sushi, attentive staff, and professional and funny chef. We had everything, uni, toro, Kobe beef, etc.  

Our chef asked us how we heard of the restaurant at the end. We said yelp. And he was like, don't we have really bad reviews on yelp? We told him no it's actually 4 star with 1000+ reviews. 

Also, always seat at sushi bar when u have real sushi. This applies to every place. Sushi bar sushi is always better than table sushi.
author: Yunfei Z.

description:
This place is good but not THAT good. My sister and I ordered omikase sashimi, a bento box, and kobe beef nigiri to share. The omikase was good but i noticed there were some chewy, tendony parts of the sashimi that indicates that the sushi chefs didn't cut the fish right. Also, the tuna (both white and red tuna) in the omikase was a little grainy and you could tell it wasn't the freshest. The bento box was pretty good (fried oysters, shrimp and vegetable tempura, and yellowtail/tuna sashmi). The best thing we ate was definitely the kobe beef nigiri, it came with a dipping sauce that was slightly sweet and was the perfect compliment to the beef - definitely order this!

I was debating giving this place 3 or 4 stars because of the service, the waitress was very attentive and sweet. But no, i'll give this place 3 stars... its definitely overrated. This is one of those places I wouldnt come back to unless I could expense it or if some shmuck took me on a date here (and i didnt have to pay). Not worth the money.
author: Sheena N.

description:
I will go back here every time I am in San Francisco. The food was spectacular! The presentation was well done and the service was good. 

You will have to wait, but you can order a drink and enjoy the atmosphere in anticipation of a superb dinning experience. 

Freshest of fish, Miso-est of miso soups. Sake-it to me baby!!!
author: Autumn W.

description: Ebisu is the best sushi you can get , ive been a loyal customer since esa,eric, tommy and george worked there ,freindly staff the owners are wonderful and welcoming , i never get a table , we always sit at the bar and order straight from there, chep roll , spicy tuna handroll with habanero and dinasour feet are delicious, if you really like seafood get a seafood salad spicy with a side of rice. If and IF your lucky get some albacore toro  with ponso sauce . Best sushi EVER . My mouth is watering just writing this
author: T S.

description: Superfresh sushi, i chose the omakase sashimi went awesome. Grilled squid too. Highly frequented but very nice staff
author: Tracrium T.

description: It's time to start using a wireless restaurant paging system. You're note pad doesn't work during high volume times and you are loosing customer's because of it. Food is good however.
author: S L.

description: Got here at 9:30pm and there was still a 45min wait. Totally worth it though. We ordered the Kobe beef sashimi which was really fresh and tender, not as chewy as I expected. Next was the omakase plate which I probably could've ordered just to myself. There were about 7 different types of sashimi on there but smaller cuts than normal. Lastly, the most impressive crunchy roll I've ever had- poke, avocado, fried tempura bits wrapped in rice and soy paper..soooo good. Definitely a high quality sushi place for a reasonable price - will be back a bunch I'm sure.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Came here with 2 other people on a Wednesday night and the wait was about 30 mins. We decided to put our name on the list and grab a beer at a bar nearby since the waiting area was a bit cramped. Our bartender was pleased to hear that we were getting dinner at Ebisu and raved about how good they were. 

We were quickly seated when we got back and our servers were very attentive. We got 2 large sakes ($6 each and actually tasted pretty good!), tempura, and 3 special sushi rolls. Everything tasted amazing and the price/portions were fair. The restaurant itself is on the smaller side but it didn't look cramped or outdated. Would definitely come back!
author: Jamie B.

description:
very good. 

service was great. sushi was fresh and high quality. and pricing was not over the top. I truly enjoyed my entire experience dining at Ebisu.
author: Shadi N.

description: Love this sushi place. It's small but not too quiet; family friendly. Price is great and sushi is good.
author: Mary C.

description:
Sushi and happy hour! WHEEEEEEEEEEE

Babe and I came to Ebisu last Friday evening to eat sushi. Upon entering the restaurant was almost all filled up but luckily we got a table. Prior to getting a table I took a look at their specials board and they have $1 draft beers from 5-6pm for happy hour! WHAT?! THIS IS GREAT.

So we ordered two $1 Kirin drafts (can you see how proud I am for ordering such cheap drinks?), QP roll, xxx roll, dragon roll, dexter carter roll and the boston roll.

QP roll - you can order it with a level of spiciness, I don't recommend it, since it takes away from the taste of the roll. I would try it again to taste the scallops.

XXX roll - the special of the day, with mango slices. I could hardly taste the fruit tho.

Dragon roll - just a typical dragon roll

Dexter carter roll - basically my beloved 49er roll with avocado

Boston roll - possibly my favorite out of all rolls that night

Servers are pretty nice and friendly. The dining area is feels a bit cramped but still allowing the patrons to have an intimate conversation. My night at Ebisu was enjoyable. The portions are a bit small for the price you pay tho. A tip is to come here early if you like it here, the wait can get pretty long.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
TL;DR: Probz my favorite sushi place ever. Stay for the Matcha Creme Brulee, leave because there are a ton of people clamoring to get in.

Either get here early, or plan on getting here closer to closing. This wasn't my first rodeo at Ebisu. I first stumbled upon Ebisu a few years ago. My roommate at the time was trying to take me to a different spot, but the line was way too long. Approaching closing time for most locations around the area, we jumped on Yelp. 4.5 stars, 400 reviews? Not bad, let's try this place.

Almost 1000 reviews and several visits later, Ebisu still takes the top spot on my list of favorite Sushi joints. 

The restaurant itself is small, but they do make solid use of the available space.If you come during prime dinner rush hour, be prepared to wait. Ebsiu has always been very popular, but appears to have boomed over the last few years. Depending on your group size, you can wait anywhere from 15mins-1 hour. Trust me when I say it's well worth the wait.

Ebsiu's fish is always fresh. Their speciality rolls aren't drenched in various sauces and are very creative (Hot Link roll for example. Prices, in my opinion, are fair given the quality and portions given. There is a rotating door of appetizer offerings (Kobe Beef Sashimi, Calamari Tempura, Lobster Dynamite) and a "Chef's Choice" selection of speciality rolls aptly named "XXX". 

Here's what we ordered last night:

- Miso Soup (not overly salty like most places)
- Spicy Tuna Hand Rolls (Probably THE best spicy tuna I've ever had.)
- Uni nigiri (They have fresh UNI that still comes in a shell, but don't know how to order that)
- Salmon nigiri
- 49er Roll (Salmon over avocado with a thin slice of lemon on top.)
- XXX Roll - Yesterday, it was a salmon mango avocado wrapped over their spicy tuna. 
- Matcha Creme Brulee
