Everything was delicious and incredibly fresh. The Matcha Creme Brulee is the perfect way to cap off a great meal. It isn't too sweet and and unlike most other matcha flavored sweets, you can actually taste the green tea. 

Service is excellent. The servers aren't there to make friends (that's what the Sushi Chefs are there for!), but they'll seldom forget any request or item that you've ordered. The food comes out quick.

Ambiance - My gf and I used to come here if we wanted a quasi romantic setting. That no longer seems to be case. While the place is nicely decorated with a modern feel, the surge of tourist traffic takes away from that just a bit.

Go ahead and make your normal sushi selection, but be sure to save room for the Creme Brulee!
author: Chris Q.

description: Came here right after Hardly Strictly Bluegrass on a Saturday night, so it was fairly packed.  Once seated, service was very fast and friendly.  Seems more fun to sit at the sushi bar, as the chefs are very sociable and do fun tricks with the food.  It also appeared that those sitting at the bar had extra perks like sliced oranges with their meal.  Table service was just fine though.  And kudos on the free refills on the diet coke and tea!  We had the beef sukiyaki which came with miso soup and a bowl of rice.  We also had a roll topped with wakame that the menu did not specify was spicy (so I had to eat less of that one).  If you are sensitive to spice, it might be worthwhile to confirm that nothing you ordered is spicy.  Overall, I would come back in a heartbeat.  Such a warm experience and delicious food!!
author: Christina G.

description:
I went yesterday for the first time.
The sushi is ok, good, but I had superior many times. 
The rolls were all 'broken' I couldn't pick up a piece without disarm it.
Too much rice and caked.
I don't think I will come back.
author: Masama S.

description:
The Boyfriend & I were really craving Japanese but didn't really want t go to Sushi Raw since it's not that easy to get to from our house. Since it was still early for dinner, we tried our luck here; we were able to be seated right aways...at the last 2 seats in the restaurant.

Since we were sitting at the sushi bar, we ordered a bunch of different sushi role & nigiris. The California roll was decent & didn't use the kind of imitation crab that's mixed with mayo. The Salmon toro was good but it was not really all that fatty. The Kampachi was sweet but not the best that I've had in the Sunset. The Crunchy roll was interesting. I couldn't really taste the poke & I wish it was wrapped in nori instead because it could've use a little extra crunchiness.

IN addition to the sushi & nigiri, we also got the $25 Omakase sashimi plat. We got 8-9 types of fish with at least 3 pieces each. The quality was not the greatest & the slices were on the small side; but it was definitely a good deal for the price.

The highlight of the meal for me was the Chawanmushi. I love this steamed egg dish but haven't had it since moving to the US 15 years ago. The whole thing was not too salty & the egg was silky smooth. The only negative is the overcooked shrimp in the middle...but that's the way it is. It does take about 15 minutes to cook so order early.

Even though we got here slightly before 5:30, the restaurant was already super packed. And if you arrive after 5:30, expect a crowd or even a line out the door. There are 4 chefs working behind the sushi bar so serve is usually pretty quick. The sushi bar is a bit cramped so get ready to get to know your neighbors.
author: Karen S.

description: Ebisu is an excellent traditional Japanese restaurant. Very fresh fish and great service.
author: Adam T.

description:
Thanks for accommodating our large table of 7 in such a tiny place. Their max group they allow is 8 people. Although we ordered a little extra sides that never came, the staff was great! Our waitress knew what she was serving and when we asked for a speciality, she knew what to do! 

I'm just happy I got my hamachi jalapeño.
author: Mimi H.

description: I can never turn down Japanese food :) I've never been here before so my friend and I decided to come here for lunch and we were lucky to beat the rush. We got seated right away. We decided to go with the lobster tempura, Kobe beef sashimi, cherry blossom roll, and the Dexter Carter roll. The lobster tempura was okay, it's like any other type of tempura..just lobster. The Kobe beef sashimi was interesting and yummy. I've never had beef like this before. They give 3 different types of sauces to eat it with (green sauce - spiciest, red/orange sauce - medium spicy, and white - not spicy). Definitely recommend this dish! The rolls were delicious but believe me when I say they don't skimp on the rice. Eating both these rolls filled me up so quickly I felt like I was going to explode. I believe I've found my new go-to sushi place.
author: Melanie C.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised with Ebisu.  I passed by it many times, heard good things about it, and always wanted to try but never made it to the top of my list.

Finally made it to Ebisu and I am quite pleased with their quality and varities of fish they have to offer.  

We arrived about 10 mins. pass 5 when they just opened but the restaurant already fully seated with patrons.  I was curious if Ebisu was really that good.  Seated at the sushi bar and the sushi chefs were nice, courteous and funny.

All the nigiris we ordered were excellent.  You just have to go and try for yourself.
author: Shirley H.

description:
I know, I know, the wait is a painful but it is worth. Once they call your name and you are seated, before anything look at the tables around you and all the lovely dishes around, not only they look good they are Delicious and fresh.

The fish is very fresh! The rolls are great here, they have your favorite classics but they also have some that are unique.

If you love sushi, you will definitely love Ebisu.
author: Yas J.

description: Small, Japanese restaurant in inner sunset with limited seating but fresh quality sashimi. Would recommend!
author: Sunny L.

description: Me and my 2 friends wanted to find a fairly priced and good quality sushi restaurant in the city. We found Ebisu on Yelp and decided to go to dinner. We waited for less than 15 minutes for a party of 3 on a Saturday night. They literally had the fastest sushi service I have ever had and the quality is killer! My friend got her first roll within 5 minutes of ordering and the rest of the rolls and food came within 15 minutes! I usually have to dip sashimi in soy sauce to make it taste good but the fish they have is so fresh that I ate it by itself. I ordered the dinner combo and it was so much food and all of it was amazing!!! This place is definitely a gem!!!!
author: Kayla C.

description:
Actually the best sushi I have ever had. THe wait can be long since they do not take reservations but so worth the wait. Bento box lunch specials, great sushi and URCHIN!!
Love the decor as well! :)
author: Amanda M.

description: My first time to sit at the bar, first time to also order the deluxe combo of sushi. They served it all on one plate rather than piece by piece like the other customers surrounding me. I was still craving amaebi since I could see all the table orders leave the bar. The chef was very nice and knowledgeable. Offered my amaebi heads to either be deep fried or in a miso soup. I ended up using one head each to try both. I will come back because of the fresh fish
author: Janelle O.

description:
My wife n I drive from San Jose to this place when we're craving for sushi. We found this place by accident.  We've been going to this place for over 2 years now.  Top quality sushi at a reasonably price.
We love SF so many cool places to go n eat.
author: Manu3l L.

description:
3.5 star.  

Came here after seeing the 4 star rating.  It's a small place, still packed with diners on late lunch hour.  We ordered the omakase, which was only for sashimi and they have 2 price tier, $25 and $50.  The waitress said the $50 one is more premium, more uni, so we ordered that one.  As it came out, the fish varieties weren't too special, there was uni and it tasted sweet, but not really like a lot of uni.  

We also ordered oyster on the shell, ok to below average, I'd rather prefer the fat ones fresh from oyster farms; lobster dynamite, which was really yummy with the sauce though slightly spicy.  The best dish is the wagu beef raw slices.  Dipping them in the sauce, it felt so thick, warm and flavorful!

The menu is quite extensive so it would be good to come explore next time.  We easily hit the bill over $100 without ordering too much.  Service general's ok, but no tea refill or water refill.
author: LeeLee C.

description:
I've been to Ebisu once, so while I can't make any declarative statements, I can say I was disappointed. Walking in, the decor and overall ambiance of the place was great. It had a neat modern feel to it and was different than other sushi restaurants I've been to. 

The sushi was good, but it wasn't anything spectacular. The most disappointing of my evening, however, was the fact that they completely rushed us out. To their defense, my friend and I did come on the later side (around 9 or 9:15), but they were supposed to close at 11pm. We ordered some appetizers and rolls and sashimi to share, and they brought all of it out at the same time, even though our table was already too crowded. They then told us they decided to close early. They began stacking chairs on tables around us while we were still eating, and I even had to stop them twice to stop taking things off our table because we hadn't finished them. Around ten, we basically gave up and left as they practically pushed us out the door. 

It sounds like this place is normally a lot better, so maybe I picked the wrong night, but the service was definitely not acceptable.
author: Katie M.

description: Everything is as what other yelpers indicated.  However, I have been to other places that serve fresh and good Japanese food without the lengthy wait time. It is absolutely not worth the wait as you ended up in a tight eating environment.
author: Frances C.

description: Good, not great.  I thought the sashimi plates were very small and not worth the money.  Fried oysters were good.
author: Trish M.

description:
I was referred by my boss about this place and i kid you not when he said this was a fresh amazing sushi place he was right. Even their miso soup was delicious and after every meal they offer green tea or hot water which i heard japanese tradition and is healthy to drink after every meal
I highly recommended you get what you pay for..

Only con is that parking is hard to find.
author: Priscilla G.

description:
I've lived in 4 different countries (3 in Asia) in my life and this restaurant has The best sushi dishes I have ever tasted in my life. The best.

Fish were all very fresh and despite what other reviewers might say the food here are not by any means mediocre. Service is great and Kevin and Julio on Friday night are jovial and funny characters behind the sushi bar who are world class sushi chefs.

 Try off-the-menu Spicy Scallops with Quail Eggs roll, and if you want to go all out as you should on this visit here try 3-4 serving of Omakase Sashimi Mix. It is a dish that is work of art and absolutely mindblowing in flavors.

Must visit if you love sushi and you are in SF.
author: Al L.

description: It's been ages since I've been here. I don't know why I stayed away, must've been the wait. We got here early this time. I loved everything they served us. We sat at the bar and the chef was amazing! My favorite thing was the salmon toro.
author: Leah L.

description:
I visited Ebisu for lunch by myself. I was relative busy for a late lunch on a Saturday but I was able to get a seat at the sushi bar. Good sign that they have loyal customers.

I went with one of the sashimi combos which was delicious. The sushi man was really nice and talked to me a bit about the different fish on my plate. I also ordered a couple of nigiri sushi to finish it up. All dishes were really fresh and tasty.

I liked the nice but simple atmosphere of the place and the pro-activeness and enthusiasm of the staff.

I recommend a visit.
author: Eduardo S.

description:
Super yummy sushi.  Fish is really really fresh and so I can't complain. We also ordered their poke which we liked, but the pieces were cut a biiit too big for my taste.  Talk about huge chunks of tuna haha. 

They also have sake flights!! So so cool. Must try that next time with the sushi. 

Just be careful. There's a reason this place gets busy - it's just good quality fish.  The wait can be long both to sit and to eat.  We waited foreeeever for my nigiri :( Other than that, if you want good sushi, come here!
author: Steph S.

description: Came here for dinner at the sushi bar and dined with Eric as our chef. He asked us want we wanted and we asked him to surprise us from the best cuts of fish and any other recommendations. All of the food, from the rice to the cuts of fish were excellent. We also tried the slow roasted pork belly, fried fish skin, a clam dish, and a soup finisher. Everything was absolutely delicious, the fish was incredibly fresh. I will definitely be back soon.
author: Loren B.

description: Some of the best sushi, raw and/or cooked fish I've ever eaten! Small but nice ambiance, plan to make my way back.
author: Tangible H.

description: Sakimakisa, get drunk with the sushi chef at the bar. Ebisu has kept the raw fish party in your mouth going for decades. While I miss Goemon (where the sushi and rolls were something to aspire to) and there's no karaoke, I respect that Ebisu significantly reduces your chances of choking on fish by keeping the atmosphere professionally cool. Sushi and rolls are the way to go. Their second restaurant across the street has more cooked food options. Definitely open up your wallet for the good stuff; live scallop, live shrimp (with fried shrimp head included) and tuna belly. There is always a wait to get in. Even though chivalry is dead, you could bring an extra sweater for your friend to prevent the wait factor from blowing up in your face. Nobody likes a cranky kitty or a barking dog.
author: Anna L.

description:
SO the worst day to EVER go out and eat is VALENTINES DAY. duh. but I still decided to come here on that horrendous day.. and let me tell you at 8:30... THERE WAS STILL A SFJSKLFJSLDF LOAD OF PEOPLE. I'm standing here thinking, dam this must be some bombass sushi...or it better be. So while I was sitting there waiting for a table, my bf was looking for parking. parking was no joke. Parking in this neighborhood, on a FRIDAY... ON VALENTINES DAY is probably ever driver's worst nightmare. I think we ended up waiting 45 minutes instead of 1hr + because all the people before us left :) Smart move. 

The servers here are really nice. Toi seated us at the bar and let me tell you that just made the experience here that much better. Our sushi chefs were Julio and Kevin. They were amazing and entertaining. They made our dinner experience really fun. 

We ordered:
Hawaiian Poke - one of the best poke I've had. Delish! The tuna was so fresh! there wasn't too much sauce so it was the perfect combo. we wanted to order another round

Sake (salmon) Sashimi - really, the sashimi here is really fresh. I'm not one to eat raw fish, but dam - i ordered more after this plate X| I heard the sashimi here was good so after waiting for so long minus well try it right? so glad i did.

Maguro (tuna) Sashimi - same. it's like the tuna was swimming in my mouth haha not really but it was great! 

49er Roll - this roll was really interesting. even though it was a super thin slice of lemon, you could really taste it with the roll. it wasnt a tarty lemon - it was rather sweet. went well with the salmon sashimi and whatever else is in there

#29 Roll - i guess i really have a thing for salmon... except this one the salmon was cooked and then the whole roll was topped with raw tuna. really interesting. compared to our other roll, this one was really sweet.

Peach Sparkling Sake - its cold. it's peachy. its really sweet - and it was their Valentines day special... i would prefer this for desert.. not during the meal kinda just tastes like juice, peach juice. 

Hot Sake - i never found hot sake to taste good... still don't but when you have chefs like we did, you wanna thank them ;)
Saporo - so we made sake bombs and cheers-ed to valentines day and the end of the night, we didn't leave until 11? 

And of course, this place is NOT cheap. but it was really fresh. would definitely come back - but its more of a once in a while typa place. The chefs mentioned, FRIDAYS are the best day to come :) - although they are the most packed...
author: Kristina L.

description:
Ebisu is usually my go to place because I work in the area, but I went with friends yesterday for dinner. The service was slow and rushed at the same time...

We got there at around 6:30, and waited less than 10 minutes for a table. Between 3 people, we ordered both the raw and Panko Oysters, the Arch Deluxe and Family Affair rolls, Hamachi Kama and 2 Chirashi bowls.
Raw oysters were cold and clean, Panko Oysters came out hot.
Hamachi Kama is smaller at dinner than at lunch, or maybe that's just my imagination.

Everything came out delicious as normal, but my main issue was that both the older waitress and our own waitress checked up on us about every 3 minutes towards the end of our meal. Besides the fact that we barely finished half the Chirashi, which came out a lot later than the rest of the items, they kept pushing us to wrap up since a wait had started. Not a huge fan of that since we did order a lot and were eating at a normal pace.
author: Derrick C.

description:
Sushi chef Kevin deserves all the accolades I can give him. He was personable, attentive, made delicious nigiri, and was able to discern what I liked and adjust suggestions accordingly. Not that it's relevant to his sushi preparation, but the main can also hold his liquor-my friendly neighbors were plying him with Sake shots all evening which seemed not to affect him in the slightest. 

The place smelled a little fishy when I first arrived, which gave me initial pause, but it was unjustified-the fish was fresh and outstanding. I supplemented my omakase with an order of bacon wrapped scallops from the kitchen, and I can't recommend them more highly. The center was perfectly undercooked and the balance of scallop, bacon, and spicy sauce flavored was perfect. 

I had to wait about fifteen minutes for one seat at the sushi bar at 8:15 on. Thursday night, which I didn't think was bad, and my bill was a completely reasonable $40. I'll be back the next time I'm in the inner sunset.
author: Brent E.

description:
Favorite sushi in the city. Ebisu is so frickin delicious, you can't go wrong with any roll. Try the XXX if you don't know where to start. And get the Pink Cadillac appetizer. Trust me. It is amazing! Scallops wrapped in salmon. Even if you don't like scallops or salmon, you will like it. 

The chefs are super nice, water is refilled constantly, prices are good (great considering how good the sushi is), only downside is there's often a wait. But we got here at 6:15 on a Thursday night and got seated within 10 min! Just choose your time wisely and you're guaranteed to have a great meal.
author: Maleenee B.

description: I love sushi!  Everyone knows that.  That's why all my friends take me to their favorite sushi place when I come visit.  I haven't tried the other sushi places in the area, but Ebisu has to be one of the best in Inner Sunset.  Fresh fresh fresh!  We ordered the kobe beef sashimi, omekase, deluxe nigiri, Romeo and Juliet roll, and live scallop -- everything was delicious!  The best was definitely the scallop they used on top of the Romeo and Juliet roll though.  Service wasn't the best, but not bad considering how busy they are -- this tiny place gets packed quick, and the wait can be quite long.  But no worries, there are plenty of bars nearby for you to grab a drink while you wait.
author: Anna C.

description:
Before hitting up the Cal Academy of Sciences for Nightlife, we hopped off Muni and started walking towards Golden Gate Park looking or a place to grab dinner. I remembered hearing the name of this place from friends before, so we stopped inside at around 6pm on a Thursday night.

We were given the option of sitting at the bar or at a table. We decided to sit at the bar and were immediately offered a beverage.

Both the waitress and the guy at the sushi bar were very attentive. Our orders were taken and food/drinks were delivered in a timely manner. Presentation was impeccable and the fish was definitely fresh (seriously, the salmon was vibrant)! Price-wise, it was comparable to any other sushi place. By 7pm, this place was definitely packed and a small line started to form at the entryway.

If I'm ever out in the Inner Sunset and looking for sushi, this will be my new go-to place!
author: Leana L.

description:
WOW.

We came at 5 and didn't have to wait at all, but there was a pretty big wait for it as we left. 

My standards for sushi have been raised ten fold. I don't know how I'll go back to the East Coast knowing that it's going to be hard to find a place that beats Ebisu.

The $25 sashimi platter for 1-2 people fed us three perfectly. The price tag is a STEAL considering all the slices of sashimi you get -- 3-5 pieces of tuna, yellowtail, salmon, young yellowtail, halibut, octobus, albacore, smoked tuna, and butterfish. Oh my God so divine. Every single piece is . The sashimi is thoughtfully arranged and each piece is melt-in-your mouth delicious. Please do yourself a favor and get this platter.

The rolls each of us got:
Caterpillar roll: An upgrade of the standard eel and avocado roll. Really solid and the avocados are really fresh. Arranged in a cute (guess!) caterpillar, with sprouts as the antennae. 

Family affair: My roll. And my favorite. Tuna and albacore with avocado and the killer...spicy aioli. A great twist to a spicy roll and the tuna and albacore were perfect partners.

The Special -- Halloween special: Japanese squash tempura with salmon and nori on top. SO ingenious!! I can only describe it as shrimp tempura on crack. Serious points for being fun with their specials.

Also points for having a bowl full of chocolate for me to take.
author: Karina L.

description: I had the rainbow maki and the maker also with ginger. The fish was fresh, the device exquisite and the atmosphere was great. I sat on the bar and they have a market place feel to it. They have gluten free spy Saudi which is key!!
author: Reinne T.

description:
Probably the best sushi restaurant in SF. You would think there would be plenty of good sushi places in this city, but this one tops them all. Pass on all those fake Japanese places that sell mostly rice-filled rolls, this place has legit fresh fish. 

I've been coming to this restaurant my whole life, and will keep coming back now that I moved back to the area. The renovation makes the restaurant look very modern and clean, but the key to the restaurant is the owners careful attention to detail. I think some of the sushi chefs have been there for over 15 years.

Order anything on the menu and you will not be disappointed. Try the specials, ask the sushi chefs for their recommendations.
author: Daniel K.

description:
Okay so the food is okay. they have sushi, udon, teriyaki dishes, and all the usual stuff served in a Japanese restaurant, except perhaps ramen. 

HOWEVER, their service was quite reprehensible and one of the older Japanese ladies who works there as a waitress is in fact quite rude. my family and I come to this restaurant all the time as we live less then a block away and we love japanese food.

Well anyways, I would always order the same salmon teriyaki bento box which usually comes with a bowl of miso soup, a salad, and some broccolini/ fried potatoes. But, the thing is I absolutely hate their salad, so I would always ask the lady to replace the salad with an additional miso soup or additional broccolini instead. However, according to the waitress and her boss, I have to pay extra if I ever want to replace the miso soup. Ok, so normally I would have no problem with paying a little extra but the fact that I have to pay an additional 2.00 just to add a little more broccolini (when I am already giving up the salad) is just plain ridiculous. The bento box is already 20 dollars and the portion size is small when compared to its atrociously high cost...

To conclude, though the food is decent. the food is definitely NOT WORTH THE PRICE especially when it comes with such POOR SERVICE. You will probably be better off dining at Kiki the Japanese Restaurant next door, as the price is pretty much half that of Ebisu.

However, I would like to note that the younger caucasian lady and the younger japanese man whom work there as well provide much better service so if you ever decide to go here order from them NOT the older japanese lady.
author: Don C.

description:
Some of the best Sushi in town..... will return, soon....

This place has some of the best grade fish in town.  Sushi lovers get ready, the fish melts in your mouth.. enjoy
author: Diego R.

description: Disappointed... I used to rate this place 4 stars and was my go-to sushi but after today I am not going there anymore. Sushi rice was soggy and the way the sushi was made was sloppy. We ordered all different types of specialty rolls from dragon to rainbow, and we weren't impressed by any of them. Even the presentation didn't seem right. Worst than that, customer service wasn't great at all. They rushed us to order, eat and pay. We did arrive a little late, 30 mins before closing but we called an hour in advance to ask and they told us it was fine to come. They even started putting chairs on tables next to us. This is not the Ebisu I used to know, it felt like a cheap sushi restaurant where employees don't care about service. Not to mention how they price their sushi. The worst ones are $10 a piece, and the others are $15. Definitely not worth it for me anymore. Competition is going to eat them... In my case, well, I guess now I have no reason to go eat in the inner sunset anymore.
author: David L.

description:
Been coming to this place since the early 1990s and it has always delivered a supreme level of sushi and other dishes. Hands down it is the best sushi restaurant in SF and one of the best on the west coast. And I've been to scores of them!!! 

Go for some of the specialty items that you won't typically get at other spots, including the bonito, aji, live scallop and the piece de resistance - the blackened cod. The latter is a melt in your mouth explosion of delicate flavor that might require a cigarette after you complete the experience (figuratively speaking of course). And the selection of toro including bluefin is just incredible - and you can taste the freshness and quality

Put it his way - my dad lives in southern CA and has literally flown up for dinner at ebisu and flown back the same night!?!

That's all need be said!?!
author: Robert R.

description:
It was about 9:45 pm and my friends and I were extremely hungry after walking around in Downtown SF! Most places close at 9:30 so we were looking online to see which places were opened late and we came across Ebisu! 

When we got there the place was packed! We had to wait for 2 groups of two people before we would be called. We waited about 20 minutes until they called our party of 5. The atmosphere in there is really pleasant. When we sat down, they automatically gave us tea, handed us menus, and asked if we wanted water. 

The waiter suggested their specials which were on the whiteboard, however, we didn't exactly understand what he was saying.We got the Sukiyaki, two dinner plates (one chicken teriyaki and the other with salmon), and also a bowl of udon noodles that came with tempura. The rice plates and the sukiyaki came with a bowl of rice and miso soup. The miso soup tasted pretty good, normally its tasteless at other places. The waiters and waitresses constantly came by to see if we needed any refills with tea or water. And when we needed something, they were always there. The food was a little bit more pricey but you can't expect  for it to be cheap when you go to a sushi place.

Overall, this place has GOOD FOOD and GOOD CUSTOMER SERVICE!
author: Jeanette Q.

description:
A friend took me here while I was visiting town. The pork belly (kakuni) was out of this world! Miso soup and edamame trio were both on point. XXX roll was outrageously delicious! We were so happy with the food!

The ambiance is perfect. Though, seating is a little tight. We made friends with our neighbors, so it wasn't a big deal. 

Service was great with our first server and slipped a bit with her helpers. Nothing terrible, just a little slower than Anita was. I would highly recommend this place.
author: Natalie G.

description: Maybe the best restaurant in San Francisco. Absolutely the best sushi.
author: Ian M.

description: I'm not a Japanese food connoisseur, but I thoroughly enjoyed this place. Felt a tad bit rushed at the bar but overall a good experience. The sashimi and Louisiana hot links roll were great and very fresh. Hamachi Kama is my favorite appetizer, but I feel like parts of it were over cooked. Will definitely be going back!
author: Christie Y.

description:
Super rude over the phone.

They take no reservations, they won't add you on the waiting list and there is apparently an "hour" wait  every night. I can't believe this place is owned by the same people who ran the  hotei restauarant that was closed.

Awful.
author: Frances S.

description: Im not a big sushi fan , but the tempura was great and you have to try the tempura lobster tails very good. The environment was cool a little crowded and everyone seemed to be enjoying their food. The service was good and i only gave 4 stars because we had to wait 1hr and 15 mins to be seated 3ven though people after us were seated first .
author: Jenny G.

description: The salmon teriyaki was delicious, so was the dragon roll. Felt like the waitress wouldn't stop coming to our table and was like "eat your salad it's good" haha but anyway, my advice: the food is delicious but do not get the crunchy roll (with the soy bean paper) tastes like Funyuns! Other than that the food is good!
author: Katarina L.

description: There were 4 of us for lunch last week around 1230, we were seated right away at the bar, tables were not available. I had the chirash http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ebisu-san-francisco?select=YxFVNG0CFJrs2Ym7iRiDjA#YxFVNG0CFJrs2Ym7iRiDjA yummm. The fish was so fresh, it was like butter. I heard the waiters speaking Cantonese, so I'm not sure if any of workers were Japanese. The food was good even if they weren't from Japan. For $20, I would have expected more rice though, but there was plenty of fish, scallops, fish eggs, imitation crab...not really sure what I ate. I saw someone next to us with the salmon skin roll, it looked like a palm tree. I must get that next time. When we left, there was a long line. Phew, beat the rush!
author: Kylie L.

description:
I went here a few times when I first moved to San Francisco. It was a big deal then to eat a place like Ebisu because it would set my wallet back a bit.

The first time was very good but I didn't feel close to full. In the subsequent visits, the quality went down but the portions remained the same.

Although the sushi was good, the small portions never justified the high price.

There are other spots now in SF that I'd rather go to than Ebisu. More bang for the buck.
author: Art O.

description: It's very good. QP roll is good. It's a very small place, and it can get busy.
author: Mona L.

description: This is my hubby's favorite place for over a  decade now from when he lived here, and we now both love it! Quaint, always busy and lively, and unpretentious! Tip: stick with the fresh fish items and you will be utterly pleased. Do not go to his place if you do not thoroughly enjoy raw, "un-mayoed" sushi, or traditional Japanese cuisine. Their tempura udon is a 9/10 for me, the agedashi tofu is fabulous, and again, the FISH is fresh and reasonably priced.
author: Rachal C.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised, today. The deluxe sushi offering was satisfying. the fish was very fresh. The the ratio of fish to rice was balanced. Although, if the fish slices were a tad larger I would have been happier.

My friend had the bento box with the teriyaki beef. she said the meat was very tender and delicious. there was so much in the box she had to take some home

Service was friendly and efficient during a very busy lunch hour. the joint was rocking.  All in all we enjoyed ourselves very much and will return.
author: Debbie T.

description:
What a great Sushi Saturday find! Special thanks to my fellow yelpers for leading me to try a local spot I never even noticed.

I went here with a friend to celebrate a birthday. After reading about the horrendous wait we made an effort to get there shortly after they opened for dinner. I run on Xicano time so that was like 6:30ish (they open at 5). 

We walked in and were asked for our party size by a sweet older woman, who I later learned is the owner. I love sitting at the bar and it was still available. Score. We were seated immediately. Our sushi chef was Julio, he was amaze. After learning we were celebrating a birthday he def set the tone and made the experience. Oyster shots (Served with quail egg, tobiko, negi, daikon, ginger and ponzu)!!! One for each person on our end of the bar. The shots were good for the occasion but not likely something I would order regularly.

Right off the bat we got a bottle of the Kamoizumi Daiginjo SAke which was a great pairing for our meal. It quickly came to the bar along with two individual edamames. To start we ordered the Oysters Barnabi on the 1/2 shell with uni, ikura, uzura and ponzu. They were crazy good. Something about the texture was great. 

We decided to do omakase and added toro and had the chef serve up whatever else he saw fit. Our first plate was Sashimi and it was super fresh and beautifully cut. Then followed the Toro which was the show stealer. 

We then had two cute baskets of ceviche. I was not a fan. The fish was great but I'm Mexican so ceviche just means something completely different to me. A fabulous nigiri plate followed that included some amazing Escolar. Def a must! After that we were served a special roll with spicy tuna which was amazing. 

The dessert was meh! Just ice cream and fruit. Julio was great but the servers seemed a little off. We didn't have a consistent person refilling water or checking on us. Also, minus 1 star= They don't let the chefs drink with us. What? I know crummy right!

All of that food plus tax and tip came out to about $340. Overall, I loved the decor, the fresh sushi, and Julio the sushi chef. But for that price point the wait staff and overall vibe were not up to par. I did however notice that this is a very regulars oriented place so maybe the treatment was because we were first timers. Either way the food is a 5 but the vibe and price make it a 3.
author: Caro S.

description: The wait was long. The wait for food was long. Service was slow. The food was mediocre. Probably won't come back.
author: Michael Q.

description: All you can ask for in a good sushi joint. Fresh sashimi, rolls were delicious, and must get their red bean ice-cream. Everything was delicious here!
author: Ingrid C.

description:
Came here to celebrate our friends birthdays and had a good time.  Since we had a party of 8, we had to wait for over an hour for seats.  They are really busy on the weekends, so if you have a big party, I'd recommend to come early and be prepared to wait! 

If you've never tried sashimi kobe beef, I'd recommend that you try it out.  It was pretty yummy and has three different sauces to dip with it. My friends ordered a bunch of their hot sake and got pretty tipsy off of it, so its a definite YES. Their sushi rolls are a bit small, so order a few if you are hungry, otherwise you and your friends might leave feeling HANGRY. :)
author: Carrine J.

description: Slow service. Waited almost 40 mins for our food. Still not here... Food is alright. Nothing to get too crazy about. An average sushi restaurant with the higher end presentation and environment.
author: Carmen Y.

description: Came here after a day at the Academy of Sciences. My friends and I were impressed with the quick service the fresh food and the cool atmosphere. The miso, edamame trio, gyoza, roll, nigiri and chicken teriyaki were so delicious. We will definitely return! Thanks for the incredible birthday dinner.
author: Melissa J.

description:
3.5

- Amaebi was good.
- Omakase sashimi decent
- Udon was good, thinner noodles than i'm used to seeing.
- Uni was good. 
- Rolls are soso
- Interior design is nice. 

Overall nice swanky place to dine at with *decent* sushi, but didn't leave me satisfied.
author: Julie K.

description: They have great service, awesome food, and keep all the traditions including giving you a warm towel to wipe your hands with and has a beckoning cat for good luck. And the best green tea I've had in a long time.
author: Glyn W.

description:
Delicious food. I really enjoyed the service and food here. It's a little pricey for the bento boxes for dinner, but they are delicious and have an interesting assortment of foods. The sashimi is so soft, almost like butter in the mouth and tastes so fresh!

I got the bento box with chicken and sashimi. The chicken is very moist but the flavor is lacking. All the flavor is in the sauce which is okay, but I've had chicken better elsewhere. The sashimi was very good, along with the tenpura. The salads and the assortment of vegetables were very well cooked. 

I would try it again--definitely one of the better Japanese restaurants in the area.
author: Natalie M.

description:
Omg. Amazing! It was my first time coming here. At first, I was a little skeptical to come here due to the location. Once I arrived, I can tell it's a poppin' place. My friends walked around the block and found 2 other sushi places within a half mile radius, but they weren't packed at all. We waited for about 30 minutes on a Sunday night (labor day weekend), which I can say isn't too had a wait and it was worth the wait. We ordered several dishes, but the one that really caught our attention was the oo toro -- which was the super fatty part of the blue fin-- and the Kobe sashimi. Hands down, those were the highlights of the place. The oo toro and the regular blue fin toro literally melts in your mouth within even chewing! It was so good! As for the Kobe sashimi, I've never had such a wonderful dish. The cuts were perfect and the taste of the sauce was on point. When you add in a bit of garlic and Chile paste, it was perfect! Other dishes we got were uni sashimi, salmon sashimi, tuna sashimi, ebisu combo, chirashi, and a few others that I have forgotten. 

I will most definitely come back whenever I'm in sf.
author: Andrew T.

description:
Always AMAZING sushi and great service even when busy. This is the place to go for top quality, excellent execution and absolutely scrumptious sushi. This is my go to place for quality and a great experience.

I have been here many times - not busy and super busy alike. Always great service and great food.
author: Zoe D.

description:
My friend was visiting from out of town and we were both craving sushi so I yelped and this place came up with some of the best ratings so we decided to try it here.  

It was kind of hard to find parking but that's the area in general.  The wait was about half an hour? This place was pretty packed! 

So we got some nigiri with some fresh mackerel (the chef's recommendation) and hamachi belly. NOMNOMNOM, I don't ever mind paying for fresh sashimi that melt in your mouth.  We also got some other rolls: Arch Deluxe and Louisiana Hot Links.  The Arch Deluxe was amazing but the Louisiana Hot Link was aight.  It's just because I don't like it when the fish is deep fried and I do not fancy the little bonito flakes... lol they're just weird to me. 

Overall we really enjoyed it.  I should've gotten the the sashimi samplers.. wahh, next time!
author: Lisa L.

description: Amazing!!! If you love Japanese food, you must visit this place. I'm a vegetarian but The food is great and the servers are unbelievably nice!!!!
author: Toni D.

description: I have been a regular to this place and don't mind waiting for more than an hour, sometimes two, for a table. The food is okay so it attracts more and more guests in the past year. It really upsets me tonight that our waitress was practically pushing us out even before my son finishing his hand roll! We waited for more than an hour and we finished our meal in less than 45 minutes. I understand there were customers waiting but they don't have to clean up the dishes while we were still working on it, not to mention that they never asked us if we want any dessert. Definitely not the type of service that deserves $120+ bill. I guess I need to find another Japanese restaurant in the neighborhood that values its customers.
author: YY S.

description: Sooooo good! Might be the best sushi I've ever eaten. It was so fresh! We got the Kobe sashimi, dragon roll, #29, double hamachi, rainbow roll. All wonderful! The staff was so friendly and sweet that it made it even better! Go, just go!
author: S. B.

description: Best sushi place in the inner sunset. Wait is worth it and it has wonderful ambiance.
author: Stephen M.

description: Still one of my all time favorite spots to get Japanese food in the sunset. Dinner is great, but lunch deals are even better! Best of all the quality hasn't changed and the owners are the cutest!
author: Kristen C.

description:
They charge a $1.2 "box fee" for pick up. Now that is called nickeling and diming. The food is pretty good - about 15-20% better than average - but the prices are about 25% more expensive than average.

The mindset of the owner to charge a $1.2 pick up your food fee basically ruins the food and the entire Ebisu image and experience.
author: Jacob J.

description:
Best Sushi in bay area. The Sushi chefs are wonderful, the fish is impeccable, and we very much enjoyed our warm dishes. 

I was not impressed, however, with the servers. They were dismissive, particularly of females, and multiple times walking away before people were done making requests or asking questions.
author: Jessica R.

description:
When I first started going here it was the only outlet and it was before they remodeled. It was always crowded (lot's of standing by the door) and it was one of the few really legit sushi places in town. I also wasn't as discerning back then but it was the beginnings of understanding the good stuff from the shite. Co-worker really loved it and it was the go to places. For $20 you can get the Chirashi w/ Misothat has
Maguro, sake, hamachi, ebi, albacore, tsubugai, hotate, tobiko, ikura and kanikama. That's still a really solid price considering the quality. For bigger eaters you'll have to supplement a bit but it's not a bad way to start. I've never had the cooked food so I guess I'll now have to go back with all this discerning-ness and see how that goes
author: Kim N.

description:
There's really no reason to go anywhere else for sushi, except for maybe the Tsukiji Fish Market. 

Anyhow, sit at the bar, order some stuff off the specials menu and talk to your chef. You're guaranteed to leave with a smile on your face. This place is good. Really good.
author: Dmitriy D.

description:
Review by G.G., 1st Grader

Imagine you are walking down 9th Ave. You will find the best sushi in America. You won't believe your mouth - this is unimaginable. It is very, very, very, VERY amazing. It smells like yummy. You won't regret when you have their barbeque or their lobster dynamite.
author: Eric G.

description:
Ebisu is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Hands down. The staff has always been very welcoming, I feel like I am being cordially invited into my mother in laws home for a wonderful supper full of laughter and joy. 

#1 Miso soup is the best I've ever had.

#2 Whoever selects the fish there has an amazing talent! It is always so fresh, flavorful, almost buttery. The texture is always perfect, and I've never been disappointed. It's the kind of place that makes me want to try everything on the menu, things I would never dream of trying at lesser sushi places.

#3 The green tea ice cream. OH MY. What a way to end a meal. An absolute delight.

Wait staff has always been prompt, helpful, and friendly. 

Only downside is they are a small place and busy. I actually like how intimate the restaurant feels, but don't come with a big group or make reservations. I've only been with a party of two, and haven't had to wait too long.

Wonderful place. Not just favorite Japanese restaurant for me, favorite restaurant in the whole city.
author: Richard G.

description: Came here on a week night and it was packed- that's usually a good sign. The food was fine.  Here's a story for you: one of the rolls we ordered came with a hair on it. I flagged the server down, she whisked it away and she said they would go ahead an make us a fresh roll. When she brought out the "new roll" they had basically just taken off the contaminated piece and re- served us the same roll! I could tell because the hair was on the end piece of the roll and the "new" roll they brought out was missing just the end piece.  If you're going to make a fresh roll then shouldn't it have two end pieces? First of all gross, second of all, your server flat out lied to our faces. Won't be coming back here again!
author: Jojo L.

description:
If you are in San Francisco, you expect top quality food experiences. Well if you love sushi, Ebisu is the place to go, immediately.

My wife and I dined here on a recommendation, and they didn't pull any punches. They have really took the time to make sure everything they serve is outstanding to the smallest detail. The hamachi kama is the best I've ever had. The green tea is superb. We went in fast and hard... Lobster Tempura! CHECK! Kobe Sashimi! CHECK! Kampachi! CHECK! How bout a Crab Handroll!? CHECK, CHECK CHECK! I believe someone told me it has been here for 30+ years. Old School Kick Ass Sushi!

I'm so happy we found this place. The person that recommended it to us is a saint.

And the low prices won't make your credit card cry....

I'm going back tomorrow.
author: Andy G.

description:
It's unclear to me what makes this place super outstanding.  It's absolutely possible, however, that I got the wrong things while I was here.  I came with my husband and our two friends for a double date dinner and together, we proceeded to order WAY too much food. Here's what we ordered:

- Maguro nigiri (2 pieces): This was OK, but better than what I was expecting
- Deluxe Sushi Combo: Didn't get a chance to try this, but it seemed like a fairly straightforward aggregation of sushi. For $20, it seems like a reasonable deal, but am not sure about quality.
- Gyoza (2 orders): It's pretty hard to mess these up, and I will say that this was great to share with a group of hungry adults. 2 orders was probably aggressive.
- Family Affair Roll: This was not good at all. The spicy aioli was WAY too much. I would definitely advise against getting this if you're not a big mayo fan.
- Sukiyaki: Also very meh. I wouldn't advise getting this either. It's definitely a lot of food, but don't be deceived: most of it is vegetables.  The amount of beef was minimal and tastes nothing like traditional sukiyaki.
- Chicken Katsu: The parts that I had was OK, but as expected, a lot of the chicken was very dry.  Probably the "safest" dinner entree you could order, but nothing I'd write home about. Lots of food though.
- Green Tea Creme Brulee: Interesting concept, very green tea-y, but I actually really enjoyed this.

Overall, I don't know why people wait for hours to eat here.  I honestly didn't think anything here was worth a 45 minute wait.  I would rather wait down the street for Nopalito instead.
author: Lisa I.

description:
Foods pretty tasty and fresh but they don't value their customers. The lady who sat us was not friendly. 

We had dined in and ordered some sushi to go. After we had paid our bill,  we were sitting at our table finishing our tea while waiting for the to go item.  Since they had already collected our money, they thought it would be ok to make us move outside to the waiting area to finish our tea so they could seat another party.  This only made us feel unappreciated as a paying customer. Because of this experience even though the food is good I will think twice before returning.
author: Elm E.

description:
Well, I was kicked out of this restaurant tonight.  My friend and I had dinner here tonight. Sushi was great, service was fine, all in all an enjoyable dining experience, UNTIL....

Two minutes before we left.  We paid our bill, my friend was finishing her glass of wine, we were chatting- and suddenly the hostess came by stopped at our table and said "you know, we have a really long wait in our waiting room." Taken aback, my friend quickly downed her drink, we gathered our stuff and pretty much ran out the door to see about 2-3 tables worth of people waiting in their area. They weren't rioting, they were waiting. In the waiting area. Thats what you do there. I did it, about 45 min before.  It's not as though we had been sitting around for 30 minutes, we had literally just paid our bill and she still had a drink!  And frankly, even if we had been sitting there for 30 minutes, NOT ACCEPTABLE!  I vouch for the sushi, it was good, but not coming back here. Apparently I'm not fast enough..
author: Swaicha C.

description: In my opinion, sushi is easy to learn but extremely hard to master. Ebisu doesn't live up to the standard anymore. Toro sliced paper thin, and the rice doesn't have the right tightness and stickiness. What a waste. All the chefs are now Chinese and chatting out loud in Chinese during working hours. This place has lost its magic, Japanese tradition and professionalism. Extremely disappointed. Really hope Fujii San can bring the standard back.
author: David M.

description: If you can get pass the long wait, crowded room and loud atmosphere, Ebisu is worth the trip.  Mind you that Irving Street can be a headache trying to find parking, so beware.  As for the food, we had agedashi tofu, hamachi Kama, panko breaded deep fried oysters and a variety of nigiri.  All large size serving and quite tasty.  The uni nigiri was superb!
author: Joel M.

description:
Unfortunately my last couple of visits haven't lived up to my previous review.

The main problem is that the portion sizes have decreased pretty significantly. The lobster dynamite has literally halved in size and the cuts of fish in the omakase are much smaller than they once were. 

I used to go to Ebisu every couple of weeks when I lived in the city last year, but now am in no hurry to go back. SF has too many other great sushi joints to try! :-)
author: Steph A.

description:
I've been coming here since I was about 4 years old - back in the day when they had the seating in the back where you would sit on the pillows?? Anyone else know what I'm talking about? No... ok... it was cool, I swear...

Anyway, I may be a little bias because it was the place I always went to, but it is the real deal. The sushi is so fresh and half of the menu items just melt in your mouth. My favorite guy at the sushi bar is named Tommy - he makes some killer stuff. I'm wondering at what point I can bribe him to move to Seattle where I live now??

Their remodel (back in 2009 maybe?) makes the place look classy which is fitting for their excellent service and beyond delicious food.

I come back home 3-4 times a year to see my family and you can ALWAYS bet I will *kindly* enforce we all go to Ebisu for one meal while I'm there.
author: Justine F.

description: Super friendly, fas service. The fish couldn't get any fresher! Be prepared for at least a 45 minute wait on a weekday.
author: Gabriel C.

description: A great discovery. We have already tried a lot of Japanese restaurants in the city. We love sitting at the sushi bar and interact with the chefs to get their recommendations and have to admit Ebisu is already on our top 3 sushi spots in SF. The staff was outstanding: fast, sweet and their recomm. were spot on. We really liked the Omakase for the high quality of the fish and because the pieces were coming at a perfect pace. Special shot out the Eel and Umi Nigiri, both ridiculously tasty.
author: Aleix V.

description: I've had 20 something check ins here meaning over the course of the years I've dined here pretty often. Last night I decided to order take out and much to my surprise there was a $3 charge just to get take out. They call it their "box fee". I'm pretty unhappy that such a thing exists because I've gotten take out at a lot of high end places in SF and not once did I ever encounter this. Like dude I'm not even dining there it's a take out order. Sigh. Also, when I got home a couple of the rolls were falling apart every time I'd use my chopsticks to pick up the pieces. The sushi still tastes good but just a suggestion I hope one day they remove the box fee. Like do you need me to bring my own box or container for you guys? You already make a lot of $ here. You have to understand from a customers perspective it doesn't really make sense especially if they're just going to pick up their order and take it home. Imagine if u were to go grocery shopping and every bag was $3......would be shocking huh? Just saying.
author: Diane L.

description:
We came here on Saturday evening for dinner. Before we came, we called and tried to get an idea how long the wait was for two people. The lady over the phone said 'it's not too bad', so we rushed over there and only saw the line was almost out of the door.  But I was determined to try this place, so we waited for our table.  Luckily, we got to sit at the bar after 30 minutes or so.  It was a very busy evening, but I like to take my time and enjoy my sushi at the bar (especially if we are paying a lot for this meal!)  
We saw some special on the menu and asked the chef about it. Instead of explaining to us exactly what they had, he just said he will order for us. So we trusted him... but I wish we didn't...    The kobe beef sashimi ($15) was too much for us (12 pieces) since i wanted to try other fish.  So i was not too happy about that.  

We also tried some nigiri:

1. hamachi toro: pretty good ($8.5)

2. salmon toro: also good ($7.5)

3. amaebi:  had better ones ($9.5).  And when i asked what options we had for the shrimp head, the chef said they would fry it. When i asked about cooking it in miso soup, he responded that they would do that too.. So when we requested for miso soup, he came back and told us that the kitchen already fried the head!  again, this should never happen at a Japanese restaurant! 

4. lobster tempura ($15):  never had lobster this way before. interesting, wish there were more sauces to make it more flavorful.

5. ocean trout nigiri ($8): i've asked for it to be slightly torched.  not bad... but again, i wish the chef can recommend more and better choices. 

6. we ended up trying live scallop special at the end since there weren't any other fresh fish we were really interested in.  However the problem was it was an order of 8 pieces of scallop nigiri ($18). why would they do that again?  i just want to try one piece!!! but i was 'forced' to commit to eating four pieces if i wanted to try it..  and sadly enough, it was not the freshest or the best scallop i've had!  again, a bit disappointed!  

after all that, our bill was around $100.   Were they good sushi? not bad. I've had better and cheaper ones.  The sad part is although i was full, i didn't walk out satisfied.   Maybe I am just too spoiled by all the other really good Japanese restaurants I've been in LA and San Diego.  Come on, SF, show me some good sushi!!!  Or did I just expect too much??? maybe i should've just ordered some rolls and be happy with that.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
I have a new to go to spot when I'm craving for sushi!!

My friends recommended this place and I'm so glad I took their advice to try it out. We came here twice already and it still amazes me. My favorite of all is their salmon. It's fresh and melts in your mouth. Also, their prices aren't outrageous like other sushi places I've been to.
author: Stephanie W.

description: The best sushi I have ever eaten! Everything was incredible. I am going to miss this place :(
author: Fatma P.

description:
I am constantly on the lookout for amazing Japanese joints. I LOVE this place. The first time I went was with the BF. We came in on a Friday night, so we expected a wait. I believe we ended up waiting about 1.5 hours. Was it worth it? YES.

I know there are many Japanese places that are great in SF, but I've yet to try them all. As of now, Ebisu is in my top 2. We ordered the oyster shooter as an appetizer, "fish & chips" which was an appetizer of the night or something, 49er roll, Double Hamachi, an order of sake & Romeo & Juliet. 

Everything was delicious and fresh, but my absolute favorite was the 49er roll. As I've mentioned before, it's a rule of thumb for me to try it if it's ever on the menu. Best 49er roll I've had in SF. 

All in all, our bill came to about $100. Definitely not a place I'll be going to on a whim or just a random night considering my college student budget....but for special occasions, definitely.

Just go, you won't regret it!
author: Kathleene E.

description:
BEST SASHIMI/NIGIRI IN TOWN! 

Everything is super fresh and high quality. Was disappointed they didn't have fresh uni the night I went but I'll be back for it another time. They did have fresh scallop though which we did order. Melt in your mouth goodness. They also brought out this other dish to accompany the scallop which was made from the I don't remember what but it was strings of crunchy stuff and very good.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Always want to try to restaurant and finally did.  Came here with my friend around 8:30pm.  Luckily, there was no wait for party of two.

The service was just ok.  Kinda slow.  We sat for about 7-10 minutes then the server came over and asked us for the drinks.  The food also took a while to come out too.  

We ordered:

Hamachi Nigiri  - The fish was fresh but the vinegar in the sushi rice was too much.  I could say too sour.  Definitely ruined the taste of the fish.

Romeo and Juliet Roll -  It had Scallop, Salmon, Avocado, Tobiko and Japanese Mayo.  The rice here were still too much vinegar but it was better with the rolls because it added to other ingredients and sauces.  The scallop and salmon were fresh but the rolls were pretty small.  

Rainbow Roll - Very standard and nothing special


Agedashi Tofu - The fried tofu was ok.  Lightly batter.  My favorite dish of the night.  

Overall the dinner was just ok. Kinda pricy and maybe we just came here at the bad night....Too much vinegar in the rice and that definitely ruined all the sushi and fish.
author: Liza T.

description: Ebisu translate into the god of fisherman; very suitable name for this place. still happy after a year of coming to this place, and each time it still surprises me how good it is. I love how the sushi chef always comes up with different selections and ideas for my nigiri. He knows what i do and don't likes as well as alternatives. It's always great to try something new from him. i suggest don't be a stranger to and try to avoid the bar; i think that's the best seats in the restaurant because you get live entertainment from the sushi chefs but also you can build a relationship with them.
author: Leme K.

description: Every roll and dish is out-of-this world.  By far the best sushi place in San Francisco.
author: Cassie C.

description: Anything baked there is delicious. It had interesting menu items, but it worked somehow. Baked oyster and rolls are so soft and light, the texture is extraordinary!
author: Wilson T.

description:
In summary to my review below: long wait and staff is unorganized and rude. Not worth the wait!

Waited an hour and a half to be seated. There was only 2 of us in my party. The hostess had given our table to someone who was on the list after us and didn't apologize when confronted. When we were finally seated our waitress seemed to have a staring problem along with a big attitude. After receiving our rolls, we asked for ginger and we did not receive the ginger for another 25 minutes. Our waitress did not ask how things were till way after (read a similar review about this on Yelp). Towards the end of our meal, the staff was rushing us (also a theme in other reviews). The waitress boxed our leftovers in front of us. It didn't seem necessary but she wouldn't let us take over. She also looked like her soul was being sucked out of her while she did so.....such a happy dinner! I was hoping to really like this place but the long wait and poor service will keep me elsewhere.
author: Louise C.

description:
This is a small restaurant in a part of SF that I have actually never been to and I'm so glad that I came here. It can be easy to miss as it has blue awning/curtains hanging over the door (a steeple in Japan). You enter and automatically are greeted by the serving staff and cooks with "Irrashaimase!" (another custom in Japanese culture; greeting the customer into their business). I felt like I was back in Japan.

There is both seating at tables and at the bar and it's pretty busy. But our waitress was very quick to give us menus. We decided on getting an order of tamago, unagi, and a special roll they call "Family Affair". Wow. This sushi was to die for good! It was so fresh and beautifully prepared. I love tamago, but you can generally tell when it's actually been prepared versus being pre made. This was definitely made right on the spot. And the unagi was warm and slipped right onto my tongue. And I really enjoyed the Family Affair roll; I was curious to see if the combinations of onion and tuna was going to work but it blended beautifully.

Next time I come back here I definitely want to sit at the bar and watch them make the food and talk to the chefs!
author: Saroya W.

description:
Very fresh fish! We tried oyster on half shell, lobster dynamite(daily special), agedashi tofu, 49ers roll, kobe beef nigiri. All of them were awesome. Lobster dynamite was the best among the best. You can taste the freshness and the service was awesome too.

Only cons: hard to find a parking around here, which was understandable in the city tho.
author: Wang W.

description:
This is some of the best sushi I have ever had. The fish is fresh, the service impeccable, and friendly and great selection of foods. 

My personal favorites are the Romeo and Juliet, and Family Affair rolls; the Hawaiian poke, and the fresh salad. With some wine these dishes make for a memorable dinner.

My only quibble is the take-away orders seem to be smaller than the dinning in. So where a roll being consumed in the restaurant would be plenty of food, the take away order seems to leave me wanting more. However, the price is the same.  

This brings me to the reason I order take away - the long wait time for a table and inability to make a reservation. It's a small place and very popular. So, one can expect that  unless there for lunch, or for dinner at exactly 5pm or the weather is inclement, the wait may be upwards of an hour or more.

That's not to say it wouldn't be worth the wait, because I have waited an hour and despite being so ravenous I could eat my own hand by the time I got seated, I was glad I waited after the food arrived.
author: Shannon V.

description:
Hands down the best sushi I've ever had in my life. Been to many places in sf but this is about the only place I now go to. Took my family of sushi lovers and they all said it was the best they had ever had. Not only that the staff is great, always busy but so nice and helpful. My boyfriend made a mistake in his order and it was his fault and the server fixed right away free of charge knowing full well we had made the mistake. We always sit at the bar and love to talk with the chefs. They're funny, down to earth people that really went above and beyond there job no only with the food but with how they treat you like your a friend over for dinner. Truly an amazing place with amazing staff and the best sushi the city and California has to offer. Thank you for all you do and the outstanding experiences I always have.

Jade
author: Jade D.

description:
I've heard some very positive things about this restaurant, so this evening I thought I would try it out. 

I saw the sashimi options and went with the Omakase (the Chef's sashimi selection for 1-2 people). It came, it appeared very nice at first, but as I began to eat I noticed that the cuts of fish were done sloppily. The rough cuts were somewhat acceptable, because I wasn't expecting the finest sushi dining. But as I began to eat, I noticed several scales still on my fish. As I ate the fish, something seemed off. This was supposedly the fresh fish of the day, so I continued eating, paid, and went home.

Since then (about a couple hours or so), I have been very sick with some kind of food poisoning. It is extremely negligent of them to serve fish that has turned and unfortunate for me to have to feel this way.

I now do not trust Ebisu and will definitely not return again.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Definitely would come here again ! not the bestttt sushi i had
but the service here was just... FABULOUS ! my TEA never hit the bottom of the cup !
they always came around with the tea pot and refilled it. and i Drink a LOT of tea when i eat sushi ! 
The waitress was very funny and kind and helpful when it comes to ordering since it was my first time there with my date. we were being very indecisive and she helped us through the menu.
Gave her a $20 tip ^_^ hope she got to use that for herself. lol
author: Jenny N.

description:
Epic night at ebisu! Girlfriend brought me here on a surprise dinner and loved it. Top quality sushi rolls and an incredible raw beef starter. Chef was willing to create an improvised impromptu special for us and fit the bill perfectly. Had some sake with the meal; neither of us are particularly knowledgeable in this department, but our waiter was helpful, patient, did us right. 

Easily one of my new top favorite sushi spots in the city, I will definitely be coming back!
author: William L.

description:
I chose the combo 3 bento ( it has Salmon teriyaki, maguro sashimi and vegetable tenpura).
The potion was huge. I think some people can't finish to eat all. I was satisfied with all food and service. 
Especially the Salmon teriyaki was good. It was grilled perfectly and sauce was not too sweet and salty. 
But I found some points  to improve. The maguro sashimi was little bit fishy so I had to eat  with wasabi. And the vegetable tenpura was coating too much so I couldn't taste original vegetable flavor. 
The price is little bit expensive for Lunch but you can enjoy many Japanese food in this box so you might accept it. Totally I enjoyed the food and service so I recommend.
author: 瞬

description: Best Sushi in all the land!!!! Great customer service....Nice people...You really feel at home when you come in here. I truly appreciate good customer service. You just want to sit in here all day and never leave.
author: Glynn G.

description: The food is really so so. Fishes are not that fresh. I ordered the scallop nigiri and the taste was covered by the lemon. And the oyster dynamics was not good. Couldn't taste either the oysters nor the uni. The tasted was overwhelmed by the sauce which I didn't like. Then ordered the sake clam, the soup was too salty and again I couldn't taste the clams at all. Very disappointed with the food.  Nonetheless, the service was good, the atmosphere was decent. Maybe go back for a drink???
author: Phoebe W.

description: The first thing that got my mouth watering was the architecture.  What a beautiful interior!  Very authentic and a great mixture of traditional and modern.  The food was as delicate and beautifully structured as the restaurant.  I personally ate a gazillion different things and was impressed by each bite.  If I could translate the 5 stars into one word, it would be: MMMMM
author: Alex T.

description:
So thankful I barely had to wait! Wanted to go to Nopalito's but they said the wait would've been like 45 minutes ): 

Anyways, I ordered the Saba Steak (shioyaki because I didn't want teriyaki, & it means it's just salted, no sauce) which was a perfectly grilled piece of mackerel! When they first served it, it looked a little dry but then I opened it up and it was soooo moist! Couldn't have been cooked better. My dish also came with a really nice portion of salad which was super fresh and delicious. It was vibrant and had a light dressing which I really enjoyed. There were also little portions of other veggies on the side and came with a bowl of rice and miso soup (which was a little sweet strangely). I really enjoyed this dish because it's not very heavy, the portion was perfect, and it tasted great! I also tried a king crab & a salmon skin hand roll which were both delicious. The crab was nice and fresh. Super sweet with an avocado for a nice creamy texture. The salmon skin hand roll was nice, too. It was nice and crispy, but it was more of a textural experience. There were some, I believe, pickled veggies inside which was nicely dressed. Lastly, since it was Valentine's day, they had a special roll in honor and it was composed of spicy tuna on the inside, and avocado and tuna on the top. There was also "gold flakes" on top, but I'm 99% sure we just ate glitter hahahhaha. And I would have preferred the spicy tuna to be a little spicier since it was a very mellow. 

All in all, I would come back to try more of their specialty rolls! I saw other tables' orders and they looked beautifully delicious. I can tell they treat their food very well and get good fish. Prices aren't too bad either for the quality and portions! It has a nice atmosphere, friendly service, and a pretty interior (:
author: Holly P.

description:
Pretty decent quality here.  My last review must have had me in a bad mood.

Updated from my visit yesterday: They do not skim on the Uni.  Very good here.  Love the variety of fish.  Tried new things like salmon toro which was very good, and sardine which surprsed me and XXX which was awesome.

I've been here many times in the past and the owner Steve hasn't changed one bit.  Tom and Suzuki still work their magic behind the counter and it's hard not to stop drinking the night away here.

Always good times are had here.
author: Tony U.

description: Good hamachi, 49ers roll, rock and roll.  Reasonably priced.  Fast service.  Gave us free edamame and oranges.
author: Niniane W.

description:
Have been here 3 times now and fall in love with it more every time. This can be credited as my "gateway" sushi restaurant. Before coming here I was the teriyaki salmon/chicken and rice girl. Now I've graduated to a variety of nigiri and some rice paper rolls (seaweed and I aren't bffs). 

Tips: get there close to opening. They don't take reservations so getting there for first seating is key to not waiting. If you can sit at the bar it's awesome to have the sushi chefs in action serving you food directly. 

Cant say enough good about this place - definitely worth a try.
author: Maggie F.

description:
I love coming here, everything is always super fresh, the staff are super friendly and attentive, Tommy is awesome and is a great entertainer behind the sushi bar. 
The seafood salad is the perfect way to start, and all of the specials on the board are all worth a try. 
The sake list is good, make sure to try the black devil it's really smooth. 
Everyone I have taken here has gone back on their own. 
Go early, the earlier you go the less wait and more available street parking. 
Everything I have tried here I would eat again and plan to in the future.
author: Blake R.

description:
Quite possibly the best sushi I've ever had.

Now, this is probably not saying much because all my previous sushi was in Indiana. San Francisco likely has much better access to fresh, quality fish, being on the coast and all. But still, when I tasted the first bite of my sushi roll, I felt like I had been missing something in my life until that moment.

We sat at the bar, and I ordered the XXX roll, the chef's special, though I didn't even know what that was until I got it. But trust the chef, he knows what he's doing. My friend got lobster tempura, which was pretty good, but my roll was better. The service the whole time was excellent.

Then, to top it all off, one of the chefs at the bar did a fancy trick with an orange and then gave a lovely spirally piece of edible orange artwork. Loved it!

My co-worker who lives in the Market district recommended Ebisu because he goes here all the time, and I'm super happy I followed his recommendation.
author: Bethany S.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday because Haname Brasserie was closed.  Ugh.  The host was non-speaking and a little rude.  Shoved us in a corner at the bar when there were several open seats at the other end, presumably so he didn't have to walk that far to fill up water glasses.

The food was impressive, but more expensive than what we were looking for, and quite honestly, NOT what we were looking for.  Sometimes you just want a simple sashimi plate without crunchy weird mollusk bits, and a nice bowl of miso soup.  This is not where you're going to get it.
author: Benjamin E.

description: Super fast service, even when the place was full. We got all of the dishes we ordered quickly and the staff was very attentive. Really, really good sushi.
author: X-topher B.

description: It was alright. The atmosphere was pretty cool. It was around 9:30pm so the workers could have been tired for all I know.
author: Kristy A.

description: Don't expect a warm greeting by the mamasan. The place seems to get super busy just after 6, so it's obviously a good place to eat since the people show up....?? I wasn't super hungry so got the Chirashi box which was good, except for the fake crab and something that resembled octopus and tasted really fishy. The other person who went with me got the grilled salmon which looked good, but I question the health aspects of salmon served outside of Alaska.
author: Joshua M.

description:
I have been to this place twice and I have had a very pleasant experience both times.

The sashimi here is very fresh and tastes great. The Omakase is reasonably priced given the high quality of the fish. Both times I sent some beer to our chef, who greatly appreciated it. I'm generally not a fan of ankimo, but I really liked it here. The standout dish for me was the ikura with quail egg.
The service is a little on the slow side but that is expected considering how busy this place is. 

The atmosphere is pretty casual. The last time I was there it was really hot and stuffy inside. I'm not exactly sure what happened to the AC.

Overall, this is one of my favorite places for sashimi in the city.
author: George Z.

description:
Ebisu is my go-to sushi and sashimi spot! 

My boyfriend and I probably eat here once a month if not more. It is the freshest fish that just melts in your mouth! Whether you are coming with a small group or with your special someone for a date night, this place will not disappoint. I do recommend sitting at the sushi bar for a great sushi experience. All of the sushi chefs are amazing and engaging if you want to spark a conversation.

My favorites: 
- Salmon Sashimi
- Double Hamachi Roll
- Salmon Toro (salmon belly nigiri)
- Hamachi Toro (yellowtail belly nigiri)
- Negitoro Roll (tuna belly with green onion roll)
- Boston Roll (crab, raw salmon, and avocado roll topped with tobiko)
- Unagi Nigiri (BBQ eel nigiri)
- Lobster Tempura (fried lobster tail chunks drizzled with house mayo sauce)
- Lemon Garlic Edamame
author: Sharon L.

description:
So my experience here wasn't as great as most of the other Yelper's on here. I came here on a Thursday night for dinner to meet a guy for a first date.  First mistake was choosing a Thursday night (same night as Cal Academy's Nightlife), so parking was horrendous. I was already running late to dinner and then it took me an additional 1 hour to find parking. It was so bad I had to pick up my date and he helped me look for parking around the area. The parking here that night was worse than trying to find parking on a sunny day at Dolores Park. What gives? So I was not off to a good start.

Luckily we did have reservations to this place, but we still sat at the bar.  I wouldn't normally complain about eating at the bar, except on a first date, it doesn't allow both people to have a decent conversation since you're in that awkward position where you constantly have to turn to the side in order to talk.

We ordered a mixture of items including sashimi, nigiri, some rolls and some drinks. I thought the quality of the food was good, but not worth it for how ridiculous it was to find parking. The bill was quite expensive for two people, but the worst part of the night was that my date made me split the bill. Ouch. Needless to say, there wasn't a second date. Call me traditional, but a guy should always offer to pay on the first date as a sign of chivalry and a girl should also offer to help pay as a kind gesture, but the guy should not allow her to. I'm just saying.

This rating is more a reflection of my experience there that night, which was very unpleasant. Always come hungry, never come hangry (hungry + angry). In any case, perhaps my rating for Ebisu will go up if I ever make it out to these neck of the woods again to give it a second try, unlike I did for my date that night!
author: Sophia H.

description: Delicious food, great service, & a nice ambiance. My close friends and I went here for dinner and ordered 6 different types of rolls. They were so fresh and full of flavor. Each roll was cooked perfectly and had different tastes. The wait isn't long either if you go early for dinner. Oh and for dessert the green tea ice cream and red bean ice cream were to die for.
author: Amanda D.

description: Premium Blue fin Toro... drops mic.
author: Jessie L.

description: I love this place. What's not to say about it. Daily specials are good. Wait can be long. But service is fast. Sushi is super fresh. Haven't had anything here I didn't like, and I have slowly been trying a lot of different sushi items. I haven't tried anything but sushi.
author: Marian G.

description:
Great sushi in the inner sunset! Spicy tuna wrapped in avocado, it is two per order, we both got two orders.....as a warm up.

It was one of those nights when you have the super hungries and keep ordering. We hadn't been out for a while so decided to order whatever we wanted. Super fresh sashimi salmon,  double hamachi rolls, a family affair roll. 
Super food in a casual place.

Will be back. Like tomorrow for dinner!
author: Dani K.
