description: I came here a couple of times for Omakase sushi with some friends and it is one of the best culinary experience I've ever had. Tonight, it just raised to a new level. I sat next to a customer who has been coming to the place for 30 years, and he gave us some items that 1)no where to be found on the menu 2)never seen even for chef Omakase. These are some of the best things I've ever had in life. Better than the famous egg on egg on egg in Sakamai in NYC. Needless to say, I got a membership card.
author: Mengmeng C.

description:
My favorite sushi restaurant of all time! 

I've been coming here since I was little, when I wasn't even allowed to eat sashimi and my parents would only order the caterpillar roll for me. All these years, I've never been disappointed. The sashimi is always fresh! And that's all I really ask for when it comes to sushi. I've been to many sushi restaurants before, restaurants that are world-renowned and $$$$. But I still find Ebisu superior, maybe I'm biased...

Things I recommend ordering:
Uni (always fresh and melts in your mouth)
Amaebi (so sweet and succulent) 
Tobiko (the biggest and crunchiest tobiko I've ever had anywhere)
Romeo and Juliet roll
Double Hamachi roll

What else can I say? Ebisu is the best!
author: Bianca C.

description: Solid food with a casual neighborhood atmosphere and nice interior. Probably the best quality to value ratio compared to other sushi restaurants in Sunset. Will definitely return.
author: Tina W.

description: The fish is so fresh and everyone here is very attentive and friendly.  Wish we lived closer, but worth the trek for good sushi.  The 49er roll and family affair rolls are my favorite.
author: Liz L.

description: Came here a little after they opened so we didn't have to wait in line. The service was great, our waitress was really nice and attentive. We ordered the Romeo and Juliet roll (the best one), tootsie roll, and Louisiana. The Louisiana roll is a bit spicier. Overall everything was delicious and tasted really fresh! Definitely coming back. Prices were affordable ($7-$15 for specialty rolls). Only advice is to come early - it started to get really packed as we left.
author: Mighty N.

description:
MMMMMMMMMMMMMMMM SUCH YUMMMMMMMMM

shib swear shib iz not cate. but raw fish tast such grate here. bestest japan fud in sunset. fishy lik to so melt inside of doge mouth.

1. locashun:
- parking such phailing. take N muni and stope at 9th & irving.
- inside look such beauty. wood everwhere. shib feel like shib in japan. such nostalgic
- many wait. plz come erly or plz come late. then not waiting.
- can get many loudz. since wood everwhere, noize echo and can get loudz.

2. fud: wow. doge is heppy doge. wow. get chirashi. many beauty. so feesh. feesh is almost such perfect every tim. sometim not as good, but one of best. SALMON IS GRATE. also, miso soup is doge favorit miso. such gud flavor.

TIP: wai peepo like two strike no ball? fish taste weird. work better if fish fresherer. stay much away from two strike no ball.

TIP: get green tea, kirin, and miso. shib call this SUCH JAPAN LIQUID TRIFECTA. perfect combo for meal. tea balance miso, beer balance tea, miso balance beer. many perfection.

3. service: shib think serbice is such nice. girl always such refill shib tea, and ask if "everyting is O.K." Food come at normal speed.

shib report card: service A++, fish A++, appetizer B++, locashun B++
author: Doge S.

description: Best sushi I ever ate in SF! The fish is super fresh and the chefs are very friendly as well!! Best sushi ever!
author: C X.

description:
AMAZING!!! You could close your eyes and point to anything on the menu and it would knock your socks off. Seriously, this place is incredible. We've probably ordered everything here and it's all been to die for. I would list my favorites but then I would end up writing a novel on here :-) there's a reason they've been around for 30+ years!!!

Side note: there's always a bit of a wait (esp on the weekends) but you can order Sapporos and sit down while you wait to be seated. 100% worth it though.
author: Amy G.

description: If there was some sort of Venn Diagram of food quality, value and service, Ebisu would be that little part in the middle where everything overlaps. You have to be patient to eat here - its purely first come first serve. There is nothing amazing about the fish, but its quality is decent and the sushi chefs are friendly and attentive. While the omakase sashimi is a steal, I'd skip it, they don't really put their best fish into it  - go a la carte instead. I actually enjoyed their non-sushi items more - edamame trio, chawamushi, live scallop with fried bits. For ~$30/person you will walk out stuffed and happy - such a deal!
author: Snuffles B.

description: Ebisu's portions are smaller now, which makes me like the place less, but my change in rating is mostly due to my more refined sushi taste the past few years. Since I tried places such as Saru and Wako, I can't justify giving Ebisu five stars.
author: Paulina F.

description:
We like that it is good and affordable.   they can actually provide some $$$ level sushi at $$ prices!   Service is good. only complaint is sometimes it seems to be a bit too sweet for me!  I love the original taste of fish!

a good place to hang out and have good sushi all in all!
author: Shuting Z.

description:
SUSHI! I came here not really expecting to eat much because I had already eaten dinner.  But I couldn't resist!  The wait may be awhile but the wait is worth it.  

My friends and I ordered:
kobe sashimi--one of my favorite dishes! The kobe sashimi kept rolled and there were a couple different sauces for dipping. I definitely recommend getting this.  It is well worth it.
omakase for 3 people--plenty of sashimi for 3 people.  The fish was fresh and delicious.
potato bug roll--basically a roll for unagi lovers.  It was good but I thought the the double hamachi roll was better.
double hamachi roll--this roll was really good.  I haven't had rolls in awhile. And this roll was worth eating.
live scallop--It came as a nigiri placed on the scallop's shell.  They also deep fried the other part of the scallop for us.  The scallop was delicious.

We sat at the sushi bar and the chef was very attentive and friendly.  I normally don't sit at the bar because I find eating with more than 2 people to be quite difficult.  It was a little difficult this time but with the friendliness of the chef, it was worth it.  The service from the waitresses was also good.
author: Jessica T.

description: This is a good place to get your sushi on. Seating is limited so better come early. Order the rolls and sushi. It's worth every cent. And the omakaze too. Wash it down with a cold glass of beer. Enjoy.
author: Ram B.

description:
I'm not a sushi person. I am just...I'm not. I'm pretty lukewarm when it comes to the raw stuff, but I will eat a roll. So the boyfriend and I meander over to this place, and he's got high hopes, and I'm hoping there will be yummy rolls for an uncultured fool like myself.

The reason this place gets a 5 is because they completely changed my mind about raw fish. We got the double hamachi. Usually, I'm hesitant. Raw fish reminds me of fishy gummi bears, and I just can't handle that. But the double hamachi was ridiculously amazing. It had yellowtail on top, hamachi in the center. After putting one in my mouth, I'm pretty sure I almost cried, because I can't believe I've been missing out on this. I've had hamachi before, but I can see why the boyfriend was always complaining about other sushi restaurants - this is the sort of quality he usually looks for, and I confess that I see the light.

The place itself is pretty tiny, but very well-decorated. The servers are super friendly, if not hurried - still, because the place is so small, you can see how busy it is, and even though it was busy, a server was never hard to come across. At one point I was staring off into space and a waitress came by asking if I was okay. I must've looked distraught, but I assured her all was well.

I would definitely go back, and next time, I want to sit at the sushi bar. The nice old man was really funny and I was jealous of all the people sitting there and getting their sushi super quickly (if you sit at the tables, expect the normal wait time for table orders). Or perhaps I can come at a time when it isn't packed full of loud drunk people. Now that I think of it, there was a lunch menu...
author: Robbin A.

description:
I came here for a late lunch on a weekday and it was still pretty crowded with families and children. 
We started with Kobe beef kushiyaki skewers which were marinated with a tasty sauce but a slightly overcooked. We then ordered a family affair roll which was above average in freshness and ingredients. We followed with nigiri orders of scallop, albacore toro, and butterfish. I highly recommend all three.
I want to try their spicy tuna wrapped in avocado next time!
author: Alfred L.

description: Best sushi place around the inner sunset. The fish are fresh and the sushi chef is extremely nice. My boyfriend and I was sitting there debating on an additional roll to order and the chef made us a special roll. The green tea creme brûlée was very good also! Have been here for a few times and will definitely come back again.
author: Crystal W.

description:
As I've gotten older, I've become increasingly open to eating raw seafood. Came to Ebisu one night with my fran, and he insisted that we get the sea urchin... uhm... not too open to THAT just yet (I didn't enjoy it but he did). However, I am a huge fan of Ebisu's sushi+sashimi. Everything was reallyyyy fresh, and even though I forgot the names of the rolls, they were all delicious. Service was good -- waitresses were friendly and food came out quickly. 

Ebisu is probably the best Japanese restaurant in the city -- it's sort of small, but the exterior is really cute (and fitting for a Japanese establishment) & their sushi is phenomenal.
author: I. L.

description:
The fish is some of the best I've had in town. Loved it. I took my mom, stepdad, and GF here. We each had the chirashi except for the gf (who's a vegetarian). None of us had any complaints about fish - delish.

The only downside was that the vegetarian roll they made for the GF was a bit pricey at $15! No fish and it came out to a 15 dollar roll? WTH
author: Astro D A.

description: I came back and got the Chirashi and it was pretty darn tasty! Fresh fish and a lot of it, the sweet egg was yummy and the rice was flavored perfectly. My friend got the bento box and it was so many different things in it, looked good! $20each for both entrees
author: Karen T.

description: My family and I Lovveee EBISU! Our favorite Japanese Restaurant in the City ! You can NEVER go wrong with Ebisu. Customer Service is always excellent and Food is amazing. My Favorite meal is the Beef Teriyaki/Steak with spinach and potatoes and broccoli.
author: Alyssa M.

description:
It seems like every Thursday night you have to fight off the hoards of people leaving Academy Nightlife. Most of the restaurants around 9th and Irving were packed but we snagged some sushi bar seats at Ebisu. Often times I enjoy sitting at the sushi bar knowing that you interact directly to the person preparing your food. 

Miso soup - not watered down like so many other places

*Albacore Tataki - bigger portions than I would have thought. Lightly seared on the outside with onions and ponzu sauce aplenty. http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/waW-nUlXZvDk7QnKuMzsIg/l.jpg

Boston Roll - slightly disappointed to find this in the specialty sushi items on the menu. Felt like a simple salmon roll

Rainbow Roll - a good mix of different raw fish on top of still steaming sushi with tempura shrimp on the inside. Fulfilling

i really wish we had the appetite to try more items on the menu including the special items written on the blackboard behind the bar. The waitresses were hustling and everything came out fast. Altogether, the entire staff works like a well-oiled machine.

____
Aug '11 Health Score - 74...yikes!
Circled around at least twice for parking
author: Dennis L.

description: Delicious and reasonably priced! The service was so great and the food came out so fast. The wait to be seated wasn't too long. The sushi tasted so fresh and was presented so nicely. I only wish I took pictures before I ate everything!
author: Reina C.

description: I always love the food here, it's so fresh and the quality is fantastic. I sat at the bar with my family and the sushi chef took really good care of us, checking up on us once in a while to make sure we were ok. I highly recommend the hamachi Kama and any of the sashimi. My only complaint was that I felt REALLY rushed by the wait staff. I was asked close to five times whether I was done with my food. They were clearing plates way too quickly. Maybe sitting at a table is better if you're trying to leisurely enjoy your meal.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: My favorite sushi spot in the city. Great sushi, rolls, and dinner dishes as well. It's a small, "hole in the wall," restaurant, so be prepared to wait some nights, but it's definitely worth it.
author: John V.

description: Living in the area, I would say that this is the best sushi restaurant around where I can just walk to. Everything here taste very fresh and the service is fantastic. Love that they have new specials every week, giving me something new to try every time I visit. The price is the average price you'll see in a semi-upscale sushi restaurant. The decor of the restaurant is very modern and quite inviting. However, the place can be a little tight when its a busy night. I would definitely recommend to my friends and family.
author: Arda S.

description: Live clam was delicious. The rolls (XXX, Double Hamachi) and mirugai were good, but eating live was really the way to go. Live clam came with 6 small nigiri pieces and some tempura veggies on the side making the $18 worth it. Wait time was about 20 minutes at 8:30pm on a Friday night. They do not take reservations. Stopped by the bar across the street for a beer for 30 minutes and we were already called. The tables moved fast here! Sat at the sushi bar - the sushi chefs were very friendly.
author: Aleyna S.

description: Fanciful menu, extraordinary food, great service. Get there early, sit on the floor, try everything, and hang on until there's no sake left in the place. (If you can't get in, head for their sister restaurant, Hotei, just across the street.)
author: Michael P.

description:
I've been eating here fairly regularly for at least 10 years and have never had a bad meal or an unpleasant experience.  When I moved to SF, it was from the mid-west, where... sushi is *not so good.*  Always an experience that made me a bit apprehensive.  Ebisu was the first place I was taken in SF, the place that made me love sushi, crave it, eat it several times a week.

The wait staff is nice, friendly, and attentive in a polite way -- not hovering but there when you need them.  They pace meals well, bringing one or two orders at a time, clearing plates constantly through the meal, and checking back to make sure everything is OK frequently.  Someone is almost constantly coming through with water and tea refills as well.  There can be a long wait for a table during peak hours on weekends, but it's a very popular place, so that is to be expected.  I usually go in early or on week nights and rarely have a wait.

The restaurant was remodeled a couple of years ago, and I like it a lot better now.  It looks cleaner and more modern.  That said, I miss the tatami room in the back, which was great for larger parties. It is a bit difficult to bring a group to Ebisu now.  I find it is best suited for parties of 4 or smaller, and the dining configuration is even more cramped now that they've eliminated some of the seating space in the remodel.

On to the most important matter:  the food.  I'm easily put off by "fishy" smells or tastes.  I've never found that to be a concern here.  Fish is always very fresh, cuts are good.  They have a wide selection of both more conventional dishes and Westernized specialty rolls.  Some of the rolls are unique to Ebisu and quite inventive compared to other sushi places in this city.  It is true that they have scaled down the menu after the remodel, but there are still enough choices to keep anyone happy.  My "must order" list always seems to grow, far beyond what I can actually eat in one sitting. :)

My standard order (why, yes, I'm a glutton):

1) 49ER ROLL - This is a must order.  Ebisu has ruined me. Theirs is the best; if it's on the menu at any other sushi restaurant, I order it, and then am disappointed when it's not as good as Ebisu's.  If it's not on the menu elsewhere, I'm crestfallen.  It is now impossible to be satisfied with a sushi meal if there is no 49'er roll.  Last weekend, one of my friends had to endure my attempt to peel slivers of lemon to put on my non-49er-roll at another establishment.  The combination is really *that* good.

2) Sashimi - usually sake or hirame in my case, but I've yet to hear of anything that's not good.

3) Kobe beef sashimi or nigiri, whatever is on the day's special

4) UMESHISO maki roll - I feel as strongly about this as I do the 49er roll; not coincidentally, this is also one of the standards by which I judge sushi places.  A bit unfair, unbalanced, and strange, I know, but hey, I am all of those things!

5) Ebisu Maki - I'd thought they'd dropped this from the menu, but it's just been relocated under the non-specialty roll section.  It's a maki roll with salmon and a bunch of vegetables (like sprouts, cucumber, some root veggies, can't recall exactly).

6) The a la carte skewers I've tried have been quite good and I usually order one or more after failing to convince myself that I've ordered quite enough already.


There are a lot of other wonderful things that I don't order, because I am allergic to them, and consequently, my life is very sad.  But my friends order them, rave over them, and I drool and wish I could eat them.  For example:
- Potato Bug
- Dragon Roll
- Caterpillar
- Hamachi Sashimi, in particular, I've heard is very good


The portions for most items are pretty generous.  Obviously sashimi and nigiri orders are not very large, but the specialty rolls are enormous.   If I am being reasonable about the amount of food that is strictly necessary, I would be content with one specialty roll, one piece of sashimi and maybe a small maki roll (like umeshiso or avocado).  I am not very reasonable though....

The only negative experience at Ebisu, is when the check comes, and I do a double take before remembering how much I ordered.

I have tried just ordering take-out to avoid this problem but it doesn't really work since as soon as I look at the menu, I find myself rattling off half a dozen items.
author: Heidi M.

description: Very very good sushi at a reasonable price.  The miso soup was good, but miso soup is not so much to write about.  The edamame trio was really good; I personally enjoyed the garlic one.  The fish was really fresh -- we ended up ordering three orders of salmon sashimi between three of us because it was so good.  We had a yellow tail roll that was also outstanding.  The rainbow roll we had was solid.  The other roll we selected had tempura in it; it was good, but I would opt to stick with fish next time.  I've had more "creative" sushi before, but the quality of the fish is as good as any I've ever had.  Service was good as well.  I'll definitely be back when I'm in the area.
author: Diane B.

description:
Came here for lunch last week and it was worth every dollar we spent! I ordered the crunchy & dragon roll and they were both delicious. The wrapping on the crunchy roll was unique and hidden crunch was pretty exciting ( you have to try it to get what I'm saying) I wish I took a picture of the food but I always forget until I'm halfway done.
Great service too!
author: Melissa C.

description: This place is amazing!!! The freshest fish I've ever had. Its reasonable and cozy. Not your typical sushi bar.
author: Inga S.

description: Best sushi in SF! The wait can sometimes be long but well worth it. There are many vegan options which is always amazing. My friends and family have said the quality of the fish is impressive and the rolls are creative and flavorful. A must for anyone who loves sushi in SF.
author: Campbell R.

description: The quality of the fish is good here but the size of the fish is not as big unfortunately. Good experience but won't be going back.
author: Nessy N.

description:
This place has gone downhill, food wise. The decor, cleanliness and service are still the same. The wait time is the same. 

The presentation and food quality has gone DOWN since I was here last. It feels more "home-style" than the nice restaurant it used to be. The cuts of meat we had weren't as refined as before. Presentation was off as well--not as pretty or stylized as before. More like bento box lunch special than a nice meal.

I would come back, but my expectations are definitely lowered.
author: Bianca U.

description:
We came here when we realized the original sushi place we desired was a further walk than expected.

We were quickly seated in a table on the side wall - away from the people, just as we like it.  Although it was later, we were coming for lunch.

We started with water, although I also ordered the complimentary green tea later in the meal - get it, it pairs well with several foods.

We tried many dishes, including the live scallops (WOW! Best scallop prep I've had in quite awhile - expensive, but it was good) and the clams in sake was great too - we ended up turning the broth into a "soup" and eating that alone too.  The sushi was good, although there was quite a bit of rice in each bite compared to the amount of fish.

There were two people waiting on us - but they didn't seem to know it - so we were a little confused, but everything worked out.

Overall, a great place to check out if you are near GGP and want to have lunch.

Be aware, for dinner, they get a line quickly.
author: Megan E.

description:
Service is sooooo slow here! 
The waitress/waiters need to be trained better so that they are more efficient.
The food was pretty decent, but def over priced for what it is.
author: Rita K.

description: Had really high hopes for it being one of the Michelin listed, but wasn't as good as I hoped. Sushi would be better. And restaurant is a bit too small and tight far as seating and had to wait in a long line. But services were really good and the interior was very clean.
author: Helen Z.

description: Excellent fish. Nothing else to be said. Also the decor is very modern Japanese and comfortable but not stuffy.
author: Jenny J.

description:
Waited around 25-30 minutes for a small table of 2. Be sure to check in with the hostess and grab their attention or else you will just be standing there.

The server was really sweet. She had a nice friendly attitude and knew the food on their menu pretty well. Came to check on us once in a while. 

We ordered the beef sashimi, Amaebi, bento combo, the oyster barnabi, and omakase that serves 1-2 people. Everything came accordingly and seemed reasonably timely EXCEPT the omakase. We basically finished everything, including the bento box and the omakase was still not here. When it finally came after what seemed like a 40 minute wait, I started to dig in. But as I was eating the radish with the sashimi, I looked down at my piece of sashimi and found a hair in it. COMPLETELY GROSSED ME OUT AND RUINED MY APPETITE. 

The waitress came by and asked if we needed a box and I said no we are done, there's a hair in my food. She apologizes and asked if we wanted to be compensated by some dessert. Sorry but my appetite was completely ruined after seeing that. 

The sashimi cuts on the omakase is small and tiny, you're basically paying for the looks and presentation of the dish. The beef sashimi is the best. The bento combos are the best and the fastest to come out. The oyster barnabi is a rip off, 16 dollars FOR ONE oyster with little uni, a quail egg, and ikura. Amaebi was okay. 

We paid and left. Overall, the food is mediocre but the price is a little pricer than most sushi places. The portion sizes are small and you easily can spend over 100 dollars for 2 people. I would not come back for a long time.
author: Jeanne Z.

description:
This place is great! Their rolls are very fresh and delicious! Love every bite of it!

My recommendations are:
1. KOBE BEEF is a must try.
2. #29 roll
3. Boston roll
4. Tokyo tower (not as good as the other though)

We only ordered 4 rolls that night because there were only 2 of us. In case you're wondering, the other roll was the Bonsai Roll. I didn't really like it because it had all these veggie and carrot so the taste was pretty much run down by the veggies. The salmon skin was good and crunchy though!! I cannot wait to go back!
author: Verdina P.

description: Wonderful sashimi and omakase experience sitting at the bar. Saw the chef skills in action and fresh fish on display. Romeo and Juliet specialty roll was delicious, sweet scallop atop salmon and avocado. A bit pricey but so worth it!
author: Peachie Y.

description:
I was really impressed with this place, recommended by a friend who lived in SF for some years. A stellar job with some more typical rolls (I tried a dragon roll and an Ume shiso roll), and an inventive combination of flavors on a more specialty type roll (Dexter Carter roll - which featured thinly slices lemon overlaying some of the freshest salmon I've had in a long time). I was also able to request a custom roll (tempura sweet potato and tuna). 

Service was very polite and there was no wait at 6:30 on a Tuesday night, though the place was filled up by 7ish.
author: Nicole B.

description:
Ebisu is one of my "must haves" every time I come back home to SF. The sushi is always fresh and the service is great. It's a pretty small place, so the restaurant gets crowded at dinner time, but it's worth the wait -- I'd suggest trying to come before 6 or after 9 if unless you don't mind waiting up to an hour, but it's worth the weight!

Personal favorites are the Dexter Carter role and Ahi tuna salad. If you come for lunch, the bento boxes are also delicious, let you try a few different things, and comes with more than enough food.
author: Christopher S.

description: We popped in like 5 minutes before closing and the staff were super kind and accommodating.  My friend and I were super hungry and ordered a ton of food - so much so that we actually pulled the table next to us over so we could fit everything!  Ha!  After we placed our order, the chefs/cooks began slangin' sushi out like it was nothin'!  Almost our entire order came out in less than 5 minutes - this is a good thing when you're hungry.  =)  This particular restaurant doesn't specialize in sauces or seasoning.  Their thing is they want people to taste clean fish.  I'm a sauce and wasabe person, so that was a little disappointing.  I would definitely return again, however, I wouldn't intentionally seek this place out.
author: Shaun W.

description: This is the best sushi I've had in SF, and pretty much the best I've had anywhere - I don't have the budget to compare huge numbers of high-end sushi restaurants, so that doesn't mean there aren't better places - but this is really really good, and I enjoy the atmosphere and decor quite a bit too - you kind of forget where you are - like a self-contained little world. The nigiri is great, of course, but I also particularly like the QP roll, and one with Salmon and thinly sliced lemon. Little touches like Miso soup and other stapes are on a different level than what you would find in a standard sushi place. Wish I could come more often. Only complaint is always having to wait.
author: Gabrielle M.

description:
Unfortunately I have to give a bad review for a place that averages 4 stars.  From the moment we walked in, the place had a pungent odor of raw fish+chlorine.  Maybe they just hosed down the whole restaurant, but we felt nauseous immediately.  We weren't too hungry so we just got the $25 omakasi between the two of us.  It was pretty unremarkable.   
The only thing that really stood out as nice was the decor. Service was pretty untrying. And we probably just ordered the wrong thing. We gobbled down the fish and bounced without an after thought.
author: James T.

description: Brought my brother and his family here for dinner. We had yellowtail nigiri, Romeo and Juliet specialty roll, chicken udon and tempura udon noodles.  It was delicious and high quality food overall. Service was also top notch.
author: Ella H.

description: My favorite sushi spot.  Everything, I mean everything is so fresh and delicious.  The place is always busy so be sure to plan for a little wait (or come at just the right time).  I honestly haven't had a bad meal here.
author: Meredith B.

description: One word: unbelievable! Freshest, tastiest toro (blue fun, albacore, hamachi, salmon), ankimo... Boy, everything is just perfect!
author: Vadim D.

description:
Although it's probably the most popular sushi restaurant in the Inner Sunset I've never really had an itching desire to check it out and have actually had some reservations about dining here based purely on the less than palatable sushi and cooked foods I've eaten at the Ebisu SFO International Airport location.  The taste and quality of the sushi at this Ebisu, the original location, was a delightful surprise.  Didn't hurt that it was also fairly priced.

Not extremely crowded when we arrived (around 5:20 pm on a Saturday), but had to sit at the sushi bar because all of the tables were occupied.  Our sushi chef was great; pleasant guy who could quickly and expertly form up some oblong-balls of rice and slice up some raw fish like nobody's business.  He prepared for us some blue fin tuna medium-toro nigiri, ikura, rainbow roll, double hamachi roll, spicy qp roll (scallop), and some other nigiri.  Good quality fresh fish in every bite.

Large crowds of folk were waiting in the vestibule area of the restaurant when we left so I was glad we ate a little early.  Good food and pleasant experience and atmosphere, so they won me over and I'll definitely be back.
author: Erich D.

description: If you love sushi, you must eat here. Period. Hands down, the best sushi in the Bay Area. Expensive, but incredible.
author: mary g.

description:
I came here with the BF bc it was recommended by his co-worker. It was a great recommendation! The place itself is not too large, but is clean, modern and decorated nicely.
 
All of the fish was fresh and tasted great.

Aged beef skewer, 4 star: i was skeptical about how they age the beef, it wasn't very big, but the flavor was great.

Teba (wings), 3 stars: for the price is was okay. The wings were very small but the sauce that came with it was good.

Seafood salad, 4 stars: decent amount of assorted fish. The fish was fresh, I wish the salad had more dressing.
author: Thuy N.

description:
It was just OK. Definitely overhyped. Food wise = 2. I gave it the extra star because of the service and of the sushi master and his great personality.

Tempura was whack. The batter was so weird and thick. Shrimp was small. Sauce was not flavorful.

Sushi rolls were small. Tasty, but small. Fish was fresh though. I give it that.

Bento box came with a lot of sides. But I ordered the beef teriyaki because I wanted some BEEF. Too bad it was tough and not tender. It also just wasn't very flavorful. I coulda asked for more terikayi sauce but I expected higher quality beef for a $16 bento box...
author: Christal T.

description:
OK. Doing a little pre-screening with the wifey for a small, upcoming wedding party dinner (8 people).

PROS - 

* Got right in (Sun @ 6pm). 
* Fresh Scallops done very nicely, with the whole skirt on the side.
* Nice sake' selection
* Friendly staff
* Hamachi (toro) was exceptional


CONS - 

* Sushi rice a little sweet.
* A bit noisy. (A few hanging  tapestries would solve nicely.)
* Cramped. Had waitress a$$ in my face.
* Tempura was a bit under done.
* $85/2 people
* Waitress too attentive. 

Overall: I was not relaxed and felt pressured to hurry up. Quality/presentation was exceptional. 

I will not return. 

 (we then proceeded to Blowfish Sushi for exact same order. See my review.)
author: Rich F.

description:
I was quite impressed by the sushi here.  Five of us came here for lunch for a coworker's birthday last week and we had a great meal.  Plus it was pretty reasonably priced, even a meal for five people split four ways!

One person got a bento box that she said was great and very filling.  The rest of us shared sushi.  Everything that came out was super fresh and delicious.  My favorite was the Romeo and Juliet with raw scallop and salmon.  We got the Lobster Dynamite special, served in oyster shells, and full of deliciousness.  We also tried the spider roll, some spicy tuna, eek, and yellowtail.  Everything was really fresh and really tasty.  They even experimented with wrapping some rolls in rice paper instead of seaweed, which was great for the person in our group who hates seaweed.  

Plus the waitstaff was actually really attentive to when our tea and water glasses needed refilling.  In all, I thoroughly enjoyed the fish here and would definitely come back for more sushi.  6 rolls for the 4 of us filed up 2 people, but 2 of us were left hungry afterward, so depending on how full you get with sushi you may need to order a few rolls.  Most of the special rolls came in eight pieces except for the spider roll in 4, and the regular rolls seemed to come in six pieces.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
I have been to Ebisu at least once a month since 1985.  Lately, since the closure of its sister restaurant across the street, Hotei, Ebisu has been completely full by 5:30 pm on weekends, so to avoid waiting for up to an hour for a table or bar seats to open up, I have had to get there by 4:45 (it opens at 5:00) and put my name on a list for bar seats.  It is worth the wait, though, as it has always had consistently excellent, fresh sushi.  As a long-time patron I have come to know the owner, Steve Fujii.  He has introduced me to some amazing new special dishes and appetizers which have become favorites.  His lobster dynamite, served in three large oyster shells, is fabulous.  The tempuras are fantastic, with light, non-greasy crisp batter coating farmer's market vegetables, fresh shrimp, or my favorite, squid tempura.  My dinner companion loves the panko fried oysters, cooked to perfection.  I prefer the fried shrimp heads that come with the ama ebi order, and also the pan-fried sand dab, especially if the whole fish is small enough to fit on the plate.  Other great dishes include the sake-steamed clams (also available with mussels), and grilled teriyaki scallops wrapped in bacon and served with an amazing red hot sauce.

Since I always sit at the sushi bar, that is what I mainly order.  Sometimes the chefs have specials that are only available for a short time, such as house-made pickled smelt, which are eaten whole.  The last time I was there, the chef prepared halibut fin sashimi dribbled with small bits of monk fish liver and shredded shiso leaves in a mild miso sauce which was to die for.  The seafood salad is also wonderful, made with several types of fish, seaweed, and pickled vegetables, with chunks of mountain potato.  This and other sushi dishes can be modified to your specifications and the chefs will also make anything you can think of, as well as creating their own surprise dishes on the spot.  I highly recommend this great Japanese restaurant, but it is best to get there early before it opens to get on the seating list.or after 9:00 when the dinner crowd starts to thin.
author: Nusi D.

description:
I come here quite often, but haven't had a chance to review this place up until now. 

5 Stars for Service
Although this place gets quite busy, I never had a problem with service. It's easy to catch the waiters or waitress's attention, no rush order, and my tea or water is always filled. 

Sat at the bar once and the chefs were friendly and humorous with regulars (I'm not a regular). 

5 Stars for Food 
They serve bento boxes during lunch so you can try a combination of their listed items, but I come here for their sashimi. 

So far the sashimi has been very fresh. If you like sashimi, you should try this place out. 

Once in a while they have fresh live uni. They have the unopened sea urchin on display when it's in season and available. 

5 Stars for Cleanliness 
Never had a problem with dirty utensils.
author: Sylvia C.

description:
Not exaggerating when I say this is the best sushi I've ever had hands down. The quality, presentation of the food, and atmosphere made me feel like I was dining in a very expensive fine dine restaurant and once receiving the check I expected the bill to be sky high but no, it was FAIRLY reasonable if not even on the cheaper side for such good sushi. 

My mom and I ordered 2 specialty rolls and 2 appetizers and the bill was only about $39, which was cheap considering the quality of the rolls and appetizers which was a good portion. We came here twice on our trip to San Francisco for dinner since we wanted to stuff as much of this sushi down before returning to our home in MN where sushi isn't a forte. 

Beware, might want to make reservations since this place is always packed. My mom and I were lucky the first time being only the 2 of us got a table right away (the last one), but on the second day we returned it was a late sunday night and we had to wait for about 20 min. But totally worth it. Will be back ;)
author: Sunny T.

description:
Outstanding service. The best I have ever received at a sushi restaurant. 

My girlfriend and I came in 30 minutes before they closed and we were sat at the bar. We ordered the $25 Omakase and the chef told us they usually only give 7 different types of sashimi but would give us 9 because we were college students. He also gave us a free fried fish because we were the last customers of the night. 

The chef had a great conversation with us and it was paired with some of the freshest sashimi I've ever had. 

5 stars for service. 10/10 for food.
author: Anthony T.

description:
My new favorite place for Japanese.
Really like the design of this place as well as the upscale-trendy vibe that also has somewhat of a cramped, hole in the wall ramen house feel in that space is very tight. It is not a setting for the claustrophobic. My friend was not happy that others could so easily peer over at our table to check out our food.. and then watch us eat it..
I, for one, liked the intimacy of it all and actually did some table-peeping myself. The food all looks so good you just can't help but do so, and it tastes as good as it looks. Can't recall everything that we ordered, but the sukiyaki, I remember, was very satisfying. I also remember that the food was high quality and worth the price. Don't expect much interaction with your server. In addition to the language barrier, the place is so busy they are much too focused on getting in, out, and on to the next table.
author: S K.

description:
My friend and I were craving for some Japanese food after going to the Academy of Sciences, so we yelped upon this small sushi place.  Upon arrival there was basically a line out the door so we had to sign in and have a wait.

After about an hour of waiting time we were seated and put in our order, but unfortunately for us the server tells us that they were out of the fresh sea urchin we wanted.  Disappointed (as it was basically our main reason for coming here), we decided to order a couple other things as well because we had waited so long.  We ordered the Scallop rolls and 49er rolls and they did not disappoint.  We thought the rolls were all delicious, fresh, and affordable.

The sushi was good enough for a second visit but I would only come back if I were in the area.

Tips:  
1) Parking is horrible especially on Nightlife Thursday.
2) Expect a long wait in the evenings.
author: David P.

description:
My boyfriend and I were walking home from Day 2 of Outside Lands, and decided to stop in to this place randomly. I actually didn't even pull up my phone to look it up on Yelp until AFTER we had been seated. The second I did I got really excited - how lucky to pop in to such a great place! 

The ambiance at Ebisu was great - it was small and intimate but still seemed fun. I really appreciated the quick service and the fact that there were so many customers at 10pm. We ordered the Chef's Special roll, which was an amazing roll that had salmon, avocado and mango on it. I also got salmon nigiri, yellowtail nigiri and sake - all of which were also great. I loved how fresh the fish was -- this is definitely a good spot for sashimi or nigiri.
author: Shruti N.

description:
Wow still just as popular as I remember in 2000.  The 4 of us waited about an hour to get seated on a Friday night.  Luckily they'll serve beverages for those waiting!  

We shared the omakase for 4 ppl - all sashimi.  Fresh fish but would've been nice if it was served nigiri or with rice.  And shared several small plates - eggplant, chawan musi, black cod, spinach, etc.  It was all very good but not cheap.  
I could tell they wanted us out since people were still waiting.   Glad to know this classic neighborhood gem is still here.  

4 stars for the remodeled ambiance!
author: Meredith K.

description:
It is a consistently wonderful experience with fresh delicious fishies.  The agedashi tofu is particularly good.  

Also, if you get the choice between a table and the counter - the counter is a fun experience to chat and thank the talented sushi chefs.
author: Jenn D.

description:
So funny thing, of the two people that showed up to this restaurant, one is a vegetarian and the other was one that didn't eat sushi, however, we *still* enjoyed ourselves.

I was meeting up with my friends while I was in town for work.  Unfortunately, one was stuck at work, so it was just the two of us.  Apparently this place was a regular spot for my friends so my friend already knew what he wanted before we even sat down.

After looking through the menu, I settled on the Chicken Katsu and my friend got an order of veggie tempura and I think it was the veggie tempura rolls.

The food was quite delicious.  My Katsu came with soup, and a salad plus rice.  Yum. 

Service was great.  Our server was so nice.  The restaurant is really small though.  

Also - parking is a bitch here.  Remember you are in the city.  There is a paid parking lot right across the street from the restaurant ($10 bucks), but if you are lucky, you can find some street parking (which is metered during the day)  Apparently you can also park in Golden Gate park and walk over.
author: Grace C.

description:
This place is just that good. Our first time here and this place made me fall in love with sashimi. Their salmon sashimi is melt in your mouth good. Smooth and buttery. Everything else was delicious. The miso was piping hot which I love. Most places it's just lukewarm. Their rolls are also delicious. We had the family affair roll. The Hawaiian poke was also really good. Although I prefer their sashimi and nigiri much more since the fish cuts are already so good, it doesn't need other flavorings to enhance it.

It is a small place with limited seating, but we didn't have to wait, since we came later on a week day. Our waitress was also very attentive and kind.
author: YoungEm T.

description:
The reviewers here are missing an important dish: the veggie udon soup is one of the most mind-blowing, healthy food items around.   Super broth, great noodles, and a mown field's worth of serious greens.  

This alone can keep a body going for a couple of days.
author: Jimmy T.

description: Best sushi I've had in SF. Also had some great appetizers. Definitely coming back here!
author: Rajesh S.

description: Always worth the wait. Wonderful service, and even better food. Hanukkah roll every time.
author: Natalie S.

description:
I've actually been here on two occasions. The first time made me wanting more, the second time, not so much.

The first time I came with my girlfriends. We were craving some fishy fish fish sashimi! We got the Oysters Barnabi and the Chirashi! We all got the same thing since we didn't want any of those rolls. The oysters barnabi, holy smokes, was that thing DELICIOUS! I dreamt about it all the time! Everything just melted together once you slurped it up. The uni, especially, was so delicious. First you taste the uni, quail egg, and oyster melting together and then you get an aftertaste of ponzu sauce, sealing the deal. We kept gushing about it even after our chirashi came. As for the chirashi, wow, so much delicious fish! Extremely filling and definitely worth the price! The fish was all so fresh and delicious. Melt in your mouth kind of stuff too!

The second time I went on a date with my boyfriend. Since he's not too fond of fish, we got a roll. Well, we still ordered the oysters barnabi since I kept dreaming about it, as well as the Ebisu Combo. This time however, the oysters barnabi didn't exactly knock my socks off. The uni didn't seem that great and it didn't taste as fresh. Maybe it was just the day and time... But I was definitely a little upset it wasn't that great. As for the Ebisu combo, I would have to say the chirashi is much better. The ebisu combo has an extra roll and not as much fish as I wanted. We also ordered the Swamp roll, which was good! 

However, they charged us $13 each for the oyster barnabi when the menu clearly stated it was $9. They also overcharged the first time I came with my girlfriends, $10 instead. But it was only a dollar more so we didn't complain. But the second time, there was no way I was going to let it slide. One more star off for that.

Overall, the second time was just average compared to the first time. I think it's just because of what I ordered. I'll definitely order the oysters barnabi for a third time to see how it'll be! I also see a lot of people ordering the rolls so I definitely want to try more!
author: Bonny C.

description: The best sushi I ever eaten. Lots of fresh fishes making out on sushi and sashimi dishes. Best ever tasted!!!
author: Thelma N.

description:
So, to preface, I'm in no way a sushi expert, however, this was the best sushi I have ever had. I came here with a group of coworkers and we had a decent budget (about $50 per person) and ordered the following:

Vegetable Tempura appetizer - pretty standard, nothing really outstanding

Lobster Tempura - this was delicious, flaky and tender - I think the portion only amounted to one bite per person (6 in total) but it was very, very good

Seaweed Salad - standard again

Rainbow Roll - fresh tasting, filling

Sushi: (here comes the good part):

Hamachi Toro
Toro (Bluefin belly)
Uni
Kobe Beef (strange, I know, but one of my favs)

These four items were the highlight of the meal. Each was so fresh and delicious, they just melted in my mouth. They were super expensive (between $14 - $18 for two pieces), but it was certainly worth it.

We also ordered the four person Omakase, which was a ton of fish and super fresh - I would recommend it for groups of 4 - 6 people.

The service was friendly, the sushi took a while to come out, but I didn't expect this to be a fast service - I want the sushi chefs to take their time preparing my delicious dinner! They also had a really good happy hour - I think before 7 certain beers were only $1.

I don't live in SF, but if I am ever back, I'd love to return to this restaurant.
author: Thao N.

description: A million stars just wouldn't cut it for this place! The sushi is seriously excellent & it's incredible how each & every piece just melts in your mouth. We love anything toro & tonight had the salmon & hamachi toro which were out of this world. The albacore toro was sold out by 7pm so we settled for the non toro cut & thank goodness we did as it was amazing too. Other superb standouts tonight: escolar & the scallop. We tried the red clam which was ok but not my favorite as well as the xxx yaki butter hotate. I thought it had a touch too much lemon. We adore this place & we highly recommend sitting at the bar & conversing with the sushi chefs....they are super friendly & have great recommendations!
author: Nicole E.

description: A truly exceptional restaurant with unparalleled quality. I recommend sitting at the sushi bar for an enhanced, and much quicker, experience. The sushi chefs here are phenomenally knowledgeable, funny, and incredibly good at what they do. The quality of the fish? To. Die. For. Literally. Everything, right down the nori seaweed, is absolutely divine. A true gem of San Francisco!
author: Anon E.

description: This is probably my favorite Japanese restaurant in the city, where the food is actually made by Japanese people. (I say that because it seems like majority of the Japanese restaurants in the city is owned and made by Chinese people). Anyways, if you like tempura, try the Lobster one; that's so mouth watering to me. Overall, everything seems to be yummy to me here except for the price. It's a little on the higher end, like for two of us, we can order up to $100 worth of food easily. But if you were on a budget, you can probably do $50-60 for two.
author: Pudgy G.

description: Omg the best bento box that has ever been created - seriously. Yes, it's a bit pricey, but the quantity and quality of food you get is unbelievable.
author: Amy Y.

description:
Yummy...tempura lobster and hamachi, need I really say more?  Why yes, I guess I should.  Come prepared to wait, don't come starving because you will more than likely have to wait more than 30 minutes.  It's a small restaurant, so not ideal for parties larger than 4.  Great service, very attentive staff and even better service if you sit at the bar.  

Sushi is always fresh, perfect amount of wasabi and pairs perfectly with saki or beer.  I craved sushi while I was pregnant, of course I couldn't eat it, but I daydreamed of sitting at the Sushi Bar here enjoying Hamachi, shiro-maguro and hot tea!
author: ERICA G.

description: I love the food here so I will keep coming back. Service in the dining area has improved significantly since the renovations.
author: Ricardo O.

description: I tried Ebisu for the first time a couple weeks ago. My friend had been telling me about it and finally came. It was busy as usual but ended up sitting at the sushi bar so didn't have to wait to long for a spot. It was fun to see them making your sushi. The service was fast and friendly and the chef in front of us was also very kind. We got the poke appetizer and a couple speciality rolls. The poke was amazing and the rolls were unique and delicious. We had the triple x roll. You could really tell how fresh the fish was!! Sometimes it's hard to find a really good sushi restaurant in the city but this one stuck out and will be back for sure!
author: Emily F.

description: It's a tiny restaurant and you'll likely wait in line before being seated but it's worth it. The best part though, it's actually a family friendly place! The waitstaff promptly put away our stroller, gave us a highchair and smiled through the flying chopsticks.
author: Hoda T.

description:
I frequent San Francisco pretty often. One of my go to places to eat is Ebisu. I love it for its location, price, atmosphere, freshness, and taste. Here's my rundown.

Location: Conveniently located at one of the stops along the N (9th and Judah), just a few stores down. Parking is pretty standard for San Francisco. You might be able to find a space along 9th or on adjacent streets. Save the environment though and take the Muni as there's also a lot that you can do in the area after your meal (drinks and dessert).

Price: Pretty reasonably priced. Not the cheapest in terms of sushi but the substance is there. I've had more expensive sushi in The City but there was no discernable increase in value at these places.

Atmosphere: Very welcoming and intimate. Especially compared to the cold outside in Inner Suset, the service is warm and friendly. Just get past the wait, possibly by having something to drink, and get ready to enjoy the experience. For extra fun, sit in front of the itamae (sushi chef). They're quite a "punny" bunch.

Freshness: Almost all of the seafood tastes like it came fresh that morning from the sea. It doesn't have the texture that might come from refreezing and thawing fish. If you want an extra special treat, take a look at their specials and, better yet, order the life uni when they have it. I ordered it once and it was still moving on the table when it was served to us. To this day, it's still some of the best sea urchin I've ever had.

Taste: Unlike a lot of other sushi places I've tried in SF, Ebisu's flavor comes off as well-balanced. There is no heavy reliance on mayo or sauces. Instead, a careful balance of more natural flavors helps inform the dishes. For a great example of this, check out the Dexter Carter roll.

TL;DR: Great taste, value, and atmosphere. If you're anywhere near Inner Sunset and have a craving for sushi, give Ebisu a try.
author: Kevin H.

description: Julio is quite possibly the most enjoyable sushi chef on the planet. Great, fresh, sushi. Local favorite. Stop telling people about it!!!
author: John T.

description:
If you like to wait over an hour for some overpriced mediocre food, then you came to the right place.

We came on a Friday night and of course it was busy. We waited about 45-1 hour to be seated even though they told us it would only be 30 minutes. Whatever. It happens and we dealt with it. But after finally ordering, it took nearly 30 minutes to get our food! Hello?! We ordered non cooked items and why does it take 30 minutes?! Service was so slow! And sadly, the food itself was just mediocre. It wasn't bad but it is not that great or amazing by any means either. 

I will not be coming back. I was so unhappy with the service and the food. I have had better quality sushi elsewhere with better service and even cheaper prices! Not a fan of this place. Sorry!
author: Sarina A.

description: Tried this place today w my bf bc he just moved to the neighborhood and we haven't found out go to sushi joint..until today! This place has a great vibe, just bright enough lighting and super quick service and to top it off the food was killer! I thoroughly enjoy a quick and yummy and not overpriced sushi joint and this is it! We will back many times!
author: Nicole H.

description: The wait was super long but well worth it. As others had mentioned the 49er sushi roll was just perfect and the dragon and caterpillar rolls were very delicious. Service was quick and we would love to go back and try other stuff :)
author: Faezeh F.

description:
I really enjoy coming here. They have great service, delicious sushi and some other interesting menu items. 

I love sushi. But, it doesn't exactly stick to your ribs. So, I usually like to order something in addition to the raw fishies.  And, it's easy to do here. Their soba noodles with a side of Tempura is huge, tasty and effing huge. 

Their sushi rolls are pretty standard. I think they really stand out in their simple, sushi and sashimi. We usually ask about what's fresh and then dig in. 

Today, for lunch, we had 6 rounds of sushi (2 pieces per round), a big bowl of noodles, tea and miso soup for only 43 dollars! Pretty good value. And, those hamachi, salmon and tuna sushi bites were deeeelicious. I'm still envisioning them in my greedy gob!

We come here for lunch about once a month. But, maybe we should go more. The service is always very, very friendly. Arigato Ebisu.
author: Dusty B.

description: Kevin was our sushi chef. He was awesome. He gave us all kinds of tips about sushi and San Fransisco. The pork dumplings were amazing!
author: Tabitha M.

description:
We got the recommendation from our hotel bartender.  He said that they have the best spicy tuna and also ask the chef to make me your special.  I was thinking the best spicy tuna??? Spicy Tuna is one of my favorites to order back home in Hawaii.  I tried a lot of Spicy tunas and wanted to compare.  
We got their about 5:30 PM and we had to put our names on the list.  I believe they have a 1st seating at 5:00 PM and it was a full house.  So we were in the waiting room in the front and offered us hot green tea.  You can also order beer to get your drink on while waiting.  A table opened up but we passed it up to sit at the sushi counter.  It was well worth it.  So we sit down and order a Sapporo.  I ask the chef for the spicy tuna roll.  Made it really fast and served it to us.  My girlfriend doesn't eat raw fish and she's not much of a sushi eater.  But she was willing to try.   It was excellent and I must say that this was at least in my top three. My girlfriend also thought it was delicious, huh, really.  Then we requested the chef to make us his special.  Wow, this was amazing, not sure what it was but the combination worked.  I believe it was a ahi roll with toro, tobiko, green onions, and bonito flakes on top and a special sauce.  My girlfriend also loved it and she couldn't stop saying how delicious it was.  If she likes it then it must've been good.  Hopefully this place will have her liking sushi more so we could go to more places back home.
author: Reid I.

description: To be honest, I'd rather go to cheaper, less upscale sushi restaurants where I would pay half the price for the same amount of comparable food, but I think this place deserves four stars for their great service, nice modern decor, and delicious food, especially their melt-in-your-mouth sashimi. I ordered the 8 pc sashimi combo ($16) with half hamachi and half sake and 1 order of butterfish nigiri ($7.50) and 1 order of tamago nigiri ($4). Definitely felt overpriced to me, but their fish was so fresh! My bf ordered their sukiyaki ($19), which came in a huge bowl, probably only a couple inches high. I had some of his and it was pretty good. So much more meat than noodles! I would come back here to try their rolls and other entrees, but maybe during lunch when prices are a little cheaper.
author: Stephanie G.

description: Came in here for an early dinner.  The place gets pretty busy but the staff is welcoming and friendly.  We enjoyed all of our selections and will definitely return when in town again.
author: Andrew V.

description:
Love this place. The hamachi maguro last night was delectable. The sushi chefs are amazing and the service is very attentive. All servers pretty much scan the tables and our server had been there for 5 years (nice, tells me they take care of their employees). 

Yes, the wait can be daunting but once seating it's pretty much what you came for: great sushi, nice service and the reason why people will travel for your 'neighborhood gem'.
author: Janine S.

description:
My buddy and I went in on a Friday night to find Ebisu bustling with restaurant patrons. There stood 4 sushi chefs behind the sushi counter chatting it up with customers. 

We ordered our food and started to dig in until we noticed our sushi falling apart when we picked it up. Ah..FAIL..

1 Sparkling mineral water, green tea, 1 plate of Sake (Salmon) Sashimi and a Rainbow roll for $40?!

I'd like to say here that this place AIN'T CHEAP, and parking is a NIGHTMARE. Other than that, enjoy every morsel of food on your plate! xD
author: Jason C. J.

description:
Great place, awesome food!

This side of Inner Sunset can get pretty trafficky and parking is normally very very hard to find, even on regular weekdays.  I always try and just park a few blocks away; walking gets your appetite up anyway.

Place can get pretty pricey, but what Japanese establishment doesn't?

Highly recommend:

OYSTER QUAIL EGG UNI SAKE SHOOTERS - a shotglass with a raw oyster, raw quail egg, raw uni, soy sauce, hot sauce, and scallions filled to the top with sake.  Bad ass drink for $9-10

Kobe beef nigiri - rare slice of kobe beef over rice, comes with a sweet savory dipping sauce.  $7 for two

Crunchy roll - not your conventional crunch roll, wrapped in green soy paper.  Check it out for $7.50 a roll.

Great tasting food, no joke! Gets really crowded at prime time dinner time, so be prepared
author: Christopher N.

description: We came here for the first time last Saturday and this is officially our new favorite sushi spot! The seafood is super fresh! I highly recommend the Louisiana hot link and the Family affair
author: Emily K.

description:
Best sushi I've ever eaten, which has been a lot. I've tried places all over the city, and I decided to try one closer to home last night with my boyfriend and it was the best decision! 
We started with miso's ( great)

Then we tried the chef's special roll that night which was Salmon and avocado inside with butterfish (escolar) on top. It was delicious!!!!!!!

Next we had the Boston roll ( I don't remember all that was in it but it was awesome!!)

And then finished with albacore nigiri. (awesome) 

It wasn't over-priced. Normal for sushi. The waiters were attentive and polite. 

Only bad thing- they don't take reservations. But we'll definitely be coming back!
author: Emily F.

description:
We came here for the izakaya fare. Not just the sushi because they have an extensive menu, and is even vegetarian friendly. Needless to say, my vegetarian friend was satisfied, as well as the rest of us meat lovers.

Try some of the kushiyaki, especially the mushrooms. Umami from the mushroom are amazing. The black cod, the nasu degaku (eggplant with miso sauce) are simply delicious, amongst the other things. 

We also had some hand rolls (the one with uni and salmon roe is very fresh and delicious), and some sashimi. All the fish was very fresh and good. I loved every single fish I had, including the uni and the anago, which are usually hard to find or not so fresh.

They also have a good list of sake to accompany the good food.

The waitress was nice and attentive, and the interior of the place feels way nicer than a typical Asian joint. However, the ambience is on the loud side. We ended up stepping outside and skipping dessert so we could talk.

There is a long wait, but I think it's worth it once in a while. You can call ahead to put your name in the list, but they won't seat you until your whole party is present.
author: Alice C.

description: close to UCSF medical. Sushi was excellent quality, but for me the fried oysters were a true treat. Light not the least bit greasy. My vegan dining partner was happy with various tofu dishes
author: Eugene T.

description:
This was a gem to find (even tho they have a ton of yelp reviews).

There is usually a wait, we waited about 40 min.

When i first walked in i saw mostly sushi specialty rolls being brought to lots of the tables so i wasn't too happy because i prefer traditional nigiri sushi.

However we ordered the omakase anyway and it was pretty dam delicious.
Chefs are awesome, huge cuts of fish.  The Albacore was probably the best albacore i've had.  And for the price... it was definitely amazing.
author: Steven F.

description:
I don't even eat sushi, and I loved this place. I haven't eaten fish in 15 years but recently started to eat cooked fish again and am working my way into raw. I decided it was time to put on my big-girl pants and finally try sushi from the best sushi spot in town. 

Everything was so fresh and tasty, so I imagine it's even better for big sushi eaters. The service was friendly and quick too. We got there early, so were were seated immediately for some happy hour beer prices, but it got crowded quickly.
author: Annie C.

description:
This place is great! Some of the freshest sushi I've had in the city. I came here on Valentine's Day and the wait was over an hour, but it was worth it. The sushi was delicious. There wasn't one thing I got that was bad. 
I will say that you should be comfortable dining with your neighbors. The tables are so close together it feels like you're eating at the same table. But the service is awesome. The waitstaff is very attentive. 
I'd recommend this place for sure.
author: Jenn A.

description:
This is the best sushi place I've been to in my life. A testament to how good it is, is that I dined in Ebisu a couple of years back and I'm writing the review now. To this day, its sweet memory is still fresh in my mind every time I have sushi. 

The freshness of their fish and sushi ingredients is second to none. The avocado they use is so tender that it could melt on impact with your tongue. 
The way the rolls are made, with perfect rice to other ingredient ratios, will indicate to you that the sweet family that operates the restaurants are no trained amateurs. It is an art that they have cultured over time. 

Last but not least, the food presentation is definitely the cherry on top of the sundae. If you order a caterpillar roll, it will actually resemble a caterpillar (we ordered two, they were as beautiful as they were tantalizing)

Ebisu, one day, God willing, I'll visit you again :)
author: Zuheir K.

description:
This place is our new favorite since we moved into the 'hood. We stumbled upon it by accident on our anniversary and fell in love with it; we went back last night and it was still excellent.

Really, it is just good on so many levels. The ambiance is super-cool. We sat at the sushi bar both times and the sushi chefs were really nice, friendly, helpful (and it's fun to watch them work!) 

The food is awesome, at least what we've tried. The fish for the sushi and sashimi is so, so fresh--the taste and texture are really head and shoulders above most of the sushi places I've eaten lately. We also had the sake-steamed mussels last time and they were delicious as well.

Our favorite is the chef's assortment of sashimi...last night we also had a XXX roll which was just wonderful.

I think the price is very reasonable--not cheap, but not more than what I'd expect to pay for sushi either. Considering the quality, that makes it a good value in my book.
author: Jennie S.

description:
In my opinion, you know you are a sashimi fan when you can truly taste the subtleties of their different flavors and textures. My boyfriend and I came here to top of our night with second dinner :) and ordered a plate of the chef sashimi minus the rice. 

Now, I cannot remember everything that was on the plate but everything was amazing. (Cannot speak for yellowtail because we skipped out on it). Our waitress also brought out an excellent bowl of citrus ponzu that went amazingly with the pink fish on our plate. 

Not sure I would come for the sushi (from the look of other tables it seemed a bit small). But my whole experience comes down to that plate of sashimi that impressed me so much. Love it for the level of freshness and quality.
author: Tracy Joy K.

description:
Came here on a Sunday night around 8:30pm and waited about 5 minutes for a table. 

I seriously have never experienced faster made/served sushi. The sushi rolls came before anything else... Our miso soup was probably the slowest to be served. 

Highly recommend the simple, yet delicious Double Hamachi and their XXX roll which for us was: Spicy tuna in avocado, salmon plus mango, tobiko and scallion. That was delicious.

4 specialty rolls+ a seaweed salad + a craft cold sake + 2 bottles of Sapporo light + 4 bowls of Miso Soup turned out to $24-28 dinner for a group of 4. That's a pretty good deal for the quantity and quality.
author: Joanna H.

description:
My family has been going here for nearly (or longer) 30 years. The owners are fantastic and so kind. Everything is always so fresh and tasty. The XXX #2 roll is perfect if you love shrimp and scallops but everything I have had here I've loved! 

Tip: it's well worth the wait!
author: Laura H.

description:
Dinner at the bar. Food 4.5/5
Sushi: Salmon toro, halibut, escolar, bluefin tuna, scallop, some fish liver thing...
$36 per person
author: Olivia Q.

description: Kevin the main sushi chef was incredible. This was our first time to San Francisco & to Ebisu. We will be back the next time we're in town. He even taught us the right way to eat sushi, "with your hands." Finally I can quit fighting w/ chop sticks.
author: Jim M.

description:
Just want to write an update because their sake steamed clams went up in price from $9 to $12 since I last wrote about it.  It's pricy but still very fulfilling and one of my favorite places to get that item, especially for its richness not found elsewhere so far.  I'm sure I won't be able to help but come back just to order this from time to time.

The service is still overall good.  At first they seemed somewhat inattentive to my walking in despite the place seeming rather slow.  At first I wondered if it had to do with the change in some staff I noticed.  However, after I sat down and ordered everything was well.  In fact, I even got a friendly greeting from one of the remaining staff because she know the sake steamed clams are my favorite there.

Also, I thought I take an opportunity to finally write a counter-review to (at least in my mind) the INFAMOUS AND NOTORIOUS NOBU K.  The fact that people like me come to a place that provides a spoon to go with the miso does not make us stupid, as his 2007 review states.  Here I probably got a spoon because I ordered the sake steamed clams, but there have been other places that provided me a spoon with the miso soup and I enjoyed the experience (proper in his mind or not). To me, he shows so much narrow-mindedness in most of his reviews (at least those that have not been flagged and removed by Yelp, which he must certainly hold the record for and very deservingly so) that to me is unbelievable.  I agree with a fellow Yelper who elsewhere also wrote a counter-review of him in 2009 on another listing calling him nothing more than person full of hate.  In fact I can think of many more terms (both adjectives and nouns) to describe him but won't go that level here.
author: H K.

description:
wait time is kinda of sucky. i recommend sitting at the sushi bar! (not as long of a wait.) it's super cool! and it's fun! you get to see what the sushi chefs make and how they make it. they're also really funny and friendly as well!

hands down... the BEST sushi i've EVER had. there's a fair amount of selections on the menu and everything on it, looks so good! they also have plenty of specials that change on a daily basis. (which gets posted up on the black board behind the sushi chefs.)

the sashimi... WOW... it's so freaking fresh!! mMm... i want to come back... NOW. oh, they also start you with your own dish of edamame and you also end with dessert. :)
author: Ann T.

description:
wow! Probably one of the best sashimi places (in terms of freshness) in the SF area that wasn't $$$$ rated.

Although we waited for about 20 minutes at 8:30pm to be seated, it was worth the wait.

We ordered: $18/person (tips and tax included)
Hanukkah Roll (3.5/5)
QP Roll (3.5/5)
Double Hamachi Roll (5/5)

Major plus for the decor :) Will be back again!

maybe I will try lunch since it will be cheaper!
author: Jen H.

description: This place is de-licious! I've been here two times, and both times I walked away happy and stuffed. There's soo much to choose from. I like to order from the kushiyaki menu. Their kushiyaki menu are small plates of goodness. The Kobe beef dry aged teriyaki glazed is my absolute favorite!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
A day of Japanese: after getting off the muni at 9th we walked to the Japanese tea garden. In the way back we were craving sushi and stumbled upon Ebisu 

We sat at the sushi bar greeted by a good warm towel and served directly by the sushi chef which is typical high end Japanese restaurant. The food was just great and fresh, nasu was done perfectly and the matzo balls had an amazing broth.  Sushi was damn good to especially that days xxxroll or there chefs special 

Highly recommend
author: Frank N.

description: Incredible food and fantastic service! There is an excellent vibe in this small restaurant. I am truly grateful to have experienced this lovely place!
author: Jeffery B.

description:
One big negative - waiting an hour on a Saturday night. 

But the sushi and food was excellent, and at the end of the night I was surprised it was worth the wait. 

The hamachi toro, albacore toro, and all the sushi was excellent. Their gomae has seaweed incorporated with it - so yummy. The clams in broth were also great, as was the chawan mushi. 

I always wish I went there lot often.... If it wasn't for that long wait.
author: Jon H.

description: Everything was delicious here! We ordered the Agedashi Tofu, oysters on the half shell, a variety of rolls, Uni, Hamachi Sashimi and teriyaki chicken. Service was great and our server was very attentive to check in every so often to see if we needed anything. We ended up paying around $160 for 4 people, not bad for everything that we ordered!
author: Michelle H.

description:
Really fresh, great value (not cheapest spot, but great for what you get) and delicious. 5 stars for having gluten free soy sauce, knowledgable staff, unique menu items (especially the rolls) later hours. 
More items to try, so id come back.
author: Vanessa C.

description: Probably the best sushi I have had in my life. Showed up at 5 pm and sat at the bar. Place filled up quick, but regardless, service was excellent.  Had the 49er which it was to die for.  Will visit again next time I'm in the area!
author: Cristina H.

description: Love the cherry blossom roll and agedashi tofu. Cozy place, lines can be long, so we feel very very lucky when we can walk in and be seated (good to go when it's raining ;)). Parking can be difficult in the area, as there are several restaurants. Service is always awesome and quick. Our go to place, as my fiancé believes this place to be the best in SF.
author: Cindy L.

description:
Everything here is excellent.  

The staff is friendly and helpful.  
The chef's sashimi platter is very tasty and fresh.
The trendy, yet cozy atmosphere makes it perfect for any occasion.  
The fancy sushi rolls (if you are into those) are amazing - The Romeo and Juliet roll is great. 
The price is very reasonable. 


Overall, Ebisu is a great restaurant and I am excited to go back!
author: Juliana K.

description: We come here every time when we are craving for sushi.  Always fully satisfied happily going home. :)
author: Jennifer L.

description: Parking is so hard to find around here! Other than that, the food is simply amazing. It was my first time here and my friend me how great the sushi is. We ordered a bunch of rolls and a appetizer to share. We got the arch deluxe, dragon roll, sake nigiri,and  rainbow roll. We also got the edamame trio which was three different flavors! One was flavored with salt, spice, and garlic. I have to say, the garlic one was my favorite! As for the rolls, they came with around 8 pieces and they were huge! I got the Sake nigiri and the salmon was so fresh that it just melted in my mouth. Literally! My cravings were definitely satisfied. Although, I though it was pricey for 3 rolls and a appetizer to add up to $60. I would probably come here again once in a while though!
author: Valerie C.

description:
Did someone say SUSHI?!?!
My favorite food!
I ordered the bento box #3. . .
the salmon was cooked to perfection. . .so buttery. . .LOVE it!
I can't believe i was so stuffed leaving the place.

The amibance is very modern, I felt like I was eating in a high-class resto!
Inside it was small and intimate. . .
Omakase is $50-$100. . .
author: Remie M.

description:
Wow, maybe we came here at a bad time, (30 minutes before they closed for lunch) but our experience was way below par, especially for a SF sushi place where prices are above average.

As we were seated I eyed some girl's sake sashimi order and I immediately felt like we've made a mistake. The fish did not look fresh at all and lacked that shiny bright smooth texture. 

Most of the rolls we ordered were poorly made, falling apart, and 90% rice. The piece of fish was barely bigger than the size of the thin lemon slice on the 49ers roll. Ridiculous. 

You're better off down the street at Kazu. It's smaller but the flavor/fish quality is 10x better. 

Incredibly disappointed. Service and environment were nice though.
author: Lisa N.

description: Delicious!  If you appreciate fresh, great tasting sushi, this is your place.  Yes, the wait can be long, but it is worth it!!
author: Adam B.

description:
I've been here a number of times now. Only now getting around to making my review. The thing about Ebisu is that the food is good. You can't knock it. There's a lot of pseudo-Japanese places in the City that are actually NOT made by Japanese hands. The majority of Japanese places in the City are run by either Chinese or Koreans..*gasp*..yes it's true. But like most white-Americans, nobody can tell the difference. It's really a sucker's bet. I've been to these places before and the food experience is quite awful. You can tell that non-Japanese sushi chefs just aren't that special. There's definitely something missing there and you can't substitute it. 

Ebisu offers something different. It's a Japanese-run restaurant with real Japanese sushi chefs. The only drawback to this place is that it's always so damn crowded. There's really no time when you can get a table in a hurry. That doesn't exist. You sign up and wait..and wait. In some instances I've seen people wait for over an hour for a table. The place isn't bad..but during rush hour (I'm talking Friday, Sat dinner time) you could be waiting quite some time for your sushi rolls. 

The last time I went to Ebisu our sushi rolls took awhile to get to our table. It was at least 45 minutes from the time we ordered. It wasn't pleasant and we wanted to cancel since it was getting late. Yes, isn't that terrible? Problem is, these guys don't do reservations..which means they don't do the Open Table business. 

In any case, if you are lucky to get your act together early and get a table, order all the sushi you can before the crowds show up..because trust me, they will. Ebisu is a very popular place. 

While the wait staff aren't much to speak of, the food really is.
author: Tiffany R.

description:
I've come to this place a handful of times because I live right up the street. Last night was the best service I've ever gotten here though!! It was our first time sitting at the bar and we got so lucky because had the best sushi chef ever, Julio! He was super attentive and and nice! He even made a custom roll for my friend and named it after her! It sucked to wait 30-45 min for a table, but the great service made up for it! 

5 stars all around!
author: Nikki S.

description:
The restaurant's atmosphere is lovely - dark, lots of rich wooden textures, and the bar in sight of most tables, so you can see the sashimi and sushi being prepared in front of you. 

The green tea is good, but not strong in flavor. The miso soup is perfection - steaming broth with small cubes of tofu and seaweed. 

I ended up going for the deluxe combo plate (maguro, sake, hamachi, hotate, tsubugai, ikura, tobiko and unagi). The maguro & sake were perfection - smooth, buttery, fresh.
