I wasn't crazy about the tsubugai, but maybe I'm just not used to eating it. The whole thing was $18, a little pricey but so worth it. 

Side note - the rolls looked AMAZING, tried to convince my dad to order one so I could steal a piece or two, but he went with the Combo 2 (sashimi, maki sushi, & tempura bento), which he was happy with.

Second side note - they had a Yelp check-in deal which seems to promise 2 giftcards for Southwest Air, but it's actually for a raffle (slightly misleading, but not that big of a deal).
author: Claire S.

description:
This is our go-to date spot when we're craving sushi. The rolls are usually delicious, but sometimes they're a little better than in other instances. The first time we tried the XXX Roll we nearly creamed our panties. It was BOMB.com

But this last time we went it was good, but the panties were still in tact. 

Either way, this place always hits the spot and it's always a successful date night. It's also great that Starbucks is right around the corner for my way cheaper dessert...just sayin.
author: Brisa D.

description:
I tried taking my dad for some ever so awesome San Tung but the line from hell prevented us from even trying to put our names down.  My ex took me here about a year ago and I thought "Wow, this is Japanese food."  What I mean by that is I go to a lot of Japanese restaurants in San Francisco but a lot of them are California fusion or not as authentic as I like.

My dad eats Japanese food almost every other meal.  I brought him here after being in the Bay Area for about 2 days visiting me.  He a big smile on his face as he was eating and finally approved of a restaurant I took him to in the Bay...which I don't understand.  You can throw a rock in this town and hit a good place to eat but all the complaints are "This is too fatty....I don't like this....what's that?"  You know what?  You don't like to live!  Shut up and trust me that you'll like it.
author: Ashley I.

description:
Who puts scraps of leftover fish ON TOP of their nigiri as garnish??? Is this NIGIRI TARTARE?? Just look at these photos posted by fellow YELPers. The cuts are disgusting. 

http://s3-media4.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/piaUdhmCwIyo4SsN_i3QJw/o.jpg
http://s3-media1.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/RMx46I6b-pJH0TsB5KyhaA/o.jpg

Quality sushi? Delusional.
author: Q C.

description:
It is with much sadness that I write this review.  

Ebisu used to be my all time favorite restaurant years ago. I have brought friends, boyfriends, lovers and everything in between to this place, sitting only at the sushi bar (tables are for squares).  I used to come here before sushi became popular, before I had my first job, before it got crazy.  (I don't know how I ever paid for this pleasure before!)  The sushi chefs and the owners would see me coming in each week with a different person.  They would greet me with a "Hey Teri!" and turn to greet whoever is following me in, only to realize it's someone different than the previous week.  (If anything, the staff at Ebisu must have known more about my business than anyone else!)  They would ask me about my family, mentioning they saw my sister or brother there the other day.  Yeah, our family goes there a lot.

At one point, I used to come every night, dropping almost a hundred dollars with my dining companion as we gorged on nigiri, ankimo, oysters on the half shell, and whatever we desired that evening.  I remember this one night we were across town eating sushi.  We ordered one thing, tasted it, looked at each other and said "Ebisu?", paid for our one order, and left.  We hauled ass back to the Sunset so we can take a seat at the bar and eat what we knew would satisfy our craving.

It's been awhile since I've returned to Ebisu, and I was bringing a friend who hadn't been there in over 7years.  She was skeptical as her first time wasn't the most memorable.  But she was willing to try again...with me.  

I arrived at 7 pm and there was no wait as I sat at the sushi bar.  Drink orders were taken and hot towels came out.  Edamame was placed in front of me as I waited patiently for my guest to arrive.  I was sitting in front of a new sushi chef, new to me, and maybe new to Ebisu?  The guy next to him I've seen before, but my regular was booked up on his end.  

We ordered nigiri - maguro, amaebi, hamachi, aji, sake, unagi, and ikura.  I was disappointed with the thin slices of fish sitting on my rice.   I was used to generous slices laid out over my rice, covering it completely.  Hmmm...what happened?  My ikura eggs were so little!  Two pieces smashed together, and I initially thought it was just one piece.  When I realized it was my two order, I felt gypped!  

I ordered the ankimo and our amaebi heads arrived with tempura dipping sauce.  I always ask for Ponzu sauce to dip the heads in and had to ask not once, but twice for my sauce.  Meanwhile, my heads were not hot by the time I got to them.

I'm a big water and tea drinker, especially when I'm at Ebisu and I have always appreciated that my glasses have never been empty when I am there.  Usually they are pretty good with filling my glasses so I don't notice they are doing it, but that wasn't the case this time.  Maybe they cup was closer to me than usual and they had to interrupt my conversation to ask to refill it.  But I remember when they used to come around the other side and just fill it w/o any interruptions, I miss that.  

I guess the next time I go, I'm going to wait until I get to sit in front of my sushi chef regulars because I think that alone will change my experience.  Ebisu brings back such fond memories.  Gosh, the screaming laughter that would evoke from my mouth when I was in great company, and that was always without alcohol involved.  How  I miss those crazy days!

Update: 12/01/06 - Sadly, Ebisu remains three stars...barely at this point.  The service was okay.  I waited for my regular chef, but no luck! The one I had was juggling too many parties at one time, and sushi was just average.  The only highlight was the live uni - see the photo above ($17.50).  Damn good for that.  

Update: 11/28/07 - Open seats were available in front my sushi chef and that made all the difference!  They were out of live uni though, which made me sad.  But I had the bonito sashimi with creamy sauce and I just love picking up every single tobiko egg left in that dish. It's just so good with the onions and stuff.  Yum!  Good size nigiri pieces in general, much better than my original visit for this review.  The BF was impressed with the fattiness of our amaebi here as well. 

Service was much better this time, and more like what I was used to.  Tea and water were perfect and I didn't feel any vultures on me.  And of course, hearing "Hi Teri!" didn't hurt either.  Their stars went back up to a four now.
author: Teri C.

description: I come here often as I can... I generally don't mind the long wait when they can serve us Sake by the door. That's one extra star. This is one of the best sushi place in SF when it comes to the quality and the value. The location is great, too. It's near Golden Gate Park, SF Botanical Gardens, and short ride to/from Ocean Beach on N line. For the food, the fish quality in everything was outstanding, and great long list of sake. All of the Sushi Chefs are very friendly and extremely sharp with their craft. I highly recommend anyone to come here!
author: Ryan C.

description:
This is a great spot to enjoy a night of sushi and beer. Yum.

Although it's definitely bigger than it looks from the outside, the restaurant was pretty packed and the wait time on a Friday night was about 45 mins.

Luckily there are plenty of places to walk around to kill time (there's a magic shop three blocks away!), and the service is pretty quick once you get in. 

I had the chirashi bowl ($20) to really taste the freshness of the fish at everyone's else recommendation. It was extremely satisfying and at a great price-point. My friends were more adventurous and started off with an oyster in sake shot ($7) and variety of rolls.

Based on my experience, I would definitely come back to try their other delectables. Not sure if I would forgo my chirashi bowl though :)
author: Lucia C.

description: Best sushi in San Francisco hands down.  The fish is fresh and yummy!  I go for the omasake chef special and oysters on a half shell for the appetizer every time I go there.  The XXX roll and 49er roll are my favorite.  The Giants roll is also really good!  Their sea urchin is to die for.  I sat at the bar one time and the sushi chefs were very friendly, attentive, and fast.  There isn't one thing I've had there that I didn't like. There is a long wait and the restaurant is small so I go and put my name down and go down the street to BlackThorn to grab a beer while I wait.  Can't recommend this place enough.
author: Victoria A.

description: The best sushi place in San Francisco! We go to this place several times per year.  This is a place you should go for high end nigiri.  The fish is so fresh and delicious that it almost is a shame to hide it in a roll with too many other flavors.  All the sushi chefs are extremely skilled, and our favorite is Jeff.  Ask them what their freshest catch is before ordering.  Definitely sit at the sushi bar if there is space!
author: Tony M.

description:
If you can look past the line and finding parking in this area (and uncoordinated waitresses), Ebisu is a great place to satisfy your sushi cravings. If you're a fan of seafood, you will really appreciate the variety of items on their menu. Everything tasted fresh and the chefs are excellent technicians at crafting and plating the dishes. 

We started with a plethora of appetizers to share, which included the fried oysters, maguro and hamachi sashimi, and three specialty rolls: the poke roll, halibut tootsie roll, and the cherry blossom roll. The sashimi was melt-in-your-mouth good, but at $2 a piece, it will definitely put a dent in anyone's wallet. The sashimi alone cost $32, but I guess that's a drop in the ocean for all the medical professionals in the area.

For dinner, I shared the Ebisu sushi dinner and the kurobuta tonkatsu. Both came with miso soup, which would later turn out to be the bane of my dining experience. I loved everything in the sushi dinner except the long neck clam. I can only describe the texture as rubbery and plastic-like, but it crunched with each bite. The tonkatsu was perfectly fried, but although it advertised premium center cut pork lion, the edges were just fried fat. The salad that came with the tonkatsu looked and tasted good. I'm not much of a salad person, but the sesame dressing made it quite appetizing. 

I was having a pretty good time at dinner until the waitress came by to take away the miso soup bowls. She clumsily dropped them on my back, spilling the leftover broth onto my sweater, jacket, and pants. I didn't get a single apology, only a look of shame as she responded with "It was only miso broth, there's no oil in it." If that was supposed to make me feel better, it didn't because it somewhat sucks having to eat your dinner with soggy pants marinated in miso broth. Forget getting anything compensated or getting a drink on the house - It was pretty upsetting to not even get an apology. Come for the good sushi and seafood, leave before a dumb waitress drops her load of dirty bowls on you.
author: Bailey Z.

description: I eat A LOT of sushi! Every time I'm on one of the coasts, I try to eat as much fresh fish and sushi as possible. Of all the places I've been, this is the best. Awesome presentation! Incredible combinations!
author: Scott L.

description: Of the many places this remains one our favorite sushi restaurants. Of course we really like nigiri which they cater to.
author: Robert B.

description: I came here for lunch today and although it was busy, I was able to sit at the sushi bar. The sashimi was delicious and fresh and the XXX roll was great. I did ask to trade out some types of fish in the sashimi but the sushi chef forgot and I didn't want to ask again. Will definitely come again - the menu is extensive and looks amazing and ambience is great.
author: Jessica R.

description: Worth the wait! I went with a few friends to Ebisu around 630 on a Saturday and we were told the wait would be about an hour. Side note, there is a cute wine bar a few blocks away that was great to grab a drink at while waiting. We finally sat down around an hour and fifteen later. We ordered three rolls, some nigri, salmon skin hand roll, cucumber salad and vegetable tempura. Everything was great! My favorite roll was the crunch roll and i would highly recommend the salmon skin handroll. The interior is very small but well decorated. This is not just your local sushi joint. The service, food, and ambiance is a step above. I would highly recommend giving it a try.
author: Jesse F.

description:
Getting to inner sunset can be a pain if you don't live in the city, but at least the wait wasn't too bad on a Sunday night, and I got lucky with parking!

Of course they have various rolls on the menu, but what I liked more was the cooked Japanese dishes, like chawanmushi, miso eggplant, black cod, etc.  They had a lot of lobster specials, so I couldn't resist the lobster tempura. At $15, there was a generous amount of meat and not too much batter. I preferred soy sauce and wasabi to their aioli, but I really liked the dish. For vegetables, the ohitashi duo was a nice light dish (spinach and pea sprouts with bonito).

As for the sashimi, it was fresh, and favorites included the escolar (butterfish), hamachi toro, and maguro. We also got a couple of rolls - the Tokyo tower was probably the prettiest one.

As for sake, they have a limited selection, but prices are reasonable. We had a large bottle of the hoyo kuro no Hana for $45.   

Presentation of the dishes is beautiful. It's a pretty small place, so it's probably not the best for huge groups.  With 2 or 3 people, sitting at the sushi bar in front of the chefs is probably a better option (per my friend, who's a regular there).  It wasn't as expensive as I thought it would be, and it's a nice neighborhood Japanese place.
author: Marilyn H.

description: My first time at Ebisu was so much fun, probably because of the delicious warm sake that I inhaled. Came here for lunch with 2 friends around 1pm on a Thursday and did not have to wait for seating. The decor was very modern, sleek and sexy! The sashimi was fresh, melt in your mouth and the selection was impeccable. Ordered the Omakase, Negimachi roll and my friend ordered the beef donburi. Not a big fan of donburi but this was one of the best since the beef and white rice was of very good quality. A bit pricy and the portions are smaller but quality is top notch.
author: Rosanna T.

description: This is some of the best sushi in town and prices are beyond reasonable! It is always busy on a Friday night, so you might have to wait a bit to get a table, but I assure you it's worth the wait! Love this place.
author: Fabiana D.

description:
I found this joint on yelp. Had a great date with the hubs at the Academy of Sciences and wanted to grab some lunch nearby before we continued our date to Sunset and explore the Sutro Bath Houses. I digress, back to the review of Ebisu...

Pros
- Came after the lunch hour rush ~1:30PM, so got seated right away 
- Ambiance is cute, cozy and clean 
- Waitress was super nice, but if you have a few tables - customers tend to get undivided attention 
- I ordered an obento lunch (beef, sushi and gyoza) and the box had lots of veggie side dishes - seaweed, spinach and salad. Pleasantly surprised. The sushi consisted of CA role and maki (not listed on the menu).
- Beef came with delicious tiny yukon potatoes - small amount, kind of a garnish, but it was tasty. 

Cons
- I ordered my beef medium and it came out well-done. Yikes! 
- Order took forever
- The obento menu did not list all the items that came with it so we over order, ordering a side of CA roll (not knowing it came with some in the obento)

Conclusion
- If Ebisu is the only joint available in the neighborhood, sure I'll go back. But my first option is to try another sushi place in the area.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
I had lunch here and it was good.  It wasn't too crowded and the quality of fish was good.  They have a lot of creative rolls so it's kind of fun.

I had one of the bento boxes that came with some sashimi, tempura, cut rolls, etc.

Service was great.
author: Dan P.

description: The Bento Lunch box at Ebisu is one of the best deals in San Francisco! You get a variety of items: Miso soup, seaweed salad, tempura, leaf salad, sushi, and choice of sashimi or meat. Service is promt and friendly! Definitely check it out.
author: Cynthia P.

description: I brought my wife and two daughters here to sample the sushi on a Saturday afternoon and even without reservations we were seated within 5 minutes. We like this area because there are plenty of choices and the prices are more affordable than elsewhere in the city. I generally judge a new sushi bar based on their ikura, and Ebisu passes with flying colors. The roe are fresh, vibrant, and pop nicely in the mouth. The maguro melts in your mouth like butter. The scallops, ebi, and hamachi were also delicious. My only complaint was the rice, which was cooked well, but lacked in flavor.  Overall, it was very high quality for the price. We ate our fill for $60 and will keep this place in mind for the next time we are taking friends our for sushi.
author: Robert M.

description: Really solid every time - the ingredients are top notch and the service is good as well. Bento boxes are a great deal!
author: Aaron S.

description:
I've had really good sushi - and Ebisu beats them all. Delicious and quality sushi, great service: definitely worth the line, if there is one.

Favorite rolls: Modern Family. XXX roll. 49er. Sashimi. This these aforementioned items to guarantee the most delicious, eclectic, and fresh sushi you could possible get in not just the Bay Area, but probably the country.

My fiance is a vegetarian and even she has said that the quality of the avocado+cucumber roll, and veggie tempura, is better than of any other sushi she's been to.  

Also, don't be afraid to sit at the bar. it's awesome to interact with the Chefs. Suzuki at the end is a riot!
author: Abraham B.

description:
I can see why this is one of the more popular sushi restaurants in the city.

We ordered the 49er, spider, and swamp rolls. I've had the 49er and spider at other restaurants but this place was better tasting. It was my first time trying a swamp roll (house poke and seaweed) and I liked it a lot. The table next to us ordered the lobster tempura which looked freakin amazing. Definitely need to try that the next time I'm here.

Service here was better than any other sushi restaurant I've ever been to. Some other popular places usually have terrible wait staff who seem too stressed to care about your experience, and the less popular places (i.e. lower quality food) can only pay attention to you because they have no other customers. Our waiter didn't try to rush us with ordering, was eager to explain the specials and his recommendations, and checked in on us frequently to clear plates, refill water, etc., despite having many other tables to wait on.

I don't know how bad the wait would be on the weekends, but if you go on a Wednesday night, there's pretty much no wait. The place is small and busy but there was always at least a table or two available for anyone who walked in.

Best sushi experience I've had outside of Tokyo.
author: Allen C.

description: Had high hopes for the place given how jam packed this place was and they actually had a Japanese Edo sushi chef. Had the chefs selection sashimi and a couple of rolls. The sashimi was was nothing spectacular and the rolls were equivalent to the rolls you find at a Chinese buffet. Left disappointed.
author: Michael T.

description:
Last night the bf and I were craving sushi and chose Ebisu out of the endless list of 4 and 5-Yelp-star restaurants in the Inner Sunset (Funset!). As we passed the better-known Koo and eyed its fancy bar, we starting having second thoughts but trudged on through the blustery crap that was last night's weather.

There was a long wait for 8pm on a Tuesday, which we took as a good sign, and went to pick out a movie at Le Video during our wait. We got back at the right time and were seated at the bar. We giggled excitedly as we hungrily read through the massive menu. 

We ended up ordering three rolls (Boston: my fav, Rainbow: good, #29: ehh, I think we had had too much tempura/shrimp by that point) and KOBE BEEF SASHIMI OMG it was so good. the bf, the former-vegetarian-of-12-years had a moment of doubt but his eyes quickly glazed over in happiness. 

The chefs were amazingly friendly and offered great recommendations, and we happened to be seated next to a regular of ~20 years named Robert. He decided to order us a round of oysters, which we returned with a round of sake. Soon enough it was an hour past closing and we knew his life story.

In conclusion, the magic of Ebisu's sushi bar should not be underestimated!
author: Laura K.

description: We decided to try this place on a recommendation of a friend, and it was great! We arrive right when they opened because we were warned they fill up fast. It is a very small restaurant. We sat at the sushi bar and were looking at the special up on the board for a few minutes when the sushi chef asked if we were ready to order, or if we would like him to just make what he feels is the best. We let him take care of us, and it turned in to such a fun experience! Everything he put in front of us was not only beautiful, but so fresh and flavorful. Each bite of fish was melt-in-your mouth delicious. He even made some things that were not on the menu for us! I definitely will be going back here...hopefully soon!
author: Sarah A.

description:
This is my absolute place for sashimi and rolls. We always go here when we are on San Francisco.

Food is fresh and always great!!!

The wait is worth it.
author: Karen S.

description: I've been to Ebisu twice now and I'd have to say:  this is my favorite sushi restaurant in San Francisco. We've only sat at the tables so I haven't had the chance to sit at the bar yet, but the chefs look very friendly and welcoming; they take shots of sake with their customers while continuing to serve at an excellent standard. What makes this place great is their nigiri selection, a few of my favorites are: otoro, kobe beef, and sake toro. I've never been to a restaurant that offered salmon belly and the nigiri is the best I've ever tasted.
author: Mark G.

description: Crowded, packed and frankly, lacking in service. What they have in good quality food, they lack in service. The sushi is very fresh and the fish quality is great, expected for the price. Yet, it didn't surprise me. The place was so loud, you had to yell your order more than once and the service was slow. Frankly, not as great as I expected.
author: Esther C.

description: The best sushi in our neighborhood and others in SF.   Many times we sit at the sushi bar.  The sushi chefs are all great and very friendly to us.  Some of my favorite rolls are the 49er roll and QP roll.  The fish is always so fresh and delicious.  We also enjoy the steamed clams, hamachi...I can go on and on.  When we sit at a table we get more sushi, a salmon dinner, Gindara- fantastic!  We like the fried oysters (Panko).  All service is excellent. Sushi is not cheap but you get what you pay for.  There is always a wait unless you get here when the restaurant opens.  It is worth the wait and price!
author: H. D.

description:
**4 STARS** relative to:
Japanese restaurants; sushi bars

If you want Japanese food in a modern setting and excellent service, then Ebisu provides just that. Catering to a more American clientele, the service is more attentive than most Japanese restaurants and the food presentation is eye-catching.  The $13 house udon I ordered is served in a wide cast iron pot brought to your table with a lid on top. The soup is piping hot and the portion is surprisingly large, just the way I like it. I enjoyed my dining experience and would most definitely visit again if I'm ever in the area.

**Strengths**  Upscale service. Modern, zen-like decor. Above average food. Beautiful presentation.

**Recommend?**  I would recommend this place if you're looking for good service and a clean, trendy setting to enjoy your Japanese food.  It is a more upscale dining experience than expected of usual sushi bars. This place is pleasing to the eye and senses.
author: Lovina C.

description: This place is the bomb! If you want a delightful experience, SEAT AT THE BAR! Julio and Suzuki are the best, and I've always seen the entire staff being very kind despite the madness. They're busy for a reason, so expect to face a line on Fridays and weekends. Have a drink while you wait. My tip: go with "how the chef's like it" option, but remember to let the chef know if you have any restrictions, they'll appreciate it too. Price range will depend on how hungry you are... I'm a sashimi/nigiri lover, so I can drop $100 bucks easily for these guys! I LOVE THEIR FOOD! : )
author: Gabriela M.

description:
I love this place. I've only been here once, but the guy that brought me here and I decided that there must be something special going on with the fish served here. 

We decided the owner must be raising the fish himself. Or someone is pampering them, feeding them gourmet fish food and possibly even serenading them to sleep at night. 

We ordered the Crunchy Tuna Roll which was sweet with a crunchy aftertaste and the Rainbow Dragon Roll (sans crab) added yellow-tail belly, which was very filling and completely bursting with flavor. 

I also had the miso soup which was delicious too (and I know why mention it, right? believe it or not I have had bad miso soup...lol) 

I seriously would not pass this place up if ever in the area... just to get at least one more taste of the amazingly good (possibly extremely pampered) fish!
author: Cassandra E.

description:
The food: it's not often that I rate sushi 5 stars, but Ebisu definitely earned it. It's a sleepy little neighborhood joint in Sunset, but inside it's charming and neat. We ordered the "two balls no strike" which was balls of spicy tuna covered in avocado- rather bland- but it was with my Sashimi Sampler that I was blown away. The tuna was authentically ruby red, and the yellowtail and even the mackerel were savory and as fresh as it gets. Who would've expected that from this tiny place?? Nice surprise indeed.

The bad: The servers look a bit gloomy, but that was probably because we walked in close to when lunch time was wrapping up.

The good: If you're into those authentic Japanese appetizers like fried oysters or salmon cheek this is a great place to come.

Ambiance: trendy, authentic Japanese

Overall: Great for lunch and/or dinner, some of the freshest sushi i've had in the bay area. The only competitor for me is Geta sushi in Piedmont on the east bay.
author: Jackie T.

description:
Is it just me, or do I have the worst luck when it comes to finding a good Japanese joint?

The dreaded 9th and Irving, tons of restaurants; very little parking. Luckily Ebisu had a rather short wait time (on this particular night), so that lowered my cortisol level as we stepped into a dimly lit Japanese restaurant. 

~Orders were taken right away-no complaints there. 

Okay, so here is goes. After our orders were taken, we practically became invisible in there. We were situated in the corner (but no excuse to forget about your customers).  Our food did not come until about 30 minutes after we ordered. To add an insult to injury, the couple who were seated AFTER us, received their food way before I did. And as a hungry man you can imagine the rage filling up in me (although I kept my composure). 

Order 5 dishes, only 4 came as we sat there/ my stomach lining getting ready to devour that 5th dishes that never came. So I flagged down the waitress pondering where the missing 5th dish is. Because we already finished the 4 dishes that were brought us prior, she had no way of knowing what we ate already, and what the 5th dish is. Luckily we still had the menu in front of us, and due to the process of elimination we were able to narrow it down to that elusive 5th dish. 

long story short: we ate the 5th dish, it was good.


Notable:
+Decor
++Short wait time (Saturday evening)
+Presentation of the dishes

Rating...?
Three starts because of the little incident stated above. I probably won't be visiting this place again, but hey who knows, maybe I will visit to review this place again. Until then god speed and may the force be with you.
author: Bobby S.

description: Very good sushi. I had the oysters on the half shell, which was a good preparation with soy sauce and tobiko. I also had the omakase menu and a side of rice. The fish was fresh and tasty, but the restaurant is on the expensive side. I would return but probably after trying a few other places.
author: Ruchi M.

description: One of the best sushi experiences of my life. Been here a few times over the years and they never disappoint. Sit at the bar and they will take good care of you. It is often busy but worth the wait!
author: Phil D.

description: My favorite sushi restaurant in the Bay Area.  Nice ambiance, great staff, especially Tom and Suzuki, which add color to the atmosphere.  Sushi is a bit pricey, but well worth the money, as it is some of the freshest and best tasting in the bay area!
author: Jonathan C.

description:
At first, i saw this place at SFO G-Concourst. and i decided to try this at their main location, and food was better. I didn't  grew up in Japan, but i traveled a lot, i know how top quality sashimi taste like. And service was great, all of associate are very customer oriented. and owner is always there to greet you. 
 
I will definitely go back there.
author: Danny P.

description:
Their fish tastes fresh and it's a nice lively atmosphere to share drinks with friends (without being overly loud).

I have to put one of their specials on blast though... the Oyster Dynamite with Uni. We got seated at the Sushi Bar (our sushi chef was pretty convivial by the way), and I was able to sneak a peak at these Oysters that the lady seated next to us had ordered. She recommended that we get them because in her words they are "slurpin' good".

I must say that typically I prefer my oysters chilled and served raw on the half shell, but I wanted to give them a try especially because they looked so good AND had Uni on top. If you're fan of oysters and uni you won't be disappointed... you get this really creamy, salty, umami taste. Something to definitely come back for.
author: Jeffrey J.

description: Pricey but gooooood. The one bad thing about this place is it will ruin it for all other sushi spots. You will forever be comparing other sushi restaurants to this place. Average price for a roll is $13. I know there are places that charge way more but it is still a little much for me. There was one waiter (only non asian staff member there. she was actually white); and she was super duper nice. Great at explaining all the rolls. She could be a sushi reviewer herself!
author: Brandon M.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE. I've been here a few times, twice at the bar, and I have to say that's 100% the way to go. I came with my parents tonight and Isa was our sushi chef. We just left everything to him and he did an outstanding job. When my mom grew full and my father and I kept going, Isa surprised us by making miniature nigiri so that my mom could try what we were having without over-stuffing herself. She was delighted!! Not only was he a great chef, he was very perceptive. Today, the anago was my favorite, while my dad liked the aji and oyster, but honestly, I would just let them choose or suggest what they think is best that day, since it always changes. I also had a lot of fun chatting with both Isa and Eric and Kevin. Kevin was my sushi chef the last time I came a few months ago. He is also phenomenal and very creative! Overall A++++ rating for Ebisu. I can understand why my aunt who recommended this place to me is a regular.
author: Kellie L.

description: Enticed by the high reviews, we had the 49er rolls, veggie tempura, teriyaki salmon.  The tang of the lemon with the fresh salmon on the 49er rolls was just right.  For dessert, we walked up the street to Holy Gelato.  Will be back!
author: M H.

description:
Went on Thursday night 7:30PM. And we waited about 20 minutes. There is small waiting area outside of the dining area to avoid cold weather outside. I noticed people started their bill and ordered drinks while waiting. Place looks really modern and updated. I like it. Dining area is not that big. Has many two person cafe tables that can be combined together to make larger tables. There is also seating at sushi bar with three chefs working the station.

Ordered:
Sappora Draft $5-good price!
Ebisu Sushi Dinner $25-(Tuna, long neck clam, freshwater eel, yellowtail tuna, scallop, salmon, salmon roe, hirame and flying fish roe nigiri sushi with kappa maki and spicy tuna maki )-not bad and fair price for the variety and amount. I think I would like to try the Chirashi $17.5 next time. There was too much rice after eatting this plate.
Double Hamachi Roll $12.95-Yellowtail and green onion inside out roll with yellowtail tuna, green onion and tobiko on top-I love Hamachi, but I was in love with this roll. Actually, I was a little disappointed with the over taste and texture of this roll. I will not be ordering this next time, eventhough I still love Hamachi.
Poke Roll $6.95 (Chopped albacore tuna seasoned with soy sauce, Japanese seven spices and onion)-I like this. I would definitely re-order it.

On the blackboard which is seasonal items ordered:
Dynamite Oyster with Uni $10-(Baked oysters with cream).See picture. I LOVED THIS. It was so creative. Somehow they found the right receipe and wrapped the oyster juice and some kind of cream. When you eat it, you are eatting the freshness of the oyster and able to drink the seafood juice from the shell. I loved it. I am sure it was fatty, but it was such a clever dish. 

After trying this blackboard item (these are specials written behind the sushi bar), I am so going back to try more.

One more item, I think was impressive I saw other tables ordering was their fresh UNI. I am not a fan, but I saw the dish. It looks very fresh and they like to present it ontop of a real UNI spikey shell. 

This place is better for two people eatting. Because it can get kinda crowded. I don't recommend for families or with kids.
author: Janice T.

description:
Great, fresh sushi. The fish is always good - I totally recommend the life scallop, it's amazing. I don't like the fried things that come with it, so I usually just ask for a cucumber salad instead. Everything else is delicious, but that is something special.

On top of the great food, the owners and servers are so nice. I love going here.
author: Emily K.

description: This place is amazing.  Fresh sashimi and no nonsense sushi.  There will be a wait.  My favorite is the fresh scallops still squirming in their shell.  Oh so good and that is why it has been in business for such a long time!  Countless sushi restaurants in that neighborhood have come and gone but Ebisu still stands.
author: Grace C.

description:
Very poor experience here, would not recommend at all.

First off, you're in for a very long wait.

We ordered a lot of food, as we had never been here before, and wanted to see how they were. We ordered sashimi, an Omakase, and a chicken dish.

Ate some hamachi sashimi, and was immediately disgusted by two things. 

1) The fish was mushy. I eat a lot of sashimi, I love the stuff. If the meat is mushy, then that means that the fish is not fresh, and may have been frozen. Considering how pricey the food is, and frankly, just food sanitation issues, raw fish MUST ALWAYS BE FRESH. That's why raw fish is supposed to be delicious, healthy, and expensive, because you only use the best quality and freshest fish possible.

2) There was lemon juice in it. This basically confirms that the fish was not fresh at all. You eat sashimi for the taste of the fish, the natural subtle flavors and sweetness of it. There's only one reason you would add something like lemon to a sashimi: the fish isn't fresh, and they need to mask that fact.

And no, it didn't taste good.

Next up was the Omakase. I could not have been more disappointed by this, unless I had gotten food poisoning. In the Omakase, we only received cuts of common fish, very regular cuts of the meat, and the waitress did not tell us what fish they were. She just set it down for us and left. Which didn't matter that much, because we knew what they were. They were the most common fish you can order, like tuna, salmon, and mackeral. And they weren't even good cuts of the fish.

Here's why this is the worst part of the night. If you don't know, Omakase in Japanese basically means "I'm trusting you to take care of it/me." It's putting your faith in the sushi chef and give you the best he can offer you. The freshest fish, the best cuts, the most interesting foods and presentations. It means something when you order an Omakase. When I left it to the restaurant to show me what they're made of, they came back with averages cuts of common fish. And it wasn't even fresh. And this is why this review is a 1 and not a 2.

The chicken dish was fine. Nothing spectacular. Very safe flavors, and very not Japanese tasting. Considering we got the chicken dish last, it made very clear what kind of establishment this was in retrospect.

Come here if you want crappy, low quality, overpriced, Americanized Japanese food.

But hey, at least I didn't get food poisoning.
author: Tom H.

description: One of my top cravings during pregnancy has been the fresh sushi at Ebisu! They have such a great variety and I never leave hungry. They do tend to get busy as it is a popular place so I like to order to-go. I tend to order the sake nigiri, 49er roll, Dexter Carter roll or the XXX rolls. The staff are friendly, hospitable, and the family have been in SF forever. I love this place.
author: Ashley H.

description:
Best sushi I've ever had.  Everything we ordered taste fresh and amazing! I came here with my boyfriend looking to try something new. This place exceed our expectation. We are quite picky when it comes to seafood because we hate anything that taste too "fishy". 

Here is a list of food we tried and really loved
Kobe beef sushimi
Dynamite oyster
Lobster tempura
Sake steamed clam
double hamachi roll
soft shell crab roll

If you want to try something new, you can try green tea creme brulee. It's not too sweet and you can really taste the green tea flavor. 

The price is decent, not too expensive at all compare to other japanese restaurants we've been to in Marin. It's worth the drive to the city.

Expect to wait for your seats, because it is a small place. It doesn't matter too much for us though because the food makes up for it.
author: Selina Z.

description:
I've been enjoying fresh sushi at their sister restaurant Hotei for the past 3 years and during that time Ebisu was under construction. I had only heard great things about this spot and when they finally opened, I was lucky enough to enjoy dinner at their soft opening. Wow!! It was truly amazing and quickly became my new favorite sushi spot. The dinner menu is a thing of beauty. All 4 or 5 pages of it! The cedar plank salmon is to kill for and everything we had that night was absolutely fabulous. 

After walking around the Academy of Sciences for a few hours, I was getting hungry. Hunger turned to starving and starving turned to I need sushi now!!!

I had the most amazing, fresh, delicious live scallop I've ever had!! We got down with Salmon sashimi (my all time favorite) a rainbow roll. The sushi master was nice enough to hook us up with a variation of the rainbow roll b/c my date was not able to enjoy the shrimp tempura that comes with that roll and it tasted even better than it usually does. He was on top of his game, which is always a huge plus and he was quite entertaining. The owner was there and I just love seeing this man. He's one of the coolest guys I have met in all my years of dining in SF and works his ass off!! His hard work is greatly appreciated by this sushi lover. I love this place and could honestly eat there 3-4 times a week.
author: Hector G.

description:
It is pretty okay.
Not my first choice.
Although, they have been in business charging them crazy prices for a long long time so...guess they are doing something right. Just not right enough for me to recommend it nor for it to pop in my mind when I need my fix. It is no longer the only above mediocre joint in these parts so I recommend saving some cash and hitting up Kazu down the street. I'm partial to that joint when I'm in this hood.
author: Grubbinator A.

description: Solid Sushi Restaurant.  Never had better sushi, our server was very attentive and helpful. It was a little cramped, but it was worth it get here early otherwise you'll be waiting for a while. I love their Toro selection. Thank you Ebisu, a bit pricy but worth it.
author: Elt M.

description:
This place is not bad, definitely more of a group, party kind of place since it gets kind of loud. But my gf and I figured out how to blend in with the atmosphere, order the large sakes LOL. There was a bit of wait, and this place is pretty big. Long line of seats at the sushi bar and plenty of tables. 

Service is quick and attentive. We ordered an oyster baked w/ uni appetizer dish but they gave us the one with lobsters. We told our server and she took care of it and we were glad we had her fix it. We also had the kobe beef appetizer, which was also delicious. I ordered a bento with chicken/ sashimi/ and tempura and it's one of the best bento boxes I've eaten. She ordered the $25 chef's choice sashimi. (Sorry I don't know the names of any dishes because the sake...)
author: Roger N.

description:
My wife and I had an outstanding meal at Ebisu last night! She brought me here when we were dating and it has been our favorite sushi restaurant for years, when we can get there...

We were lucky enough to arrive before 6 so we had almost no wait, maybe 5-10 minutes max, it took us longer to find parking.

We started with the tri-flavor edamame, the garlic was outstanding and the chili lime had perfect heat.

We didn't feel like sashimi tonight but it has always been a hit. We ordered 4 rolls: double hamachi, rainbow roll, dragon roll and #29. While all of them were outstanding, the dragon roll stood out as especially melty last night. The #29 is a bit on the large size for a roll, but tasty none the less.

We had great service as usual and thoroughly enjoyed our meal. We will always come back when we can get there!

On a side note, a group of three came in and a gentleman was in a wheelchair. The staff was completely accommodating and made an effort to make them comfortable.
author: Rob F.

description: First night away from baby for our anniversary and I had waited a year to come here after some reviews by friends.  Did not disappoint!  We did omakase at the bar. Would not have it any other way. The attention to detail and the complex layering of flavors was amazing. Home made soy sauce, fresh halibat, Escobar....we were spoiled. Absolutely take time and enjoy the rich textures and let you senses take in the different blends of fish and tastes. Can't wait to come back again and splurge for next big night. Thank you.
author: JL S.

description:
I never came here before I did because it LOOKED like it'd be overpriced and could not beat the sushi places I'm loyal to.  But  because the bf and I were walking around grouchy and hungry, trying to find a place to eat, I didn't care anymore.  Every other Japanese place is closed at 3pm on a weekday.  I'm happy to say that Ebisu didn't disappoint =)

The restaurant is sleek and modern.  This would be an ideal place to take a date.  I only ordered a roll and uni nigiri, while the non-seafood eating bf got the beef teriyaki.  I did catch a peep of a tray the sushi chefs were putting together and it looked so goooood!  As usual, the bf's food tasted better than my own, but mine was pretty good also.  The uni was very firm, so I knew it was very fresh.  The beef was very tender and flavorful.  

I'd come here again.  Not my first choice for sushi restaurants, but it's say...top 5 in the city.
author: Tokki M.

description:
My husband and I have been here three times over the past six months and have had an excellent experience every time. I've always been a bit of a sushi conservative, but the last time we sat at the bar and ordered omakase (chef's whimsy) and it was incredible. The chef explains what he is serving and it was all delicious, even the pieces I was unfamiliar with.

We are new parents so we go early to beat the lines, but even at 5pm this place is full, word has clearly gotten out.
author: Lex L.

description: A small place but definitely hits every palette. Very fresh sushi selections, appetizers and entrees. The chefs are very nice and accommodating. If you are a sushi fanatic, sit at the bar and let the chef entertain you with their creativity!
author: Edelwisa J.

description:
I usually don't like to eat sushi, I only like this sushi place. 
Its fresh and I don't get sick after eating seafood.
This is a place where  you want to bring all your friends. If I meet any new friend who tells me that they like to eat Sushi, I will tell to try this place. But don't bring cash becasee the price is always higher than you expected to pay. It;s very expensive but its worth tho
author: Anita J.

description:
This place doesnt take reservations so be prepared to wait... but it is totally worth it! The fish is so fresh and simply melts in your mouth. You can tell the quality of the food from their miso soup. It made miso happy :) 

Service was fast and staff were friendly
author: Niki V.

description:
Its the first time I went to a Japanese place and ate sushi - how its supposed to be eaten. So pretty pleased with the entire situation. We were planning on going to a Thai place nearby but it was closed and thats how we started eating here. 

There is a pink sushi - with crucnhy somethings inside it. Very weird and tasty. 

Quiet ambience. And the food is great.
author: Neelakantan N.

description: I've eaten sushi in many, many places, this joint is mediocre at best. the waitress, an American girl barely had an IQ of 40, my wife asked some questions and you'd think she'd been asked to explain Quantum Physics. They did bring out the requested items for my young nephew quickly which is a plus, however, the sushi and sashimi portions were not that big and I don't think the fish was super fresh. I ordered a yellow tail roll and the fish used was leftovers that had been chopped up practically into a paste. The eel was not properly skinned and had tough jagged pieces of skin on the underside. The waitress didn't check on us and the service was Meh! The rolls were more rice than fish and all in all I wouldn't go back.
author: Bill F.

description: We went here on a Wednesday night and the wait was not bad at all. In fact, we waited maybe ten or fifteen minutes. The service was nice and quick. The only thing we didn't like was the tuna sashimi. It was a little bit chewy and didn't taste completely right. However, everything else was really on point. We tried the Double Hamachi roll and some nigiri (Sake Toro, Albacore Toro, Uni, Ikura, Umi Masu, and Unagi). The bill came up to about $100 for two of us and I think, some items are slightly overpriced. But we did enjoy our dinner.
author: Sara S.

description:
Visiting from Chicago, and a local friend took me to Ebisu for dinner.

EFFING phenomenal.  We sat at the sushi bar.  I loved everything we had, but my favorite part was when I asked for my traditional tuna & avocado roll... and he asked if he could doctor it up.  Sure!  I suggested jalapeno, and then he added spicy mayo and fish eggs... He then torched it before handing it over, and it was the best sushi roll I've ever had.  So great.  

Also loved the warm hand towels :)  and the orange slices at the end.  Thanks Ebisu!
author: Holly O.

description: Per a friend's recommendation, I came for lunch and ordered the Chirashi.  The fish is exceptionally fresh (better than Koo and comparable to Jimisan) and I also liked their inclusion of scallop and clam sashimi =D  The inside is small and cozy with modern, dark wood furnishing.  Head sushi chef was very friendly and energetic too, which made my experience all the more pleasant.  Def a fan!
author: Eric F.

description:
My boyfriend and I were long over-due for a sushi date and so ventured to Ebisu. When we got there, there was a list and plenty of people hungrily waiting in the foyer and outside. Instead of being deterred, we simply wrote down our names and hopped over to Mucky Duck's for a quick beer and by the time we returned it was our turn! We were barely gone 15 min, and the place was packed, so I was surprised at the quick service.

Firstly, the ambiance is always great, laid back and yet with an upscale vibe.

Secondly, our server, Justine, was a delight. Always there when we needed her, incredibly nice, and a definite treat. Also, Sarah was wonderful as always. She recognized us and though we weren't seated in her section, still wanted to make sure we were doing great, that our meal was delicious (of course it was). 

We decided on the dinner combinations, plenty of food for $20, and also the Chef's special roll! Seldom do we encounter sushi we don't like (rather, never) and being indecisive, left it to the chef! He whipped together a roll neither of us had ever had, but it was fresh and had plenty of flavors that flawlessly compliment each other.

And the sake! 

Needless to say, it was a wonderful date, and we took home leftovers that were still delicious the next day. I definitely recommend this place, the staff is friendly and attentive, and the food is reasonably priced and absolutely delicious.
author: Di M.

description: I definitely will not go back to this place. Sushi was not fresh at all and pricy for the poor quality. don't know what all the good reviews about. I regret reading review on yelp and chose this restaurant.  Waited for about 45 mins And the hostess was so rude. After 30 minutes I went up to ask her How long do we still have to wait,  she totally ignored me.  So rude!!!! nasty sushi and horrible oysters.  Service was not all that great. And when we paid the bill,  they decided to keep all the change over 30% of tip. I had to go up to tell then to give me Change and the lady looked at me like she doesn't know what I'm taking about.  Finally I got my change back.
author: Alexis K.

description:
1) plastic wrapper in miso
2) bone in california roll
3) waitress who avoided eye contact (i guess if you don't see unhappy customers then everything must be ok)
author: Stephan T.

description: Great food and yummy sushi. The service is very good but gets extremely busy!!! Try to reserve a table.
author: Marie-tess R.

description: The food in Ebisu is just fine although we didn't find it impressive at all, but I wouldn't write this review just for their food. What was really disappointing was their unacceptable service! We picked this restaurant after reading its good reviews on yelp. We chose to go on a Friday night and spent 25 mins finding a parking spot 5 blocks away, very normal for SF though! The restaurant was super packed and they were obviously lacking in service. It was so loud that my husband and I needed to yell 3 times to order. Maybe we picked the wrong night, but won't come back again!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I have such great memories from this place from when I used to take dance class in the area. I had not been back since the remodel, so it had definitely been a while.

Ebisu is just as fresh and delicious as it was years ago. I ordered the omakase for 1-2 and my fellow diners ordered the seafood tempura. Everything was top quality and our server was so gracious and patient with my 87 year old grandfather.

Wish I lived closer or it was more accessible by Bart. I will for sure be back whenever I get the opportunity.
author: Sasha S.

description:
In our recent trip to San Francisco, my wife and I were in Golden Gate Park and were looking for a good sushi place within walking distance.  My wife found Ebisu using Yelp and saw it was close by, (a short walking distance from the Academy of Science).

We got there right as they open for dinner and were the only ones there, but it became busy about 20 minutes after we got there.  The decor was nice and the service was excellent.  The sushi was reasonably priced and a la carte, unlike most sushi place in Vegas that are all you can it.  All of the fish was extremely fresh and flavorful.  The ginger was also very fresh.  Unfortunately I do not remember all of the rolls we had, but I can say that you wont be disappointed with what you order.
author: Matthew K.

description:
I absolutely loved Ebisu.

Food was great, presentation, everything was great. I came here with my uncle and aunt, and boy do they know how to eat! They ordered a bunch of uni that just came in that morning. It was so fresh and delicious oh my GOODNESS. SO GOOD. The chirashi was really nice and had a TON of fish in it. The poke was tasty. The agedashi tofu was a little weird (no grated daikon,... and they had fried shiitake instead?? weird)., but whatever it tasted great. We also paired it with this really nice sake... I don't even want to know how much that cost my uncle. 

But what really amazed me was the service. During our dinner ,some other lady from another table projectile VOMITED down the tiny hallway of the restaurant, some of which got on my purse. I was completely grossed out, but the staff was very efficient at cleaning up the floor and my purse. Thank god my purse is plastic and not leather- I would have had a FIT if they messed up a nice one.

I was able to get it well cleaned, thank god. It was absolutely disgusting. But the staff was great about it.

Still can't believe some idiot vomited all over the floor. She just drank way too much and went BLEHHH. Who does that at a nice restaurant?! She should be ashamed of herself. No class at all.

I will def be back :) Hopefully next time will be vomit free!
author: Jade R.

description:
What a hit or miss restaurant. 

But basically, when to go, in my opinion, is on a date if you're a gal and the guy is paying, or anytime when you're not paying because this place is pricey, pricey, pricey. Parking is inconvenient (not their fault), and the wait is pretty much LONG if you're not going to be here when the doors open. 

I do not recommend getting the cooked food dishes - stick only to the sushi, and basically as fresh as the sushi can get. I got the Sake Steak, shioyaki style, and the fish was overcooked (so tough), a bit flavorless, and needed a lemon - which they didn't give. The salad, fried veggies/roasted potatoes were amazing, but I didn't spend $15 for mouthwatering sides :( 

The tempura is a bit soggy and average at best. On top of that, the sauce just makes the tempura even more damp and flimsy, and the flavors don't even adhere to your fried veggies. I wouldn't recommend the tempura at all, even through they give you tempura brocolini - not sure if it's the batter or the cook. 

Sashimi (yellowtail) tasted fresh, but it was lukewarm too, which gave the fish a bad taste that made me slather it in wasabi and soy sauce. I've had a sashimi combo before and recall the fish being amazing, so maybe they had that sitting out for a while before they brought it to us :/ 

Family Roll was NOT impressive. The avocado was not ripe. The sushi fell apart when we tried to pick it up, and I'm not sure how fresh the fish was either. Would not recommend. 

Live scallop was pretty tasty. The fried tempura that accompanied it was delicious - now that was perfectly fried, cripsy, little oil, and full of flavor - and I could tell that it was really fresh. Plus the display is really cute - I just wonder why it's called live scallop when they basically give you mini scallop nirigi. So how live was it before we got it?? Curious. 

However, the service was excellent and the staff was very accommodating. The owner even came by and apologized that she couldn't seat our table of 10 together.

Overall this was a sub-par experience at Ebisu because of the food. I wonder if lunch would be better since the chefs aren't in a rush to push out the dishes. I haven't crossed off you yet Ebisu, but you're definitely not at the top of my list.
author: Christal Y.

description:
Sorely Disappointment. Had lunch with Mom. 
We ordered:
Kobe Sashimi - kobe was soft, decent appetizer. Not sure I would order it again tho.
Oyako don - chicken was on the dry side, nothing special
#29 roll - the roll fell apart the moment I tried to pick it up with my chopsticks =\ this was a huge turnoff for me. Isn't a sushi roll supposed to be rolled tightly?? I dont get it, this is kind of a noob mistake....     
Spider roll - 5 pieces, decent
Hamachi Toro nigiri - pretty good, might order again

Sigh. I was really looking forward to this! I really wanted to like Ebisu!
author: A b.

description:
I've been here several times and realized that I have not yet written a review for this place! A pretty decent sized menu selection of both food and drinks (both non-alcoholic and alcoholic beverages) and the decor very bright & colorful. 

While I'm not a huge fan of raw food (I came for the cooked), my partner loves it. Fresh and good quality sushi & sashimi. 

Wait staff is also pretty attentive (or at least they try to be) considering how busy this place gets. But overall experience is a positive one and I would definitely go back!
author: Killah K.

description:
This is probably my favorite Sushi bar for a number of reasons that go beyond just the quality of the food. Don't get me wrong, the quality is fantastic here and although I have been to restaurants that offer even better quality and selection, it's the overall experience at the bar which brings me back here on a regular basis.

To be clear, if you come here with a larger group or specifically want to be seated at a table, your experience will be a mixed bag. The food is still great, but your wait will be long, the ambiance noisy, the waiters appear a bit frantic and unorganized.

On the other hand, if you sit at the bar - either by yourself or with a partner - you will have an infinitely better experience. Especially, if you develop a rapport with a specific chef over multiple visits to the point where he already knows your preferences and will customize the food for you. Of course, this is true for many other Sushi bars in general, but what's nice about Ebisu is the non-threatening, non-snooty atmosphere. All chefs here are very friendly and accommodating. 

I guarantee you won't just have a great food experience but a fantastic social experience as well.
author: Andre B.

description: Great ambience with even better fish and to top it off, the chefs are incredibly fun and witty!
author: Veronica M.

description:
I was going to give this place 2 stars for "potential", but on second thought, no.

My partner and I were in a celebratory mood, and were willing to spend much  more than we usually do on lunch, especially considering the great time we had at their sister restaurant across the street.  Sadly, it was a wasted effort.

Upon arrival, we were seated at a table near the door, with one seat directly in the main line of traffic.  We asked to be seated at a table further back, but were told that they were expecting larger groups for lunch, so they didn't want to break up the tables.  Mind you, as a party of 2, we were only asking to be seated at one of the 2-person tables they had combined for parties of 4, and the table we requested was not "reserved", just "held" because they get very busy for lunch.

Although off-putting, we decided to take the uncomfortable table nonetheless, as the place was 2/3 full and the ambiance seemed nice. We rearranged our chairs from the 12-6 position to the 12-9 position and settled in. Our server then proceeded to win us over with his knowledge of the sake offerings and his generally pleasant demeanor.  Unfortunately, that was the highlight of our experience.

I should have known something was amiss when another server made a point to bump my chair (which was now out of the main line but narrowing the line between tables) as he went back and forth, finally loudly blurting out, "Would you PLEASE move your chair back?!  You're creating a really big obstruction!!"

Normally, I go out of my way to assist servers in restaurants--they have a tough job, and have to deal with more than they should, but the volume, attitude, and the look on his face (which said "I don't want you here") was just too much.  We walked out.

To our pleasant server--sorry we didn't stay, order a big, expensive lunch (as was our plan), and tip you well (as we always do).  To Belligerent Boy, it's your fault.
author: Tom M.

description: Came here twice so far and nothing negative to say yet.  Sushi is absolutely good, decent price, casual ambiance, very packed inside. I would def call in before you come here cuz the twice i have visited have been packed. Minus 1 star for the location. Parking is extremely difficult.
author: Rose P.

description:
Dont get me wrong, sushi here is good.

BUT, the manager who runs the wait list and seats people - middle-aged asian woman, her name is Yao - is somebdoy who lefts much to be desired. The wait here can easily be an hour or more on Friday/Sat nights, even for a party of two like ours. Yao the manager conveniently favors a person on the second page, about 10 down from the other people waiting to be seated and gets him and his date seated. On pointing that out to her by multiple people, she acts as though nothing happened. 

Thats not where it ends. Half an hour later, she goes and conveniently, again, seats somebody (party of two, like us) whose name is right below ours. On pointing that out to her, all she can say is "sorry". Clearly there is favorism happening here, as well she is likely plain math/reading deficient to not be able to follow an order on a list. 

With waits of more than an hour, and this kind of unexplainable activity happening around the wait list, I choose to take my business elsewhere unless this issue is resolved.
author: Sonali A.

description: Kakuni was delicious. Also had their rock-n-roll, poke roll, and Hot Louisiana Link roll (spicy yellowtail), which were good. Very friendly service.
author: A L.

description:
I came here on a random tuesday night and it was ridiculously crowded. Why is this place so popular?? It was good, but not outstanding. If anything, it was overpriced japanese food that tried too hard to be gourmet.

I had the shrimp & vegetable tempura and tried some of my friend's chicken terriyaki. Again, both were good, but not outstanding. Did we just order the wrong items?

Two stars for their unjustified overpriced menu items and for lacking lion king rolls.
author: Jenny T.

description:
This has got to be one of, if not favorite, sushi place in San Francisco. Every single time I come here, I try something different and I've been blown away with each dish.We decided we were in the mood for some quality sashimi and I decided to Ebisu because you can never go wrong here. The line was 20-30 mins long so we decided to go to Yancy's, a bar next door, to pass the time. When we got back to the restaurant, we were seated right away. We got the lobster tempura, sashimi platter for 2, Bluefin Tuna toro and the 49er roll. 
The highlights of this meal was DEFINITELY the sashimi. Maybe we were a little tipsy from the bar next door but I don't know why we decided to get the lobster tempura since we were only in the mood for sashmi.It wasn't a bad choice though! There were huge lobster chunks that were deep fried to a nice crunchy texture. The sauces they drizzled on top was perfect with the dish. However, we could've done without that dish just because we weren't in the mood for something fried. It was around $20.The 49er roll was good. Nothing to complain or rave about. 
But oh my gawd...was the sashmi delicious. The Bluefin Toro blew our minds. I don't even know how to describe it just because it was that delicious. It didn't even seem like we were eating fish just because the chunk literally melted into our mouths and the sweet vinegary  rice paired so perfectly with the tuna. It was SO good. However, it was a $16 dish for only two pieces...I think it's because tuna is becoming endangered. Oh for the love of God, please let there be more tuna. We need to do whatever it takes to save this delicious fish.....and still be able to eat them. *Still drooling*
Another great dish here was the sashimi platter. We got the $25 platter that can feed 1-2 people. It was also really delicious. The variety of fish were perfect and fresh. There are a lot of places that have sashimi platters and their fish is so chewy! The texture here is just so drool worthy and honestly, you forget you're eating fish.

I love love love this place. However, because the price and quantity of the food they have here is a little bit high for me, I come here when I feel like I want to treat myself. I think eating at Ebisu has raised my standards for good sushi and I recommend everyone to try it here at least once.
author: Lina L.

description: This place is so good! This is my second time here and it was a great experience. We took my boyfriend's mom here and she thought the sushi was fresh! Which it was because the sushi was basically melting in our mouth. Service was much better than the first time we went which is a redeeming factor!
author: Trang N.

description: Been here when they frist opened and love it till this day! One of my favorite Japanese Restaurant for sure. It never fell. It's a bit small but worth the wait. That's why their always busy! The restaurant speaks for itself! !! :)
author: Michele T.

description: Fish was realllllllly fresh, so a definite plus! and what else I liked was that they served us Asahi beer (in the big bottle!) :-). It's also conveniently located off the N, so another plus for public transportation!
author: Christina C.

description: Ebisu used to be good but it's turned into a mediocre gathering for techies and snobs.  The ambiance is terrible and the fish isn't fresh.  The noise level is absurdly loud as well.  Don't be fooled by what used to be good,  before it was remodeled and marginalized.
author: Zach H.

description:
I was so disappointed and so disheartened that this place is busy over places so much more deserving, that I'm writing my second Yelp review ever.

First, the sushi is nothing special and overpriced. This was my first time coming to this place, and based on the wait and how busy it was inside, I was expecting it to be delicious. Nope. When my first roll came out, I couldn't believe how thin, soggy and wimpy it was. It was sad. My second was decent, but certainly nothing worth waiting for. I was with three other people, none of whom raved about their food either. I can name five other sushi joints within 3 miles with far better sushi, I just happened to be with someone who wanted to try this place. She was disappointed, too.

But, the biggest disappointment was not the food . . . it was the final impression. Not 5 minutes - - really, 5 minutes, I'm not joking - - after we settled our $90 something dollar bill, the hostess came to our table, where we were sipping on the last of our drinks and chatting, and ASKED US TO LEAVE because she needed the table, because there was a wait. Had we been lingering after dinner for 20 or 30 minutes, and after a few not so subtle hints to leave, had this occurred in a more friendly manner, I might have been cool with this. But, after 5 minutes!!!?? After leaving a sizable tip for a lackluster meal??? While we were still finishing our drinks???!!! This is unacceptable.

Having worked in the restaurant industry in my early 20s, it's obvious that this is absolutely one of those restaurants that pushes through people to just keep the tables turning. Normally these type of places just rush you through your food, but I've never actually been kicked out of my table. 

Sushi bars are a dime a dozen in SF  . . . This one, with its so-so, but nothing special food and outrageously disrespectful attitudes towards the customers that keep it in business, doesn't deserve to be in business.

I'm happy to go somewhere where I'm not treated like cattle and I can finish the drink I paid for.
author: Trisha W.

description: My new fav Japanese spot. Kobe beef and sake steamed mussels. Yum! Need I say more?! They also have a long list of sake varieties. Staff was wonderful considering how busy they were on a Saturday night.
author: Phuong P.

description: Just go there. Best sushi I've ever had and totally reasonably priced. The 49er sounds strange but is genius. The dragon and sashimi platter were definite highlights too. Expect an hour wait.
author: Angie E.

description: Had an bad evening with Ebisu! If you decide to take ppl at the last minute, please treat us like regular customer!! Feel like eating fast food... Paying 15$ for a roll but the quality is suck!! Very disappointed!!
author: Mandyy S.

description:
I came here several times in the 80's and 90's and it was our go-to Japanese restaurant when traveling through San Francisco or doing something at UCSF. 
Fast forward 30 years later and it's still as good as I remember. The decor is a bit dark inside but service was prompt and the food/sushi was all delicious. We came here for lunch and it was pretty crowded. Didn't notice a horrible fish smell like some people describe in their reviews...and I hate that smell. 
We will definitely return.
author: Barb B.

description: There sushi is fresh! The Crunchy Roll is a must have!!!!!! I think I remember a month where my family and I came here at least every week.
author: Andrew N.

description: wtfffff the service sucks!! They're having a $100 for $85 special right now. So I called a day before to ask if I needed to buy the deal and they informed me that when I dinned in I could tell them of the deal I saw and they would then take off the $15 from my entire bill. That was a lie because when I got there they said no and didn't even bother to compromise. You're better off at Koo down the street. Seriously go there instead.
author: Phoebe L.

description:
4.0 Stars

My good friend and I stopped in to try Ebisu last Saturday night. We walked into a cozy restaurant with a nice newly remodeled interior. The place had an industrial/modern vibe and I was really enjoying the decor.

Ebisu offers a wide array of dishes. From hot/cold appetizers to bento combination boxes to barbequed skewers to sushi, their menu covers a good range of Japanese food.

Between the two of us we shared the following items:

Agedashi Tofu
*Fried tofu served in tempura broth served with negi, daikon, and ginger
*There was a light batter around the soft, silken tofu that got slightly soggy after sitting in the broth. I suggest eating this dish quickly when it comes out.
*I really enjoyed the broth that came with this appetizer.

Sukiyaki
*Japanese style iron pot with Kobe Beef, fishcake, tofu, carrots, napa cabbage, and glass noodles.
*Dish comes with a bowl of rice and miso soup on the side.
*This pot of sukiyaki is HUGE and there are plenty of ingredients inside. I would recommend splitting this between two people and ordering an appetizer and sushi roll on the side.
*The Kobe Beef was sliced thin and a little raw when the dish came out. If you like your beef a little more cooked you can leave it sitting in the hot broth a little longer.
*The broth in the sukiyaki was even better than the agedashi tofu broth!

Double Hamachi Roll
*Yellowtail, Scallion, and Tobiko
*Who doesn't love Hamachi? I have no complaints on the soft, butter texture of the fish so why not double up on something so tasty?
*The roll is fairly simple and still delicious.

XXX Roll
*This was the blackboard special roll of the day. You can select Chef's Special instead if you're extra adventurous and the chef will conjure up a mystery roll for you.
*Salmon Hamachi Roll in Avacado Poke.
*This roll was quite different with the poke sauce and was slightly spicy.

My friend and I probably over ordered a sushi roll and were definitely grabbing our stomachs by the end of the meal.

I really enjoyed my experience at Ebisu. The sushi was very fresh and the rolls were a decent size (not too big, not too small). There are plenty of things on the menu to choose from so there's something for everyone.

As a side note, I feel this restaurant is still intimate enough for a date spot with the nice decor and good food, however it can get a little loud inside especially since the tables are packed pretty close to one another.

== A MUST TRY! ==
author: Jason H.

description: My first time here and it was not bad at all! I came here with some friends and it was great! We ordered many different dishes of foods to share, and I had my first oyster shot and it was BOMB! I never thought it would taste good and Imo not exaggerating when I say its good because I'm a very picky eater and i dont usually eat raw oysters ! Their sushi rolls were great, and well made, they baked oysters were just as good, the hamachi (fish tail) was to die for as well, the meat would just melt in your mouth. Like most Japanese restaurants it is pricy, but the place is well worth it. Great service great food and nice place setting inside.
author: Tiffany K.

description: This place has a really cozy setting. The sushi is unbelievably good. Also, their chicken teriyaki is superb.
author: Arash F.

description: Worst food/service I have ever received. Highly disappointed in my experience, and would recommend you take your business elsewhere. Sorry guys.
author: Josh P.

description: Been coming here since I can remember and it just seems to get better as time goes by, definitely my go to place for Japanese cuisine and sushi in San Francisco!
author: gene f.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Miso = came out with a lid on! Nice! Keeps it warm for when I'm ready to drink it
2.) Oyster shooter = in sake. 
3.) Squid appetizer
4.) Sashimi Combo = omg I normally don't prefer octopus or shrimp sashimi but it was goood and ate everything on my plate! The Sashimi however was SOOOOOO MELT IN YOUR MOUTH GOOD! 


SERVICE:
Very nice staff :) Came with a very big group and they were very accommodating and everyone in my party was very happy. Had cake too, which they provided the plates and silverware. 


ATMOSPHERE:
The presence of a professional Interior Designer's is definitely felt.

10.9
author: Angela L.

description:
There are a lot of good sushi places in town so I look for ones that raise the bar by offering something a little special compared to the others, like are they unexpectedly cheap...unexpectedly hip...or do they do something extra well. If the sushi is good, these extras are what make me decided between sushi-restaurant-A or sushi-restaurant-B. 

Ebisu's special extra is kushiyaki! Little amuse-bouches on skewers. Besides excellent fish, you should get a couple of these little skewers offering kobe beef (we assume "kobe" but it's not stated), scallops, and more for $3 per. Delicious, and the ones we had came with a barbecue sauce that holds up to scrutiny.

The decor is nice. The service was nice. The saki was nice. Ebisu is a sushi joint worth trying.
author: Luke M.

description:
This place sure has a lot of reviews, but based on my experience, I don't see why it should be so popular. 

I tried the trio of edamame, the tootsie roll and rainbow roll. The edamame came in three flavors: sea salt, lime and lemon garlic fried. The sea salt one had a nice, soft saltiness, the lime had a sour spiciness, and the lemon garlic had a garlic flavor reminiscent of garlic fries at an amusement park. There was some good flavor, but I think I just prefer edamame on its own, with a pure, fresh taste.

The tootsie roll had salmon and green onion and was wrapped in soy paper. There was a nice crunch as you bit in, but overall it was a bit bland. The rainbow roll was not great. The fish on top was not fresh at all - it was mushy and also cut in very small pieces, completely lacking the firm elasticity that sashimi should have.
author: Elaine L.

description: Super quick service. I was in a line full of people, I got my seats within 15minutes. Amazing! There's line ups before the place even opens. What people would do for good food. I was impressed by their level of quality, the servers would go an extra mile to serve you  and make sure you are enjoying your meal. My tea and water is always full and my food served very quickly. I don't remember waiting for much after I ordered, and I was counting minutes for food to arrive as I was hungry. Ebisu ended my misery very shortly. THANK YOU. They comforted me with quality sushi. I love their lobster tempura with mushrooms. Yummy! I had the arch sushi and giants sushi. Super impressed by them. they are sooo  busy, but they manage to pull through taking care of everyone.
author: Diana T.

description:
I'm updating this review based on my parent's experience.

 After my previous review, the management contacted me apologizing for our experience and granted us a $50 gift card.  I passed this gift card to my parents who went back to Ebisu and had a "great, delicious dinner."

Thank you for your compensation.
author: Laina V.

description:
Pricey but always worth it. Consistently great. Sit at the bar, and if you have deep pockets, let the sushi chefs spoil you....If you ever get the chance to eat the live uni -- WoW! Fatty tuna is another favorite. If you're not into raw -- try the mussel broth dish.

This place is a favorite among the UCSF crowd. The cheaper restaurant owned by the same people is across the street, but far from the same experience. There is a paid parking across the street in the funeral home (?) lot. Expect long waits if you go during weekend rush.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
A very nice Sushi bar that is unique and creative in their offerings. Dishes you don't often find such as their Kobe Sashimi beef, Live Uni and excellent Poke-based creations. The prices are higher than many sushi spots, but the quality of the fish reflects it. The Hamachi Toro is a prime example. Melts in your mouth.

It's a busy place so be prepared to wait. Very friendly owners and lots of regulars. Also a nice walk from Golden Gate Park over to Ebisu.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Came here for a dinner after spending a day at Golden Gate Park. The place was pretty packed considering we arrived at 6, it's pretty early for dinner. The good thing that we didn't have to wait long for our seat. 

We ordered:
- 49er Roll   8.95
Sliced salmon, lemon, avocado, tobiko and shiso
- Poke Roll   6.95
Chopped albacore tuna seasoned with soy sauce, Japanese seven spices and onion
- Tootsie Roll    6.50
Halibut or salmon with green onion, deep fried and wrapped in soybean paper
