-(Hosomaki) Negi Toro  Fatty tuna belly with green onion      7.50

The sushi was okay, the one that made a long-lasting impression was the 49er roll, with the sliced lemon on top, it's very different than any sushi I've ever tasted before. Not in a bad way, but just out of the ordinary for me. 

Service was great and friendly, the place was really busy as it got to dinner time and barely any room for people to walk between tables. Kinda tight. Will I come back? Maybe, cause I saw our neighbor's order of Sashimi and its presentation made it really yummy...
author: Jenny B.

description: don't know about the long line...it was not bad but certainly not worth the $$
author: Weikang H.

description: Ebisu is my go-to sushi place. Never lets me down. Tommy is an amazing sushi chef. Try to sit at the bar in front of him if you can. All fish is very fresh and the new renovated look is super cute too!
author: Alysha K.

description: Salmon sashimi really good and melts in your mouth. Unaju is a big portion with oily eel which tastes like heaven. Udon is fresh and amazing to chew. But the total price not too pretty lol
author: Monnikka M.

description: Best service & best food ever! Toro, black cod, caterpillar roll, Romeo & Juliet roll, 49er roll, family affair roll, cherry blossom roll, crunchy roll, hamachi toro, salmon, fresh uni , poke salad. Get them all!
author: Julie K.

description:
one of the few places, that has chawanmushi- which I love.
Good sushi, nice restaurant. Miso cod was awesome. This place has a lot of traditional Japanese dishes that are hard to find elsewhere. Their sushi is very fresh and was great.
author: Caroline D.

description:
I've been looking for a place that I'd park myself and my wonderful friend whenever we have a craving for a delectable raw craving. 

I've recently have acquired a taste for fat. Fish fat. So, toro was my ultimate goal that night. 

I know parking is horrible in this area and it took me a few laps around the block until finally the paid parking lot across this place got a free spot. 

Thinking about it now, the valet was sort of racist. He gave the other couple a tip of what to order at the place, and all we got was, have a nice night. 

Anyway, back to Ebisu. I was set to order the lobster tempura and the kobe beef, but mostly my mind was set to ordering every piece of toro they have. 

Guess what, I got distracted. I did order a lot, like the kobe beef sukiyaki. This was sort of off putting. It was a teensy bit sweeter than the usual sukiyaki. 

Then we had some oysters, 5 sashimi (forgot which ones), and 4 diff. toro. The one that I was craving the most, I forgot to order. Oh well.

We did enjoy some of the dishes. Oh, she didn't like the Chawanmushi. The texture was not right somehow.

Anyway, I'll be back and this time, I'll know which ones to order...and a lot of them.

....obviously, I liked the place. I don't have anything bad to say, except that past midway our dinner, everything kind of tasted the same. 

We will order more variety next time.
author: Bryan J.

description:
One of the best sushi I have had. and it's not only sushi, appetizers and the entrees are flavorful and delicious and the waiting staff are helpful.
Food(5/5):
I don't know what to recommend here, everything I ordered here was fresh, tasted good and made with love! if you know what I mean.
Service(5/5):
the restaurant was busy in multiple occasions we came here but these guys just handle it very well
ambiance and cleanliness(5/5)

If you in a sushi mode just save your time and go Ebisu!
author: M W.

description: Can I give them 0 stars? Seriously made a yelp account just because of this bad service. They did not honor the 85 for 100 "special". Go to koo down the street. The owners here don't care about their customers.
author: Trang V.

description:
I would give it 5 stars except that I have been here 5 times and have been overcharged atleast twice.
The second time, they didn't even apologize. The bill at the sushi bar does not provide a breakdown of the pricing so they will either "check a more expensive sushi dish" before it is ringed up, or they will just play dumb and pretend they didn't know the prices in the menu, which is ridiculous. 

It is really irritating that probably thousands of people are overcharged here each month and no one has even noticed.

The sushi chefs are nice and the food is good.
author: Graduate S.

description: Great little sushi bar!  This place had a line so we knew it must be pretty awesome.  Our friends that took us there also highly recommended it.  We waited about 40 min. for a table, but it was well worth it.  The sushi was fresh and our server was very attentive and almost seemed to anticipate everything we needed before we said we did.  I love little sushi places like this and I wish I lived in the area so I could go back often.
author: Mike S.

description: This place use to better. Or maybe my standards have changed. I got the tempura udon and 4 piece hamachi sashimi. The sashimi was good but the pieces of fish were very small. The udon was ok and tempura a good mix of different vegetables. There were shitake mushroom, pumpkin, green bean, broccoli, onion, potato, and a few others. There were a lot of noodles and I boxed half of it to go as I couldn't eat it all. I would only go back if my friends wanted to go there but probably would suggest somewhere cheaper and better quality. I noticed that my friends's rolls were pretty rice heavy, which they confirmed.
author: Annie P.

description:
What a nice sushi place! I walked by it all the time and never really paid attention to it but we were in the area early in the evening so my boyfriend suggested we try it. I hear it's usually packed with a long wait but we were able to snag one of the last tables that evening. I really wanted to try the Kobe beef appetizer since it came highly suggested on the Yelp page but it turned out to be very underwhelming. It comes with 3 different "toppings" to dip into the sauce but I didn't feel that either of them added anything extraordinary to the dish. 

We had 4 rolls - Catepillar, Swamp, Romeo and Juliet, and Louisiana Hot Link. The Louisiana Hot Link was kind of dry but it did taste like sausage so I give them props for that. The other three rolls were great though. Perfect balance of rice and fish and not drenched in sauces and dressings. It all tasted fresh as well. Sushi dinners tend to get heavy and cause food comas but this meal was refreshing and very satisfying.
author: Brittany L.

description: Tried this place for about 3 times. Twice during lunch and once during a very busy Friday night.Their sashimi/nigiri are very fresh but the portion size does not compared to Sushi Sam's. I think Ebisu's prices are about the same as Sushi Sams. I would opt for Sushi Sams since that's the case. Service was great tho.
author: Alyce l.

description:
We were hungry after our visit to the Deyoung and Ebisu was it! The place was almost packed with a large party waiting to be seated. Sunday at 1 pm, we put our name on the list for 2, and got seated within 4-5 minutes as there were a couple small tables open. 

Service was attentive and our water or tea was refilled two times during lunch. We ordered salmon shioyaki lunch, King Crab California and cucumber rolls, and salmon sushi. Everything came out in a timely fashion with rolls coming out first. 

The portion of the salmon shioyaki was generous. There were two cross sections of salmon that was just so delicate and delicious. My friend commented that they use sushi grade salmon for the grilled salmon shioyaki. The salad was much better than a regular salad. It had bits of different greens, cabbage and radish, carrots and tiny sprouts and sesame dressing. The carrots were steamed to be a little more than al dente. Miso soup was not overly salty and delicious with bits of seaweed and tofu. My friend ate her salmon sushi plain with the yummy California & cuke rolls. 

Everything was fresh and delicious! I would definitely come back!
author: K M.

description: Killer $20 dinner deal combo! Will definitely be back!
author: Eucalyptus J.

description:
I will always remember this place as the first place my friend and I ever had our first omakase experience! My friend and I stopped by here on a whim after a long bike ride in the city and we suddenly had a huge craving for sushi. Unfortunately we were about six miles from our cars at the time and couldn't exactly bring our bikes into the restaurant... so we asked if we could put our names down... then promptly raced to our cars in about 20 minutes and made it back to to Ebisu just in time to get our table. Score! :D

This place is great! The atmosphere is very quaint. We were a little bit awkward in our spandex and bike gear, but it was incredibly worth it. It is a bit on the pricey side, but the service is pretty good.

Even though we weren't at the sushi bar, we decided to get the omakase (it's listed on the menu for people who aren't familiar with the concept). Would've preferred to do it at the bar, but at this point we were just happy to have a seat.

The fish was delicious! Absolutely succulent and perfectly prepared. There is a significant difference between fish served here and at other standard sushi places. Now that I've had omakase at other places I can't say this is the best, but it is definitely up there. The fish is much fresher and doesn't have a fishy taste to it. There was a good variety as well, which offset the slightly more expensive cost (a lot of it was stuff we usually wouldn't order ourselves. The scallops were amazing. We even ordered another nigiri plate because we were trying to figure out what we had eaten (the waitress forgot).

Definitely a good experience all around and one of the best sushi places in San Francisco. Would definitely come back all the time if it weren't for the price... Otherwise I'd be super broke! :(
author: Denise C.

description:
After a 45 minute wait where the hostess never once acknowledged us or gave any type of update or even so much as a smile we were seated. 5 of us on a Saturday. I lived the that hood when they first opened and I have to admit they make some pretty wicked rolls. Creative and delicious. Pricey for what it is, but hey.
The terrible service started almost immediately. AFTER we were all seated someone came over picked up the place setting of the person opposite me and moved her with absolutely no grace. Then someone picked up all of my place settings and told me to move while they moved and wiggled tables to squish even more people in. Funny nobody tried that when WE were waiting.  When I order, I would like to think the wait staff at least makes a note of who ordered what. Not at Ebisu. Dish after dish arrived and we were constantly interrupted by "Who ordered the Bento Box?"  Over and over and over and over. Nobody picked up the empty plates and just handed the enormous Bento Box to my friend and left her holding it mid air with no place to put it. When II asked about the Sake and the wait person answered "it's ok"  I just thought ohhh, wow, that was helpful, N-O-T. 
The food is fine...not the best I've had and again I remember the hand rolls as being pretty good, but we didn't have that. The noise level is insane. I mean insane. I could not have a conversation with anyone without yelling. 
As  the owners of successful restaurants say,"Even if the food is fantastic nobody will come back if the service is lacking."  Busy is great , but they need to work on some service issues. 
My last pet peeve is after ridiculous service when a server comes back to the table after everyone has finished and asks if everything is ok. Um, yea, but it wasn't for about 25 minutes.
author: Lanie D.

description:
The first place I can remember having really good sushi. I mean sushi where the fish is über fresh and comes to you via an actual sushi chef, not a floating conveyor belt. Also where I discovered ankimo..that delicacy of monkfish liver marinated in ponzu with grated daikon...
Obviously I've had great sushi since - a lot of it - but Ebisu still ranks up there with the best. Almost wish I still lived in SF...such fond memories of some seriously grub-worthy meals.

So it can get a little pricey and the wait longer than usual to get seated. Hey, if that's the case and people still insist on coming here, they must be doing something right. There's not a whole lot I can tell you that you wouldn't be able to ascertain for yourself after just one trip to this place. That is, IF you appreciate good sushi. 

Wait...there is something after all. Right across the street from Ebisu is a little place called Hotei. Some may think it's a noodle joint but little-known fact (although after these many years it might be a well-known fact by now) is that they are affiliated with Ebisu and you can get Ebisu sushi at Hotei. The line at Hotei is generally not as long, plus they also offer a myriad of donburi, noodle, and rice dishes. 

I still prefer getting my Ebisu straight from the source but it's nice to know there's an alternative should the wait become epic some day and a plan B is in order.
author: Saya V.

description:
I've been wanting to eat here for a long time. Perhaps I had hyped it up for myself but I was a little disappointed. We got here like 5 mins before 6pm and had to wait just a minute for them to clear a table otherwise no line. We had just made it in time to take advantage of the $1 draft beer. The place is definitely on the small side.

I did enjoy my chirashi ($20) and thought it was pretty good though not the best I've had. I'm happy that the rice was seasoned with some added sesame seeds. The chirashi looked small in its box but i still left a little less than half to take home. The bf's tempura dinner looked a little small and sad for $15. We were both disappointed but I may return for some chirashi which is still comes in second for me. I thought the prices were a bit pricey overall.
author: Helen L.

description:
The boyfriend and I came here the other day for a lunch date.  We were seated at the bar, and ordered some sushi from the chef and some seaweed salad and the kobe sashimi from the waiter.  I'm not sure what happened, but the waiter forgot to put our order in so we sat there waiting for a while for the rest of our food.  When he finally realized it he apologized profusely and gave us the seaweed salad on the house....but then when we were rung up another waitress gave us the bill and charged us the salad anway. Totally fine, we didn't care that much, but our original waiter felt awful and gave us a card for a free sake or appetizer next time we were there.

The sushi was delicious.  I'm still learning to like this whole sushi business.  I don't eat seafood, I hate the smell of it, but fresh sushi is somehow fine for me.  I'm learning, and it's places like this that makes it a lot easier for me to welcome sushi into my life.

We'll definitely be back here!
author: Quynh-An P.

description: Some of the best Sushi this side of the dateline. I've been going there since it opened.  I've had sushi all over Japan, Okinawa, in NYC, Morimoto's in Philadelphia, in S Korea, LA, Hawaii, j-town & union  square in SF. Steve Fuji was my original sushi sensei some 25 years ago. Followed by Kenny Chang of the very much missed Solano Sushi. I was at Ebisu just last week & it was as good or better than the more trendy spits in the City.  Great fish, perfect rice, their spot at SFO was one of the few things that made my trios there bearable.  I don't do rolls usually so I can't speak to that for the roll fanatics. I would assume them to be as good as one could get anywhere  in the City.
author: Saul B.

description:
After Sushi Tomi's (Mountain View) sukiyaki, I thought I'd have a difficult place finding sukiyaki that was on par. To my delight, there's Ebisu. Ebisu is what some people call a mediocre sushi place. I honestly don't know. I stay away from raw fish, so I can't speak for the quality of the fish.

Their sukiyaki was $19 and perfect for two. I'm Korean and I really enjoy my soups/stews with lots of rice, so if you do as well order an extra (or two) bowl of rice / person. The broth is light but hearty, sweet but savory. I ordered the beef sukiyaki and there was a decent portion of beef, vegetables and noodles. Finish off your meal with their mochi ($6 for 3 pieces of mochi). My friend ordered sashimi and some rolls. Total for the meal came out to be $80. Not too shabby!

Ebisu gets crowded, their dining area is small and intimate. Get ready to be seated close to your fellow diners. Wait time ranges from about 20-40 minutes depending on the day & time you go. 

Parking: If you must drive over, look for parking on Judah rather than on Irving.
author: Rosa L.

description: We got here near closing time and the place was still packed!  We were amazed on how upscale the place looked with the sharp angles of the wood paneling on the walls and the roof.  Typically this place has tables of 2 or 4 so we were lucky we got seated in a quick amount of time since we had a party of 5.  We ordered a Chirashi, Romeo and Juilet, 49er, Boston, and Hot Link.  I was so sad that the Omakasi option was not available so I had to go with the Chirashi option instead.  My party was mainly into the rolls and I was more a nigiri kind of guy.  The whole party raved on the tastes of almost all the items.  People were 'meh' on the 49er since the lemon overpowers the whole dish.  The chirashi was on the smaller and less variety than what I normally get.  But the quality of the fish was still there.  I actually liked their hot tea for some reason.  It really hit the spot and cleansed the palate pretty well.  They also have a deep sake menu that I was tempted to try.  Service was OK.  They were pretty busy closing up that we had to wave them down a few times to get stuff done.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Ebisu just got much better. Tonight we tried the Swamp Roll, the 49er Roll, the Tempura Lobster, the Miso w/ Clams, and the Seaweed Salad. Everything was super amazing. Miso with Clams tastes way better than normal miso soup, omgosh yummy! Both of our rolls had really good flavor combos...apparently the shiso helped with that? 
The waiters are incredibly accommodating and friendly. Especially our waiter who was smokin' hot and a sweetheart. 
By far one of my favorite little sushi joints in the Sunset.
author: Sonya D.

description:
This place is tits-to-face crowded. Be prepared to wait 45+ minutes if you arrive at 7PM for dinner. You're going to be sitting in ~close quarters, don't be surprised if your arm ends up in someone's Udon. Juss sayin. 

First of all, it's rare to find a sushi joint with (miscellaneous fish) belly, but this place had a few- including my all time fave Yellowtail belly. Holy Toledo! I wish all fish melted in my mouth like this. And Butterfish! God. For the freshness of the fish, I opted for a sashimi only meal. This was a month ago, and I'm still talking about it.
author: Gaggan B.

description: Tasty food! The fish was very fresh. We went there before the lunch time to avoid the crowd. There was a line after we were seated. I want to assure you that the food will be well worth the wait.
author: Helen Y.

description:
WOAH. This place is WAAAAAY better than Kiki's!!  Their menu is incredible.  You could sit there all day ordering sushi and not have the same roll twice.  And you can really tell that they use the best fish available.  I loved the atmosphere- it was really loud and fun and everyone was drinking- love it.  The only thing I ordered and didn't like was the kobe beef roll. It was weird. 

It's a little pricey, but well worth it.  Mmm. I'm getting hungry just thinking about it.
author: Nina B.

description: Melt in your mouth sashimi  makes it seem like a short trip to Japan without the airfare. Be prepared to wait during peak dinner hours as this place is a favorite to many locals. The environment can get a little sound meter to it's peak. Close corridors to your neighboring diners so don't spill the beans to something you don't want others to hear. If you opt for something fresher, there is daily service from SFO to Japan.
author: James C.

description:
I have been coming to Ebisu since the 80's, and it's a great place to take people from out of town or another country, especially people that have never tried sushi. I have made several new sushi fans, because this restaurant is so reliable for providing a good experience. The owners come over and say hello, they are really nice people. The fish is always fresh, and the presentation of the dishes very good. 

Last night I took my husband and family here for the first time since the remodel. The restaurant looks really nice. However, we ordered some of our favorite rolls, and noticed they are not the same as before. For example, the spider roll used to be an artistic masterpiece, that they actually made to look like a hairy spider! There were six pieces, the claws of the soft shell crab were the spider legs, and the body had green daikon sprouts for "hair". Last night, we thought there was more batter than crab and it was just four pieces all in a row. Inside out rolls did not have much tobiko on the outside, and I thought the California roll was just middle of the road. 

I plan to keep coming, because I love the proximity to GG Park.
author: Janette R.

description: I went to Ebisu based off of yelp reviews and I have to say I it was excellent.  I had sat at the sushi bar which I would highly recommend.  The chef was very friendly and described different offerings that they had on the chalk board tonight.  He also was sure to follow up and make sure I was enjoying my sushi and asked if there was anything esle I wanted,  The staff in general were very friendly.  I was by myself but I think this would be a great place to go with a group and order many items to share.  I will definitely return, by myself, for takeout, or with a group.
author: Ian K.

description:
The experience I had at the newly re-modeled Ebisu was out of this world.

First, even amongst the busy, crowded restaurant the service was attentive and quite on point.  Our server was always checking up and when she wasn't around other waiters were quick to help us with our needs.

I had gone here once with my brother and it was pretty good, but the food seemed exceptional Saturday.  I love when the sushi rice is firm but soft and not too sweet and falls apart just a little bit.  The 49er roll's salmon was so fresh, it tasted like butter and the lemon just topped it off.  The spicy tuna was also very flavorful, not just spicy.

My guy got the chicken katsu salad which he devoured and I got to taste, which tasted light and fresh, which is rare since you are eating fried chicken.  But the batter of the chicken was panko-light and not greasy and the actual chicken was moist!  He also ordered a blossom roll which had salmon and its roe, and it looked so pretty.  And the topper was the one lamb-chop.  It was grilled perfectly, so that the meat was medium rare and also seasoned well.

Our friend also enjoyed very much her rolls which I didn't taste but knew was good since we all ate every stray rice.  YUM-O!

I'm glad it popped into my head to go there Saturday night and that the wait for a table was pretty quick.  I got lots of props from my dining partners that night!  SCORE!
author: Susan C.

description:
Here is a sushi place where you'll want to bring a wad of cash or a credit card with a bill just paid, because the menu is extensive and the chefs' special creations are aplenty, and plenty creative. And, if you're a sushi-lover, all of it looks good! Luckily, everything my boyfriend and I had there tasted as incredible as it looked. Some of the best sushi I've had anywhere, even in this city. The rolls were beautiful, vibrant with color and absolutely delicious. The nigiri was just as great, and the selection is better than most I've seen. Of course, we ended up sticking to our usuals of saba, unagi and hamachi, which were phenomenally buoyant on the tongue, but it is nice to know that we could go for something uncommonly found and feel secure that it'd be delicious. 

And with some warm sake and a couple large Asahi Blacks, any meal of raw fish is elevated to the level of being unforgettable. My particular outing here was as a birthday celebration (a treat sponsored by my generous boyfriend), and it was simply wonderful. This is certainly helped by the attentive and lively staff, the talented sushi chefs, and the charming, curious, wood interior.
author: Jake m.

description: Been here on a few occasions over the years since I'm a local to the inner sunset. It hasn't changed much. To put it in a nutshell: fresh fish, decent cooked food. It's on the pricier side, so if you want cheap, walk down the block to Kiki's. Go wild on their sushi bar items like their variety of toros. The rolls are pretty generic but that doesn't mean they aren't tasty and beautifully crafted. I really love their kushiyaki! The bacon-wrapped scallops and the kobe beef were absolutely the bee's knees. They were the bomb. Savory beyond belief. Sigh... As for the entrees, the sukiyaki meat was a bit overcooked at the chicken nanban wasn't all that thrilling. Nevertheless, if you really want to appreciate this restaurant, you might want to come with friends that love raw fish and isn't afraid to spend a lot on quality fish.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Came here with a friend after work around 6:30. There were only tow of us so we were able to get seated right away..and at the bar. 

This place is fantastic!! Service was great and rolls are delicious, very unique. I forgot which rolls we had but the fish was fresh and the chefs are a delight. The atmosphere is great and feels like this restaurant should be downtown somewhere, very modern looking with nice lighting. 

 It gets packed very quickly so try for an earlier dinner otherwise you will wait 30 min. 
Sake was good too!
author: Lana K.

description: The sushi is so fresh,  it started to swim off of my plate. Julio is the best..only his name is spanish.
author: J.P. H.

description: So, so SO incredibly delicious. Had the $25 sashimi plate, 49er, Romeo and Juliet, and rainbow roll and topped it off with the green tea creme brûlée. it was all-around perfect. Go there.
author: Jo Marie T.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE this place. I've been going here for years and the sushi cannot be beat. Never had a bad experience. The owners are really cute and remember my name, which is impressive given that I'm a twin.
Great service, fabulous and fresh sushi and I like the new interior. Parking is hard, but muni is close and  if you live around here it's nice to walk.
Happy hour beer specials are really nice.
Run don't walk.
author: Ms S.

description:
First sushi dinner I've had since moving to SF, and it was definitely a great one. 

The special XXX roll of the day had some great raw fish and fried japanese pumpkin, really enjoyable. It was a little steap price-wise at $15, but super tasty. The spicy tuna, which had a different name (sorry can't remember!) was also great.

A stand-out - and I know this is strange to ever even consider calling a stand-out - was the miso soup. Honestly one of the best I've ever tried. Oh and the individual sushi pieces were to-DIE-for.

Will 100% return soon!
author: Nicole H.

description: First time here.  Staff were very nice.  Food was great; fishes were fresh.  Place is a little cramped.  Parking was hard.  Uni was a little overpriced.  Overall, decent sushi place.
author: Wendy T.

description:
I am in search of the "best" sushi restaurant in SF.  Yeah I know there is no true "best" restaurant since taste is all subjective but at least according to my taste buds.  This place is good but I wasn't wowed.  

They had life fresh uni which I ordered but it had a weird taste.  I've had fresh uni at Shimo's and other restaurants before and it doesn't have that weird chemical taste.  I also ordered their sof shell shrimp tempura hand roll.  I've never had or heard of soft shell shrimp so decided to try it.  It was just like tempura shrimp but the shrimp was fresh and the shell was fairly soft.  I also ordered salmon toro, hamachi and butter fish.  All were good but nothing special.  

My wife ordered their tempura udon.  The udon was good but the tempura battered needed some work.  It wasn't crispy enough and was a bit mushy.  

The service was decent.  They are certainly very busy so the wait staff is always on the move.  They at least came back to check on us and refilled our water twice.  

I probably would come back but like I said it's nothing different than most places like sushi puzzle, shimos, tekka, etc.
author: Michael T.

description:
This place SUCKS.  It saddens me there are people out there that actually enjoy this place. They need to branch out and try some real sushi.
The Sushi I had all taste the same like it was all stored in the same piece container and instead of having its own unique taste, it all joined in for one blah taste.
For the first time ever we stopped eating it and left, I am not going to risk the chance of food poisoning at this dump. 
The sushi has to come from a sewage treatment plant.
The place is awful and for anyone to actually enjoy it...NO COMMENT
author: Kenn P.

description:
Instructions for a successful Ebisu visit:

-  arrive early to avoid long wait times
- sit at the bar
- order sashimi: most reliable fish IMO are hamachi, albacore, escolar
- if you are willing to spend a little more, order the oyster barnaby: oyster on half shell w/quail egg, uni and the big balls of salmon roe... mouth orgasm there
- request the sushi chef to make you a roll w/items you desire (I picked hamachi, escolar, and avo and Isa whipped up a delicious-ass roll!)
- don't order the standard rolls because it will be nothing what you expect

No issues w/service as it is usually excellent.  Sushi chefs are flexible and know what the hell they are doing.
author: Michelle W.

description: I've been here once or twice before the remodel. Service was prompt as soon as you got seated. We started off with the Edamame Trio and Veggie Tempura. The edamame trio was great, I loved the three different flavors. We also ordered the 49er, Dexter Carter, QP and Spider Roll. The sushi was fresh and delicious. I loved the lemon on the 49er and Dexter Carter.
author: Adelina W.

description:
After dancing it up and having a blast at the Cal Academy of Science Nightlife (http://www.yelp.com/biz/california-academy-of-sciences-nightlife-san-francisco#hrid:-f3oALWLjE6_nlLXKdA59A/src:self), me, the birthday girl and my other girl were craving sushi after looking at all the fishes in the aquarium. 

We sat immediately and were served insanely quick. The best part is that the sushi bar already prepares a plate of ginger and wasabi for the patron and a small plate of edamame. I ordered the Crunchy Roll which was delicious! Sucks that I had to fill up on cheese and bread beforehand. The food was grubbin', the service was good and I was in good company. 

I'll definitely be back.
author: Jamie L.

description:
Poor service. Pretentious place. Too bad the chef got hurt and the other chef threw a fit as soon as he saw us when we went to try out Tuesdays special at Ebisu. 

My wife still wants to go back there for their special so this rating might change in the future. For now, Ebisu gets 1 star
author: Vimal T.

description:
I love sushi and Ebisu might be one of my new favorites! Ebisu has a surprisingly modern interior for a restaurant in the Sunset, the dim lights and ambience makes it a great date spot but the real reason to try this place is for its sushi. The sushi is fresh, you can taste it in every bite. The sashimi is cool, smooth, and melty, the rice a perfect pillow for the fish. 

What we ate:
1. Lobster tempura: how unique! You get a decent amount of lobster, and it tastes great with the wasabi mayo dip.
2. Kakuni: braised pork belly with satsuma puree and ginger glaze. this dish is sweet/salty and the meat is so tender it cuts into shreds. yum.
3. Crunchy roll: good
4. Double hamachi roll: hamachi was so good, and 2x the amount on the outside and inside, double wow
5. Large Sapporo, wish we'd known about the HH deal

Everything was excellent, the service was good, the sushi chefs were friendly = a great neighborly food experience! Next time I want to come back and order a chirashi....
author: Nicole L.

description:
If I was grading on the food alone, we are talking 5 stars here. The tobiko ... so crisp and flavorful. One little pop carried the full force of the sea with it. The Bonito Tataki, a true favorite of mine, was the best I've had anywhere. 

On the downside, no reservations, and it is a bit of a hassle to get and stay seated. Took about 1/2 hr to get 2 seats on a Friday at 8pm, not surprising. Ended up at the bar, which I highly recommend, as our sushi chef made great off-the-menu recommendations. However, us and another couple were asked to "scoot down" during our meal so they could shuffle seats at the bar. Not the end of the world, but not 5 star treatment.

The menu is a bit unwieldy, with way too many items. I recommend picking a few things you know and love, and then letting the chefs take control. Everything we ordered off the specials menu was outstanding. When we requested the XXX roll, our chef went off the menu, I noticed the same things going on next to us, with the chefs interacting with the customer and coming up with a tailored creation. The Ohitashi Duo was really yummy and unique, if you want some veggies involved.

The prices are pretty standard for SF Sushi joints. We blew about $100 for 2 people with 3 beers each and a belly packing meal. They have a holiday deal going on, where you can get a $100 gift card for $90. Probably a good investment before you go.
author: Scott B.

description:
Small and always a wait during dinner but the service is great as staffs are very attentive and quick at getting extras (ginger & wasabi) when asked. Since it's a small restaurant, it is pretty noisy so if you are looking for an intimate dinner, you will not find it here, however, if you want great sushi and bento boxes, this is the place. 
My bf and I had salmon toro, hamachi toro, lobster dynamite, 49er roll, caterpillar roll and a bento box (beef teriyaki, salmon teriyaki, tempura) and everything was amazing. I especially loved the salmon toro because it was buttery goodness! Also loved that they asked how you would like your beef cooked so when I asked for medium, it came out medium and was tender and pink inside. There are a lot of other japanese restaurants that are cheaper but quality is not there. I definitely think the prices at ebisu are fairly reasonable for the quality.
Dinner cost us $77.76 w/o gratuity and the both of us left with a full and happy tummy.
author: Meuy S.

description:
Best sushi I've ever had.  Ever.

I saw this place mentioned on a Burt Wolf travel show on SF.  But I had no idea how good it would really be.

I had a great spider roll and some things that I'd never had before like toro and salmon belly.  Just melt in your mouth.  I'm getting hungry for sushi just writing about it.  Crazy good.  

Cost was my only holdback.

I'll just have to go the next time I'm in SF.
author: Marc W.

description:
Ebisu may be my new go-to sushi place in the city. A couple nights before, I'd had some mediocre sushi from Jimisan across the street, and that unsatisfying experience set off a craving for some legitimate, good sushi. I turn to Yelp for advice, and this is one time that it did not fail me.

We ordered three things: the Live Scallop special, the Crunchy Roll, and the Family Affair Roll. The Live Scallop came out to be two dishes, with the more tender flesh served as sashimi and the more toothsome muscle as strips of tempura complemented very nicely with scallion tempura slivers. Delicious. The scallop sashimi was so fresh and sweet, and the presentation was beautiful. The shell was deftly cut open with a soy/green onion dipping sauce pooled into one half, while the other half held the sashimi.

Both rolls were excellent. The Crunchy Roll was just right, with nice texture from the tempura flakes. The Family Affair was amazing, with the albacore on top melting into my mouth, and the spicy aioli melding with the spicy tobiko perfectly. 

The service was very attentive; our waitress was enthusiastic and patient in explaining the specials, and our hot tea (which was great, by the way) was continuously refilled. The place is small and can get noisy, but really, it's not that bad at all.

I highly recommend this place for the freshness and quality. I'm really pleased to have found such a gem in the Inner Sunset, and will definitely be back soon to try the other things on their menu!
author: Stacy S.

description: I can't stop thinking about the crunch roll...it was so good w/the soy paper wrapping, which I had never experienced before. I got there pretty close to opening and was seated right away. The tables filled up quick so make sure you get there early and sign up or you'll probably end up waiting 45 min or so. The food took a little while to come out, but they brought out each roll as it was made so it kept us going. I didn't get a chance to try anything besides a few rolls, I can't wait to go back for more!
author: Vaishali S.

description: I loved this place. Everything I had was really good except for a couple of the sushi rolls. The chicken katsu and sukiyaki were amazing. It's a little small place but it's worth the drive and wait.
author: Collin W.

description: Very good XXX roll + rainbow roll. Chef's are a lot of fun! I recommend sitting at the sushi bar.
author: Charles Z.

description: The first thing we ordered was the kobe sashimi - 12 thin slices of melt-in-your-mouth kobe beef rolls with sides of radishes prepared three ways and garlic soy for dipping. I've waited so long to try raw beef. What a treat! We also had the Omakase (Chef's selection of sashimi), followed by Double Hamachi, Family Affair, Rainbow, and the Chef's Special (Albacore, Salmon, Mango). Everything was great last night. Among the sushi rolls, my favorites were the Chef's Special and the Double Hamachi. The most amazing part of the meal was by far the sashimi platter. The fish is so incredibly fresh it makes you not want to eat sashimi from anywhere else anymore. The sashimi platter had me at the first piece (it was hamachi). The hamachi just melted in my mouth. I'm a regular sushi consumer, and Ebisu is probably the best I've had.
author: Jenny C.

description:
I love Sushi very much! After have read all the reviews, I believe Ebisu should be a right spot for Sushi fans like me. My husband and I went to Ebisu for a lunch on Saturday. Fortunately, we didn't need to wait for a table. The restaurant is well decorated in a very Japanese style. I like the walls covered with woods. The light inside is dim, so it creates a kind of romantic atmosphere.  The waiter there was very nice, polite and attentive.  One of the two ladies was nice as well. She continuously checked our table and added tea for us. However, the other lady is not that warm. She was blunt when she picked up the empty plates and asked us if we needed anything else when we finished the meal. 

We ordered three rolls: 49er rolls ($10), Rock n Roll ($9), Crunchy roll ($10) and a Chicken Teriyaki Bento Box ($15). 49er Roll and Rock n Roll were good but the portion was small.  I was very disappointed on the Crunchy Roll I ordered because the flavor was totally off.  It seemed like that some of ingredients were not fresh. It had a taste like the peanuts went to bad. I did asked the waiter what was the green wrapping sheet outside of the sushi and I have been told that was soybean paper. I guess that strange flavor might be from the soybean paper. We definitely wouldn't order it again when we come back next time. The chicken teriyaki bento box was pretty good. The presentation was nice and you could have many items including miso soup, 2 shrimp tempura, a few pieces of vegetable tempura, 4 or 5 pieces of sushi, salad, sea weed, spinach(?), rice, and chicken teriyaki. I have to mention that chicken teriyaki was very tender and favorable. This lunch bento box could be a highlight of the entire meal.   

I think we will come back. Hopefully, I can give five stars next time.
author: Wendy W.

description: Fave sushi bar in San Francisco.  There is usually a wait but well worth it.
author: Rachael V.

description:
I come to Ebisu pretty often since it's in my neighborhood. It's not my favorite spot in the city but it's conveniently located for me. Everytime I go there, I order the dinosaur feet. They give you a pinch of sea salt along with it which i LOVE. The "Two balls no strike" is amazing, especially if you love spicy tuna. I always wondered how they wrap the spicy tuna in the avocado....

Their fish is always fresh, I only wish they had a bigger roll selection ! -1 star because their service isn't always on point. Sometimes they're pretty attentive, other times they're not. It irks me when someone that got seated way after me gets served before me. 

Overall its a place worth visiting.
author: Tammie P.

description:
This is the first place to introduce me to the wonderful delicacy that is SUSHI!
The fish is fresh, the atmosphere is "cool," the food, overall, is above average!

I want to LIKE/LOVE this place, BUT I am being nice when I say my most recent visit was "A-OK"

- Our server (Ken) was really good, BUT he needs a better "supporting cast"
-$50 Omakase: Fish was exceptional, BUT it took 40+ minutes to get to the table
- Long wait means more food: 15 minute wait to get menu
- Assorted tempura plate: REALLY GOOD, BUT it wasn't ours
- Blue Fin Toro: Looked really good, BUT also not ours
- Our "Behind the Green Door" roll: Looked good, BUT that went to another table

Ken had to explain to us that they made ANOTHER mistake and the kitchen was closed so they would have to make the (Behind the Green Door) roll with something other than Shrimp Tempura.

Let me be clear, our server (Ken) was awesome. He was really nice and he did everything he could to make this a pleasant experience for us. He also covered the cost of the tempura that we ate.

With that said, an "A-OK" rating is only because I am willing to give this place another chance.

Finally, I noticed they had a "Help Wanted" sign outside... I concur.
author: Menandro M.

description:
The food is excellent here.  The style is somewhat comparable to Tantos down in San Jose and less like a traditional Japanese restaurant.

I think the best things they do here are their fried foods and fritters.  Although I am not usually a fan of fried things, they do it like a good Japanese place should be able to do it: light, delicate, and not too oily to the touch.  Really liked it here.

Love the happy hour here.  Best time to go.
author: Mark M.

description:
I was introduced to this place as San Francisco's best sushi by our taxi driver.   Let me just tell you, that our taxi driver needs to change his profession ASAP into a connoisseur.  It was amazingly fresh and given to us amazingly fast.  We did have to wait about 45 minutes to be seated, but it was well worth the wait.  
Definitely sit by the sushi bar.  The chefs are hilarious and so friendly.   The price was quite decent.
author: Niyera D.

description:
The sashimi is amazing. My friends and I walked in not long after 5PM, maybe ~5:30PM and the place was almost empty. But as we were sitting and chilling, the place quickly began to get packed. We sat in the corner, so I didn't really notice people walking in or out. But when I lifted my head, DANG, there were hella people. A friend had previously been there before, so she was telling us about the restaurant. We ordered the $200 chef special, and it was totally worth it. Not only was it beautifully arranged, but it tasted like... heaven? They also fried the fish and shrimp when we were done.

They don't hurry people at all, they let you sit and chat and do whatever you want. They're very patient and polite. The place was really dark. It doesn't look like it in the pictures, but when you're in there, it's really dark. The interior is beautifully decorated though.
author: Stacy C.

description: Fantastic sushi.  Love the sashimi, a generous portion of super fresh and delicious fish, great for sharing, 8 pieces per order -- I've had the tuna, salmon, yellowtail, butterfish, fluke, all delicious.  Also great agedashi tofu and assorted fancy rolls.  Also great for takeout!
author: M D.

description:
the wait was ridiculous on a friday night! but me and my bff were still tipsy from happy hour (hehe) so the wait didn't seem that long to us.

i don't remember exactly what we ordered but what i do remember was that it was pretty good!  the steamed mussels. ughhhhhh these were good.  

we also had some raw sushi (salmon and something else) I am not a big fan of raw fish but i didn't cringe when i ate it so that's a good thing! and i ate more than one piece! that's a milestone for me lol

the bf and I had uni sushi (a little fishy but to be fair the first time i had uni it was super fresh right out of the shell so my expectations are high)

a couple of cooked rolls - spider and dragon yumm

raw shrimp - this one was yucky! it had a weird aftertaste and it was super gooey
author: JUDY L.

description:
It's like being in Japan in terms of atmosphere. The plates are amazing, here we see that food is seen as an art.
Everyone is very nice and friendly excepted ONE waitress which was particularly unpleasant and absolutely not smiling. It really spoiled our experience. It makes you wonder why she works in a restaurant in connection with people.
I feel sorry for the other who work hard over there...
author: Cel N.

description:
"Im not really hungry, but i can always get Ebisu"

My sushi baseline. Every other sushi place can be worse, as good as, or better than Ebisu. So far there have been a few "as good as" (Zushi Puzzle on lombard being one) places, but no "better than", and a ton "worse than"s to various degree of worse.
Awesome food. Salmon and Tuna nigiri are staples of sushi (like Margherita pizza for pizza), and when you try them at ebisu you will see the superbness im talking about. Sometimes there's a wait but its always worth it. Sitting at the bar is way more fun then sitting at the table. But either way the freshness of fish and quality of preparation is superb :)
Another thing - if you're adventurous - and they have fresh uni - definitely give it a try.
author: Oleg H.

description:
The food was really good. The chefs were really creative. The service was great although there is a long wait to be seated. 

Little far from home but will be back if have the chance :)
author: Vickie Z.

description: I'm very picky about which Japanese restaurants I return to, and this is one of them! Yay :) Although I only come here once in a while because dining here every night would definitely break the bank, and I'd have no monies to function like a proper human being. My favorite dish here is the hamachi kama. Their sushi rolls are also delicious. I enjoy sitting at the sushi bar and watching the chefs prepare the rolls. The only problem is when I start to run out of space because I can't eat faster than the food comes out. This restaurant is also great for date nights! Just make sure the Mr pays... Cuz like I said, it ain't cheap! ;)
author: Lily Z.

description:
Recently renovated for their beautiful interior! 

AMAZING SUSHI. recommendations:

raw oysters.

Double Hamachi Roll.  

Swamp Roll.

SEAFOOD SALAD! (mix of wakame salad, and different cubes of salmon, tuna, albacore, clam, hamachi, and dakion coated in a sweet miso sauce)

Potato Bug.

Cherry Blossom. 

BOMB.COM. See you there :)
author: Lauren Y.

description: Been here a few times, and always a pleasant experience. Love they have live sea urchins. We got to see the urchin before they prepare it behind the sushi bar. One of my go-to whenever I am in town and have time.
author: Stella W.

description:
WOOHOO! AS GOOD AS IT GETS! 

I've found it. best sushi restaurant in san francisco. actually it may be my all time favorite sushi restaurant. ever. 

I came here with my family last night to throw an intimate surprise birthday dinner (party of 5 -- it's a small space) for my mom and it went perfectly! 

The service was phenomenal! From the moment we sat down our server went above and beyond in making sure the dinner went off without a hitch and even helped us with the cake we brought (storing, putting candles on it, bringing it out after we finished eating, then plating the cake!). 

We mainly had sushi rolls and each roll was basically perfect. the fish was absolutely melt in your mouth heavenly and the perfect balance of fish, rice, & toppings (i hate it when they drench your sushi with too much sauce... and at ebisu, they really let the fish shine w/ only just enough sauce to complement). 

what we had: 
# 49er -- Salmon, Lemon, Avocado, Tobiko and Shiso
# Family Affair  -- Tuna, Avocado, Albacore, Maui Onions, Negi, Tobiko and Spicy Aioli (we got 2 of these b/c it was soooooo good!!)
# Dragon -- Unagi, Kanikama, Avocado, Tenpura Shrimp and Cucumber
# Chef's Special -- tuna, albacore, & mangos 
# Spicy tuna roll

and it's so nice inside!! I love it, you step in and it's a great surprise :) love it.. 

Seriously, can't wait to come back!!! 

5/5 stars!
author: Jo C.

description:
I must be one of the lucky ones, but after a last minute change in plans to grab dinner in the Inner Sunset, our group found ourselves at Ebisu. We were quickly seated, and took in the cool menu behind the sushi bar, where most of the omakase, also known as chefs whimsy, are located. A few of us ordered the various omakase, and others ordered rolls. Everything was masterfully put together, with a great attention to detail. I particularly liked the baby squid that came with our seafood, and the kobe sashimi was also quite nice.

From start to end, the service was perfect, and the food was better. If you're in the neighborhood, or not, stop by Ebisu for a great meal with friends and family.
author: David M.

description:
Ebisu was one of my favorites back in the day.  They went through some remodeling a few years back, and for some reason we kind of...forgot about this place.

Now I'm back and I love it more than ever!!!

Family Affair - Tuna, Avocado, Albacore, Maui Onions, Negi, Tobiko and Spicy Aioli

Behind the Green Door - Seared Skipjack, Shrimp Tenpura, Maui Onions, Tobiko, Scallion and Creamy Aioli

Crunchy - House Poke, Avocado, Tempura Crumbs and Soy Bean Paper
(I love Soy paper rolls in general, so if you do too, this one is a must)

Fresh Uni - (yes, it's still moving on the plate)!

The Hamachi/Salmon/Bluefin Toro are all super fresh and well worth it!

I'm so glad i found you again Ebisu!
author: Anthony L.

description: My family loves this place! First off, expect to wait for at least 30 minutes if you are more than 2 in your party - they don't take reservations and after 6pm it tends to be packed. That said, my favorite dishes are the specialty rolls such as the Family Affair, 49 Roll and Behind the Green Door - all incredibly imaginative and delicious! The beef Sukiyaki is unbelievable - huge iron skillet filled with so many ingredients I lose count, and it's also a wonderful dish to share. The teriyaki and katsu dishes are also top notch - plentiful portions with a generous helping of salad and roasted vegetables including carrots, potatoes and broccolini, something I wouldn't have imagined at a Japanese restaurant. Feels more like an Italian presentation on the plate, but I find the veggies a wonderful contrast. If you love batter-fried anything, try the Chicken Nanban; the accompanying sauce is creamy and wonderful, similar to tartar sauce. Also love the Kobe beef kushiyaki; yes the skewers are small, but the meat is tender and sprinkled with sesame seeds. We also love the touch of the salmon row on the California rolls - what a crunchy and delicious extra treat. The servers are very efficient and friendly - Justina is our absolute favorite! So happy to have another great place in our neighborhood...we are officially "regulars" and love to come here with friends.
author: Rebeca M.

description:
Sushi is one of those foods that I can eat all the time.  On a quest to fill my stomach with food, my dining buddy and I decided to head to Ebisu.  We parked, and started walking down 9th....half way down the block we noticed we went too far, but where was Ebisu???  Apparently they're remodeling, and are now combined with Hotei across the street.  

I've been to Hotei a few times for their ramen, so now I wanted to try Ebisu's sushi.  I like the menu because they actually have pictures of their rolls, so I can see what I'm ordering.  We ordered the Arch Deluxe, QP roll( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/4Mm42zhUeBjXyu9ixOXC0A/l ), 49er roll, Double Hamachi Roll( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/3Z-7na4vp4ih-77jCsm4Bg/l ), and some potstickers( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/XSbuN3J0uc8b0DZ2QasL8w/l ).  

Unfortunately, the food didn't taste as good as it looked in the pictures.  The Arch Deluxe and QP rolls were the only ones that I thought were decent.  The other two just seemed too mushy.  Nothing really stood out to make me want to come back.  And the potstickers were burnt on the bottoms, and the skins were too thin so they'd break apart easily.  I've definitely had better.

Looking at Yelp, I see alot of good reviews, so maybe I just went on an off night. I'll be back for Hotei's ramen, but I don' t know if I want to risk getting Ebisu's meh sushi again.
author: Patra I.

description: SO tasty! Definitely expensive, and when the sashimi combo says for 1-2 people.. don't believe it. It's really just appetizer sized. I'd come back.
author: Wendy C.

description:
My cousin took us here after we labored for hours helping him move.  Yes, my hours of labor is only worth one meal.  That's what friends and family are for, apparently.

That, and maybe he helped me move like four times and this was my first time returning the favor.  But, I digress.

Post-moving workout, Ebisu tasted delicious.  We wanted to go to Koo but it was too busy so we gave this place a try.  Maybe I felt bad because I wasn't paying, but the bill was higher than I expected.  Given the quality of the sushi though, I thought it was fair.

I would come back if I was in the area.
author: Erika C.

description:
Came here on a Friday night around 8pm. The lady taking the names down said the wait would be around 45 minutes but we decided to stay anyways. It actually turned out like two parties from the list left which made the wait shorter. We were seated around 20 minutes. The restaurant is different from other Japanese restaurants that I usually go to. They have a lot of fancy dishes that are reasonably priced. 

The menu is not like your typical Japanese restaurants menu. Let me just say that the service was GREAT. The waitress named ANITA I believe was really helpful and answered any questions we had about the different dishes on the menu. She also told us about the specials of the night. She was very informative on some of the dishes we weren't sure about. She also checked on us time to time to make sure we were enjoying our meal and to see if we needed anything. GREAT customer service!

This is what we ordered: 

Kakuni  -Soy braised pork belly with satsuma imo puree and ginger soy demi glace 

Salmon Shioyaki -Yuzu soy marinated with teriyaki glaze

Deluxe  sushi -Tuna, clam, freshwater eel, yellowtail tuna, scallop, salmon, salmon roe and sea urchin nigiri sushi with king california maki

Poke Roll  - Chopped albacore tuna seasoned with soy sauce, Japanese seven spices and onion

The kakuni was delicious. It was cooked perfectly. The sauce was fingerlickin good. There was a good amount of fat and meat. It tasted like baby back ribs to me without the bone. Salmon shioyaki was a good deal. The marinate definitely gave the fish that great flavor. And it was actual Salmon pieces. Not a fillet like at other restaurants. And it came with two big pieces. It was accompanied with sauteed pieces of really tender eggplant slices. Mmmm. The poke roll was alright. I wanted a spicy tuna roll but they don't carry it. The waitress suggested the poke roll instead. It wasn't even spicy so I would pass on this next time. The deluxe sushi came with fresh pieces of fish and california roll made with REAL CRAB. 

This was a great experience and look forward to coming here again. Most likely not during a busy day tho.
author: Fran N.

description:
Actually 4.5.  Great food and service with reasonable prices. Surprised given how close it was to the touristy Golden Gate Park but maybe this neighborhood restaurant was typical of the quality and value outside of the Union Square touristy area.
Sushi was fresh and tasty.  Spider roll was delicious.  Terriyaki chicken was nicely done and huge portion.  
Waitress dealt with allergies very well. Felt pretty confident that we were receiving correct information to make our ordering decisions.
Will be back if ever in the neighborhood.
author: B W.

description: THE BEST SUSHI EVER!!!! INCREDIBLE!You could close your eyes and point to anything on the menu and will not be disappointed!  We've been coming here for about 6 years now and it always the same, - great experience and delicious fish every time! Would recommend - seafood salad, 29 roll, QP roll , double Hamachi roll, fresh Uni. We drive from Santa Clara on a regular basis, so its definitely worth it, trust me! :)))
author: Kateryna K.

description:
What's funny is that even though the menu is THE EXACT SAME as Hotei across the street, Ebisu has a better rating. It's the same food people! Witness the power of persuasion of fancy decor.

Essentially both are OK Japanese fair. Nothing special. I've been dragged here a few times and never left very satisfied.  The udon broth was missing something.  The sushi is not nearly as good as Koo or a few others in the neighborhood.  Not the best choice even in Inner Sunset.
author: Zack S.

description: Everything I thought it would be and more! It's worth the wait and I was not disappointed. Probably some of the best sushi I have ever had. They sat us at the sushi bar with my toddler son. Thank goodness he might the only toddler in the USA who prefers an eel avocado roll to chicken nuggets. PHEW. I was nervous it would be insulting to the sushi chef to have a toddler sit there but I think he was actually shocked about him eating an entire real fish maki. Anyways, we tried a bunch of rolls and loved everyone. I would especially recommend the scallop. Amazing. The only thing that wasn't thrilling was the clam on daily special sushi we ordered. Also, try the bacon wrapped scallops from the hot items menu.  I would come here frequently if I  Iived nearby.  After eating here, it made me sad to go back to second rate Chicago area sushi.
author: Erin B.

description:
Absolutely awesome sushi. Definitely in my top 3 places in the city to get some. After it's reopening, the decor has become quite beautiful and the whole atmosphere has just really shifted.

One of my favorite things about Ebisu is that you can order item after item and they won't rush you or ask you to order all at once; when I go out for sushi I like to try a lot of different things and mix it up. This is encouraged here. I constantly have the feeling of being in a very fancy and well to do sushi restaurant without feeling the pressures of price or formality.

Everyone is very friendly and there are some real sushi delicacies on the  menu. You can have any traditional dish while also getting to try more experimental rolls that are often catered to the Bay Area or SF specifically.
author: India K.

description:
I hate to write such a horrible review, and my first one at that! but the service we had was horrible. I use to wait tables so I give them a lot of slack, but this was unacceptable. 

So the awful experience: our waiter struts over with this appetizer, sets it down and walks away. I'm pretty sure we didn't order this dish, so I get his attention and he comes back. He looks at the dish proceeds to tell me the dish name and just stares at me. I respond by saying "oh, I don't know what this is.... I don't think we ordered this?" He opens the menu, shoves it in my face points to the dish on the menu then just stares at me again. After this weird staring contest he picks up the dish turns to the table BEHIND us and sets it on their table and tells us "oh, wrong table", and then just walks away. He didn't even have the decency to apologize. Unfortunately, that isn't even the end of the story. When paying  the bill we decided to pay in cash. the bill came out to around 42 dollars so we put in 60 because we didn't have change. The guy picks up the bill and never comes back with our change. We sat there for 20 minutes waiting..... I would understand if it was extremely packed and no one was able to get to the register to give out change but it wasn't even that busy. We tried to get our waiters attention, but he just ignored us. We were so annoyed we just ended up leaving.
author: Elle C.

description:
Came here for their Happy Hour with my girlfriends. It took awhile for them to even bring us water, but once our waitress showed up she was really great, and even made some great suggestions about the menu.

Their specialty rolls are a lot cheaper (and still just as big) as other places. However, be aware that they aren't all wrapped in seaweed. They're wrapped in this pink soybean paper. Maybe I'm not as much of a sushi junkie as a I thought I was, but I've never seen this before and to be honest I was NOT a fan. The soybean paper has the same consistency as the sushi rice, so it makes the whole thing feel kind of soggy and unappealing. 

I did also order the Two Balls, No Strikes, which I thought would be like delicate little balls but ended up being these huge honking monster balls of fish and avocado. They actually look amusingly suggestive! And are delicious! However, I wish I'd known just how giant those balls were, because they filled me up so much I could barely touch my soybean-encased rolls. *That's What She Said*

Also, their $1 draft beers are excellent, but it requires at least $15 of food so...if you think you're coming for some cheap beer and nothing else, you are most mistaken. I spent quite a bit of money and maybe it was just my rolls, but I left feeling sort of gross. However, my girlfriends really loved all their food (Spider and XXX roll), so maybe I just need to order something different.

I also really like their bathrooms. The outer doors are sort of hidden in this cool wall, which gives this space a really great touch of personality.
author: Rachel A.

description: This is the best sushi restaurant that I've ever been to, though of course I don't have the full range of sushi experiences to choose from, hence my 4 star review (I imagine there are even better ones for people of unlimited means). Definitely a fantastic dining experience, with really quality fish, awesome service, and a great, modern yet distinctly Japanese styled room to enjoy it all in. I highly recommend the Family Affair roll, the edamame trio, and their version of the 49er roll is sublime. Omakase is always a great choice here too. Definitely make this a stop on your sushi tour of the west coast.
author: Kenton  K.

description:
I have to preface this review by saying I only had the live uni here and nothing else. That's right people, I came with the sole purpose of the live uni and nothing else. Eat with purpose!

I came here on a weekend for lunch with a friend and the place was empty which got me a little nervous but later on, I would be glad for the good fortune as the sushi chef gave us his undivided attention the entire time there.

My friend and I ordered just 1 order of the live uni. What was incredible is they take the live sea urchin and split it open right in front of you and put the hollow shell face down on a bed of ice. So while you eat it, you can watch the spines still moving! Great show and presentation.

What made this even more unique is when the chef put it in front of us, he apologized that the pieces were so small (I guess they were smaller than average? Honestly I couldn't tell) so he prepared another order on the house. Crazy good luck right?

Well it gets better as my friend and I were saying how the uni tasted so much differently than what we were used to, as it was just incredibly rich, buttery, and slightly sweet. I think the chef was so happy that we could taste the difference he pulled out a small box of already prepared uni and told us the uni in here is the lower quality kind they use for rolls and other pieces. He gave us 2 orders of this uni (on the house) simply because he wanted us to taste the difference between fresh/live/expensive and the boxed/cheaper uni. It was night and day difference as the boxed uni was slightly bitter, darker color and not sweet at all.

So in the end, my friend and I had 4 orders of uni for the price of one, an excellent time with the chef and knowledge of what's "good" uni. Again, I have no idea if the other food is good as we just had the live uni. But if the service and live uni is this  amazing and excellent all the time, then they could serve pure garbage and I'd be just as stoked to come here.
author: Alex N.

description: can get packed at night. the fish was fresh, you cant go wrong, just order everything on the fresh fish board
author: Long C.

description: I went on a Thursday night with friends and this place was packed. Luckily we arrived early and didn't have to wait too long. We ordered the Boston and Tokyo Tower rolls. They were great and really fresh. We also had the Oysters Dynamite and it was amazing!
author: Alene Y.

description:
Girls' night out with Amy and Pauline.  I haven't eaten here since the renovation (about 2-3 years ago).  Before the renovation it was excellent.  This past week, oh oh oh, oh oh oh oh oh oh my.   This could resurrect any sushi lover on whatever ails you.

As I've tweeted, the lobster tempura and Panko oysters were out of this world.  Sushi, as always, fresh, and the best I've had anywhere hands down.  Like my longtime friend Gwynnie P said, come early.  Before 6:30 or for lunch.  If you don't, there'll be a wait, but it'll be so much worth it.
author: Lani C.

description: Had dinner here on Sunday after a visit to the Academy of Sciences and a stroll around Golden Gate Park.  Love the energy here.  The sushi was terrific!  The service was quick and friendly.  We will be back!
author: D L.

description:
If I lived closer to Ebisu, I'd be in some serious sushi debt!

Their sushi is fresh, flavorful and creative. I love that they incorporate citrus with fish, two foods that should be paired together more often!

Ebisu offers a fun atmosphere, excellent service and an impressive menu.
author: Lauren T.

description:
Been here 5 years ago and wasn't impressed.  Recently went again to give it a try based on the yelp reviews and still wasn't impressed.

The atmosphere was nice but it is so enclosed that there is a fishy smell.  The food was ok but more expensive than other Japanese restaurants. Prolly woudn't come back.
author: Cin T.

description: I came here from Reno just for sushi and I was not disappointed. The waiter listened to what I liked and made special mixes of fish and fruits. I felt valued and I got to eat some of the best quality fish I've ever had. It was worth the drive and I'll be doing it again.
author: Anna A.

description:
Came here with a semi hungry stomach with a friend. I wasn't expecting to get full off tonight's meal, but I ended up leaving feeling pretty much the same - semi hungry. Here's what we ordered....

Live Uni
XXX Roll 
Double Hamachi Roll
Umi Matsu Nigiri (Sea trout)

Total cost added up to ~$68 after tax and tips. 

So the food was delicious. It really was. As a matter of fact, I haven't eaten anything that can be comparable in awhile. The food was authentic, and didn't have any of those imitation crabs or weird sauces on it. It was straight up raw fish, period. If there's avocado, there were only hints of it, not all packed up.

The atmosphere was nice. It was pretty loud, but it was packed with people. Would make a great catching up place. Or a date =]

The live uni special was disappointing. It was pretty much an uni shell on the bottom, white radish, then around 6-7 slices of uni. I was expecting more - that sea urchin was BIG. But no, it has as much as around 3 uni nigiris. It tasted like... uni. I was expecting it to taste somewhat difference since it was literally "freshly killed." But oh well. I'm a fan of uni, but I think the amount they gave wasn't worth the cost ($20)

The two rolls were great. The fishes were all fresh and firm. Dipping it with a hint of soy sauce w/ wasabi and ginger was exceptional. The rice had a unique hint of flavor in it too. I just wish it wasn't so small.

The nigiri was pretty much "eh" I've never had sea trout before... it looked pretty much as a sake sashimi (salmon). It also tasted similar to it. But then again, I didn't get to have a "thorough" taste, since the piece wasn't as large as I thought it would be, and I only had one try of it. But I don't think it was worth the money. I think I should've tried Tai or Aji. 

All in all, the food was great. It satisfied my taste buds, but it didn't satisfy my stomach. We were considering going to a Viet place for some pho afterward, seriously.
author: Calvin D.

description: Uni got soo expensive.  That's the problem with Ebisu.   Some things that you eat there, get so pricey all of a sudden without a notice.  Been a regular customer since 1996.  Now, I barely go there...
author: Alex R.

description:
Sushi chefs play make up three "roles" (not rolls)

A. they cook, ... obviously
B. they are comedians, with sly laughter + stories to tell
C. they are my unofficial shrink

Looking past their creative knife skills, and dove white chef wear, sushi chefs are artists beyond the naked eye.  With the eyes of an observant hawk, they look for gesture and cues from their patrons at the coveted sushi bar.

With a frown on my face, my sushi chef would tell a ridiculous off beat joke, pushing my sorrows off center stage.  

Smelling the scent of a recent break up, a few pieces of nigir toro (buttery tuna belly w/ slice onions) would heighten my senses.  They essentially are, my food ninjas.

Sure, new Japanese restaurants have been springing up in the Sunset district, but Ebisu has remained a neighborhood favorite.  After almost thirty years, owner Steve Fuji is giving his reign to son Eric Fuji. Pressure pressure.
  
One step through the front door, the smell of fresh fish permeates the room.  Almost every night, the sushi bar is filled with satisfied customers exchanging smiles and jokes with the sushi chefs.  The décor is meant to resemble a home, but without the smelly socks or thong ( I meant underwear) on the floor.
  
Ebisu goes through a large volume of fish, keeping the ingredients very fresh.  With buttery texture, the nigiri toro ($7.50) exemplifies why tuna belly is a prized commodity.  Sprinkled with tobiko eggs, the double hamachi ($12.50) harmonizes the taste of perfectly seasoned rice with sea sweet fish.  Highly recommended, the uni nigiri (sea urchin -$8) explodes with tones of creamy texture.
    
Brushed with a sweet glaze, the caterpillar roll ($9.50) adds double layers of buttery texture from avocados and eel.  Roll number 5 (currently running a sushi contest-$10.00) is all about temperature contrast.  Filled with albacore and maguro, the deep fried roll is accompanied with a sweet 'n spicy curry mayo.
   
Skip the tempura appetizer ($6.25) as the vegetable and shrimp lacked crispiness. Ending the meal on a sweet note, two chunks of tamago (egg omellette -$3) sushi was a great choice.  During my eating adventures in Tokyo, I learned that it takes a very skilled chef to master this multiple layered egg piece + meant to end the meal on a sweet note. 
 
After graduating from UC Berkeley in 2004 with a business degree, Fuji worked in corporate American but did not feel appreciated.  He attend California Culinary Academy and receive a degree in Hospitality Restaurant and Management. 

After working for notably Nobu in Las Vegas, he took his skills and decided to dedicate his full effort to mange his family restaurants.   Eric Fuji admits that his parents would rather he work in a career that was required less hours of work, he firmly admits that he choose this path because he is passionate about the work.   

Despite working long hours, Eric Fuji appreciates that his dad took time to attend his son's baskeball games and cello concerts.  His goals is to work hard to keep the legacy. Currently, the Fuji family has an additional Ebisu sushi restaurant at San Francisco International airport as well as a noodle restaurant Hotei located across from Ebisu on 9th Avenue.

Fuji prides himself especially since the restaurant is one of a handful of Japananese owned Japanese restaurants in the city.  

In an attempt to show appreciation for loyal returning customers, a reward program has been established. Unique sushi dishes also sets them apart, including  live uni (sea urchin) and whole Aji (Spanish mackerel).   

May you find a sushi chefs that meets all your needs, well .. at least most of them.
author: Rayfil W.

description:
Ive been wanting to try this place not only because of the 4 stars on Yelp, but also because of the recommendation of one of my coworkers. Ended up coming on a Friday night, and the wait wasn't too bad. It was an estimated 45ish minutes for 2 people, but ended up being around 25 to 20.. A lot of people on the list basically bailed, so it went pretty fast. Our waitress was named Anita, according to our receipt, and she was nice.. Very helpful and friendly, while frequently checking up on us.

For appetizers, we ordered the poke role and kakuni. The poke roll was alright, but tasted too much like onion and wasnt very spicy. But let me say, I loooooved the kakuni (pork belly.) Super tender and delicious. Its making me want more just thinking about it. Its definitely something you should try if you havent already.. (For those scared of the name pork belly, the meat is a bit like ribs without the bone, only way more awesomely fantastic.)

I ordered the deluxe sushi, which is basically a nigiri sushi combo with california roll as well. The nigiri sushi was good, and very fresh. Even the salmon roe was good (though unavoidably salty.) My one complaint is that they ran out of uni, but let me substitute it with one of the more expensive types of fish on the menu.

Another plus is them using real crab for the california roll. I however do not like california rolls. It doesnt even seem like real sushi to me.. My fault for forgetting to ask if I could sub it for kappamaki or something.

I tasted the salmon shioyaki, which was good. I thought it was weird that there was teriyaki sauce on there though.. Isnt shioyaki usually just with salt?

Anywhoo, I thoroughly enjoyed my meal (especially the kakuniii) and would come back again.. If I can ever find parking!
author: Alison A.

description: Will come back again; incredibly friendly staff, delicious food, and great bathrooms.
author: Zach M.

description: Been here several times this is a trendy place for dinner.  Good for dates not so good for kid since it's a tight place.  I order the Chirashi and Adedashi Tofu.  That will make or break if I like the place or not.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
My super demanding, hip Saturday night was heading towards leftovers and bed with my Kindle and David Mitchell's "Cloud Atlas" but, fortunately, my refrigerator was empty.  Randomly decided to pop into Ebisu in the Inner Sunset.

I've been here once before a long time ago (back when they had that awesome pork belly app on the menu) and I had loved it.  This time was no different.  The fish has been fresh every time I've dined here.  We had a miso soup and seaweed salad to start.  Many places use frozen seaweed salad that they thaw out during the day.  Sometimes this can lead to pretty slimy stuff but Ebisu must rinse theirs out with water or something because it comes out clean and vibrant not dark and mushy.  Maybe they just have a really good supplier.  I don't know but that stuff is addicting.

I guess I should mention my parents used to run a sushi joint and I worked in many a sushi restaurant in my early years.

Anyway, back to the food.  We had a tempura appetizer; tako (octopus), hamachi toro (yellowtail belly), saba (mackerel) with shiso leaf (Japanese mint), and ikura with uzura (salmon roe with raw quail egg on top) nigiri.  All were fresh and cut in decent portions.  Large enough to be worth the price but small enough that it didn't choke you when you put it in your mouth.  

For the rolls we chose 3: Behind the Green Door, Hanukah, and the Louisiana Hot Link.  "Green Door" was on the crazier side with numerous ingredients.  Still very delicious and plated beautifully.  The Hanukah was a smoked salmon/salmon skin roll which had a bit too much rice and not enough salmon skin.  The famous Louisiana Hot Link was spicy yellowtail, burdock root and bonito.  That one was an odd but still tasty flavor.

The food is fantastic.  The space is really small so there was a wait the last 2 times I was here.  Not a big deal for some good food but the waiting area just inside the front door is TINY.  Last time I was here it was winter and waiting outside was a bummer.

Service is efficient and friendly but they need to work on pacing.  Our waitress was very attentive but kept trying to clear plates too soon.  She even stood by the table next to ours, asked the guest if they wanted the last piece of edamame on the plate, and proceeded to wait around while they ate it.  That was the only thing that bothered me.  But everything else was GREAT.
author: Chloe G.

description: It's pretty good, but not great. Plus, factoring in the difficult parking situation in the area and wait, unlikely to be the easiest dining experience. I did enjoy the soft shell crab appetizer. Nice flavors, sauce was good. We got the omakaze 2 person set which was pretty typical fish - salmon, tuna, bluefin, toro, etc. Still pretty good. We also got the fish soup with yam noodles. It was a good broth but on the salty side. OK, maybe too salty after enough ladles of soup. The tofu and shrimp was good, but I wasn't a huge fan of the chunks of fish that seemed to get a little overcooked in the broth. With some other great choices within walking distance, I'm not sure I'd automatically think about coming here again unless there are bad waits everywhere else.
author: Allie Y.

description:
One word to describe this place is FRESH.

My bf and I shared one appetizer and four rolls.  I wasn't too full but it was all delicious.  We had the Pink Cadillac for appetizers which is the scallop wrapped with salmon, this was okay.  All the rolls we gotten we're pretty good.
