I think the only one I wasn't loving so much was the Romeo and Juliet roll, well first off, it came out a little late and I was starting to get a little full as is already, and second, I think the mayo was too rich even though they only used a little bit.  It was pretty heavy for every bite.  My favorite roll was the #29. OMG. LOVE. It was crunchy but still fresh and just everything you can want.  I also like how they don't drench their sushi with sauces which masses the freshness of sushi.

The only thing is that this place gets so pack and the neighborhood is hard to find parking.  We got there at like 5:30 and had taken the last table and when we left there was a long wait.
author: Mimi P.

description:
Seafood salad at Ebisu is yum-oh.

Get here early or come for lunch to avoid the wait.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
Absolutely outstanding sushi.
Fresh, simple, and served bar style.
The delivery reminds me of my favorite sushi place in NYC (Sushi Yasuda). 
I did end up returning the wine I ordered because it didn't taste very fresh but I'm holding firm at five stars because the fish quality is just outstanding.
It's a no frills, authentic sushi restaurant where you know you can count on a great meal served straight to you by a sushi chef who really knows his stuff!
author: Lianne Z.

description:
Good food for the price.  Higher than average quality.

Busy and tight though.
author: Cathy U.

description: This place has been up there for sushi restaurants in SF for a long time. A reason for that they have been consistent on occasions I have been here (except Sundays when main chef is not working)  I went in early on a weekday so didn't have to wait and they had special on pints of Sapporo. I had a chirasi combo and rainbow roll. Service was fast and the sushi was great as always. No wonder it keeps bringing people back again and  again. I guess its the old charm which makes me prefer this place over other places.
author: Elvis A.

description: It's just as the 3 star rating says. A-Ok. When I came here, the meat wasn't as good as it was in the past. It wasn't horrible, but it just wasn't as good as it was in the past. Other than that, I know they say it's Kobe beef, but I'm 99% sure it isn't real because I have tasted real kobe beef, and their beef didn't have nearly enough flavor. I give this place a B-. Better than average, but not outstanding.
author: Ashton Z.

description:
This continues to be my favorite sushi. I now live in Phoenix and I look forward to any trip to SF as I know I'll come by here. I dined here again last night and enjoyed some terrific live scallop, kobe sashimi and hamachi nigiri. The fish is always top quality and extremely fresh.

The service was prompt and friendly like it has been on each trip I've had to this restaurant.
author: Alex N.

description: Ebisu is really good, I always eat at the sushi bar and the chefs are always friendly. The fish is fresh and the this place has a nice atmosphere. The rolls are delicious and original. Definitely in my top 5!
author: Brendan W.

description:
This place was GREAT! Who knew?!

I have a fab friend who recommended I try this place when looking for delicious, cheap sushi and this definitely met all expectations! Plenty of menu options and all reasonably priced! 

The space is very small, so I can see how there might be a wait on busy nights, but it didn't seem to be deterring any customers when I was there. Interestingly enough, there were people of all age groups inside too... some older couples, some kids, infants, 20-somethings-on-a-date - interesting crowd all crammed in this tiny, funky space off of Lincoln. 

Great service too - our waiter was so nice and so attentive.  He also was quick to provide any advice or recommendations, all of which were welcome and well-received! 

The ingredients are top notch too - I don't have any legit cred to back this up, but as a big seafood fan I could tell the fish was fresh.
author: Elizabeth B.

description: So I finally was able to try this place out after living near here forever and it lived up to the hype. The sushi was great and really fresh, but what really sealed the deal for me was the chicken teriyaki platter. I think it was the best chicken teriyaki I ever had it was cooked perfectly. Definitely recommend this place.
author: Jamie Y.

description:
Great sushi and great customer service! I have been going there for years and it does get pricey, but the ambiance makes up for it. I love their sushi rolls, because they are definitely very creative and light on the rice.  Also, I love their appetizers. 

I highly recommend for a date night or more intimate setting, because the lines are long and seating is better accustomed for smaller groups. 

Overall, I'm a fan!
author: Magdalena Z.

description:
Met a friend for lunch on a Saturday and was seated right away.  We were able to have a relatively leisurely lunch while catching up on the last few months of our lives.  

She had the chirashi and I had the swamp roll, double hamachi roll and kanpachi nigiri.  I guess I was hungry.  I was really in the mood for uni but they were out.  The rolls were  fine and my friend's chirashi looked great.  Aside from having to park 6 blocks away to avoid meters, it was an easy place for decent sushi.
author: Seong P.

description:
The first thing my Canadian cousin said after getting off a flight from Thailand was: "I've been craving sushi; we have to go to Ebisu!"  Straight from SFO to Ebisu after a 2-3 week culinary romp through Vietnam and Thailand.

And of course, we started off with a round of $1 Sapporos and Kirins (every day from 5-6PM).  The sushi was pricey, but that's expected for the freshness.  The fish was delicious and wasn't drowned in sauce.

As this was a pre-party meal before bday craziness, the waiter comp'ed us TWO desserts for the two bday folks even though we had a party of 4.  Ice cream with strawberry Pocky sticks.  ::rubs tummy::
author: Kevin W.

description:
Absolutely love this place! Nice decor, excellent service, and delicious food and drink, makes for a perfect combination!

It's so nice to find a high quality sushi restaurant in a neighborhood like the Sunset, and while you pay a little extra for that high quality, the prices are still reasonable.

The selection of both sushi and other dishes is great, with some outstanding special rolls. The specials board changes on a daily basis and so far I haven't been disappointed with anything I've ordered here.

The tune is super yummy, the sauces are great, I appreciate the real crab in my california rolls, their miso soup is the best ever, their gyozas are perfect, their tempura light and tasty, I could go on..... you really can't go wrong.
They have a good selection of beer and sake too, and if you sit at the bar the chefs always manage a conversation, despite being very busy.

Great for dinner and lunch.
author: Izzy A.

description:
Waaaaaaah. I've only heard good things about Ebisu and unfortunately, I wasn't impressed.

I think it may have been the service that turned me off.  Our waiter was really friendly but slow and inattentive.  Meh.

The fish was fresh (ahi and salmon) and there was there was the perfect amount of wasabi in the ahi.  The miso soup was okay, not enough tofu and I had to add a bit of shoyu and the tea could've been stronger.  I also had the spicy ahi roll which was okay; the spicy ahi is definitely not the same as it is in Hawaii.  I think I should teach them a thing or two about spicy ahi, it would for sure be a best seller.  

I will try Ebisu again because the fish was really good and I do like fiiiiiiiiish.

Oh and it's quite pricey.
author: Marisa R.

description: Definitely pricey and be prepared to wait a long time, but the food is exceptional here and worth the hassle, especially for a special occasion.
author: Amanda F.

description: I wish you people would stop writing such great reviews for this place!  The line is WAY long! :)  I do love the experience of eating here.  Not only is the food amazing, the service and bar are really fun.  It's the best place in SF to eat sushi.  But shhhhhh......
author: Eileen L.

description: I've been a loyal Ebisu sushi customer since 1998 or so when one of my friends took me there.  Their fish is fresh and quite a bit of variety.  They have quite a few combinations that are my favorite.  49er roll, sunrise, 2 ball one strike, aji tataki, fresh uni when available etc.... all is good.  This IS the sushi place that I recommend to all my friends.
author: Gerald S.

description:
Some DAMN GOOD SUSHI! Let's be honest here, I'm a cheapie. I don't buy ANYTHING full price.. and if I do, I'm gonna try to find a coupon on line, or bargain. So my husband who is a total opposite of me, will splurge on just about everything. He would rave and rave about Ebisu, and I'd keep saying noooo.. lets do something like Yum Yum Fish. Which is about 1/3rd the cost. Of course he wouldn't agree. Until one day I agree... 

We ordered his favorite 49er roll and some deluxe roll. I ordered the vegetable tempura, and a caterpillar roll. OMG the caterpillar roll was so CUTE! I didn't want to eat it. Of course I did, and when I did it was soooooo good. The ingredients were amazingly fresh and the texture was right on. I'm not a big fan of raw fish, but I must say the 49er roll is something you have to try, even if you don't eat raw fish. The veggie tempura was standard. They included some pretty funky veggies in there. I didn't finish it since I didn't know wth the veggie was. (even after taking a bite) 

I've been to Ebisu 2x now. The first time was a great, the 2nd time was great BUT the sushi chef was a bit sloppy. The sushi kinda fell apart as we picked it up with our chopsticks. Once it was in our big fat mouths, it tasted the same.. so hopefully that sushi chef was just having an off day. All good, we all have our off days. 

Will I be back - HELL TO THE YES! 

P.s. You can call ahead and try to get a reservation in. Def recommend it for dinner - since there can be a long wait at times.
author: Alice E.

description:
God I love this place. I found this place by word of mouth. It's a far ways from where I live, parking gets kinda tough. But if you go, it's well worth it. Gets busy. They don't take reservations. Try sitting at the bar. Sushi comes out faster and better there. We've also sat in the pagoda looking thing (where you take off your shoes and sit cross-legged). Very cool, but not cool if you have a bad back or freakishly large legs where its hard to sit cross-legged. 

Rolls are unique and damn good. They have the usual names of the rolls, but have some tweak about them that make them different. ie. rainbow roll or dragon roll, etc. 

Highly recommend, street parking gets tough, go later as the wait gets long, not really good for a party place (the place is small and cramped).
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
One of the reasons we even tried this place was Park Chow was crazy crowded.  Maybe we should have waited after all.

The true rating of this place closer to 1.5 stars.  The reason is the food did nothing for me.  In fact, everything had a kinda sweetness to it and seemed fake.  I can't really explain.

I guess this place is okay if you didn't know any better because ignorance can be bliss.  In this case, substitute bliss with tasty.

In fact, these are the dinners that make me cringe.  There was no real satisfaction at the end of the meal.  Although my stomach was full, I still craved something.

in search of flavor packed yelp
author: Dan B.

description: I thought it was very solid. Beautiful bustling room. Awesome edamame trio, ribeye steak (BIG), $1 happy hour draft beer. Nice waiter. Premium toro nigiri always excites me - this is no exception. Only problem was: Ate it too fast.
author: Andrew K.

description:
4/5 stars on the Wing Scale... (rounded up due to lack of complaints)

- Quality of product: 2 of 3 stars 
- Quality of service: .5 of 1 star
- General feelings of happiness: 1 of 1 star  

This is Hubby J and my favorite sushi spot in the Sunset. We never have complaints about the quality or the freshness of their ingredients. Portions are relatively generous. 

J is more adventurous and likes to try the blackboard specials.

Personally, I find their specialty rolls delicious and worth trying. My favorite is the double hamachi roll... no nonsense yellowtail goodness (punctuated with some oniony notes). Yum...
author: Wing Y.

description:
Definitely one of the best places to go to for sushi.  The fish is fresh, marvelous, and pretty damn cheap.  I think the Nigiri is well priced, especially the Salmon and Mackerel - they are just too good for what you pay for ( under 5 bucks !! )

  The Drunken Berries Dessert is phenomenal - raspberries and black berries soaked in sake with ice cream. I have yet to try and other desserts and am quite looking forward to their vanilla brulee.

  There can be a huge wait, so come early or an hour before they close to avoid the dinner rush.

  My favorite place is to sit at the bar.

  Enjoy and eat well !!
author: Anthony N.

description:
Three stars for service and three stars for food.

Shhhhh.... don't tell my boyfriend.  This is his favorite sushi restaurant (so he took me there last night).

We sat at the bar and ordered nothing but sashimi.  Honestly, it was good, but not great.  

The waitress interrupted us mid-meal, and asked that we move over one seat to accommodate a 3-person party so they could sit together at the bar.  She then brought us a large hot sake to make up for the trouble.  That was a pleasant surprise from an average sushi spot.
author: Kristen S.

description: I love Ebisu.  The staff is professional.  They get people seated as quickly as they can since this place is always hopping. The fish is fresh.  My faves are Omakase which is sashimi from the chefs selection, the edamame trio and the good ol' rainbow roll.  Make sure to not come too hungry since there is usually a wait - which is totally worth it.  I wouldn't bring a large group as I imagine the wait would be very long.  This place is pretty small.
author: Kra C.

description:
Ok, so this place is still 5 stars. 
Just have to stress how the employees here work like a well-oiled machine. A random hand cleared an empty plate from our table just as a nother hand was setting down a new one. Unlike other places where you can't even get your own waitress' attention, you will be helped by anyone who's around. The chef's are always fun to talk and joke with. This place should win an award for best customer service, and every employee should be employee of the month!
author: Giovanna C.

description:
This spot is more like a hole-in-the-wall. It's located in the Sunset right below an apartment/house unit. I've heard that they will be remodeling and making the location a little bigger and I'm very excited about it.

ADVICE: Get there EARLY for dinner on the weekends

My personal faves:
- Hamachi Kama: SO GOOD and juicy.
- Kobe Beef Sashimi: a plate with I think 10-15 slices of beef. Melts in your mouth and the sauce is amazing.
- Aji Tatake: 2 orders of small Aji nigiri and the whole raw Aji fish was stripped of it's meat, skewered, and the rest of the meat was sitting on the inside with light flavoring. The stripped fish is then fried and served back to you. Goes GREAT with some beer.
- Hirame Nigiri: I just love Hirame
- Dragon Roll: Very filling for the price.
- 2 Balls, No Strike: Spicy tuna balls wrapped with Avocado slices

Ambiance:
I've been here a handful of times. Despite the large crowd it brings in, the atmosphere is wonderful. It's loud and friendly. Sake bombs going off left and right. It's a really fun environment. It gets really packed on weekends, but that only shows just how good this place is. Sometimes customers wait over an hour just to eat here. The longest I've ever waited was a little over an hour. Sometimes customers don't even bother waiting and leave once they see the crowd, but I stay every time because I just really like this place.

There's a, I believe, a 20-seat sushi bar, about 10 tables and a Zashiki Japanese room where you can take off your shoes and eat on the floor. It's not too dark or bright. Seating can get a little crowded, but it's only because they try to make room for their customers in such a small location.



Service:
Being a small and very fast-paced family restaurant, it's hard to find employees who can keep up with the pace which is why they are a little short-staffed which kind of makes the service a little slow sometimes on real busy nights.

The staff here is very friendly and they always have a smile on their face even if something goes terribly wrong. It's all about the smile!

There are two servers who stood out the most to me. I believe their names are Maname and Charlie. They both give EXCELLENT service and try their best to help you  to their full potential.

The sushi chefs are very friendly and love to make conversation with customers at the bar. Depending on how busy, you can always ask them to try and make something different for you and they will do it.

The owners are usually there so you can ask them any questions that you have about their menu and all that.



Price:
There are a lot of overpriced sushi restaurants out in the city, but I have to admit that the prices here are VERY reasonable for the quality.

I've heard/read a lot of people giving really good ratings for high-end sushi restaurants that have great quality foods and beautiful presentations and HIGH prices. This spot can give you that for so much more less than what you would pay at a super fancy sushi restaurant.



Parking:
Because it's in the sunset, there's street parking. But there is also a small private lot right across the street that charges a FLAT RATE of $8, which is alright.
author: Heidi C.

description:
Showed up here after work on a Friday night with 2 friends. We waited about 20 minutes before being seated. While waiting though the hostess took our drink order and delivered them so we could sip while we were waiting. We ordered one of the cold Sake's and it was really smooth and had a great flavor (sorry I cant remember the name).

For an appetizer I had one of the best seaweed salads I have ever had. It tasted really fresh and had great flavor. We ordered several of rolls and one clay pot. They were all tasty. The only problem we had was not being able to finish our food. 

Our server was really patient with us and made great suggestions. We thought it was great service overall.
The quality of sushi was great and the price was definitely reasonable. If you are in the area and want sushi I would definitely suggest this place!
author: Tuesday C.

description:
The sushi is great here but I have never been more disappointed with the service.  Understanding that they were busy, we tried to be patient.  However, we tried to order take out, because we were entertaining, and we were put on hold 7 times!  The hold time was over 5 minutes each time and we had to keep calling back.  I think that they don't care for women because when my girlfriend would call, she was placed on hold but when I would call, they took my order right away (I was actually laughing about it while my girlfriend was fuming).  After I placed our order, which was expensive, we were quoted 30-40 minutes. 
45 minutes later, we arrived at the place and waited another 20 minutes because they kept ignoring us.  Eventually, we had to make a little scene only to realize that our order had been sitting 2 feet away from us the entire time!  The two host kept helping everyone else even though we would ask for our order, only to be ignored.  
I was very confused and not impressed with the whole situation!  
The way that they run their business is a great way to not have a business.  I will make sure that I pass this on to all who I know because it was actually more insulting than annoying.  

Sushi-great!
Service-a crime against humanity!
author: Joe E.

description:
Excellent sushi spot.  Top notch.  A little expensive.  Decor is not as good as the fish.  Parking isn't the greatest.  If anytime one of my friends says, "Want to go to Ebisu?"  I will always answer yes.  Melt in your mouth sushi.  I have been many times and the place is already reliable.  

At lunchtime I feel a little out of the place with the other customers, but who cares.  I am here to eat.  The staff is super nice but often really busy just talking to the big mouth regulars who talk loud and about whatever they want to and really stuff themselves there.  But who can blame them, it's a great spot.

Check it out.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
I'd heard many things about this place (all good) for the past 4-5 years and finally got a chance to give it a try.

Ebisu turned out to be yet another sushi joint that I can not only tolerate, but actually enjoy the sashimi.  

Two reasons why it took me so long to try this place:

(1) Long lines drive me batty.  

(2) Rumors of overly priced fish threatened to make me break out in hives.

Luckily I went - no hives (it was actually quite reasonably priced, especially since we didn't over-order) and the meal was certainly worth the wait.

Slice on, sushi kings!!
author: Shinny L.

description:
Love getting lunch here on the weekends. Bento boxes are awesome. You will notice the little touches like wakame, spinach and sprouts.

They have seasonal items also which is worth a look.
Not really a fan of their sister restaurant Hotei across the street. Ebisu is a step above ;)
author: Cortland T.

description: This place was awesome!  Can't imagine a better experience. The live scallops were a great addition as well!
author: Melia B.

description: Honestly GREAT food & service...  The best sushi we have ever had... ! but way too noisy. they should do something about that wood ceiling that reflects all the very loud talking throughout the whole restaurant!!
author: HungryHippo L.

description: Absolutely great experience. The sushi is phenomenal and the service is superb.  If I can complain about anything, it would be about the long wait time usually expected at a place this good. I have been coming here over 10 years, and know it as the go-to place for sushi in the city.
author: Ivan S.

description:
It is just plain stupid how much I love this place.

Every time I have an out-of-towner coming to visit, I always make such grand plans to sample new restaurants (because, you know, SF only has ONE BILLION of them). I browse on Yelp for must-trys, make like 10 reservations, then await the fateful day. Then, when the time actually comes, I say, "Let's go to Ebisu!" 

Seriously. What's wrong with me.

(No, but REALLY seriously, try this place. It's so good.)
author: Ash V.

description: any questions??!!! find a seat at counter....with the famous SUZUKI_SAN!!!! you wont be disappointed!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: chris f.

description:
I hate fake crab.   I once saw a documentary on how they make the fake stuff and it grossed me out.  Fake crab is the Hot Dog of the seafood world. 

Real crab is available at Ebisu.  The fish is fresh and I like eating here.

I used to come here a lot more often when I worked in the area and we had this super cool discount card for frequent diners.   I don't think they do that anymore which is too bad.
author: Katharine A.

description:
Sushi snobs - the sushi isn't worth the wait, they're experimenting in unorthodox ways, so don't come here, and stop reading now.

Ok for everyone else: We sat at the bar and had a very fun time. Some of the other reviews describe the sushi chefs as stern, but the guys there that night were extremely jovial and nice. The other patrons were friendly regulars who were able to recommend items we wouldn't have tried otherwise.

As we were sitting down, the sushi chef in front of us was preparing live uni as the patron next to us was covering her eyes. This is the first place in the US I've seen prepare live uni, and it was an indication of how unique the experience in front of us would be. Unlike, like the other patron, we weren't afraid of seeing live uni and ordered one immediately. Since it was live, it was very fresh, but was not the sweeter type of uni that we prefer. We also ordered a mix of sushi and rolls. The sushi, although not the best I've ever had, was fresh and buttery. The 49er and Swamp rolls were creative and tasty. However, the rice was over-vinegared and took away from the experience.
author: Judy C.

description:
Well now here's a rarity: me walking out of a Japanese restaurant all stuffed. The tea and the miso soup are scalding hot, but delicious. Had the shrimp tempura with sashimi bento and it was quite a decent amount grub. Nice wooden interior...

By the way, how competitive is this area? Three sushi joints a stone's throw from each other!
author: Maximillian M.

description: The sushi was great and I loved the kobe sashimi!  I am very excited to go back to Ebisu and try other dishes.
author: Amber P.

description:
Definitely more authentic than most, Ebisu does not pretend to be one of those Asian Fusion restaurants.  The three of us showed up on a Saturday night sans reservation and fully expected a 45-min wait, which turned out to be more like a 20-minute one. 

The tables are clearly a tad bit too small and too close for comfort, so it's definitely not a place to take a girl that you are dying to impress for a nice romantic date.  There isn't much by way of decor or ambiance either - one long sushi bar with four sushi chefs hard at work on the left hand side of the narrow restaurant, and the most interesting thing is probably the big blackboard filled with a wide variety of mouthwatering daily specials.  

But if you don't care about any of these things, or you don't have a girl to impress, then Ebisu's clearly the bomb.  

Where do I start? 

We kicked off the meal with two of the daily specials - after much deliberation (it WAS a crazy-big selection) we settled for a dish of delish grilled chicken wings glazed with sweet teriyaki sauce (PS: NOT to be confused with knock-off chicken teriyakis from most sub-par fake Japanese restaurants) and a trio of thinly sliced and extremely fresh maguro, hamachi and sakae. 

Then we ordered the famous albacore tataki with ponzu sauce (hold the sliced onions!); two balls of avocado-wrapped spicy tuna; chicken yakitori sampler (you GOTTA order at least one thing from the robata menu); and, the most substantial dish of the evening, the heavenly potato bug roll - a freshwater eel roll topped with even more freshwater eel.  

Content, we dug into the dishes and started the discussion panel on the topic of trials and tribulations of single ladies in San Francisco. 

For the three of us (all of whom are rather big eaters), the total damage was $28 per person including tip, money well-spent.
author: Ange L.

description: Absolutely love this place. Convenient location in the inner sunset but good luck with parking! The freshest fish I've had in San Francisco, and the rolls are delicious (we had the Family Affair roll, which was amazing).
author: Abby C.

description: the food is very very good . but parking is a problem as well as wait time . but its worth it . bonito sashimi in a creamy white sauce is so delicious must try
author: elena m.

description: I am surprised I'm giving Ebisu 5 stars, but they earned it. I did not expect to be amazed after reading the other reviews. I came here on a day I had food poisoning (from an earlier meal). I was neither happy nor hungry but I had to keep my dinner commitment here. After ordering several dishes, including the omakase selection, I was blown away and wanted more. The selection of fish I was served was extremely tasty and high quality. I will remember this meal and come back for more.
author: Thomas M.

description:
So happy that Ebisu is open late on weekends!  We went at 10:30 at night and despite the late arrival, service was still spot on!

Everything we had was amazing, espceically our last dish, the Lousiana Hot Link.  Not sure how the chefs turn yellowtail into this delicious New Orleans bite, but it was pretty darn amazing!

Lastly, all three of us were full and only came out about $35 a person including a litte asahi lite and unfiltered sake!  I can't wait to go back again!
author: Robert L.

description:
Maybe I'm just an old faithful at some of my other Japanese spots, but this one was alright.  Went there on a Saturday night with a friend and the wait was around 20 minutes.  It wasn't so bad.  The place is small and it gets loud in there.  

The food: it's fresh and I can always tell by their Uni if the place is legit and it was.  The sashimi and nigiri pieces are fresh.  The toro was not as buttery as I have had at other places.  When I ordered the Aji (Spanish Mackerel) they didn't even include the tail/bones that should have bee deep fried and served as your side.  That's a No-No!  

Had their Chawan-mushi (steamed egg) and it came out just right, but needed slightly a little more flavor.  The 3-flavor edamame was unique and different which was a good change-up from the regular salted version.  Dessert menu, well, forget about it.  The best the waiter said was their green tea ice-cream and creme brulee.  Really? They didn't even have mochi!

Service: quick and ready to pick up your plates, since the table is quite small.  So they were definitely there and on point.  

Bottom line: Yah, this place is acceptable and I will go back, but only if I was in the area.
author: Meshell C.

description: Great sushi in a wonderful environment. I had the avocado, salmon, mango roll and it was amazing. The staff was really helpful in answering questions as well.
author: Emily S.

description: Gotta Love the Crunchy Roll and the 49er Roll.....delicious!  Also recently had the Kobe Hot Pot and loved it....Decor is great and the service is always nice as well.
author: Morgan C.

description:
I used to live in the Sunset Area of SF. This is one of the sushi places I frequently got to. Nothing remarkable really. Food is fresh and parking is as what you expect in SF a pain in the ass. Unless you live around like I used to-W-A-L-K.
It's close to Golden Gate Park and that is sweet..
author: Janet D.

description:
A longtime staple in the Inner Sunset, I prefer to dine here for lunch and avoid the overflowing dinner crowd.  This was my first meal here since their remodel.  The dining room, sushi bar, and restroom were fully updated with a modern decor and nice wood finishes for the sushi counters and bar area.  After being seated, we were quickly given their updated menus, considerably different from the old laminated sheets.  
After studying the menu, the Bento Boxes seemed like the best choices on the menu.  At $14.00 per meal, there were five combination choices of which I chose #5.  Here's what came with my order:
Miso Soup - Smaller bowl, but tasty and just right salt-wise.
   ** garnish - a small plate of three different pickled vegetables was a
     pleasant accompaniment for the hot broth.
Bento Box - five compartments
a) Wild greens salad with cherry tomatoes - light dressing mixed evenly with the salad
b)  Trio of Japanese salad - Three small mounds of Japanese style spinach salad, seaweed salad, and marinated pea sprouts.
c) Gyoza - Four freshly pan fried pork filled dumplings with a spicy vinegar dipping sauce.  It came temperature hot.
d) Veggie Tempura - Battered pieces of brocolli, carrot, lotus root, bamboo slice, and Shiitake mushroom with ponzu dipping sauce.
e) Kurobota Katsu - Fried pieces of lean pork tenderloin.  Higher qualityof meat and small sauce compartment with katsu sauce and yellow hot mustard.
This came with a bowl of white rice which I barely touched.  By comparison to the competing neighborhood spots, this meal is on the pricey side, but the quality of the food justifies it.  We tried to order from their new specials board behind the sushi masters, but the selections are only available during dinner.  I will miss their Sukiyaki Donburi from their old menu.  However, the new menu gives me new reasons to come here.  If you haven't dined here since their remodel, you might think that you're eating in a new restaurant.
author: Mike C.

description: So this last visit was better, but I was with someone that knows the staff so no doubt this was helpful. Sushi was fresh and some great fish that aren't usual or clearly not as tasty in other places. I've bumped them up to 3 stars since I got in and enjoyed the food-now I need to see how it goes without a known person with me!!
author: Dr F.

description:
Can't eat, closed Mondays
No food makes me, sad panda.
Cross street, go Hotei.
author: Jesse C.

description: This is my favorite sushi place in SF. Love the crunchy role and 49er role. Almost everything is amazing here, including the service.
author: Rebecca D.

description:
The food here was better 3 years ago.  I recently went there for dinner and the waitress was not understanding my orders.  I got quite frustrated.  The sushi was just ok.  One of the rolls were messy looking and I could of made it better.  The Uni is very good.  The sake not cold enough.  Kinda overpriced for the service and food quality.  Not sure if i'm going there again.  Go to Deep Sushi - 29th and Church St.

Very overrated with all these people going there not knowing about real sushi.  I rather go next door to chinese/hispanic made sushi at Kiki.  For $140 that I spent for 2 people at Ebisu, I could of feed about 6 at Kiki and be just as satisfied.
author: Kevin L.

description:
When it comes to SF Sushi, Ebisu isn't the sharpest crayon in the box.

In fact, Ebisu is like a dull knife.  It will do the job, but it won't do so with any pizazz or force.

The food really lacks lustre, but the atmosphere is fun and the chefs are entertaining.

Word on the calle is that they are going to remodel and make a large bar, so there will be something to do (DYL!) while waiting 45 minutes for a spot.
author: Joanna M.

description:
Considered the best sushi in SF.

I ate here over 8 years ago, and it was impressive then.

Now, I eat here, and the menu's gotten a real overhaul of changes, and the menu looks to be more...how do I put this...Americanized?   What is with some of these rolls--not very Japanese!  

And what is with the insane prices?  They have gone up in prices, but down in portions.  

There is always a wait for this place.  They do offer three types of seating... at the sushi bar, at a table, or on the floor with a lowered table and all.  Service is efficient, and used to be friendly here, borders on rude now.  

Tip: I've heard that they own Hotei across the street... and it is!  Go there, the Japanese food is better, and while the selection of rolls is smaller, it is actually better and slightly lower in prices.  

Oh, and parking is a complete pain here...so good luck.  :-)
author: Fannie S.

description:
I so wanted to like this place.  I mean, anyone who has walked by Ebisu knows it's probably the cutest/quaintest restaurant on 9th Ave Inner Sunset, reminiscent of the beautiful little restaurants in Kyoto.  Unfortunately, the food was so disappointing and so terribly mediocre, only to be matched by the lukewarm attitude of the wait staff.  

I really don't get the 4-star rating, but like I've said, the ambiance is so nice, perhaps it makes patrons forget how bad the food is.
author: S. I.

description:
Incredibly fast service, insanely fresh fish and great sake. What else could you ask for?????? 

My mom and I went to Ebisu for dinner one night. She ordered the Chirashi bowl, and I ordered the salmon shioyaki and california roll.

I think I died eating it. The sauce was so good with the salmon, and my mom's chirashi was melt-in-your-mouth fish. 

I just found my favorite place in the city.
author: Monique K.

description:
Tuesday, 8:30PM.

Packed house! Party of twos are on the fast track to get seated, so we got hooked up with a table within the minute.

Quickie:
+Good sushi (quality and variety)
+Clean joint
+Awesome service (knowledgeable, attentive)
*Lively atmosphere, to the point where the two of us were shouting!
- Taut seating, not much privacy between tables

And then...?
1 appetizer + 2 specialty sushi rolls may not seem much, but my friend and I left Ebisu in repletion. Awkward spacing is a mere bagatelle, the comfort food and nice staff makes a return trip necessary.


**********
Mo' 4-1-1:

1.Chawan Mushi
(Steamed egg custard with shrimp, chicken, shiitake, edamame, spinach and fish cake)
     +Blow on it before eating it: it's hot, firm, and delicious (TWSS!)
     *Chicken and fishcake are the only items that really retain their flavor
2. Rainbow Roll 
(Shrimp tempura roll with seasonal fish, albacore in this case, on top along with tobiko and green onions)
     +Fresh fish, so fresh fresh
3. #1 Special Roll
(Salmon top roll wrapped in spicy tuna with avocado and sprouts)
     +Spice is just right, great staff recommendation
author: Chuck N.

description: Really great Japanese food. And for a girl who comes from Asia, that's saying something. The Kobe Beef Sashimi was simply excellent so was the Lobster Tempura. Don't bother with the chicken teriyaki though. A little on the costly side (a lot) but definitely worth it. Quaint, cute little place as well. Long wait, but again worth it. Will definitely come back again.
author: FungYing T.

description: This place is awesome! One of the best sushi restaurants in the city. The fish was super fresh. My fav was the 49er roll. Give it a try!
author: Erika B.

description: Ebisu is my go to sushi place in the inner sunset. Their rolls are super fresh and their service is excellent.  They have all the typical rolls (ie: Caterpiller, Dragon, etc) along with some interesting specials that frequently change.  The pricing is really good relative to the quality.  The only drawback is that this place is really popular so expect to wait 20-30 minutes for a table of two on a weekend.
author: J W.

description: Still excellent after all these years, usually a bad review here means people just don't know about sushi or were frustrated with the wait...
author: Chuck D.

description: Simply the best in town. Family run so loving care into every bite. The owners never miss a night making sure your experience is as good as they intended. Creative rolls, generous pieces and best sushi selection in town. Quality unsurpassed.
author: T W.

description:
The Kobe beef sashimi w/ ponzu dipping sauce was possibly the best Japanese food experience I have had in San Francisco. The crunchy roll was also refreshingly delicious. I would skip the chicken wings and gyoza.

This place has great service and a cozy/cool decor. The small plates do add up quickly, so if you aren't too hungry this is a great place to go.
author: Lauren Y.

description: Went here tonight for an early dinner. Sat at the bar alone :( ( since its my first week in SF and I dont know anyone). Anyways, the chef's behind the bar were great, prompt and professional. I had the miso cod because I wish I could live at Nobu and, it was really well prepared.  For dinner I had the special roll that was mango, salmon, avocado, scallion, tobiko, which was amazing. Also very well done. I was going to go for some sashimi and asked for a menu but the woman thought I was making a checkbook signal so brought the check. So other then that it was a great experience. Every dish I saw around me looked amazing and their fresh daily market selection was top notch. There are I think 3-4 other sushi places on the same side street but this was the only one at full capacity and with people waiting, the others looked pretty dead.
author: Max S.

description:
I used to go to Ebisu with the boys a long time ago.  I dunno why I stopped going but I'm glad that this place popped up in my head  when I was thinking of a place to eat for dinner.

Got there around 8pm on Saturday night after trying to find parking for about 10 minutes.  It always takes a while to find parking anywhere in the city and I have come to terms with it.  The wait was about 20 minutes or so.  There are some chairs inside where you can sit and wait  or you can just hangout outside and enjoy the crisp night air.

The decor is really cool.  The floor, tables, ceiling were all made of different types of wood that gave it a modern Japanese feeling to it.  The staff is super friendly and are on top of their game.  The lady that was taking names in the front even remembered my GFs name as we left which is pretty cool.  You don't really get that anymore.  

The food was yummy for my tummy:
Pink Cadillac:  Grilled scallops wrapped with salmon.   Good concept but a bit over grilled taking away from the texture of both.  Still good though.

Hamachi kama:  Grilled yellowtail cheek that was hella big and contained lots of tasty meat.  I've had this at other places where it was a lot more moist.  Maybe it's not here because the grill was too hot and was over cooked?

Escolar sashimi (butterfish):  Holy crap dude!  Best sashimi everrrrr. Repeating: EVERRRR  Truly has a buttery texture and melts in your mouth.  You don't even need soy sauce and/or wasabi so don't even try to use them and ruin it.

Family affair roll & Romeo and Juliet rolls:  Random rolls that were picked based on the description and both were excellent.  The rice is made perfect.  A tad warm, soft, and the right amount of vinegar. Combine this with the fresh fish and other ingredients.  I savored every bite.

Overall, a great experience.  Satisfied stomach = Satisfied customer = Will come back again
author: Suzi K.

description:
3.5 stars.  4 stars for quality of fish but docked half a star for preparation of the sushi.  

Last time I ate here was in 2003.  I was afraid of going back because my taste buds has improved since then and I thought that Ebisu may have been a popular mediocre sushi restaurant that somehow prevailed over time.  I went recently for dinner by myself and sat at the sushi bar. I ordered some fresh sushi from the chalk board behind the sushi chef:  salmon-toro, hamachi-toro, kampachi-toro, uni.  There were two nigiri pieces of each type of fish. I wanted to order the albacore tuna-toro but they ran out.  The fish was very fresh, however, the nigiri sushi did not follow normal sushi convention such as applying some wasabi between the fish and rice,  Also, the rice were not packed as firmly as they should be for a couple of my nigiri pieces.  The sushi chefs were very busy with a lot of orders coming in from the tables and they certainly looked frazzled.  I finished my meal with the house salad, which was unnecessarily topped with fried noodles.  But the vegetables and dressing in the salad were tasty - I just pushed the noodles off to the side.  

All in all, the fish was very fresh but the final bill was actually pretty pricey, I guess the price you pay for quality fish.
author: Kai C.

description:
The sushi is fresh, no doubt about it...but it is cramped, elbow battles with people next to us and we were two girls. Also the waitress forgot our tea...unacceptable! I'm not a very demanding diner, but just because they have loyal customers, doesn't mean the new ones want their drink to be forgotten, it was cold too so i needed the hot tea to warm up. I won't lie though, me and my dining partner both chowed down, we were super hungry. If there is a long line, don't listen to the hype, just go across the street or to one of the million other restaurants on irving.

"meh I've experienced better." that's why I give it 2 and not 3, it's not bad, but considering all the other factors that's how i feel.
author: Lily G.

description: Best sushi in SF.   Hamachi and Kampachi excellent!  Service was professional, friendly and super attentive.  Got in and out in 30 minutes!  Love it
author: Jay K.

description:
I love sushi.  I love Ikura.  I love Tako.  

And now I love Ebisu.  A LOT.  

Maybe it was the Sake.  Nope.  Not the sake.  Cuz I can get that anywhere.  

Maybe it was the American Wagyu Sukiyaki, the Japanese hot pot with sliced American Kobe beef, tofu, yam noodles and vegetables.  Cuz that was yummy, too.

Or, maybe it was the perfect slices of tako on my nigiri sushi, which was not tough, or chewy but perfectly cooked so that I didn't have to wrestle it in order to eat it.

Or just maybe it was the cozy 2-top we were seated at next to the faux barn wood paneled wall with the low lit candles.  

More likely, though, It was probably just the perfect evening, with the perfect person, and the perfect dinner and the perfect date.
author: Jacquie L.

description:
didnt blow my mind. (but i luuuuvvvvv sushi, so i think it takes a lot to 'blow me away' lol)

omakase was pretty decent for $25. ill be back just for that

everything else we ordered:
kobe beef was ok. not best thing ever.
hannukah roll? (i think thats what it was called. kinda sucked.)
family affair was pretty good
teriyaki chicken was pretty bland. 
tempura was fried: tasted 'normal'
ankimo was pretttty good.. my new favorite! :) [although $11 is a lil steep]


they were outta uni anddd oysters :(

and the wait kinda sucks, but ill definitely be back. :)
author: Lisa N.

description:
Amazing sushi I have to say. My daughters do not frequently eat seafood, but they loved the tofu here. The tofu is perfectly cooked and crispy on the outside. The sauce that it is served in is salty and warm and delicious. Good luck having my girls eat raw fish if it is not from Ebisu. They enjoyed every bite and so did I. 

In addition to the great food, the service was supreme and the chefs are very friendly.
author: Danny C.

description:
I came here for the first time today.  The space was pleasant enough.  My party of two was seated promptly.  A nice waiter explained the different types of sake and we ordered a sampler.   

The menu was much more pricey than most other sushi places.  Regardless, I was looking forward to trying out this place and having a nice lunch.  

While we were perusing the menu, another waiter came by and in a rude tone said to my partner, who was seated next to me, "Could you please move, this is a HUGE obstruction."  

UNACCEPTABLE.  We took our jackets and walked out of there.  We ended up at Perilla, and had an enjoyable lunch there instead.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Possibly the worse service I have had in years. 

Me: We're here for the happy hour.
Host: You want sushi bar?
Me: No Happy Hour.
Host: 5-6.
Me: Yes I know. 
Host: Draft beer only $1. 
Me: Yes, I know. 

My boyfriend and I were then seated. And our male server was actually pretty decent, however, the many  horrible female servers who did not know what they were doing and had nothing else to do prevented him from providing an enjoyable dinner service. It's not that they weren't trying either, they were just making stupid mistakes. I say they because each time something new pissed me off, it was a new female server. For example, I'm starved--the only reason I don't hold out for a cab to Katana-ya. BUT I had to wait to eat my first course because the girl who brought it decided that the moment you set down food is the moment you ask permission to slowly remove small items off the table because you can't hold dining ware in your hands. ANYONE in service knows utensils and any course changes are suppose to happen before the food gets there, so when it does the customer can eat. Ebisu on the other hand, brings me food without utensils. When I can finally get someone to give me utensils and stick a bite of fish in my mouth, another dumb girl comes by and asks me if she can take away the wrapper from my chopsticks. Again, our next chirashi bowl comes and of course as soon as I can get some food in my mouth, a girl comes by and asks if she can refill my tea. Imagine every few seconds, may I remove this bowl for you may I remove this cup for you may I remove this utensil for you may I refill this for you may I remove this trash. 

The icing on the cake was when the host was freaking out that people were waiting and tried to come to my table and serve us (the poor male server just trying to do his job saw and had a WTF on his face) to rush us out. Then when I was putting a card into the card holder, a rude server comes running over and picks up the bill (both hands) with my hand still inside it, closes it on my hand, and runs away. 

Ebisu, fire all your female servers and you'll make a lot more money.
author: Taun T.

description:
SO GOOD!! I really love this place!  The food is good, the service attentive, and the atmosphere is casual yet can be good for dates and such.  

I've had their rolls which you can get their creative ones or just normal rolls which are just as appetizing!  The bento box is a must have with so many things that come in it including my favorite seaweed salad!! The salmon teriyaki is yummyyyyy!! and the sashimi is fresh!

Good place to go to for lunch! or quant yet casual dinner date ;)
author: Nikkie P.

description:
If you are looking for high quality sushi with generous flavorful cuts, then this place is *NOT* for you.     If you are looking for relatively cheap sushi that isn't terrible, then this place may be for you.

1 star for the very attentive waitress
1 star for the pretty good hand-roll & the Asahi extra dry

Everything else was sub-par and there was a long line on top of it (why there was a wait is beyond me.....this food is definitely not quality food worth waiting for).   

Besides the hand-rolls and the beer:
We had the Swamp roll which looked great and whose ingredients are everything that I normally love to eat, but it too lacked flavor.

We ordered the 49er roll.  This roll, which looked good in the photo and in the description was practically all rice.   There were such thin pieces of salmon on top of it that you could barely taste the salmon.

And, we ordered the Cherry Blossom Roll.  Again, practically all rice, and very minimal flavor.

We ordered "Aji" (aka spanish mackerel), which was listed on their daily specials menu.   It never came, and when we asked about it, they said they had just run out.........strange, since we ordered it at 7:30pm and it stayed up on their daily special list until the time we left at 9pm.

Lastly, their regular soy sauce is ridiculously salty..... I have had soy sauce in a ton of places, but none anywhere close to as salty as what was at our table.

Our bill for the two of us $50 + tip, which I guess isn't bad for subpar sushi.    I personally would rather spend an extra $20-$40 and get some quality stuff bursting with flavor.    The places I have found in the Bay area that fit this bill so far are   "Sushi Tomi" in Mountainview, and Sushi Groove in SOMA.
author: Marc P.

description:
4.5 stars - wow, just wow.

We came here as a small group after visiting the Nitelife at Cal Sciences.  They are open kind of late and the food and service was excellent for 10pm on a Thursday evening.

Walking in it has clean lines, a modern/ traditional Japanese feel and the whole place just feels comfortable.  It's a smaller restaurant so it creates an intimate feel but without being cramped.  Everything seemed super clean and I love that, especially when eating raw fish.  Throughout our meal the tables were cleared and even after the work stations were done for the night they were throughly cleaned with a hose, soap and water.  Loved the atmosphere!  Great for a date or a group of friends.

Our waiter was fantastic.  He was really informative, efficient and curteous with a sense of humor.  Throughout our meal he was a just a pleasure and created an already great experience into a spectaucular one.  Another server was also happy to come and tell us some of the fish we couldn't pick out or describe our sake.  With a smile and geniune friendliness she added to a great time.

We all shared a sake sampler, $12.  Really a good selection, crisp, refreshing, good pours and really fun to share and discuss.  We started with a few of the appetizer specials and I was amazed.  The freshness of the fish, the combination of the flavors and the beautiful presentation all came together perfectly.  Even the miso soup was rich, flavorful and one of the best I've had.

I got a sushi combo to share and all the fish was top notch.  My favorite was the scallop - not usually but it was sweet and buttery and perfect.  The uni was also great, super fresh and a fairly large portion.  By the time I was done I was stuffed and full.  Luckily I had my boy there and friends because it is definitely plenty of food.

It isn't cheap though, but it certaintly it worth the price.  Go for some of the specials, really interesting and great quality.  For the quality of food, ambiance, staff and presentation I would come back in a heart beat.
author: Sabrina A.

description:
This is my ex-roommate's future husband's favorite sushi place, so I clearly had to give it a try.

Before I forget, did you notice that some reviewer named Jesse gave Ebisu 3 stars because it was closed on a Monday? That would like me deducting points because I got a splinter from my chopsticks.

Anyway, we sampled a few dishes, all of which were good but not exceptional:

- Ebisu Udon
- Yaki Gindara (warm sweet cod)
- Double Hamachi Roll
- Rainbow Roll

For $50, good variety and quantity. The real issue was time...

This was THE slowest service I have ever encountered. It took over an hour for him to get a hamachi roll. I could have walked to the ocean, rented a boat, and caught my own fish in the time it took to roll up some yellowtail. We were in the restaurant for over 1.5 hours.
author: Lou S.

description:
I hesitate to give Ebisu high marks because that will mean we will have an even harder time getting in! They open for dinner at 5 and we were there at 5:02 and were the 5th party in line.  Clearly, they are doing something right. 

We had Oyster Barnabi and Pink Cadillac as appetizers.  Both were lightly flavorful and just enough that our mouths were watering for our main courses, Teriyaki steak.  Some restaurants will say their main course is served on a bed of potatoes, quinoa, or what have you and they mean a twin bed at best. Our perfectly cooked, tender and very flavorful steaks were served on a king-sized bed of deliciously sauteed spinach with broccoli rabe, grilled crunchy carrots and just a few slices of Yukon Gold potatoes (superfluous as there was rice, too).  

One of the specials was tempura whole lobster tail. We didn't hear that until our entrees were on the table.  I'm by necessity gluten-free, but I would gladly do the meds for that deliciousness. 

Please, please don't go to Ebisu.  I want to go back!
author: Cheryl W.

description:
Awesome sushi, sake and beer!  

We have been taking a our visiting friend around to different sushi spots (since he doesn't get the same quality in Texas)  This place is most definitely at the top of our list.

I usually hate Spider Rolls because they have a fishy taste, but the one I had here was amazing!  They also made us a sashimi platter with 3 pieces of each fish so each of us could have one of our own.  So thoughtful!  

We got some cold sake that came in a cute vase-like bottle, and they were kind enough to wash our bottles and wrap them up for us to take home, since we showed interest.  (I later discovered that they were using the same bottle as a vase in their bathroom)  

The servers were very friendly, dishes were picked up quickly and drinks refilled before they were at the end.  I will most definitely be back!!!
author: Dina P.

description:
Pros:
Super fresh fish.
Best miso soup ever. 
Try the escolar xxx roll.

Cons:
Long wait times for tables
author: Cynthia J.

description: I LOVE Ebisu! Super fresh sushi (I could eat the 49er roll every day) and I love their reward program.
author: Lauren B.

description: Ebisu is my favorite Japanese restaurant in the city. I highly recommend the restaurant to anyone looking for an authentic sushi restaurant. Their seafood is always fresh and they have a great selection of sake that compliment the meal. Their appetizers are very good and I highly recommend their agedashi tofu, which I think is the best I've had in America. (originally from Japan).
author: Cody M.

description:
Very good sushi. The best? Not the best. I still think Tekka is the best sushi in SF. But Ebisu is very good. I love sitting at the counter. It can get loud in there since it's not a huge place and if you're sitting at a table you sort of have to scream but if you're at the counter it's much more intimate and you get the sushi right away from the sushi chef. 

Their dinosaur feet app is yummy and you can't go wrong with any of the nigiri sushi however if you like those fancy rolls those are good too.

....sushi chefs are dope. I need to learn how to make sushi.
author: David C.

description:
Man, I really REALLY wanted to like this place. I usually go to Kiki's cause it's cheap, but occasionally I wanted to treat myself to a good meal if I believe that I deserved it! 

So full disclosure: I didn't actually order any sushi. I had four appetizers all of which were disappointing. 

Kobe sashimi: I thought I would be getting beef carpacchio, but it was thick cut, and served at room temperature, not cold. The sauce it came with was hard to differentiate from EXTRA sodium soy sauce. 

Sake broth clams: bland, expect for the hints of gross fishiness. 

BBQ shrimp and chicken wing skewers: again, bland. Also dry

Sweet red beans served with red bean ice cream: I know, I know, why in god's name would I order dessert if the main course was so disappointing? Two words: sweet tooth. But not THAT sweet! The red bean stew thing was cook to a perfect texture, and them some genius poured a pound of sugar on it. Gross. 

The service however is nice, I'll probably give this place another try and only order sushi
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Came here yesterday for Valentine's Day dinner and the wait was pretty short; about 30 minutes before we were seated.  
Only thing I can complain about is that the seating area is so squished!  But the food quality and the service makes me forget that I am sitting next to the wall with my elbow almost touching the elbow of the person next to me...and we are not even sitting together in the same table.  Can't wait to go back!!!
author: judy l.

description:
Never had anything here I didn't like. The wait can get in the 30 min range but it's well worth it. it's fun to sit at the bar here and the sister restaurant across the street, hotei is amazing as well.
Suzuki is an amazing sushi chef and a delight to talk to. This is easily one of my favorite sushi places in the country.
author: eric f.

description: Love this place! Everytime I come here, I am in heaven. Their fish is just so fresh. They tend to give you big pieces too. Knocked off a price for the small and crowded restaurant and the difficulty to find parking in the Inner Sunset. A little on the expensive side as well. But you won't be disappointed if you come here to eat. I know I never am.
author: Brock W.

description:
The best combination of ambiance and sushi in the city of San Francisco. Ebisu is a small bustling restaurant in the heart of the foggy avenues of SF. It's an eclectic neighborhood that has a lot of good eats, but Ebisu is worth the visit (and wait if you go during primetime). The restaurant itself is incredibly inviting and clean. It's recent renovation was a fantastic way to bring a modern twist to what most sushi aficionados consider a SFS (San Francisco Staple).

The entire menu is as good as it gets for japanese food. Search no more for San Francisco's best overall sushi restaurant (and yes, I've been to Sebo and Blowfish) -- this is it.
author: Alex B.

description: My favorite sushi restaurant. My family and I have been coming here for over 10 years. Many tasty things on the menu. Try the Crunchy or Tootsie rolls.
author: Christian B.

description: Ebisu has quickly become our Friday night destination every time I come to visit the boyf in SF. Impressive -- and so far, all delicious! -- variety of menu items, both hot and cold, and the sushi is always fresh. Fantastic, friendly, and helpful wait staff easily give this place the 5 stars it deserves!!
author: Justine M.

description:
ahh it was goood! 

Super popular place, but i guess the whole area is considering i had to drive around the block like 3 times just so i could find metered parking. 

I'm also glad i went in alone. I feel bad for the people that came in as a couple, or group since i saw them waiting even after i got done eating. That and because i was seated at the bar before them. 

Sushi chef here was pretty cool, brought out a real down-to-earth relaxing, homey attitude amongst the customers. Really friendly, and fun to watch interacting with his customers. 

I was so disappointed though! I really really really, wanted to try the live uni! It was market priced at around 25, but seriously, how many other places serve whole live uni, and above that, a public display of its demise right before your eyes. Sad enough though the Chinese  table of 30 sitting directly behind me ordered the last two. 

I did still have the sashimi, which was nice, fresh and cool, excellently sized and slice slabs of ahi, maguro, salmon, hamachi and ika. And i still had to get my uni fix one way or the other, so i placed and order for uni nigiri. This also came out fresh, and cool. The highlight of my dining experience especially because i was so sadly denied of it after he sold the last two. 

He told me to come back the next Thursday. I wanted to scream sobbing, "Ill be gone by then but thanks for letting me watch you prepare it!" 

Next time i visit San Fran I will visit Ebisu once again, I'll be the first person waiting at the door before they open, and the first person to order live uni ftw!
author: Arthur S.

description: Five stars to bump the rating a bit and because they are in my hood! Love the Double Himachi roll, the Crunchy roll, the 49er, and more. Their miso soup is good, too.
author: McKay G.

description: Came here with some friends after some drinks on a slow week night. The specials were tasty, my bf had uni and said it was good. (He had to tell me, im good not knowing) I had a crunchy roll that was just ok. Everyone's food was fine, it was just the sub par service that made them get four stars. Ive been told its better when its busier, I guess ill have to come then.
author: Shannon D.

description:
5-stars for . . . Steve (the owner); for consistency, best-quality sushi I've ever had (even better than what I had in Tokyo) . . . and, for the price. If you want Hype, go to Blowfish, or whatever . . . this place (although the nice remodeling job, fancied it up a bit), is down-home, awesome sushi.

I used to go to this place twice a week, when I could afford sushi that often.
author: Peter B.

description: I have been to Ebisu for dinner many times in the past and went there for lunch yesterday with my friend.  For $15 you get a delicious bento box with 6 pieces of maki sushi, 4 or 5 pieces of sashimi, house salad, seaweed salad, assorted tempura, miso soup, and rice.  (There are other choices for the entrees but that was mine and I believe it is combo #2.)  The price is OK but the quality of my meal was superb!
author: Annie L.

description:
The highlight of Ebisu was, for me, the Cherry Blossom Roll. It was easily a high four star roll, while the other rolls I tried (Crunchy Roll, Poke Roll and the King California) were lower three stars at best. 

Despite showing up at 9pm on a Tuesday, I still had a bit of a wait for two people. The restaurant is well-designed, with a fairly diverse clientele. 

Boding against Ebisu: the fairly inattentive wait staff, as well as the general "blah-ness" of most of the rolls. I also tried the trio of edamame, but ended up disliking 2/3 of it (I wasn't a fan of the garlic or the lime-infused). 

I'm sticking to Sushi Bistro.
author: Tom A.

description: Sunday night with friends and family we waited for 30  min to be seated  , sushi and sashimi was GREAT! Service top notch ! Thanks.
author: SF G.

description: Not only does the inside of this place look chic and hip, the food looks just as cool.  It is the best sushi I have ever had.  This is my favorite sushi restaurant.  I have recommended it to many people and all have been pleased.  Ebisu ends up being everyone's favorite sushi restaurant.  The people that work there are SO kind.  The sushi is also not any more pricey than anywhere else.  If anything its less expensive.  This place will exceed your expectations of a sushi experience.  All of the other dishes that aren't sushi are just as amazing.
author: Stevy S.

description: As a native san Franciscan I can say that Ebisu is Absolutely the best sushi in San Francisco. The Rice is perfect. Ebisu is exquisite!
author: Slade N.

description:
I ordered my usual $35 worth of sushi along with one of my favorites, ikura, and a Dextercater.  I judge places on their ikura and Ebisu failed MISerably.  It smelled like it had been in the refrigerator too long.  I ate one because I had it in my mouth but right away, I began to feel queasy.  Someone joined us for a quick order, ordered the ikura and she wouldn't eat it - said it smelled off.  We sent the three pieces back and I made sure we weren't charged.  

The Dextercater roll and oshitashi was good so I'm leaving two stars, but I was thoroughly set back by slow service(seating and ordering), slow food arrival and crappy ikura.  Someone at he other end of the table had something go wrong with their sake order but I was fixated on my experience.

There are too many places to eat quality sushi for mistakes.  It's right near our friend's place and when they suggest HOtei ebisu, I'll have to back out.
author: Demetrius X.

description:
I may have found a new favorite sushi spot...

Stumbled in here last night looking for some good sunset eats and I was really impressed.  The fish is incredibly fresh and the ingredients are spectacular.  We had the following:

1.  Miso soup.  Warm and palate-cleansing.
1.  Goyza - savory and flavorful; loved the sesame dipping sauce.
2.  Behind the Green Door - had to try it - loved the skipjack and the creamy aioli was a refreshing touch.
3.  Louisiana Hot Link - looked interesting, so we gave it a try.  Yellowtail was delicious but the bonito flakes gave it a somewhat fishy demeanor.  My least favorite, but definitely not bad.
4.  Swamp - I will never eat plain 'ol spicy tuna again.  The seaweed salad on the top gave a good contrast to the spicy poke inside.
5.  Family Affair - best of the night.  All the fish simply melted in my mouth and left me wanting more (even thought I was completely stuffed).  The maui onions are a great addition, making everything taste fresh without overloading on flavor.  Loved the spice at the end.

Keep in mind that this is a very small place, so if you go expect to wait for a table (I don't think they take reservations).  Our service was fantastic, the staff was knowledgeable, and I loved the wood decor inside.  Highly recommended for anyone who loves good sushi; no doubt I will definitely be back again.
author: Drew W.

description:
I love sushi, but haven't had it in a couple of years due to a few factors. One, I was pregnant from June '08 until March '09, and sushi is discouraged for pregnant ladies. Two, I'm allergic to gluten, and the thought of navigating a menu laden with fried batter and soy sauce was enough to keep me away. But tonight, I felt like reuniting with one of my old favorite cuisines. 

At Ebisu, I was limited mostly to the sushi (and nigiri, at that), so it's a good thing they sat me at the sushi bar. My chef helped me pick out some rolls and other things I could have, and he stuffed me full of fresh, delicious fish. One of the waiters initially steered me away from most of the items from the kitchen, but came back to tell me that they could make the bacon-wrapped asparagus and mochi gluten-free. It didn't take much to sell me on that one. 

The fish was super-fresh and delicious, with generous pieces of fish on the nigiri. My favorite was the saba; I wound up ordering seconds. The bacon-wrapped asparagus was also a treat. 

Amusingly, I was seated next to someone who had also been tested for a gluten allergy, and a woman on the other side of me was allergic to shellfish. The chefs handled everyone's needs admirably. 

Amazing food, wonderful service, happy tummy. Thanks, Ebisu!

(A tip for celiac sufferers who like sushi: bring your own wheat-free tamari in a small bottle.)
author: Beth W.

description:
Fantastic place for Japanese food.  I personally love the teriyaki chicken, but the sushi rolls are also fantastic.  They have new specials every day so be sure to ask.  Seating can be a little tight since Ebisu is so popular and for good reason. 

We will be coming back at least once a month!
author: Christian M.

description: Changing this to 5-Stars because sitting at the Bar with the Sushi Chef's made it an even more amazing experience. The sashimi is always super fresh, and if you let them, they will get creative and concoct a special surprise dish which is always extra tasty. One of the Chef's was missing an ingredient and had someone run to the store to get it to make a special role for us. That's what I call customer service! Highly, highly recommend the Fresh Scallops, and prices are very reasonable for the City.
author: Emily B.

description:
Long wait, even though we got there early-ish...but it was a Sunday. Delicious sushi-all fresh and good quality fish. The miso with clams hit the spot. Lively atmosphere...hard to park nearby.
All in all a good night out with friends.
author: Kyla L.

description:
I will gladly drive over the GG bridge to eat here. it is only a 15 minute drive from Sausalito, and well worth it. The fish is extremely fresh and wonderful. The decor, warm and inviting. I sat at the sushi bar, and Ricky the sushi chef was informative, nice, and made me feel comfortable sitting there. I usually opt for a table since I am a bit shy, but as soon I was walked in, I felt it was not intimidating so sat at the bar. 

All the fish I ate was outstanding and at a very reasonable price. 

It has Sushi Ran beat hands down for quality, service  and price.

On Tuesdays during lunch, they have a $30.00 Omakase tasting menu. Great deal! I will report back when I go!
author: Christine E.

description:
Overpriced for what is was

Years ago the sushi at Ebisu was so much better. I think the quality totally went down, and they are just trying to cash in on their good reputation. The sushi was ok, but at their prices, I think you find much better places in S.F.
author: Carol Y.

description:
I came here for lunch thinking that I'd have to wait for an hour to get seated, but I only had to wait for 15 minutes. The sushi was good, but I think a lot of people blow this restaurant way out of proportion. It's not the best sushi restaurant in the city or anything, but it's one of the better ones. I've never had the sashimi, but I had the caterpillar roll - not bad.

 I really don't like the atmosphere of the restaurant, and I think the service was shitty. Not super impressed.
author: Christine A.

description:
- the wait could be long
- dragon roll is delicious

Awesome. Done.
author: Roll N.

description:
My friend had been ranting and raving about how this is the best sushi she's ever had and that we needed to come here some time, so while I was out with some friends and we were craving sushi, this is where we ended up.

I don't know if I came on an off night, but after eating here, I seriously went home and double checked to see if we went to the right restaurant. From the way this place was described to me, I was expecting to have a gastronomical orgasm. 

I looked at their specials board and was disappointed to see that they didn't have the lobster sashimi. They had 3 different kinds of toro, but I decided to stick with the menu food. 

They have genmaicha here, which is a plus, most restaurants serve plain green tea (which is supposed to be more expensive), but I like the flavor of genmaicha better. The rolls were good, but not special, and their sashimi didn't seem very fresh. The service was horrible, we waited 30 minutes to eat here and had to hang out in the weird San Francisco fog outside while we were waiting to be seated. Water/tea refills were very slow, and it took a long time to pay our bill and get out of there.

I felt REALLY bad for exposing my friends to Ebisu when I promised them an extraordinary sushi experience. I guess I'll learn to actually eat at a restaurant first, before talking about how good it is.
author: Grace Y.

description: Mmmm came in for a birthday dinner with my friends-- there is a bit of a wait (15 minutes or so) but the food is excellent and fresh. I ordered the 49er roll in reverence of the mighty SF 49ers who advanced to the NFC Championship this year. But I would order this roll any day-- it's so light and refreshing with those paper thin slices of lemon on top. I also ordered the caterpillar roll and my friends got the bento boxes with the enormous portions. Come for the delicious sushi and the nice service.
author: Patricia M.

description:
My niece was craving sushi for her 15th birthday, and I'm glad I trusted all of the other Yelpers out there! We went on a beautiful Saturday afternoon- there were plenty of tables open as well as a few seats at the counter.

The sushi chef and wait staff were very patient and answered all of her questions about the different rolls they had. I ordered  a kobe beef roll and a bento box. Everything was fresh and tasty (and I am NOT a fan of sushi)

My niece ordered the #29 as well as the sea urchin. She loved the #29, and also eating some of my food. She wasn't a huge fan of the sea urchin though. My wife ordered one of the bento boxes as well. 

Great experience, the staff was all very patient and friendly; and the food was fresh and delicious. Thanks to Ebisu for giving my niece a nice birthday lunch!
author: Brian E.

description:
I don't normally hop online immediately after an either good or bad experience and write up a review but Ebisu deserves the best treatment possible - because that is what we received when we dined there tonight. 

I didn't feel like cooking and we both got off work late, so my wonderful husband treated me to a night out. Earlier this spring (4/20), we had been on a walk home when some guys on the street caught our attention ;-) and in the process they gave us the low down on a few great places to eat lobster in town. The one that stuck out was for Ebisu, where they claimed we could get lobster tempura. 

Well, it was nothing short of amazing. I don't know if it is available all the time but I highly recommend it. We also got some of the best, freshest hamachi I have had in a long time, if ever. 

Not only was the sushi fresh, we were served quickly and cheerfully. Our 2 top was quiet and in the back of the room, but we were served immediately and in and out in about 45 minutes! Also, the price was right - 2 special rolls, a kitchen special and 2 orders of hamachi with a bottle of nigori for under $80. 

We will definitely be back!
author: Katie D.

description: Best sushi in the neighborhood that I've had so far! Rolls are a bit pricey but probably about average for SF. It was the only rainbow roll I've ever had with fried shrimp. Not my preference, but it was good I'll admit. I still think the Richmond has superior food in this realm, but Ebisu was awesome.
author: Lauren C.

description:
I love sushi and consider myself a connoisseur and i can without a doubt say....this is one of the best sushi places I've been to in San Francisco that is filled with awesome sushi places. 

You have to get a spicy scallop hand roll...it's the best I've had. 

We ordered a XXX roll which is the sushi chef's special roll of the day. It was a shrimp tempura roll (and it was the perfect amount of tempura...lightly battered and fried...very fresh) with benito/katsu fish (like a darker tuna) on top with thinly sliced onions, tobiko, green onions and a very light mayo based sauce....I think i creamed my pants after the first bite. 

We got to the restaurant when it opened and we were the second group seated....by the time we finished our miso soup there was a sea of people waiting to get in. 

It was awesome!
author: Philip H.

description: Would love to agree with the other reviewers about the quality of the food, but we never made it inside. Went for a special birthday dinner, was told 30 mins. (went early), then we waited more than an hour while dozens of people who came later were seated first. Eventually the hostess told us it would be much longer and she sent us to the dingy sister restaurant across the street. Really doesn't matter how good the food is if they don't give a crap about new customers. Don't bother unless you're a good friend of the staff or you love waiting.
author: Spud H.

description: I think this place was great and worth the wait.  The lobster dynamite and sake  steamed clams were too die for.  The hamachi kama (yellow tail cheek) was succulent and the overall quality of the sushi was excellent.  However, the ikura could used more eggs as you don't want too see rice through the eggs.  Spicy tuna roll tasted "oniony '?? .  Definite come back. Four star service.
author: rino f.

description:
Its gotten better the last couple times ive eaten here.  Soft shell crab is delicious, the tako, umi masu, maguro, and hamachi are fresh and melt in your mouth like butter.  Im beginning to keep Ebisu on my go-to sushi list.  And the nigori sake is so good -   careful though, you might end up ordering multiple bottles before your food even comes out.  This is always my mistake.  But what a tasty mistake it is.

Though its a pretty popular spot in the area and usually very busy, ive never been left waiting more than 10 minutes.
author: Juv C.

description:
After a long day at work, the bf and I wanted some yummy sushi. Fortunately, Ebisu did not disappoint. They seated us pretty quickly but our waitress didnt come by for a good 15 minutes to ask about drinks. sadface

We ordered their oyster appetizer, the cherry blossom roll, double hamachi and the roll #29 ( or was it #26?). The oysters were awesome! It was baked with uni, some kind of thick creamy sauce and topped with masago. y u m m y! 

The double hamachi and roll #29 was really good and fresh. it satisfied my/our sushi cravings. However, I wasnt a fan of the cherry blossom roll It was poorly made; the salmon was falling off  the sides and the avocado filling tasted weird. Hence, 4 not 5 stars.
author: Stacy L.

description:
I would not call this my favorite Sushi place for a few reasons:
1. Price to quantity ratio is way high compared to similar restaurants
a. I would expect much more sushi for the price
2. Quality is on par with other sushi restaurants
a.  Exception is a Tuna Handroll - avoid at all costs.  It was one of the worst handrolls I've ever tried
3. Variety of sushi is not much different from other places
4. They don't take reservations
5. It is extremely difficult to find parking

There are, however, some positive things that I can share about Ebisu:
1. Service is great - waiters are very patient
2. Fish seems to be fresh
3. Interior design is great
4. The place is CLEAN (which is very important)
author: P F.

description:
LOVE this place. My favorite sushi restaurant across the county.
