Service is impecable! The entire staff works as one team. It we put anything on the edge of the table for pick up, it's gone in less than 30 seconds. They're not pushy about what you order (just how it's served!). Sometimes the service hovers around the "We just want to flip this table asap" side, but it's still the best we get in this city.

Ordering: You can either order the full meal all at once, or a few items at a time.

Food: Served in the traditional sushi master style, where the sushi is made with such great balance of flavor and texture that no extra soy sauce or ginger should be needed. If you eat at the bar, they serve you just the right amount of condiments. If you eat at a table, no one will judge you for adding extra soy sauce or ginger. The seaweed salad is the freshest I've ever had. The rolls are just amazing. I do wish they had a couple more vegetarian rolls, but I have a good enough time that I can excuse the fewer options.
author: Zee S.

description: packed to the gills on a Sunday night.  Humming with people but you can still hear your table talk.  I really enjoyed this place.  Although I dont believe it would be my go to sushi place, I would go again.
author: Mark M.

description:
i had an awful experience here. i really wanted to like it, the decor was cute and i love sushi... however it was just terrible! 

the sushi came with a piece of plastic inside of it -- how does that happen -- and the waitress was too busy to ever bring over water. i'm very disappointed. i also got sick after eating here. :( super sad.
author: Hello G.

description:
I had always wondered, as a Japanese native, why Americans rave about Ebisu. There has never been anything special about it, except snobbishness.

Tonight, the owner's wife treated me like I was retarded when I inquired about our reservation. Sure enough, when my boss, who knows the owner, showed up, the wife completely changed her attitude. WTF, it's one thing to serve mediocre food; it's another to pretend you are a five star restaurant. Well, let's see how this would go...
author: K S.

description: I love this place..... only thing had to wait a bit for a table...... but their sushi is one of the best. Will see u soon !!!
author: Boris M.

description:
Great sushi, extensive saki list, and fantastic atmosphere.

My husband and I are frequent diners at Ebisu. I think our favorites are the crunch roll and lobster tempura. The edamame trio is also a very good, interesting twist to the standard edamame appetizer. 

Our least favorite was the swamp roll.
author: Beth D.

description: This was a birthday lunch with co-workers and it was a success. I ordered the teriyaki chicken and dragon rolls which came with miso soup. The miso soup was very flavorful and warmed me up. I think we ordered so much food we couldn't finish it all. I have the left overs with me at home. I think I will visit Ebisu again especially since it's within walking distance from my work place.
author: Mia B.

description: THIS PLACE CHARGES AN EXTRA 5% ON ALL TAKE-OUT ORDERS!  AND THEY TRY TO HIDE IT FROM YOU BY NEVER GIVING AN ITEMIZED RECEIPT WITH TAKE-OUT.  I've been ordering from here for over a year and just found this out.  There is plenty of equally good (and better) sushi in the area: sushi Kazu and Koo to name a few.  I love to support local business, because I feel they are more honest than large corporations.  I am sad to say I will not be returning to Ebisu any time soon.
author: shelby p.

description: The bento combo boxes are great. The teriyaki salmon tastes delicious.
author: Nico. P.

description:
Great place! great food!

The bad - nothing to do with the restaurant but the area surrounding it, no parking AT ALL! don't bother driving there between 6 and 10 pm, it is almost impossible to find parking! I circled around for 40 min and found a spot 6 blocks away!! :-P 

My friend was really generous and offered to buy me dinner at Ebisu, and when I heard it's a "company paid" dinner, I thought lets try all the expansive stuff :-D why not!!? 

Fresh! all the sea food we got tasted so fresh! toro, uni, sashimi... no fishy smell at all! my other friend who lived in Japan for many years also said the sahimi dishes were great!

I ordered Kobe beef nigiri, but right now I cannot recall what it tasted like, next time I will have to get the sashimi beef plate, I think that will allow me to "get to know" the beef better :-P the waiter told me those were imported Kobe. Live scallop dish is a must have!!! it was the first time for me, and I absolutely loved it! Toro and Uni ... so fresh! so good! Toro just melts in your mouth!

We ordered the usual rolls, california, dragon, Caterpillar etc, and they were all above my expectation. grilled chicken wings, grilled fish cheek are fantastic! the hamachi kama was a bit on the dry side, but very flavorful.  if you have not tried Chawanmushi (steamed egg in a cup) before, give it a try.

Service wise, we waited for about 30min because we missed our reservation spot, the manager was very nice to us, and squeezed us in even though the line was long. 

Check out photos posted by me.
author: Joe H.

description:
Good sushi, good decor, good service, all in all great experience!

The fish is very fresh and their roll very yummy.  Plus the sushi chefs are great, we always have a great time chilling and talking and joking around with the chef.  Too bad we can't buy them a beer, stupid law!

O the waitresses are cute, that helps too!

Sometimes there might be long wait, so try to make a reservations.  But you know what? well worth the wait everytime!

They also have tables really backed up into each other so claustrophobic need not to show up here on weekend nights.  

They also have this discount card thing where you can get points for eating there and eventually getting 10% off? I think.  

They are not open on Sunday so be wary when you plan your trip!
author: Jacky T.

description: Wow!  The artistry from this place is amazing. The plates look sooo good that i didn't want to mess it up by eating it. But i was hungry. :)  It FREAKING tastes better than it looks. Amazing. Try the dinosaur foot. It's my favorite.
author: Dee L.

description: Sat at the sushi bar and the chefs were fun and friendly.  Sushi was fresh and delicious.  Not an overwhelming amount of rolls but good variety.  Was tempted by the "Louisiana Hot Link"roll and while it tastes and smells like the name, I wouldnt get it again.   Also, be prepared to wait as it's quite popular.
author: C W.

description:
I am from Toronto, Ontario and this place is amazing. Sushi and Sashimi will never be the same back home 

Food: They have tons of different rolls but I mainly had the nigiri and it was all melt in your mouth type of sushi. The one I liked the most was the hamachi toro. As for the rolls the Arch Deluxe was really good especially if you like soft shell crab. 

Service: The service is second to none. They were very accommodating even though the place was almost closing when we got there. Always engaging and asking if we were okay and filling up our drinks with out us even asking. 

Highly recommended especially if you are visiting from out of town. 

VS
author: Vince S.

description:
The don't get 5 stars because the seating is inefficient.  The food is great, but unless you are at the sushi bar, seating for even a 3 top is tough.  I thought their sushi/sashimi dinners were well priced, the portions were good sized, and the chefs to not overload the wasabi.  

It sucked climbing over folks after our dinner ended.
author: Pablo E.

description:
Sushi is ok, but a bit overpriced for what they offer. 
However, always crowded and noisy, cramped and seating not so comfortable.

For the price, I would definitely always go to Jimisan just up the street...
author: D T.

description: Anticipated a delicious meal but was disappointed. Not worth the wait, always a line out the door. Fish was fresh but have had way better sushi rolls and entrees elsewhere. Not worth a return.
author: Meredith S.

description: ok NEVER coming back. if you call to pick up and they say "30 minutes" then 30 minutes it should be. we arrived on the dot, at the specified time to be told our order was being packed. if it were 5-10 minutes late, well that is mildly passable. we have been waiting a total of 75 minutes so far (ie 45 minutes over the f due). packed order, they didnt start preparing it til i yelled at someone. wait staff are as rude and incompetent as they come. questions? restaurant want to discuss? no didnt think so.
author: Marcus D.

description:
Came here once on a Wednesday night for my birthday with my parents and a second time for my sister's birthday on a Sunday evening (long weekend).

My parents kept talking about a sushi place off Irving and they finally decided to take me there for my birthday.  We sat at the sushi bar and we were offered exceptional service.  The owner and his son were so funny and they kept a good vibe going with everyone sitting at the sushi bar.  We tried a lot of food including the mud pie (not a fan, because im not a fan of uni), the ice bucket (which was really good!), chawan mushi (always my favorite), and a good selection of sushi rolls and nigiri.  I loved the kobe beef sushi. I could not stop raving about it to my sister, which is why we had to come back a second time for her birthday.  We also had one of the specials which was a giant scallop (I think) or something like that. It was really fresh and delicious.  

Ebisu is a little on the pricey side, will still always be a favorite.
author: Christine L.

description:
Very traditional sushi, not a lot of creativity.  All of the ingredients were fresh and high quality.  Sashimi was small but very high quality. Monk fish liver was some of the best I've had.  Rolls were solid but not as bursting with taste as I'd like.

Service is good. They kept my water and tea filled the entire time.

Prices seem more expensive than $$.

I doubt I'll go out of my way to go back.
author: Peter G.

description:
Really yummy sushi here & excellent customer service + super fresh fish. Quick service and delicious food!!
In a great area with lots of other stuff to do - like go to the park to walk off all that sushi!
author: Diana T.

description: Stopped by for lunch, coming back to the bay after two years away.  My wife remembered it fondly and was, I think, happy with the return.  I unfortunately can't say I thought much of it.  It's sushi, and was somewhat acceptable, but really no more than that.
author: Craig L.

description: Wow! The artistry from is place is amazing. The plates look sooo good that I didn't  want to mess it up by eating it. But I was hungry:)  It freakin tastes better than it looks. Delicious!!! Try the dinosaur foot . It's my favorite.
author: Sunnie W.

description:
I hadn't been here since they remodeled, and I must say that I'm pretty impressed. I was just expecting to come here thinking that the interior was going to look different, but they up'd the entire restaurant. Not only did the remodel change the look of the place, but they have taken the opportunity to change the menu as well, and even the way they plate food now looks nicer. 

The good things stayed the same....like how it's still really family owned and operated. How Steve(husband) is running the kitchen in the back, Coko(wife) is overseeing the floor, and Eric(son) is now working at the sushi bar. They are always so personable and so many regulars come in because of this.

Now, the new things:
They now have sapporo and kirin on TAP, people. YES!!!! Now THAT'S what I'm talking about! They also have these mixed drinks that are soooo good. I think I almost made my "O" face drinking their Melon Breeze that had watermelon juice, nigori sake, and YUZU (oh, i love yuzu!).

We ordered some of the classics....natto maki, tobiko, amaebi (which I think Ebisu carries some of the best around the neighborhood), 49er, and QP roll. The amaebi heads came out fried with a dab of shichimi (japanese red pepper) and green tea salt, which made the dish very classy. I think one of my favorite things about this sushi joint compared to others is that the flavors aren't overdone. I'm all about the simplicity of flavors when it comes to raw fish. Even though rolls are a completely American-invented thing, I hate it when I go to sushi joints and get rolls completely drenched in unagi sauce or topped with too many different layers of fish after fish or just way over-fried.

We also tried a new item, the Panko Fried Oysters which came out w/this chili yuzu aioli. OMG, this was orgasmic. Although, I couldn't really taste the yuzu, it was still deeeelicious! 
By this point, we were pretty full, but I definitely want to come again to try other new things from their menu. 

The only downfall was that I missed the zashiki room, which they took out and made an extra bathroom instead, but I completely understand why they did it. As a customer, it had that authentic appeal to it, but as someone who once worked there, it was a BITCH to get in and out of because you always had to take your shoes off to go in. I remember when coming out of there carrying empty plates and glasses once and ATE IT....

Anyway, this place really improved....2 extra stars worth since my last review!
author: Emy s.

description:
Ebisu will always hold a special place in my heart because it was the first date in SF with my (now) fiance. 

The chefs are real artists. It is the most beautiful sushi in the city without sacrificing any of the flavor. They do traditional rolls the best and also have tasty innovative rolls. They have a great staff that are willing to make a recommendation. 

They have been a little busier since their remodel so you might have to wait for a table if you go during peak hours. Try to go early on a weeknight, but if you can't its worth the wait. 

Let Ebisu into your heart, let the miso soup warm your soul.
author: Halley B.

description:
I want to be as honest as possible.. our service was HORRIBLE!!! 
I felt rushed and we did arrive about an hour before lunch ended. I understad the restarant business, as i was a server for 6 years, and i was dissapointed. On a positive note... the BENTO box WAS AMAZING!!!!!! i had the salmon and sushimi box. 

id like to also clarify one thing, it really was only our srever who was rude.. the rest great!!!!!
author: Christina P.

description:
Yes, I am a fan! 

The hubs and I come here often.  It is consistently good, and the sushi is fresh and yummy.  It isn't the best sushi that I have ever had, but it is  good and affordable and nearby.  The lunch specials are amazing and the wait is never too bad.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
What to say... my first night out on a mission to hunt for a good eat. I was craving for fish at one point cause I was generally getting tired of eating steak and having to eat stuff at the house so I decided to do a hunt to eat at irregular times of the day.

What to expect / what I had:

- Omakase
- Chirashi
- 2 cups Onigoroshi
- Sukiyaki [take home order]

When I first entered that night there was a couple that was waiting to be seated before I was. Since I am usually a solo patron and when I was waiting to be seated I didn't really expect to see this place be really busy, but it was :O

The lady that was taking the people to be seated looked really.. really worried somehow. I was pretty patient to be seated cause I didn't really mind on where to sit at the time. When my time was up and she asked me if I didn't mind having a seat at a table instead. I didn't mind but I was in the middle of everybody else at the same time Owo! 

A friend of mine told me that when you are seated in the middle of a place by yourself you are to be expected to be an honored guest. I didn't understand what that meant but I took it as a compliment. At first I felt odd seated at a table that's good for 4 people but I shrugged it off. The place was filled with people from table to table. I was surprised that the middle table in the center of the room wasn't taken up by more than a a few guests. Sometimes, you feel a bit odd when you're in the very middle when you're eating by yourself with no companions.
 
The waitress was nice and took my order right away. I just started off with a glass of water and then ordered my first cup of Onigoroshi (lit. "demon slayer / killer"). Then I took my order of having 1 order Omikase and followed up with an order of Chirashi. When the Omikase came out it was the chef that was the one that presented it and served me telling me what he cut. O_o~! I don't usually get that type of service out of the blue  but it was nice to have. It was excellent I had much of the wasabi since it would have been a waste to use too little of it. All I can say is whats a good sashimi meal without a cup of sake or alcohol to go with it. I decided to go with the onigoroshi this time because I didn't really feel like plum wine. After my first eat was done I pretty much did the same thing with the Chirashi set. By then I was full, I didn't have time for desert but I did want to take something home so I ordered a Sukiyaki :)

My only downside was that when I ordered my Sukiyaki to go the broth must had something special about it to eat through the paper bowl packaging. D: At least... it didn't leak past the plastic bag it was contained in cause that night was very foggy / misty. 

I left being full and was happy with everything afterwards the waitresses were nice and smiled back. Also the one that seated me thanked me for dining there before leaving. You know when you leave there are times it should be like this. I'll have to come back again on a special occasion.... :D
author: Xeirhen V.

description: Best agedashi tofu you will ever consume in your entire life. Also the guys behind the Sushi bar are super funny and accommodating, and they always make sure you get a cutely cut up orange at the end of your meal. 5+ stars.
author: Camilo D.

description:
After desperately searching for a place to eat on a late Friday night, the BF and I landed on Ebisu. I really liked the inside--it was spacious and reminded me of a Japanese restaurant I really liked in my hometown. 

As for the food, I thought it was okay.  The BF ordered a sushi combo while I ordered the tonkatsu bento box. The fish wasn't watery, but it didn't taste super fresh either. The tonkatsu was definitely not as good as DeliCa's either. Our two dishes ended up being around $40 after tax and tip. Final verdict is that I wouldn't mind coming back here and trying something else.
author: Angela L.

description: This is my absolute favorite restaurant in the entire world. They have the best hirami (halibut) and the freshest tai (snapper).  I could tell the tai was fresh because it was super pink. I also like the way the way they season the rice with soy sauce before serving. The chalkboard specials were extraordinary especially the blue fin tuna.==
author: Jane D.

description: It's a nice place for Japanese food and have a nice time.  The only bad thing is a small place, so, you have to make reservation,  unless you want to be outside waiting for a table!
author: Cesar Jose C.

description:
There's not really much to say about Ebisu.  I had lunch there.  The food was serviceable but entirely unremarkable and forgettable.   

Fried tofu was just OK. Very little hint of frying.  Not too much taste.

A bento box had some chicken teriyaki that was chicken, some shrimp and vegetable tempura that was shrimp and vegetables, and some sushi that was sushi. All undistinguished.

If you are starving.  Don't die.  Come here as it's not too expensive.
author: David D.

description:
I went shortly after they finished renovations and it was kind of a disaster.  

It can be summed up by: They ran out of rice.  

Yup. They ran out of rice...a SUSHI restaurant in the inner sunset.    It caused about a 45 min delay, while me and my sisters were starving. Eventually they brought some over from Hotai, across the street (apparently same owners).

We weren't asked if we'd like anything else and one of the waiters spilled water over someone due to the very cramped design.

The food was fine...not great but good.  

But for as may sushi places as there are in SF....I'd say you can probably do better.
author: Matthew B.

description:
We got there right at the beginning of service. 

Loved, loved, loved that the chefs were playful and so helpful! They let me pet the live sea urchin at the Sushi Bar. Of course, right after, one of the chefs told me "You touched it, now you have to buy it" and started laughing. I love laughter with my meals.

Don't let the exterior fool you, the inside is well done. Great sushi experience!

Had my first raw scallop here. Boy, was it delicious! Not afraid to try things when I know the quality is there.
author: Payal P.

description:
This place is tiny and it get's packed! A very nice zen sushi spot. I am not a big fan of their overpriced sushi but everything else was good. Their oysters were fresh and served cold, very mouth watering.


Ebisu is a memorable spot where I tried my first live sea urchin. It was suculent, weird but it melts in your mouth like butter. It was practically moving when it was served. The chefs there are quite entertaining, well one guy was. He was really nice and made the experience pleasant.
author: Tam T.

description:
Loved my experience here. I have heard great things about this place and it totally met my expectation. The fish is very fresh which makes the texture of the fish just melt in your mouth! :D  

I started with the miso soup, which is a big deal to me. I hate watered down miso, and i hate miso that has powdery texture. There miso was on point. Flavorful yet not too overwhelming.

We ordered a sampler sashimi plate that had yellowtail, tuna, salmon, and another fish i can't remember but it was very very good. Again, texture and freshness was amazing! 

Overall, this place was great! Service was fast and waiters were very nice and knew how to answer our questions so I give this place 5 stars .. and I will be back here for sure!
author: Irene K.

description:
Ebisu is trendy, cozy, and the food is great. I would come here with friends, or family, or maybe a date. Maybe.

The restaurant is small. The decor is simple and delivers a warm, inviting feel. 

I ordered the salmon teriyaki dinner. The salmon was moist and juicy. I loved it. The miso soup was just right. A friend of mine ordered the rainbow roll and she seemed to like it. 

The only downside is that service was very rushed! We were asked if we wanted to order while still looking at the menus. The waitress asked many times if we were finished. Our check came quickly. I know that this place is busy and that they want to seat the starving people that are waiting in line at the front of the restaurant..but I don't like being rushed!

I would still definitely recommend this place. It probably isn't the place for a slow paced romantic date or to catch up with a friend that you haven't seen in 10 years. But you know, its your call. Even if the service is rushed, it doesn't necessarily mean that you have to be. They probably aren't that busy every night anyway. 

The right blend of food and ambiance is enough to lure me back in. Until next time, Ebisu.....
author: Lena A.

description: My favorite japanese restaurant in the city! Their uni is fantastic. I love their rolls (esp. the XXL). Their lobster dynamite is a killer. And their red bean ice cream is fantastic. The ambiance is great: everything is in wood. Only problem: the line can be very long so it is better to go around 9:30pm...
author: Jinouchou T.

description:
First time here. And yes I'll come back.

Nicest-looking interior design I've ever seen for sushi restaurant. The sushi bar is all wooden and it looks really nice. Their tableware are gorgeous. All white. Every piece looks great. I even love the way they fold their napkins.

The waitresses did a very good job. I can't find anything to complain about their service. 
 
The reason I didn't give them 5 stars is the price. I ordered 2 rolls. Delicious, but a little too small in size for that price. However, their grilled eels are different from most sushi places I've been to. Crunchy, but tender.  Delicious! The other roll I tried was good, not great. 

I didn't try their sashimi but saw it from my neigbor's table. They looked really appetizing. Great knife cut, indeed.

They also have the best tasting miso soup. And it's free.
author: Sue R.

description:
I have been going to Ebisu since 1998, and seen its steady stream of customers and loyal fans swing in and out, me included. Ebisu should be branded as a SF restaurant institution with its 30+ years of longevity especially in this quick, fast, up, and burn dining industry in SF. The recent transformation is absolutely amazing and hopefully it buys an eternal business life, at the discretion of the owners and not the economy.

The remodel included astounding handwork on industrialist and minimalist wood cuts. The position of each piece of wood deflects harsh halogen lighting to set a balanced ambiance. The tatami room was sacrificed for 2 nice bathrooms, which I appreciate the practicality when human nature calls.

The menu kept the oldies and goodies and has been spruced up with fresh specials and omakase listings on the board. Some of my loves are fresh scallops and uni cracked right before you. The smoked salmon salad was a pleasant tasty surprise: strips of salmon tasted like an Alaskan lox bagel on a bed of salad. When I can not decide on a sushi roll to accompany my sashimi and nigiri-based meals, the Triple XXX roll with rotating fish on the specials board assists with a quick executive order. As mundane as gyoza can be at other places, the dumpling are DELICIOUS at Ebisu, definitely worth ordering! The special sake and soju drinks are lightly flavored and pairs great with dinner.

Everytime I think of sushi night, Ebisu is amongst my top 3 sushi rotation. I have to admit the remodel drew me back after a few years of being MIA. The sushi is as fresh as ever.
author: Cathy H.

description:
I'm very sad to give Ebisu two stars, as they used to be very high on my list of sushi restaurants. But sadly, I need to do so after visiting Ebisu since their recent remodel. 

Overall, I think they did a nice job of trying to create a modern Japanese zen-like environment. The new waiting area feels more like a dentist's office or a spa, but it's nice. 

We were seated fairly quickly in the main room - maybe 20 min wait, which isn't bad by Ebisu's standards. It was super loud in the main dining room. Louder than I remember. Worst thing, was that the new recessed lighting in the ceilings is highly unflattering, not to mention that one of those little bulbs was directing right into my eye. At our table, you were either blinded by the light, or it was too dark to see the food or menu. 

The menu has been all jazzed up, perhaps the prices increased too? Sake flights??? Come on people - the whole thing just seemed a little pretentious to me. Our server seemed to have a personality disorder. His affect was just odd. I'm sure he was new and nervous. He barely said a word to us. 

I do still love the QP and Arch Deluxe rolls. 

Ebisu definitely disappointed us since their remodel. I'm sorry to say that I doubt we'll be back. We miss the old Ebisu.
author: Anne Y.

description:
Heard good things about this place so I decided to come with my sister and dad. There was a one-minute wait but it's negligible. I read in another review that the menu was exactly the same as the sister restaurant, Hotei, across the street but my sister pointed out that there was no ramen anywhere on paper. Darn, I wanted a wide variety to try out all the goodies. That's likely the distinguishing point between the two restaurants. 

The atmosphere was very unique and kind of warm but noisy. The ceilings aren't very high so even if all the tables don't have hungry foodies blabbing, it'll still echo noises. The staff are very welcoming and are attentive 90% of the time, I mean they are only human! 

We took a lot of time to analyze the menu but it was pretty worthwhile to do so. A few of the quick tips suggested the Kobe beef sushi so we got that, the teriyaki chicken dinner, katsu dinner, dragon roll (see pic), and the crunchy roll. Aside from the miso soup, the Kobe beef came first. It was a mere 2 piece, which disappointed me since I was hoping that each one of us could try at least one piece if not 1.5-2 pcs each. It was alright...I didn't think too highly of it and was hoping the rainbow roll would make up for that. The next dish was the teriyaki chicken dinner followed by the katsu dinner. The salad was a giant heap, good thing. The chicken had a good texture to it. The katsu was very ordinary, at least to me, even with the sauce. My rainbow roll was yummy! I highly recommend it!! After all three of us nearly finished the dishes, we still were not satiated so we ordered the deluxe sushi dinner which is composed of tuna, salmon, scallop, yellowtail tuna, clam, salmon roe, sea urchin, unagi, and CA rolls (see pic). It's a sampler dish for the amateur sushi eater with one of each except the CA rolls. 

Our bill was $81. High in our wallets but it was a good experience. I think we'll come back if the random occasion arises again.
author: Dominic T.

description:
This sushi restaurant is definitely up there. The service and food is excellent. This restaurant creates an intimate feel because it's a smaller restaurant but at times you can feel cramped! Great for dates and gathering with friends.

The sushi here is good and the fish is fresh. For the price I pay, I'd rather go to sushi sams in San Mateo.
author: Li Z.

description:
Sushi was only ok....got the dragon roll and rainbow roll. Very small pieces of fish. Was fresh but the sushi rice was poorly made.
FYI, they charge 1,50 if you order take out, not packing leftovers, actually paying $13 for a to go sushi roll, they tack on a extra 1.50 for a box to go. Ridiculous on charging customers for that!!!! Was close to canceling order...
Overall, sushi was average....really overpriced based on experience
author: Jim S.

description:
We came here on Sunday for lunch and had a great meal.
Service was fine. The fish was very fresh and we left quite satisfied.
The restaurant was half full and our rolls took awhile ( I noticed that they were preparing 7 trays of sushi to go) so we enjoyed a couple bottles of sake and beer while we waited-which wasn't a big deal for us.   

We enjoyed the following:
Arch deluxe - excellent
Swamp roll- very good
QP- very good 
Crunchy roll- excellent 

We're looking forward to returning soon.
author: Lizete S.

description:
Ebisu hasu deliciousu oystersu.  Though primarily advertised as a sushi restaurant, I feel like Ebisu has more to offer than just your everyday catch.

I started with the Seafood Sampler.  This includes Oysters with Momiji Ponzu, Asari Clam with Sake Mignonette, Tiger Prawn Peelers, and King Crab with Wasabi Cocktail Sauce.  You can tell just from reading what's included in the sampler that Ebisu is a restaurant that likes to find interesting ways to pair seafood with classic Japanese ingredients.  The crab was a little disappointing mainly because the sauce was not as flavorful as I was hoping it would be.  The prawns were you typical prawns.

The clams and the oysters were another level though.  The clams had a really nice, subtle taste of alcohol, which was topped with a solid combination of diced scallions and wasabi.  The best, though, were the oysters.  I love ponzu sauce, but have only really had it with teppanyaki.  Using it with oysters topped with masago was a revelation.  That the oysters tasted extremely fresh only added to the already delicious bite.

For mains, I had the Ebisu Sushi Dinner and the Chirashi.  Overall, the quality of the sushi/sashimi was good, but not mind-blowing.  Both came with a wide selection of sushi/sashimi, like tuna, yellowtail, salmon, etc., but none of the seafood really stood out.  That said, the sushi dinners were still really good and satiated my craving for sushi.

Overall, Ebisu is a good place to get consistent sushi, but a really great place to try newer and less traditional flavor combinations.

GET:  Oysters with Momiji Ponzu
author: Michael K.

description:
Not being familiar with the area I consulted Yelp and a few other places to find a tasty Sushi place while visiting my girlfriend in the sunset district.  After settling on Ebisu we strolled down to find a rather uninteresting facade just off of Irving st.  Upon entry however we were very pleased to find ourselves in a very nice space. 

 The waiting area was a little small however it wasn't an issue as we were promptly shown to a table. As some other reviewers had stated, the place is really nice on the inside.  A warm yet modern vibe with bright but not glaring lighting and comfy seating and tables.

The hostess was pleasant enough and the service was prompt but the servers were not particularly friendly tho all the sushi chefs behind the bar appeared to be in good spirits and appeared to engage the customers sitting at the bar in a fun and positive way.

Our food was quite good. Miso soup to start with was pretty standard but a little salty for my taste but by no means unpleasant.

I ordered the Ebisu sushi plate which included Tuna, long neck clam, freshwater eel, yellowtail tuna, scallop, salmon, salmon roe, hirame and flying fish roe nigiri sushi with kappa maki and spicy tuna maki.  The fish was well prepared, the rice was of good texture and didn't fall apart when eaten.  I am not a fan of roe of any variety but I gave it a shot and the flying fish roe was not bad.  

My girlfriend had the Swamp roll and a hand roll of some variety with Mackerel and ginger which was quite good.

Overall the venue was A+ the service was C and the food was B+.  We'll definitely be giving this place a second go.
author: Andrew W.

description: Sushi is by far the best!!! Service is a little touch and go. I REALLY wish they would expand to a larger space. The wait makes it almost not worth it.
author: Slone F.

description: I have mixed feelings about Ebisu.  On the one hand the sushi is excellent.  Very fresh, very tasty.  However, their beef teriyaki was dry and overcooked.  What's more when I told the waiter he could not have cared less.  He didn't offer to replace it or refund it.  Just didn't care.  Similarly, we also felt that they are getting arrogant about their popularity.  We called at 10am and tried to reserve a table for my son's birthday party of 8 -- no deal.  I can respect the policy of not taking reservations, but they wouldn't even humor us by being polite about it...e.g. taking our name and saying "...come in and we will try to get you seated as soon as possible."    I would also add that restaurant gets very hot.
author: Eric W.

description:
So, I decided to be adventurous and try another sushi place besides the one I always go to.  I'd hoped I'd discover another delicious sushi joint, maybe even better then my spot in Cole Valley, but boy was I let down!

I guess I shoulda known it was going to be bad when a non Japanese woman took my order, no offense.  Anyhow, it was overpriced and the portions were small, example:  my see weed salad was tiny, yes it wasn't that expensive, but it also wasn't that great and tasted like it had been sitting out all day.  Also, the trio of edamame was terrible!  
The edamame were over cooked and bland.

The Boston roll was the best I had and it was just good, not great.  My bf had the chicken teryaki dinner and it was OK, except for the HAIR he found in it, ewwwww!!!! He did like the salmon sashimi however, but that was about it.  Overall, I was displeased with the food rthere and will never go here again.  They really need to step up their game!
author: Molly M.

description:
So overrated!! I bypassed this place many many times because the wait was so long but people kept telling me how it was their favorite sushi place in the city. We decided to stick it out this time and waited about 90 minutes. Service was pretty much non-existent which explains the long wait. Our sushi rolls came out on a HOT plate and they were so loosely wrapped that they fell apart and unrolled before we touched it. Taste was really mediocre. It took so long to grab the attention of a waiter to order more so when we finally waved one down we got our check and picked up some pizza on the way home.

If possible, go to neighboring Inner Richmond and experience Sushi Bistro. No hype and unpretentious. Just fresh sushi the way it should be served. And for those who like rolls, there are so many creative ones here that actually taste different from each other...not just variations of California rolls.
author: Thu S.

description: Their udon bowl was tasteless, bland, and overpriced. Their sushi rolls had poor presentation, although their fish roe on the rice edge of the roll was big, giving it a crunch and releasing all the juices inside.  The noise level was pretty loud and there was a wait for the restaurant.  Because they were busy and I was a party of 1, they seemed to forget about my order at first and it took them quite awhile to bring out my food.  I would not go back because of the overpriced, poor service, and bland tasting food.
author: Lawrence E.

description:
We walked in, were told of a 15 minute wait, had a beer around the corner and then sat down to good service and yumminess.  We ordered 2 rolls - the spicy tuna and 49 roll, then had the Oysters with Uni (4 for $10), after a seaweed salad.  For $50 including tip and a big beer, this made for a perfect dinner.  Their sushi, preparations, service, and environment really do make for a great experience.  

The room is crowded and noisy, there's no getting around that - it's bistro seating in addition to the sushi bar.  The noise level oddly gives each table a bit of privacy - it almost makes a white noise and you aren't bothered too much by your neighbors.  

I'd go back and recommend it to people outside the neighborhood.
author: Paige B.

description:
Went last night for an early dinner at 5:30. Tables were already starting to go so we sat at the sushi bar. The chefs were all very enthusiastic about their favourite cuts, which were as tasty as advertised. Service for appetizers/entrees was haleable via a well-timed "sumimasen" and the Vanilla Pot de Creme dessert was absolutely astounding. Will definitely be back, although at the same early hour (when we left at 7:00 there was a considerable wait, which is a pity as that's my favourite dining hour).

The chefs were entertaining to listen to as they bantered with each other and discussed their backgrounds.
author: Justin B.

description: Always a hit.  My Go To sushi in the city.  Fresh and always a couple of extras you may not find at the sushiya down the street (not talking "fusion rolls", I mean fundamental seafood options.)
author: jeff f.

description:
Loud. Very, very loud. 
Everyone, every table, waiter and patron were forced to yell at each other. Much louder than a typical loud restaurant. I'm amazed that this has not been mentioned here. 
. 
I've gone to Ebisu for years and I've always loved the place. Sitting at the bar, putting myself in the chef's hands, it's always been one of my favorites. This is why we went there on a Friday night which also happened to be my birthday. The remodel looks great and for us,  it was the first time there since the unveiling. We decided not to wait for a space at the bar and after about 40 minutes we were seated at a small table in the now very crowded room. Since the remodel the tables are packed together. Honestly, we were elbow to elbow with the two-tops on either side of us. Then we waited for service that never materialized. 

The noise level was so high you could have easily landed a jet in the place and no one would have noticed. The waiter approached us but then turned to the table next to us and yelled loudly, very loudly, asking for a drink order. They were seated well after us but for some reason the waiter did not know this fact. He never turned to us, just waked away.  So... we left. The hostess mentioned that this occurred often. Unfortunately, we never even tasted the food which by the looks of the "new" menu has undergone a change. It seemed to have more "fusion" type dishes and higher prices. 

Since I have always enjoyed this place before the remodel, I will probably return on a slow night in hopes of less noise. I'm not expecting much though. The hard surface of the ceiling bounce the sound back into the space. It looks good but it's hardly functional for a busy restaurant. The designer who came up with this should reconsider what they do for a living....

BTW: We walked around the block to Sushi Kazu where we sat at the bar and had one of the best sushi meals we've ever had. The place is quiet and more traditional, much like Ebisu once was. We made new friends and shared sake and discovered a new favorite.
author: Ken H.

description:
Wow, Yelp, you have failed us!  This place was so bad the fiance and I are still reeling days after our disastrous meal.  I'm writing this with the hope that it will save future sensible, fish-loving folks like ourselves, who might otherwise be distracted by the high number of 4-5 star reviews.

1. Hot towels came, but were then left on our table throughout the duration of our meal.
2. We usually never order California Rolls, but the reviews said they use real crab meat.  That turned out to be false.  We got the dinkiest roll I've ever seen.  Moreover,
3.  THE RICE WAS LONG GRAIN!  LONG GRAIN!!! it wasn't sweet sushi rice, nor was it seasoned at all.  It was also brittle and cold.  WTF??
4. The 49er roll, also highly touted, had the thinnest slice of fish on top, and no fish inside.  If you read through some 5-star reviews (which I just did), you'll find people who say they don't like raw fish but loved the 49er roll.  I'll get to this problem later.
5.  We should have walked out after the above major fails, but unfortunately sat through what came next:
6.  A very dry and overcooked hamachi kama.  When the waiter came by and asked how things were, I tried to politely mention that the kama was dry.  He said "aww, I'm sorry, even with the sauce it's dry?"  Sauce should never compensate for improperly cooked fish!!!
7.  Tried to use the restroom and had to turn around after entering.  I've never seen such a dirty restroom in such a pretentious environment before.  There was pee on the toilet seat and all over the floor.  That is the kind of clientele this place attracts?

Back to the problem I mentioned in #4.  I hate to say it, but when we looked up from our awful meal, we found ourselves in the twilight zone:  the entire restaurant was packed with non-Asian people, leading the fiance to say: "Yelp should at least have an ethnicity vector attached to each review."  True that!  If a place serves Asian food, Asian reviews should predominate.  It's not that different from de-prioritizing a vegetarian's review for a steakhouse.  

But blindsided by the large number of largely positive reviews for this place, we apparently turned off our authenticity sensors.  In hindsight, if we had only read the reviews in detail, we probably could have figured out this place was crap.
author: Lisa S.

description: What a fun place to have sushi! My boyfriend and I decided to indulge in sushi. So, Ebisu it was!  The sushi chefs are incredibly nice and generous! Each cut of the sushi was heavenly. The escolar and uni just melted in my mouth.  The interior decor is fun and artsy. I can't wait to go back!
author: Christine K.

description: Arrogant service and pricing.  I had a miscommunication with the sushi chef over how many pieces of sashimi constituted an order.  When I questioned my $30 bill for eight pieces of admittedly good fish, I was told that it was common practice for a sushi restaurant to show prices for nigiri and that sashimi was a different (undisclosed) price, i.e. I should have known.  I have eaten sushi in Tokyo, New York, Los Angeles, and for twenty years in San Francisco and I've never been surprised like this.  In Tokyo, the host would be distraught at failing to please a customer.  On 9th Avenue, tough luck and thank you very much...
author: Andrew S.

description:
FOOD GOOD.  SERVICE BAD.  VERY BAD.

Ebisu has nice people and arguably the best Oyakodon I've ever had anywhere (including Japan), but SERVICE IS TERRIBLE!  Perhaps because they just reopened after remodeling, but I've experienced the same disorganization across the street at their sister restaurant, Hotei.   Today I took my staff to Ebisu for lunch after having made "reservations" this past Friday.  In confirmed with the kind lady on the phone that they do indeed take reservations.  6 people at 12pm on Tuesday, 6/30.  Confirmed, no problem, the kind lady told me.  After arriving promptly at 12pm today, we waited (no exaggeration) 35 minutes for our table.  I asked the hostess (turned out to be the owner's wife) if they had our reservation.  She said they don't take reservations.   But when I explained my confirmed phone call, she changed her response to, "actually, we forgot your reservation."   What?!

It gets better, after ordering, our food came out piecemeal over a forty-minute period and drinks came after three inquiries and then I had to get up to ask the owners wife for water.  Like I said, everyone is nice, food is delicious.  But their service was so egregious, they looked like Keystone Cops.   Here's the kicker, someone in our party was actually friends with the owners!   Even he was shaking his head in disbelief.  If service and eating in a timely fashion mean anything to you, come back in a year when they've sorted things out.
author: Ike K.

description: I'm writing this review to balance the review Bill F wrote, who I was with at this restaurant, as I think it's unfair to Ebisu. While it might not be the best sushi I've ever had, it is very good and very fresh. When you do not frequent sushi places a lot and then order the most basic rolls you are not going to be wowed by any place. I also think you need to understand the prep that goes into sushi before making blanket statements without backup. Just another person's opinion.
author: Deb D.

description:
I am so glad that I can still say that I love Ebisu and am thrilled to give it another well-deserved 5-star review.   

The remodel is a welcome addition to a restaurant that serves some of the best sushi in San Francisco.  At first I was worried that they would make it cold and uninviting, but the decor successfully blends together old-world Japanese architecture with a modern flare.  Now every time I bring someone to Ebisu, I am excited to show them the subtle details and styling cues that make the decor a winning work of interior design.  I do however miss the Japanese sitting room.

The staff is extremely courteous and knowledgeable.  The waitress that always serves me reads the specials menu as-if she wrote it herself.  Although I know the menu by heart, her suggestions for new things to try are always guaranteed to please.

In addition to remodeling the interior, they also took this opportunity to revamp the menu and give the presentation some flare.  I always knew that their chefs were culinary artists, but now their work looks as beautiful as it tastes.  There are new appetizers that could easily quality as a meal themselves (for instance, the sashimi treo), but blend seamlessly with the rest of the menu.  Luckily, my favorite items are still gracing the menu -- double hamachi and QP roll.

To pair with your meal, be sure to do yourself a favor by ordering a "Melon Breeze."  This sake-based melon and cucumber drink is bound to make you grin with joy.  But be careful, you will probably be ordering many of them.
author: Serge S.

description:
Came here last night - on a Tuesday - and Ebisu was PACKED.  And I can totally understand why!  

My partner-in-crime and I were STARVING come dinnertime.  Accordingly, we ordered 4 rolls, the edimame trio, and the vanilla pot de creme dessert.  All items were delicious!

The 4 rolls we ordered were as follows: the double-hamachi, the XXX (with spicy tuna and albacore on top), the chopped scallops, and the crunchy roll.  The fish was delightfully fresh and all of the rolls we got were mighty tasty.  My favorite was the XXX - so good!

The edimame trio was also yummy!  The garlic edimame was flavor country.  Mmmm:)

Finally, the vanilla pot de creme was quite good as well.  There was a strange gelatinous substance on the top that we didn't really like, but once we picked it off and got to the vanilla-y goodness inside, we were quite happy:)  The strawberry sauce on the side complimented the vanilla custard quite well, but it was also delicious without.

I really enjoyed Ebisu and am happy to have found another sushi restaurant to throw into the mix!  I'll be back!
author: Julie S.

description:
Came here with the roomies for a fun roomie dinner and ordered nearly the entire menu between the three of us. ebisu's sake kasu marinated black cod with sesame chile beurre blanc is to DIE for. at $7 for a tiny 4 oz boneless fillet, it was heavenly, and cooked to just the right amount where it wasn't too buttery, but not too well done either. 

we ordered:
49er Roll- Sliced salmon, lemon, avocado, tobiko and shiso
Crunchy Roll- Spicy tuna, avocado and tenpura crumbs wrapped in soybean paper
Poke Roll- Chopped albacore tuna seasoned with soy sauce, Japanese seven spices and onion

and the Deluxe Sushi dinner, which consisted of: tuna, clam, freshwater eel, yellowtail tuna, scallop, salmon, salmon roe and sea urchin nigiri sushi with king california maki

aside from the spectacular black cod, the Crunchy roll was my absolute favorite... we all left the restaurant popping out of our coats and sweaters, stuffed as portobello mushrooms at an Italian restaurant and happy as ants on chocolate crumbs. all in all, 4 stars!
author: Cheryl F.

description:
Freaking amazing!!! I haven't really found a sushi spot that I have actually liked in sf, and this may be my new found love!!!!!!!

The sushi was fresh, and the rolls were magnificent! The place was jam packed, and very busy, but that makes me want it that much more!!! I actually just sneaked up the the sushi bar just for one, and devour this amazing sushi within 10.5 seconds! well not that fast, but this is pretty much how it went

I found amazing parking 5 seconds
I walked in 1 second
I walked to the bar 1 second
ordered 30 seconds
ate : 5 mins
done and content : 10 mins :) for a wait of 30-45 mins and being on irving.. that was unheard of!!!!!!!!!


for next time I'll take my sweet time, but seriously AMAZING!! that you ebisu for making me actually think sf has good sushi restaurants :)
author: Nina M.

description: If you're looking for very good Japanese food, this is a prime choice. Everything, from seaweed salad, to sashimi, to rolls was great. Ambiance is essential - don't expect anything too fancy, and service tended to be a little too fast. The place has usually a long line and doesn't accept reservations, so keep that in mind, especially during weekends.
author: Steve E.

description: Went again this past friday.... the food was so out of this world good that it makes me want to scream the F word at the top of my lungs from every roof top in san francisco.  Unbelievably delicious.  So good it hurts.  Every other Sushi restaurant in San Francisco pales in comparison to the wonders and lore being created at Ebisu on Lincoln and 9th.
author: Mike G.

description:
This is such a great example of how strange and ridiculous Yelp reviews can be.  I am reading negative reviews of people talking about their recent experinece and I am thinking this place has been closed since November 15th, 2008 for a complete remodel and just reopened today May 12th for the first time in several months.  So these Yelpers may want to recheck what Sushi place they just visited because it sure wasn't Ebisu.   

So I have watched the remodel over the past 6 months and eaten here frequently since the days of the 90's tech bubble.  Finally this place has a makeover to rival the food.  I urge people to come and take a look at what a gem this place has become.  The remodel is spectacular and rivals any restaurant in the city.  The details of the craftmanship are worth seeing just by themselves.    I ate here the other night prior to the opening and the food was as amazing as ever.  

Congrats Steve the place looks amazing and I have no doubt it will be taking the city by storm as people find out you are open again for business.  

Open today May 12th, 2009
author: Aaron B.

description: My wife and I have been going to Ebisu since we were dating.  Food is always exceptional.  I had the lobster pura today.  It's an appetizer.   But I ordered a bowl of rice with it.  Lightly breaded.  I would order it again.
author: Sonny C.

description:
FABULOUS fish, service and presentation. Ebisu is the standard by which all other sushi bars are judged and one I rate above even Sushi Tomi because of the friendly chefs who joke and serve directly from the bar. (Sushi Tomi chefs are too busy to chit-chat at lunch). Suzuki is a grand master and the remodeled interior is great - though I hardly notice when the fish is sooooo good. Don't blame them if it takes awhile to get a table.

I'd do a detailed review of all their fish but after 15+ years being blown away by the quality what can I say? Its all the highest quality and fabulous. There's no chance of getting old fish here.
author: David E.

description:
I sometimes balk at visiting restaurants that don't take reservations and I know there can be a very long wait, but I continue returning to Ebisu.  The waits generally are not that long (10min-45min) and well worth it!

Some of my favorite dishes are the creative Oyster Dynamite (oyster, sea urchin and dynamite sause, baked on an oyster shell) and the teriyaki kobe skews.  However, the sushi and sashimi are also first class.

For those that care, the decor is great and atmosphere is lively but not too loud.  It's really the perfect set-up and possibly my favorite japanese restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I'm getting tired of giving sushi joints 5 stars, but again, this one is fantastic.  They DO NOT have fresh wasabi, which should automatically get them dinged a star, but the abundant selection of fatty belly cuts were amazing.  We had chu-toro (medium) oh-toro (fattiest) sake toro (salmon belly) and hamachi toro (yellowfin belly) and they also had live uni... not as fairly priced as Kiji, but still under $20 for fresh uni is a great deal.  Their sake menu is broad enough to satisfy anyone's desires... from the milky unfiltered stuff (not something I'd drink)  all the way to the highest polishing junmai daiginjo sakes, Ebisu has it all.

The service is excellent as well.  We sat at the bar, and one of the chefs recognized me immediately.  Now I have not been to this place for nearly 7yrs, but that last time I went was very memorable, but I won't get into that here.  

Bottom line is there are plenty of excellent sushi places in SF, but if you find yourself in the sunset, you definitely want to go here.
author: Josh F.

description: Excellent and fresh sushi. Great service.
author: Kendra T.

description:
How the mighty have fallen!!! 

Since I had relatives in town from Canada who craved sushi, my thought was to overwhelm them with Ebisu. Boy was I wrong. Since it's been a couple years since I've moved out of SF, I take the blame for suggesting this place.

Bottom line: Service has gone to SHIT. Sushi orders were served 30 minutes after everyone else received their plates. Awkward when everybody else is done with their meals and people at the table were still waiting for their sushi orders. 

Detail: 
Food - 4 stars. Ordered special appetizers: scallops, lobster, and oysters. Very good. 
When the sushi came out, it was fine. Nothing exceptional. And tainted by the terribly slow turnaround time.

Service - 0 stars. If I could go back in time, I really wish I hadn't recommended this place. Such embarrassment.
author: t l.

description:
Service was great! The servers were excellent and attentive. The rolls on the other hand, were bland and lacked creativity. This was very disappointing, seeing it took close to thirty minutes to finding parking nearby this joint, seeing that it's in the heart of a plethora of food places in Irving. 

Wish I went to Gordo's, the Mexican place next door instead. You eat a little, you learn a little, about what people can hype up such an average place to be. Ebisu seems like one of those places that use their well-known name to lure people in, but end up serving them mediocrity. People will keep giving them good reviews, but as a person who worked, lived, and breathed sushi for such a long time, I thought this place was very average.
author: Anna T.

description: Great quality of fish. The wait on a Saturday night is unbearable. Decent prices for excellent sushi, though I would avoid the chef's special.
author: dan V.

description: A great place to get a bowl of hot Udon soup in a chilly day. The kobe beef was so tender and delicious! My friend ordered the dinner combo 1 and it looked really great too. The waiting line was long because it was a Sunday evening but it wasn't too bad for two-people groups - we waited for about 10 minutes. Will come back again!
author: Cheng W.

description:
Star for remodel, star for Uni and star for service. 
No star for rolls, no star for sake. 
Now details: 
Stars for:  - great remodel, nice furniture! 
                  - amazing Uni, great design, very fresh and not very              expensive! 
                  - good service, very friendly people
No Stars: - rolls and nigiri - to much rice!!! 
                  - bad quality hot sake
I'd just go back to eat uni, other than that the food was OK and I am not going back.
author: Antonia N.

description:
The majority of my friends are inner sunset natives, and would probably scold me for writing this review...

I used to enjoy dropping by Ebisu here and there with my neighborhood buddies, but after the remodeling, the place has gotten quite pretentious. 

Prices raised, over-hyped, super long wait in crammed area, ok service.

The fish there I admit is fresh, but for the price and the wait nowadays. I don't even bother. I'd rather go to Shimo's either on Taravel or Clement and save myself a little money and time for if not equally fresh fish, even better!
author: Tip S.

description: Service was good, very cute little restaurant though! I love how its dim and very warm inside, almost like a cabin. I ordered the Hanukah roll i believe, I wanted to try something different. The roll was good and very pretty the salmon roe ere huge! but the sad thing was..the sushi I wasn't able to enjoy it as much because the rolls kept falling apart :(. More rice than meat. enough said
author: Susanna P.

description: One of my favorites in San Francisco. Very fresh food materials! If you want to have something to eat in inner sunset, this should be the right choice! The only thing is when we asked the waitress for the wifi code, she said no. Maybe it's because we went there late, and they were going to close.
author: Liwei Z.

description: Thank you!  Finally a good Japanese dinner!  Great rice and good price!  Definitely will come back!
author: Angel A.

description:
I've been coming here for over 30 yrs. It's gone through periods of ups and downs but it is clearly very popular again. Cooks and sushi chefs come and go. The wait on this week night was long even as we sat waiting after 8pm. The tables are all crowded into the little space. There's a lot of bumping as the waiters came around to serve food. It feels very cramped if you're a large person. The tables are also small. They grab away any thing that looks finished. It's a bit awkward if you want to hold onto your plate if you finished first but want to pick off your family's plates. There is a bit of a rushed feeling because they want to seat the people crowded around waiting for a table.
If you stick with the sushi, sashimi, you will find it definitely worthy of 4 stars.
The entrees, I would give them a three to a 3 1/2 star rating. The tempura is weak, and bland. The chicken teriyaki was dry... but the entrees are very reasonably priced. 
The sushi can add up quickly and you can be shocked when the bill arrives.
The place is clean and servings beautifully presented.
author: jane f.

description: sitting here now and havent received my food yet but when I checked in and tried to redeem the 2 free southwest gift cards they advertised, the employee said "oh that's old, I dont know why they havent taken it down yet". Yeah ooooook. minus stars for you without even trying your food yet. False advertising.
author: Joey T.

description:
Some regard Ebisu as "the best sushi in SF", yet I'm not convinced they're deserving of such a grand title.

Why you ask?

Well, I doubt that the best sushi house in SF would allow several short black hairs to go out on their spider rolls.

'nuff said.
author: Katie C.

description:
Still may favorite sushi place in SF!

Everything is always delicious...gotta keep my crunchy rolls and swamp rolls as my standards, then we mix it up. Tonight we had one of the chef specials: the XXX roll, which was red tuna and avocado rolled with seared albacore on top. DELICIOUS.  Love the trio of Edamame appetizer, and our Maguro Nigiri is always fantastic and clean.

Everything always tastes fresh, the service is attentive, and they've really expanded their sake menu!

Best of all is they have a rewards program: you get a card that you earn 1 point for every dollar spent (not including tax.) Once you get to 100 points, you get 10% off. Your points keep accruing, and once you reach 1000 POINTS, YOU GET A $100 GIFT CARD!!! I just earned mine tonight! Hooray!  You can use your card at any of the Ebisu locations and at Hotei across the street.

SO long story short....Ebisu, I love you and I always can't wait to come back!
author: Audrey K.

description:
We headed out to see the new Ebisu last night. (after many visits to hotei during its renovation) 

She loves Sashimi, and i of course love everything she does. We waited for a seat at the sushi bar, you must do that at Ebisu, its just not worth it otherwise. Ordered the Omakase Goju or the Chef's sashimi selection. lots of super fresh tasty fish. That's all she needed and the chef kept winking at her and trying to get her to try some more. 

I also had the Teriyaki Chicken Thigh (yea at a sushi place, but it was great.) 

Ebisu, still one of the best.
author: Ben A.

description: Great, fresh sushi! Excellent service!
author: Kenneth G.

description:
Dear Guy Who Brought Me Here On What I Thought Was A Date,

I appreciate you picking your favorite restaurant to take me to.  I didn't even mind that you said you had a gift certificate that you wanted to use.  Ebisu has a great reputation and I was very excited to try it.  I was even excited to hang out with you.

I also really appreciate that you appreciate my love of sushi and have a strong love for it yourself.  In fact, I learned a lot about sushi on our "date" because your are so knowledgeable about Japanese food.  

I was also impressed that you wanted to wait for seats at the bar in a certain section because you liked that sushi chef.  When you let the chef just start preparing anything he liked for us, I was giddy with joy and excitement at the culinary adventure that was about to begin.

The scallops were outrageously delicious, as were the "holy trinity" of nigiri - hamachi, sake and maguro.  I tried the sea urchin, but was not a fan.  I know that's your favorite, and I suppose it's an acquired taste.  

The food was overwhelmingly plentiful as was the sake and beer.  By the end of the meal I was tipsy and full with a general feeling of satisfaction.  

That is, until you told me that your gift certificate was for $40.  

I mentally did the math in my head and, well, I'm no genius, but the total I came up with was far more than your gift certificate would have allowed.

When I offered to split the rest with you, as a polite gesture, never expecting you to say yes and still think that I was going to go home with you especially when the rest was close to $100 because you ordered a shit load of sushi that I didn't even want and you DID say yes... well that kind of killed the possibility of you and me being naked.  Ever.

Had I known that this was going to be the case I would have stayed home with my cats and some pre-made sushi from Whole Foods.  $7.99 and no awkward hugging/"lets do this again" empty promises/dodging kisses at the end.  Because, let's be honest, I was kind of going though a breakup and accepted the "date" with you because I needed some validation (and you were REALLY nice).

So you see Guy Who Brought Me Here On What I Thought Was A Date, although I never expect to be treated to dinner on a date and usually offer to split, I rarely actually have to pull out my wallet.  I mean, have you seen me?  

The next time you go to Ebisu and let the sushi chef get buck wild with your order, I would suggest you ask your date approximately how much she intends on eating and prorate.  You never know, it might just get you laid.

You can thank me later.

Best,

Rachel G.
author: Rachel G.

description:
I love this place!   I've dined in and done take-out.   It gets pretty crowded and when I'm in SF I have my neices with me, so take out is the easier way.   The owners are super nice.  They always make special allowances for babies and kids,  very accomodating.   The specialty rolls are delicious.  Usually we order several and share so we can all get a taste.  All of the sushi is fresh and never has that "fishy" taste.  The sukiyaki, tempura, steak and salmon teriyaki are freshly prepared and delicious.   The uni,  sea urchin, never tastes like ammonia like it does in some other places.  

I give this place a thumbs up!
author: Sandy C.

description: Ate here for lunch during the week and had the Sashimi special...$22, say whaaaaa!!!!  It came with miso and the fish was very fresh!  I'm super picky about my fish not smelling like fish and they passed the test.  I would definitely come back for dinner sometime!!!  Service was ok.  Not the best and most enthusiastic so I knocked off a star.  I love the ambiance.  You feel like you're in a sushi restaurant even when you're sitting at a table.
author: Meli B.

description:
Checked out the restaurant last night.  There are no reservations but the food is well worth it.  They have a lot of entrees on the menu as well.  There was so many things that looked good in the menu that I wanted to try.  Definitely coming back for more.

*If you like uni (sea urchin) try the Mud Pie!  It's tempura fried.  Try Pink Cadillac (scallops covered with salmon) and roll #29 (yellowtail in soybean paper) ;)
author: Kristen T.

description:
Based on the Yelp reviews, this place sounded perfect and I was super excited! Parking is extremely hard to come by over there, but luckily, as soon as I arrived, I got a parking spot right in front! This got me even more excited! Unfortunately, the experience was downhill from there...

The waitress (don't know her name, some girl with blue streaks in her hair) was pretty nice noticing that my friend had her baby nephew so she gave us a booth seat. The booth was narrow so my friend felt more comfortable keeping the baby on the floor under our table and not in the way of anyone. The waitress said we can put the baby on the booth, but we politely declined and then she said if the ppl next to us need to get out the baby will be in the way but they were fine with it and we said we'd move him if they need to get out, no biggie. The waitress then proceeded to grab the baby car seat and move the baby herself. Excuse me, but you don't EVER touch anyone else's baby. If you were to drop him on accident, you'd be dead meat. My friend and I got up and said we'll just move him then, but she insisted on moving him herself, squeezing her butt in between our table and the table next to us that's not wide enough for a person to fit through and then using only one arm that looked like she didn't have a good grip at all on the car seat and placed the baby on the booth that was, in fact, too narrow but she pushed the table in so that it would be "more stable". If that was my baby, I would have had some strong words with management, but I kept quiet because it's not my issue, but I do see this as a big issue. I used to work in big chain restaurants and she simply should have said "Keeping the baby under the table is a fire hazard. Can you please put him on the chair or booth" or she could have moved us to a corner area that had more space for the baby but not touch him. So that was how it started which already erked me...

Food wise...
- Ahi Poke Salad: They don't offer it on the menu and when I asked the waitress if they had it, she was clueless to what it was. After trying to explain it to her, I nixed the idea all together.
- Crunchy roll was one of the better ones but it was still avg. 
- Cherry blossom looked really really cool but it was doused with too much lemon, which took a lot of the taste away. Otherwise, it would have been good.
- Ahi poke roll I was really excited about and it turned out to just be a spicy tuna roll, smaller than the size of a California roll. 
- Potato bug roll was pretty good, but more pricier at $14 vs. the other rolls which were $6-$7. It was def not worth $14. 

I just wasn't feeling it. It wasn't terrible though, don't get me wrong. But it was average, which is why I'd give it a 3 star but the unprofessional waitress experience made me wanna drop it down another star but i didnt this time. She was nice, I think she meant well, but touching someone's kid is just common sense, not a good idea. Venue has nice, modern ambiance and is simple and clean. Maybe the plates are better? But I'll pass on the rolls...
author: Lucky N.

description: Get the kobe sashimi, deluxe nigiri combo, and a sake flight.
author: Phuong M.

description: More like 3.5 stars but definitely a good neighborhood joint.  Some of the sushi was fantastic, others just ok.  Service is good.  Stick with the sushi - the izakaya type dishes left a lot to be desired.
author: Eric C.

description:
I like this place. Would probably give it 3.5 stars. 

What I liked:
Ambiance: Relaxed environment, neighborhood crowd
Food: Loved that the chef whipped something up for us. Sushi was enjoyable. 
Price: Very reasonable
Service: Friendly and attentive 

What I didn't like:
The wait was hell and they don't take reservations so go on a day and time that's not busy. 

In all I'd say this is a solid sushi place that's worth checking out.
author: Shreya C.

description: Bummer - I wanted to love this place and, meh? Not so much. I had four things: edamame, toro sashimi, house salad and a deluxe roll ('Behind the Green Door'). The toro sashimi was outstanding. The salad was with totally spoiled greens. The edamame was mealy. The roll had some unfresh fish. The service was snappy and everyone was nice. I might come back.
author: Catherine C.

description: One of my favorite sushi spots!  The best Hamachi nigiri and Hamachi toro, my mouth is watering : ) Everyone I've taken here falls in love at first bite, you will not be disappointed.
author: Nikolette S.

description:
My roommate had been raving about this place, so I decided to take advantage of the "guy I'm seeing" 's indecisiveness and made him go here. 

First we had a drink at Yancy's, by the way their service is horrible. So we get to Ebisu, and I order the kakuni pork appetizer my roommate recommended and it was DELICIOUS. Guy I'm seeing was all about weird stuff like live fish and got up to pet the prickly blowfish like thing they had held hostage. So I took command and ordered some more stuff like the spicy scallop QP temaki which was really good. Also, we got the triple x sushi roll which was recommended by the server and that was good but not amazing like the kakuni.

Also, if you go for happy hr tues-thurs 5-7 and mention you saw their ad online for a free sake you get a carafe for free just for mentioning it, don't need to bring in a coupon like it says on the website. So we got the free sake and it was pretty awesome.

We both deciced our favorite thing was the kakuni, but I will be back to try other stuff for sure.
author: Ashley B.

description:
Visiting SF for the first time and stumbled upon Ebisu by searching for RewardsNetwork restaurants near where we are staying near UCSF with my brother & his girlfriend.  What a find this was.

  Went on a Friday night with 6 people and got seated quickly.  The service and hospitality here was impeccable. There was always someone there attending to our every request and need.  

The best part though was the food-- Top Of The Line Sushi!!!  We each ordered something different and sampled each other's order.  There was not a disappointment in the whole bunch.  I had the Kobe Beef Sushimi (Awesome!!!) and the Dynamite Oysters (Spectacular). Also the Poke roll was a treat. 

Some of the rolls were pricey, but definitely fresh and delicious. You can't go wrong here.
author: Eric B.

description:
Had a sushi craving and this was one of the few places that are open for lunch. The place is pretty small so I imagine it might be hard to get a table during dinner time.

Tataki was yummy! Everything here is fresh and the fish just melted in my mouth. We also had the double hamachi, swamp roll and the hirame sashimi. 

If you're looking for sushi that's deep fried with cream cheese and covered with sauce, this is probably not your place.
author: Jenny N.

description:
Apparently I'm not the only one who was anxiously awaiting the re-opening of Ebisu!  The restaurant is on the block where I work, so my coworkers and I had been watching the remodel happen, and relying on the fast-foodish Kiki for sushi in the meantime.  

So, Ebisu finally opened last week, and I made my first visit to the newly remodeled space.  The new decor is a huge improvement, and the space feels welcoming, modern, and comfortable.  

The service was a little shaky -- they clearly aren't running like a well-oiled machine yet -- but my server was attentive and friendly.  I think it would be impossible to expect them to be perfect this soon... most if not all of the staff is new.

The food was as delicious as always.  I got the Lunch Bento Box 2, which had sashimi, maki, tempura, miso soup, rice, and various salads.  All of it cost $14.   Everything was delicious, and it seemed like they put a lot of thought into the presentation -- the carrots in the miso were cut like little flowers, there was a lemon slice in my water, etc.  

Now I just have to be careful not to go back too often... I try to keep my lunch spending under $10. :-)
author: Jane A.

description:
I have been several times and all that was eaten was awesome!
The grilled fish collar is my fave
They have good prep habits as well.
True Sashimi Warriors !
author: Fat ass g.

description:
Came here on friday because all week long I had a craving for sushi! I came here with a few people...and luckily they were on time, so they were able to put there name down for a table..and by the time I got there (about 15 mins late) we were able to get seated right away. It was really busy because it was prime time dinner hour @ 7pm-ish. Oh yeah, ebisu currently moved across the street to Hotei, because the old location is being remodeled or something.

We decided to order some appetizers (tempura, gyoza, salad), and 4 rolls, my favorite the ikura nigiri, and after seeing the table next to us had this giant bowl of ramen that looked so good..we decided on the 4 us to share a bowl of ramen.  The ramen was delicious..one of the better ramen places I've had in a while. And the bowl was HUGE. Seriously...it's enough to feed 2 people easily. The sushi rolls we got were pretty good too. Everything was fresh, and came out pretty quickly. 

Too bad they do not take reservations here. Because the line was really long by the time we were done eating. Prices here are very reasonable, and even after we paid the bill we sat around talking for a little bit and they didnt even kick us out of the resturant - so we were not rushed at all. The current location is a small space, but it works.
author: Betty S.

description: the new Ebisu is fantastic.  I've been going for years, and while I miss the old place, the updated interior is prefect.  Not to mention we enjoyed some incredible dishes there after a late night at the Academy of Sciences that I can honestly say I've never tried before.
author: Mike V.

description:
i came here recently for dinner and was quite happy with my dining experience at ebisu.  the waitress was very helpful and attentive as we were probably the loudest group in the whole restaurant.

dishes & imbibe:
5 bottles of sake
cup of cold sake
agedashi tofu (must order!  they add a couple pieces of tempura mushroom as well)
swamp roll (lots of seaweed on top)
panko oysters (this was okay, they shrink in size when fried)
udon pot (a large helping)
spicy tuna roll with soypaper 

they don't take reservations, but they are able to accommodate groups of different sizes.  if you're in the 9th and irving area, i would definitely recommend coming here for sushi/dinner.
author: Carli F.

description:
Although I went here for the first time less than a week ago and gave it 4 stars, my second visit cemented this place as a 5-star joint.  Here's why:

1. Itamae Isa-san is the epitome of a convivial, funny chef.  I arrived at 2pm, after the lunch rush, and the place was relatively empty (compared to Saturday, when it was packed!).  He and I chatted at length about cuts of fish, the history of sushi, and obscure terms like "jabara" and "shimofuri."  If he didn't have an answer, he dragged other members of the staff into the conversation.  Did you know that shimofuri is a term,  meaning fat-marbled red meat, that is used for toro and beef carpaccio because shimo evokes images of frost, delicate and white?

2. Isa-san cured me of my aversion to escolar (because of the icky watery cuts -- post-frozen --- I'd had at Daimaru).  I simply asked him about escolar -- without ordering it -- and he quickly prepared a mini sashimi dish with three little pieces of escolar on it, with minced ginger and a dab of yuzu paste.  It was terrific, cost me nothing, and will undoubtedly inspire me to order lots more of it from them!  That's good service!

3. Isa's cutting and presentation are top notch.  He served my hamachi toro and otoro sashimi plate with a couple of pieces of halibut wrapped around cucumber sticks.  I like that he uses lemon slices and finely sliced cucumber flowers, which adds to the wholesomeness of the overall plate.

4. I like that Isa and Tommy (my chef from Saturday) have different cutting techniques, which makes for pleasant surprises even when you order the same dishes from them.

I have such high confidence in Ebisu at this point that I'm prepared to give up my specific regimen and give them omakase freedom the next time I visit.
author: Andrew L.
