description: It's a little bit overpriced here for the food. Ordered a Crunchy Roll and a ribeye steak. The only part of the roll that was crunchy was the tuna. It was alright. It was kind of weird that they had a pink wrapping around the sushi. I've never seen that before The ribeye took awhile to come out. It tasted good for the price but then again that's the first time I ever had ribeye. I thought the spinach they placed beneath the ribeye added nicely to the taste of the steak.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
In San Francisco, this is by far my favorite place to go for sushi.  I've been going to this place for years, and it NEVER disappoints.  There usually is a longer wait for this restaurant since it's tiny, but the wait is definitely worth it.  In the past year, the place went through a remodel, and it's evident that this place is a little pricier than Kiki's Sushi a couple doors down.

The sushi chef always has different specials, but when the raw kobe beef and the raw scallops are on the menu, you definitely have to get them.  They literally melt in your mouth.  They have the typical special rolls, and I'm a big fan of the Swamp Roll, 49er Roll, and Arch Deluxe.  If you just want sushi for dinner, you could opt for their signature combo: The Ebisu.  It has everything you will ever need for a great meal.

By the way, ask for the Ebisu frequent diner card...you'll accrue points and discounts on your future meals...
author: Mark P.

description:
I used to be a big fan of Ebisu, despite the long wait line. Fishes are always fresh here. Their live scallop, live uni, and Kobe beef sushi are just awesome! 

But something changed after they renovated the restaurant. 

The pricing has never been cheap but it was justified by the quality. But now, with the new trendy decor and additional receptionist, they jacked up the price even more. Also, the new layout somehow made the restaurant  more cramped than before. The service level has dropped too. Given all these, my overall dining experience here isn't as positive anymore. As a result, the food become way overpriced and has been turning me away from Ebisu. 

Last but not least, one of my two favorite sushi chefs there left after the renovation. I wish I know where he is now!
author: Stephen L.

description:
Really excellent fish, although the cuts are usually a little thin and it seems to be a bit more expensive than similar quality meals elsewhere. 

Its pretty loud and chaotic there, and thus not really a favorite...but they are open late and the service is excellent.
author: Essron J.

description:
I've heard about all the fuss about ebisu for years, but never got around to trying it out myself. Well after years of being in the gray, I am blown away ! The owner, the lovely lady that greets you at the front is so cute and really tries to seat everyone as soon as possible and the food was amazing!! The waiters were moderately attentive but they can use some improvement. However, everything was very fresh and it was very obvious they they use amazing produce. When I saw my fiance try raw fish without spitting it out, I knew this place was a winner! To top it off, one of the chefs is Julio! He was very famous at Ichiraku, a restaurant that used to be great but became subpar and will probably close soon with Julio working at Ebisu. He's the best :) 

Do yourself a favor and come here. Yes, it is more expensive than other sushi/japanese restaurants, but it worth every cent!
author: Elena L.

description:
recommended by a friend who grew up in the city, I disregarded any negative yelp reviews and went to check it out.

This place has some rolls that I have never seen anywhere else.  Simple rolls such as the Tootsie Roll and more exclusive ones like the 49er roll took me by surprise: i never knew that a piece of green onion would complement tempura salmon so well, and I also didn't realize thinly sliced lemon would complement anything sushi-related so well either.  Definite props for those.

My sister flew into town and we came here to eat after hanging around golden gate park.  located at 9th and irving, there are plenty of other japanese restaurants there, but this has been the only one i've tried.  We went right around 5pm, when dinner had just begun, and the friendly staff seated us very promptly at the bar.  They were very helpful in helping us choose some rolls and some appetizers (for once the waitress did not "recommend" the most expensive or second most expensive item on the appetizer menu!).

given a warm handcloth we started eating.  when my sister wanted to get a picture of the both of us, the dining patron next to us refused to take a picture for us; surprisingly, the sushi chef offered a minute later to take a picture for us from his side of the table! that was definitely a first as he took the picture and washed his hands before proceeding.  A minute later, the waitress also came over and offered to take a picture for us.  these two actions speak very well for how pleased i was with the service here.

all the rolls we ordered were very good and moderately priced.  if i ever visit SF again, I'll definitely drop by this place again.
author: Albert L.

description: My all-time favorite spot for sushi, and I always ask to have my order prepared by master sushi chef Suzuki. Standbys: 49er roll, rainbow roll, seafood salad, dragon roll, spider handroll, hamachi and hamachi toro nigiri. You can also sit at the sushi bar and sample the day's specials or ask Suzuki to whip up something special just for you with whatever fish and/or special ingredients you like.
author: Sharman G.

description: Came here for lunch with some friends and I really liked the atmosphere. As soon as I entered we got seated. Their sushi is good! Nomnomnomnom. I ordered the Romeo and Juliet and the spider roll (check for name), and my friend ordered the dragon roll, and my boyfriend ordered #29 roll. Everything I ordered was delicious. My boyfriend liked everything but he complained about the portions. Other than that I will most definitely be coming back here!
author: Tina F.

description:
This place is GREAT!!!
Chef Suzuki is absolutely the guy to sit in front!
Quality, taste and price...everything is very good, except always very busy regardless. Make sure to check with chefs for specials of the day. There are a few items not even listed.
Make sure to have a reservation, plus some patience to wait even with reservation.
They have also good selection of premium Jizake as well.
author: Ken K.

description:
The best fish! -some others may match the quality but none exceed.

My brother discovered this place in the early 90's, became addicted, and I think eventually ended up stealing TV's to pay for the habit.  He's left SF since then but I've been hooked for the past 10 years.

Aside from the flavors and freshness, the other thing I've grown to love over the years is the lively, friendly and completely unpretentious vibe.

Last time I was there for lunch, they were sending out several fresh platters with a driver - he was en route to the Four Seasons - they order catered platters from this place...

The fact that this place isn't even in the top 20 on yelp seems to say more about the yelpers than it does about the restaurant.
author: David B.

description:
Good place for sashimi. Yum! One of my faves is the double hamachi roll.

I've never been a big fan of teriyaki, but I'm fond of  the chicken teriyaki here. It's juicy and flavorful and not drenched in thick teriyaki sauce or overcooked like it usually is at other places. Doesn't have that burnt taste, either.

Place a bit small. Sushi chefs are  friendly.
author: Jamie W.

description:
Okay firstly, the food deserves 5 stars, but its only getting 4 because of the service.

     I went in there for lunch the other day and granted it was pretty busy and it looked like they were understaffed, but I was still disappointed when I asked for another glass of ice tea and a water and I received neither before I finished my meal (20-30 min later). 

     Other than that, I got the shrimp and vegetable tempura, which was really delicious! I usually hate vegetables and have to force myself to eat them, but I found that they were quite yummy this way. 

I will definitely be coming back here, and I will be bringing all my sushi loving friends. I guess I'll just have to keep reminding them if I want my drink refilled
author: Chelsea C.

description: Best sushi I've had in San Francisco. Pricy, but worth it, and both times I've been here I've been served by Julio, who just might possibly be the best sushi chef in the city as well.. Excellent.
author: John B.

description: We had lunch there once with unagi don and stir-fried noodles - they were okay.  We went back and had sushi there - their sushi was very mediocre.  Fish was mushy and rice was hard.
author: Pamela S.

description:
Ok, I'll re-write this review.
My problem with this place is, 
There are 5 Sushi guys behind the counter and there is an old man, I think he is the only well-trained sushi chef in there.
So, if you are lucky to get the sushi from him, You'll like it.
Or,
You'll enjoy the busy, crowded atmosphere that reminds me a bit of Kurosawa's High and Low, the dope exchange dancing scene between a girl and the main character. That place. ( see the movie, you'll see that Korean writing on the wall.)

I don't know.
But, 
point is this, you don't know and you can't tell who is making your sushi order. 
Generally speaking,
It is very important to know who is Your Sushi Chef in any sushi place.

I can trust the old man but other 4....?

Good sushi place shouldn't have so many sushi chefs in there.

I think the location is helping this place a lot to keep them busy.
Mixed race, safe neighborhood, less Asian and more white maybe.
but,
I just don't want to have a cheap, crappy miso soup come with a Ren-ge in it.
Ren-ge is a funny lookin' spoon for Ramen Noodle.
But for miso soup?
That is a Korean custom, not Japanese.
Japanese always use "Hashi" for a miso soup.
That is fxxxin' lame.

That shows this place gets more dumb customers who don't know how to eat Japanese food properly.
That's why they give you a fxxxin' spoon to drink a Miso soup!
They treat you like a baby.

I thought this place is authentic Japanese place.
They think Americans never know how to eat J-food properly.
Why don't you ask for a fork to eat Nigiri? 
Huh?
I think this place is good for beginners who have a bit trouble using chopsticks.
So, 
Make a big mess of rice, soy sauce and wasabi.
Take 2 bites and double dip into the soy sauce.
Go ahead.
Eat anyway you want. Nothing wrong with that.
Have fun. 
It's just Sushi. 
They don't care.
They just make everything easy for you.
They just need a lot of dumb customers who think this place is like Japan.
But,
Hell No.
You'll never learn anything about sushi here.

I think if you go there once, you'll know the long line and that's it.
Go somewhere else instead.
Yup,
Life is too short,
I will go somewhere else instead.

There are lots of Sushi places out there!
I don't want to waste my time for Ebisu's long line.

P.S. there was a hot-tempered floor manager lady who  treats you like you owe her a favor to get a seat.

Well, Ebisu, he wasn't Japanese anyway. He was a member of "Shichi-Fuku-Jin" ( Seven Good luck Gods) from China.
Hahaha!
author: Nobu K.

description:
What is my favorite food? 
Sushi.

So if you want to take me out, take me out to sushi. (This doesn't mean that I won't pay!) Seriously though, I can eat sushi every day of the week. For every meal. I LOVE sushi. Which is interesting, because I didn't start loving it until I came back from Japan. I take after my mom, who didn't develop a palette for sashimi until 5 years ago. 

Anyhow, I love that Jessica and I have very similar taste in food. Burritos, CPK, fro yo, sushi... she's my ideal dining companion. On this particular evening, we were craving sushi and neither of us had been to Ebisu. We knew that we'd be taking a chance there because there's always a long wait, but we figured that it was almost 9pm on a Tuesday and we wouldn't have a problem. WRONG! The waiting area was packed, but we decided to put our name on the list. We nearly gave up, but when a table in the tatami room opened up and no one before us wanted it, we jumped on it.  Personally, I think it's more fun to eat on the floor. 

We dove right into the menu, and didn't really check out the specials board above the sushi bar. We ordered our standbys: the spicy scallop rolls, the dragon roll, and the spider roll. Everything was tasty and fresh. The portions were on the smaller side, but surprisingly, we were totally satisfied with the amount. We didn't feel the need to order any more. When the bill came, we were shocked by the fairly low amount: $28, including tax and tip. 

While I'm not sure if it lives up to all the hype, I'd definitely go back again. Next time, I'd like to try the omakase. The table next to us was having it, and all the chef's creations looked amazing.
author: Connie C.

description:
You know what's great about Ebisu? I mean, besides a lovely selection of fresh nigiri, creative and beautiful maki, mouth watering sashimi, a not too bad sake selection and an obviously consistent top rating in the Inner Sunset neighborhood?

You get surprises at Ebisu! In the form of your bill. Because when the waitress offers you (not once, twice, but three times) the special, and says "Today special is live scallop" and you say, "Live scallop?" and she says something in great detail, nodding her head, then repeats, "Live scallop" and you try to visualize it but fail miserably and only can come up with an image of a little tentacled thing wearing an Axl Rose style bandana, so out of curiousity you eventually give in and order the special. 

And it's pretty tasty, although not mindblowing. 

And then you get your bill. And at the bottom it says "live scallop" and across from it there is a nice round figure of a couple of digits that you absolutely didn't expect, something that is about 50% of the entire bill, and makes you blush and feel like the entire staff of the restaurant pulled a fast one on you and taught you some sort of object lesson in remembering to ask proper questions.

Don't you just love surprises?
author: Tanya F.

description:
Bad experience here when I brought a friend for the first time.  In the past I had no problem with ordering for the gluten free.  This night they made SUCH a big deal out of it, I felt like a spot light was on me.  The chef came over and told me I should be checking with my doctor on what I can and can't eat there.  The hostess followed me and my friend out of the restaurant and wouldn't let the issue drop.
This was all after order sushi items that were stripped down to just fish and rice (no seaweed, no sauces, nada)...and I wasn't told about this when ordering.  I was brought items that were nothing what I expected when ordering...and thus had to send it all back.
I don't understand how after going here for at least 10yrs why all of a sudden being identified as gluten free would have you be treated like a freak under a spot light as all the tables around you stare and wonder what the problem is.

no bueno

ps....the fish is still amazing....but this experience was soooooooo bad, and that was after waiting 45 min for a table, and then another 40min to be served at our table.
author: Q L.

description:
Been here 2 to 3 times in the last ten years and sad to say none of the visits shined in the least bit. Horrible suki-yaki, jive ass rolls, and nigiri.
Back in the day this was the more famous Japanese restaurant in the area, and pre-Yelp nobody else knew where to go nearby.

Jessica T is right. Ebisu and San Tung are the only restaurants in the area that always have lines. The only difference with me is that I will go back, no, CRAWL back,  to San Tung in a heartbeat and am willing to line up for their five spices beef noodle soup (apologies if some of you don't like it, but this was a favorite of my late father's when we used to spend Saturdays at the original hole in the wall location), spicy honey garlic chicken wings, and of course the boiled pork and cabbage dumpling goodness.
I've always walked out happy at San Tung, even at its current location #2 that doesn't quite taste the same as the former #1.

If sitting at the sushi bar only and getting the original old #1 sushi chef serving you is the only way to enjoy a visit here, then it is not worth my time. Especially when Koo is just a stone's throw away where Kiyoshi-san's craft and ingenuity can easily give you improvisational multiple orgasms while jazz music is playing in the background.

So anyway, I'm in a foul mood today. 

Looky at the restaurant's website and their online menu:

Appetizer: Matzoh Ball - Fresh ground fish with spices and deep fried. Oy vey, this is so wrong. What is a deep fried fish ball with a Kosher/Jewish food name doing here? If I were hard core Jewish, I'd rather be banned from the synagogue for eating nigiri laced with crab, scallops, and oysters, than eating a deep fried fish ball called Matzoh (and not in chicken soup either). OK I take that back, deep fried fishball is ok so long as it is skewered and served in a Hong Kong style curry sauce....

------OOOOOO (accept no substitutes)

Mud Pie 7.00  (Sea urchin tempura) - this sounds so wrong. Inside the sea urchin, inbetween the yellowy golden brown lobes of gonads are some dark black yucky stuff. Perhaps if the stuff is tempura fried then the name mud pie would be apt.

Lunch: 
Sashimi $9.50 - Fresh raw filet of tuna | soy sauce | Japanese green mustard. I thought wasabi was a horseradish kinda thing, or a root. Japanese mustard is karashi and yellow brown. 
 
Sushi:
TORA fatty white/red tuna seasonal. I like TORO (and of course the reviews of my man Toro E), but WTF is TORA?

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TORA

or is it Ebisu's Freudian slip about the Pearl Harbor attack movie?

NEGIMACHI yellow tail with green onion 4.75. How cute. Re-inventing something called Negi-Hama. Maybe it is a play on "Nihonmachi?"
What's next? Negi-rame? Negi-guro? Negi-ba? 

EBISU MAKI salmon with vegetables 5.50 - OXYMORON, when they explain in ABOUT US, that Ebisu himself in the restaurant logo,  holds a fishing rod and a sea bream (tai). Yet they use salmon in their namesake roll.

Kudos for not mentioning spicy tuna in their online menu I suppose.

But bottom line. Ebisu Ebisucks.
author: Ken K.

description:
The sushi chef who invented hand rolls was probably so pleased with him or herself at the time for making something that looked like a raw fish ice cream cone and still tasted good that it never occurred to him or her that there is no graceful way to dress these with soy/wasabi mixture. I'm only mentioning this because the wait staff at Ebisu won't laugh or sneer when your novel solution to this problem turns out to be kind of messy.

And while they're really nice, you might wait a long time for the crab cakes and vegetable tempura roll, even if they're really good when they get there, and you may wait quite a while for your check as well. Ebisu is popular so it's busy on weeknights and the staff appears to work at a leisurely pace. 

But yes, the crab cakes and the vegetable tempura roll; check the specials on the whiteboards to see if they're there, along with a lot of other appealing stuff. The temaki are worth a try as well; the fish is fresh and the proportions are about right. It's not the cheapest sushi you'll ever eat, but it's not the most expensive either. There's a heavy emphasis on big non-traditional rolls (There's a chaunakkah roll on the menu and I don't think there were latkes or chocolate gelt in it at all) so if you're looking for authentic this may not be your place, but what we had tasted good.

If you're looking for the best sushi ever (and you're willing to pay for it) there are better options in town, but check this place out if you're in the neighborhood. Ask for extra napkins.

AK has this to add:
"if your girlfriend is of the cranky-hungry variety, you should encourage her to order a raw roll in addition to the deep-fried sushi goodness and crabcakes that require additional prep time."
author: matthew r.

description: Out on a cold foggy night in San Francisco, with a cold that's got you all stuffed up? I got two words for you: Hot Sake. That really hits the spot in a special way. I got the Chirashi which comes with Miso, Maguro, sake, hamachi, ebi, albacore, tsubugai, hotate, tobiko, ikura and kanikama. Personally I really liked my choice and even though I'm not a big fan of Miso I enjoyed it. We also got a couple of different orders of sushi to share; which my dinning companion ordered. I had a good experience but if you don't know much about sushi, you should take someone who knows what they are talking about.
author: Anna B.

description: I don't know if we came on an off day or ordered the wrong things, but i definitely wouldn't say this was the best or even more fresh than average sushi in SF.  The rolls had way too much rice, the fish was just ok and not well cut. The other dishes were slightly more exciting then the sushi, but not outstanding.  The service was odd and not super welcoming, and the prices were too high for what you get.  I think if I was in the neighborhood, I'd be ok with eating here, but wouldn't come back otherwise.
author: beverly l.

description:
I really don't understand how Ebisu has been voted in the top 3 best sushi restaurants in the bay area year after year.  This place is SO mediocre...ho hum...average...NOT exciting at all.  There is NO WAY they are up there with the top two- Ozumo and Sushi Ran....its baffling how they make it up there, really.

Its small as hell, kind of ghetto, there is never any parking in the area, there's always a really long wait and the sushi is just ok.  I always find the sushi to be a very small portion, sloppily put together, and the timing is always awful.  That's something I just don't really like about sushi restaurants in general- they can never get the timing straight, and everyone's food is coming out at all different times and nobody knows which is theirs. That is especially true here at Ebisu, because the servers are anything but helpful.  They are a bit rude, in fact...especially about the whole wait list situation.  Yea- there are MUCH better and more organized Sushi restaurants in this city,  people...try Sushi Bistro on Balboa.  Now thats a hidden gem.
author: Genevieve M.

description:
I am in more than like with Ebisu. I am not in like with the crowds and all the people who also are in more than like with Ebisu. 

I have recently fallen in love with sushi and can't imagine a month without it's sweet tastiness in my mouth. My second favorite roll of all time (and trust me, even though I'm new to sushi I have eaten more of it than those who have been fans for life) is the 29 Roll. Why do I love the 29 Roll? Not for the name **flashbacks of high school kids pushing me and not getting up for the elderly on the 29 bus while I'm trying to get to Happy Hour** but for some very simple facts:

1- It has tempura shrimp/unknown white fish/ green onion inside (bonus points for having multiple fried items in one roll).
2- It is covered with tasty tasty ahi.
3- It has green onions, tobiko, and that sweetish sauce I can never remember the name of all over it. 
4- It's big.

The other rolls are also great, 49er, Dragon, Tootsie, Rock n Roll, and so many more. Great selection which is the key to all great sushi places. 

The chefs are great. Very interactive and fun. They will do sake shots with you. (More bonus points)

If you're coming with a big group, there are tables in the back you can reserve, take your shoes off, and sit on pillows. You can be a little more obnoxious here with your sake bombing. 

One good thing about this crazy busy restaurant is you can pick up! My favorite... Take out comes with pretty flowers for decorations and never enough soy sauce. 

Only negatives- crowded, expect a wait and it's not open on Sunday afternoons which is when I always seem to crave me some 29 Roll! Also parking can be difficult, but try the Park.

All in all, I love you Ebisu.

NOTE: They do not use peanut oil in their deep fryer and are good about special orders.
author: Ali R.

description:
I've never gotten all the hype over Ebisu, to me it just seems some folks are just not getting out much. I mean it's good, fresh sushi, but not worth the wait by any means. 

I've been here for lunch and dinner, and would go back if in the area, but it's not someplace I'd drive specifically out of the way to get to, and great sushi should have that effect.

Over the course of my visits, I've had all sorts of rolls, nigiri, sashimi. Some have been excellent, some have been not so, and to deserve so much hype, the cuisine just has to be impeccable.

For the best sushi in town, my money's still on something like Sushi Zone, Zushi Puzzle, or Redbox.
author: Nish N.

description:
Probably the second best sushi I have ever consumed  Ebisu has highly skilled chefs, fresh fish and great service.  The wait can be a major pain, but I have never regretted it.  This is where I made the first inroads on the vegetarian mentioned in my Dry Creek Kitchen Review.

MY FAVORITE:  get a spot at the bar after work and order a big Sapporo and the Live Scallop.  It's not really alive, but it was when you ordered it, and the scallop sashimi comes surrounded by fluffy, crispy piles of tempura scallop that melt in your mouth.  One of the finest ways to relax at the end of a long day on the job.
author: Quinn S.

description:
Mediocre sushi.

I can't say the sushi made any impression on me, with the exception for the few pieces that didn't seem to taste as fresh as they could.  They do have an interesting selection of rolls, but nothing so unique that I am willing to make a special trip for.

Over priced for the quality of sushi and the service.  I've been several times and they never let me down with their consistent mediocrity. 

I think with the selection of so many other excellent sushi places around the city, I don't want to spend my money on their sushi.  I think the hype of this place comes from people who haven't ventured to other sushi houses - expand your horizons and you'll see that there is a world of sushi that borders on the sublime, not the mediocre.
author: Christy L.

description: Came here for a lovely dinner with my friend and I really enjoyed it! The sushi was fresh and the appetizers were creative and tasty. I loved their chirashi!! The only downside is that the restaurant is slightly crowded, not enough space in my opinion. Nevertheless the service was friendly and I'll definitely be returning!
author: Becky W.

description:
I've been here twice now, at a table a few weeks ago and at the sushi bar tonight.  The table is probably a 3 star experience given the spotty service, but tonight I was at the sushi bar and it was such a great experience I'm giving Ebisu 5 stars overall.

The hostesses have always been friendly and accommodating, but the waiter we had the first time I was there was a bit spacey.  He left two things out of our order of nigiri and left us wondering where he was for a while.  At the sushi bar we ordered sushi from the chef behind the counter, and other items from the waitress.  She was pretty good, but a bit slow on the tea/water refills.  

The sushi chef was really great!  He was friendly and talkative (though not too talkative), and given that he liked to blow-torch lots of items he was entertaining to watch!  He joked with us that he'd burned off his arm hair, haha!

Edamame was included, served cold.  Here is the other things we had:

Ama Ebi - served with the deep-friend heads, delicious!
Aji - we ordered a second one it was so good
Iwashi - so fresh, tasted like the ocean (in a good way)
Uni - fantastic
Sake, Ahi, Hamachi - fresh and tasty
Kampachi - least favorite, a bit chewy
Rainbow Roll - yum!
49er Roll - I don't order salmon much anymore, but this was good.
Negihama Handroll - premade fish mixture, but yummy!
Salmon Skin Handroll - done with the blowtorch, awesome
Miso Soup - delicious flavor, but I would have liked some seaweed
Seaweed Salad - good, tastes like it does everywhere

I am happy to live so close to this place, and definitely will be back many times in the future, I love sushi!

Oh, the room is very cool too.  Apparently the recently reopened after a remodel, and I have no idea what it looked like before, but it looks great now.  Lots of different types of wood and metal surfaces, simple tables and chairs.  I'm a fan.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
I've been called a lot of names in my life...  Shorty, Goose, Kid, Sushi Snob, etc.  And even though this is my first review I must start it on the write note.  

For the last 11 years I have been going back and forth with my love/hate relationship with Ebisu.  It was a real treat to eat there...   Expensive, long waits and sometimes meaningless service.  But the Fish was excellent and pieces nicely cut (depending on who your chef was), the creativity was endless. 

For the first 5 years of my SF Sushi experience I had 2 favorite haunts.  Hamano and Ebisu.  Hamano changed owners a few years back and went to shit...   I fell back in love with Ebisu and quickly became friends with the entire Fuji family who have owned and opperated Ebisu for over 20 years.  

Dont be fooled!  The new menu with all the fancy pictures is for the tourists.  At one point in time the menu was a 1 page laminated piece of paper with limited items.  Much different was the colorful unique items hitting the Bar and tables that wern't listed on the menu.  Such as: The Sunrise, Dinosaur feet, QP roll, seafood salad, and the 49er roll (Salmon/AVO/Lemon, an Ebisu original so I was told, not a huge fan).  What made Ebisu special was you were forced to interact with other patrons and the chefs to discover these hidden gems for yourself.  It's a bit different these days...  Limited discovery but still an adventure no matter how you order!

To be honest...  I never use a menu at Ebisu... I use my eyes and my nose...  Then I let the Sushi Chef do his thing...  My favs are Jackson, Tommy and of course the master, Suzuki San.  A local legend who speaks 32 languages!  Amazing!  

I am always up for a new adventure.  Come join me anytime.  No waiting and the experience will blow your mind.  

Okay now my review:

Fish is some of the freshest in the world.  Sake Selection is decent.  Beers are all bottled and they have all the imported and domestic Japanese originals.  Make friends quickly by offering a sake bomb contest for free beer!  Live Uni when available will amaze.  Live Scallop is top notch.  Ankimo is house made.   O-Toro, Chu-Toro, BLUE FIN!!! The Aji rocks!  Steve says he invented the Miso Butterfish that Roy Yamaguchi made so popular.  It is great here!  The Unagi is crispy and the Tamago will take you to heaven.  The Sushi chefs have lots of tricks hidding up their sleeves let them mystify and levitate your sushi experience!  Happy eating.
author: Scott S.

description:
A little background on myself. I moved here from Hawaii about 2 years ago where they have really great Japanese food & the best sushi! Thanks to yelp, I've found some great places to eat except when it came to Japanese food, or more importantly, sushi.  After reading the great reviews on Ebisu, I decided to give this place a try. 

When I got there, the place was packed at around 8pm on Saturday. The decor was beautiful and we were expecting the food to be just as amazing. Despite the professional looking sushi chefs behind the counter, the food was very disappointing. First of all, the rolls were a lot smaller than average and tasted very bland. Second, I don't think they added vinegar to the rice. Third, the fish smelled old, which is a huge no no in my book.  

I don't understand why people think this place is good. I guess my search for good authentic sushi continues...
author: Moxie C.

description: This sushi was so good we had to go back twice! We were only in the San Fran area for about 36 hours and we made it a point to visit it again before we left.  The place is small but has a great atmosphere.  The sushi is fresh and they have a huge selection of rolls.  We wish we could eat there everyday.  100% better than any other "seafood" you can get in the bay area.
author: Laura F.

description: The chicken terriyaki was the best I've ever had, but the sushi wasn't to my liking. My friend got the kobe beef terriyaki and it was pretty bloody being medium well. The waitresses were nice and even gave my sister a birthday ice cream scoop.
author: Clar S.

description:
Came here with some friends who live in the city, but it was recommended by a coworker. Wasn't disappointed, the sashimi was fresh and the place was cute if nothing special. I've had better sushi in LA at many places, but I would happily come back. The service was great and spot on, and prices were good for this type of food.

Although it is quite busy, it's always oddly quiet so even though it's small people talk very softly.

Food - A-
Ambience - B+
Service - A
Value - A
author: Forrest D.

description:
Ebisu you broke my heart.

My family lives in the sunset and from the early eighties I have enjoyed the incredible cuisine that Ebisu produced (past tense), sadly something changed...they renovated the place, but on top of it changed the menu to modern/fusion where the food used to be the tradtional dying breed Japanese, today it is modern and has lost the old school feel and warmth.

The newly remodeled interior is chilling and cold.  Sounds bounce off of the modern wall material making the place uncomfortably loud and the drunk sushi bar patron ultra-obnoxious, lights shine in customers eyes (as my brother has complained), and the overall staff have changed from friendly and warm to hip wannabe this place is so cool so we can skimp on the service. I actually think they fired the great staff they had before, and I smell a lawsuit brewing...

I am adamant about only yelping when I like a restaurant but here I felt compelled and spurred on by my WHOLE family who feel like a member of our family has been killed and a piece of our family history has been stolen from us all in the name of profit and progress.  

Life will never be the same and the sun has set on this iconic giant of the inner sunset.  These days you will find me across the street at the sister restaurant, Hotei, where the food is somewhat the same but also losing that classic Ebisu touch.  Like the ocean tide, time came for Ebisu to change, sadly that change was ill advised and I hope Ebisu and company realize they have lost true patrons, the heart of the neighborhood, who have been loyal to them for decades. For now it seems that Ebisu has died and gone on to Japanese restaurant heaven. Farewell my Ebisu, Sayonara.
author: B D.

description:
Oh! I'm really surprised with this place! I really didn't think much of this place until my best friend took me here yesterday. 

The venue itself is a little small and it really sucked that it was raining and we were all packed inside in the waiting area. BUT, good thing it was just us two and we ended up getting a table pretty quick at the bar. I really liked sitting at the bar.  I really like it when a sushi restaurant is somewhat authentic. The sushi man who was taking care of us tonight always spoke in Japanese when he asked for something or took in orders. He was also REALLY attentive which I really liked too because it's hard taking care of customers AND making all that sushi for the restaurant. 

So, we ordered the #49 roll, crunchy roll, a hamachi nigiri and a california temaki.  I thought all was really good!  The only negative fact I had with my food was the rice was a little on the crumbling side.  I kinda don't like my sushi to break apart when eating it because traditionally, you're supposed to eat it all one bite. Every time I picked up a sushi, it kept falling apart on me. However, their fish made it all okay. LOL 

I also like that they have a sea urchin just chillin' on a plate in front.  I've never tried it but it's a delicacy and I've been told that everyone should try it once.  Maybe next time....
author: Hanna P.

description:
Pretty cool sushi place. Nice scene: cool tables and lightning. Get there early before the crowd does for dinner. Pretty good service - there was some misunderstanding on our order which the staff accepted gracefully. Our crunchy rolls were delivered late (not that great either) but points to the staff for proactively checking with us if we got it yet after our first follow-up. 

Food - california rolls looked good. My teriyaki chicken (yeah, yeah, I know, lame) was delicious. The salmon was two good sized slices, quite a good portion for a dish. All in all, decent food and service.
author: Apple P.

description:
I first encountered Ebisu in '04 while on a job interview in San Francisco.  At the time, I was sitting in a hotel room out by SFO and Googled

"Best sushi in San Francisco"

Ebisu kept popping up in the results!  A $30 Taxi brought me to this little bit of heaven the first time and I always take the return whenever I'm in town.

As with any fine sushi experience, 
- always sit at the sushi bar
- never rub your chopsticks together (it's not classy people!)
- wasabi goes on top of your sushi, not in your sauce
- never order with pencil and paper -- the chef knows what's best

Ask for the Pink Cadillac (a scallop wrapped in salmon, lightly grilled and then sliced in half), Kobe Beef sashimi or the miriad of rolls customized to your liking.

...and don't forget to obtain / use your Ebisu / Hotei Rewards card which will get you a 10% rebate on future visits!
author: David B.

description:
The best part about Ebisu, for me at least, is that it's a mere 5 blocks away from where I reside. This can become quite dangerous but usually I'm pretty lazy after work and don't feel like making much of an effort for dinner out anyway.

But, this place is awesome and they have a stellar selection of yummy yummy rolls. I love the #29 roll; I'm not totally sure what's in it but there's definitely some tempura in the middle and it adds just the perfect amount of crunch to be desirable. There's another roll which I can't remember the name of...I'll have to ask Ali Gato...but it has lemon and I believe salmon (?). Anyway, this is another one of my absolute favorite, mouth-watering rolls which you must try when you go.

It is always busy so if you come for dinner expect to wait a little while. You can always offer to sit at the bar and that decreases the wait by a bit. 

The sushi chefs are quite friendly as well as the wait staff. They're very efficient and accommodating. I've been here multiple times and never a bad experience. 

This place rocks!
author: Kristin R.

description:
I really like Ebisu because I'm one of those faux-sushi lovers who enjoys all components of sushi except for the raw fish...I know, I know...
Anyhoo, Ebisu likes me just the way I am and to prove it, they have a great tempura veggie roll available! It is so damn good!!! AND order the crabcakes. Just trust me on this one...they will wreck you for all future crabcake experiences. Sit at the sushi bar where all the locals sit, or grab one of the sit-on-the-ground-barefoot tables in the back (just make sure you to wear clean socks!).
author: Autumn K.

description: I've been going to Ebisu for several years, now and haven't been disappointed yet.  In fact, a friend from out-of-town ALWAYS makes it a point to go there and I'm always his number one "date"...their innovative style coupled with what is to be assumed REAL Japanese flair is certainly alluring as well as, delicious.  The wait staff is more than accommodating, and Steve is incredibly fast with our orders, let alone they are of course, delicious.  Worth the travel time to get there!
author: Chris G.

description: This is one of my favorite Japanese restaurant. Their sushis are always fresh and yummy. The service is great and the atmosphere as well. I highly recommend it, and is worth the wait.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Been here twice now and I'd say it's hit or miss (3.5 stars really). The first time we came about 3 weeks ago, it was pretty good, 2 of us almost tried something from every part of the menu, sashimi, donburi, hot/cold appetizers, nigiri.
The omakase was very good that night, the beef sashimi ok, unagi don - pretty good, panko oysters ok.
We were in the area again and decided to stop by again as we liked it the first time (there was quite a wait that time) and there was no wait as we were early. We got the omakase again which was mediocre (probably due to chef selection), omote which was ok and the ebisu udon which was good.
Our overall impression is that it seems to vary a little too much. The restaurant itself is cute, with a nice ambiance. The wait staff were very good both times we were there. We may go back again but most likely would try another place in Inner Sunset if we venture over there again.
author: Nick L.

description:
Quiz of the day...

What is a Suzuki?

A)    A sweet sixteen gift for daddy's little suburbanite.
B)   Cubicle boy's first choice for his fantasy baseball draft.
C)   A method for pushy parents to teach their tots a musical instrument.
D)   The best damn sushi chef in San Francisco.

Obviously, considering the context, the correct choice is D.  And you can find him over at Ebisu's.  I gotta say, although their sushi is great, I go primarily for the staff.

Sit at the end of the bar where you'll have Suzuki or Tommy making your sushi right before your eyes.  Mention tennis, and you might win over Suzuki's heart--garnering you the choicest cuts and creative pieces that the plebes at the tables could only dream of.  

I usually let them feed me whatever they suggest, though I have a penchant for premium toro, saba, and (I'll admit it) Boston rolls.  Pass me some edamame and warm sake and you've got a very happy Kat.
author: Kat P.

description:
The sternness of the sushi chefs is an indicator of the quality of their sushi, and Ebisu has the sternest sushi chefs around. 

Ebisu's sushi is fantastic.  It's a crowded restaurant with tables a little too close together not to hear the conversation of the people next to you.  Their fish is fresh, and the rolls are the best.  I like the #29 and Hanukkah roll.  

On a sidenote:  If I could do one job for a week, a top-20 contender would be to work as a chef in a sushi restaurant.  Other options would be: blue angel pilot, being Jim Morrison sometime in 1968 (if that's a job), and caveman (ditto).
author: Phil K.

description:
The sushi is real and the sushi is great.  Ok, I haven't actually been to the restaurant since I was a kid, BUT they catered the sushi for the cocktail hour of my wedding and it was amazing. They made enough wonderful and beautiful sushi to feed 180 guests while enjoying cocktails at the Legion of Honor Museum. 
When I selected the sushi I stuck to the classics because I am a sushi snob and am not really into the 3-inch wide rolls doused with mayo, sauces and tempura. And the classic sushi was wonderfully executed. If you want excellent sushi for your next event, order from Ebisu!
author: Erika T.

description:
Cherry Blossom- hands down the most delicious sushi in town. For that, I will give it 5 stars.
Their Miso soup is also exceptional. I like how small and intimate it is. The waiters are always incredibly friendly.
Love this place.
author: Elif U.

description: My review is completely biased. One of my good friends was a regular here for many years & he knows the chefs by first name. So for what it's worth. This place is awesome (except for the line! ugh) the sushi is sublime, be brave - if you're sitting at the counter, ask your chef to just be creative & make you a "chef's special". Like any good sushi place, they buy their fish daily. Fresh fish is the key to good sushi. I won't bore you with what I like, but I will suggest the "Romeo & Juliet" roll as a great starter.  If you're heading out for a big night on the town - go for an oyster shooter. Enjoy. It's worth the wait.
author: Aaron B.

description: Best sushi in the city hands down. I'll write a more comprehensive review later. I just wanted to make sure I at least gave them 5 stars.
author: Charlie A.

description: LOBSTER TEMPURA NOMNOMNOMS, nuff said. Oh yeah, there fish is pretty fresh too.
author: Helen Z.

description:
Hubby kept telling me about THE BEST sushi he had ever had years ago with his friend Jason.  I tried to find it online- I-bisou.  Would help if his memory included how to spell the name!

Sunday brunch- we were hungry and ready to eat lots of yummy sushi.  No line.  In fact, we were the only ones at the sushi bar.  We put ourselves in the hands of the chef and let him surprise us.  First roll blew us away- shiso, two types of tuna, and a complicated mix of other things.  Melted in our mouths.  We then had sashimi- toro, salmon, tuna, yellowtail.  More rolls.   We should have ordered the live scallops.

We were joined at the sushi bar by  regulars.  We gleaned lots of info from the conversations.  The $1 mil renovation actually shrunk the sushi bar a few seats- so, longer lines on busy nights.  Hoitai .the steet is the same owner- uses same fish and everything- so, if people don't want to wait, they go across the street.  The chef said they are always the top three sushi places rated (what are the other two?)

I've been to Nobu in NYC and that was phenomenol.  This was as good, but in a more Japanese way.   We will be back.
author: E T.

description:
What's up with the hype? Sushi was OK, but not great. I know folks who swear by this place, but given the cramped dining room and the constant wait to be seated and the mid-level sushi, it's befuddling. 

We had the following:

nigiri: 
-striped bass: quite good
-salmon: nothing special
-oyster (kaki): I had never tried it before, and it was quite tasty
-octopus - average
-toro: subpar and pricey

maki (can't remember all the names of the rolls): 
-QP roll (scallop): probably the best roll we had
-king crab, mediocre
-eel (inside and out), mediocre
-and we had a 4th roll but I have no real recollection of it, that's how memorable it was.  

I liked the size of the rolls. In comparison, while both Sushi House and Joy Sushi were highly recommended to me, I felt that the sushi was overwhelming. The flavors of the rolls weren't balanced due to the size. Ebisu is definitely better, but overall, given the wait times and the cost (I've had better sushi for much less), I don't understand the hype.
author: kathy c.

description:
My Sunset friends call this place overpriced, and the Yelp reviews are decidedly mixed.  But it was voted #3 Sushi spot in last year's San Francisco Magazine Reader's Poll, and that's got to count for something, right? Right?...[crickets]

Noticing that one of the main gripes was the crowdedness, I decided to call in an order for take-out.  I showed up at 12:15 on Friday and the place was almost empty...so much for my careful planning.  It's a pretty small and dark place, with an awesome room in the back where you can sit on the floor japanese-style.  There were a couple guys in there with their laptops on the tables--nice.

My order was ready when I got there and delivered with a smile...oh, and a bill for a cool 20 bucks.  Now, since the website doesn't list the prices for the rolls, I had no idea what this was going to cost.  But I only ordered two rolls: a Spicy Tuna and a #29!  I'm guessing the #29 is mondo-expensive since it's got fried fish on the inside, and tuna and roe piled on top.  Pretty damn tasty, but sushi like this falls squarely into the working-class category, and for that I can go to Yum Yum fish for way less.  So as usual, the Sunset krew (and the Yelpers) were right.
author: Wes M.

description:
It is what it is. Ebisu has a great reputation in the Bay Area, and it's well deserved. My friend and his family own and operate the restaurant, so I may be slightly biased, but even then I've never had a bad experience at Ebisu. The sushi is always, always on point, whether you're getting rolls or sashimi, and the staff is always friendly. I prefer sitting at the sushi bar when Tommy's working so we get the good stuff AND I get to take shots with him. 

The downside is there's almost always a wait to eat here, but in my opinion it's always worth the wait. Plus, my boy Charlie hooks it up with edamame or drinks while we're waiting.
author: Edmund C.

description:
One of the better japanese restaurants in San Francisco.  I've been here multiple times and I always have a great experience.  Granted, the wait at times can be up to about 30 minutes and parking around that area is not that great, but the food is exceptionally tasty and if you are lucky enough to go with like a friend or two....you got  to try sitting at the bar and start up a conversation with one of the sushi chefs.  The service at the bar feels to be better....i got the extra attention, went straight to the chef to order our rolls, waitresses seems to be more attentive to the people at the bar (because the chef will call them out for u).  

Actually, they are so damn attentive....i was missing my last batch of wasabi into the soy sauce and under my breath I was talking to myself saying "damn...i need to get some more wasabi" and voila....the sushi chef dropped some more wasabi onto my plate even before i finish my statement.  Damn...now that's good ass service!
author: Dave L.

description: Best sushi place in SF so far. Creative authentic dishes. Fresh fish. And the head chef is generous, friendly, and very personable. Has a very affordable omakase, too. Highly recommend this place. Come early as seating is first come, first serve.
author: Robert L.

description: I came here on a Tuesday night and was surprised to see the place packed! The service was fantastic, the waitress steered me away from the Cherry Blossom roll because the fish is pickled in that roll. I ended up ordering the 49er roll and loved it. I have to agree with everyone else and compliment the place on the freshness of their fish. My only complaint is that it does smell a bit like an aquarium when you walk in, but for that detail I'd give it five stars.
author: Marina S.

description: food was delicious. i got the sukiyaki. it was definitely worth the money. the seafood salad is highly recommended as well!  its a busy place so make sure you go early for a table!
author: Louis O.

description:
Purely on Sushi alone, there are plenty better, more authentic, Japanese cuisines out in the city, but Ebisu prevails in their specials of the day menu.  The Kobe beef sushi is a must, and live scallop is simply amazing.  The wait time varies between weekday and weekend, but usually tolerable after 7:30.   I find the service to be great, out of all the years I've dined at their sushi bar, the chef has always been affable and attentive.  Try the bar if you are tired of the table waiting, you will not be disappointed.

Be sure to check out that tiny little board near the sushi bar, it has some of the best and rarest fish/lobster in the city.  Live uni? check!
author: Wei H.

description:
Ebisu , , , yummers! 

I've only been here a couple of times and I've enjoyed my visits very much. Both times we sat at the bar, it really is the best way to experience sushi. There's nothing like the personal attention and interaction with the sushi chef. And these guys are characters!

The restaurant is medium in size, well decorated and offers floor seating in the back. The food is delicious and the the service is great. Pricing is what you would expect from a good sushi restaurant, not too pricey but certainly not cheap. 

I love Ebisu, I am sure I will be frequenting this place plenty. Probably more likely in the spring/summer months. I prefer sushi (and most raw food) on warmer days.

P.S. Ebisu is VERY popular and not just a neighborhood, but city favorite. You might find yourself waiting up to an hour to be seated, plan accordingly.
author: alexa c.

description: Went there on a thursday night with my friend Jenn.  This is her fav sushi spot.  She warned me that there is usually a 30+ min wait especially for your fav sushi chef.  We waited for 45 and got eric.  I think that was his name. born and raised in sf and apparently his parents owned the spot. eric hooked it up with the freshest raw fish i have even had.  Did about 9 different sushi.  so yummy.  the yellow fish was off the chain.  the bill wasnt as bad as i thought it would be.  remember folks cheap sushi is rarely ever good.  The coolest thing about the place was the chef and staff was very friendly.  Their recommendations were on point. In fact eric made his own special roll just for us.  Looking forward to coming here again.
author: Justin I.

description:
Three stars for the food, plus an extra star for the service. I'll explain why.

I came here on Saturday night with two young, very hungry and tired children. I was babysitting (all day!) and the boys' mom actually recommended this place as a neighborhood spot they frequent for dinner. 

I surmise walking in with little children is enough to make the staff of any restaurant secretly cringe inside while donning a fake smile, but they greeted us very warmly. As soon as we were seated, the kids looked like they were about ready to fall asleep. So the waitress kindly offered the back room for us. You know, that room in every restaurant where you take off your shoes and sit on the floor? That one. Thank goodness for that, and I am so glad they were so accommodating.

I chose our dinner items right away and we didn't have to wait very long for our order to be taken. It was standard fare, keeping things pretty simple for the kids: chicken teriyaki, chicken udon, and a spicy tuna roll (that was for me). The chicken teriyaki was probably my favorite of the three; they kept the skin on and made it crispy. The sauce was slightly sweet and I'm glad the chicken wasn't drowning in the sauce like in some other places. However, I was a tad disappointed to see that the udon noodles were not as thick as I tend to like them. The spicy tuna was definitely spicy. The kids were happy with their meal too... phew.

Anyway, I survived this experience with children so it's definitely enough to want to make me come back with friends my own age. Crisis averted. Score.
author: Monica N.

description:
Mmm... Ebisu.  Have to say I'm really surprised to see the overall rating is only 3.5 stars.  I love Ebisu and its sister Hotei and go to both often.  If you are a sushi novice and only want California rolls, this is a waste of money and not the right place.  

My favorite rolls: Spider roll, Double Hamachi, Arch Deluxe and the Rainbow.

We also always get an assortment of Nigiri including the toro, which is always so so so good. Tried the Kobe beef sashimi last time and really liked it, although best without the sauce.  

As far as the ambience/atmosphere, maybe I'm just not that cool, but I like it.
author: Erica O.

description:
This is my favorite place to get sushi, hands down.

The owner is a great host, always attentive and generous.  All the sushi chefs have a great personality and great attention to detail (whenever I sit at the sushi bar, I ask them to make me something special and it's always beautiful, delicious and different).

My favorite items are the double hamachi roll, QP roll, 49 roll (it has a thin slice of lemon on top -- awesomely good) and 2 balls no strike.

Go try it out, you'll like it.
author: Brent T.

description:
First time at Ebisu wasn't too bad.

The sushi was better than some of the local sushi places around GG Park. The decor and the bathroom were quite nice. I probably wouldn't recommend this place if you just wanted to communicate with someone one on one because you will probably have a difficult time hearing however if you are in the neighborhood this is a decent place to stop by.

Back to the food I would say that it is decent although nothing that really stood out. The fish seem for the most part fresh, and there wasn't any major problems. The servers were quite up to the task regularly refilling water while also coming around every so often. That probably earned it an additional star. The seating arrangements didn't seem too bad if you like a cozy atmosphere. I didn't try the sushi bar however it seem to be quite interesting.

I probably would go back and try their other dish offerings. I just wouldn't make my way out if I lived outside of the neighborhood.
author: Scott S.

description: Best bento box. The bento box i got for lunch was one of the better ones I ever had. Highly recommend.
author: Max T.

description:
There definitely SEEMS to be a great variety and creativity of rolls here... but if you compare the descriptions or try them, you'll find that it's the same 10 rolls repeated with very slight differences.  Still, if you're not a sushi snob and you haven't been here before, don't let me stop you.  They also have a room with a big low-height table that's great for large groups.

On the other hand, if you're big on sashimi/nigiri, you won't be too impressed.
author: Rego S.

description:
After hearing about this place since I sprouted the short and curlies, I finally made it a few weeks ago.  From what I hear, it no longer is what it used to be, but the gf and I really liked it.  I'd have to give Tsunami over in the Western Addition the edge, but this is a great sushi restaurant.

Hotei across the street has great udon soups, and you can actually order ebisu sushi from there as well (but it's a limited menu I think).
author: James M.

description: I love sushi and this place is awesome. The sushi rolls are delicious and they serve the traditional and the modernized rolls. This place is pricey and the wait can get ridiculous, but it's worth it!
author: Jean Y.

description:
This place is so overrated. I recall eating there maybe five years ago, and thinking, "hmmm...okay...i guess i can see why its garnered all this attention. not great, but sufficient." 
recently, i've returned a few times, and man, talk about a disappointment! it don't smell too good; the sashimi is terrible -- warm, not fresh, leaves a bad taste in your mouth; and the rolls are uninspired and messy. 
it really chaps my hide when places like this attract so much hype and buzz and deliver a false notion of what good, quality sushi is.
author: jennifer y.

description:
Examining the quality-to-price ratio of this sushi restaurant shows that it's quite a good deal.  The fish is always fresh, the menu is small, and the food is excellent.  This is one of the better sushi places in San Francisco.  Plus, I think it's pretty cheap considering the quality of the food.

It's a very small restaurant, and very popular, so be prepared to wait for your table.  They don't take reservations, so show up early.  Large parties are not easily accommodated.
author: Rajiv B.

description:
I came to this place with my husband after watching Wicked. We thought the food was pretty good, liked that the Sapporo came from tap, and felt the ambiance was charming enough. 

It's a great first date sort of place. Nothing spectacular.
author: Michelle Y.

description: I gotta say that this is the best sushi I ever had in my life. Very fresh
author: Motaz H.

description: They have the best toro! After eating it, everything else tasted like it was made by a 3 year old. This is not an insult to the sushi chefs. This is a testament to how fresh their fish is! Since it was a Tuesday my date and I decided to risk it and not make reservations. Score! We were seated immediately since the other parties waiting were three or more people.  As soon as we sat down, I ordered a large hot sake. It went down really smooth, which is probably why I had at least 1.5 on my own. Then came the sake sashimi, various rolls and of course the star of the show; the toro! Amazing food, great service and lively place! I can't wait to go back! I hear their udon is really good, must try it next time I'm there.
author: Danielle W.

description: This place rocks!!  The food is spectacular and is my favorite sushi place!  Went again last night, the place was packed (so you know it's good), and they accommodated us right away.  The crunchy roll and tokyo tower are my favorite rolls, and never disappoint!!  Ken our server is AWESOME!!!  He is so nice, right on, and knows his stuff when any question about the menu comes up!!!  Way to go Ebisu, again a great meal!
author: Lisa C.

description:
Honestly didn't like it at all. OVERRATED to say the least.
The service was very good though, and the staff was so friendly and submisive (just the way I like it !! ha ha) -

But that doesn't make up for the fact I didn't like the building, the atmosphere, the place, the location, or most importantly the food !!

Just not good flavors, and I felt the substance/meats was cheap and not of good quality.

I am not going back ever, and would say this place comes very highly NOT RECOMMENDED from me.
author: Joel D.

description: Went for lunch. The seaweed salad was awesome, the yellowtail nigiri melts in your mouth, the rolls were tasty. The staff is a little unorganized. People repeating orders, asking if we need drinks again... The male server on Saturday also just threw down our check... Another example of driveby serving. Food is great, service could be better.
author: Sun K.

description:
This has been my favorite sushi place for a long, long time. I don't go as much as I used to, simply because the budget won't allow it, but when I feel like splurging, I am never disappointed by the quality of sushi at Ebisu. 

I'm surprised by all of the bad reviews, but, the level of sushi quality seems to be in the eye of the beholder. Yes, it's pricey, but it's worth it. This is very high quality sushi. You have to pay for it. But, that's ok, I've heard the same from people I have taken there. Most really love it, but some don't think it's worth it. All I can say is if you consider yourself a sushi connoisseur, try Ebisu out. I really think  you won't be disappointed. The service is great and the sushi chefs very helpful. 

They recently remodeled the place and it looks great. That part is about time. It was getting pretty stodgy looking.
author: Rich M.

description:
I've been coming here for going on 10 years now and I'm still a fan.  This place rarely disappoints.  Well-made sushi and sashimi, good rice, good soups (try the udon, it's not even on the menu anymore but still excellent).  

Favorites include:  hamachi, fresh scallop (they fry up the innards for you), fresh uni (straight from the urchin!), hamachi kama.

It's basically all good.  Bravo for staying good and consistent, Ebisu.

ONE MORE NOTE:  EBISU has NOT been as good since taking residence in Hotei.  This is, well, understandable.  I'm not sure when they'll get back to operating out of their home location across the street again.  I probably would wait until that time, however.
author: Austin L.

description:
Went there with a group of people and it was the best sushi I have had in a while. And I have high, high expectations. Exec Chef Brian-san totally knows how to create delicate dishes that reflect a truly interesting japanese quality. Kobe beef skewers, braised pork belly, grilled ika, live scallop(which was there before as well) fresh fish or the upmost quailty.
Then there is the sake - Yumedono and the 1.8l bottles of Dewakasura Dewasansai. Delish!
author: Sara A.

description: I like this place, you can never go wrong ordering anything here. They have a lot of specials so just ask the owner or chef to make you something special. It is always crowded here on weekends, so make your reservations or expect to wait for 20-30 mins.
author: Sandy L.

description:
49er ROLL! DEAR GOD TRY THE 49er ROLL! Swear my life on it you'll love it. 

Ebisu is everything I've ever wanted in a sushi restaurant. It's one of those places where every bite you take you just have to close your eyes and have a "moment". 

The service is outstanding (Anita you are the best!), the sushi chefs- personable and kind, and the owners are just the most adorable people I've ever met. The owners are there every night walking around, working, and making sure everyone is happy. You can tell this place has history and a true cult following. Almost every time I go in there I end up chatting with someone who is there at least a few times a week. I've found myself there more than I want the staff to notice, myself ;) 

I'm used to most sushi places being dark and serious, Ebisu is not that. It's warm, friendly, and very upbeat. 

The prices are very reasonable and they have a $1 pint between 5 & 6 on weekdays. Things to try:

-Hamachi toro & escolar nigiri
-49er roll
-xxx
-mussels
-lobster tempura
-Fresh live uni
-The seafood salad
the list is endless...

Give this place a shot, you'll be happy you did :)
author: karmasabitch l.

description: Sushi at its freshest, however, the price tag reflects the quality.
author: Karina A.

description:
Ebisu = fresh sushi-making machine! 

We walked in here on a busy Friday night (post-De Young museum happy hour) and were seated within 10 minutes. While we were waiting, they offered to take our drink order to make chillin' in the entry a bit more comfortable. Nice start. 

Soon after we were seated, we ordered, and then the delicious sushi began to flow plate by plate. Every time we finished a plate or had a drink to be refilled, one of the 5 servers would zip by and clear, refill, drop-off, or replace. Service with a smile...and drill sergeant efficiency. 

The fish itself was great. Fresh, nice sized pieces, and good variety. The 49er roll had small bit of shiso leaf inside each piece and a fat slice of lemon on top that made it divine. The striped bass and halibut nigiri pieces were excellent as well. 

Our server recommended a nice small bottle of cold sake that came in a cute glass jar thing. I'm a sucker for cute glass jar things. Definitely worth a trip across the park, even in the fog, and even if there's a bit of a wait once you're inside.
author: Kelly R.

description:
I am not super crazy about this place. Especially when it's crowded...

A drunk birthday party was very aptly located in the Shoeless Cave in the rear of the restaurant.  That was fun listening to them shout to decibels unnecessary in a small environment.  Sadly though the place was packed and in the Cave we were sat.  I know it's the way to do it when you sit on the ground in a Japanese Restaurant but it was so very uncomfortable since they tried to fit three of us in a small corner.  

The sushi was okay...not uber exciting though.  The Caterpillar Roll had old avocado on it and the crab was imitation...I can only assume they ran out of the real stuff and downgraded to faux crab.  The Arch Deluxe was good though...crunchy and tempura-y.   Funny though that they named it after a Micky Dee's expired burger...remember that burger!?! Mmm...potato bread bun.  

Anyways....They either don't have a straight up Spicy Tuna Roll or they just told us that so we would upgrade price-wise to the Spicy Tuna Roll w/ Yellow Onion and Tobiko. (I forgot what it's called).  

It's okay...not super-special...and I have yet to go to Hotei across the street and only because it always seems to be closed.  Why is that???
author: Jay H.

description:
Always an awesome, sushi-rific experience.  For best results, sit at the bar, preferably at one of Jackson's spots.  Then let him know what types of fish you like and how spicy. Following that, he will whip up several surprise rolls for you based on variations of your selections.  You will pat your yummy with glee and swear undying love and loyalty to Ebisu and Ebisu alone.  
(Also, something I don't think I've seen anywhere else - some of their rolls are made with a pink-ish soybean paper instead of seaweed.  It's a really interesting take on sushi, and it doesn't detract from the flavor at all.)  GIve it a try!
author: Becca V.

description:
Great sushi, but pricey.

I really only crave for the Kobe Beef Sashimi - that's definitely worth the money.
As an example of how they inflate their prices:  Masumi sake is supposedly $50 a bottle.  Psh - go to TRUE SAKE in Hayes Valley and get the same bottle for 24.99!
author: A Z.

description: My favorite sushi restaurant in SF. I got spoiled after going to the Tsukiji fish market in Japan. The fish at Ebisu is super fresh. I've never been served anything second rate, and I eat here often. The live uni is delectable. I used to hate uni, until I learned there's a huge difference between so-called "fresh" and "live" uni. Their chirashi is fantastic - every piece fresh and tasty, unlike other places where they put whatever they can't sell in their chirashi. The sushi chefs are warm and it's superfun to eat at the bar. I'd give these guys 10 stars if I could.
author: Katherine L.

description:
It's OK.

Food is ok.  Perhaps some of the items on the menu might be really good, but their menu of rolls doesn't include prices, so poor folks like me are hesitant to commit to "surprise me later with the bill."  The rolls I tried were ok.  The pork katsu I had was dry.  Went with a group on a Friday night.

Atmosphere: It's crowded not only by customers, but by employees.  Over the course of the meal, I think every employee of theirs brought something to our table and taken something away from our table.  I guess it's a good sign of a lot of customer service, but at the same time, every 3 minutes an arm reaches over your shoulder.

Service: be prepared to wait...  to get in and then for your food.  If you get more than one item, you'll wait for each item (including rice).  We were a group of 9 and it took a while.  We waited as each roll came to our table.  Then when people were finishing up the rolls, the food came out item by item.  You'll be hungry when the food gets there.
author: Jason K.

description:
So when i first moved to the city everyone said "Go to Ebisu! Its the best sushi in town!"  

WOW were people wrong.  I don't know who reviews this place with 5 stars and absolutely loves it so much, but this place is pretty freakin bad.  I mean they over price the customer for sushi that's probably average at best.  The place has a funky smell and their fish was not fresh at all.  

Now maybe its just me, im from southern california and i have eaten ALOT of sushi in my short time, and well this place is really nothing special.  Perhaps i disliked it so much because it was so overly hyped up, but no matter how i slice it, this place is ridiculous.  The proportion of quality and price says it all, and this place is vastly disproportionate.

The one thing that i did like about this place was the great service, the servers were all very nice and attentive and i never had to ask for a refill on my water (which is a big deal for me).  
That's about all that i liked about this place.

Go here only if you really must, if you want good sushi for a fraction of the price, try kiki across the street or ten a few blocks down on irving.
author: Mark R.

description: we've never had sushi there, but wife and I have had various bento dinners and yosenabe. our experience has been uniformly good - fresh ingredients, honest taste, great service, variety of dishes and ingredients, and great value for the money - in our experience, the best value for its kind in sf. we've always left very satisfied.
author: Akir M.

description:
Remodeling looks great.

The TUES lunch special is my favorite.

Parking is tough (try off-peak hours).
author: Francis M.

description:
Hubby was very excited to take me there when they'd opened after remodelling. Went for a mid-week dinner first. There was a The sushi was very fresh and absolutely divine. My favorite item is definitely the spicy tuna handroll. I made the mistake of ordering a special - rock shrimp dynamite, that was very rich and I did not like it - I think it's a personal taste thing. Seems a shame to go for any of the cooked things when the raw fish is SO good.

UPDATE:
My favorite thing is now the YUMMY Swamp Roll - spicy tuna and seaweed roll covered in seasoned seaweed salad shreds. It is the kind of thing I dream about and crave. I have to keep going back for my fix! Also their sushi ginger is especially YUM and the waiter gave me a box of it to take home when I waxed lyrical about it.
author: Writer G.

description:
I recently traveled to San Francisco and was very excited to try the local sushi places.  I reside in Chicago but travel the US for work so i have had a lot of sushi in my lifetime. This place hit the mark.  Eric the chef helped me out. I told him to make me whatever he wanted and he really did a great job.  I am not the best with names but several days later I am writing this review and had no problem remembering. 

I would highly suggest the Family Affair. 

A+ to Eric, he rocked!!!
author: John B.

description: Great atmosphere and awesome sushi!!! Though I recommend you stay away from the poke.
author: Y S.

description:
Recently visited SF from Texas in early January.  My friend suggested we go to Ebisu for dinner and I am very happy that he did.  This place has very good sushi for a very good price.  I couldn't believe my bill was only $33.00.  I had Sake, a beer, a specialty roll, 4 pieces of Nigiri and an order of the pork belly appetizer.  All were spectacular.

This place is hands down one of the best sushi restaurants I have been too, and I know good sushi when I see it as its one of my favorite types of food.

The only complaint is that the space is small so we had to wait 40 minutes, but there was a bar across the street and they called my cell phone when our table was ready.  The hostess was very nice about it, and apologized for the wait - not that we cared much. 

Short version: amazing sushi for very little money.
author: Andy C.

description: Great sushi and lots of fresh specials. This was my second trip here, first time for dinner, and  last night I tried the albacore toro nigiri, crabcakes, fresh seared cod, stripped bass nigiri, rainbow & dragon rolls and kobe beef sashimi, and I was completely satisfied with every single item. This place has a very unique point system in which you can earn discounts. C'mon, everybody loves FREE sushi, right?! Parking is a little tough in this neighborhood though, but I think it's worth it.
author: Chelsea P.

description:
This review was really meant to be reviewed 4 years ago.  Yeah, that's about how long I haven't been back.  The last time I went, I remembered the Blue Fin (from the Blue Fin Tuna) sashimi and the fatty tuna.  And that it was always packed.  I just got tired of the wait.

When I do get a seat, I always order the hardcore raw stuff and it was always fresh.  If I wanted noodles, I go across the street (their sister company).  

That's all I remembered about them.  According to more recent reviews, it seems like they had remodeled and cut down on portions...hmmm.  I must go back when I can and make an updated review.
author: Vanna S.

description:
Ebisu has been voted top sushi restaurant in SF for ages, and this review is well deserved if you are ordering what a reviewer is. What I  mean is, don't go here and expect to be "wowed" by your usual rolls. Go here, sit at the sushi bar, and let the chef serve you what he wants, and most importantly, be willing to eat whatever they dish up. 

The Scene
Ebisu is not luxurious, or even elegantly japanese. It's kinda dark, little outdated, and a bitch and a half parking wise, and the waitlist situation is atrocious...but you aren't coming here to be pampered....you are coming to eat amazing fish in ways you have never tried before. 

The Food
Like I said, don't go here and order your usual sushi assortment and expect to be wowed.....order the things that the chef recommends, or the things that look "scary" to you on the menu...believe me, you'll love it.
author: Bianca L.

description: Lots of best evers, including dragon roll, miso soup, albacore tuna.
author: aaron h.

description:
I have been going to this place for soooooo many years. 
It's always good. 
Though I haven't been there for this past couple years because I have been trying new places, I just went back last weekend.
Actually service got even better. 
Food is excellent as usual.
We ate Squid nigiri, Saba nigiri, Kobe Beef nigiri -excellent!, Aji nigiri-really good!, Salmon nigiri, Spicy hotate sushi... so on.
Also I ate Louisiana hot link roll - this one was not so good...

Well, A~nyway! I still love this place and will keep going back.
author: Green Mango Y.

description:
Just went there for a quick lunch. Ordered the chicken bento lunch box. It was VERY good. Didn't have time to try Chawan Mushi but will next time. 
I had a little bit headache after lunch. Not sure whether I got from their food or due to stress. Since I couldn't confirm, I will still go back to this place because the food was so tasteful!
author: Ile F.

description:
Ebisu has some really great things going for it:

Swamp Roll
Spider Roll
Kobe Beef Sashimi
QP Roll
and many other delightful little bits. 

The tatami room kinda sucks as it's just literally sitting on the floor, usually they're raised a little so you can put your feet down. It's small and crowded but it's consistently good sushi at a fair price.
author: Jake R.

description:
Looks great after the renovation, but food still tastes the same.  Great service...sushi bar is fun.  We have our favorites that we can't help but always order...but it's all good.  We seem to take a lot of our out of town guests here.  Super fresh seafood.

Doesn't take reservations, but worth the wait for me.  You can always put your name on the list and give your cell phone number and they will call when you're table is ready, in case you want to get a quick drink if there's a wait.  Or you could wait there and order a drink from them.  Street parking is tough.  It gets pretty crowded around typical dining times, so we like to go earlier or later.

Always get excited to go there.  Only thing is that it's not super kid-friendly and the biggest party we ever brought was 5 people. Enjoy:)
author: kim b.

description:
Not sure why I should even write a review since there are so many of them but feel I must after reading all of the one star rating. 

I have been going to Ebisu for well over ten years and while not every time was fabulous many times were.  I have NEVER had a bad meal there and have eaten at 100's of sushi restaurants and many of them in the bay area.  Ebisu is in the top 5 all time sushi places (NOBU and UBON don't count).

For the best experience sit at the sushi bar and give them a freehand with your meal (Omakase)...Awesome.

The only reason of the missing last star is the wait to get in can sometime take a while and they do not take reservations.  Once you are in, the service is impeccable.
author: Rob L.

description:
4/23/2016
So I decided to eat here for lunch on a Saturday.  Parking in the inner sunset on saturdays are a pain as usual so be prepared.  Not the restaurant's fault of course.  I don't know what's going on but the sushi was ok again.   Not incredible.  :-(  Was I just not hungry?  Am I getting sick again?  I mean, the hamachi was fresh as was the tuna and salmon.
