The eggplant stood out with its melt in your mouth consistency.  The tempura calamari was good but I couldn't help but think a heavier batter (non tempura) would work better.  Maybe I need to go there on a date instead to have the food be incredible.  


7/8/2006
Hmm...has their quality gone down?  I dined here over 3 years ago and the food then was DIVINE.  ORGASMIC.  I might even say it was really good!  Everything just melted in my mouth.  Unfortunately the wait was long and the restaurant was always packed.  

I haven't eaten there for awhile and returned a few weeks ago.  I was happy it wasn't packed and I was served quickly.  Unfortunately, that might have been a sign.  Because the food wasn't the same!  The sushi....I swear it shrank in size.  The appetizers I ordered were delicious... I don't know... maybe I need to try again but I'd hate to have another so so meal with their prices.  

No complaints about the service there.  Always prompt and welcoming.
author: Animal K.

description:
Ebisu is GOOD! Several of my friends crap themselves about how they have the best sushi in the city. I have to admit that I didn't find it merited that level of praise, but I will agree that it's pretty freakin' yummy. I'll sometimes travel from other parts of the city specifically to go Ebisu, even. I haven't been there in a while so I can't give much of a specific review right now... I'll update this later, I suppose.

From memory, though: on a sushi scale of 1-10, Ebisu gets an 8 or maybe even a 9.
author: Heather H.

description:
I really don't understand why this place is so wildly popular? It must be the location. It certainly can't be the long lines and smell of dead fish! Seriously - it SMELLS! Has anyone else NOT noticed this?

I've given this place a few tries and found it to be expensive, and average at best! The last straw was bones in my ahi carpaccio on my last visit - grody! Definitely not worth the wait, considering there are a zillion sushi places in SF. Try Kazu Sushi right around the corner on 10th/Irving for a much better experience, little to no wait, and no stench!
author: Craig G.

description:
This place is overrated. Sushi is average, and the service is mediocre. Waiting times are really unacceptable, and the only reason why people keep coming here is because the zagat rates them. Prices are a little higher than they should be, and I really hate the fact that their portions are small. Way way small. 

Oh, and a tidbit, the fish is not that fresh. I've been to too many sushi places to not know the difference. It's just an average sushi joint that regularly hyped up over things that are the norm in other sushi restaurants in the city.

But it is a nice place to take a date, if you need to fill in the time.
author: Clinton L.

description:
What I like from Ebisu is that they don't try to act like they're some fancy Japanese restaurant, it's very down to Earth, but at the same time their staff members are very distant from their customers.  Although I don't agree with the comment below stating that Ebisu is better than sushi in Japan (being in Japan before, I have experienced the crummiest, shady looking sushi joints that far exceed what Ebisu offers), it has it's charming characteristics, though this place would be your typical run-of-the-mill restaurant in Osaka.  I went to the one on 9th street, and it was small but rather cozy place and at the time the lunch crowd was piling in so me and some friends got some bar seats.

I always enjoyed conveyor belt sushi in which the sushi goes around the people sitting at the bar, Ebisu didn't have one, but it's alright.  It felt like the food I ordered did not have any heart to it.  Watching these chefs put together a roll with their depressed looking faces were saddening, like they didn't enjoy the people being there.  They had a Kobe beef sushi roll on their specials so I wanted to try it.  I know that Kobe beef is expensive to serve, but paying 12 bucks for two rolls of rice with thin paper-like meat on top of it was not what I expect.  Seriously, it was like eating wet paper, you could only taste the rice.  I didn't pay 12 dollars for two rice balls.  Other than that Kobe beef special, everything else I ordered was sufficient and filled the craving that the Kobe Beef didn't.

What I liked most about Ebisu was it's small private rooms deeper in the restaurant.  It's very izakaya (Japanese bar) like that you must take off your shoes and sit on the tatami mats.  I guess the three stars mainly go for my like of the interior of the place more than the actual food itself.  That really explains a lot, if you want a nice, cozy place with decent sushi go here.  If you want a taste that would blow your mind, go to Japan and walk in the alleyways, you'll find what you need there.
author: Simon L.

description: Excellent sushi and noodle soups, and incredible service.  We were ordering take out, and the waitress thoughtfully brought us tea while we waited.  Located right by the park, this is a great stop.  I will be back!
author: Alice Y.

description:
Why do people like this place?! It was possibly the worst service I have ever gotten at a restaurant...

I was meeting my friend on his one hour lunch break, and the waitress took so long to take our order and bring our food that he was a half an hour late getting back to work! 

Not only that, but we only ordered one halibut roll to share... Why would it take an hour to make that? And to make things worse, the fish tasted/looked like CAT FOOD! It was so very terrible.

Forget Ebisu! Any other sushi restaurant in the city can top them.
author: Chelsea H.

description:
Not as good as we expected! :(
Went for a birthday celebration, but food just average only.
The service was OK. Midge hostess was rude, did not let you sat the area in the back of the store. I wonder why? I hate to sit in the walkway, in front of the front door.
What a 'mean' store! Should fired her!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
The one in SFO is more reasonable, (same name only?)
author: Cherlyn P.

description: The service is horrible. The food has definitely gotten worse. They only treat you like royalty if you're a regular or if you know the owner. Otherwise, don't expect good service.
author: Tammy W.

description: I'm dating a hot Japanese guy who is a sushi fiend, and he told me that this place was really good so we went. The sushi was absolutely amazing, and the service was really good too. I know this sounds crazy, but I can't stop thinking about their miso soup; it was memorably good. Go here if you want good sushi!!
author: April Y.

description: Some of the best utSushi in SF.  I usually love their specialty rolls on the big board.   But, I swear they used to serve a few cocktails....hhmmmm
author: Maggie M.

description:
I hopped in here when I did not know what to eat one night. I sat at the bar and the sushi man was very personable and friendly. He didn't speak much english but the fews words he knew were very expressive.
I had the tempura dinner like a fool when I should have ordered everything at the Ngiri a la carte menu. I devoured the tempura and sashimi and began to eat the Ngiri a la carte menu. It was the shit!
I'd go back in a heartbeat. YUMMY!

FREE EDAMMEMEME!!
author: Pascal C.

description: The best value bento box I have ever eaten.  For $15 it was a days worth of fresh and deliciuos food.
author: Brian B.

description: i hate to even give it a 1 star, but they make you.  Place really has a horrible fish smell and the food was just ok to poor, but how can you eat in there.  God, it's in all the tourist book!! Stay far, far away.
author: Ann L.

description: steve and suzuki (sushi guys) deliver some killer fish here! when looking for a good sushi bar, you have to have volume. this place rocks all night long, so they are turning over fish at a really good clip. that also means that they are ordering fish more often. you get the idea. Ebisu is good and has been good for a very long time.
author: Jeff W.

description: wow. Now that is the good sushi I've been waiting to find in San Francisco. Sitting at the bar is so much fun because the sushi chef was smart, funny, entertaining, and created special delicous rolls just for us! Our food was affordable and scrumdidlyuptious.  (note: do not offend the chef by rubbing your sushi in mounds of soy and wasabi, especially if it is a spicy or mayo roll!)
author: Mark S.

description: I' ve been there with  my frens restaurant was almost full for sit we 've to wait for min.I loved there sushi there really awesome n delicious.On the sushi counters chef was friendly he makes our dinner more memorable wanna go again and again.
author: raja g.

description:
Now I'm no sashimi connoisseur, but I've been to enough Japanese restaurants to be able to distinguish what's the good, the bad and the ugly and I definitely can toot my own horn when it comes to differentiating poor quality sashimi from the good quality-- taste wise and appearance wise. (I've had sashimi as dry as the Mojave desert and as fishy tasting as that foul smell emitted by the dead whale laying on Ocean Beach... and that smell is BRUTAL. Just imagine tasting that. BLEHK!)

Anyway I already had a preconceived notion about Ebisu based on its appearance-- it looked pretty trendy, clean and modern so I decided it was safe to assume that Ebisu would have fresh sashimi. And even if I'm not a fan of assumptions, luckily mine was correct! My friend and I decided to split the Deluxe sushi plate and order another side dish of red tuna sashimi. I must say, hands down, the sashimi at Ebisu is by far the best sashimi I've ever tasted. IT'S SO DELICIOUS. Like melt in your mouth, buttery, soft, creamy, "I'm salivating right now just from remembering that sashimi, oh my god kill me now" type of delicious. And usually I'm the type of person who passes on the salmon roe, but since the red tuna sashimi was to die for, I thought "what the hey, if the sashimi that I love tastes like heaven, I'm sure the salmon roe (my least fave) will probably taste just as good." And once again I was right! The salmon roe was bursting with flavor. It was a little salty, but deliciously salty.

Also the edemame was spectacular. Instead of serving the traditional salted edemame, the edemame here comes in three flavors-- Okinawa sea salt, togarashi lime and lemon garlic fried. Like seriously? How cool is that! The next time I'm dying for a sushi fix I already know I'll be coming to Ebisu for sure. Not only is the food delicious but the atmosphere is cozy, the restaurant itself is adorable, the prices are reasonable and the location is definitely not out of my way.
author: Ally C.

description:
"Wow, it looks really good in there. . .", states a passerby.

"Well, get in there and put your name on the list.  You should eat here", I think to myself as I am walking into Ebisu itself.  This restaurant has endured years of many nights with a long wait list that never seems to be crossed off completely.  It also went through a recent renovation - meaning, updated decor, dinnerware, everything, and higher prices.  However, it doesn't deter me from eating here.  The fish is always fresh, entrees well portioned, and wait staff utterly attentive and gracious.  The specials are always intriguing too - I had a Zukie (sashimi in a light soy sauce, similar to poke) and a soup with clam and sake (to cure my stated headache.  it worked!).

So if you ever pass by this place, thinking "wow, it looks nice" and "I'm hungry", get in there and put your name on the list!
author: Julie C.

description: Visiting from San Diego and we needed a good sushi place so we went to Ebisu.  It was fantastic. Having eaten at the likes of Nobu, Katsuya and other high end establishments, I'd place Ebisu up there w. them!  Staff was very friendly.  I'll definitely be going back next time I'm in the city!
author: Rob C.

description:
Let's talk catering a lunch: I'm giving Ebisu 5 stars because Eric is the BEST! I called in a catering order the day of and Eric delivered! I catered for 14 people and the presentation was awesome. I would  not recommend calling in a catering order last minute - one or two days up to a week is fair notice. Keep in mind there is a $20 delivery charge, but the food is fairly priced. 

The sushi was scrumptiously and beautifully presentable with orchids. My clients loved the food and there were tons of rolls. We had teriyaki chicken, tempura, yakisoba and tonkatsu. The food traveled well and the customer service was great. 

Sorry to say, I've never dined in, but the catering for lunch is a hit!
author: Gina M.

description:
Overly hyped, I'd say... too crowded for average quality, overpriced food.  The sashimi felt weird.  The shiso leaf they put as garnish was NOT even fresh... it was semi-wilted and dirty.  I happen to like eating shiso leaf with sashimi... this was not a good experience if you're looking for GOOD sashimi.

Rolls that I thought were good/pallatable:
Hannukah roll (salmon all over)
Swamp roll (tuna inside, wakame salad outside)
Spider Roll (soft shelled crab with veggies)

The ankimo (monkfish liver) was the best... pretty good portion for its price.  You can't really mess ankimo up, because it can stand on its own (just serve it up with some cooling garnish, e.g. daikon radish or cucumber slices, and semi-douse with ponzu sauce... then it's set!)  
The sushi were just okay, but not stellar like Godzilla sushi.

I didn't have an overall bad experience, so I can give this place another shot.  Maybe I just didn't order the right thing... but for the price we're paying, shouldn't everything be great?!  (I'm just disappointed in the sashimi)

I went there for a birthday celebration... we got to sit in the back, Japanese style (no shoes... so I suggest you wear FRESH socks to not offend your company).  Apparently they have FREE DESSERT COUPONS on their website... so if you want free ice cream, make sure you print those out.  (free ice cream too if it's your birthday---with a candle on top)... free ice cream doesn't mean really good either... the ice cream was just okay.
author: Grace M.

description: Decent sushi spot. Like the interior design. I've only had the chirashi and assorted sashimi which were both good but not the greatest. Probably a bit overpriced in my opinion. Great if you're spending a day at gg park an want a decent sushi fix. 3.5 stars.
author: Ngoc N.

description:
I had a wonderful experience here the other night. The food was fresh, the chefs very helpful and jovial.

Eric one of the employees gave me a warm welcome in the waiting room as we waited a few mins for a seat at the bar.

Tom was one of the chefs, and was very helpful and very friendly.

The Kobe Beef Sashimi was Tasty, as well as the Live scallop. My 2 favorites. 

This place does seem very busy, and for good reason.

I will be coming back. I had a great experience.
author: Larry L.

description:
OK place to go for sushi. But I rather not go there again. Parking is a total pain, place is small and wait is long. Well, the space and wait would have been ok for me if only those worth the while. 

The food is not awesome, it is standard/good though, but nothing special. I've had better sushi and variety of Japanese food. 

I went there based on a friend's recommendation. Not very impressed, actually it was not very good because busy as they were, service was thrown out the window. Then I gave it another shot after a while. Well, still the same. 

Not a family friendly environment, that means for group with small children. Food price is borderline expensive. Nothing memorable at all about the service quality other than the wait for the food after we ordered was also long (in addition to the wait prior we got seated). My suggestion is to not go there hungry.
author: Kat S.

description:
What you consider the best sushi is a very personal thing, so I can't say that others might not like a different place better, but I think this is the best place for sushi in the city and we basically no longer go anywhere else. For the past 15 years we've patronized this place and have come to know the owners, a really great family. 

The sushi is fresh and delicious and is cut from fish bought at the fishmarket, not defrosted from shipped factory cut product. All the sushi chefs are required to be able to cut down a whole fish into sushi. This is important because many, if not most, sushi bars in the city depend on shipments of pre-cut and frozen sushi from big companies. That factory product can be old, dyed, etc., you can tell if it's dyed by examining the rice that comes into contact with the sushi and if it has taken on a lot of the color of the sushi that's a dead giveaway, parden the pun. We judge the quality and freshness of a sushi place by eating the sea scallop; if it's sweet and delicious that is fresh. If it is nasty tasting, avoid the place. If they don't offer fresh scallop and only include it in cooked rolls, you know they are buying from a factory. If they push rolls that include a lot of cooked fish covered in sauce, that's a good indicator that their fish is not fresh because they are covering up the off-flavors by cooking and drenching in sauce. None of that is true here at EBISU where the sushi is great and the scallops are awesome. They often have live sea scallop and sea urchin too, which is a whole other level of fresh. 

The only caveat to the positives is that occasionally they'll get a new sushi chef that is not quite up to the standards of the others that have worked here for years, but given time they improve up to the standards of the others. Service is good, many of the wait staff have been there for years and they are excellent; sometimes during off hours they have new people that are not quite as good, but again I figure with time they fix that. If you want the best experience sit at the bar and buy your sushi chef a beer near closing time on a weekend. 

The only real drawbacks here? Parking is a miserable crappy experience here, and there's a long long line to get in for dinner after 6PM on weekends. Other than that- you'll love the place if you love really great sushi.
author: W M.

description:
The only reason i took off a star is because they are alittle bit pricey.  Their wait is kind of long if you're pretty hungry; however, i don't mind wait, just the price thing kinda gets me.  However, their sashimi is so  good, just melts in your mouth good, especially their yellowtail and tuna..Mmmmm.. I especially love their Rainbow Roll, its heaven!  

Me and boyfriend love us some salmon teriyaki.. kind of pricey, but good and meaty..just the way i like it. It comes with a side of not over cooked veggies, rice, miso and salad...Mmm-mm-good
author: Karen F.

description:
Very good and fresh sushi!!

I love this place for sushi. The chefs are always friendly and helpful. A lot of variety in raw fish and different types of sushi. I'm not into the rolls or cooked dishes, so this is definitely a place I like to get my fresh and raw sushi. 

The prices are not bad at all for quality sushi in the bay area. I have paid more for lower quality sushi and can't say the opposite. There is usually a short wait, so far... I've made it to the sushi bar in 20 minutes. The parking is not so good around Judah and 9th. 

Lastly, my recommendation is their live Uni when they have it. Once you have tried the live uni, you will never have the uni that comes from the box anymore. It's $15 for the live uni, and it is worth every bite.
author: Lilian T.

description:
Gosh...I am torn between a 2 star and a 3 star.  So, let's just give them a 2.5.  I was really looking forward to coming here last night as the dinner served many purposes.  We were having dinner to celebrate a birthday, I was also meeting my friend's wife for the very first time and last but not least, it was dining out for life in San Francisco and Ebisu was a part of that.  So, needless to say, I was super hyped. However, I left disappointed.  The sushi was not fresh and portion size was small, very small.  It was like mini california rolls.  Even their combo plates were small.  

So, why the 2.5 rating?  

I found parking right outside.  Okay, fine that has nothing to do with the restaurant but hey parking is golden in this area and cuz it was literally right ouside...they are getting credit for my parking good luck.  

Also, service was good.  Even though the girl appeared new to the service industry...she was very attentive and nice. 

Lastly, they were able to take 9 of us with a last minute phone call...though the only reason why I didn't have a reservation in the first place was because when I called a week earlier, they informed me that they didn't take reservations.  I guess maybe why they were able to take us was because they just weren't that busy....and I can totally see why.
author: Stella C.

description:
So I just finished my dinner her at Ebisu, and I am not satisfied. 

The rolls we had were the 49er roll, one with soft shell crab and garlic in it, and one with avocado on top, with unagi inside. All these rolls were whatevers, nothing special. Actually they tasted kinda plain. 

I also ordered the pork cutlet, that tasted ok, but my friend said it was dry, so she didn't want to help me eat it. 

I don't know how these servers were taught, but once you finish a dish, they take it away instantly.  Some of you may think that is a good thing, but not when you just put the piece of food in your mouth. I've heard of pre-bussing, but this is a bit overboard. Twice I had to tell our server that we weren't finished yet, b/c she wanted to take our plates away.  I really felt like I was being rushed, and I hate that feeling. It gets kinda annoying.

It may have just been that day, but that experience alone is good enough for me to never eat there again.
author: Peter K.

description:
My girlfriend and I came here for the first time and sat at the Sushi bar.  Our Sushi chef was very knowledgeable and friendly.   We really liked the atmosphere and decor.

Started off with the Cherry Blossom Roll  (My fav) and the Arch Deluxe roll...both were sooo tasty!!  We then had the Sake Toro, and Hamachi Toro, again, very delicious and very fresh!!!  

Lastly, we finished off with a couple of dishes we have never tried: 
- Ankimo (Steamed Monk Fish liver)  - very fresh and tasty
- Kakuni  (Soy braised Pork Belly) - extremely tender and flavorful

All in all, this was a great sushi spot, with very friendly service.  We will be back!!
author: km k.

description:
We frequent this place like it was a ritual for us 10 years ago when my boyfriend and I dated. We remembered the service were great,especially the sushi chefs behind the bar that's where we would seat. They entertained while we ate. We shared great laughs with them. Their sushi always fresh. We  are great fans of hamachis and sashimis.
Now 3kids later and married to then boyfriend. We take our kids here. My kids love sushi,this would be the place we take our kids when ever we are in town. Service is still great,food is fresh as it gets. We ordered the chef special,dragon roll,49ers, and spider roll it was devine we were satisfied.
When I had to change my baby's diapers,I asked our waiter if the bathroom have a changing table? His reply No! And walked away. I got up with baby and diaper in tow walked toward the restroom when the nice hostess asked if I want to change in the waiting area. I explained to her my reasons. She then proceeded ahead to find one of the lady waitress to retrieve two chairs to place inside, the nice hostess arranged the chairs to where she felt it was safe enough for me to lay baby down.
We for sure will be back soon.


0
author: Vuoch. L.

description: Delicious food. Long wait. Expensive. Clean bathrooms. Good service. This place is tiny so if you're attempting to eat here on a weekend, get there early and/or be prepared to wait. Man the food was totally worth it though. Great place for a date.
author: k h.

description: My first time here and I can truly say they have the best Japanese food I have ever eaten. Their black cod tasted great and the texture is like butter. The dragon roll and crunchy roll was also very good. Best service I have ever had at a Japanese restaurant.
author: David S.

description:
When Ebisu is on its game, it contends for best fish in the city but the consistency of product varies wildly.  Experiences ranged from revelatory Toro and Uni one night to disappointingly metallic white tuna belly a few weeks after.

Of note, the live scallops and Kobe beef are must-order items when on the menu; the O-Toro and oysters can be amazing.  The chefs are on the reserved side, the fish is pricey, and waits can be long but on a good night, Ebisu is about as good as it gets in the City.
author: Yan G.

description:
We had a party of three and came here on a Thursday evening at around 7:30pm. Put our names on the list, and went to get a few drinks while we waited. We actually got a call within 15 minutes, but were in the middle of our drinks so we asked them to skip us. We figured since we were such a hassle (we actually first said we'd be there, and then called back and said we'd rather wait for a table) we might not get as good of service. But nope! The hostess was very nice when we got there. We got seated at around 8:15pm at the bar.

Sake sashimi || 8 thick slices of salmon. yummmm!!!!! Quite tasty and great texture, though I've had more buttery/mindblowing flavor at Tokyo Go Go.

Negimachi Temaki (Hamachi with green onion) || Loved the crunchy crispy seaweed on the outside! It's the worst when you bite into dried seaweed and it's so tough you have to pull it off. But not this one. Great seaweed and great rice and ingredients. Though, the fish was a little bit on the mushy side.

Negi Toro Temaki (Fatty tuna belly with green onion) || My boyfriend got this and thought it was great!

Kakiage (Tempura fritter of edamame, shiitake, sweet onion, scallop and shrimp) || REALLY TASTY. I think the tastiness of this dish overpowered the great-but-not-amazing sushi I had. All the ingredients are basically fried as a whole in batter. It comes out on a big round dish, cut into pizza slices with a side of the tempura sauce. I think my boyfriend and I had about four slices each. YUM!!!

My boyfriend's friend got the spider roll and said it was very good.

Since we sat at the bar, we got to watch the sushi chefs work quickly. Pretty amazing to see how they work. They were also very friendly and social. Service was also pretty good. Although they were really busy, they managed to fill my tea cup at least 4 times so I was never left without tea for more than 20 seconds.

All in all, I've had better sashimi, but this place is AFFORDABLE for sushi that's pretty good (and has crispy seaweed!). I will definitely come back!!!!

Be sure to get that tempura appetizer!!
author: Angela H.

description: They changed their menu a bit when they reopened, but I don't care because Tommy and Shizaki are still there.  They always take good care of us!  We don't tell them what we want, we let them decide what we're eating and it is always delicious.  The service is consistently good and the nigiri is to die for.
author: Susan B.

description:
Well, I am not sure about the best sushi on earth but it sure is good.  Ebisu has great ambiance, a great sushi selection, great chefs, and an even better reputation.  It is without pretense, which very important for a slightly pricey restaurant.  If you go here get the Pink Cadillac; a salmon wrapped scallop, flash fried (for about 2 seconds), and served with some delicious dipping sauce.  So good.

Ebisu is a great place for a quite dinner or a group.  I recommend sitting at the bar, but I am usually of that opinion when it comes to sushi places.
author: Phil M.

description:
My wife is Japanese and we've pretty much given up on getting good Japanese food in San Francisco. We've heard a lot about Ebisu, the hype and reviews suggest that it's one of the best Japanese restaurants in SF. Well, if it is, then it's just a reflection of the sorry state of Japanese cuisine here.

First impressions upon entering the establishment; hmm, ok, kinda grungy and kitschy faux-Japanese look to it - I can live with that if the food is good. Service; Chinese restaurant style service in a Japanese restaurant, hmm, maybe I'll look past that if the food is ok. 

We look at the menu. It confirms my initial feeling of the lack of authenticity here. We order a combination of rolls, nigiri, and Aji Tataki. The Aji arrives first. This was noteworthy, it was fresh, and considering Aji has to be perfect to be decent, this was a good sign. 

Unfortunately it was downhill from there. The rest of the sushi was mediocre at best. The fish was at least fresh if not of the best quality. However, the execution was crude, the proportions all wrong, the balance of flavors unrefined. The rice was terrible, and poorly prepared, and the nori was some of the worst that I've had - it was tough and leathery in texture.

All-in-all, it was a dissapointment. We're just going to have to drive the six hours to LA every time we feel like having good, authentic Japanese cuisine.
author: Adrian L.

description:
My father and I went to Ebisu tonight as per recommendation of a friend.

Instead of waiting for seating, we were seated at the bar immediately, which was fine, it added to the atmosphere being surrounded by (friendly) strangers if anything.

A woman next to us overheard us saying that we'd never been there before, and recommended the sushi chef Isa. Apparently she'd been coming here for twenty years, and told us that he'd never done her wrong, so we let him make us whatever he wanted. We didn't order anything specific, just left our dinner up to him.

That was a fantastic decision. 

Every time we ordered a roll, it became more and more delicious. We never had to wait long for another fantastic assembly of fresh fish and perfect ingredients to make its way over to us. Everything was delectable, and Isa definitely knew what he was doing. Beer was plentiful, fish was fresh, everything was fantastic.

We'll definitely be back.
author: Matt B.

description: I had a great lunch experience here. The service was prompt and very friendly, management was very hospitable, and the sushi was really fresh. Wonderful sushi spot. I'll be back for dinner.
author: ali s.

description: The food is very good here and yes it gets busy. To be honest, the portions were too small and expensive for me. Staff is nice and since they remodeled, the ambiance is also very nice.
author: Johanna P.

description: Even though I don't eat raw fish, I found several yummy things here!  The gomae was perfect, the miso eggplant was delicious, and the agedashi tofu was spot on!  Service was excellent.  Can't wait to return!
author: Winnie L.

description:
I just don't get why Ebisu is so popular.  The food is so bland and medicre.  The decor is just blah.  The place is cramped.  I just don't get it.  I would say at least 50% of Japanese restaurants are just as good or better than this joint.  Maybe it's the price as it's inexpensive for Japanese?

Expect a very predictable, stereotypical Japanese decor - blue curtains with white characters / waves, cheap paper screens and light colored chairs/tables.  Old waitresses in kimono.  You get the idea.... old school, middle of the road Japanese joint.

The food offering is fairly standard: fried items such as tempura, tonkatsu, donburis.  Sushis include rolls, nigiri and seaweed based rolls.  Food is okay, nothing innovative and nothing that stands out.

The line is long and parking is difficult.  If you decide to go, park in the Goldgate park and walk over and go before 6.
author: Paul K.

description:
Ok, I came here a bunch of times a couple years ago and was always happy with the fresh sushi and the great service from the Japanese ladies who took your orders and the outgoing sushi chefs. I hadn't gone in a long time and when I went last week after their remodel I was extremely disappointed in the quality of the food.

I ordered the negihamachi roll and the spicy tuna roll. I tasted the negihamachi and it tasted super fishy and all you could really taste was the green onion. I have never sent anything back in a sushi place cause I have been shame, but this tasted so bad! My bf got the sashimi plate and didn't eat half of it because all the fish tasted old and had no flavor. The spicy tuna had way too much onion in it as well and it just looked like brown mush.

After we left, we both felt slightly sick. I have a pretty strong stomach when it comes to food too! I am sorry to say I will never come back since there are so many great sushi places to choose from (i.e. sushi zone).
author: Jesse M.

description: When I'm eating at a sushi place for the first time, I often like to order chirashi -- it gives me a good chance to sample a variety of their fish.  The chirashi here was fantastic!  I mean, maybe I was just having a major protein craving but I can't remember the last time I've eaten a meal that intently.  My boyfriend ordered the 49er roll and a rainbow roll, and both of those were super fresh and tasty as well.  This place is great!
author: Lisa S.

description: Really loved the edamame trio and tempura cherry tomatoes. Sushi was really fresh and yummy too!
author: Natasha M.

description: The sushi is delicious and the the vibe is cool. This is definitely a great find in this neighborhood!
author: Emily P.

description: I have been to  Ebisu about 6 times and I aways believes it's an average food for an expensive restuarant.    The reason I still go there  because there are limited choice of Japanese food in the area that are decent and yet, my employer picks up the bill most of the time.  I went there today, ordered a few Rolls and two of them are just gross, the cherry blossom roll and the so call louisiana roll (spicy hamachi).   This is probably the first time that I had a Cherry Blossom roll that uses marinated salmon in the roll that tasted and smelled  like rotten fish,and on top of that, the rice was overly waterly..., yes waterly. Too much water in the sushi rice when cooking the rice.  I called the waitor and told them about the weird tasting sushi and the waitor said the fish in the center are marinated and that's why the flavor is over powering.   Why on earth would you use a marinated fish on the sushi roll that would over power the freshness of the fish, unless the sashimi used is not fresh in the begining.   I was craving for a spicy tuna roll and yet, they recommended the Poke roll which is spice tuna, and the Louisiana roll ( the spicy hamachi).  I like hamachi over tuna, so I ordered the Louisiana roll. When the roll came, I had no idea that he roll was actually cooked minced hamachi and it's not spicy at all. I am really not a spicy food eater and that roll is not spicy at all.  Both of the roll sucks  and the remaining rolls are just ok..  The only thing that I like about the Ebisu is their bento box, love the variety of the bento box and it's fair for the price,   However, this is probably the last time I would go there.
author: Wil M.

description:
This has to be one of the best if not THE best sushi places ever. You can understand why it got so many awards once you eat there. The service is always outstanding and the sushi chefs are definitely masters in their art. Presentation is beautiful. Freshness of food is great. 
I consider myself a sushi connoisseur with all the different places I've eaten and the fact that I pretty much try everything on the menus. So take it from me, this place is definitely top notch. Sit at the bar for a more interactive experience.
author: Cary S.

description:
Would be five stars if they could get their service and atmosphere together (I agree!).  They do need to work on their bathroom through---always smells stale and dank back there, and the bathroom itself really needs to be cleaner and updated to make me feel better about the overall cleanliness here.  Will change this review when/if the bathroom changes. 

I've been coming to Ebisu since we moved into the area (7 years ago---25+ years in SF) and it is by far my place to go for sushi and their 49er roll is always a part of my standard order.

I only order sushi and can't speak much for their other food.  never had a bad roll here (but I did have terrible sushi at Hotoi across the street, so don't be fooled into thinking you'll get the same sushi there).

The fish has always been fresh and the rolls are consistently great.

Once a while (maybe 1 in 15 times) they take WAY to long to get you your order and the rolls can come in one at a time over a weird time interval.  I've started to ask them to bring the rolls all at once when they are particularly busy, and that solved the problem.  

Try to get there by 6:30 to avoid the sign-in and dreaded wait. 

I would NEVER go to Goemen instead of to Ebisu.  Their service is WAY slow and their food is average.  Kiki is also an "eh."  

Ebisu is the best sushi in the Inner Sunset BY FAR and one of the best in the city if you don't care about decor.
author: TC C.

description:
I eat sushi 4x's a week, from San Diego to Vancouver. This place is in my top 3. Sit at the bar! The rice is excellent. Rice is as important as the fish!!! Try the live scallop, #29 roll, 49er roll, spicy scallop hand roll. Hamachi nigiri was excellent as well. Salmon belly, and albacore toro are excellent. They put a touch of shiso in many of the items.... I love Shiso. 

I've seen a few negative reviews about the cooked food here. I can't comment, I have never ordered anything cooked. Why would you? It's a sushi bar.
author: G C.

description: My friend had taken me here for dinner. He had made reservations but we had to wait around 45 minutes before we were actually seated. The place was so busy! Normally such a long wait would really irritate me but their service was so great. They had given us complimentary drinks to apologize for the wait. It was some kind of citrus cocktail-DELICIOUS! Our server was very attentive and made our experience that much better. The food itself was so fresh and appetizing. It was a more modern take on such a traditional type of food. The only real issue I had was parking. Such a pain!
author: Eila S.

description:
new favorite-reliable sushi place close to home. fish was super fresh. appetizers and rolls were innovative (Roll bite-sized thank you, i cannot handle rolls that are the size of a hamburger patty- so unappetizing!!!!)

the cherry tomato tempura was so fun and delicious. scallop sashimi. soft crab roll. droooool

shared sake bottles with a friend and left with a lovely smile to continue our night with some dancing. 

will continue to Ebi my Su as long as i shall live
author: Carolina S.

description: I stumbled in here when i decided not to have ramen that was across the street.  The name seemed appealing so i decided to try it out. The fish was delicious! It was really fresh where the fish would basically melt into your mouth.  I sat at the sushi bar and order several things.  Definitely a place to try out if you want some fresh, great sushi! Place gets crowded though towards the weekend and you woud have to wait about 30 mins to get seated but it's worth it!
author: Logan T.

description: I've seen walked past this sushi restaurant many times since i've lived here. While eating breakfast at Howard's Cafe, I happened to be sitting next to the owner's (of Ebisu) son, Eric. I've been wanting to go there since I found out about it... So that night my cousin was coming into town and we decided "when in rome......Eat Sushi!" haha, My boyfriend and another friend came along with us and we all had an amazing dinner. I had a Dragon roll which THE BOMBSKI! Its not my favorite roll, but it is now, however, I'll only order it at Ebisu. Speaking of BOMBSKI, my cousin and I had 2 sake-bombs, which i never drink! I have to say, we had a great time. The restaurant is very sheik, sexy, and romantic... great for a date-night. Eric remembered me from earlier and made all of us feel very welcome. The wait-staff was very very very friendly and attentive. Thanks Eric, I'll be back soon!
author: Dora Z.

description:
I've been eating here since 1984.  It has remained the best year after year.  Steve the owner always makes his way to say hello and ask about my mother who has moved to LA.  The fish is always fresh and tender.  I tried live scallop the other week.  Didn't think I could do it, but it was the sweetest thing I'd ever tasted.  Love the tatami rooms.

Thanks for everything Steve.  Sandra & Mamasan
author: Sandra K.

description:
The remodel is pleasant but I miss the old place. Still the best sushi in San Francisco.

Toro 
Kanpachi  
Shiromaguro Toro  
Umi Masu  
Uni
Tsubugai  
Negimachi
Bakudan 
Negi Toro  

All favorites here, service is impeccable, always great food and a great time.
author: Dragonfly C.

description:
Forgive me father, for I have sinned. I promised not to return to Ebisu after my last disturbing time here 5+ years ago. But I saw a commercial for its sexy new digs, and wow, it sure does look swanky!

However sitting at the bar I was reminded how the food is still subpar. Our son-of-the-owner sushi chef had a bit of ADD. We had to wait for 15 minutes between pieces of fish, even though it was early and not too busy. My girlfriend's hand roll was a sloppy, falling apart mess. He also forgot parts of our order. But the icing on the cake was when I saw him prepare the monk fish liver appetizer. I was shocked to see that the liver, in the cooler, was wrapped in store-bought plastic like freakin' liverwurst sausage. Fois gras of the sea, it was not. Here's a pic of the actual brand...
http://seafoodnaturals.com/site/products-ankimo.html
Uh, aren't you guys supposed to be taking this from the monk FISH and dazzling me with your masterful food prep? So basically I'm paying this "chef" for putting some store bought. processed stuff on my plate? Give me a break, this place is so lame, not worth the hype or price.
author: Brady K.

description: Good food, and good service. It was maybe a little expensive, and we had to wait. However, this is the place to go for japanese food in the inner sunset
author: claire l.

description: Voila! Finally a really delicious Japanese restaurant that is not overly priced. This is my favorite sushi place in the sunset. Be sure to try Behind the green door, Family Affair, XXX special, uni, mussels in sake sauce. They also had a halloween/thanksgiving themed sushi roll that was to die for when I first ate here. It had pumpkin for crying out loud! Such a wonderful combination of sweet and savory. Their mussels were really really good (not to mention the broth!). This has got to be one of my favorite sushi places to date. Cozy ambiance, mood is very romantic, and the staff is prompt and knowledgable. It can be packed and parking can be a pain, so try to get there before 6pm to beat the crowd before dinner time. Overall, fresh rolls, good flavors, decent price, and friendly staff. Thumbs up.
author: Ana B.

description: The place got crowded real fast, but luckily we got seated before the dinner rush. My rolls were slightly more petit than I would have liked for the price I paid for them, but they were exquisite-tasting enough to keep ill will at bay. No complaints about the service, except that the place is tiny and picking your way around seated patrons gets tiring. Good experience overall.
author: Angie C.

description: Great value sushi place. What a great find! I went here on a Thursday night for a work dinner. Fresh fish and quick service. Only wish it was closer to my apt. The restaurant is small and the space is quite constrained so definitely not a good place for groups. The restaurant does get quite busy for dinner and becomes noisy but you are still able to have a conversation without being too distracted.  Overall, Ebisu is a low maintenance, no frills neighborhood sushi joint; authentic, fresh and great bang for your buck.
author: Debbie C.

description:
There are a ton of better places, however, we come here because we know one of the sushi chefs who "hooks us up."

The sushi itself is decently fresh, nothing to write home about. But when mom wants some sushi, this is her default place because of the service with a smile.

However, the ultimate fail in my book... the chicken karaage is made with white chicken breast so it doesn't have the fatty tenderness authentic karaage should have. fail fail fail. didn't they get the memo that dark meat is the prize?
author: Sean L.

description:
Not the biggest fan... I mean it's okay- everything was fresh and the service was really good, I just wasn't really impressed by their selection of sushi roles, I dunno- I've definitely had better sushi before.  

And when we tried to use a gift card they told us they couldn't process gift cards yet... um okay so why do you sell gift cards if you can't process them?
author: Karen B.

description: Ok sushi place.  Ok, Ok, let me think hard.  Just Ok.  Not very surprising.  The wait is amazingly long.  Don't go if you are super hungry.  You will be starved to death in front of the restaurant.  Parking is as hard as winning the lottery.  I spent 90 minutes eating in the restaurant.  Before my :( dinning experience.  I spent a 90 minutes combined waiting and finding parking. Sorry guys. 3 stars only.
author: William F.

description: I grew up around the corner from this place. The owners are actually friends of the family but they are incredibly nice and make you feel so welcome! The food is awesome too! Some of the best Japanese food for your money you will find!
author: Julian P.

description: Best sushi I've ever had, be sure to try the Kobe sushi paired with an amazing dipping sauce. Also offer an awesome 2011 "No Tax" deal. Pay with cash, you won't get charged tax!
author: Sean B.

description: Still great. Incredibly fresh fish, including some specialty items like sea trout and butterfish. Great rolls (49er  and Crunch rolls are my fave). Attentive and sassy service. Even some nice desserts (vanilla pot de creme with warm strawberries highly recommended). Sometimes there's a wait, but it's worth it!
author: David B.

description:
I too, think this place is a tad over-rated.  I didn't have a bad experience here but nothing screamed out for attention - basically, it was a forgettable experience.   Not sure why this place is famous...

Needless to say, I did not get a sushi orgasm.
author: Chris B.

description:
Ebisu offers really good sushi.  However, I have to question whether it deserves all the hype.  Personally, I think there are at least two better sushi restaurants in the city (both at approximately the same price range as Ebisu): Jimisan (a block away down 9th Street) and Tsunami on Fulton.  Nonetheless, Ebisu is still better than almost every other sushi restuarant in the city.

Update: Ok, I went to Ebisu again last night, and I now feel compelled to come back, edit my review, and award it five full stars (which I probably should have done from the beginning).  I still personally prefer Jimisan, but Ebisu is definitely one of the best sushi restaurants in the city.

I mean, really, the 49er Roll, the Caterpillar Roll, and the Dragon Roll are unbelieveably good.
author: Matthew H.

description:
I figured I would take a break and write a little something about Ebisu since I had dinner there last night with a good friend and catching up.  I suggested the place because I've had food from Ebisu (but always take out).  We were surprised to see it was busy and it was 9 something in the evening!  Not the best place for good conversation because it is rather noisy but the food and the service were quite nice.

We had the Caterpillar roll and sashimi (well, that was my choice - Salmon and Yellow tail).  We thought it was pretty neat the sushi chefs were having a contest to get their roll on the menu!  We had Roll #4 with shrimp, avocado, salmon roe, and some other good stuff I can't remember but that thing must have been good because I inhaled half of the roll!  Of course, when you dine with a man, they are always hungry so he ordered chicken teriyaki.  Not enough teriyaki sauce (boo) yet there was a really interesting cold mashed potato concoction on the side (yes, it was actually tasty).  Overall, I do heart Ebisu.  So much selection that you do have to come back but just be prepared to wait a little bit for a table.
author: Dorothy S.

description:
FYI: Ebisu is currently closed for remodeling. We ate at Hotei, its sister restaurant - they are serving Ebisu's specialty rolls but the rest is Hotei's menu. 

This review is strictly for Ebisu's specialty rolls, since that's all I was able to try. LOVED the double hamachi roll (recommended by our waitress) but the QP roll (scallop) was my absolute fave. Roll prices are not listed on the menu, but these two were $12.50 each. Will definitely come back to try Ebisu's full menu when they reopen.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
Two of us went to Ebisu on a Thursday night and got in without a reservation or wait. The place did fill up shortly after that. Our food was ok, we got an assortment of sushi rolls, a seaweed salad and the Ebisu Udon bowl. The sushi was tasty but wasn't anything special. Pretty standard. The udon bowl was very good. 

On a side note, that night, there was a family next to our table with 2 kids that were getting up and running around the tight spaces between tables. One kid even knocked our table and was invading on my partner's space while we were trying to eat. The parents saw this but did nothing. I finally said to the child, "excuse me, you're bumping our table" and the negligent mother proceeded to make a wise crack to us and then talk badly about us with her table guests. When they were leaving she continued to bitch and talk about us, so I said out loud "stop talking shit about us" and she then got in my face and started to rampage and say gay-hateful comments like, "I hope you two work out as a couple so that you'll never be able to have kids" then her husband got up and said to me, "are you a supporter of Prop 8?". I told the rude people to just get out and leave us alone.  They were so disgustingly rude that everyone in the restaurant looked at them like they were crazy. 

The staff was actually very nice about it and consoled us after the crazies left. That was nice. Ebisu would have received 5 stars from me had they forced the crazy couple to leave immediately and stop harassing us, but they didn't. They might get a 5 star if they contact me and tell me that they have black-listed the family and will never accept that family in the restaurant again.

To the couple, I hope you read this, if I ever see your family in the area again, you had better watch out because I will be sure to confront you and make your night the worst you've ever had. You'll wish you never left the house.
author: Foodie F.

description: Once again, Steve impresses with the fish so fresh, it must have swam into the restaurant last night. Hamachi toro to die for - I haven't had fish this good in a while. The rolls, which have been copied by many chefs, are still best prepared at Ebisu. While competition is fierce, Ebisu is still unbeatable. Way to go!
author: Tatiana C.

description:
4.5 stars
You can't lose at this place..  Always fun atmosphere and fresh and unique dishes are always available.  Can be a bit of a wait, but me and my man had our 1st date here, so this place is very sentimental for us.  Expensive, but worth it..
author: Rose C R.

description:
This place has the most fantastic salmon roll that I've ever tasted in my life ever ever.  They put a slice of fresh lemon on top and it was like an explosing of sunshine in my mouth.  I will not soon forget that!  They cut up an orange and serve it with a toothpick for a little post-sushi treat.  Very very nice.   For sushi, totally reasonable.
: )
We went there around 3:30 on a Saturday and sat at the sushi bar.  YUM.  I will go back next time I'm in SF for sho.
author: Brent F.

description:
Ebisu definitely lives up to their hype.  I always had to wait when I go there, but I can't blame them.  They always have good business and being in such a small space, it's difficult to not have a line.  Ebisu workers do their best to get people in and out, so you won't have to wait more than 1/2 hour.  Let's get to the nitty gritty!

I've sat at the sushi bar and on a table and I enjoyed both locations.  The sushi bar has great sushi chefs that are busy yet make sure all your requests are met.  I remember one time, we didn't get anything to drink yet, so our chef grabbed a waitress and made sure she didn't forget about our drinks.  What service!  

All their sashimi is fresh and their sushi is spectacular.  Their service is wonderful and will keep me as a regular patron.  The prices are moderate.  Definitely try this place out.  Ebisu is one of those few restaurants that live up to their hype!
author: Manton R.

description: I always try to eat here when I'm in town. Been coming here since '94. In my top 5 best sushi bars of all time. Traditional, fresh and excellent.
author: Ian D.

description:
we just got home from this place.
service is terrible
hostess is clueless

birthday dinner meant zero to where  she chose for us to spent our time

empty place

and they seated us at the bar
not a bad thing usually
again the place was DEAD ,
and the hostess seated a loud family with food -throwing children right next to us

on december 25 in a busy neighborhood joint ?sure!
but DEAD tuesday night in the sunset ?
not worth the trip
food is good but soooo not worth the bill or the trip

service sucked
any question we had about the sake menu
was answered with "uhhh ?" 
and every 2 minutes there were some bussers hands in our faces 
no reason to "turn" tables ,why rush us through dinner?


so ...
no , don't go!
so many great sushi places in this town!

would have left a "zero" for rating
but the food was not so bad
so "one" is what they get 
from me

and i'm not coming back...
author: jet b.

description:
There are so many hole-in-the-wall sushi bars that are better than Ebisu. You know, for the longest time, I shouted this view from the mountaintops, but I was shunned, like Adam Sandler's Waterboy, unappreciated for my sophisticated minority palate and skills (though I still can't dunk).   

Ok, seriously, my litmus test for a sushi bar is the hamachi sashimi -- yellowtail -- and the magoro -- tuna. Here, on 2 separate meals, I got the brown edges rather than the fleshiest butter-colored yellowtail you should expect and the tuna was more stringy than sushi-grade.  

Brand-name sushi bars I'd recommend instead: Blowfish, Sushi Ran, Ace Wasabi.
author: Ben S.

description:
You have to go to these types of Japanese restaurants to get sashimi you can trust.  Believe me.  I went there for the 1st time this week and I found decent grade sashimi, sake and hamachi kama, and service that was pretty damn good.  I was disappointed when I paid the bill.  I feel it was a little over priced considering the decor or the environment isn't like Ozumo or something. 

I had:
Sake Sashimi
Sake kama
steam rice
blue fin toro nigiri
=$35 with tip :|
author: Jason A.

description:
I like Ebisu. The sushi is really good. It's not the best in the city, but it is very close. I like sitting in the shoe-less area or at the bar (the sushi chefs are always funny). 

Their hirame is excellent, as is the scallop nigiri. The Dragon Roll is the best.  Go with some of the specials and suggestions from the staff and you'll have a really good meal.
author: Allyson V.

description:
Yes, I am one of those people at the bar that knows the name of the sushi chefs. We come here that much. I feel bad that other folks don't have that kinda good experience when coming here, and to be honest I am not all that surprised.

Those that know don't come here during traditional feast times. You come here early or don't come at all. I don't believe in waiting more than 30 minutes for anything, but some folks totally don't mind, so more power to you. 

I happen to think the fish is pretty good and I don't mind paying for good fish. But then again, this is at the early end of dinner (or lunch, what have you). Yes, if you do hang out there long enough you'll get to see the special dishes made for you by your sushi  chef, but this is the case at any sushi restaurant. Better good sushi at a price than skanky sushi that's a STEAL! Bleh.

Parking here is ass, so find room at the lots on 7th by Gateway HIgh. (another entrance on 6th, I believe). Walk, dammit, it won't kill you.
author: Charlene L.

description:
This is the place to do Omakase in this city.  Make sure to tell the host before they seat you at the bar, so they give you a seat in front of Suzuki-San -- and just let him take you on a sushi journey.  

He has some italian chef training in him, said he has lived and cooked in italy, so he does some unorthodox things with his fish -- like marinating tuna in red wine.  Unorthodox and absolutely delicious.  His chit-chat was pretty entertaining too, and watching those hands work...just...an amazing sushi experience.

Also -- they give regular customers rewards in the form of 10 and 20% discounts.  I'll definitely be going back.
author: Eugene F.

description:
This place used to be great a few years ago, before the area went uber-trendy/neo-yuppie.  Now, as someone else mentioned, it's been riding on it's laurels for years - the perfect way to put it.  I went there recently for the first time in years, and the food was meh.    Not bad, not great.  But very meh, for the price (which is just a bit over priced, but not astronomically so).

The fish on the nigiri was damn anemic.  It was like they took a slice 60% the size of a regular slice, then stretched it thin over the rice.  The rolls were....interesting....if you're in to that stuff.   They forgot about my friend's dinner order until after the rest of us had finished eating our sushi/sashimi.  It wasn't an "oops, we'll bring that out now", it was an "doh - we didn't put that order in, let me run to the kitchen".  They didn't even offer any sort of compensation for that (at least a free desert, or free/discounted dinner for the one that was late).  I'm only subtracting half a star for that though - figure it's just a one time thing, but still...

And the crowd?  Sure, it's crowded, but that's normal, but it seemed like a majority were tourists/out-of-towners.  I overheard somone at the table next to us ask their dining companion "What part of the city is this considered?", to which they replied "This is the Inner Richmond".  I looked at my friends (we're all locals), and we just shook our heads.
author: T C.

description:
I went to Ebisu for lunch and I don't think it was quite worth it for lunch.  If it isn't priced well for lunch then I would have to assume that dinner would be overpriced as well.  The hype doesn't live up to the food.  

Even the sushi at Miyaki's is better than here, at least they have a better selection of rolls.
author: Herb C.

description:
2.5 Stars!  Totally OVER RATED.  Six  years ago when I didn't know any better, I thought Ebisu was the bomb.  I was so impressed with this place that I took my gf here when she wanted to eat "the best sushi in the Bay Area".  Well, being that  "I had not been around", I thought it would be a good idea to bring my gf here.  WRONG!  What a mistake!  She was not satisfied at all and told me that I needed to take a trip with her to LA.  She told me that "LA sushi is so much better than Ebisu".  I look at this girl totally confused because I was satisfied with dinner and could not believe that it could get any better than this.  

A few months pass by and my gf and I take a trip to LA to visit her family.  During our stay, we hit up like 3 different sushi joints in LA.  OMG!  I was totally blown away!  Sushi Sasabune, Hide Sushi, and Sushi King totally changed my standands for sushi.
author: Steve D.

description:
I did not eat any rolls this time and it's surprising.  But what surprised me even more was that the stuff here is really fresh.  Let me explain.

Kobe Beef Sashimi:  Comes with a sauce for u to dip in and it brings out the beef flavor.  Melts in your mouth goody.  You don't taste the freezer smell which sometimes happens, but not here.  YUM!

Sake Salmon Sashimi:  Fresh, sweet and just the right amount of fat.  

Hamachi Sashimi:  Complimentary of one of the sushi chef and with free food, of course it's good!!  But it was fat and sweet and extremely fresh.  

Touro:  Very fresh, soft and you must have it here.  There is none of that fish smell and melts in your mouth

Amaebi:  Sweet and juicy.  It was also huge!  I rarely see a serving of amaebi this big, and I feel like it was worth my money.  

Raw Oysters:  Clean, fresh and I did not taste any dirt of gritty stuff in it.  Even some nice oyster bars in the city don't clean the oysters that well.  I give extra points to them for that.  

Overall, this place is awesome.  Fresh everything.  Staff is friendly.  Long wait though, but once you sit down, the food is worth it.  I recommend the bar.  The chefs are friendly and they will tell you what's fresh today or what's not really fresh.
author: AhLin C.

description:
Food: A little overpriced, but one of the slightly more authentic Japanese places left. The menu is quite extensive, and the location is convenient. The rolls are well-put together, but I wouldn't say the quality of food is excellent.  The presentation is pretty good, though.

Ambience: The place is not very lively at all, a bit dim, and a little awkward.  Maybe I just didn't come during the right time.

This place is just generally too blah to be a date place, and too expensive to be a weekend sushi spot.  So, I don't think I'll be returning anytime soon.
author: Audacity L.

description:
This is the restaurant from which I compare all other japanese restaurants to. "The sashimi is not as good as ebisu." "They have more rolls at ebisu."  Although there are definitely better restaurants out there, Ebisu's menu is consistently fresh and well prepared.  

Even though I love ebisu, I can't bring myself to give them 5 stars.  Perhaps i'm tired of the long lines, maybe I feel less appreciated for my business, or even..dare I say... my palate is becoming more sophisticated. Whatever the reason, Ebisu is still one of my highly regarded restaurants.
author: Ezduzit S.

description:
Now, I haven't eaten here in a few years, so I can only review what I remember. The sushi was pretty good... fish was fresh... and service was "ehhh". The place is GOOD, but nothing SPECTACULAR. 

Good luck with parking. Best bet is to park closer to UCSF and walk a few blocks.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
Isn't it supposed to be amazing?

No it's not. 

Average sushi but nothing special.

Very americanized rolls, but tasty.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
Tried this place as my aunt and I were in the mood for sushi and it happened to be right there.  Oh, and my aunt had heard of it.  :)  

Atmosphere-wise, it's just like every other sushi place.  Prices are decent.  We ordered a roll in addition to our 2 meals, which came with miso soup (looked tasty, too bad I'm allergic).  The one odd thing was that they totally timed everything poorly so that I was left watching my aunt eat her meal for a good 10 minutes before mine came (mine wasn't even that hard - tuna sashimi and tempura!).  

Overall, decent, but they could work on the timing of serving their dishes.
author: A L.

description: The fish here is incredibly fresh.  The mushroom skewers we had had some kind of magic marinade they were so good.  We ordered the chef's sashimi selection which you can share with 2 people or finish by yourself if you're really hungry.  The salmon was so buttery soft I could have eaten a whole plate of it.  The ambiance is great and the service was friendly as well.  Best sushi I've had so far in the inner sunset - we are so lucky to have this place in our neighborhood!
author: Kimberly J.

description: I think this is as good as it gets.  Very nice staff and the owner is usually always there to talk.  The highest standard of freshness and presentation.   I love this place.
author: SF Goofball G.

description: Lunch box is fully loaded. Great value.
author: Jacqueline X.

description:
My son and I discovered Ebisu 2 yrs. ago and have tried to make an annual trip ever since..and we're from So. Cal!  
  Finding a sushi restaurant with the freshest fish, NOT covered in sauce and/or tempura fried, creative dishes and just the right ambiance is very hard indeed.  The wait can be tediously long(be sure to sign in on that  clipboard) and it ain't cheap, but try to score a seat at the sushi bar and be prepared to be W0WWeD!!!  Besides, after an 8hr. drive the cheque is the last thing I  and my tummy care about!
  On both visits, we have been lucky enough to be waited on by the owner's son, who is efficient, friendly and intuitive in suggesting sushi you will enjoy.  There was a 2 part scallop dish he served us which still brings longing to my heart and tastebuds.  The combo fresh seafood platter with mussels was on ice and delish , my son wolfed down his chicken teriyaki , and to this day my husband still longingly plans imaginary trips here.  In short......eat here or DONT...more for me! =)
author: Dennielou S.

description:
Ebisu must mean overrated and awful in Japanese because those are definitely the words I would use to describe my experience here (yes, I know that's not what it really means).

I went to dinner here tonight and vow I will never go here again.  I heard so many good things about this place from friends and was excited to find another sushi joint.  I'm a huge Japanese food and sushi fan and always love trying new spots.  This restaurant was a complete disappointment.

First things first, the place is small and parking in the area can be tough.  It's obviously a very popular place since there was a huge wait for a table.  My friend got there early to get our table, so when I got there I only waited another 15 minutes.  We had a table for 5 and were seated at a table for 4 with one of our friends kinda sitting halfway in an aisle and halfway on the side with 2 others in our group.  I tried to look past all this since the service started off okay and I was excited to try some of their rolls.

My friends ordered their food and I (being hungry) ordered a Poke Roll, a #29 roll (Yellowtail tuna, salmon, shrimp and green onion wrapped in soybean paper, deep fried with tuna on top), and salmon nigiri.  We received our rolls at separate times, which was fine.  I received my Poke roll first and it was smaller than I expected, but was okay.  The salmon nigiri was pretty fresh and I was pleased with that as well as the #29 roll.  The sushi was good (no major complaints), but definitely not any better than other sushi spots I have been to.  We also ordered some sake.

We were okay with everything (at this point I would have given 3 stars) and then it happened.  The bill showed up.  One of my friends had ordered 2 rolls and only received one of them.  She was okay with that as long as it wasn't on the bill...and of course it was there.  We flagged down the server and let her know that we hadn't received the one roll.  The server gave us attitude about the situation and said that she would take it off.  Great, right? Well, she sent another server to say that she had brought the roll that was missing and argue with me about it.  I made it clear what I ordered and what was delivered to our table.  We did NOT receive all the food listed on the bill.  After going back and forth with these servers for about 20 minutes, they removed the Poke roll (which cost less than the other roll that was not delivered to our table) from the bill.  We gave up and just paid that bill and I promise I will never go back here again.  I plan on telling everyone I know to avoid this place.

Let's summarize...parking is tough in the area, the restaurant is small and there is a long wait, the sushi is just okay and the service started off good, but ended terrible.  Ebisu...FAIL.
author: Ruben P.

description: Went back here on the 4th of July right before we were going to head to out to see the fireworks. We had everything from Uni, Toro, Escolar, Albacore and a few special rolls made by the sushi chef. I totally recommend sitting at the sushi bar, which is the only place I ever sit when I'm here. Although we missed the fireworks there were fireworks in our belly's because everything was DAMN GOOD and fresh!
author: drew s.

description:
Feels like you're in Kyoto having sushi.  The fish is fresh and the service is great. Simply one of the best.  You can't go wrong except show up early or you will have to wait for a table for awhile...even on a weekday.

Here's a secret.  If you don't want to wait, go over to Hotei for a short wait and they serve the same sushi from Ebisu.
author: Julia H.

description:
It used to be that this place was the shiznit for Sushi. We braved long lines and the crowded little foyer just to have our monthly fix of Ebisu. They were making interesting rolls and fish. Now? Eh, not so much. Hey Ebisu, take a lesson from Bill Clinton: Change is good!! Though, even if they were making something out of Anaconda, I'd head elsewhere. If I get the Ebisu urge, I go to their joint across the street, Hotei, for some Udon and a couple of Maki. One thing Ebisu always has: good, lively atmosphere. Tough for them to compete with the new kids on the block: Koo.

3 duckets for being a SF original, minus 2 duckets for STILL being a SF original.
author: Johnny C.

description:
Good, but overpriced.  And the wait is ridiculous.

On the other hand, their chef is hillarious.  The old guy.  If you go I recommend sitting at the bar.  You'll hear interesting stuff.
author: Igor N.

description:
Don't you find it annoying when the people sitting next to you at the sushi bar are such regulars that the sushi chef is adorning their plates with endless complimentary sushi, and your stupid little order is nowhere to be found?

Oh, it's just me.

On a food-related note, the fish didn't stand out one way or another.  Simply nothing remarkable about it.  

Do note that if you like your sushi or sashimi room temperature, this isn't the place to go.  My maguro was ice cold (which I like, but people've told me it's supposed to be served room temp, so you know ... fair warning).
author: Ann M.

description:
Having been to Ebisu a number of times in the past, all I can say about waiting for a table is timing, timing, timing.  It's hard enough trying to find parking around that area, waiting for a table certainly won't be any much easier.  The few times I've been there for an early dinner around 6pm, I've been able to get seated without a wait.  They're open Saturday for lunch, and it's quite empty, except around 2ish, oddly enough, which was when it got crowded.  If' you've had bad sushi, you'll appreciate what Ebisu offers.  Ebisu does not load its sushi with rice to fill you up and skimp on the contents.  The rice-to-content ratio is just right to savor the mixture of flavors in one bite.  

I got a little adventurous and tried the cherry blossom roll, which had salmon and smoked salmon...it wasn't great because the rice was falling apart from the roll.  So, I'd suggest sticking with the conventional rolls.
author: Ginni S.

description:
I am not a pescatarian.  I don't like fish, or really anything that comes from the ocean, river, etc.

So it is never with great enthusiasm that I join my friends for sushi.  Sure, I can find chicken teriyaki just about anywhere, and I can usually enjoy the kappa maki, but it always looks like more fun to order all those crazy rolls.  

Well, thanks to Ebisu, I, too, can have some fun.  They have a delicious vegetable tempura roll, which is wrapped in soybean paper instead of seaweed (included in my distaste for things that come from the ocean!).  So good!  Why don't more places offer this?  On top of that, I'd say Ebisu is reasonably priced and the other non-sushi options are tasty as well.
author: Christina D.

description:
Ebisu is the sushi version of Cheers - and I love how they make me feel like Norm!  I always have so much fun here - the vibe is great and the sushi is excellent.

My faves:
- Sushi chef Tommy
- Yellowtail nigiri
- Spicy tuna roll
- Pan-fried yellowtail cheek (hama-something), 
- Fresh scallops, diced and sauteed w/ shitake mushrooms in a baby omelette
- The picture of cats playing poker on the wall behind the sushi chefs...

Parking tip:  Park in the Golden Gate Park at the 9th & Lincoln entrance.
author: Tina T.

description:
Here is my most honest and unbiased review on Ebisu...  and why people love and hate this place.

No, it is NOT a place where you do omakase, because I agree with other Yelp reviews: 1. Not all chefs here are great.  But they're all pretty good if you communicate with them on what you want; and 2. the price is high...  so it's tricky to control that when you go freestyle.  On the chefs...  Why are some of them not up to the standard?  I think after making spicy tuna roll, roll after roll, a lot of your desire to be a good sushi chef can just simply evaporate.  How good does one need to be at making spicy tuna roll...  anyway?  It's got lower grade tuna with a lot of hot sauce.  Buy it at Whole Foods if you will.  So how should one order at Ebisu?  You have to let go the old fashioned approach of trusting your chef blindly, but not so much as to embrace everything you see on the menu.  

I go there (or used to go there when my rent was cheaper at a few blocks away from the restaurant) for the guarantee on certain items I love so much.  Black cod.  Live scallops.  The entire Aji prepared from head to tail.  Incomparably fresh Uni (or live Uni from time to time, if you're lucky ).  And once in a while I throw in Kobe beef sashmi and some salmon belly.  Or any other interesting fish that is on the special board that day.  I have not been disappointed.

To be able to indulge ridiculously fresh fish that many other restaurants will just outrightly tell you that they don't have it because people don't eat that here...  I don't consider the price at Ebisu ridiculously high.
author: Jiajia C.

description:
I wish that I had a better experience here, I am so sad. 
So many people have recommended it to me and I wish I could sing it praises. 
I had the tuna which was great but the Halibut ---- oh the Halibut. It had turned way south and gone bad. Then I had a roll which was ok but nothing to write home about and this Pink Cadillac - ew. Not yummy at all. 
At the end of my meal I got a bill for 50 bucks. Not good and I had to pay top dollar for it - boo. 

I may give it another try but on someone else's dime.
author: Shawn P.

description:
PROS - fresh, creative rolls, carry-out options, variety

CONS - no reservations, a little on the pricey side, non sushi food items tend to be on the bland side

One of the better Japanese restaurants I've been to but it's by no means the best... just my opinion  :)
author: Jess R.

description:
The sushi here is decent but not super amazing. i wasn't that impressed. 

maybe the best in 2000 but i guess someone else took it.
author: oth k.

description:
This place used to be SOOO good. What happened?

I went there on Sunday and none of the rolls tasted good. When eating the first bite of a roll with salmon, I started wondering what was wrong with the salmon? Why was it so slimy? I couldn't figure it out!- Oh wait- that's the taste of fish that is really unfresh! In a city full of amazing sushi options- sushi zone? Why would anybody eat at this overpriced relic?

2 stars exclusively for the service, because the waitress was really nice!
author: Tasha R.

description:
First let me say that I eat Sushi once or twice a week. Second let me say that I work in the restaurant industry. Hence why I ask the question to other yelp users, why complain about wait times when that just means that the place is good, popular and full of people. Come early, stop ranting...

But I digress. The fish here has ALWAYS been superbly fresh and of great quality. The chefs definitely take care of you (I only sit at the bar so maybe that's part of it too). Try the Spanish Mackerel, its to die for. Ask the chef for a selection of Nigiri or Sashimi for the adventurous. The fish is just always good.

The rolls are quite good too. I liked the 49er b/c you just taste the salmon and lemon. Its simple and good. Some of the more specialized rolls are good too, but not spectacular.

Service is attentive, but perhaps a little overzealous about bussing.


Oh and for those who just CAN'T wait, or go b/w lunch and dinner, just go across the street to Hotai, its almost as good (same owners and mostly same menu).
author: Morgan A.

description:
I don't really understand the hype about Ebisu. I've heard it's the best in the city but I personally have tasted better. The rolls are pretty pricey for being mediocre. Also, the wait is extremely long and the tables are wayyy too close together. The last time my boyfriend and I were there, it felt like we were on a date with a father and daughter pair. They were basically listening to our entire conversation. Other than my unpleasant experience there, I think the staff is very friendly and you should try it before you judge it. 

PS. Parking is difficult, go early!
author: Vikki K.

description:
I would give Ebisu 5 stars for the freshness of sushi, but I'm short-changing them because the service, though authentically Japanese, or maybe because it IS authentically Japanese, is totally confusing. In other words, sitting at the sushi bar, you are served from behind with certain items, but then have to place your order with the sushi chef.  While this isn't unusual, it was extremely frustrating on this particular night.  That being said...

You will search far and wide before you find fish fresher than Ebisu serves, especially the variety that they serve.  With a $100 gift certificate in my pocket, we were all about the splurge and ordered almost entirely off the specials of the day menu... 

Which included Live Uni... So, I wasn't entirely prepared to have a sea urchin cracked open on a bed of ice... it being somewhat similar to having a fish with its eyes staring back at you from its deathbed... And my dining partner was extremely ambivalent.  But, hearing my father's voice in my ears, "Live dangerously, daughter," I forged ahead.  What the heck - when am I ever likely to spend $18.50 plus tax and tip on such an adventurous dish, I ask you?  

It wasn't horrible.  It wasn't foie gras... but pretty damn close, just a fishier version:)

Ebisu is not the hot new latest hippest trendiest let's smack them with crazy rolls (mostly full of rice)... It's for the aficionado of fish and if it's quality that you want - two thumbs up!

p.s.  When we offered the chefs sake ('cos what's the point of sitting at the sushi bar if there are no "Kampais" going around?) we were told that it was recently banned... something to do with fear of law suits:(
author: Lorraine F.

description:
