After a visit to GoldenGate Park the hubby and I were in search of good eats before my flight home, he had to stay behind for work anyhoo...we stumbled on 9th Avenue and walked a few blocks to see what cuisine would satisfy our hunger....after seeing so many choices - we decided on sushi and since Ebisu was packed it was the one we would try out. It's a tiny little place and had a full house, but we managed to get seated right away.

I ordered the 49ER Roll (Sliced salmon, lemon, avocado, tobiko and shiso) - the roll was packed tight and the lemon kept the flavor pretty fresh. Hubby ordered a Seafood Udon, I thought it was a-ok, I myself prefer Ramen over Udon.....overall 3 stars for good eats and nice service; however, when in SF again - I wouldn't go out of my way to dine there. There are just too many dang choices of eats, I dig the Bay Area....
author: chelo a.

description: Always love Ebisu, never dissapointed, worth it to wait
author: Marsaulina V.S V.

description:
This place used to be excellent. They used to have great quality fish and wide variety of delicious rolls. 

After renovation, even though it looks more trendy and the wait is much less, the quality of the sushi and the restaurant has worsened significantly. 

Sushi now consist of more rice than fish and are bland; the previously elaborate menu (with the option to order something off the menu -- you could just tell the waitress what you were in the mood for, and they would just make it!) is now much smaller, simpler. They don't even have Philadelphia roll!

Before they used to have waiters running around and you would always have good, fast service. Now our waiter was moving in slow motion, was unable to recommend sake and messed up our order.

This place used to have such a great reputation!
I doubt I will be coming back.
author: Yelena K.

description: Don't know what is wrong here -- but let's not knock a great restaurant that has become a part of SF culture! Let's rally! I like Ebisu. It's on the older side but you can count on interesting, fresh sushi. Plus I like that I went there 10 years ago and I can still go today. Long live Ebisu!
author: p v.

description:
Terribly disappointed with our first visit to Ebisu.

We ordered sushi to go and our completed order was left unnoticed by anyone at the register for nearly 30 minutes until I asked about the status of our order.  By that point nearly 60 minutes had past since we initially had ordered.

TOTALLY UNACCEPTABLE!

Regarding the sushi...I'm sure (for other people) it's tasty and materials are fresh.  Our sushi would have probably tasted better if it hadn't been overlooked by Ebisu's staff.  As it was, by the time we ate, our sushi that was supposed to be warm (i.e., unagi, etc.) was cold and mushy.  Cold fish on various sushi were room temperature and not particularly appetizing at that point.

Maybe our experience is the exception at Ebisu but my wife never wants to return and I think with so many other worthy sushi restaurants in the city that we will take our business and appetites elsewhere.

Too bad.  We had high hopes for Ebisu but they never gave themselves a chance with us.
author: Scott T.

description: My favorite sushi place - good quality fish,  good service, and nice owners.  Have been coming here for years.
author: Val S.

description:
I've not been back to Ebisu in a long, long time because I was not remotely happy with the food.  Now that they've remodeled, I decided to come here for lunch after a morning of energetic volunteer work with BFF and her hubby at the American Cancer Society's annual Strides for Breast Cancer Walk.  

The interior has been nicely remodeled and appears roomier even 'tho the space hasn't changed much. There are 2 unisex bathrooms in the rear, right before the kitchen.  We were admiring the beautifully polished curly Koa wood adorning the sushi bar.  Additionally, because we were so inquisitive about the redesign, the waiter told us they used bamboo flooring and sections of the old wooden walls (other sections are bamboo as well) were salvaged  from a North Bay barn.  Yea, for sustainable construction!

BFF and her hubby had the Bento Box , a good amt of food for $14 each. It had a mix of salad, seaweed salad, sushi, and your 2 entrees. She had flank steak slices and gyoza.  He had tempura and teriyaki chicken.  They came with miso soup (salty good, carrots slices, tofu and 2 chunks of potato!).  We started off with the poke roll $6.95 with chopped poke in the center surrounded by rice and hamachi nigiri ($4.75 for 2) which was very tender but lacked the wonderful flavor that a good hamachi can have.  I ordered the shrimp (5 of them) and vegt tempura ($9.50) which came with rice.  It was very good with crispy batter and a slice of lotus root, broccoli, green beans, yam, carrot.  Tea was complimentary.  I would definitely consider coming back but it can get pricey for lunch, running well over $20 per person.  We've ordered large platters of sushi from Ebisu for lunch at work recently, and found the sushi rolls wrapped in pink or yellow colored seaweed to be very good.
author: Ry T.

description: I actually just got home from eating here. I always saw a big line outside and always wanted to try it. Anyways, I give this place 2 stars because it has nice ambiance and the service was attentive BUT it only gets 2 stars because the place is overpriced for extremely small, less then average portions. I mean yes dragon rolls usually go for $13 but not for something as small & unfilling as the one from this restaurant. Another complaint was that they pack people into this restaurant like sardines. If I moved the wrong way I could've literally hit the woman next to me. Honestly $40 for 2 specialty rolls & one pathetic excuse for a specialty roll is truly not worth it. Will never come back. The saying is right, curiousity killed the cat.
author: Dessa S.

description: Yelp helped me to find a good place to eat in SF a couple of times already, but this time it was fail. Rolls with herring (?) and onion (Behind the green door, I believe) could be good as a snack for vodka, but not for tender roll. Arch deluxe roll is something big and hard to chew. The place is very small, too crowded. Two starts for the  good service though.
author: Dmitry A.

description:
I've been coming here for nearly 22 years.  My first time was as a student, just before the 1989 earthquake.  The owners, Steve and Koko have been in the sushi business for over 3 decades.  
Consistently excellent, top quality sushi and top-notch service.  
Portions have remained generous and they are always happy to pour me another glass of "mother's milk" (cold unfiltered sake).  Especially good is the fresh toro and live scallop.  Uni is always fresh and borders on obscene the way it makes you feel as it slides down your throat...I miss their mascot, "Smokey" the cat, RIP.
author: Kathy H.

description: My wife and I love this place! Well worth the price! We always leave full and more than satisfied.
author: Eric H.

description:
What a PITY.  Been here so many times we have a "frequent flier card" or whatever it's called.  Disclaimer: yes, we went for Christmas eve. Probably the regular chefs were off, HOWEVER...
1. Skimpy on the seafood.  six oysters breaded in Panko:  You sure there's oysters in there? Caterpillar roll: where's the unagi?
2. Something very wrong here: had to send back a $25 piece of beef. Completely inedible due to a mountain of salt it was cooked with. They comp-ed us 50% of the cost, but wouldn't give back the steak, even though I could've scrubbed it and the dog might've eaten it. Seafood hot pot. didn't taste like fresh seafood, and that's not cool at all in a seafood restaurant.
3. For the cost of the food, it should've tasted a whole lot better. This seems to be the trend though. Half the time, half of the food is tasty (like the dynamite oysters) and half the food is either "eh" because it's either over or under seasoned.  You just never know what you're going to get, so better go to Jimisan up the block where it's more consistent.
author: Nini M.

description:
overpriced and undersliced! I've never been overly impressed with the grade of their sushi. Even we be sushi was better than this place.

the last time I went to Ebisu (in 2001), they tried to switch over to the dinner menu on me when it was still 45 minutes from the lunch menu expiring. Sneaky little farts.

I would not recommend, based mostly on price and my obvious personal grudge.
author: Steven G.

description:
Excellent Sushi, terrible wait. Worth the wait though. I come here on rotation with my 2 buds and we can rack up a good $150 for the three of us. That takes care of our bottles of sake and rolls. Look for Akira or Jackson. They are the best sushi makers behind the bars and if you want a roll that's extra special and not featured on the menu, ask for "Behind the Green Door." it is to die for! 

I have yet to try their other noodle house, Hotei, right across the street from ebisu, but i look forward to it. The owners and staff are very nice and always remember us when we come in. It's just always a shame to see disgruntled customers yelling at them asking when they'll get seated. 

This is a sushi treat... :)
author: Alyson C.

description:
The great thing about out of town visitors is that it gives me a great excuse to try out new spots.  We can experience the new spots together!  So, my cousin was in town for business, her husband tagging along.  She went out with some work friends, leaving us to explore the city on our own.  Sushi anyone?

We went on Thursday at 5:30.  I was expecting a long wait since that's what I've also heard about this place.  To my surprise there were only a handful of people, mostly sitting at the bar.  We sat at the table at first, but then realized how much fun people were having at the bar, so we switched.  The hostess yelled, "Cancel!" and then there was a bit of confusion, which I felt really bad about.  We didn't know it would affect so many people to move our seats.  But they were accomodating and in the end it was find.

We started with sashimi.  Glorious chunks of himachi, sake, toro....I'm salivating just thinking about it again!  Then we ordered the spicy tuny roll.  It was good, but not great.  BUT, when we ordered the Arch roll...it was game over.  I'm a sucker for soft shell crab.  The  heat of the crab, the coolness of the rice, the sweetness of the mayonaise...it was all so freakin good!

Great dinner!  4 and a half stars.  I'll save the 5 stars for a dinner when I have a When Harry Met Sally moment  :)
author: Sonic D.

description:
I give you 2 stars!

Not because the quality is really 2 stars, but the quality relative to the hype is ridiculous.  Some people talk this place up big time, but I find it "pleasantly mediocre", especially given the myriad other options that have superior sushi at a better price.

I am a firm believer that you cant rate a sushi place on one visit, and thrice I have been, however I doubt I will go again.  Each time it is just way too OK for me to shuffle over up in there...
author: Evan R.

description:
Ebisu is quality sushi.

It's too bad I won't go back here because of all the bad karma points I logged back in my "man-eating" days.
author: Kali D.

description:
4 stars. Negative .5 stars for the wait! I'll round it off at 4.

Why is there always a wait here? I must have been here, at least 30 times, and I've only NOT waited, maybe once! The line speaks for itself.

Service and food here are spectacular. I've never had anyone here, that speaks English, as a first language, but it adds to an authentic experience. Don't worry, they still get your order correct.

Seating can be packed, and I doubt having a huge party here, is even possible. The tables in the rear, are pretty fun. They make you take your shoes off. Some people might not like it, because you have to sit on the floor, but it's an experience.

Everything here is tasty! I wouldn't say it's the BEST sushi in SF, but I've had so much worse. It's medium priced, and you get a little more then what you pay for.
author: Charles K.

description:
Can't wait to come back in for my seaweed salad roll, cherry blossom roll, hamachi nigiri, and edamame!

Had a problem w/ a take-out order in the past, but management promptly corrected the issue.  They were both prompt and generous in admitting and fixing the mistake.  That's good management.  And that's why they've been open for something crazy - like 22 years!
author: Charla W.

description:
I didn't visit the restaurant but I had a large catering order for our company happy hour...I worked with Eric who was very helpful & accomodating (tho sometimes it was difficult to get in touch with him). & even though the delivery was late, the sushi came ready to go, looked incredibly fresh & tasted even better. I definitely want to visit the restaurant for dinner & will use them in the future for our catering needs. 

*read the bio of the owner on their website, it's quite interesting
author: Kimberly P.

description:
Great place!  Except not open on Mondays :( !

No, really, a great place.  Go there for lunch before or after going to the DeYoung or Academy of Sciences in GGP.  It'll really make for a fun day!
author: B Y.

description: This place was great in that the waiters were very nice, and hilarious! I got to sit in the section with the low tables and got to eat while laying my knees and legs to my side on the floor. Authentic and comfy for sure. The menu had a variety of exquisite foods I've never tried before. It's a bit pricey, but worth a try! If you go, definitely get the inside room.
author: Cindy S.

description:
By now everyone who knows Ebisu knows they have great sushi.  On food alone, this place is 4-5 stars.  But when I take into consideration service and value...well they leave a lot to be desired.  I've been going to Ebisu since high school, but hadn't been back in a couple years.  The remodeled restaurant looks great, but the prices have been more than adjusted to match.  OK so this is SF and we are used to living with that, but the service now is notably subpar.  We went on a Friday night and after waiting patiently a good 30 minutes were seated.  Not 2 seconds after our asses hit the chair the waitress was asking us if we knew what we wanted.  We hadn't even opened our menus yet.  Then after opening the menus, she was back in like a minute asking for our order.  Fine, we were hungry so we just divied in.  From then on they were eager to clear every dish from our table even before we were finished!  There'd be like 1 or 2 pieces on a plate and she would show up asking if she could clear it.  How about some time to enjoy our meal?  I know restaurants want to turn over tables, but rushing people this much is ridiculous.  

I like the sushi so I'll probably go back, but definitely at off hours.  Lucky for them the sushi is good so it's difficult to stay away for long.
author: Al K.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants. Never had a bad meal here. The staff and sushi chefs are all personable and the food excellent. The fish is extremely fresh. The only problem is it is a small place - so go early or go late, or be prepared to wait.
author: Audrey H.

description: The sushi is so fresh! I love this place!
author: Marina K.

description:
It's interesting to me the buzz this place gets.  Then I realize who is reviewing this place.  People that really don't live and die for sushi.

 These are the same types that rave about a certain wine... but really have no clue at all of even what grape they're imbibing. 
 
"hmmm I think that this one is really oaky,,,"  

Please,,,you wouldn't even know what oaky is...even if the whole damn tree fell on you.

You know what?  If you're judging a sushi place by the rolls they make...get a clue...rolls are not sushi...they are an abomination of sushi...a Frankenstein that has been bastardized by non Japanese.  It's like judging a Mexican restaurant by the burrito it makes.  You know what?  They don't eat burritos in Mexico...just like they don't eat a freaking Louisiana Hotlink Roll (WTF?) in Tokyo. 

 If I took raw dog, slathered it with mayo, added some tobiko, and called it a "Ruff Roll" some people would be extolling what a wonderful sushi I made.

So when you really get the sushi here.  It is average at best.  Most of the fish is...well...limp...not the freshest or else the chefs aren't handling the fish with care.

People are so clueless.  Did you happen to know that most of the people working here aren't even Japanese, they're freaking Chinese?  Nothing wrong with that since I'm Chinese too...but when i go to a Japanese restaurant...it just seems to me that I'd want all of my chefs to have grown up making that cuisine their whole life.
author: J C.

description:
"Ebisu" is Japanese for mouth watering.  Not really, but roll with me.  If you love sushi, Ebisu is a dream come true.  The rolls are beautifully prepared and delicious (but I agree the absence of prices on the picture menu is shady) and the sushi is divine.  

I especially recommend the live scallop, which is usually listed on their sushi special menu.  For this dish, they prepare fresh scallop sushi (6 tiny nigiri arranged neatly on a scallop shell around some ponzu sauce).  As an added bonus, you also get a fried onion bloom to compliment your scallop sushi all for the bargain price of around $14.  I have it virtually every time I go, and I've never been disappointed.  It's consistently fresh, light, and flavorful.

Originally, I included ambiance in the minuses category for this restaurant, but they renovated and the new space is gorgeous.  It's still a little tight, but the architecture is beautiful.

Minuses: Parking is a bitch (but really where in SF is it not?), but there is a lot directly across the street that costs $8 flat fee to park, so if you're desperate and have a decent cash flow you won't have to scour the Sunset for spaces.

Update: The parking lot is gone, so parking is more a bitch than it used to be.  Leave a little extra time to find a place and be ready to walk.
author: Brooklyn S.

description:
I think Ebisu has been considered in the top echelon of sushi places for a long time. I hadn't been there in years, but just stopped in by myself on a whim recently. Sushi is still great, particularly the staples, and the chefs are attentive and talkative at the bar. 

That being said, something about the experience feels a bit dated now. Along with the popularity and the resulting difficulty getting in, I think there are plenty of reasons to go somewhere else.  But I'll give credit where it's due - these guys make beautiful and delicious nigiri and rolls (if not the most creative in the world), with a specials menu that always seems to have some tasty choices.
author: Jon W.

description:
Everyone has always raved about this place.  I've been three times and each time I come away thinking, very good, but great?  As great as everyone says?  No.
That's why I'm giving it three stars, I'd prefer three-and-a-half, but that's not an option.
Try it yourself.  I'm obviously in the minority.  I may go back, it's good, I'm just not sure it's worth the wait and there's always a wait.  Also, it's a bit out of the way for me.
author: Kara H.

description:
Ebisu is far from being the least expensive sushi place to dine at in SF, but they do it very well. I came during happy hour and was given the edamame trio to start with (edamame three ways--garlic butter, sea salt, and pepper). For my meal, I ordered the a sashimi trio appetizer, which had three slices each of maguro, hamachi and sake served with shaved oshinko cucumbers, fresh onion, carrot, avocado and ikura, and then drizzled with a sweetened soy sauce ($10). I don't know that the flavors all melded together in this. Seemed to be some kind of deconstruction of a Hawaiian poke, and I think I prefer real poke over this. Nonetheless, the fish was fresh and tasted good.

I followed this up with an order each of medium toro ($7.5), shiromaguro ($4.5 I think), umi masu/ocean trout ($5.5), and kanpachi ($4.5-5.5--I don't remember). All the fish was very fresh tasting. I was a little disappointed with the umi masu, but that was due to personal taste. 

I ended off with the 49er roll, which was avocado maki topped with sake and a thin slice of lemon ($8.95). I think next time I will pass on this. I felt the flavor of the fish was overpowered by the lemon, so I was not a fan. Still, I will definitely return.
author: Crystal L.

description:
I had only tried their sushi platters for parties before, and the sushi was quite good.  

Finally getting to sit down in its renovated state, I can say that the bathroom is nice :)
The spacing is a bit cramped, and we had to ask for a table that had more lighting, even though it was during lunch time.

This place is all about the food.  We had one of the better caterpillar rolls here.  Also had a cold noodle dish(not soba) that tasted yummy.  The lunch combination is a lot of food, which was not what I expected.  Couldn't finish everything; had to take it home.

Pricey, of course.  Two entrees and one(or two) roll(s) cost nearly $50, if I recall.  But I came away impressed.
author: Stephen N.

description: This place good. Kinda expensive for the portions given, but the quality is very good.
author: Matthew T.

description:
the quality of the fish is not bad, but also not superb. kind of like ok, but nothing special. 

the price is probably average. the service is pretty good, but it took a few times before they'd refill my tea / water. 

given all the choices we have in SF, probably will explore other places first, before considering returning.
author: Danielle A.

description: longer line and wait endless...waiting at shamrock until table ready....busy, loud and ebisu doing business well....apparently previous long closure for renovation...and maybe reason for crowds...seated after lengthy wait...large sake $five and beer $six first...menu browsing next...order of rolls and ebisu combo sushi $twenty-five....additional items from others contributing to family pot....finding smaller thinner roll creations...seemingly more authentic, but little more disappointing rice balls...ebisu sushi dinner nothing fancy and not sold yet on the hype....overall finding dinner experience chaotic and sushi dinner unmemorable....$one-hundred-eighty total for filling meal for three....
author: Hen A.

description: Love this place. Beautiful decor, hadn't been here since they remodeled.  Food was well crafted, off menu playfulness was abundant at the sushi bar.  Took our time (stayed while two couples came, ate, and left)  and noticed our water glasses were never empty and the plates were cleared promptly.  We enjoyed a bff girls night at the bar: I wanted absolutely everything off the board and tried not to order menu items.  We were in for a treat.  Shared a bottle of their unfiltered Alladin sake: sweet, but drier than Sho Chiku Bai, which I always have but I wanted some new flavor.  We had the following dishes: started with oyster shooters, then Kobe beef nigiri, we wanted seaweed, so definitely got the swamp roll, hamachi toro nigiri, a special roll with habanero mixed in for a total kick in the mouth, aji nigiri, another special roll with Kobe, unagi nigiri and a taste of Japanese pork skin, aka finished sashimi skin sliced into a ling strip and deep fried in light tempura batter, served with a few slices scallion and it was all insanely delicious.  One thing I noticed is the perfect cohesion of rice to fish on their nigiri.  Rice was perfectly seasoned: no textural issues, didn't fall apart, was good rice to fish ratio (i.e. Good balance) and the fish was excellent quality.  Falling apart from freshness, clean smelling and so texturally consistent.  The aji and Kobe roll were highlights.  Never had aji and it's resemblance to Saba is only skin deep.  Eric sliced the top of the skin in diagonal slices along the length of the fish and it was the meatiest, sweetest simplest offering that had the best bite of the night.  I enjoyed the generous oyster shooter and 1/3 cup of sake and quail egg mixture.  I say generous because I had to breath in between gulps as it was just so much to shoot!  No complaints here!
author: April L.

description: Dearest Two Balls, no Strikes: Albacore wrapped lovingly in thick avocado and crafted into delicious orbs. I dream of you.
author: Rachel S.

description:
I have eaten Sushi all over the world and this place is right up there.
I prefer sitting at the sushi bar and they have BY FAR the friendlies sushi chef's I have met anywhere.
author: Odyssey S.

description:
Choices are all tantalizing. Fried rice is the best fried rice I have ever had. All of the specialty rolls are awesome, except that I really didnt like the 49er roll (just because it had lemon slices on it).

Service is decent.

Wait: long, because a lot of people want to eat here, but worth the wait

Atmosphere: typical for a japanese restaurant

I would eat here every chance I get
author: suz s.

description: This restaurant has the "best sushi in SF".  I thought there sushi was really good but very pricey.  Service was good, but i couldn't help think how pricey the sushi was after leaving this place.
author: Janice V.

description: Ebisu is authentic, and that's hard to find in a city filled with Asian fusion inspired restaurants. The food is GOOD, the fish is FRESH and you'll be dreaming of hamachi for daaaays.
author: Alex H.

description: We have been going since we found the place 18 years ago. Everything is so delicious. Ask for Tom at the sushi bar and he can make you wonderful things you can't find on the menu. Must try the Sunrise, yummy.
author: Angela W.

description: This is the best sushi restaurant in SF.  Outstanding, fresh, amazing, creative, etc.  You may have to wait for a table or for space as the sushi bar, but the service and the quality of the sushi here is first rate. Try the Crunchy Roll.
author: Mosey S.

description:
The freshest most delicious sushi . . . and if you sit at the counter and allow the sushi chef to present you with his selection of the day. . .you will be treated to a feast. . . outstanding!

The secret to this place, is before you even look for parking, have your shotgun person jump out, sign up on the clip board. . . so you wouldn't have a long wait. . . 

Cooked items, for those squeamish of heart (re: raw fish), is equally delicious.  Has been the top sushi restaurant for years. . and considering how many Japanese restuarants are popping up. . .
author: Kea C.

description:
Don't believe the hype.

It's not bad but certainly not anything near worth the price and wait.  It's the first place I've been to where the basic rolls came out cut uneven.  Take the drive down the penninsula to San Mateo to avoid the crowd and get something authentic where you would even see Japanese patrons.
author: yohs m.

description:
The best sushi I have ever had.  

I have to subtract a star because of the sloppy atmosphere and its really crowded.
author: Mary S.

description:
Ebisu is my favorite sushi place in San Francisco. Sure, it's not the trendiest place in the world, nor the fanciest, and I might (maybe not) concede that it's not the all-time best sushi you've ever had in your life. It IS, however, completely consistently good sushi, generous portions, and so reasonably priced. I eat a lot of sushi and this is the most consistently top quality place I've been to in the city. I generally leave there talking to the people I ate with about how yummy it was and how if I weren't so full, I would still be eating more and more ebisu sushi. 

Plus they have the frequent flyer card, and so I get free sushi all the time. Is there anything better than free sushi? I think not.
author: Jen B.

description:
After eating at Ebisu three times, I'd have to say that it has perhaps the highest quality fish I've ever tried. Offsetting that positive, however, is the atmosphere, which is loud, dark and cramped. Also, the prices are sky-high.

For those who are willing to pay a big bill and don't mind a squished environment, Ebisu offers the best quality sushi around.
author: Scott M.

description: This is a place that I frequent often whenever I make my way to San Fran.  We ordered a couple of specialty rolls (cherry blossom, tempura, and ?) and my friend suggested the cod, which was delicious.  They have a good list of various sake and we ordered the 2nd one from the list (can't come up with the name for the life of me), which had a floral and sweet taste to it.  I can't wait to visit SF again, which means a visit to Ebisu!
author: Marilyn P.

description:
I really can't believe I spent so long looking forward to going to this place again. I am beyond disappointed. What used to be a very good Japanese restaurant is now very Americanized with terrible service to boot. 

The food is OK, though it has changed a lot. Instead of seaweed there are potatoes and carrots in the miso soup, which I have never seen before for good reason. The salmon dinner special is two slabs of salmon and a tiny bowl of rice on a huge white plate instead of the tray with salad, pickles, salmon, rice, etc. that they had before. They also don't serve tea as the default anymore.

The waiters there made me very uncomfortable, since as soon as I finished something one of them would immediately grab the dish or bowl. They constantly hovered around but never said anything or asked how the meal was. I felt very unwelcome.

Another change I didn't like was that the menu no longer has any pictures, but then again, if I had seen what I was going to get I would not have stayed.

There are many other Japanese and sushi restaurants in San Francisco, and you are better off going somewhere else.
author: Rachel L.

description: this was the very first place i ever ate sushi ate. Steve was a great person to learn how to enjoy japanese food. I especially enjoyed the Unfiltered saki. Many nights i had to have assistance walking up stairs to the apartment with Rick and Walter. Glad to see they are still in business. this is a spectacular place to eat SUSHI. YA Bonzai!
author: Janice R.

description: The best sushi in town!  We love this place.  The second best thing about it is the fact that the owners are usually on the premises.  The best thing is the food.  I wish they took reservations and that they would get o-toro in more often.
author: David H.

description:
I was driving aimlessly around the city, avoiding rush hour back to the East Bay, when I decided I'd better get a snack before heading back. I pulled out my phone and Yelped sushi bars around where I was. This place has over 600 reviews, so it immediately captured my attention. So the decision was quickly made. I went in around 6 on a Friday night and it was only half full, which surprised me, but maybe the crowd comes later? Anyway I was immediately sat and supplied with water.
I started looking over the menu, and of course a snack turned into more of a meal. I was looking at an order of the gyoza as well as a fresh cold roll and one deep fried. I was looking to try something different, and my waiter was very helpful with suggesting rolls to try. I ended up with a California roll with real king crab as well as another I can only explain, can't remember the name. 
The Cali roll was perfectly crafted and the ingredients were delicious and paired wonderfully together. The other roll was a slice of green onion wrapped in raw salmon, wrapped in seaweed paper and deep friend in tempura, wrapped in rice, the orange roe balls, and soybean paper. Delicious! I can't stress how good this roll was. It was what the waiter recommended and I can't say I would have ordered it on my own. 
The order of gyoza was one of the best I've ever had, and I've had many. The sauce had a nice kick, and the gyoza are made about an inch long and beautifully plated. Meanwhile, all the staff kept my water glass full (BIG factor in my eating experience, since I gulp water as I eat.)
 All in all, I spent about $22. And left so satisfied I would have paid twice that. They had a huge blackboard covered in specials, a diverse menu, fantastic staff, and a very cute, chic restaurant. I'll go back anytime I find myself in Inner Sunset, itching for some Japanese.
author: Megan B.

description: They did a major renovation inside sometime ago, and they spent a lot of money. It looks a lot better inside now. Also, the quality has improved too. I see them paying more attention to details and perfecting what they doo. Cruncy Roll is really good for a non-raw eater. Their sushi and sake selections are very well done. . Sure, there are better places but this is one of my favorite "Casual" Japanese places. Try it, you won't be disappointed.
author: Marisa S.

description: My daughter had been wanting to go here for quite a while so we went for her birthday. Had two wonderful appetizers I had never seen anywhere else - Trio of Edamame (Okinawa sea salt, togarashi lime and lemon garlic fried) and tempura cherry tomatoes. Lots of unique items, good service, good food. Good food, not the cheapest place (we have a great Japanese restaurant in walking distance of our house that is a bit cheaper) but loved their imaginative menu.
author: Ranger A.

description: This place gets a lot of hype because at one point it was said to be the best sushi in SF. I don't quite think that's true but it's not bad whatsoever. For some reason I just don't like their rolls much. The food itself is really good (sushi rolls aside) and the portions are very respectable. You can't really go wrong here. They just remodeled it so that helps somewhat and I think they are now open on Sundays so if I were to go eat sushi on a Sunday ( not typical of me) that's probably the place I'd go. Place gets packed fast though so try to  ake reservations if you can.
author: Cesar H.

description: I've been eating at Ebisu for almost 15 years! This is the "Art of Sushi"! The chefs, Tom and Suzuki have been slicing and dicing here for over 20 years! Amazing sushi creations. I've tried some of the other 'best sushi' places and have to tell you I felt like I was cheating, and suffered because Ebisu goers there is only one "BEST"! Steve and his wife Koko are there daily, his sons are the heirs to a sushi dynasty and will do well. I doubt Steve will ever not be there! Come and see why there is a wait to get in and no reservations! Its soooo worth the wait. Sit at the bar!!
author: Foodie D.

description:
Probably a 3.75 star rating, so it'll become 4. Review for the sushi only - It was good. Out of all the sushi places I've tried in the city, this one is fairly good. Nothing was amazing but it was all pretty good. The sashimi was fresh and the rolls were simple, yet creative. Fairly priced as well. For the money, it's good. Good atmosphere and friendly, competent waitstaff.  Good good good! There was one roll in particular that had me almost thinking it was great. I forgot what it was called but it was on the left side of the sushi page and it had soft shell crab in it...Maybe the second from the top. Now that was excellllllent.

Crowded place so come early and/or be ready to wait anyways. Parking in the area sucks so be ready for that as well.

The search for the best sushi continues...Msg. me if you have a "to die for" place!!!
author: Con L.

description: I had dinner here last night and it is one of the best sushi houses I've been to.  The service was great from the entire staff as they were fast and courteous.  The food was delectable.  The attention to detail put into making each piece of the course from the appetizers to the main course was amazing.  The thinner slices of sushi and the compartmentalized rice divided by the sea weed was unique, creative, and tasty.  You have to try the Kobe beef skewers as an appetizer, they were butter soft and absolutely delicious.  The service and food was outstanding but I have to highlight the chef's ability to deliver an exquisite taste and an extraordinary presentation.  I would definitely recommend this to anyone.
author: Yancy R.

description:
What can I say but crap, crap crap. No ambiance, probably the worst presentation in the city & what else should I have expected from an establishment that has imitation crab proudly displayed as a sushi choice.

What a place what an experience, Ebisu is now part of my bottom three worst Sushi Bars ever, joining Ace Wasabi & Sushi Chardonnay.
author: Bill K.

description: great service, atmosphere, and always stellar sushi.  Only downside is it's a bit pricey but oh so worth every penny!
author: Jocelyn S.

description: As far as sushi goes, it doesn't get any better. I've been going here for years and it has never failed to impress me. It's the best sushi in San Francisco, so it's probably the best on the West Coast. Try the live scallop!!!
author: Gavin M.

description:
I like Ebisu because I had alot of firsts here, and they were all pleasant. Tried geoduck for the first time in my adult life, (I used to snort them down by the pound as a toddler, according to my mother), had uni for the first time (sea urchin), spent fifty bucks on a single meal for the first time (this was not so pleasant).... Also ordered a couple rolls, one of which (spider roll) was rather dry and skinny and not very tantalizing, but the second of which (rainbow roll) was great. Everything was fresh and nicely prepared. Great stuff.  They definitely make good sushi and nigiri here. 

Most disappointing was that they didn't have sake sorbet that night. Will have to go back to try that.
author: Polly F.

description:
Overpriced for my sushi tastes and the long wait didn't help either.  Definitely ask for the price before ordering your rolls if you are on a budget.  Our bill came out double than what we thought or at any other sushi place!
On the bright side, the fish is certainly very fresh and the rolls are creative and artfully done.  
Oh, and if you don't want to wait, walk across the street to Hotei and get the same sushi there.
author: SFFoodie F.

description:
For all the hype that this place gets, I found it to be really really average.  I may be downgrading it because of the hype, but overall given you have to wait 30min to get seated I didn't feel it was worth it.

Prices are okay, food was okay, service okay.  It was just okay.  I found their choice of sashimi in their combination to be boring.

Still searching for ultimate in Japanese dining.
author: Doug C.

description:
Overcrowded, and put frankly: simply mediocre (or worse). Had a very suspect piece of hirame there last time. Downright off. 

I really don't get all the love (and the lines). Sheep mentality? Or just people not being particular enough? They don't do anything that dozens of other sushi restaurants do all over this city.
author: anon m.

description:
I can only give this place 4 stars because the food would have to really knock my socks off for me to give it the 5 (the food is good).  BUT I really do enjoy eating out here.  It be loud some times.  There's a more  'private' formal area in the back which can be really loud if a birthday party sits next to you.  If you're part of that birthday party, then it's really awesome.

Potentially long lines.  Another good way to spot this place on 9th is look for the small crowds frequently huddled/shivering outside it doors.  You can call ahead and ask them to put your name on the list -- I suggest this path

I think there needs to be a third wait list to get to sit by the oldest of the Sushi chefs.  They're all pretty cool, but he's a lot of fun.  If you bring a hot date, there's an excellent chance he'll be more interested in talking with her then you.
author: RiCH K.

description:
A friend of mine introduced me to Ebisu about a year or so ago and I've been addicted ever since. I like the intimacy of the restaurant, you know, with the chefs and tables so close. I'm pretty sure the owners are there every night, as there is a sweet older gentlemen usually browsing the tables, asking if everything's alright.

I really like that they are creative when I ask them for something new that's not on the menus. Oh oh oh oh oh and the seaweed salad is taaaaaasty!
author: J S.

description: Been here a few times and the food is always very good I just wish the service was faster, especially when trying to get a table or food for more than 4 people it can take a long time. Other than that everything here is very good.
author: Ashley K.

description: I have to admit, the remodel is really nice...but it's still tight in there.  I'm not too impressed with the sushi, for the price.  Were these jr. size?  I left hungry and down $$ and grabbed a sandwich afterward.  Workers also seem disengaged, and our waiter had claimed my sister's meal didn't come with rice, when we had to ask for the menu and show it to him and then he had to give the "my bad".  Whatever...
author: Mark B.

description: The sushi here was great!!! I went on a Friday night with my bf and his bff. The monk fish liver was the best Ive ever had. Soft and creamy!  The hamachi Kama was really good too. The price was the best part. We paid a little over $100 bucks for four people. And we were stuffed.  Totally worth every penny.
author: diana n.

description: Tommy is the shit, we love him! WE love this place - best sushi in the world and right in the neighborhood.
author: Courtney P.

description:
I can't believe this was my first visit to this Sushi landmark in San Francisco.  My mother is a long time fan.  Sushi is not normally my first choice of food-that may have all changed with my dinner the other night.   So fresh, so welcoming and so delicious.  The tempura...omg.  So light so delicious.  The Sashimi was amazing.  I have to admit that I ordered pretty basic items...being so new to sushi, but I loved them all.   Great fun sitting at the bar, watching the chefs and drinking an ice cold beer.
Totally tasty.
Skippy
author: skippy M.

description: I was a sushi virgin till tonight when I went to EBISU. My friend ordered for us and I loved the 49er roll and the sashimi. The fish was very fresh and it was very high quality. It does get loud in there and there is a wait if you get there after 6pm because the place fills up real fast.
author: Nadia N.

description: I have had sushi all over the world, in Japan out of Japan.  And Ebisu is still amazing for their ability to consistently execute spectacular dishes on a consistent basis. Downsides are that the premises are too small for the demand but that is more a function of the idiocy of the City and County for not permitting them to build the place they want to across the street (the old mortuary property) and that they have far better staff behind the sushi bar than some of those in front of it. Still love it to death.
author: Kenton H.

description:
This has to be my favorite sushi spot.

The quality and freshness of the sushi is top-notch.... Not once have they disappointed.
Great atmosphere with friendly and attentive service.
The sushi-chefs are fun to hang-out with (I always sit at the bar. When busy, I 'm happy to turn down an open table and wait for a bar-seat ).
If you're into rolls, the crunchy-roll is a must have. 

Give it a shot, this place is a gem.
author: Luca C.

description: this place has gone way down hill.  the sushi was not fresh. and one of the sushi chefs had black fungus growing on his finger nails.  gross.   I will not be returning here.
author: Eli W.

description: Best Sushi I have ever ever ever had.  Well worth my 1 hour and 45 minute wait.  My mouth is watering just thinking about the melt in your mouth hamachi!
author: g m.

description:
My favorite sushi joint in the City.  
Being that I think I am cool and know good sushi, but mostly because I think I am cool, Ebisu gets the nod for overall winner.

I've been to many places, but not all, and Ebisu has never failed me. 

I've eaten at many of the hole in the wall sushi places and , no, they do not hold up to Ebisu.  

In rating Ebisu, one must understand that it is a country style Sushi joint, not a flash (Blowhole[Blowfish]), not a tourist destination, not a sushi-on-boats place.

Yes, you will have to walk up to the specials board and lean over someone at the bar to read it. Yes, it is a bit humid and loud and tight and a wait for a table will most likely happen.  It just is not a place for a Nelly. Thankfully!
author: Jason L.

description:
I was amazed at all the puffery going about in san francisco of Ebisu. After a while i realized that it probably would be a good idea to go there, so when I came, immediately was seated and shown to my table on the floor (as I requested).

The food was very satisfying, the chefs were entertaining and the waitress was very informative. I ended up ordering spicy sushi rolls with a side of steamed sticky rice. To put the frosting on the cake, as if we needed it after so much food, they gave us complimentary green tea ice cream, it was delicious! 

My advice is to go to Ebisu with family or friends.
author: Deana T.

description:
The Mighty Morphin Power Rangers were cool at one point too.  They were brassy, sassy, full of sheen and clever wit.  One never knew what next Saturday morning was going to bring but it was bound to be hi-kicks and hi-jinks for a solid half-turn of the clock.  Then they kind of started taking their audience for granted.  Always rotating in whimsical bad guys (and whozit-Morphins), carelessly disguising one storyline after another, seemingly without rhyme or reason thinking we wouldn't notice (but we do, oh we do).  The plot lines thinned, and the value-add of the experience declined in inverse proportion to ever-rising Yelp ratings.  The table service became sloppy and peonic, the orders late, sushi misdirected like a frisbee on the beach, and even when served done so wasabi-free.  Everywhere patrons happy mumblings begin turning to angry rumblings, nary a fresh water glass to be served, and me-wonders what it was about Morphin Power Rangers that ever kept me-a-fist bumpin the TV in the first place.

Hello Kiki.
author: Jim W.

description: What I like most about Ebisu is that they don't really use a lot of crappy sauces all over their rolls. The fish is so fresh and all the food taste so good. I ordered a simple spicy tuna roll extra spicy. The chef chopped up jalapenos and mixed it with the tuna rather than dousing it in spicy mayo. He also used soy paper. It was no joke THE BEST ROLL I'VE EVER HAD!
author: Jamie E.

description: It's kind of overrated.  The sushi rolls were good but I kind of have doubts about the quality of the fish. I can't help but have the feeling that it's been americanized.  I had heard so much about Ebisu before, but I would rather walk 5 minutes down to Koo for more authentic japanese food.
author: Deanna L.

description: The Family Affair was a delicious roll, along with the 49er. The atmosphere is casual and authentic, with a hopping vibe and friendly wait staff. Enjoyed every minute of our meal. Arrived on a Saturday at 9p for a table of two and were seated right away. We will be back!
author: Alana S.

description: I wasn't expecting much but was pleasantly surprised. Sushi rolls were all good. Had the cherry blossom roll because someone else had recommended it and it was tasty. The highlight for me was some sort of poke salad. I normally find poke to be sweet but this wasn't, which I'm glad about. The udon soup was yummy too. The decor was modern and clean. It was noisy though, to the point of not being able to hear the people I was eating with. A solid 4 stars. Good, but not perfect.
author: Stephen C.

description: Wow, this was some of the best sushi I've had in a very long time.  Friends have recommended Ebisu over the years, but I never tried it until today.  I have seriously missed out on some amazing sushi.  Lots of catching up to do at this place.
author: Kandi K.

description:
The food is great. The service okay. 
I've been going here for years. Lately I noticed the size of the sushi has gotten much smaller. Not only the amount of rice (which is okay to reduce--less carbs), but the fish. The owner said he could either raise prices or make the food a little smaller. :(
The miso there is traditionally made. Mr. Suzuki is fantastic as ever if you have the opportunity to sit by him at the sushi bar. He is entertaining and funny. 
I hope they go back and rethink this decision.
author: Martha G.

description: Ebisu is still my favorite sushi restaurant. The wait can get crazy at times, but at the end we still leave happy :). The remodel looks great, but it looked great to me before the remodel too. I'm just happy to have Ebisu open again! And not only do they have great sushi, now they added desserts to the menu....on one hand it's good, because I love the desserts there, on the other hand, I can never leave now without ordering a dessert, and that is very bad for my diet :).
author: Alina S.

description: Hands down, best sushi place in the city. I like traditional Japanese dishes and not the fancy roles so this place is perfect for me. It's very busy so there is defintely a wait, and parking can be problematic if you go during dinner time. However, its worth it! I got kobe beef sashimi, toro, tuna, salmon, tai, pretty much all sashimi. The rolls here are average(again i'm not into rolls) and the udon is pretty bland. Overall, def come here for their fish!
author: Perry L.

description: I ordered the Chicken Udon ($7.95), a spicy tuna hand roll ($2), hamachi hand roll($2), & shrimp tempura hand roll($2). All very very good for a take-out only restaurant. I would suggest getting there at around 11:30am, because the lunch crowd is a nightmare. Everything tends to sell out by around 2pm. Everything was very fresh and tasty. The Chicken Udon was not too salty and had plenty of seaweed, green onions, and noodles. I will definitely be back!
author: Bobby D.

description:
I've been eating primarily Ebisu for sushi ever since I started eating sushi...which was at ebisu...get the picture?   Everywhere I've ever gone to has failed to compare to this place on the general quality atmosphere- phenomenal experience of eating at the bar and chopping it up with the chefs as desired sharing sake shots, or intimately feeding your date like nothings except the space of the bar you take up.. The new remodel did throw everyone for  loop, the tatami matted room is gone, but bathrooms are bigger and better.  Service is top notch, selection is the best, and note my food highlights:
(some of these only made it on the menu a few years ago)
Pink Cadillac,  (salmon wrapped scallop served grilled with garlic sauce)  yeah it's dreamy like a 64 convertible...
#29 ( aka, JUN 29 as in chef jun made this originally) truly amazing...a must order.
yeah the miyagi's are great... the live sea urchin (uni) really gets the table excited, and your tongue.  foie gras of the sea.. don't be surprised if it's all gone though...
don't do the hot sake here, take the opportunity to order a sake known as "heaven of tipsy delight"  or bring your own premium stuff- they will put it on ice for u for like $10!!!)
It IS worth the wait, you can order on-line, pickup is easy, the freshness is always apparent: bottom line... stumbling, or waddling from a sushi protein high/stuffed belly will leave you satiated till breakfast.  realistic though: dinner for two ranges from 45-145 dollars depending on sake ($5 hot stuff with $4 beer, mixed food ) to all the delights ( food and sake)   and that "good life" meal, 50 bottle of cold sake, little extras like fatty toro sashimi, etc.  it's up to you.  it's what you make of it and that flexibility is one reason it is packed everyday all year.  it's approachable, sophisticated, and run so professionally...All other sushi places in the sunset and most of sf... shame on them once you've seen the light here...You won't see a table of high schoolers drinking here like other sushi places that don't ask and don't tell,  so expect the best and you won't be disappointed.

A good first yelp yeah?
author: Adam O.

description:
Okay: the sushi here is great!
But: I don't like to wait forever to get seated. I don't like to feel rushed  when I eat dinner because 20 other people are waiting for a table outside. I really don't like the fact that the menu doesn't show the prices!!
I used to eat here a lot, but there are other good sushi places in the Inner Sunset...
author: Iphigenie S.

description:
We stumbled into this place on a Monday and I am very glad we found it.  It was filled to the gills (always a good sign) but there was one open two person table in the back corner where you sit on the pillows.  

Then we started ordering.  The first two rolls we had were fantastic.  Then we had some oysters, which were good, but nothing to write home about.  After paging through the menu one more time I saw the Louisiana Hotlink Roll.  Now the boyfriend is from Louisiana and loves everything associated with it, so we ordered it.  And let me tell you it was amazing.  It was hot in the middle and cool on the outside and absolutely delicious.  We also ordered some sort of sampler of different rolls, it was also ok.  

Oh we got a bowl of miso soup that was just ehh.  But all in all the meal was tasty, kind of expensive, but not insanely expensive.  I would definitely go back.
author: Rebecca R.

description:
Love this place.

I first went here with a couple of years ago with a group of friends, and I've been going back ever since.

The service and quality of sushi is awesome here.

I love taking groups of friends here, as compared to Kiki's or Kitaro's or the various Okazuyas around the city. Those places are good, but the quality here is just awesome. You get what you pay for, especially when you have multiple mouths and tastebuds to satisfy.
author: Patrick K.

description:
Sit at the bar, let the chef have his way with you! They are pretty reliable with the mouth orgasms.

Anyway, it is the sort of place you can go for more than 20 years, twice a week, and still get something new every few times. 

Yes, it is busy, and the parking is a pain if you refuse to walk more than a block, but so what? It is all about the fish and the food in general, and if you go there regularly, the culture...you walk in a solo, and pretty soon you are chatting with the chef and whoever is sitting next to you.

Tip: watch what is going across the bar...it is quite alright to say "Gimme one of those!"
author: Robert P.

description: We LOVE sushi and this is our favorite place to eat it. We live on the Peninsula and the battle of traffic and parking is all worth it just to eat here.  Place is on the smaller side and tables are cramped, but the food and service is excellent.  We usually order off of the daily specials board and have always enjoyed it.  Get there early otherwise plan to wait for a table.
author: Carolyn E.

description:
Last night was a sad day in my life. I've been going to ebisu for over a decade. This restaurant has seen me through multiple birthdays, dates and every boyfriend I've ever had...it was my rock. I was excited to eat at the newly remodeled location last night, it had been too long. Instead this is what I got...
1) a RIDICULOUSLY long wait...I had a party of 3 and the hostess was seating parties of two and four before us because "there was a very limited number of three party tables" There was a party of three waiting before us for 1:15 mins and they got upset and just ended up leaving. The only reason why we got seated was because we demanded they add a chair to one of the two person tables. 
2) all the food came out at the same time served on annoyingly large dishware for the size of the food
3)The crappiest rolls I've ever experienced=all rice no filling
...Ebisu has gotten too hollywood and I can't deal with it. :(
author: Al N.

description: Love the Sushi - always fresh and best to sit at the bar and have the chefs get creative.  Restaurant is quite loud and a bit tight but otherwise great place for sushi in the inner sunset.
author: Kevin C.

description: this place is CRAP!!! LOL! JK! there is nowhere else like this in san francisco, if your just visiting; this is the place to go for top fresh of the boat sushi!! the staff is great minus charlie and eric, but the rest of the crew is just down to earth/friendly; they have the patience to teach new palates about japanese food and the demands from the more experienced!
author: Corwin C.

description: Their tempura udon is delicious! That and half of a caterpillar roll -- Rest assured, I'll be in food coma heaven.
author: Cat L.

description:
This is the Best Sushi Overall!
Been to literally hundreds of Sushi Restaurants all over the world and also in SF.  Taken folks from all over the world here. Everyone has proclaimed it the best sushi they've had. From Broadway folks to British corporate types to Hong Kong execs... Been going there since the mid-80's. Chefs have come and gone - and started their own places, but Ebisu still has the same high standards.
Not the place for fusion rolls laden with sauces (even though some places have done that well). Just good, fresh sushi and rolls with complementary combinations. Not that once or twice they havent had the fish too cold or warm...but hey, we've all had an off day in our lives:-) 
The owner and family have kept their quality high thru 2 remodels and to the next generation. And...they are Japanese...one of the few. Summary: None better, some as good. This IS the Sushi Place I take my friends and visitors to.
author: A K Y.

description: I love to sit at the bar and chat with the friendly sushi chefs. Never had a disappointing meal here.
author: Elsa M.

description:
This is one of my favorite sushi spots in the City.  It's often a bit of wait but worth it.  It has the best blend of fresh sashimi and innovate rolls that many establishments have since copied.  Great for sashimi, sushi, hot noodles, and appetizers.  Service is adequate too :)

Keep in mind though parking can be tough during dinner hours in this area.
author: Hotung T.

description: Great Sushi Place! This place faces stiff competition from several other sushi places on 9th Avenue. One of the best Sushi places I know. Prices are reasonable, especially for the quality that you get. I am coming back, again and again...
author: Jan H.

description:
i never understood the hype of this place. been several times, and each time its truly a big fat

ehhh.

MUCH better places in sf.
author: Euge L.

description: This is a place I would have called superior in, say, 1989 but has rested on its laurels for at least a decade. Go to Kiss or Red Box or Amasia for much better, less trafficked sushi. Hotei across the street is decent noodles though and owned by the same people.
author: patrick g.

description:
you know, when you feel like Japanese food, well... americanized japanese food, this place is great.

I came here with 2 other friends and although I'm pretty sure they messed up our seating order and we waited MUCH TOO LONG... the food was worth it.

we had a bunch of rolls you would never find in japan and i can't remember any of the names but they were all fabulous. the menu is so extensive i remember having a hard time deciding what to choose.

agedashi tofu was good as always.

seriously its been a while since i went and me sitting here typing this review and im still thinking of the agedashi tofu... 

the tempura was fluffy yet crisp too. i approve.
author: S T.

description: I think this could be the most over rated sushi restaurant in the city.  I'm pretty picky about sashimi, and this place didn't impress me.  It's not bad sushi, just not the best I've ever had.  I prefer Koo on Irving Street for really good raw.
author: Honey L.

description: Okay, I don't get it.  Last night was my first time and the only noteworthy item was our appetizer - the Bud Light.  Someone, tell me what's good here.  On second thought, don't.  I don't want to wait in line for my sushi.  Next!
author: T-Bone L.

description: We went to Ebisu on July 4th for lunch and we were so happy to get a table w/o a wait. The food is delicious from the bento box to the sushi. We tried a little of everything and it was all great. My favorite was the grilled yellow tail collar and the twice cooked eggplant w/ miso sauce appetizer. The bento box is so big and yummy and full of fermented side veggies my son loved it. We will definitely go back soon.
author: mojgan v.

description:
Major disappointment with Ebisu.  We called  the restaurant at 7:15 p.m. to add our name to the wait list.  Was told that the wait would be 30 minutes, maybe a bit more.  Arrived at the restaurant at 7:40 p.m. and checked in.  We were not seated until after 9:30 p.m.  

Hey, I understand if the restaurant is busy.  However, tell me the truth about the wait and let me make an informed choice.  Don't just keep leading me on.  

Once we were seated the service was not very good.  Had to remind server to bring the miso soup and ask for a tea refill three times before I actually got it.

That said the sushi is very good.
author: ani k.

description: Ummm... after a long day of not working and instead going from bar to bar, Ebisu sounded wonderful.  I brought my friend from out of town since I had such a good experience last time.  After several sake shots with the sushi chef, George, he told me about his special, George's roll.  I asked what was in it and he said he could not tell me, because it was a secret.  So of course I poured us all another shot and said... George, make me your specialty.  He insisted that he was the only one in the city and world that made this unique and delicate sushi roll.  He said he would not even tell his kids how to make it or what was in it.  What a guy... dinner was great, service was fun, energetic and quick.  Again I had a great time and wonderful food!!
author: Megan L.

description: I really like going out for sushi, and for all the raves, I feel like this doesn't live up to what I like. I felt the rolls were over stuffed and made eating unpleasant. I felt the quality was sub-par. I do also feel that sushi places that use photographs for their menus really do a disservice, it makes the food seem really unappetizing.
author: Alyssa C.

description: You know, I wasn't that impressed.  I had previously heard a lot of hype about this place, but it definitely didn't deliver.  The fish was good to start but I do feel that as the night progressed, and more sake bombs occurred, the amount of fish that they gave us diminished.  Hmmm .... All and all it was a fun experience as we had a big group of 6 and we got one of the great tables in the back.  But, the feature of this place is the sushi, and it wasn't that great. Thus, three stars!
author: Amanda L.

description:
I decided to take the muni to try the talked about taste of "Ebisu". I walked to be seated immediately at the bar. The host provided me throughout the whole night with much attentiveness. The quality of food here is the fun part to describe. It's more of a fancy sushi joint in my opinion because of how close the chef is to me.

I liked the blue fin it was the belly more premium so that just tasted like sweet butter melting. Yakatori was grilled at a perfection so it made it prefect eating. The beef tataki seared at a med-rare point with a savory sauce. The sushi selection was fresh but nothing usual from the norm. If you want to take a date here it is recommended. I had dinner with three for around $100 check.
author: Kevin N.

description: Back again to sit at the bar tonight. Eric and Isu (sp?) were working the bar in front of me and tonight was the opening night for a sushi roll contest. Best roll gets added to the menu. So first up an asparagus tempura and salmon roll which was crispy and delicious. Next up was a tuna based roll with ponzu sauce and curry mayo. This was fantastic. I finished it off with a Tuna Tataki with ponzu, onions, ginger and garlic.
author: Phil M.

description: My mouth is still resonating from the silky tuna, red and glistening.  The Kobe Beef sashimi makes me want to eat an entire Kobe Beef, a whole one, live and all, and dip it in the nice garlic/vinegary/sweet sauce they have.  Ebisu, Ialreadymissu.
author: George S.

description: my daughter lives near here, so we went last night.  Very good sushi excellent tempura lobster all at a very good price.
author: pochini m.

description: Not bad at all, I'm a very picky eater when it comes to sushi. I need them fresh. and this one is indeed pretty fresh!! the only thing is the parking, it takes forever to find a parking space. but other than that, Ebisu is very delish!!!
author: Wendy K.

description: This was my first time back to the restaurant since the remodel and it was nothing short of AMAZING.  We got to sit at the sushi bar which was nice because the sushi chefs were able to recommend some special rolls that weren't even on the menu.  The Hamachi was to die for... super fresh and tasty.  I wanted to try the live Uni they had, but no one else in my party was brave enough to try it with me... maybe next time.  All in all I was very impressed by the sushi and the service!
author: Jen F.

description: I have a credit card just for them.  Despite it being several years, I'm still paying it off.  I'm serious.  Expensive, but very addictive.
author: Tangerine L.

description: You kids in the Sunset need to get out more. Why this place is considered one of the top sushi places in San Francisco is a huge mystery. All the rolls are smothered in mayonnaise, and the cuts are paltry.
author: Rene D.

description:
bottom line: outstanding nigiri, typical but solid rolls. a great catch in the vast sea of sushi joints (pun INTENDED!).

i had been wanting to try ebisu forever and was not disappointed. we walked in at 8:30 last night (tuesday) and there were about 4 parties of 2 ahead of us on the list. crazily enough, the hostess called our party before the others were seated. i didn't complain... :) maybe she knew i was a yelper? we were sat in the back room on the tatami mats. pretty cool spot -- i didn't even know it existed.

i started with the green salad, which was average -- none of that delicious gingery-mayonnaisey-fatty-goodness dressing on top. it was an overly acidic vinaigrette. not terrible but not nearly as tasty as others i've tried at other japanese resturants. the one at grandeho's in cole valley is the best i've ever tried; it's huge and has tons of yummy crisp veggies, perfectly dressed.

we had 2 rolls: the caterpillar and the #42 (i think that's what it was called maybe the #24?? not sure...). they were both delicious and fresh but nothing unique. i must say, the caterpillar had the most adorable presentation... a few sunflower sprouts coming out of the 'head' as antennae. v. cute :)

then we tried a bunch of nigiri: aji (spanish mackerel), sake, maguro, and the striped bass (a special which the waitress suggested). the nigiri were the highlight for me. they were all excellent and lightly accented with wasabi or garnishes such as scallion. absolutely delicious, all was fresh and beautifully presented... thin and tender cuts of fish which simply melt on your tongue. the aji was by far the most delicious i've ever tried. the striped bass was good, but i enjoyed the other pieces more.

the service was also friendly and extraordinarily efficient.
author: Jill M.

description: The #29 roll is very tasty and visually pleasing. The edemame had 3 different flavors all which were delicious. I have only good things to say about the food and the service. Will definately return many  more times.
author: Rita J.

description: A LOT of people think that Ebisu is overrated. I am not one of them. Still, Ebisu can be a bit lack luster if you sit at the tables, don't try any of the specials, just have rolls, etc, etc. But if you're willing to be a bit adventurous, you'll have a great time. Just ask the cooks what's fresh and go with it. Give the monkfish liver, uni, or kobi beef a go.
author: michael c.

description: I've come here repeatedly, starting well before I actually moved to SF, and the experience has been just a tiny bit less satisfying each time -- not so much that I can put my finger on it from one visit to the next, but over time, it adds up: higher prices, smaller portions, increasingly lackadaisical service. I'm sure Ebisu will be able to keep coasting on its reputation for a while longer, but I don't think I'll bother coming along for the ride.
author: Fawn F.

description: My fav place for sushi - wait can be a bit long.  They also will prepare and deliver platters of sushi for parties.  Friendly to kids (if your kids are patient enough for the wait).
author: Dan D.

description: Going through rennovation, so they are over at Hotei.  I miss them... can't wait for them to be back.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: The lady at the front desk skipped our name not once but twice!!!!!!!!!!!!!   When we asked for water the waitress told us that there was something wrong with the water system - now wait this is a restaurant -how are they washing their hands and the pots and pans?????   Or are you trying to sell us a drink?  My husband demanded a glass of water and it was fine.  Waited 45 minutes for excellent food.  We were told that sushi bar and take out has preference over tables.  Then lady at front door brought us complimentary edamane as we were paying our bill.  What am I missing here?
author: EM F.

description:
Beware...children are NOT welcomed at this restaurant.  I felt that our party of eight were discriminated against and indirectly turned away because we have 4 children with us.  My wife and I love this restaurant and go there often in the past without our chidren.  We thought that our East Coast sushi-crazed friends (w/ their 2 children) would enjoy another great SF Japanese restaurant  since they have been boasting about this Ironchef Japanese Restaurant in NYC. 

 So....at 8:15pm, I called ahead and the hostess put us on the waiting list for 9:30pm.  We arrived at the restaurant at 9:15pm and was told to wait for 20 minutes for our table which we have no problem with. 
Ten minutes later, the hostess came to us with a female whom she introduced as the owner.  At this time, both the hostess and the owner told us that the wait will be verrrrry long and specifically said that we should try Hotei (across the street) or Tikki (couple doors down the street).   

I think if Ebisu or any restaurant want our business  they would not suggest the other 2 restaurants nearby especially in this hard economic time.   Therefore, their action lead me to believe that they do not want our business this time because we have children with us.  I finally got the message and told them I felt that that they do not want us there because of the children.  Before our party left, I told the hostess that these are my friends from the East Coast and I want them to have a great SF sushi experience before flying out early morning.  As much I love their sushi, I will not return there ever.  It was an embarassing moment for me  in  front of our guests.
author: vin p.

description:
My husband and I were in SF for the King Tut exhibit.  It was about rush hour headed North when we finished and we didn't want to sit in traffic.  We decided to stop for some sushi.  We used an app on his iphone, that told us to go to 9th Ave for which ever restaurant we had origionaly chose. Once on 9th Ave, we just grabbed a parking spot as soon as we found one and decided to walk.  Well,  there were 3 sushi restaurants all within steps of our car and one another.  How would we choose?  We usually don't, but this time I decided to follow the crowd....

We arrived along with about 3 other groups.  They seated us quickly.  The service was good.  Not overly attentive, but they were there to answer any questions we had.

I usually let my husband do the ordering when we go to Sushi so he went for it.  We started out with Miso Soup because it was chilly outside.  It was good.  The Tofu was very smooth and almost creamy.  It was different and good. 

Then we had the 2 Balls No Strikes.... well this turned out to be a home run for me.  While we did have to ask how to eat it (smash it up into small parts) the spice was great!

They sent out a very small portion of calamari for us.  WOW!  We had never been there before!  We felt special.  The calamari was VERY good in my opinion.  It had a little spice and flavoring in it!  I would totally order that next time.

We had 2 other rolls.  The Hot Link was eh, at best.  I heard my husband order it and thought it would be spicy.... the Hot in Hot Link, refers to the temperature.  Trust me, we ate it.  But I don't think I would order it again.  It just seemed very bland.  We were having rols with some great flavor, and then we were just a bit disappointed with that 1 roll.

I can't remember the name of the last roll that we had but it was good.

Over all good service, great sushi.  This is the best sushi that I have had in a long time.  I am happy that we chose to come here instead of the sushi place we parked in front of.  it pays to follow the crowd sometimes.  We will be back, probably with some friends.  It looks like a small dining room, so i would suggest reservations (I assume they take them).
author: M J.

description: Ebisu rocks.  Every time we go, the waitstaff is accomdating and the sushi chefs are really fun and engaging, if you sit at the bar.  I have always had fresh, high quality fish and the rolls are creative and delicious.  Yeah, the wait is long if you go at peak hours, but in my opinion, it's worth waiting for.  Not as trendy or obnoxoius as the other top sushi places in the city, either.  I'll keep going back and back and back and back and back.....
author: Jessica L.

description: I thought their rolls were excellent.  So much variety it's overwhelming.  Everything was fresh, yada yada yada.  The only down side is the wait and the fact that they stuff people in there a little tight.  While there I saw a full beer knocked over by a waitress trying to squeeze around people.  I hate lines and I hate feeling crowded so that was big turn off.  I also don't know if traveling out to the Inner Sunset is really worth it.
author: Corey V.

description: . Very good  sushi  and I love my sushi and sashimi MMmmmm fresh salmon *drools*. Both are good here. The presentation  is excellent, they give you  a hibiscus flower on your plate. I'm a sucker for flowers what can I say I'm a girl and :D
author: Kristina S.

description:
I've been going to Ebisu for years (we live just a couple of blocks away) and had some good experiences. I will however NOT go back anymore! The food is good but not exceptional and I'm more than tired of the wait and the tight and crowded room. This Sunday I called before 7pm to have them put my name on the list (for a party of 3) and they said 15-20mn wait. We were there at 7:15pm but had to wait until 8pm before to just give up and leave! There was no apology or sign that they cared the least.

If you're only 2 people and are lucky it's worth the try, if not there are better places in town.
author: Jean-Luc S.

description: Hands down my favorite sushi place in the city. I am particularly a fan of their sake nigiri, which is always as fresh as you could hope for. Their menu of Japanese food is pretty good too, so you have a lot of options. Get there early because the waiting list can get long.
author: Wade W.

description: Def has gone down.  There are too many other great sushi places to wait for a table here...  The nigiri was mangled, and the rolls were pretty average.
author: Melanie C.

description:
despite all the haterade, ebisu is actually pretty good.  i have eaten there many, many times (i live in the sunset), and have never been disappointed.

i've introduced several of my vegetarian or mostly vegetarian friends to their delicious tofu steak (which isn't on the menu, so ask for it!) and the vegetable tempura roll.  they are so good that i can never stand to order anything else.

if the line is long, just go to hotei across the street.  they'll let you order anything from the ebisu menu without the wait.
author: Sarah B.

description:
good/acceptable:
-miso soup
-teriyaki salmon
-red bean ice cream
-looks "cool" from the outside

bad/unacceptable:
-The service was odd. The sushi chef was yelling at a couple of waitresses in between charming the customers at the bar.
-Unreasonably priced
-Closed in tiny room seating
-Fruit flies galore, one landed on my plate and expired

My mom and I wanted to try something new and ended up paying $45 for each other's company. If we are in the area again, we will just go back to Kiki's for half the price, bright atmosphere and tastier food. I will not be a patron of their establishment unless someone else is paying!
author: Solitaire M.

description:
I was very excited to come to Ebisu for the first time tonight.  I was planning on meeting friends out in The Haight for the awesome drink special at Trax tonight, and I decided to meet up with my boyfriend when he got off of work and try out this new sushi spot.  I had read some really great reviews on Yelp, and a couple that worried me, but that comes with 300+ reviews.  

But what really hooked me was their website.  I visited it and their menu really impressed me.  The had a few roll combinations that sounded delicious, and I was intrigued by the idea of three different flavored edamame.  

Some of the reviews had me concerned with how long our wait might be, since we were going on a Saturday @ 7.  But my boyfriend got there just moments before me and put our name in for 2, he said I wasnt there yet and that he was going to smoke a cigarette and the hostess said she would set up a table for him.  By the time I walked there and he took his last puff, our table was ready and we were seated right away.  I wouldn't say we had the best seats, allll the way in the back of the restaurant where the runners run in and out and semi-squished between the sushi bars patrons and a wall.  But none the less the lighting as good and it wasn't very loud, no need to shout, and out locations actually allowed us to get great service, so maybe it was a blessing in disguise.  Our waitress was very nice, friendly, and attentive.  She was continuously filling our water glasses and made sure to not overload our cups with just ice, very considerate.

My boyfriend has a not-so-secret obsession with crab cakes.  So when our waitress was spouting off the specials for the night I couldn't help but laugh at his facial expression as she told us about the 2 crab cakes the had for the appetizer specials.  It was 2 very large, very flavorful crab cakes for $7.50.  Not something I would normally get, but since it was date night with the hubs I decided ti splurg and do something nice for him.  And it was definitely a good choice.  They were so hot and moist and literally melted in your mouth.  They were a little rich, but I normally think that of crab dishes.  But they were both perfectly cooked and were a great treat.  We also ordered their trio of edamame.  One with normal sea salt, one with lemon garlic spice, and one with chili lime.  THEY WERE AMAZING!!!  Not only were they delicious but they gave me so many ideas of ways to flavor edamame in my own home.
