I then ordered a Tokyo Tower roll (shrimp tempura), a Swamp Roll (spicy albacore with seaweed salad on top), and the Tootsie Roll with Halibut (deep fried halibut with green onions wrapped in yellow soy paper) and the boyfriend ordered the Chicken Teriyaki dinner.  

I can honestly tell you that their Swamp Roll was hands down one of the best sushi rolls I have ever had in all of my sushi dining experiences.  Beautiful spicy albacore (we're talking a very generous portion of albacore) and perfectly seasoned seaweed salad on top.  I was very impressed and eager to try the other rolls I had ordered.  OUt next was our Tootsie Roll.  This was just ehhh, almost borderline bleeehhhh to be completely honest.  It was the smallest portion of fried halibut in the inside this roll.  And very thin sice of uncooked green onion.  I wasn't a fan of this, and was rather disappointed in fact since halibut is my favorite fish.  And then my boyfriend Chicken Teriyaki dinner came out.  There was a surprisingly large amount of chicken in his dinner.  With little potato chip thingys on the top. It was more Hawaiian BBQ than Chicken Teriyaki.  And the portion was rice served with it has half of what it should be.  And for $15 this dinner really should have come with more than a smll side of rice and miso soup.  Maybe a salad?  Or some veg tempura?  That would really make it worth it.  And sadly, there was no Tokyo Tower.  When we ordered our waitress couldn't find her little notebook pad so she didn't write anything down.  And, just my luck, she forgot my 3rd roll.  She said she would bring one out, but by the this time we had already finished all the food and were beginning to be full.  So we just asked for the check and went on our way.

There were some great flavors I tasted here.  Our service was great and the prices were relatively reasonable.  Overall I had a very pleasant experience and would recommend if you live in the neighborhood or are passing through.
author: Chelsea C.

description:
In my opinion, this place sucks.  
Sushi chefs who take more pride in drinking with unsuspecting Gaijin than delivering quality sushi.
I brought one of my good friends and his date here one night.
We both grew up on Oahu.  We both know quality fish.  We both know great sushi.
Sure I'm Yonsei.  Sure I fucked off four years of Nihongo.  I don't give a shit.  I take pride in my Japanese ancestry. I am thankful for being able to have a palate educated in part by the beautiful dishes my relatives have given me the priviledge of enjoying.  Dishes made with Japanese pride.
I was embarassed.  This is not the kind of gastronomic experience San Francisco should be known for.  
Service was dismal.
Sushi was ineffably bad.  "Not quite fresh" fish, Nigiri that looked as if it was shaped with a whisk, rolls that were falling apart.
It looked like a bunch of alcoholics seeing double made our food.  
Drink up!  Have fun!  HANDLE YO' SHIT!
I mean, we're friggin paying for this shit, right? 
That's ok.  I know Chinese owned sushi spots that make better sushi than you!
author: Barry A.

description: The qualities of their sushi rolls were much better than my last visit. However, it was still a very crowded and noisy place.
author: Rita L.

description: I think this place is overrated.  It seems to be like most of the sushi places I've been to but nothing special.  Unfortunately, the last time I was there, my boyfriend and I got serious food poisoning that lasted two days.
author: Dana C.

description:
Best sushi in San Francisco that I've discovered to date, hands down.

Delicious food. Beautiful presentation. Great service. Great atmosphere.  Prices aren't cheap, but are great value considering how amazing eating here is.

This is sort of sushi place where it pays to get the specialty rolls are they are works of art.  That said, even the most basic rolls or nigiri are beautifully plated.

The only possible downside here might be wait-time, since it's a popular place, but it has not personally been a problem.  They have separate lists for the Bar and Tables, so if you don't have a preference you seem to get seated pretty quickly, especially for parties of two.

If you get the chance to sit at the sushi bar in front of the oldest of their 4 sushi chefs (bald with bandanna), do it!  You will be in good hands!
author: Jared D.

description: This is my new favorite sushi restaurant.  Too bad I live on the other side of the country...Ugh.  We came here on the Sunday before Memorial Day, right when they reopened for dinner.  Place packed up really fast.  We ordered a lot of food and paid a hefty bill for it, but it was worth every dime.  I would totally do it again (as long as my wallet doesn't mind!)  Between the two of us, we ordered the Kobe beef sashimi, omakase, kaki fry and yosenabe.  The beef sashimi was so soft, fatty and beefy (sorry for lack of words to describe awesomeness).  The omakase is just the chef's choice of sashimi.  We got a great assortment of seafood and all for $25.  Bf ordered the kaki fry, which was fried oysters w/ potatoes.  Came with rice and miso soup.  The sauce for the oysters was really tasty...it was reminiscent of tonkatsu sauce.  I ordered the yosenabe (seafood in broth w/ yam noodles).  The broth was a little salty, but it doesn't matter - I still ate it all.  Came with two big pieces of fish, giant scallops, couple shrimp, clams, fish cake and mixed veggies.  I wish it had more noodles though (I'm a carb whore).  Our water was great, he deserved the giant tip.  He was knowledgeable of sake and was extremely attentive.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
heart-pounding.
palms sweating.
stomach churning with butterflies...
I couldn't think straight.

That's when I got down on one knee and asked Ebisu to marry me.
author: Devin K.

description: Best in the bay. Amazing fish, talented sushi masters. Anyone that prides themselves as knowing where to go to get sushi sets Ebisu apart from the list. It's a special place. One that becomes a tradition either daily or weekly as some regulars enjoy or simply the place you go when you want to raise your spirits or just get some good fish!
author: Darin A.

description: Best sushi ive had in a while! XXX roll on the specials is bomb!  Also try the lobster tempura. Effin awesome!
author: Brandon S.

description:
3.5 stars. I have been coming here for many many years and it had a bout of inconsistent fish so I stopped going...then a few years ago I had the most incredible meal there. It was like crack (not that I know what that is like) and I was on a high after the meal - fresh scallop, fresh uni, ama ebi, salmon, aji are my favorites. Then when they closed to remodel and Hotei was doing the sushi, I thought the sushi was horrible (fish was not fresh at all) - I went twice and decided not to come back until now (a gift card helped me decide). I like the new decor, though miss the tatami room - it's still packed in, but we managed to handle 2 kids during dinner. The hostess was exceptionally helpful accommodating the kids (Melissa?) - so thank you! 

The food tonight was very good - sake, hirame, kampachi, uni (they were out of live uni :(, but this was really good - super cold), live scallop (still my favorite, though their tempura of the scraps was better as a nest than a patty with the 2 little piles of flavored "sea salt"), aji (not the best tonight), #29 roll, and i think there were some others. They've changed around their menu a little - like trying to be a bit more of a trendy sushi place (aka Nobu) and the chawanmushi tasted different and the ohitashi was pretty horrible - well, i should say, less traditional and overly salty (the custard not salty enough and what happened to all the goodies that used to be in there?).  If you like rolls, this is a good place (not a huge fan of rolls) and their selection of more adventurous fish is good. But not quite that ephemeral meal that I remembered (could be the juggling/eating with 2 kids ;)), but I still like it and would go back....bring your credit card, it easily runs $50pp without drinks.
author: Cammy H.

description: I heard so much about Ebisu and was excited to have dinner there yesterday.  We got there around 7:30pm and the wait was not too bad.  My friend ordered 2 specialty rolls; nothing special about them.  I ordered the chef's special sashimi cause I couldn't make up my mind.  The sashimi was fresh; however, each piece was so tiny.  Needless to say, I was disappointed.
author: C S.

description:
My goodness! This place stole my veganism and delivered me into flexi-vegan territory! 
I went with a friend who is a fan of one of the chefs- don't you love it when guys have relationships w/ their chefs like a lady and her hairdresser might? Adorable.
Anyhow, this guy really was great- all of the servers were fabulous! The chef, of course, modified the most appealing rolls so that they would have the day's freshest and tastiest fish in them. I am not a huge consumer of white rice (love my fiber) and they noticed that are put light rice on my rolls! They even brought me some things without rice and told me they wanted to make sure I have enough to eat so they brought me extra vegetable tempura! 
There were four or five people serving us and the chefs gave us five or six small complimentary dishes- various mushroom and bamboo things and some fish hors-d. so moist that it melted on the tongue (yes, that is appealing)! I highly recommend the $29 or whatever the fried roll is called. 
I would say, have a visit when you are ready for some great and perhaps new flavor combinations, and not so concerned about spending a little more than average- about $35 per person.
Excellent service and rather yummy food- stole my heart and my vegan exclusivity.
author: Raven K.

description: I was craving uni, so I tried Ebisu.  I asked the waitress what the difference was between the live uni and regular uni, flavor wise, and she told me that the regular uni tastes way better and had more flavor!  (I would have thought the live uni was better)  so, i had the "regular" uni.  it was pretty good there...sweet and melted in your mouth.  we had a bunch of rolls, but sadly, none of them were memorable and they were just...meh.  I had salmon sashimi (they sliced it thinly, like i requested) but it tasted kind of...fishy. (EDIT: Since one pretentious yelper pointed out to me that salmon was a fish, I thought I would clarify and say that when I wrote "fishy", I meant that it didn't taste fresh.  Anyone who knows their good sashimi knows that salmon sashimi has more of a butter-y taste to it and shouldn't taste fishy. LOL)  Ebisu is nothing to write home about.
author: Cheryl L.

description: This is one filled-to-the-brim-overflowing-with-customers Japanese restaurant. A total neighborhood (and perhaps San Francisco) favorite, the food will by no means treat you wrong. That said, there are places just as good that won't make you wait an hour or pay the slightly higher prices. All one need do is spend a few minutes searching on Yelp.
author: Patrick G.

description: When it comes to Sushi, I'm not interested in paying a premium for smoke and mirrors.  I don't care if it's swanky or, for cryin' out loud, if a dj's spinning techno beats.  The sushi here is always fresh, buttery and delicious.  People who know good sushi come here.
author: Ann L.

description: Uni was quite fishy (and not in a good way). Sushi was OK. They forgot our soft-shell crab appetizer and brought it at the very end. They tried to pull a "are you still waiting for anything else?" but I'm quite sure they forgot it. It wasn't very crunchy. Not terrible, but overpriced for what you get.
author: Rob T.

description: Ebisu has spoiled me for life! The 49er roll is so perfect, I cringe when other sushi spots dub their roll by the same name. Everything is so fresh, service is spot on and the live Uni was amazing! I must stop typing to avoid drooling.....
author: May W.

description: Great Japanese food! Sashimi is fresh. Creative display of food. Good service. A bit noisy but overall, a nice place to eat.
author: Holly M.

description: Went there a while back...had hamachi roll...it was inedible...like the fish was going bad....I told the server and showed her the uneaten portion of inedible, and possibly dangerous piece of nasty fish...politely of course...she yelled at me saying that it was fine...I wanted to dropkick her...suffice it to say I will never go back.
author: Jessi B.

description: I can be yet another person that loves this place? And how to give that an original twist. Has the same look as so many other Japanese restaurants, but the feel is something a little more like, "You and I both know we are good." I went there for the first time on a first date back in the 90's and the guy said if I ate the (fried) head that they served us as a joke, he would love me forever. I don't know how his wife feels about this torch he must still be carrying for me.
author: Jean W.

description: no no no. I was told this was a good place to go. I remember trying to go here about 2 years ago and it was too crowded so we left. Finally went a week or so ago. First whats with the pictures on the menu? a little cheesy but that's cool i can deal. When food finally arrived, it was edible but far from great. We actually couldn't eat all of it, not because we were stuffed (I was actually hungry after so had to go get a hot cookie and bubble tea) but because we couldn't stomach the left over roll. I NEVER leave sushi uneaten unless there's a good reason.
author: Dave R.

description:
it surprises me that this place gets so many bad reviews.  every time that i've gone, it's been incredibly good.  the fish is delicious and incredibly fresh. there's a large variety of special rolls to try.  i didnt try it myslef, but one night that i went i saw them serving sea urchin... THAT WAS STILL ALIVE.  yes.. it was still moving on the plate!

the prices here are a bit high, but that's pretty much to be expected with good sushi
author: vlad k.

description: I'm biased because this was the first sushi place I went to back around 1983, and one of my first memories is sitting in the tatami room. But I've been back since then and I've had great sashimi and rolls. It's still my favorite.
author: Lauren H.

description: This place is less of a scene than Sushi Bistro (more of a "classic" sushi bar and restaurant) and they have the best yellowtail sashimi!  Always fresh fish, perfect miso soup, nice selection of sake (I prefer the unfiltered Nigori sake with a beer), and quality classic rolls.  Love the sushi chef who has been there forever....  always puts an orchid by my plate!
author: Cel H.

description: OveRRated.  And then of all things we got crammed into the room in back where you sit on the floor, which I might like on occassion but does not work when you're with a tall pregnant woman 8 months BiG, and two very inflexible guys, one being a certain soon to be ex  who's a natural hot-bed of heat and who ends up jammed against a wall that must have had an oven on the other side, turning it into a virtual hot-plate that a cold blooded lizzard would've loved.
author: Today Y.

description: Fresh fish and some live stuff!  Really that's the only thing that is important for a sushi restaurant right?
author: Christopher L.

description: 5 different kinds of Toro last time I went there. FIVE!  Freakin awesome.  Don't get makizushi, stick to whatever the sushi chefs are reccommending.   The kobe beef sushi is a neat expereince too.
author: matthew w.

description: This place is decent.  I went with a large party, and the restaurant is a bit tight for 10+ people in a group.  We said the traditional japaneses style, on the floor with shoes off.  It was busy for a tuesday at lunch time.  The sushi wasnt' particularly mind blowing, but wasn't bad either.  I'd come here for sushi again, but i wouldnt always push for going there.
author: Kim N.

description: My fiance and I try to go at least a few times a month.  Suzuki and Tom are the best.  These guys will always come up with a creative new treat for us.  Some of the newer guys roll a little loose, and need to sharpen their knives, but the fish is always super fresh, and service is always prompt.  Best tip is to get their early.  You can always find parking on Lincoln if you get there right around 6:00pm.  Another tip is to bring the kitchen a bottle of Sake.  They will always return the favor in kind!
author: Benjamin P.

description: Really really good! Not much of wait the last time I went (whew!) and the salmon sashimi (which I usually don't even like or order at most sushi places) was delicious! I also tried tuna belly here for the first time and I must say, not bad, if I little on the greasy side but it is the belly after all. It melted in your mouth beautifully. Rolls were also erally good. It is closed now  for renovation and located across the street at it's sister restaurant Hotei, which I hear is a good japanese noodle house.
author: Gina R.

description: Walking into Ebisu it looks like a nice place, but eating there is a different story. The place was pretty packed the night I went and I had to wait for probably an hour for a table for two. By the time we got in it was still crowded, it was sooo loud in there. Theres a whole bunch of people talking at once and some music, but you couldnt even hear yourself talking. And you also hear the whole conversation of the people next to you, who arent even sitting that close because they have to shot to hear each other. The food took a while to come, I ordered the dragon roll which came out small and skinny! It did not fill me up at all, I had to order more food to make up for it and boy was it not cheap either!
author: Angela C.

description: Was my favorite however, when I found a bone in my spicy tuna things changed.  BIG BONE.  How does one miss that during prep?
author: jessica b.

description: Definitely overrated. it is good sushi but definitely not worth the prices or waiting an hour for. Hotei their sister restaurant across the street is way better and they serve soups. Or try Goemon on 17th Ave/Irving instead.It's a little gem we found if you are willing to walk a bit.
author: Bee F.

description: Pricey and long waits.  The rolls were on the smaller side.  I heard it was better before.
author: Derrick V.

description:
I've only been to Ebisu a handful of times, but my experiences have been positive overall. I like the pictures on their menu and the fun assortment of rolls that they offer and my boyfriend really loves their raw kobe beef sushi... it's super expensive for the tiny amount you get, but he could probably eat 15 of them if money and health were no object. 
In terms of the restaurant itself, Ebisu is a little cramped, there is often a wait, and it tends to have a strong fishy smell. I KNOW that's it's a sushi place, but I just can't get over a fishy smell- it makes me question the quality and cleanliness of a restaurant. 
I am a little confused because when I first moved to SF a few years ago I heard that Ebisu was one of the best places for sushi in the city. I hope this is not true and it certainly is not reflective of my experience. I see all the awards and write-ups in the restaurant and can't help but wonder what happened?
author: Amanda C.

description: Consistently good sushi, with a varied menu.  I preferred Sushi zone, but Ebisu does not have the wait...
author: Ken and Yuri Q.

description: Always excellent, and there's always something new to try.  I tried live scallop here for the first time and it BLEW ME AWAY.  For that alone Ebisu will always have a special place in my sushi loving heart.
author: Jenny S.

description:
Checking out Ebisu served as an important lesson to listen when Yelpers are ambivalent about a place. I checked out Ebisu, solo, for lunch one day this month, and I have the following comments:

- The ambience is poor. It's dim, small, and non-descript.

- The sushi is average at best, flat-out sketchy at first. The mirugai was oddly crunchy - unlike any mirugai nigiri that I've enter tried. Their Hanukkah roll (featuring various forms of salmon) was edible, but also nondescript. I wouldn't walk across the street to have it for free.

- The service was on the slower side even though the restaurant was not busy, there were four men working at the sushi bar, and it was nearly 2 PM on a weekday.

There is nothing about this place that would entice me to come back - unless I heard truly stunning endorsements of the cooked food menu. There are too many other superb Japanese choices in the area. I'd recommend Hama Ko in Cole Valley, my neighborhood favorite - but I don't want y'all to crowd in my favorite, freshest sushi place. So don't come to Hama Ko. ;)
author: B L.

description: This place smells gawd awful.  Not a sushi fan so can't comment on the food.  Went with a friend who was craving sushi and we happen to be in the neighborhood.
author: Keith S.

description: I've only been here once, but it was a yummy and memorable experience. The crunchy rolls are AWESOME. This place seems to have pretty innovative rolls and was packed when I was there, so the word is out on the street for sure. Definitely coming back here at some point.
author: Kimi W.

description: I've been going to Ebisu now for 10 years.  If Yelp was around back then, I would have rated them a 5, but that was then.  I'm so disappointed that the quality of their sushi has changed.  I'm not sure what it is, but what used to be so good is now just marginal.  I remember there being lines out the door back in the day, but I'm not sure if that is the case anymore.  The people are incredibly nice there which is always a nice addition to the dining experience.
author: Jason I.

description: This place is really good but not the best sushi I've had.  Other than that I can't say much more.  Nothing really stood out for me as far as food or service.  I would definitely consider going back there when I'm in the neighborhood and craving sushi.
author: Julie D.

description: The best Sushi in town!  Its no wonder why people stand in line outside to get a table.  I went therer with a Japanese freind who is very picky with her Sushi.  To impress a Native Japanese with sushi is not easy.  5 stars for EBISU and I cant wait to go back.  The biggest downside is parking.
author: Jay Y.

description: I didn't know that this place was so highly regarded until after I had eaten here.  That being said, the sushi didn't live up to its reputation, at least the mainstream stuff.  My shrimp tempura rolls were rather bland.  I also ordered some special roll with salmon and salmon roe that was very salty, but that may have been my fault for wanting double salmon.  I may give Ebisu another try and order some nigiri or more "unique" rolls next time.
author: Sunny C.

description:
a long time friend, took me out for dinner this past monday nite.
for a monday nite, it was pretty darn crowded.

we started off with a seafood salad - which was a salad of sashimi. delicious, buttery and not fishy smelling or tasting. 
then we had a few rolls, potato bug - rock n roll.
then the soft shell crab and grilled yellow tail. 
all was super fresh and delicious! 

for those of you who know me.... i am pretty darn picky when it comes to eating japanese and sushi! i compare it to japan... and it rarely comes close to being descent japanese food in the city...

the only place i really really enjoy eating is shimo... now ebisu is another place i don't mind trying again!

thanks for a lovely evening - d! we gotta do it again soon!
author: kiko v.

description: This used to be my favorite sushi place. The quality and taste of sushi seemed to have dropped. Cannot understand why, but sushi here is still cool, just not like before. There's other better sushi places in SF. but if you have to come here. I would recommend their California roll, and salmon sushi.
author: HUNG L.

description: I'm very picky when it comes to sushi, and this place was a mess. After we sat down, we were moved to another table. The cucumber salad was good, and that's about it. My sushi roll looked like they dropped it on the floor, the vegetable tempura was okay, but how hard is it to ruin deep fried veggies?? We also ordered a chicken plate, which was rubbery and left untouched. Horrible experience. When we left, there was a huge crowd waiting to get be seated. Unbelievable, apparently it's popular, but not my taste.
author: Roger D.

description: This is the worst sushi I've ever had. the fish tasted days old, the rolls foul. Rather go to Koo up on Irving @ 5th. If I could give 0 stars I would
author: Felix A.

description:
Generally I am very picky when it comes to sushi. After years of trying to many places, I had narrowed it down to Sushi House in Alameda as my favorite. Since my boyfriend lives in San Francisco and I work in the city, the trip to Alameda all the time was getting too much so we decided to venture out of our comfort zone and find a place a city that can live up to our standards. After several trial and error, we decided to give Ebisu a try since it was only a few blocks away from his house.

Ebisu is not some where you would want to go for a quiet dinner. The quaint little restaurant is always crowded and loud which was evidence that the food was good since so many people are there to eat! The decor of the restaurant is cute and you have the option of sitting at a table or at the sushi bar. Personally, I love sitting at the sushi bar since I generally only order sushi anyways.  The first two times we tried Ebisu, we sat at a table which can get a little annoying because the tables are very close to each other so if you're not a people person and claustrophobic, then take out might be your best bet. After those two times, we decided to sit at the bar. Sitting at the sushi bar does have it's perks! When you are seated, a waitress brings you a hot towel to clean your hands. The sushi chefs greet you immediately and serve you complimentary edamame (which is not given to you if you sit at a table). The selection of sushi is amazing! They have a wide variety of fresh fish and they even serve live Uni and live scallops! Personally, my boyfriend and I are fans of specialty rolls. Although they do not have a wide variety of specialty rolls, the ones they do carry are delicious and reasonably priced! Their Boston roll is only $6.95!! The sushi chefs are extremely nice and helpful. Ricky, who overheard my boyfriend say how he wished they had a roll with his favorite ingredients, immediately made a roll to his liking! He hasn't stopped talking about it since! Now every time we go back, we ask the chefs to make a customized roll for us depending on what we are craving. The waitresses are also extremely helpful and nice. My drinks never see the bottom of the cup because they refill it before it is even half empty! Great customer service!

One of the best things about Ebisu on top of their excellent customer service and delicious food is their rewards program. They offer a "frequent eaters" card that gives you 1 point for every dollar you spend (not including tax). When you hit 100 pts, you get 10% off. At 1000 pts, you get a gift card for $100! Once we heard about it, we signed up immediately and have been using it since! Great way to be rewarded for being a regular!

I recommend Ebisu for sushi lovers who are in the sunset area and even if you're not, it's worth traveling to for a great meal!
author: Amie T.

description: Went on my birthday to this newly remodel Ebisu.... it was very pack for a Tuesday night. Me and my friend were squeeze into a very small table. We ordered two rolls, two appetizers..and two dessert... wasn't that great as it was expected.... very small table for 2 of us, we have to rush it to finish in order we can put a new dish on the table... it's kinda wired that we finished the two roll and the fried tofu and the chill appetizer sampler (oyster, crab, shrimp)is  still not out....but they gave us a free dessert... overall is just  a ok....
author: marian l.

description: I am Japanese and I did not see any other Japanese customer in this restaurant when I went there Friday night even though it was packed and people were waiting to get a table. (Chinese or Korean *may* look like Japanese but we can tell the difference) So that tells the quality of their sushi. The rice of rolls was too watery and Uni was too cold as if it was frozen. The sushi from Wholefoods is better than their sushi, but a lot cheaper.
author: Masayo L.

description:
Too bad Yelp doesnt offer half star otherwise, this place will get 1.5
I went to Ebisu for lunch and thought I was so lucky that I didnt have to wait in line. I've tried to eat in this place cupple times but I just couldnt fight with the crowd. And afterall, I went in, I got my food, I ate and I finally I cleared up my mind. This place is nothing great but a whole dissapointment. The food wasnt bad. it's just average, nothing great at all. The waitresses, eventhough there was 4 of them working, the service was slow and minus points when they got me wrong order and didnt take the blame (so it was my fault then, that you couldnt take a correct order) their listening skill were pretty bad(if you couldnt hear ask me again not just say "yes" and then i've never get anything that ive asked for). And in the end when my bf asked for the bill, we were shock!  $43 bucks for lunch?? for 2 rolls and 1 lunch specail!! wowww that was just the big ripped off!! trust me, im a big fun of sushi and this place doesnt worth yours money at all.
author: john s.

description: Very nice higher end sushi... a range of roll options and tons of nigiri and Sashimi.  The appitiziers are also good... especially the dumplings.  Among the rolls, I really enjoyed the poke, the Louisiana Hot Link, and the dragon roll.  Service was fairly good, although the hot link roll did come out 15 minutes after everything else.  I really ought to give them 5 stars, but I have realized that my heart lies more with a larger number of cheaper rolls [so long as they don't poison me] rather than fewer higher quality ones so it just wouldn't normally beat out cheaper alternatives for my attention.  What can I say, I lack culture.
author: Alured P.

description: Ive been going to this place for awhile now and it never fails except the long wait. Small place but i think its worth the wait. Me personally like to sit at the bar, so we can order as we eat. Plus you get to sit next your significant other. Sashimi melts in your mouth and their gyoza (pot stickers) are the best, cooked perfect. If you plan to be a Ebisu repeater, get the points card for future discounts.
author: Tae K.

description:
One of my friends was raving about Ebisu being an awesome sushi place, even better than my favorite sushi place in Folsom. I had to try it.

The sushi was alright, it was good but maybe it was because I went in with high expectations that weren't met... HOWEVER, their sashimi was awesome :) very fresh and smooth. I would go back to eat their sashimi, if not the sushi!

Probably the other drawback is parking is hard to find. We ended up parking across the street at a parking lot that charges 8.00 flat if you park there I THINK starting anytime from 5pm till 2am.
author: tianyu c.

description: I love you, Ebisu.  Do you love me too?  I think you do, because you feed me so well.  And you're so nice to me whenever I come in.  Sure, sometimes you make me wait... but you're worth it.
author: Carrie A.

description:
Sadly, this place is a little staid in its old age.  Not much of a line where you used to have to wait over an hour! Worse yet - brace yourself - when I went, all the patrons were white.  Every. Single. One. Of. Them. That's when you, as a restauranteur, know your time has come and gone.  May as well hang a little sign outside that says, "Pasta Pomodoro."

The food was mediocre. The service was slow and confused. Land of the Falling Sun.
author: Tracy Y.

description: Ebisu's sushi is superb. Tekka, Saba, Unagi, Hamachi, Kaki, ... heaven to the palate is found at Ebisu.
author: Dan S.

description: Went here years ago, and ordered way too much food. It did not help that I was eating with a vegan. Decent sushi, though places like Kabuto (previous ownership, not the current) and Kyo-ya have eclipsed it for both sushi and non-sushi dishes. I normally don't eat rolls and consider then unauthentic, but I did have the swamp roll (spicy tuna inside-out roll and seasoned kelp). Sometimes you can get a seafood amuse-bouche from the 4 master sushi chefs. For sushi, I like the toro (my favorite), hamachi, uni, and amaebi. The kaki (oysters) with lemon and ginger are nice too. No reservations, so expect a long wait. Ebisu (historically written Yebisu) is the god of wealth and the deity of commerce, somewhat equivalent to Mercury/Hermes, known for his smiling face. It's also a neighborhood in Tokyo, centered around a train station of the same name. It's also a beer brand in Japan.
author: Hao L.

description: Holy, holy baby Jebus! This phrase is appropriate to explain both how I feel about the sushi at Ebisu and to describe my feeling when three Catholic priests walked in and sat down behind me. No this is not the start to a joke...I should NOT be in the same room as priests, but my date and I found it best that they were sitting behind me and not him...however he is over 12, so maybe he would have been safe anyway ;) Soooooo to get on with the review, I actually told the waitress to give my compliments to the chef and the "fish-picker," honestly who says that? Figured out those guys are one in the same! haha, but seriously the Ahi tuna was sooo tender and deeeeelish that it was like eating toro without the price tag. Every roll rocked my world, but the double hamachi and the rainbow rolls won in the end! I am so lucky to live a block from this place...my wallet may not be so lucky though...
author: Amanda S.

description: After my experience at House of Sushi, this tasted like the best sushi I've ever had. This place seems to be supercrowded on any night of the week. I don't really remember what I ate, but I know it was solid. The decor is great and they have a good selection of different rolls and nigiri. It's a bit on the pricey side, so if you're looking to do sushi cheap, then this is not the place.
author: Srinivas R.

description: Everything was fresh enough, but I really couldn't find a whole lot I wanted to eat here considering the very long wait I endured to do so. This isn't an issue at other sushi places, I am fairly adventurous and like raw fish.
author: Caroline C.

description:
Outstanding!  Well done -- the renovations finally updated the place and expanded the bar while the food remains excellent with varied sushi and sashimi selections... plus Hotei food as a potential option from across the street.  

For my money, this is the best sushi in San Francisco.  Well done!
author: Joe S.

description: Went here on a Sunday afternoon because Jimisan, further up the street, was closed and I figured I'd give this place a try.  It didn't look quite as frightening as Kiki a few doors down.  Anyway, the salmon sashimi was tasty, but halfway frozen, which was a disappointment.  There was a pretty vast selection of rolls to choose from, and they were all pretty large.  The fish tasted fresh and flavourful but I wouldn't say it was the best I've tasted.  The seaweed salad was a bit on the stale side.  All in all, this place wasn't bad, but I'd probably to go elsewhere next time I'm looking for sushi in the Inner Sunset.
author: Jack G.

description: I am on a roll today.... let's get a couple of Sushi restaurant reviews out of the way.... Ebisu.. eeehhhh.. not the freshest and best sushi I have had.  Sure the variety of rolls is great but in the end the taste makes the difference. I can't pinpoint it. Maybe they are trying too hard?
author: Doro P.

description: Hmm, hit and miss and I always have to wait. I use to have more love for it. Now it's mostly memories.
author: Angela K.

description: The salad and vegetarian sushi was absolutely delicious! The chef made us a special vegetarian roll with spinach and mushroom. Nice ambiance and service.
author: Meg P.

description: Expensive, but so good. Fresh fish. Try the duck on asparagus. My god.  Parking sucks though.
author: mike h.

description: A consistent competitor for the city's best sushi.  Fresh, of course, but also creative and with a large seasonal selection.  There are probably better places relative to the cost, but if you are willing to splurge for excellent sushi instead of just good then ebisu is a solid choice.
author: Pug P.

description: Delicious food and a great atmosphere. Plus you can call for the waiting list and show up when it's time to be seated.
author: Noah F.

description: Excellent sushi, excellent atomosphere, excellent service.  The place is relatively small, so if you get there a little later you're going to have to wait, but the food is worth it.  Above average sushi prices, basically what you pay in LA for sushi, but it's top notch.  Favorite: Tuna rolls with avacado.  Mmmm tuna rolls with avacado.....
author: Raffi Y.

description:
Positives: Ebisu has great food (the most important thing right?), Sushi rolls are really nice and fresh. Great appetizers hot and cold. 

Negatives: Its super tight in there but I guess it adds to the ambiance, the prices are a lil steep (but the food is worth it). Parking is crazy especially on weekends.
author: hanzal M.

description: I came here once with my brother and his friend. It was good and the service was great. It just wasn't a showstopper like Koo. Maybe it was the atmosphere that did it, or I am just partial to others. My place was closed. If that happens to you then I would definitely recommend going to Ebisu.
author: Juls M.

description: I thought the quality and taste of the food here was good, better than some of the other sushi places on this street. Prices are a bit high for the amount that you get. Didn't have to wait for a table of two.
author: Janel Y.

description: Amazing food & prices! Service is wonderful and the  sushi chefs r great! My first time here and I will keep coming back for more. This is the best sushi ive had since moving here 1 year ago!!!
author: Chaz M.

description: Solid japanese fare - with good cooked varieties - like Tonkatsu, Teriyaki, Curry, Noodles, etc.  and fresh sushi combos.  The prices are decent, usually leaving with about $28 bill for 2.  Can get really busy around 7 PM on Thursdays through the weekend.
author: Audra E.

description: Great lil place for good sushi. Fresh ingredients. Clean, modern decor. NO avocados in the rolls I ordered--a rarity in this day of "fusion" sushi that has avocado in everything. Sake sampler was awesome.
author: Chris P.

description: We ate here last weekend. I was curious how the restaurant would fare after the remodel. The interior is beautifully done and there are now two bathrooms, but they had to remove that small room in the back where you take your shoes off and sit at the low tables. This was my favorite part about the restaurant so I was kinda disappointed that it was gone. The food was actually better than the last few times I'd eaten there. I think they have a new chef so there were some interesting new items on the menu, such as the special of halibut baked on a cedar plank, which was good but a little salty. They have new servers now also - our server was helpful and attentive, but not all that warm or genuine, so minus a star for that. Overall, very good.
author: Lori E.

description: wow...what a line to get into this place...but after getting seated and served our sushi..it was well worth the wait! the quality in their fish is superb! the fish melts in your mouth like butter! the escolar the salmon toro, and the uni, omg my newest fave, they were big, cold, creamy, buttery pieces so good we ordered more!...all the fish our sushi chef tommy gave us was delicious. tommy was very entertaining and funny and the restaurant has a small town feel to it. I can tell that many of the customers were regulars and were treated like long time friends. definitely a must for any sushi lover!
author: Linda L.

description: For all the hype surrounding this  place- I was not impressed. I went here for lunch and the fish was OK. I was surprised at how expensive it was and I was not blown away like I wanted to be. I will not be trekking out to the sunset for this.
author: kristen l.

description: I had always heard good things about this place but never got to try it until this last weekend. It was surprisingly quiet for a Saturday night, we were seated within 5 minutes. The sushi didn't blow me away, but didn't really disappoint either. They've sort of found that middle ground of solid but ultimately unspectacular sushi joints.
author: Cliff C.

description:
Recently revisited Ebisu.  Not impressed with the food and extremely disappointed with the service.  Our food was delivered in slapdash manner, with some of the sushi coming at end of meal after bill had been delivered and numerous inquiries.

Waiter attempted to remove food while we were still eating!  Table turnover goals seemed to trump feeding people in gracious manner.  Our guests were also disappointed.

Too bad--service lost out here.
author: Skippy g.

description:
the sushi we had melted in our mouth... it was really fresh 
the place is rather pricy and very small too...
good thing we didnt have to wait to get a table since we got there just a little after they opened for dinner.
author: charlotte s.

description: Hype is dangerous, I had heard a lot of hype about this place and was prepared to gorge myself and end the night with a nice sushi buzz.  The service was good, with a quick phone call they put our group of seven on a waiting list and we didn't have to wait long.  The restaurant itself was a little small, and they put us in a pretty cramped tatami room.  I'd say the food was average, nothing that deserves sushi bliss, but not bad.  One of my friends had the teriyaki chicken, which looked really dry, but came with the creamiest potato salad I've ever had.
author: Mark D.

description: Amazing fresh fish.  The wait kinda blows, but it's worth it.  I did try to order sashimi and for some reason I was served nigri, but oh well, it was still fish-a-lish.
author: Christina S.

description:
The thing about Ebisu is that it's just not that good.  I've been there a few times both before and after I became obsessed with sushi and I have never been blown away by anything.  The fish is fresh but not much of anything interesting is done with it.  The service sucks but I no longer dock sushi places for this because it usually sucks.  The difference here is that the staff has been rude.  Slow and forgetful.  Ok, it happens.  Rude, not if you want my business.  The last time I was there was for a friend's birthday.  We put our name in and waited and waited.  When we were next, I noticed there were enough spots at the bar to accomodate us so I asked the hostess if we could sit there.  I wanted to confer with the birthday boy first just to make sure the bar was what he wanted (he usually sits at the bar but I thought he might want a table for his birthday).  I don't like to be the decision maker for other people's b-day festivities.  Anyway, she told me I had to let her know RIGHT NOW or she'd give away the spots.  I said he was right outside the door and it would take less than a minute to check.  Basically, the bitch wouldn't let me take 20 seconds to ask a question and come back to her.  Once we got seated, at a table since I didn't want to waste her precious time, the meal was ok.  It was unremarkable but ok.  

The one thing that really sealed the deal for me though was the distinct aroma of cat pee near our table.  As the mommy of 4 cats, I'm familiar with this smell.  No, a cat didn't pee on one of us before we came in.  It was in the carpet.  Few smells would make a sushi dinner worse, I say.  Bottom line:  with Jimisan, Koo and Kazu within a couple blocks I don't bother with this place.
author: M M.

description: This is a very good sushi joint. Surprisingly for the quality and attention to detail is not over priced.
author: Clayton K.

description: Pretty nice restaurant in the midst of many along Irving.  Pretty good, except a little on the pricey side, but at least I knew that going in.
author: Joel J.

description:
This has always been our favorite sushi place int he neighborhood - really fresh and consistent sushi.  We love their miso soup.

Went to the private tasting event for the re-opening and the food was OUTSTANDING.  There was a fried seafood fritter that was my brother's favorite, the pork loin prime rib blew our minds, and the desserts were excellent.  I've never ordered off the menu before here, but I will start now.

The remodel is really cool and modern - service needed a little help, but it was their first "practice" night, so it was to be expected.
author: r t.

description: The spanish mackerel was great seasonal treat the last time I was at Ebisu. This place has decent ambiance and good Japanese cuisine for San Francisco standards. Another good dinning spot in the Inner Sunset.
author: Be N.

description: Very good. This is a good stop on the way to the museum or after shopping. The quality of the sushi is somewhere in-between todai and sanraku but that ain't bad. The prices are decent and although I didn't have a drink (it was early afternoon) the prices and selection looked good. I'll definitely be coming again.
author: Andrew W.

description: The food was good and the atmosphere was pretty authentic but it was far too rushed.  The waitress practically pushed us out so that they could use the table.  They had us in and out in less than 30 minutes and she still seemed annoyed that we wanted to chill out with our tea.
author: Peter O.

description: Decent enough sushi.. but sometimes I feel like I'm packed into a bento box while eating it.  Really.  Could they please squeeze a few more tables in this place?  I only had to say excuse me to 4 people as I slid my chair out to go to the bathroom.  And I had an easier time hearing the people I was sitting next to then the person I was sitting across from.  Thing is, I didn't know they people I was sitting next to, and well, they were sorta  boring.
author: Cosmolicious L.

description:
i heard a lot of hype about this place before i finally got around to trying it. although it didn't live up to the hype, that doesn't mean it was bad at all; i just didn't end up having a life altering moment.

at the bar, you get some really righteous attention from the chefs, and the waitresses that zoom around behind you are always ready to refill your tea. good place that is all kinds of busy - hopefully because it is so good, but I'll have to go a few more times to make sure.

by the by, there's a hapa waitress that's all kinds of hot. lay off, she's mine.
author: Darrell L.

description: Try this cool place in  the inner sunset. They have awesome sushi rolls here like the swamp roll and the 49er roll. Drink some Sapporo and have a merry time. The wait can also be quite long here so get your name on the list early. Parking in the inner sunset sucks too. Otherwise it's good times!
author: Pete C.

description: Best sushi in the neighborhood, and among the best in the city.  Waiting for a table totally sucks, though... their little indoor waiting area is super tiny, so you're often SOL and stuck on the sidewalk.
author: Patrick L.

description: Best sushi I've had in the city. If you're indecisive, just sit at the bar and ask for what's fresh--I've never been disappointed. The major downside to Ebisu is the crowds, even on the slowest of weeknights. But some things are worth waiting for.
author: Megan K.

description: The rolls here are large and in charge. I highly recommend the Swamp Roll - I mean fuhgeddaboudit, it's outstanding. But...I'd avoid the Cherry Blossom roll at all costs. Pickled salmon? Yuck. Might as well be a gefilte fish roll. I suppose it's executed well, but the idea stinks.
author: Andrew K.

description: I'm only rating the service, but I had a piece of sushi, because I was LATE to my friends birthday lunch, which started at like 1.. and i got there at 1:30 and found out i couldn't order anything why? WHY you ask! because THE RESTAURANT CLOSED AT 2. WHAT! yeah, it closed at TWO TWO IN THE AFTERNOON, MY BOYFRIEND AND I WERE HUNGRY. And just decided to get at kikisss.  yeah, it might have been the best slice of food i've eaten all day, but I was mad. So my boyfriend walked out and smoked a cig. He was about to kill someone! jeebus. and on the plus side it was raining YIPPIE... -________-" This may be my fault, but the one slice was good, 3 stars for that, -2 for the closing at 2.
author: Carolyn Y.

description: My girlfriend and I were randomly driving around and we stumbled across this little place.  There was absolutely now parking around this block so be prepared to walk.  We were torn between the 3 Japanese restaurants right next to each other and randomly went into Ebisu.  One of the best decisions I've ever made.  This place has a really simple menu, however all their dishes are really good.  If you have a small party, go ahead and sit at the bar because everybody wants to sit at a table.  You will also get your rolls a lot faster sitting at the bar.  Our sushi chef was new and was getting yelled at by the "veteran" sushi chefs.  He still made every roll really good.  He then recommended a roll to us and wouldn't tell us what was in it.  We felt adventurous and tried the roll.  Lets just say I'll be back here again.
author: Danny P.

description: Killer remodel.  I don't think a place could look more different in one year.  Still same amazing food.
author: Anna G.

description: Great place.  Best sushi in San Francisco.
author: stefan d.

description: What can I say about a 5 star sushi restaurant for quality sushi and staff?  I always feel appreciated when I walk in and out of Ebisu, and Eric, the owner, couldn't be any nicer or more genuine.  He knows what customer service is all about.  However, the main reason I go to Ebisu is for its sushi!  Judge for yourself.  The fish is always tasty and fresh, and the Ebisu chefs make the best 49er roll the city has to offer.  As far as I am concerned, Ebisu is THE best sushi restaurant in San Francisco, bar none.
author: Ben S.

description: Yummy! Went for the first time last week and it's been on my mind since.  Try the live scallops or a dragon roll with some unfiltered sake. Sit at the bar very entertaining and friendly. Will be going back for my birthday dinner next week. If I can wait that long.
author: Amanda P.

description: Good food and they serve Kanpyo rolls!  The tempura is over cooked though, too oily.  I love that they have a rewards program too.  They've suckered me into not eating at any other Japanese restaurant.  I NEED THE POINTS!  HA
author: Nick L.

description: Definitely my favorite place to eat hands down. If I could marry kobe beef sashimi, I would. YUMMY... and the live scallop... don't get me started. Ebisu has fresh sushi you can't get at your regular sushi place. Place gets pretty packed on the weekends. But of course.
author: Beth W.

description: If you always wondered what sushi in Japan tastes like...come here.  This place is phenomenal.  The chefs aren't sleezy but crazy good.  First of all, love the picture menus.  Can't do Japanese food w/o knowing exactly what you'll be eaing.  I like to play the movie in my head before actually eating my food.  When each of our sushi plates arrived, it was delish to the dish...we finished everything.  Fish is fresh, even on Sundays (when supposedly there's no fresh fish coming in.)  Service here is outstanding, sushi bar seating is actually more VIP than table seating.  I've never encountered such attentive sushi chefs before, and they don't try to hit on you!!!  What an amazement.  LOVES IT!
author: Wendy H.

description: Simply awesome! Well, yes, you'll have to wait a little bit to have a seat but the sushi selection is amazing and the quality is absolutely excellent. Someone told me that people fly from Japan to have sushi at Ebisu... sounds like an urban legend, I know, but I still dream of their Unis.
author: Dario B.

description: I've been to this restaurant twice.  The first time was in 2000 on a date and I don't remember what I had but, i remember the incredibly long wait.  The second time was last Friday.  The wait was still very long & I remember what I had & it wasn't all that.  I don't know what the hype is but, there's gotta be SOMETHING that keeps this place going.  I haven't found it yet but, I haven't completely given up the search.  The service was decent but, it wasn't great.  Very tight seating.  The sushi rolls that we ordered weren't spectacular, just average.
author: Christie X.

description: This place is the constant king of all sushi place in the city.  A fan/city/Zagat favorite forever and deservedly so.  They deliver at the highest level for straight up sushi or the more traditional Japanese fair.  Tempura Udon is the bomb!  Kobe style beef carpacio....*Oh Snap*  It is hard for me to pass up this place when I'm in the 'hood.
author: Chard M.

description:
expensive? hai. 

best sushi i've ever had? hai. 

oishii.  

caveat - i've only been there twice.  but i ate myself silly both times.
author: Bob C.

description: I went here last Friday night with a person who shall remain nameless and that person's lovely friends. I usually can find SOME vegetarian fare at a sushi establishment, but the selection here was quite limited. That being stated, however, the waitress went out of her way to make special food for me and was totally sweet. The restaurant was cozy and at once made you feel welcome with bright decor and a wonderful presentation of  each dish that was eagerly consumed by the rest of the group at the table. If you are a vegetarian, have them make the vegi tempura rolls for you. All in all, a pleasant evening, but I was left a little hungry. The person who shall remain nameless, however, was quite full and very content!! Fish lovers, this is definitely the place for you.
author: Yaamini R.

description: Favorite sushi spot in SF. That pretty much says it all. It is a good local place with fresh, lovingly prepared sushi. Unpretentious, reasonably priced, quick service.  Great tataki.
author: Alison P.

description: Best Spicy Hamachi I've ever had!  Depends on the night.  There are always people waiting outside.  There were times when i had to wait for 40 minutes, or I can easily get a seat for 10, or no wait at all!  I always hold Ebisu dear.  My boyfriend and I are big sushi fans, and we visit regularly.
author: Carrie-C N.

description: After repeated visits at random times/days of the week, I still vote this place my favorite sushi spot in SF. Prices are fare, staff always friendly. Sometimes a bit crowded and seating "interesting", but when you're craving raw fish who cares! Consistently great food!
author: Lisa S.

description: The toro was pretty good, so was the crunchy roll and the scallop nigiri.   I'd probably rate this place 3.5 stars though ... it was pretty good but not exceptional.
author: Chaz N.

description: This place was probably the bomb back in the day.  But the day has come and gone.  The interior is pretty outdated and their menus are strange...they have pictures of sushi to describe the different rolls.  Come on guys, I think we know what a california roll looks like.  The nigiri was pretty decent.  If I lived around the corner I may go back again but I don't see this as a drive across the city type of place.
author: Piper B.

description: I tried their agedashi tofu, seaweed salad, double hamachi roll (hamachi on top and inside), tempura roll, and the Hanukkah roll (salmon topped with salmon roll on rice that had salmon skin inside).  I thought the tofu and seaweed salad were good and very similar to what is served at most restaurants.  The double hamachi roll was a first; nothing notable.  It was hard to taste the fish with all the rice (too much?).  The tempura roll was also unremarkable.  The Hanukkah roll also suffered from too much rice.  All in all, the sushi was good but nothing special.
author: David L.

description: Mmmm mmm mmm. Had a quick lunch here while visiting. I'm boring. Always order the same thing. Spicy Tuna. Masago Roll. Soft shell Crab Roll. California Maki. But was super yummy. I enjoyed every bite and good food/service.
author: Bella D.

description: Expensive, long waits, and best with a regular, but well worth it.  The monk fish liver is awesome.
author: L H.

description: My fav sushi place in SF!  Great sushi and atmosphere.  Sitting at the bar is the best place in the restaurant.
author: James W.

description:
pretty much the same fare as hotei across the street...just have to decide where you like to wait. i think that the udon here may be better than hotei, but it may just be the times that i have gone. 
usually solid and consistent food with timely service.
author: Roy N.

description: Terrible!  The sushi is unremarkable and the service sucks!  I ate here with my sister.  After we paid our bill, we both had a full glass of wine left when the waitress came by and asked us to "wrap it up" because there was a long line.  I WAS FURIOUS.  Never have been asked such a question at a San Francisco restaurant.  If I could have taken my tip back I would have.  I will never go here again.
author: Nancy P.

description: Really like the sushi here & the service. The ambiance is also nice. Good relaxed date place.
author: N A.

description: You'll seat in the floor, eat great sushi, and dream of Japan 500 years ago. Sake and tea are a must. Man, the only thing I don't like is that they don't allow me to enter with my katana, tanjo and tanto....
author: Javi V.

description: Best sushi in the city and the only one where I can find salmon koji (which though not for everyone is addictive once you develop a taste for it).   For lunch, I strongly recommend the chirashi sushi.  The prices are not cheap --but you get what you pay for at Ebisu.
author: Matthew B.

description: Ebisu sushi has been the home of my birthday celebrations since I turned 9 years old. It is really fantastic, and they even gave me green tea ice cream with a candle in it and had the whole restaurant sing Happy Birthday! Anyway, the sushi is very good.. my favorite is the 49er roll because the lemon slices are so thin and the bit of rind is nice and chewy, and the salmon is delectable. I have always wanted to try the sunrise (quail egg and roe), but I'm too scared. Sit at the sushi bar! It's fun :)
author: O K.

description: I think it's always important to distinguish between two kinds of sushi lovers: those who look for the freshest and most varied sashimi, and those who love giant elaborate rolls.  Not that either one is better, but I happen to be one of the former, which unfortunately means that Ebisu is not my favorite sushi restaurant in the city.  If I had instead been the latter, I would have loved it: there is a magnificent array of rolls, and the interior is bustling with many happy customers.  A nice touch is the traditional tautami mat area, where you must remove your shoes before dining.  A warning, though: the novelty of sitting on the mat all evening QUICKLY wears off.
author: MScott S.

description: I like Ebisu, been there many times.  The food is good, sushi is great, their ramen is great, the yaki-soba was good.  There don buri bowl is good.  The price is decent, better then todai, plus better quality food.  The staff is great.  Yes the place is small, and can get filled pretty fast, so the wait for a table can take a while.  But it is worth it.
author: Marciano P.

description: Whenever the old man mentions Sukiyaki, he always mentions this restaurant.  I like the restaurant's set up.  It does have a nice "feel" to it.  No complaints about the sushi.  I guess I'm a sucker for places with "ambiance" but for reasons I can't explain, this place has lots of it.  Nice couple dinner place.  But be forewarned, if you aren't there before the crowds, YOU WILL BE WAITING.  So do yourself a favor and show up before the dinner rush.  Otherwise, keep walking until you find a restaurant without a wait.  Don't worry, you won't be walking long, there's SOOO many restaurants packed onto a block that you SOOO won't go hungry.
author: brenda b.

description: Not a bad place but, in my opinion, it's not worth the long wait in line and the difficulty parking.  I come if it's not at prime time...the food is certainly good and I've never been unhappy with my choices.  Luckily, San Francisco has many choices for Japanese cuisine!!!
author: Carmen H.

description: This is still a good standby.  It's cheaper than the more trendy sushi places - Sushi Groove, Tsunami (but not exactly cheap).  Their sushi is consistently fresh.  The wait can be long - it's best to avoid rush hours.  The place always seems busy and packed - not ideal for large groups.  If you live closeby, it should definitely be a top choice.  But if not, well, it may still be worth the trek every once in a while.  If this is too far out for you, comparable places include Wasabi & Ginger on Vallejo & Van Ness and Fuku Sushi in Japantown.
author: Jeanne J.

description:
one of the best sushi places i've ever been to.  

if you have a chance to sit at the bar, sit there.  the chef would from time to time throw in freebies for you to try.

kobe beef is awesome, una ebi (raw shrimp fried head) is also fantastic. all their fish is fresh and they cut generous slices.  

the service is excellent as we were attended to constantly.  it is a bit on the pricey side but it is worth the money and potentially the wait.

if you don't know your way around real japanese food, ask the sushi chef (the older one) and you will be in good hands.  

oh, a couple hot waitresses, for those of you that care.
author: Hao L.

description: When it comes to traditional-styled sushi, I think Ebisu does it best in San Francisco. Yes, the wait can be long, and it's constantly packed and crowded, the but the fish is fresh and uber delicious. I don't go here very often (just thinking about the parking in this area is maddening), but when I've been, I've left thoroughly fulfilled.
author: Joyce S.

description: I recommend taking friends and family members here for the first time and sitting at the bar. The sushi-chefs make each experience memorable and the sushi has never disappointed..
author: Agent F.

description: Hands down, this is my favorite sushi place in San Francisco.  No where else in the city do I get the same kind of quality, service, and at-home from a sushi restaurant than I do here at Ebisu.  Granted, I live in the neighborhood and its easy for me to get to, I bring friends from all over the city here to get sushi everytime.  They have this great frequent users card you have to ask for: at the $100 spent mark you get 10% off your meal, at $500 mark you get 20% off your meal and at the $1,000 mark you get $100 Gift Certificate.  I love Ebisu.  When I needed Gift Cards donated for my fundraiser, the owner didn't bat an eyelash.  This restaurant and the people who work there, remind me that a small town feel is still possible in a city as large as San Francisco.
author: Thanh C.

description: I do agree Ebisu has good Sushi but there's something about it that does not make me want to go there. It's not about  the place or parking, could care less about it as long as the food is good. I think it's about the staff, lol.
author: John L.

description: I ate at the one at SFO and had some of the best Ramen I've had in the US.  We went there on the suggestion of one of my Japanese Co-workers, I was skeptical, but it the Ramen had a great balance of broth, noodles, and toppings.  It's always a good sign when you finish the broth to the last drop.
author: Peter W.

description: I would not eat at Ebisu if I had to wait in line.  Lucky for me yesterday we were seated immediately.  The food was ok. We had the 49er roll and one of the rolls with Shrimp Tempura in it (forgot name) I have to say the texture on both rolls was weird.  The fish was ok, I've had better.  The tempura was crispy and the spinach salad was also just ok.  I have to say the service wasn't all that great but it wasn't horrible either.  I think the best part of the experience was the sushi chef Rika.  Would I go back? Maaaaaaybe.
author: Michele G.

description: sushi is decent - nothing to write home about.  priced on the high side.  small, crowded and LOUD!  the tables are so close together, you have to restrain yourself from inadvertently reaching over for something on your neighbor's table.  not a place to relax or have a conversation at all.  don't really understand the ebisu-hotei paradox.  hotei (unfortunately shut for the time being) has most of the ebisu sushi menu, but ebisu doesn't have the hotei noodle menu.  what gives?  hotei definitely gets my vote, but don't think we'll be coming back to ebisu any time soon.
author: Jeremy S.

description: I love this place! The atmosphere is great, the service is great and the food is most excellent! I don't know where you could find finer sushi in San Francisco. I think it is a bit expensive, but worth it. We go at least once a month. It's super yummy!
author: Erin M.

description:
I use to love Ebisu but eating there today has changed my mind. The new remodel looked nice but the service was horrible! I ordered a spider roll and a rainbow row from the friendly sushi chef. 10 minutes went by and he said our rolls were coming out shortly. Another 10 minutes went by and still no rolls. We also ordered a bento box and a donburi, which didn't come out yet. Okay, so it's been 20 minutes, where's our food??!? We joke around with the sushi chefs saying how hungry we are and they convince us that our sushi is coming. Then then give us a complementary dish of two cooked pieces of tuna. FISHY and nasty. YUK! 

So our bento box and donburi finally comes out and our sushi shortly after. The spider roll was mediocre, but the rainbow row was good. I would not come back to Ebisu. 50$ and all I get is crappy service and decent food. I pass.
author: Daniel S.

description: This is a legitimate sushi house. The people working here are from Japan. The sushi is quite good. Eat here for a benchmark on Sushi in America.
author: mickey l.

description:
Great sushi, great atmosphere, & great people.

Went here for a birthday celebration and had an awesome time.  The sushi chefs were fun and food was delicious.  Will definitely come back when I have the chance.
author: Anthony T.

description: My favorite sushi restaurant, I wish I could afford to eat here more often.  Great sashimi and rolls.  Safe place to experiment with the help of the sushi chefs.  Just ask them to help you out selecting something new and they will take care of you.  I prefer to sit at the bar.  Good date place.
author: Eli N.

description: It's like going to Wendy's instead of McDonalds; better food and service by comparison, but you don't leave saying "holy sh*t that was ___ing (positive expletive)."  it has that 'just sushi' feel, as only 15% of the menu was creative. If you like specialty rolls (although the lemon-topped 49er was a winner) , it ain't the place.  However, if you like that Italian-style neighborhood and family hospitality, this is definitely the place.  Go a few times, introduce yourself, and you'll always feel welcome....and known.  Just like Cheers.
author: Lindsay M.

description: Don't buy into the hype.  Ebisu is extremely disappointing if you're expecting high quality sushi that everyone is raving about.  The sushi may be fresh, but it's just not tasty and original, and definitely not worth the price.  If you want to pay this much for good sushi (and better ambiance), go to Blowfish.
author: Brandon C.

description: Someone turned me on to this place years ago - it's consistently good and priced well.  Too bad there is always a wait!
author: Bridget T.

description: The sushi quality here is a bit above average for the city, however the price is a bit above average, as well.  Other than that, I had great service and when I asked for less common sushi (by American standards), the sushi chef was able to deliver.
author: Kelvin K.

description: FYI - Ebisu is closed on Sundays! I haven't been to this place in forever, so maybe it's better or worse than I remember. Personally, I think it's a bit sketch when there are no prices for any of the rolls on the menu (I wonder if it's still like that?).
author: dianne l.

description: Let me preface this review by saying I am not a sushi expert, but instead I am quite the novice.  I am not nit picky on my sushi chef, I just want to have some sushi.  So if you are an "expert" in the art of how the food is prepared then this review might not be for you.  The group I was with ordered enough food to feed Shaq O'Neal, so that we got to taste a little of everything and everything was wonderful.  All of the food was fresh and clean.  It was absolutely spectacular and very reasonably priced!!!!  Overall was a great, great place to eat and like I said I am not knowledgeable enough to comment on anything other then how to food tastes and for that Ebisu gets an infinity.
author: matt g.

description: These guys have to be the best in town.  In fact I've gone out of my way to find better sushi yet to no avail.  I have never found a fresher piece of fish or more delicious roll than in the doors of Ebisu.  I give them an A+.
author: Silver S.

description: Get the eel, dragon roll, rainbow roll, monkfish.  always the freshest and best sushi around.
author: choad x.

description: This is one of my fave sushi spots in SF. (I have a couple of favorites all for different reasons).  Tom and Suzuki are my fave sushi chef's.  They always remember me and my husband (we frequent quite a bit). The sushi and rolls are great, always fresh and yummy.  My favorite is the oyster sushi, agi, and cherry blossom roll.  Oh and the crunchy roll.
author: Amanda P.

description: I've been coming here for more than 10 years and its still as delicious as ever!  I always have my staple orders: dinosaurs feet, dragon roll, and albacore tataki, then branch out from there.  Its a bit expensive but i dont mind spending bread for amazing sushi.
author: Steph S.

description:
Hadn't been in years, because the long waits had outweighed the good fish in my brain. But today, the stars aligned to give us a parking space and no wait at lunchtime, and we sat at the bar. 

I started off with the ama ebi (raw shrimp), which was extraordinary. I'm careful about where I order ama ebi, and this was the freshest I've tasted in years. We also got the "live scallop" special. This consists of 6 pieces of raw scallop nigiri with incredibly thin lemon slices on each one (transcendent!), plus the rest of the scallop muscle deep-fried with onions and some other vegetable tempura-style.

Holy cannoli, it was good. The rest of what we ordered was delicious, but those two items really shone. Service was friendly and attentive, and I suddenly remembered what all the fuss is about.

They don't have the scallop special every day, but do give it a try if it's on the special board. I will remember this meal for a long time.
author: kelly r.

description: This place is a pretty good place to go eat when you're feeling like eating sushi.  And no, I'm not talking about bento boxes kind of "sushi".  This place probably wouldn't be the best place for that.  I'm talking about the sashimi and sushi in general.  I got the Double Hamachi roll and I just simply loved it.  I might be a little biased because I like yellow tail.  If you're eating here with a friend or what not, I would definitely recommend eating at the bar, its more lively and more fun.  The chefs are awesome to talk to and they recommend some bomb ass sushi.  They definitely provide great customer service.  Overall though, could get a little pricey but I guess its a pretty average price because I'm on a student salary.
author: Kenneth W.

description: Really good sushi place we found after visiting the SF Zoo.  The nigiri was excellent, liked that they had a kobe beef roll on the menu.  That was very good.  But the standout was the tekka don, which was one of the sushi chefs specialties.  The fish was awesome and although it seemed pretty plain, the bowl was bursting with flavor.  Great dish.  Both the sushi chefs were really friendly.  If you go, sit at the bar and be adventurous and try the specials on the board.  They are all very good.
author: Keith M.

description:
Love this place, especially now after remodeling. I've been coming here for years and always liked it. But now just love it. Nice atmosphere, great sushi!!
Most of all I love the special rolls. 49er Roll and Swamp Roll are the best.

Nice service.
author: Illa B.

description: The sushi is wonderful here. Melt in your mouth. The dining room is a bit small and there's usually a line. I'd come back.
author: Dijon Y.

description: Ebisu should be the picture in the dictionary when you look up sushi.  It is the freshest sushi in the Bay Area by far.  I recommend the special caterpillar (unagi and avocado) and 49er (salmon and lemon) rolls, and the negihama (hamachi) is always outstanding, as is the aji (spanish mackerel).  Give yourself a treat and visit this outstanding restaurant.
author: Susannah B.

description: The best experience is to sit at the sushi bar and talk to the chefs.  Ask what's fresh and you can't go wrong.  Also, they have a frequent diner program which seems to be invite-only, as the sushi chef offered it to me when he recognized me after several visits.
author: Chris N.

description:
slightly above average sushi. crowded. nice atmosphere, if there weren't people knocking into you or staring you down from the doorway 
(at 6pm). We biked, so parking wasn't an issue.... should be plenty of parking near gg park. If I hadn't found such incredible sushi at Sushi Zen, I'd try it out again.
author: Jessica C.

description: Dear GOD, the agadashi tofu is delicious. Sake, yellowtail and unagi nigiri also good. You will probably not be having too much fun if you go there hungry, after 5pm, on any night. Weekend afternoons are nice and mellow.
author: Rachel B.

description: I had been told this was the best sushi in town, but I have to say I wasn't that impressed.  My order came out really quickly but there was nothing spectacular about it.  Not too pricey, and they have a neat little rewards card.  No reservations and the lines are long, so get there early!
author: Brig M.

description: Waited for about 30-40 minutes here for a table on a Thursday night, and I would have waited much longer.  The sushi was fresh and absolutely delicious, with great service as well.  Would go back in a heartbeat.
author: P. G.

description: One of the best places I have been to for sushi/ Japanese food in a very long time. I have been to this place twice and both times I have been blown away by the food i received. The last time I went I had the King Crab Special and this time it was special again. They have this sweet sauce that they bake the crab with and it was wow. Also all the stuff that comes with the meal from the soup to the pickles to Gyoza was very well done. I also liked the fact that they did something with the accompaniments such as the broccoli with either mustard or honey Mustard and it was interesting to have massed potatoes as well or i think they were anyway. I did ding it for the very small location but hey it is a helluva lot better Kiki next door and superior to Noriega Teriyaki. Still very suprioer.
author: Christopher C.

description: We went here because my friend said they have good sushi.  We disagree.  It's not good at all but they provided good service.
author: Pikachu P.

description: Yaaaaay #29 roll. Booooo rushing me.Next time you will have to pry that gyoza dipping sauce from my cold dead fingers. Booooo for leaving a bone in my poky roll. Yaaaay for taking it off the bill. We could go on like this for a while folks. A bona fide 3 star.
author: Carly S.

description: Great, consistent sushi. We've never had a bad meal. Worth the wait, but its not the only place to get great sushi. But, certainly a winner.
author: Gwenn G.

description: Lovely interior and good service. Fish was excellent. Beer and sake list also excellent!
author: Nick L.

description: Beautiful fish.  Live uni!  Wonderful sake!  Attentive service.
author: Andrew H.

description:
pretty good sushi. crowded but didn't have to wait too long. small so got attention from the waitresses pretty easy. the waitresses were helpful as well. 
they accidetally gave us an extra plate of sushi, an expensive roll too ^_^ (not really an attribute to the quality of the resturant, but def. made me like it more, hehe)
overal good, but not something to write home about. 

oh, there's a pretty cute sushi chef as well.
author: marcella r.

description: Good sushi, long wait, and some-what uncomfortable (specially in the tatami room). Bad service for larger group (we had to wait half an hour for a caterpillar roll and california roll while we wait for the rest of our party-this is one order each!). Since we had parents in town it was quite uncomfortable for them to be squeezed in the tatami room. It would be nice to be here for maybe dates or if by yourself but a definate no no to entertain groups. Other words don't bring older folks in big groups specially when they'll place you in the tatami room.
author: Diane M.

description: This is one of my favorite sushi places in SF, if not my current favorite. Very fresh, beautiful food, a great place to impress a date. Very intimate dining area (SMALL!) A SF gem if there ever was one. Great service too!
author: T W.

description: I'm very selective when it comes to sushi.  I'm usually disappointed whenever I go to sushi restaurants.  However, Ebisu consistently has the best sushi in town.  I always leave this restaurant with a big 'ole smile on my face, because stomach is completely satisfied.
author: Cherie A.

description: Oh, Ebisu...how I miss you!  My boyfriend took me there for Valentine's Day several years ago and we've been hooked ever since.  Ever since we moved to SoCal, we've been looking for a sushi restaurant that can match you but so far, they've all fallen short.
author: Marissa V.

description:
Great service, great selection of food. I had the best cod (Gindara) in my life in Ebisu. The owner of the restaurant always explains what is the best to order on each day (what is fresh) and really nice but hamble. 
It was really crowded even during weekdays but if you want a good experienence, you should go.
author: E T.

description: My neighborhood favorite!  Stefan and I always go here!  Stefan is in the process of negotiating the remodel of this fabulous sushi favorite.  I enjoy the sushi chefs, the owners Steve and Yoko!  Thank you for making great sushi and being a neighborhood staple.  I eat a lot of sushi even though I am mostly a vegetarian.  I make any excuse I can to eat here!  The service is great and the food.
author: Velvet V.
