description: Yum. Order the crunchy tuna roll. Delicious. The wait can be long so we usually do pick up if it's Friday or Saturday night. Go early to avoid the wait. Four stars because it lacks ambience and I sometimes wonder about the cleanliness....
author: Z L.

description:
my gf and i rode our gastronomic urges across the park de hypodermic last week. avid fish eaters, we decided on sushi 'stead of thai or some yummy indian. 

btw. the auto-save feature is obnoxious & distracting ... doesn't need to be seen, please go to ui class.

@ 7:30 bit of a wait - smart gobblers call ahead & get on the list. we got on both the bar & table list & waited. 

30 minutes or so.

... jeebus - auto saved again ... really, now ...

then we ordered ... damn - saved again ....

live uni. which was really really neat - since we haven't bumped into that yet. opened and served right in fron of you & served on the shell. it is from mendocino & available thursday, friday & sat. but the only buy @ 10 or so oper night. so get on it. i am writing like virginia wolf because that damn thing is going to save ag -

... ahhhh - there it goes. fuck you - you useless widget. 

toad programmer.
author: Lawrence K.

description: Never again will I return.  We sat at the sushi bar and you would think they would be more attentive to how they prepare their food.  Perhaps it was our rookie sushi sai-hu but it was my worst sushi bar experience ever.  I didn't even finish my sushi because it looked not fresh and very unappetizing.
author: Big e.

description: We got some nigiri and some rolls. Everything tasted good, except one item (yellowtail), which was mediocre. The service was nice. For some reason, we decided to get dessert. The creme brulee--and the related pot de creme--were surprisingly good.
author: N M.

description: This remains, hands down, my favorite sushi joint in the city. My favorite roll is the cherry blossom and rainbow roll. The ingredients used have an unparalleled freshness that I haven't found elsewhere in the city. The prices are pretty decent too, a little over average but so is the quality. I would suggest going on weekdays, a little earlier to catch their happy hour specials and also to avoid the lines and noise. Also, they don't have a reservation list but many times I've called ahead and put my name on the "wait list", which is pretty much the same thing. We love the restaurat so much that we opened a card with them, and get rewards occasionally. Totally worth it!
author: Elle D.

description: When i want to stick to the basics (nigiris and sashimis) Ebisu is tops.  They have a really good kobe beef nigiri that comes with its own ginger dipping sauce.  Sushi is a little small but a good bite.  I really like how they use onions with their spicy tuna roll.  Sit at the bar because the sushi chefs are fun or try to get the back room.  They also have a rewards system where you can rack up points for blowing all your money there.
author: Mark R.

description: The fish is amazing. Fresh as can be. The wait and the ambiance leave much to be desired, but I am never looking for a fancy dining experience. I want reasonably priced, excellent fish and Ebisu has just that. Wait staff is friendly and efficient, but honestly I almost like eating at the satellite restaurant at the airport better. Another note - Ebisu has always had the best shrimp tempura, but on my last two visits it was sub par. Usually it is light, crisp and flaky with a touch of sweetness, but it has been totally run of the mill on two occasions in August 2007. The rainbow and swamp rolls more than make up for this. Still the best sushi in town. No frills, no fuss, great fish.
author: Marcia B.

description: Food....superb!  I take one star off because it is too expensive and the place is too damn small
author: nono C.

description: I came here for lunch last week. I'm surprised the roman noodle was kind of good. I haven't try their sushi yet. Next time will come back for dinner.
author: Eddy M.

description: This place is grrrrr-eat! My fiancee and I come here all the time, and after having sushi all over the states, we agree that this place not only holds its own, but surpasses most everywhere. Big fans of the staff, they seem to always have wonderful ideas & recommendations for sushi. We were just in tonight, and they threw together a version of a special from ~4 weeks ago for $5!!! A silly nice gesture, and a incredibly good roll. They can be a little sloppy with the integrity of the rolls themselves, but that's really being nit-picky. The appetizers are spot on, the rolls are always a delight, and you know you're leaving happy. Get down on it, this place rocks!
author: Alberto A.

description: I came here recently for an expensive but really delicious lunch. They carry premium toro, as well as yellowtail toro. Omigosh - it just melts in your mouth! We also tried an assortment of sushi and the Ebisu udon and it was all really yummy. You can tell that they use really good seaweed too - it doesn't remain tough as you chew. I can't wait to come back!
author: Keromi K.

description: Great sushi, but not exceptional. The rolls are creative and fresh, and the service is very good.
author: L T.

description: I've been going here forever. Sit at the bar and let them make you some damn fine sushi. Be sure to have the 49er Roll and a Poke handroll. Say hi to Steve (the owner); he's such a sweetheart. As is Suzuki, the hardest-working sushi chef in town.
author: julie k.

description: I really like the sushi here. It is super fresh and delicious. The chefs are nice and they gave my boyfriend an ice cream with a candle on his birthday, I go to the irish pub down the street for a beer while i am  waiting for a table so the wait doesnt seem so long.
author: Christina G.

description:
It's been a while since I've been here, so I can't speak to comments about a change,  but on my first visit, it was revelatory.  The restaurant itself is an unremarkable no nonsense kind of place, but the chefs and the FISH!!!!  Definitely remarkable. I had never had fish that just melted in my mouth and tasted so fresh.  It gave me a whole new appreciation for sushi.

I love to go when it's a little quiet and ask the sushi chef to give me whatever he recommends.  They're so informative and attentive to your tastes, presenting their recommendations based on what's fresh, answering questions, and then listening to what you like to fine tune the next recommendation.  I felt like it was money well spent.  And eating this way is fun as well as satisfying.

Also dig the sake samplers.  Great place to investigate the cuisine.

I've been when its busy, for friend's parties, and was pleasantly surprised that even when there's a long wait, once seated, there was no waiting.  Service is fast and efficient even when it's packed.  Anyone who's ever worked in a restaurant knows what a task that is.

Thanks guys.
author: S. B.

description: These guys know what they're doing.  I took my sister and her boyfriend who were visiting from NY there this weekend, and we were all impressed.  Everything was fresh and they offer some pretty inventive rolls.  We all agreed the chefs are a big part of making this place what it is.  Try to sit at the bar if you can - that's where all the magic happens.
author: Jay M.

description: I had a great time at the sushi bar~ I just sat there and let the chef take care of me. The chef was really attentive, and the sushi was great. Probably the best I've had in the U.S. at that price range.
author: fatfat w.

description:
Too much hype for this place! 

I know many other gems to get great quality sushi in perfectportions without the wait and the price. 

I will not be going back here.
author: Maggie S.

description: This is the best sushi in San Francisco hands down. The fish is beautiful & the chef's are always fun and adventurous (sit at the sushi bar).  I have been a customer for over 12 years. In fact, I have brought people here from New York and Japan and they have all concurred - excellent sushi!
author: Donald C.

description: Went here before renovation. I'll keep it short: DELICIOUS! Everything we ate was fantastic, from the Kobe Beef sashimi (ummm, so good!) to the Aji to salmon handrolls,  and on and on. Will go here again for a special occasion. It was pricey, but worth every penny.
author: wildcat g.

description: Because he'd been such a great salesman (read drippy kissass peon), Jerktoenails had been given a $100 gift certificate to Ebisu. I'd never been there before, but everyone is always all about Ebisu. So, I was excited. The nice thing is that even though there is a really long wait there, they will give you beers while you do wait.  Jerkpoopshoot started downing sake and beer like he was a 19 year old white cap frat boy. Which, in retrospect, he kind of was. (Have fun, CLAIRE). He got really trashed at which point, the girl who he was screwing behind my back walked in. I should have known something was up because he got really crazy and anxious like. I asked him what was the matter and then I saw this (pasty Canadian)Marina girl making out on one of the chairs across from us. Apparently, she was trying to make him jealous and it was working. I had no idea what was going on, but he proceeded to get trashed for the rest of the night and as we were leaving told me that he was having an affair with that girl. And then we broke up. Anyway, I don't remember what the food was like. But I think it was really good.
author: Ahnui Y.

description: After waiting 40 minutes I checked in with the hostess- she had crossed off my name without calling us. We had to wait another 20 min to get seated....and the food was not worth it. Way better sushi and way better staff in sf! Don't bother with this place.
author: Susan D.

description:
Very disappointing.  Here's why:
The acoustics of this place are horrible.  My partner and I went on a friday night and we literally had to yell at each other in order to have a conversation.
The maki was sub-par.  Small rolls, imitation crab in the 'California King Roll' (should have asked, but the menu specified crab with a 'c'), and a yellowtail roll that I actually returned because it was not fresh at all.
Sushi that was questionable in quality.  The uni also was not fresh and the tuna, salmon and ikura rolls were completely bland.  It was watered down sushi whose day had passed.  I left almost half of my sushi deluxe dinner on the plate.
The miso soup was actually pretty good, but at $2.50 for a small serving that lacked seaweed it was not worth it.
One thing I will give them credit for is the service.  Our waitress was very nice and accomodating.  Unfortunately she couldn't save the worst sushi dinner that I've eaten in recent memory.
author: joel b.

description:
ebisu seems to be an institution in my newly adopted hood of the inner sunset.  it's so well known that my friends and i would travel into the neighborhood to check it out even though none of us lived here (at the time) and parking is horrendous around there during the peek dinner hours.  i haven't been there since i bought my place 5 blocks away but finally had to make the faithful trip over to the spot that seems to be voted "best sushi in SF" every year ... i think it's the SF weekly or guardian or citysearch or .... who knows.  one of those places that take votes for "best sushi" ... anyway.  

not sure what to say about the sushi itself...  if i hear one more person refer to good sushi and "really, really FRESH," i'm gonna yack.  aren't there other adjectives to describe sushi?  no, not really.  ok, fine.  to me, as long as it's fresh and not chewy, i'm good.  the sushi would have to be stellar and make me float above the table for it to completely excite me.  i suppose i can tell more about the skills of the kitchen by the rolls.  these are things that take a little skill and imagination to put together.  one of the more popular rolls, the 49er roll, is mainly salmon and avocado with a couple other ingredients to spice it up and i was fairly impressed with it.  and, over my protestations, someone in the group ordered the CA roll, which i always think is like ordering a hamburger at a steak-house but whatever.  Ebisu even seemed to give the lowly CA roll some "zest" and dignity.  there ya go - new word to describe sushi: zesty!  go ahead and use it, if you want, royalty-free.  the sashimi combination was a good number of different types of sushi - and they don't just stick you with the sushi that no one will order straight off the menu.  they give you some good stuff and the combination is surprisingly cheap.  probably the most amazing thing was that the octopus wasn't as chewy as old bubble gum.  maybe that's what you need to do from now on to judge the quality of the sushi restaurant: order the octopus and see if you can manage to get the thing down in less than say 7 or 8 minutes of chewing and if you can't, then that's just not good!  i've had a lot of tough octopus and was relieved that ebisu's was not nearly the nightmare i remember having to choke down at other places.  

the service is always very reliable.  i like the tables where you have to sit on the floor - although i realize that it's not everyone's cup of tea. i suppose the only thing to watch out for is the wait but i know that already and i only come here on off hours when it's not really busy.
author: dan h.

description: One of the best in the city, maybe the best :)? Sit at the bar, order from the chef's board, do try the hamachi kama and the tataki.  They always have the better seasonal cuts of fish like the fatty tuna and hamachi that are well worth the price.
author: Localista I.

description: Yummy! Went there last night with boyfriend, and Ce. We ordered a bunch of sushi rolls, which all turned out to be really good. After 4 different rolls and 8 slices of nigiri, we had some ice cream for dessert. Mocha for me, Red bean for Ce, and Tangerine sherbert for the fellas. =) My boyfriend ended up seeing a pool-hall buddy of his who turned out to be the owner's son. He hooked us up with a custom made roll, made of tuna, yellow tail, tempura and something else. Naturally, it was good- definitely something they need to put on their menu. Excellent sushi. Good luck getting in. This place is always packed.
author: Linda I.

description: too expensive, which is why i only give it four stars....but man is this place good!  i've eaten sashimi thousands of times (mostly in LA where it's amazing) but this place is right up there.  sit at the bar and you'll get your food in seconds.  the sashimi is fresh and melts like butter in your mouth.  you can get a yummy roll, but because the fish is so tasy i recommend just the sushi or sashimi.  i will always come back here.
author: katie k.

description:
went here yesterday on a whim on recommendation from a friend and i think he might've gotten it confused w/hotei across the street, we were looking for donburi/soba noodles or the like...but we ended up just staying here anyway

decor is nice but yeah the tables are packed in way too tightly

my friend was visiting w/her bf from seattle, and she instantly saw the kobe beef shabu shabu and ordered it...i got the saba steak which i enjoyed...the shabu shabu although very tasty was another story.....

it took at least 40 min for our food to come out...friend + bf shared the shabu shabu and all you really need to do is bring out the meat/veggies and the hot broth to cook it yourselves, it should not take that long to come out.  if you've ever been to a shabu house, it is cooked over an actual burner...we were very surprised when it came out on this cute little contraption that had 2 pieces of coal inside to "cook" the meat and veggies...that in no way is going to cook the meat nor veggies in a timely manner...the broth is going to get cold b/c your adding the cold veggies and meat and you'll have to reheat the dang contraption which we had to ask the server to do after the friend tried to cook their meal for 10 min...it just takes way too long...an asian lady (i believe to be the owner), came back after they took away the "burner" to tell us that "shabu shabu is different from chinese hot pot, it means to cook slowly," and didnt apologize or try to comp us in any way...it should not have to be THAT slow..i felt bad b/c i was enjoying my food but they had to wait some time to actually eat theirs...my friend worked at a shabu house in san diego in college, and she was not happy at all...although the cooking device looks cute and presentable, it is not effective...plus the kobe beef shabu was $50...apparently our table are the 2nd patrons to ever order the kobe beef shabu...so in essence we were the guinea pigs

service was ok....my friend was still hungry and ordered a couple orders of sushi from the guy server...but apparently he forgot to put the order in and we never got it, so we paid and left the place since they had to catch their plane...if you ever go, AVOID the shabu shabu...i was irritated and i didnt even order the dish
author: Alice K.

description: unlock the artist and engineer in the chefs here, be daring and select the triple x chef's special. holy carp (no, carp is not on the menu). these guys are waiting for the moment to off-road from the menu. these rolls are works of art. everything else on the menu is excellent sushi as you would expect it from a coffee table book of top notch sushis.
author: Rishi S.

description: For a trip to SF we chose this restaurant for a treat.  What a rip off this place is!  My husband and I both ordered Chirachi.  The Bento box was filled in two corners with a watery mushroom mess and the other two corners with kenpyo.  After I picked out five lettuce leaves that left little space for fish.  Sure enough they filled it with fake crab.  Whatever fish was in this dish it was slivers of tuna and a few other pieces.  I understand that there might not be perfect sushi slices but this is ridiculous.  What a sloppy job.  You simply don't care for your customers.  The two salmon skin handrolls we ordered additonally were pitiful.  They fell over after 30 seconds in their holder because the Nori was too soft and the salmon skins were cold and cold oil doesn't taste good.  We were the first customers for lunch and the rolls came out too quick.  Looked like they had them left over from the night before.  Outside the Saba sushi, nothing tasted fresh.  What a waste of our money.  We have eaten in other places with better quality and even lesser prices.  Will not return to this establishment.
author: Brigitte K.

description: The noodles here are very, very, very fresh. A bowl of Japanese noodles that don't taste homemade might as well come with 3 little freeze dried shrimp, a freeze dried carrot, and a freeze dried piece of corn (cup-o-noodle reference for those that didnt get hit hard enough by that bus) Roommate  #1got the ramen in miso broth, I got some kind of rice noodle in soy sauce broth, roommate #2 got sushi. In summation...............3 Roomates- 3 dishes- Zero complaints. Im not an algebrist, but thats pretty good.
author: Monty B.

description: good food, I haven't had an extensive amount of their sushi having been more into noodles & tempura when I went(I think it is the foggy location putting me into a warm food craving), but it was good food.
author: Heidi P.

description: Ebisu is one of my favorite sushi places in the city. The newly remodeled interior is simple, but beautiful with wooden panels on one side, loosely echoing the organic style of a Frank Gehry. Loved the genuine, super-friendly wait staff (noticed how they make good eye contact). We pretty much loved everything our waiter suggested (he's so adorable as well as our water refiller guy)- the black cod is amazing - as well as the pork belly fat appetizer (i know, the latter doesn't sound very appetizing but it's good). However, one thing I'd probably not get again is the Louisiana sushi roll - which is a bit too "fishy" for me. This is a very popular sushi place - so expect to be told that there will be a long wait. Fortunately we were seated sooner than what we were informed - 30-60 minute estimated wait. There's definitely little room to manuever between the tables and chairs so either be agile or suck in your stomach if you're not waif thin when passing through (kidding). Again, and emphatically, the black cod is a good way to start the main course - with saki! :)
author: Audrey L.

description:
i've gone to ebisu for over 15 years and the sushi there is one of the best i have had.  

the sushi there is always fresh and carefully prepared by the sushi chefs.  my favorites are uni (sea urchin) and amaebi (raw shrimp). their amaebi are much bigger than most places and taste very sweet and crunchy.  the ankimo (monk fish liver) over there has to be the best i have ever tasted... very smooth and rich in flavor.

it is definitely not a cheap place but it is worth it.  i'd much rather pay their prices and enjoy their quality of food than to go to some cheaper places with lower quality of food.  sushi has to be fresh and ebisu has that to offer. 

it is difficult to find parking around there and always a wait over the weekend.  so consider going for lunch or early dinner to avoid the crowd.
author: k c.

description: we came here before hitting up the de young, which was good, because they are very near and very fast.  but besides the convenience, this place has some great sushi!  it is melt-in-your-mouth fresh.  a great, authentic restaurant.
author: Jill k.

description: I ate here with my manatee last night.  I eat alot because Im a fatty so I ordered a variety of rolls.  The best rolls were the rainbow and double hamachi.  The tootsie roll was probably one of the worst rolls I have ever eaten and the 49er roll was just ok.  We also ordered 2 Oyster Furamotos which were pretty good.  The king crab handroll was ok but the yellowtail handroll was much better.  I asked the sushi chef what Ankumi was and he told us it was monk fish liver.  Being a fatty  all food sounds delicious but this one kinda grossed me out.  Of course, right when I was thiknig of this he gave us 2 Ankumi for free.  He said it tastes like a potato but he was wrong.  When I was picking it up to eat it the lobes of the liver broke apart. So now I had the right lobe in my chop stick and the left lobe on my plate.  If you have taken anatomy before its time to throw up.  But luckily fat people like me dont throw up, but if I did I would my barf because I dont want to waste food.  The taste was actually not that bad.  If you have eaten crown prince smoked oysters in the tin can then you have eaten monk fish liver.    Stick with the yellowtail and skip the salmon.  Be daring and try some of their sushi bar specials like monk fish liver and maybe they will have monk fish balls next time.  For the amount of food we orderd I thought it  the bill would be atleast $60 but it only came out to $40 even.  The sushi chef was very nice and helpful and the bill was very reasonable.  This is why I give Ebisu 4 stars.
author: Fatty A.

description:
went there for lunch the other day... hadn't been there since the renovations and were looking forward to eating different Japanese food from our usual hangouts... first of all, the young waitress was rough around the edges... attitude was very short/rushed... not pleasant... the sushi guys seemed friendly, though we didn't sit at the counter... we both ordered donburis: chicken teri (tasted charred) & yasai ("mixed seasonal vegetables omelette)... OMG!! let me just say that we were SOOOOO disappointed with the food... couldn't even finish them... TOO much sauce and too little rice... and the rice was drenched with the sauces; DROWNING... and the flavors were just NOT REAL Japanese food flavors!! NO finesse to the cooking at all!! Japanese foods should not be "busy" and "chaotic"... it should be "simple" and "well-balanced"... well, maybe it was our fault for expecting Japanese food at "non-Japanese-so-called-Japanese restaurant"... It is such a shame b/c people go to Ebisu thinking it's a Japanese restaurant when it obviously is not... this is not true Japanese food... I KNOW Japanese food and this is NOT Japanese food... the food was so bad that it really p-ssed us off... we don't mind paying for GOOD food, but when food is so inedible, it really burns us... We will not be going back... It wasn't busy either... And Steve (owner) was even working in the back...
maybe the sushi might be "okay"... I mean, how can u mess up with sushi as long as the fish is fresh and of decent quality? I'm sure their sushi isn't like that of Yoshi's or Ozumo, though... just thinking about spending almost $30 for two for lunch at Ebisu STILL makes my blood boil! The money spent on their recent renovations would have been better spent sending the owners & kitchen staff to culinary school...
author: joseph f.

description: i just love sushi.  plain and simple.  the sushi was absolutely DELICIOUS.  -2 stars unfortunately for horrible service.
author: Michelle B.

description:
hmm, yes, the wait is still a big pain in the cold foggy butt if you come with more than yourself and your sweetheart.  otherwise, seating should not be a problem.   also, hotei, which is across the street would be a better choice for eating if you are bringing the kiddos.  
I was excited by the choices on the new menu.  i tried some tenpura cherry tomato app, which was light and tangy yumminess, some kinda beef skewers, which were soaked to the core with tender magic marinade flavor.  personally, i could have just added a chowan of gohan and i would have been set, but there were a lot of us, so i might as well try a little bit of everything, yea?  oh, also tried some nigiris, and they were fine, next time i would like to try the duck tataki, or ankimo.
i ordered the steak medium rare, and my first observation was, this is huge!  it was above some spinach and below some sauteed enoki mushrooms, with a side of fried fingerling potato slices.  unfortunately, it was to salted for me, but everyone else loved it.  
my homies had salmon, huge! tenpura, the usual. sukiyaki, jammin!
all right, give it a try. thanks for reading.
author: yayoi s.

description: this is in my top 5 sushi bars. the live scallops are really the reason why.  not the best for rolls, more for the fresh fish and good tempura.
author: Nicole H.

description: Great neighborhood sushi! The fish is always fresh. The service is great. The newly remodeled interior looks great. Prices are fair for great sushi. We eat at the bar every time and enjoy watching The Master, Susuki, in action. They don't do reservations and the wait can get long, so go prepared to have a little sake while you wait.
author: Joe C.

description: It was a drag they don't take reservations, but once we got there we had a very friendly sushi chef and the food was good. If you're in the Sunset it's a happening place to go for sushi.
author: jeff P.

description: ROACHES crawling on wall behind sushi chef (eye-level with me as I was sitting at sushi bar)
author: I Like T.

description: Tried it few times. Hole in the wall place. Great rolls. I would go back again.
author: Mule S.

description: 5 star for tonights meal, served by the older "master" fellow (don't know his name but he's well known in the sushi world and Jimisan was trained by him I think for those familiar with the neighborhood). First of all the new renovations are bound to win awards... modern but old and classic. The space is still a little small but some thought went into it; great wood grains and stone sushi bar...solid.  Back to the food, cold sake is a must and I had the green thing ginjko ($20 a carafe)... smooth with light fruit finish. OK, food: I ordered the BAKUDAN (Ikura and Uni handroll) and things changed... some toro followed but decided to branch out and try muragai (sp?)... it was like dense oyster blissful sea water...perfect. Unspokenly gave him permission and he took care of me. Oh, I went on the early side which I'd highly recommend. Not inexpensive but if you want something special this has the potential to deliver.
author: David S.

description: A year ago I went here with a friend it was so Japanese, We got to sit on our knees and I had delicious sushi. Now today I noticed they renovated it to look modern. The sushi was still delicious but the only problem was that the spacing felt a lot more squished than before in the old Ebisu. It was still a great experience though.
author: Jacob A.

description: i had one of my most amazing dining experiences here. japanese kobe beef, monkfish liver pate, really good amaebi complete with deep fried head, and the creamiest tastiest rock-n-roll...roll ever. i also really liked their sake. the salmon was fresh and melted in my mouth. we had to wait in their tiny lobby a while so we got to hear a whiney bitch complain about someone being seated at the bar before her and her unfortunate companion. but it was well worth the wait. not overrated at all and it probably is the best sushi in san francisco. why else would they have a version at SFO?
author: Tin-Tin E.

description: i love the sushi (it's quite reasonably priced too!) but the service is definitely lacking.  almost every time i go to ebisu, they forget some part of the order and we have to wait for an extra 30-40min to get it.  there's also generally a loooong wait for a table during peak lunch and dinner times.  i recommend sitting at the bar b/c they don't give you free edamame as an appetizer or orange slices for dessert if you sit at the table :) (and you get served faster).  however, the sushi really makes it all worthwhile :).
author: Roshni R.

description: i haven't been there in over a year but when i lived in the sunset i would frequent this place.  very very good sushi back then.  any roll i tried i liked a lot and the yellowtail was out of this world.  the wait for this place is ridiculous though!
author: Swarup B.

description:
this is a perfectly run high end (hot towel) neighborhood sushi place.
-service is impeccable. the kind of place where just a slight tilt of the head will bring waitress running.
- old sushi chef knows what he's doing.
- no, the sashimi is not obscene & HUGE, it's sliced to bring out taste & texture.
-their "fusiony" forays into appetizers eg. mud pie app was uni sandwiched b/w shiso leaves & tempura fried - are really good.
-beautiful inside, cool woods are used throughout, always packed.
-not cheap, but you get it all.
author: Kim Y.

description: i say the sushi/sashimi along with everything else is good, but there's equal or better in the city. with real japanese chef i think it's fair to back there once in awhile, not the cheap eats, then again , not many cheap eats japanese places in town serving decent sushi, so i guess it's alright. can be a wait at weekend nights.
author: Angela H.

description: Been here a few times and the sushi is great....the drinks are very delicious also.  If there is a wait, order your drink and relax, take outside to the bench and see whats happening in the inner sunset for a sec.. don't wait without drinks...their sodas are yummy! i prefer this place to hotei or ten within a block of this place...It's pricier than hotei for sure, but better. Excellent wait staff, may be a small wait if you come on a busy weeknight or weekend...Portions are large,  and fresh.   Chefs are very attentive and professional and personable.  The experience here is great.. the dining area albeit a bit cramped is sumptuously decorated, very inviting for an intimate stare down....unless you wanna sit at bar..i like that experience better, cleansing my palate with sweet ginger and saki while i put my next rolll to order....ummm I took my nephew visiting, it was his firs time eating sushi (western sushi)...Even though it was crawling busy in there, they made sure to bring him a learning device for his chopsticks (tops tied),  choice of sushi was helped with, and some explanations... I appreciated the delicacy of catering to us for longer with such a packed house..Well done.  Parking is street parking, a small pay lot across the street always full... It's on the N Juda line (9th& judah)..Also try the lot on corner of 7th and judah ..
author: New Dilly G.

description: The sake menu was fairly good.  Overall, the joint is a bit pricey for the quantity of food.  The fish was fairly fresh and fairly tasty.   I get the sense that this place is a bit overrated.  Tried the eel/avocado, vegetable tempura, veggie roll, crunch and a few others, which were slightly above average.  The ambiance was pretty nice and this place was super busy (make a reservation if you can).  Service was mediocre.
author: Sanjiv B.

description: I went there recently, since they reopened after the remodel. I still love their food and the ambiance is nice. I sat near the bathroom though. At least the bathroom is clean and doesn't smell. It got really busy on the friday night, but we were there at 5:30 so we beat the crowd! The sashimi is fresh and glossy. We also got the kobe beef appetizer and that was very tasty but I was expecting the same taste from Japan. It's worth a try for a couple pieces of meat. The service is excellent too.
author: bob k.

description: I admit, the place is a little pricey..but we've been coming here for the last 10 yrs or so and have never been disappointed.  we always sit at the bar and follow chef's suggestions on the specials.  their sashimi is always fresh and tasty, rolls are imaginative and other "specials" are always worth a try..my only complaints (I can't just not complain) are the fact that parking is a b.ch in that area and the place is always very crowded (we come around 5 for early dinner to avoid the wait).
author: Laura K.

description: really fresh selection and my favorite sushi place in SF.  took my friend from japan there and he said it was the best sushi he's had in the bay area.  i'd recommend the monk fish and the taro.  parking can be a pain depending on when you go.
author: jane l.

description: This place came highly recommended to me from my boy whose opinion i greatly trust and rely on.  However this place was a giant let down.  I'm willing to chalk it up to a one time thing, but it'll be awhile before I could choke down that old and tired fish.
author: Jerry T.

description:
Interior is pleasant, the tables are spaced closely together and a very crowded feel to the place; however, it was not overly noisy.

I was very disappointed in the sushi. It was not as fresh as it could have been. I ordered chirashi and a few of the pieces had a slight fishy  taste. The makerle in particular was extremely fishy. The chirashi bowl was presented nicely. All pieces of fish were rather small.
We also ordered the maki squid appetizer. It arrived last of our order and the sauce was so salty that we could not eat the dish and sent it back. They very kindly remade the dish, but the only difference was that they served the sauce on the side. There was still too much salt.
Another of our party ordered the chicken teriyaki. The portion of chicken was very generous; the flavor overall was just average. Unfortunately, this sauce also had too much salt.
The rolls we ordered were ok, nothing special. The presentation was drab and boring. The rolls were unevenly cut and one was beginning to come apart on the plate.
All in all, I would not go back.
author: Mel F.

description: If you LOVE seafood than Ebisu has a nice array of dishes to pick. Service is great and the staff is very friendly.
author: Kevin M.

description: Everytime we can find a babysitter, I suggest Ebisu to wifey.
author: WP D.

description: let the dry erase board be your guide.....
author: sHoo o.

description: one of my favorite spots for sushi in the city, parking  is a pain, and the wait can be long, been here many times,  but the food is always pretty good, definately worth trying if never been before...
author: John C.

description:
there are a number of other sushi restaurants in SF to get much better sushi.  the nigiri was ok.  the cuts were good, but the fish was not as fresh as it should have been.  the tempura was not crispy and tasted like the frozen stuff you find at the super market.  the rolls were absolutely nasty.  the rice was under cooked and improperly flavored.  the texture of the sushi rolls was horrible.  the nori tasted stale and was extremely tough.

the only reason im giving this place 2 stars instead of 1 is because the service was speedy.

boo for ebisu!
author: Jeremy N.

description: This is the first time I've been in about 2yrs.  I remember the previous occasions being great but something has changed.  Contrary to many other entries here I thought the service was fast and friendly - I was gettting take out.  My issue was the quality.  The rolls were rice-heavy bombs; little fish and the taste was mediocre.  In the worst case one roll was fishy tasting - and should not have been.  Lastly, all the rolls used Krab - I didn't read the menu closely enough to catch that before ordering and didn't expect it from Ebisu.  This was a rare occasion where there were a lot of pieces left uneaten.
author: E. Z.

description: my absolutely favorite sushi spot. every time i go to another sushi restaurant i always find myself comparing to ebisu...whenever i want sushi i go to this place. the owner is super nice and so is his son. the best quality sushi you can pretty much find any where.
author: Cindy Q.

description: overpriced!!!!!!!!!!!  the sashimi slices are thinner compared to sakana.  i'd rather go to kabuto.
author: Dorothy L.

description: Some of the best sushi I've ever had, and it's right in my very own neighborhood!  The Hamachi Sashimi is my absolute favorite.  The sashimi combo plate is also to die for.  One drawback is the cramped seating.  I had to get up out of my chair so another party could squeeze into the table next to us.  The dragon and caterpillar rolls are also so so yummy.  mmmmm.  Service is pretty good - I waited a little bit too long for a green tea refill, however.  Overall - my favorite sushi restaurant in the city so far.
author: Kristel K.

description: One of the best yellowtail (Hamachi Sashimi's) I ever tasted.  Very traditional japanese hole if the wall local type of place with great special of the days such as Kobe Beef Sushi.  Fresh Sushi.  If you just wanted japanese food with good sushi and without the flair, I highly recommend this place.  Great as a casual date place.
author: Donna K.

description: if the wait time for ebisu was even half as long as it is, this would be a five star restaurant. fresh, classically prepared, solid sushi. that's what ebisu is all about.
author: oona m.

description: Went to lunch here with my bff one day when we both decided to ditch work and head to the city to cheer ourselves up.  Good thing our little outing started with a good lunch...it really helped get us out of our respective funks.  We both had bento box lunches that had sashimi, tempura.  I had beef teri with mine and she had chicken.  She said the chicken tasted too healthy. I think it's because it was chargrilled  and it was breast meat, instead of dark meat.  Otherwise, we both conceded that everything else in our boxes were good.  We also shared a roll that had hamachi....it too was really delicious.  You can taste the quality in the food here.  They use really fresh fish.  Oh, one last thing...I generally skip the miso soup because most of the the time, it's way too salty.  But I decided to have it that day, and even the miso soup was different from other Japanese restaurants...it was really tasty and not salty at all.  I would've given Ebisu 5 stars, but had to take 1 away because the place is looking a little run-down.
author: Aila L.

description: Rolls are great, fish is fresh, service is friendly - especially the sushi chefs...for the most part.  Try the Pink Cadillac, and try to make it early or you'll have to wait in the Sunset fog.
author: Benson J.

description: tiny and tight space, a bit over price. but they do have fresh sushi.
author: G P.

description: Good sushi.  Nice atmosphere & fun to sit at the bar.  Good service.  Always very busy.  I just don't like the strong seafood/fish odor of the place.
author: Melinda G.

description: i've been here once before and i'd have to say it's the same.  i came here last wednesday night.  i think we got there around 6:45pm and we just beat the crowd cause there was a wait after we sat down.  the service is good, but the food is ok.  we had the sashimi sampler, which was really good.  i didn't think the rolls were all that.  they were quite small actually.  i'd want to try out other sushi places around the area before coming back here.
author: Fran H.

description: I've eaten at Ebisu since it opened many years ago--or rather, I used to.  I can never get seated these days.  It was always a nice place to eat, fish was fresh--but nothing outstanding.  You really cannot find outstanding sushi or sashimi in San Francisco (you have to go down to LA for that).  But Ebisu isn't any better than many of the restaurants in Japantown.  And now I hear that Koo (which is 5 or 6 blocks away) is a good alternative.  Ebisu doesn't seem to have been able to handle it's success.  The last time I tried them, it was just past 5pm and there wasn't a waiting line, I just wanted a few pieces of sushi to take home for dinner (and nothing fancy mind you); I stopped in and asked if I could order take out and was told "no, they really couldn't handle doing take out."  Oh well.  I can shoot over to Japantown and buy my own sashimi and sushi.  It's too bad; it's one of my elderly mom's favorite places to eat but we can never get seated (and mom can't stand for very long, plus she has to eat when she's hungry or she stops wanting to eat for hours and she can't afford that).  I do think that restaurants ought to treat their long-time support customers a wee bit more special simply because we are the ones that saw them through the lean times, kept their rents paid before every other damn moron found out about the place.  But, oh well, there are other sushi places to go to (Pacific Catch is just down the block and they are always friendly and happy to do take out).
author: Kai T.

description:
wow! another outstanding meal at ebisu. the hostess was charming and attentive. she quoted us a 15 minute wait and was accurate to the minute. our server was casual while remaining professional. his recommendations were spot on. we had both of the sake flights and enjoyed them. the information cards served with each flight had just the right amount of information and were very helpful.
the food came out very quickly. almost too quickly, in fact. had i been thinking i would have ordered in courses rather than all at once. the three flavors of edamame were fun. the pickled ginger was some of the best I've had. My wife loved the grilled vegetables. The fish was really good, with the exception of the "medium toro." it was fresh enough but a little too much connective tissue. definitely did not melt in my mouth. i mentioned it to the server, who graciously took it off the bill. 
all in all it was one of the better dining experiences we've had in the last few months.
author: F B.

description: i've been going to this place for 18 years( which means i love their food) but last sat while i was there i was very very pissed at that tall lady in the front, she doesn't seat people correctly.  they used to have a wait list on the wall so everyone can see who is next but since the remodeling, they change everything.  when i was suppose to be next on the bar wait list, i asked her if the table is going to be faster, she said no, but during the time i was there(45mins), she had seated 5 tables already, i still love their amazing food but i wish i would never see her again.....usually, the front lady should be very friendly but in this case,  i just left after i confronted her.how sad!!!
author: Sham M.

description: Super fresh awesome nigiri and great rolls.  Sit at the bar and drink beers  with the sushi chefs or make friends with the couple next to you and do saki bombs.  I love this place - the food is very very good and I always have fun when I go.  One of the best sushi restaurants in SF.  The wait can be a pain, but it's worth it.
author: Jane M.

description: Good creative sushi rolls.  Fun environment and friendly owner.  Typically long lines.
author: T D.

description: I always make it here at least once when I'm in town visiting my Famliy, specifically for their Kobe Beef Sushi.  They don't take reservations so seating times will vary.  My average wait times have been ~20 min.  Sushi was fresh and the rolls were delicious.
author: Campbell L.

description: My boyfriend and I went to dinner here days before he became my boyfriend.  Who knew wasabi was an aphrodisiac?
author: Deborah K.

description: I have to agree with some of the other reviewers; I was rather disappointed by Ebisu. The selection of rolls didn't particularly interest me, nor was there anything on the nigiri list that stood out. The prices were not listed on the menu and in the end, it came out a bit on the expensive side. I will give them credit for some of the fastest sushi service I've ever seen. However, I think you can find better, cheaper sushi at other establishments in the city and not have to trek all the way out to the Sunset to do so.
author: Elise U.

description: The sushi is great and the prices are reasonable, but there always seems to be a wait for dinner at this place. There's also Hotei right across the street (owned by the same owner) that always seems to be less crowded.
author: Gloria C.

description: The line here is insane. I waited for about 15 minutes just for takeout but it was totally worth it. The swamp thing roll has seaweed on top and it's really delicious. I would definitely go back if I had time to wait.
author: foodbot c.

description: guy said the wait for a table would be 30 minutes and ended up being 1 hour instead. wth is wrong with him? he was serving tables that came after us. screw him. we finally get seated and the service sucks balls. i had to ask for more water every single time. wont even get me a new plate unless i asked. they didnt even cook my food right. only thing good was the hamachi. think we only left them a 3% tip after. hope they enjoyed that one. service is one of the worst i ever witnessed. disappointing..........
author: Cory Y.

description: I was disappointed by my last visit, but all of the other visits have been fine.  The sushi is good for the most part, although it can be prepared rather quickly and thus the presentation is not the greatest.  If you sit at the sushi bar, you were be a bit squished in for space.  There are too many rolls that have spicy things in it or unagi.  A bit more variety would be great.
author: Brian L.

description: The quality of the sushi is excellent!!!  But this resturant only caters to a certain race!!!  The parking is very very hard!!!
author: Patrick H.

description: Be prepared to wait a long time, but well worth it.  In my very humble opinion the best sushi in San Fran.  Well worth the $10 taxi ride.  If you want trendy and loud, go to that hell-hole on Lombard or Ozumo, but if you want great sushi at a reasonable price - this is the place.  Afterward a stop at Yancy's around the corner for a quick game of darts and a beer is customary for us, though it's not quite as fun anymore.
author: Matt A.

description: I think this is one of the better sushi places in the city.  The sushi is usually fresh.  The waitresses are friendly.  You have to get there the right time; otherwise, the line can get long.  Try around 6 pm.  Be sure to try the sake as well.
author: Amy V.

description: A restaurant that always seems to be packed, somewhat small place.  I usually eat at the sushi bar and haven't been disappointed.  Name the roll, they'll make it.  You can even create your own sushi perfection.  My only qualm on this place is that if you sit at the sushi bar, you never know how much they charge your for each sushi, the final bill just has the total.  One of my favorites.
author: Alex K.

description: Ebisu is hands down the best sushi joint I've ever been to. I love sushi, consider myself a connoisseur and have been to tons of sushi restaurants in and out of San Francisco. The most obvious factor is the superior quality of the raw fish. All the other ingredients are incredibly fresh as well--so much so that they melt in your mouth. The sushi rice is perfection as well--can't stand it when the rice isn't right. My favorite is the Cherry Blossom roll. They also have live Uni (sea urchin) sitting on a platter that will move when the chef pokes it, which was pretty interesting. In short, Ebisu has essentially ruined me for other sushi restaurants. Nothing else seems to compare. The prices are reasonable for what you're getting; portions are reasonable as well (8-10 pieces per order) Some items seem priced slightly above average, but it's so worth it. It can get pretty crowded around 7--if you get there early certain weekdays there are specials! FIVE STARS!
author: Melissa D.

description: Was looking forward and real excited about dining at your remodeled location. Been Ebisu diners for over 10 years...Sorry Ebisu, our recent experience was very dissappointing to say the least. We found the portions to be much smaller and the final dinner cost very pricey. Your restaurant could not accommodate odd tables for (3) diners within a reasonable wait time and we were not told of this. Was told the wait would be half to one hr. Waited 1 hr. 15 min and still couldn't get seated until I suggested to take the next table for 2 and add a chair although all even parties (2) got seated who came after us. This more than exceeded our expected wait time..Portion size e.g. 8 pc Himachi sashimi sliced at 1/4" (a little skimpy!) priced at $16 is typical of other menu portions and pricing. The specialty eel roll barely had enough eel for taste...as my friend puts it, each pc in the roll was like the "end" pc. Sorry Ebisu, nice remodeling job, but there are other Japanese restaurants who can deliver better value ...very dissappointing.
author: alice n.

description: very cool indoor spot for sushi in the inner sunset.  tasty lobster tempura and hamachi kama.  i've been a few times and the sushi seems to be better her than its sister restaurant hotei (across the street).
author: kathleen A.

description: this place disappointed me... i thought it would be good...but is only average and does not worth its HIGH PRICE... Ordered Sashimi..only 6 small pieces for 13.50!! OVerall...i only like the miso soup..lol...but i haven't tasted miso soup like this place has...it was a bit sweet...not as salty as other resturant.. after eating 60 dollars for two person...we are still HUNGRY!!!!!
author: Cherry S.
